                              73 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Pittsburgh Tribune Review

                              July 17, 2005 Sunday

Officials working to build food plots on forest land

BYLINE: Bob Frye

LENGTH: 515 words


Sportsmen who want more deer and are willing to work for them may soon be in
demand.

Officials with the Pennsylvania Game Commission and Department of Conservation
and Natural Resources are working on a plan to use sportsmen to help build food
plots on state forest land.

The idea, first pitched by commissioner Greg Isabella of Philadelphia, was
discussed by officials from both agencies at a face-to-face meeting in
Harrisburg on June 29.

"In my opinion, it's a no-brainer," Isabella said. "I told (DCNR), you guys want
to shoot deer. Our guys want to see lots of deer and shoot them. Let's do
something where we can attract the deer closer to where the hunters are."

The proposal that emerged remains a work in progress. Generally, though, it
calls for a pilot project that would put food plots on four areas of state
forest, perhaps before this fall. The plots would be designed to sustain deer in
late winter and early spring, when natural foods are most scarce.

Four areas are in consideration for the pilot project: Weiser State Forest in
Isabella's district; Delaware State Forest in commission president John Riley's
district; Bald Eagle State Forest in commissioner Tom Boop's district and an
area in northcentral Pennsylvania, perhaps Sproul State Forest.

DCNR would provide most of the funding to build each food plot, but the
commission and sportsmen would be asked to contribute money, equipment or
manpower where needed, said DCNR wildlife biologist Merlin Benner.

The food plots will be small, perhaps an acre each, though it's possible several
plots will be put on each site. Still, that wo'1t be enough to allow deer
numbers to grow substantially, Benner admitted.

"I don't think it really puts more deer on the landscape. I think it
concentrates deer probably," Benner said.

That might be enough to satisfy hunters, Isabella said. They'll have to be
willing to shoot the deer they see, though, if the program is to survive long
term.

"The people at DCNR did tell me that if these food plots are attracting deer,
and they start multiplying too high and hunters aren't shooting does, that's not
acceptable," Isabella said. "Then, this will be over."

If all that makes the food plot project seem more like a public relations move
than anything else, that's not entirely untrue.

Benner said DCNR has worked with sportsmen's groups numerous times in the past,
teaming up to provide habitat for species like elk and turkeys. There are those
in the department who see this as an opportunity to embark on a similar
partnership while educating hunters about deer habitat, deer impacts, and deer
management as a whole.

"We see some positives from such a program," Benner said.

Riley, too, said the project is an olive branch of sorts, offered by DCNR to the
commission and the hunters who pay for and carry out deer management for
everyone.

"We can't have hunters mad at everything everyone does. We've got to get over
this snit, I guess you'd call it," Riley said. "We've got to get away from this
name calling business and find solutions that are going to work for people."

LOAD-DATE: July 17, 2005

                              74 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                     May 22, 2002, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION

Foreigners linked to terror tricked INS, report says

BYLINE: Donna Leinwand

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8A

LENGTH: 1888 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON -- At least half of the 48 Muslim radicals linked to terrorist plots
in the USA since 1993 manipulated or violated immigration laws to enter this
country and then stay here, an analysis by the Center for Immigration Studies
says.

The terrorists used tourist, student and business visas, requests for amnesty
and asylum, sham marriages and lies to trick Immigration and Naturalization
Service officials into allowing them to stay in the USA, according to the
report, which the non-partisan center will release today. Even when the
terrorists did little to hide violations of visa requirements or other laws, INS
officials failed to enforce the laws or to deport the offenders, the report
says.

"Every aspect of the U.S. immigration system has been penetrated by terrorists,
so our response must be equally broad," says Steven Camarota, director of
research for the center. "Clearly our immigration system is critically important
to preventing attacks on U.S. soil. But it doesn't have to be foolproof. If you
just catch some of the people, you can often cause a large conspiracy to
unravel."


The study found that at the time they committed their crimes, 12 of the 48 were
illegal immigrants. At least five others had lived in the USA illegally, and
four others had committed significant immigration violations. Others were here
legally but should have been rejected for visas because they fit U.S.
immigration laws' profile of people who are likely to overstay their visas, the
report says.

The report's unflattering portrayal of the INS is the latest blow to an agency
that Congress has targeted for reorganization, largely because of the agency's
failure to enforce immigration laws and keep track of immigrants and visitors.
The INS does not have enough people to investigate and arrest all visa
violators, agency spokesman Russ Bergeron says. There are 1,950 immigration
agents nationwide and an estimated 7 million to 8 million undocumented
immigrants -- about one agent for every 4,100 immigrants, Bergeron says.

The INS does not have a system to monitor visa expirations and does not track
the whereabouts of foreign tourists.

"When you look at the wide range of important tasks, and the number of INS
agents is smaller than most metropolitan police departments, it becomes rather
obvious that there is a serious lack of resources," Bergeron says.

The analysis of the 48 men linked to terrorist plots here indicates that INS and
consular officials do not sufficiently scrutinize visa applicants. It also says
U.S. agencies and foreign governments do not communicate about terrorism watch
lists and intelligence reports, and adds that the United States lacks
immigration enforcement within the nation's borders.

When the INS does arrest suspected immigration violators, it sometimes lacks
jail space to hold them, the report says.

It says INS officials should not have issued tourist visas to many of the Sept.
11 hijackers because, as young, unmarried, generally low-income men without
significant ties to their home nations, they fit the profile of "intending
immigrants." That means they were considered likely to overstay their visas and
seek permanent immigration.

The study says the INS had several opportunities to keep Mohamed Atta, the
suspected ringleader of the attacks Sept. 11, out of the country or to deport
him once he arrived, Camarota says. Consular officials could have rejected his
tourist visa because he seemed to be an "intending immigrant." When Atta
overstayed his visa in December 2000, the INS could have deported him. When he
left the USA a month later and then returned, INS agents could have refused to
readmit him.

INS officials declined to commit on specific cases, saying they had not seen the
report. An official from the consular bureau of the State Department, which
issues visas at overseas consulates, says the visas cited in the report were
issued in compliance with U.S. law.

TEXT OF INFO BOX BEGINS HERE

How some with terrorist ties entered USA . . . and stayed

A report by the Center for Immigration Studies says that more than half of 48
foreigners linked to terrorist incidents in the USA since 1993 should have been
deported beforehand. In some cases, the report says, the foreigners misled the
Immigration and Naturalization Service about their intentions. In others,
authorities did not enforce U.S. laws. Among the cases examined:

Name: Omar Abdel-- Rahman

Terrorist plot: Egyptian serving life term for planning to bomb New York City
landmarks.

Status when charged: Asylum applicant

Dealings with INS or other agencies: Allowed to enter USA four times in late
1980s, even though he was put on a terrorist watch list in 1987. Overstayed visa
in 1990; visa revoked. Applied for visa under a different name and was granted
permanent residency in 1991. Residency revoked in 1992. He then applied for
asylum.

Name: Fadil Abdelghani

Terrorist plot: Sudanese linked to plot to bomb New York landmarks. Serving
25-year sentence.

Status when charged: Legal permanent resident

Dealings with INS or other agencies: Overstayed 1987 tourist visa. Lived here as
illegal alien until 1991, when he married a U.S. citizen. That made him a legal
permanent resident.

Name: Gazi Ibrahim Abu Mezer

Terrorist plot: Palestinian who planned to bomb Brooklyn subway. Said during
trial that he came to America to kill as many Jews as possible. Sentenced to
life in prison.

Status when charged: llegal alien

Dealings with INS or other agencies: Denied student visa in 1993. Got Canadian
student visa. Caught three times trying to sneak into USA from Canada. After
third try, Canada refused to take him back. INS released him and started
deportation proceedings. Arrested before proceedings were done.

Name: Lafi Khalil

Terrorist plot: Palestinian linked to plot to bomb Brooklyn subway. Found guilty
of immigration fraud; sentenced to three years in prison.

Status when charged: Illegal alien

Dealings with INS or other agencies: Issued transit visa in 1996 for travel
through the USA to Ecuador. At JFK Airport in New York, an INS inspector
mistakenly stamped his passport with a six-month tourist visa instead of 29
days. He boarded a flight to Syracuse, N.Y., then overstayed his visa.

Name: Ali Mohammed

Terrorist plot: Egyptian who pleaded guilty to taking part in conspiracy to bomb
U.S. embassies in Africa in 1998. Plea agreement sealed.

Status when charged: Naturalized U.S. citizen

Dealings with INS or other agencies: Put on terrorist watch list in 1984 but was
granted a visa in 1985. Received permanent residency after marrying U.S. citizen
in 1986.

Name: Khalid Abu al Dahab

Terrorist plot: Egyptian involved in plan to bomb U.S. embassies in Africa. Now
imprisoned in Egypt.

Status when charged: Naturalized U.S. citizen

Dealings with INS or other agencies: Studied medicine in USA on student visa in
1986. Married an American just after visa expired but divorced about a month
later. Second marriage to U.S. citizen called one of "convenience" by court
investigator. Became permanent resident after a third marriage to a U.S.
citizen.

Name: Ahmed Ressam

Terrorist plot: Algerian convicted in foiled "millennium" plan to bomb Los
Angeles International Airport around Jan. 1, 2000. Faces up to 130 years in
prison, but is trading intelligence for leniency. Scheduled to be sentenced in
2003.

Status when charged: Illegal alien

Dealings with INS or other agencies: Entered Canada in 1994 using fake French
passport. Applied for refugee status. Application was rejected, but he remained
in Canada because of a moratorium on deportations to Algeria. Left Canada in
1998 to train in Afghan terrorist camps, authorities say. Returned to Canada on
fake Canadian passport. Arrested at U.S. border in late 1999 with explosives in
his car's trunk.

Name: Zaccarias Moussaoui

Terrorist plot: French-Moroccan charged with taking part in al-Qaeda conspiracy
that carried out Sept. 11 attacks. Awaiting trial; charges carry death penalty.

Status when charged: Illegal alien; violated terms of student visa

Dealings with INS or other agencies: Given U.S. student visa in London in
February 2001 despite being on a French watch list of suspected Islamic
extremists.

Name: Mohamed Atta

Terrorist plot: Egyptian believed to have been leader of the 19 suicide
hijackers on Sept. 11.

Status when charged: Student visa application pending

Dealings with INS or other agencies: Given U.S. tourist visa in 1999 in Germany
even though he fit the profile of an "intending immigrant." That means, among
other things, that he was young, unmarried and appeared to have few ties to his
home country. Such visa-seekers are supposed to be viewed with suspicion.
Entered USA in June 2000 and enrolled in flight school despite not having a
student visa. Applied for a vocational student visa and then overstayed tourist
visa. Left USA Jan. 10, 2001; U.S. law says those who leave the country should
have their applications to change visa status voided. INS approved his student
visa request just before Sept. 11 but did not notify his flight school until six
months after the attacks.

Name: Khalid Al-Midhar

Terrorist plot: Saudi identified as Sept. 11 hijacker

Status when charged: Had business visa.

Dealings with INS or other agencies:Got "express" visa through travel agent
without having immigration interview. In January 2000, attended al-Qaeda
planning meeting in Malaysia for the attack on the USS Cole several months later
in Yemen. Entered USA shortly afterward. Identified as a potential terrorist as
early as January 2001 but was not put on CIA watch list until August 2001. FBI
unable to find him before Sept. 11.

Name: Nawaf Alhazmi

Terrorist plot: Saudi identified as Sept. 11 hijacker

Status when charged: Illegal alien

Dealings with INS or other agencies:Overstayed tourist visa issued in January
2000. Identified by CIA as possible terrorist in January 2001 and put on watch
list. FBI couldn't find him before Sept. 11.

Name: Hani Hanjour

Terrorist plot: Saudi identified as Sept. 11 hijacker

Status when charged: Illegal alien

Granted student visa in September 2000 to study at California language school.
Never attended classes and became an illegal alien.

Name: Ramzi Yousef

Terrorist plot: Pakistani serving life sentence for bombing World Trade Center
in 1993.

Status when charged: Asylum applicant

Dealings with INS or other agencies: Entered USA without a visa in 1992 and
applied for asylum. Released before asylum was granted because INS lacked
detention space.

Name: Mahmud Abouhalima

Terrorist plot: Egyptian linked to plot to Trade Center in 1993. Sentenced to
240 years in prison.

Status when charged: Legal permanent resident

Dealings with INS or other agencies: After tourist visa expired in 1986, he
worked illegally as a cabdriver. Granted permanent resident status in 1988 as
part of an amnesty program for illegal farm workers. There is no evidence he
worked in agriculture.

Sources: Center for Immigration Studies; USA TODAY research

                              Chicago Daily Herald

                             March 10, 2015 Tuesday

DuPage County in 60 seconds

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 435 words


Scholarships available:

Rotary Club of Lisle is taking applications for its 2015 scholarships. Four
$1,000 college scholarships will be awarded to high school seniors, residing in
Lisle, who exemplify the Rotary ideal of "Service Above Self." Interested
seniors may pick up applications in the guidance offices of Benet Academy,
Downers Grove North High School, Lisle Senior High School, Montini High School,
Naperville North High School, St. Francis High School, Wheaton Academy and
Wheaton Warrenville South High School. Completed forms should be sent to: Rotary
Club of Lisle Scholarship Committee, c/o Lisa Leone, Lisle Park District, 1925
Ohio St., Lisle, IL 60532 no later than March 31.

Garden plots available:

Fox Valley Park District is taking reservations for garden plots for the 2015
growing season. Two hundred and sixty plots are available on the west side of
Aurora at Jericho & Barnes Road. Make reservations at the Prisco Community
Center, 150 W. Illinois Ave., phone (630) 859-8606. Two hundred and fifty plots
are located on the east side of Aurora at Oakhurst Forest Preserve, 1680 Fifth
Ave. Make reservations at Eola Center, 555 S. Eola Road, phone (630) 851-8990.
The cost to rent a plot is $15 for Fox Valley Park District residents and $30
for nonresidents.

Top orator from Naperville:

Rowan Macwan, a home-schooled high school junior from Naperville, won the 1st
place honor and a $2,000 college tuition award at the state level of the
American Legion's National Oratorical Contest. The state contest included 19
contestants, and was held March 7 in the Peoria. Rowan will now represent
Illinois in the national contest involving contestants from all 50 states, which
will be held on April 10-12 in Indianapolis. Awards of about $130,000 are given
at the national contest. High school students interested in next year's contest
can obtain information on the following websites: naperlegion.org (oratorical
ink), illegion.org (scholarship link) and legion.org (programs link).

Police investigating death:

Hanover Park police are investigating the death of a 32-year-old man who
officers found unresponsive Monday morning, authorities said. Police were called
7 a.m. on a report of a man down near the 5700 block of Dutch Mill Court, a
residential area with apartments and condos southwest of Lake Street, according
to a department news release. Paramedics took the man to St. Alexius Medical
Center in Hoffman Estates, where he was pronounced dead at about 10:49 a.m.,
police said in the release. The Cook County medical examiner's office is
scheduled to conduct an autopsy today, police said.

                                  Computerworld

                                January 19, 1987

SECTION: NEW PRODUCTS; Systems & Peripherals; Printers/Plotters; Pg. 68

LENGTH: 118 words


Greyhawk Systems, Inc. has introduced three user options, Cadam Red Line, Plot
Utility and Plot Storage, said to make its Softplot 2122 paperless plotter
interactive.

The Red Line option is said to permit the user to make annotations and store
them within the data base.

The Plot Storage option is said to allow drawings to be stacked locally for
review. The Plot Utility option is said to allow images to be panned or zoomed.

The Cadam Red Line option costs $8,000. The Plot Utility package costs $1,850,
and the Plot Storage package option costs $3,200 for 2M bytes and $5,000 for 4M
bytes. The Softplot 2122 costs from $39,750.

Greyhawk Systems, 1557 Centre Pointe Drive, Milpitas, Calif. 95035.

                                US Official News

                           January 24, 2015 Saturday

USPTO Published Patent application of Google Inc titled as "Small-Screen
Movie-Watching Using a Viewport"

LENGTH: 243  words

DATELINE: ALEXANDRIA, Va


United States Patent and Trademark Office has received an application no.
20150023650, published on January 22, 2015, by Google Inc, titled as
"Small-Screen Movie-Watching Using a Viewport" for the registration of patent.

Inventors:   Austin; Darren Mark; (San Jose, CA) ; Elmieh; Baback; (Palo Alto,
CA) ; Sweetland; Douglas Paul; (Los Angeles, CA) ; Collins; Brian M.; (South San
Francisco, CA) ; Oftedal; Mark Jason; (Naperville, IL) ; Pinkava; Jan J.;
(Portland, OR)
Assignee: Google Inc.
Mountain View
CA
US

According to the abstract released by the U.S. Patent & Trademark Office: "This
document describes techniques and apparatuses for small-screen movie-watching
using a viewport. These techniques enable viewers to experience movies and other
media programs using a small screen as a viewport to the movie rather than
dramatically compressing or cropping the movie to fit the small screen. A viewer
may select whatever portion of the movie imagery he or she desires to experience
through the small screen at a size sufficient to perceive details of plot
elements and an environment in which the plot elements interact. Thus, the
viewer may follow plot elements central to the plot while also exploring the
environment that provides context for these plot elements."

The Patent was filed on July 18, 2014 under application No. 20150023650

contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                              78 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Star Tribune (Minneapolis, MN)

                            February 10, 2006 Friday
                                 Metro Edition

Bush describes foiled plot in L.A.;
Terrorists planned to fly a jetliner into a skyscraper, he said, adding that
four nations helped the U.S. crack the case.

BYLINE: James Rosen, Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 12A

LENGTH: 677 words

DATELINE: Washington, D.C.


President Bush outlined new details Thursday about an Al-Qaida plot to fly a
commercial jetliner into a Los Angeles skyscraper, saying it was disrupted in
2002 with the help of four other governments.

He described the "West Coast plot" to use shoe bombs to blow open a cockpit
door, hijack a plane and fly it into the US Bank Tower in Los Angeles' business
district - called the Library Tower until 2003.

The president did not say whether information about the plot was collected by
monitoring - without appropriate court warrants - some calls and e-mails to the
United States from terror suspects overseas.

The program has been questioned by both Democratic and Republican lawmakers.

"We cannot let the fact that America hasn't been attacked in four-and-a-half
years since September 11th, 2001, lull us into the illusion that the threats to
our nation have disappeared," Bush told National Guard soldiers in Washington.
"They have not."

The president had briefly mentioned the West Coast plot in October as one of 10
that had been thwarted since Sept. 11, but he provided much more information
Thursday.

Bush's aides said his speech was not timed to bolster public support for the
wiretapping of calls to and from the United States. He authorized the
eavesdropping soon after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, but it was disclosed in
mid-December.

Frances Townsend, Bush's national homeland security adviser, said that the
attack on the Library Tower was originally planned as part of a Sept. 11
bicoastal assault on the United States, but that Osama bin Laden modified the
plan to focus on New York and Washington.

"It's our understanding now that it was too difficult to get enough operatives
for both the East and West Coast plots at the same time," she said.

Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, a Kuwaiti of Pakistani descent who is believed to have
planned the Sept. 11 attacks, was also the mastermind of the Los Angeles plot,
according to Bush and Townsend. He was arrested in March 2003.

Mohammed, who had been the Al-Qaida operations commander, joined with another
terrorist named Hambali, head of an Al-Qaida affiliate in Southeast Asia called
Jemaah Islamiyah. They recruited four operatives to carry out the West Coast
attack, Bush and Townsend said.

The president said they purposely selected Asians because they would draw less
suspicion than people of Middle Eastern descent. The cell traveled to
Afghanistan in October 2001, met with Bin Laden, took a loyalty oath and
returned to Asia.

Countries not named

Mohammed trained the cell leader in shoe-bomb techniques, Townsend said. The
cell leader was arrested in February 2002, and the other cell members were later
detained as well.

Townsend declined to identify the four countries - two in South Asia, two in
Southeast Asia - that helped derail the plot, saying their government leaders
wanted to shield their nations' involvement. She also declined to say whether
wiretapping played a role in breaking up the plot.

The accounts demonstrated a victory by U.S. intelligence agencies, which endured
heavy criticism for failures to detect the Sept. 11 plot and for later
exaggerating the presence of lethal weapons in Iraq.

Yet Bruce Hoffman, a terrorism specialist who heads the Washington office of
RAND Corp., said Bush left questions unanswered about the Library Tower case.

"It doesn't really give us any more indication of whether this was a plot that
was derailed or pre-empted, or a plot that was more in the realm of an idle
daydream," Hoffman said.

Sen. John Rockefeller, W.-Va., the ranking Democrat on the intelligence
committee, mocked the plot. "Maybe they're tired of talking about [the] Brooklyn
Bridge and they're trying to find a different edifice of some sort," he said,
referring to another alleged plot that some have said was exaggerated.

But Townsend told reporters, "There is no question in my mind that this is a
disruption. It's not about credit, it's about protecting the American people."

James Rosen is a correspondent in the Star Tribune Washington Bureau. The
Washington Post contributed to this report.

LOAD-DATE: February 13, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

This & that

BYLINE: Intelligencer Journal Staff

SECTION: A; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 315  words

Garden

PLOT YOUR SPRING: The Lancaster County Department of Parks and Recreation has
garden plots available for rent April 15 through Oct. 15. Renters can apply for
a plot today. Renters pay a one-time fee of $16 for a small plot and $20 for a
larger plot. The garden plots are located off Farm View Drive, just off Golf
Road in Lancaster County Central Park. Organic plots are also available. These
are plots that have been free of pesticides and herbicides for more than three
years. To register for a plot call 299-8215.

Health

SUP AND SMILE: Humor and positive emotions play an important part in a person's
healing. The Ephrata Cancer Center and the Wellness Center, both services of
Ephrata Community Hospital, are co-sponsoring a free presentation about humor
and its role in health on Thursday, March 22. This event, which includes a free
light supper, is open to the public but requires advance registration. Call
738-4070 for more information or to register.

Free

ON THE WRIST WITH A FIST: Get a free bracelet from the V Foundation for Cancer
Research and Siemens Medical at www.smed.com/cancerresearch/registration.asp,
while supplies last. Legendary basketball coach Jimmy Valvano died from cancer
in 1993. The fund raises monies for cancer research. The bracelets read, "Don't
ever give up."

Music

MUSIC MAKERS: Students who'd like to participate in the Pennsylvania Academy of
Music's annual summer music festival, Music Naturally, can register for
auditions by calling 399-2296 or going online to: www.paacademymusic.com to
download an application. Auditions will take place in April. There are openings
for pre-collegiate and college-age string, wind and piano students for the
two-week festival, which will take place June 17-30 at the Academy's Liberty
Place location. Tuition for the summer festival is set at $750 per student, with
scholarships available. Room and board is $450.

                              80 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                     Deseret Morning News (Salt Lake City)

                             July 5, 2007 Thursday

Provo Cemetery raises its prices

BYLINE: Tad Walch Deseret Morning News

LENGTH: 338 words


PROVO -- The prices for burial plots in the Provo City Cemetery rose 25 percent
to 33 percent on Monday.

The cost of a cremation plot jumped 100 percent as fee increases approved by the
Provo City Council went into effect for the new fiscal year, which began Sunday.

Cemetery fees had not been adjusted since 1994, Provo Parks and Recreation
Director Roger Thomas said.

"Typically the cemetery will do an annual survey of other cemeteries in the
valley and around Salt Lake City to see if our fees are in line with other
cemeteries," Thomas said. "We've taken the position we don't want to have the
lowest or the highest fees. Our survey in June 2006 showed we no longer were
within that market range."

The fee increases are not high enough to cover the cemetery's costs.

"We're not fully self-supporting," Thomas said. "There is a subsidy. The
increase in the rates will help reduce that subsidy."

Residents will pay 25 percent to 29 percent more for a burial plot under the new
fee structure.

A plot with a flat grave marker costs Provo residents $700, up from $500. The
price of a plot with an upright headstone rose to $800 from $600.

Nonresidents will continue to pay more than residents for Provo plots. A plot
with a flat marker jumped to $900 from $600 for a non-resident and a space with
an upright marker rose to $1,000 from $700.

The biggest fee increases are for cremations.

A cremation plot costs $300, up from $150. The fee for opening and closing the
ground for a cremation plot jumped to $200 from $100 without a vault. With a
vault, the price rose to $250 from $100.

The fees also rose for baby plots, recording work, disinterments and other
services.

Costs for cemeteries had risen significantly since Provo's fees were last
adjusted in 1994, Thomas said.

Higher water, electricity and gas prices have affected the cemetery's operations
and budget.

The cemetery has four full-time employees, including the sexton, and one
part-time staffer. Four to 10 seasonal employees help maintain the park. E-mail:
twalch@desnews.com

                               The New York Times

                          December 10, 2014 Wednesday
                              Late Edition - Final

Rebutting C.I.A. Claims on Torture

BYLINE: By MATT APPUZO, HAEYOUN PARK and LARRY BUCHANAN

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Foreign Desk; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 951 words


Below are examples of where the C.I.A. said that its use of harsh interrogation
tactics produced intelligence that thwarted terror plots and captured
terrorists, and how the Senate Intelligence Committee undercut those accounts.
In response, the C.I.A. said the committee unfairly dismissed the value of
intelligence gathered from detainees. MATT APUZZO, HAEYOUN PARK and LARRY
BUCHANAN

Thwarting of the Karachi Plots

THE CASE

President Bush credited the C.I.A. interrogation program with helping to prevent
an attack on the United States Consulate in Karachi, Pakistan. The tip can be
traced back to the interrogations of Ammar al-Baluchi and Khallad bin Attash,
who were subjected to harsh C.I.A. interrogations in May 2003. Intelligence
reports from those interrogations state that Al Qaeda was plotting attacks on
the consulate and other Western targets in Karachi.

COMMITTEE'S CONCLUSION

The committee said in a report released Tuesday that Mr. Baluchi and Mr. bin
Attash provided information weeks earlier to Pakistani officials, who then
relayed it to the C.I.A. When the intelligence report on the Karachi plot was
issued, C.I.A. officials in Pakistan issued a cable saying they had already
known. Weeks later, when Khalid Shaikh Mohammed -- after being waterboarded --
discussed the plot, it came as no surprise to the C.I.A., who again reported
that they already knew.

''CIA records indicate the CIA became aware of the initial plotting as early as
September 2002, and that it was disrupted in April 2003, when the remaining plot
leaders were arrested in a unilateral operation by Pakistani authorities.'' FROM
PAGE 239 OF THE REPORT

Thwarting of 'Second Wave' Plot and Discovery of Al Ghurabaa Group

THE CASE

In 2006, the White House announced that the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks had been
conceived as an attack on two fronts, with a ''second wave'' planned on the West
Coast. The plot, as described by Mr. Bush, involved crashing a plane into
Library Tower in Los Angeles. The C.I.A. credited the waterboarding of Mr.
Mohammed with uncovering this plot.

COMMITTEE'S CONCLUSION

The report revealed that the C.I.A. learned about the plot in January 2002 with
the arrest of Masran bin Arshad, a Malaysian who was involved. Mr. Mohammed
confirmed the existence of the plot after being tortured, to the frustration of
C.I.A. interrogators who said he was confirming only what they already knew.

''The Second Wave plotting was disrupted with the arrest and identification of
key individuals ... unrelated to any reporting acquired during or after the use
of the CIA's enhanced interrogation techniques against CIA detainees.'' FROM
PAGES 246-247 OF THE REPORT

Identification, Capture and Arrest of Iyman Faris

THE CASE

In 2003, the Justice Department charged an Ohio truck driver, Iyman Faris, in a
Qaeda plot to destroy the Brooklyn Bridge by cutting its suspension cables. In
government briefings, C.I.A. officials repeatedly credited the interrogation
program with uncovering the plot and identifying Mr. Faris.

COMMITTEE'S CONCLUSION

The report said that it was a court-approved wiretap of another American
suspect, Majid Khan, that prompted the F.B.I. investigation into Mr. Faris. Mr.
Khan's capture and interrogation by a foreign government -- without any harsh
tactics, according to C.I.A. documents -- led to the identification of Mr. Faris
as a Qaeda member. After being tortured, Mr. Mohammed (''KSM'') identified a
photo of Mr. Faris but could not remember his name. He said that he had once
tasked Mr. Faris with finding tools to loosen the bolts of American suspension
bridges, but that Mr. Faris had been unable to do so.

''Iyman Faris was identified, investigated, and linked directly to al-Qa'ida
prior to any mention of Iyman Faris by KSM or any other CIA detainee. When
approached by law enforcement, Iyman Faris voluntarily provided information and
made self-incriminating statements.'' FROM PAGE 276 OF THE REPORT

Thwarting of the Heathrow Airport and Canary Wharf Plot

THE CASE

After the Sept. 11 attacks, Mr. Mohammed hoped to use hijacked airplanes to
attack Heathrow Airport and Canary Wharf, a business district in London. The
C.I.A. credited its enhanced interrogation of him with uncovering the plot.

COMMITTEE'S CONCLUSION

The report said the C.I.A. knew that Al Qaeda had targeted Heathrow months
before Mr. Mohammed was waterboarded. The plot was labeled ''not imminent''
because Al Qaeda had not identified pilots. The plot was fully disrupted with
the capture of Ramzi bin al-Shibh, Mr. Mohammed and others.

''None of these individuals were captured as a result of reporting obtained
during or after the use of the CIA's enhanced interrogation techniques against
CIA detainees.'' FROM PAGE 295 OF THE REPORT

Capture of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed

THE CASE

Mr. Bush credited the interrogation of Abu Zubaydah and Mr. bin al-Shibh,
another senior Qaeda operative, with providing information that helped capture
Mr. Mohammed. The C.I.A. also credited its interrogation of Abu Zubaydah with
revealing Mr. Mohammed as the mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks.

COMMITTEE'S CONCLUSION

C.I.A. documents show that Mr. Mohammed was a suspect in the Sept. 11 attacks
almost immediately. Also, in a section of the report that was heavily redacted
by the C.I.A., the committee showed that a source -- referred to as Asset X --
led the C.I.A. to Mr. Mohammed. The informant, seeking a $25 million reward, led
the agency to Mr. Mohammed.

''Contrary to CIA representations, there are no CIA records to support the
assertion that Abu Zubaydah, Ramzi bin al-Shibh, or any other CIA detainee
played any role in the 'the planning and execution of the operation that
captured Khalid Sheikh Mohammed.''' FROM PAGES 327 OF THE REPORT

URL:

LOAD-DATE: December 10, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: GRAPHICS

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              82 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            Buffalo News (New York)

                           October 1, 2008 Wednesday
                                CENTRAL EDITION

A slow takeoff for 'Eagle Eye'

BYLINE: By JOEY POLINO - NeXt Correspondent

SECTION: NEXT; Pg. N9

LENGTH: 505 words


For years, the idea of Big Brother has populated countless Hollywood thrillers
and best-selling novels. With the advance of technology in the recent decade,
the thrillers have grown more and more frequent.

"Eagle Eye" is such a thriller. Also popular in Hollywood of late is the "video
game plot" technique where more and more of the plot is revealed as the movie
goes on. "Eagle Eye's" usage of a plot like this may have been its downfall from
being an intriguing thriller to just another one of those political techno
thrillers that had potential.

"Eagle Eye" tells the story of two strangers, a slacker named Jerry (Shia
LaBeouf) and a single mom Rachel (Michelle Monaghan) who are brought together by
a mysterious woman who calls them both. This woman lures them into a game of
chase against time, taking them from Chicago to Indianapolis before arriving on
Capitol Hill. All the while, she keeps track of them through those fun security
cameras that hang off buildings and light posts.

"Eagle Eye" is not a bad movie -- or at least the second half isn't. The film
starts out really slowly plot-wise (there's an action sequence at least every
five minutes or so) -- and the first hour really drags. "Eagle Eye" suffers from
its plot unfolding over time. The fact that the plot is not made known to the
viewer gets irritating as you watch LaBeouf and Monaghan run around for either
no apparent reason, or just a confusing one. It isn't until Jerry and Rachel
leave the Midwest for Washington, D.C., that the plot begins to make a lick of
sense and suddenly this film becomes a good political technology thriller.

Another slight problem is that it takes a while to get used to seeing Shia
LaBeouf in a role other than as a teenage smart mouth or sidekick. He isn't bad
in the role, but it's just so different from any of the mainstream films he's
appeared in in the past that it takes a while to get used to.

One of the strong points of "Eagle Eye" is its successful selling of the idea of
Big Brother and how this woman is able to keep track of them. Throughout the
film, the movie cuts to what is supposed to be surveillance from the security
cameras around them. Watching the movie, you really have to wonder if any of
this is possible and I'm sure that's exactly what the filmmakers had in mind.

The best thing about the movie is its political plot that is revealed in the
second half. It feels more like a David Baldacci novel once we cross the hour
mark and the movie really shines after that point.

"Eagle Eye" is rated PG-13 for intense sequences of action and violence, and
language. The violence is typical for an action film like this, usually only
coming in the form of car/foot chases. There is one strong act of violence near
the end of the film that may turn parents off from having children watch it, but
beyond that the violence is not anything to worry about. The language includes
harsh words in one particular incident.

Joey Polino is a junior at Canisius.

***

EAGLE EYE

2 1/2 stars (Out of four)

PG-13

Starring Shia LaBeouf

LOAD-DATE: October 1, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Movie Review

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                        Copyright 2008 The Buffalo News
                              All Rights Reserved

                     The Guardian (London) - Final Edition

                                October 8, 2005

New York on high alert as foiled plots revealed: White House claims UK was among
targets: Massive subway swoop intensifies US jitters

BYLINE: Jamie Wilson, Washington and Richard Norton-Taylor

SECTION: Guardian International Pages, Pg. 15

LENGTH: 659 words


Commuters in New York were greeted yesterday by security staff wearing chemical
hazard suits descending on Penn station as the city's entire subway system was
put on heightened alert after authorities warned of a specific terrorist threat.

The alert at Penn station, triggered after a "soupy green substance" was found
in a Pepsi bottle, turned out to be a false alarm. But it added to jitters
across the United States as details emerged about claims made by George Bush
that 10 major al-Qaida attacks - including three on American soil - had been
thwarted since September 11 2001. A wide variety of targets was cited, including
a plan to fly hijacked aircraft into the Library Tower, the tallest building in
Los Angeles, and three sites in the UK.

Despite the department of homeland security describing the threat to New York as
"specific yet non-credible", city authorities appeared to take the warning
seriously, with thousands of uniformed and undercover officers searching subway
passengers' bags and maintaining a high profile.

New York was put on alert on Thursday night after an FBI source warned of a plot
to bomb the subway within days. The mayor, Michael Bloomberg, called it the most
specific terrorist threat yet received. "We have done and will continue to do
everything we can to protect this city," he said at a nationally televised news
conference. "We will spare no resource, we will spare no expense."

The threat is thought to relate to intelligence gathered after a military
operation in Iraq. According to the New York Times, information came to light
that three men arrested in Iraq were due to meet agents in New York who planned
to use strollers, briefcases and backpacks to hide bombs. The story was given
some credence yesterday after it emerged that a television station held off
reporting the threat for two days at the request of officials in New York and
Washington. Dan Forman, vice-president of news at WNBC, said the officials
stressed that they would not normally ask for a story to be held but people
overseas could be in danger if it was aired.

The New York alert followed Mr Bush's downbeat speech on Thursday about progress
of the war on terror, in which he cited 10 al-Qaida plots foiled. The White
House rushed out brief details after being deluged with inquiries from
reporters.

It is the first time the administration has placed a specific number on foiled
attacks, but Peter Bergen, the author of Holy War Inc, said:"I would have said
we knew about 95% of them in one form or another."

In Britain, anti-terrorist officials were unclear about which plots the White
House was referring to.

guardian.co.uk/terrorism >

The plots

West coast airliner Mid-2002: plot to attack targets on US west coast, including
Library Tower, tallest building in Los Angeles, using hijacked planes. Plotters
believed to have included Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, suspected mastermind of
September 11 attacks.

Mid-2003 Plot to attack targets on US east coast using hijacked planes.

May 2002 Plot to blow up apartment buildings in US. Alleged plotter Jose Padilla
also reportedly discussed possibility of using a "dirty bomb".

UK urban targets Mid-2004: US and partners disrupted plot to use explosives on
UK urban targets.

2003 Karachi US and partner disrupted plot to attack westerners at targets in
Karachi.

Heathrow airport 2003: US and partners disrupted plot to attack Heathrow using
hijacked airliners.

The 2004 UK plot Spring 2004: Law enforcement and intelligence resources
disrupted a plot to conduct large-scale bombings in the UK.

Gulf shipping plot Late 2002 and 2003: Plot by al-Qaida to attack ships in the
Gulf.

2002 Straits of Hormuz plot In 2003 FBI claimed a Guantanamo Bay prisoner gave
information that led to thwarting of plot against oil tanker.

2003 tourist site plot The US and a partner disrupted a plot to attack a tourist
site outside the US.

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                            December 13, 2009 Sunday

agriculture briefs

SECTION: B; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 422 words


Hybrid-plot results available in Illinois ELIZABETH, Ill. - Detailed results are
now available at the Mount Carroll and Elizabeth Extension offices for the nine
Jo-Carroll Extension Unit soybean variety and corn hybrid plots harvested for
2009. Carroll County plots include two reduced tillage corn plots hosted by Sam
Dykstra, of Mount Carroll, where 35 corn-on-soybean entries averaged 209 bushels
per acre and 40 corn-on-corn entries averaged 208 bushels; a no-till
corn-on-soybean plot hosted by Phil Michael, of Lanark, where 30 entries
averaged 209 bushels; a reduced tillage soybean plot at Dykstra's where 31
entries averaged 51 bushels; and a no-till soybean plot at Michael's where 33
entries averaged 64 bushels. Jo Daviess County plots included a no-till soybean
plot hosted by Kyle Embry, of Hanover, where 30 entries averaged 54 bushels and
a no-till corn plot that has yet to be harvested.

Two reduced tillage corn plots hosted by Wayne Simmons, of Stockton, were not
harvested for yield results due to hail damage Plot sponsors included 20
participating seed companies and the University of Illinois Extension. For each
no-till plot, additional assistance and sponsorship included the Carroll County
Soil and Water Conservation District and the Jo Daviess County Soil and Water
Conservation District in their respective counties. Plot results booklets can be
picked up at your local extension office or are available by e-mail by
contacting Mark Maidak, Jo-Carroll Unit director, at mmaidak@uiuc.edu
Conservation Reserve Program an option? MAQUOKETA, Iowa - Wet weather and
flooding present many challenges to landowners and operators that farm Jackson
County's bottomlands. Some landowners who are tired of floods destroying their
crops have found that the Conservation Reserve Program is an attractive solution
to the fight against wet weather and flooding. The Conservation Reserve Program
offers a few practices that bring wet areas out of crop production and into
perennial vegetation that provides wildlife habitat and improves soil and water
quality. For more information, contact the Jackson County NRCS office at
563-652-2337 or stop by the office at 6031/2 E. Platt St., Maquoketa. Class III
milk price up since previous month The new Class III milk price from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture is $14.08 per hundredweight - $1.26 higher than the
previous month, but $1.43 below a year ago. The 2009 average is now $11.03 per
hundredweight, which is $6.60 below the average of one year ago. Telegraph
Herald

                              86 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Christian Science Monitor

                             July 28, 2006, Friday

Don't take my aspiration away

BYLINE: Ruth Walker

SECTION: THE HOME FORUM; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 647 words


Have you noticed? There's a new front in the global war on terror: "aspirational
terrorism." The FBI announced earlier this month that it had disrupted an Al
Qaeda plot to attack transportation tunnels between New York City and New
Jersey. The Associated Press reported: "One US official called the plot 'largely
aspirational' and described the Internet conversations as mostly extremists
discussing and conceptualizing the plot. The official said no money had been
transferred, nor had other similar operational steps been taken."

The official's sound bite represented an echo of a phrase from some weeks
before, when officials announced the disruption of a plot to attack the Sears
Tower in Chicago.

At that point, John Pistole, deputy director of the FBI, described the state of
that plot as more "aspirational than operational." Pistole's words made for a
good quote - its almost-rhyme made it catchy, but not as kitschy as an exact
rhyme could so easily be.

"Aspire," as a verb, is rooted in the notion of "breathing on" some goal or
other - panting for it, we might say colloquially.

That "spir" element is familiar from "inspiration" and its verb form, "inspire."
This is used transitively to refer to some metaphorical breathing life into
someone - a general inspiring his troops, for instance. (On your camping trip
this summer, think of yourself as striving to "inspire" your air mattress.)

One aspires to something (greatness, perhaps) or to do something: "He aspires to
finish the marathon in less than three hours."

"Aspiration," the noun, is the goal one is, etymologically at least, breathing
on: "His aspiration is to finish the marathon in less than three hours."

So far, so good.

"Aspirational," the adjective, seems a little trickier. The Oxford English
Dictionary provides only a rather minimalist definition: "Belonging to or
characterized by aspiration." Among the usage examples it cites is one from
1967, "Everybody banging away at that final aspirational aria." Meaning what?
The aria the audience knows will end the whole production so everyone can go
home?

Encarta is a little more useful here, offering as a definition, "ambitious,
showing a desire or ambition to achieve something, especially self-improvement
or material success," as in "the aspirational working class."

The world of marketing has given us the terms "aspirational age" and
"aspirational brand."

An aspirational age is one whose characteristics customers strive to embody, and
in the West that age is thought to be 16 or 17. The idea is that marketers can
pitch to this age and reach not only those who are at that age but those who
haven't noticed that they are past it.

An aspirational brand is one sought after but not available to the masses for
reasons of price and/or production capacity. More broadly, "aspirational," is
being used on both sides of the Atlantic (though more so in Britain, it appears)
to suggest both an ambition and the fact of its being unrealized.

It's being discovered as a way of acknowledging that the glass is half empty
while pointing out that it also is half full. To say that a goal "remains
aspirational" is a positive-sounding way of saying you haven't reached it but
haven't given up on it either.

And no wonder it's catching on. After all, "aspirational" is a
dignified-sounding five-syllable word, which, if you're a government official
trying to buy yourself time to think on your feet under hot TV lights, must seem
like a godsend. If I were, say, an FBI spokeswoman trying to talk about alleged
plotters under arrest who may not be the real deal, I'd rather be able to call
them aspirational terrorists than have to call them wannabes. Wouldn't you?

Now excuse me while I go reconnect with my aspirational inner 16-year-old.

* This weekly column appears with links at
http://weblogs.csmonitor.com/verbal_energy.

(c) Copyright 2006. The Christian Science Monitor

LOAD-DATE: July 27, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


            Copyright 2006 The Christian Science Publishing Society

                           Investor's Business Daily

                              July 10, 2006 Monday
                                NATIONAL EDITION

Terror's Tunnel Vision

SECTION: ISSUES & INSIGHTS; EDITORIALS; Pg. A16

LENGTH: 513 words


War: As New Yorkers pine for a Mets pennant, Islamic terrorists have been
dreaming up new ways to kill them -- this time by blowing up the PATH train
tunnel. Wake up, everybody, the enemy's not taking vacations.

The FBI luckily disrupted the plot to attack the main road between Manhattan and
New Jersey that runs under the Hudson River. The terrorists' goal was to pack
the tunnel with a huge amount of explosives and flood the financial district in
much the same way Hurricane Katrina engulfed New Orleans.

A suspected al-Qaida operative involved in the plot is in custody in Beirut, and
authorities are looking to arrest several co-conspirators. It's not clear
whether any are being sought inside the U.S.

But several al-Qaida members who cased the New York subway three years ago as
part of a plot to poison passengers with cyanide gas reportedly may still be
here. That plot allegedly was called off at the last minute by al-Qaida
leadership. Another plot to cut the Brooklyn Bridge's support cables was
disrupted by police.

New York's infrastructure clearly remains a prime target of al-Qaida. The latest
threat to tunnels only reinforces criticism of federal plans to slash New York's
counterterrorism grant by 40%. Homeland Security's decision to redirect $83
million in the city's funds to small towns now appears completely misguided.

The tunnel plot also serves to remind us that Islamo-fascists are hell-bent on
killing us no matter what. They spend practically all their waking hours
scheming of new ways to destroy infidels, whether by fuel-laden planes or lethal
gases or mass flooding. When they're not scheming, they're praying to Allah for
succor. Every American needs to wake up to this.

Those still skeptical of the magnitude of the threat from Islamic radicals might
want to invest a few bucks and 98 minutes of their time to see a new documentary
film called "Islam: What the West Needs to Know." It is an eye-opening
examination of Islam, violence and the fate of the non-Muslim world.

"An examination of Islam's doctrines is necessary in order to understand the
motivations of its faithful today and the present violent conflicts around the
globe," says a promo for the film, which destroys the politically accepted
notion that Islam is a religion of peace. "The Muslim world today is exceptional
for being responsible for the vast majority of conflicts around the world and
for almost all of international terrorism."

The film features interviews with noted experts on Islam who explain how the
Quran prescribes violence against non-Muslims and assures salvation only to
Muslims who perish in violent death while fighting jihad against infidels.

Its sobering conclusion is that jihad is nothing less than organized warfare
against unbelievers. And the battleground is not limited to Baghdad or Kandahar
or Gaza. It extends to London and Toronto and New York and Miami, and possibly
your city.

Radical Islam has already declared war on us, leaving us little choice in the
matter. We're at war with it whether we like it or not. How many more reminders
will we need?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                            Dayton Daily News (Ohio)

                             July 7, 2007 Saturday

Burial near Wrights offered;
eBay ad says two plots at Woodland Cemetery can be yours for $10,000.

BYLINE: By John Nolan Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 346 words


DAYTON - A solicitation on eBay's Web site offers to sell two burial plots,
purportedly located in Woodland Cemetery within 15 feet of the graves of
aviation pioneers Orville and Wilbur Wright, for a price of at least $10,000.

No bids had been received by Friday, according to the eBay site.

Dave FitzSimmons , president and chief executive officer of Woodland Cemetery,
said he had no knowledge of the eBay solicitation and did not know whether it is
valid.

FitzSimmons said he did not know which burial plots the ad would be referring to
or who the owner would be. Plots in that part of the cemetery have long since
been sold, but some of the plots remain vacant, he said.

Even if the offer is valid and a sale agreement is reached, any transfer of
burial plots does not become final unless it receives the cemetery's approval,
he said.

The $10,000 "starting bid" would be approximately twice the retail price of two
burial plots in the area of the Wright brothers' graves, FitzSimmons said.

The eBay pitch identified the seller as "mortician1000," who wrote that the
plots are within 15 feet of the Wright brothers' graves.

The seller provided this description: "This is a unique opportunity for an avid
fan of aviation and its history. I am a funeral director from northern Indiana
selling these on behalf of a wonderful family I served, and will be happy to
answer any questions or concerns regarding the location and availability of the
graves and the overall validity of this sale."

The seller didn't respond to questions e-mailed by a reporter on Friday.

FitzSimmons said he e-mailed the seller on Thursday to point out that cemetery
approval is required for any transfer of burial plots. He said he had not
received a response.

Stephen Wright of Oakwood, great-grandnephew of the Wright brothers, said he did
not know about the eBay solicitation or its appeals to aviation enthusiasts.

"I guess Uncle Will and Uncle Orv are still draws, even in death," he said.

Contact this reporter at (937) 225-2242 or jnolan@DaytonDailyNews.com

                                   USA TODAY

                            February 21, 2011 Monday
                                 FINAL EDITION

These movies make short work of love, war, nature

BYLINE: Claudia Puig

SECTION: LIFE; Pg. 3D

LENGTH: 1271 words


This year's Oscar-nominated short films have an eco-friendly theme, from the
animated to the documentary. Among the live-action nominees, childhood
experiences and the vagaries of love are big themes. USA TODAY's Claudia Puig
assesses the films, which are showing in select cities. To see clips and cast
your own vote, go to shortshd.com/theoscarshorts.

Out of ****

Short films (animated)

Day & Night ***

6 minutes

Country of origin: USA

Director: Teddy Newton

Plot: Sunny Day and the decidedly darker Night are put off by each other. In
their vaguely ghostly forms, they get off on the wrong foot. But eventually they
learn from each other's perspective and become friends.

You may already have. It was released along with Toy Story 3. It's a light,
breezy tale, not the best of Pixar shorts, but that's a tall order.

The Gruffalo***

27 minutes

Country of origin: U.K.

Directors: Jakob Schuh and Max Lang

Plot: Based on the children's book by Julia Donaldson, this is a fairy tale
about a clever mouse walking through the woods in search of a nut. He faces
predators and invents an imaginary tusked beast who is not what he seems.

It's fun to hear the voices of such impressive actors as Helena Bonham Carter,
Robbie Coltrane, Tom Wilkinson and John Hurt. And the visuals are striking and
do look like a storybook come to life, but the story seems familiar and a bit
banal.

Let's Pollute ***

6 minutes

Country of origin: USA

Director: Geefwee Boedoe

Plot: A biting satire on how pollution keeps our country going, encouraging the
public to continue blighting the environment. It's a gleeful but potent
indictment on our wasteful culture.

Enjoyable dark comedy, but the satire makes its point quickly, then feels
stretched a bit thin.

The Lost Thing ****

15 minutes

Country of origin: Australia/U.K.

Directors: Andrew Ruhemann and Shaun Tan

Plot: While collecting bottle tops on the beach, a bespectacled boy stumbles on
a bizarre creature/machine. He empathizes with the creature, senses that it's
lost and tries to find where it belongs. Everyone else is oblivious or uncaring.

The best of the animated lot. The story about being an outsider is imaginative,
poignant and rich with dazzling, original visuals. It's an elegy to the loss of
individuality.

Madagascar, Carnet de Voyage ****

11 minutes

Country of origin: France

Director: Bastien Dubois

Plot: Structured as entries in a travel journal of a European who goes to
Madagascar and is fascinating by the local culture and topography. Sketches come
to life, and our armchair travels are led by a ring-tailed lemur, native only to
Madagascar.

Worth catching. A wonderful escape, guaranteed to make you want to make the long
trip to this gorgeous African country.

Short films (live action)

The Confession ***

26 minutes

Country of origin: U.K.

Director: Tanel Toom

Plot: Two Catholic schoolboys are preparing to make their first Confession but
don't have much on their consciences. They undertake a seemingly innocent prank
intended to remedy the situation. Of course, it goes horribly awry.

It's an absorbing tale of responsibility and remorse and also features a
particularly creepy scarecrow figure.

The Crush ***1/2

15 minutes

Country of origin: Ireland

Director: Michael Creagh

Plot: An 8-year-old schoolboy is besotted by his teacher. When he learns she's
engaged, he challenges her fiance to a duel. It sounds mild and sweet, but the
boy's father is an armed guard, so it's a darker tale than its title implies.

This compelling story offers more surprises and intriguing scenarios in a
quarter-hour than most films do in two.

God of Love ****

18 minutes

Country of origin: USA

Director: Luke Matheny

Plot: Writer/director Matheny also stars in this clever reworking of Cupid as a
nerdy lounge singer. He's in love with a cute musician and receives a mysterious
package delivered from Mount Olympus -- specially designed darts that make
someone fall in love with you.

The best of the bunch. Matheny is a talent to watch. A singular presence, he has
a uniquely offbeat look and an appealing blend of dry wit and earnestness. This
film was his thesis project at NYU Film School.

Na Wewe ***

19 minutes

Country of origin: Belgium/ Burundi

Director: Ivan Goldschmid

Plot: This tense film is set in Burundi in 1994 in the midst of the ethnic
strife of the Hutu vs. Tutsi civil war. A minivan is stopped at a Hutu
roadblock, and the threat of execution hangs over each person. Some are forced
to deny their heritage in fighting for their lives.

This powerful short thriller, based on real incidents, recalls Hotel Rwanda.
It's more involving in less than 20 minutes than a lot of star-vehicle action
thrillers.

Wish 143 ***1/2

24 minutes

Country of origin: U.K.

Director: Ian Barnes

Plot: A terminally ill teenager has an unusual wish that the Dreamscape
Foundation cannot grant him. He doesn't want to go to an amusement park or meet
a rock star. His most fervent wish is not to die a virgin.

This is a sweetly melancholy tale with winsome performances. The turns the film
takes deftly avoid predictability and sentimentality.

Short films (documentary)

Killing in the Name****

39 minutes

Country of origin: USA/Jordan/Indonesia

Director: Jed Rothstein

Plot: His wedding turned tragic when a suicide bomber killed his father and 26
other family members, so Ashraf Al-Khaled of Jordan has made it his life's
mission to speak out against terrorism. His odyssey is juxtaposed with the
violent plans of an al-Qaeda militant.

Worth catching. One of the most eye-opening films ever made about the fallout
from a suicide bomb attack and about terrorism in general. Ashraf's tireless
efforts to spread a peaceful message are deeply moving.

Poster Girl ***

38 minutes

Country of origin: USA  Director: Sara Nesson Plot: The film documents the
emotional fallout from the military tour of duty of Sgt. Robynn Murray, a former
cheerleader turned tough machine gunner. She enlisted in 2003 at 19 and says,
looking back, "I had no idea what I was really getting into."

At times, this film feels almost exploitative, particularly when Robynn
struggles painfully with emotional instability and depression. The toll that war
takes on our youngest and bravest Americans is presented compellingly.

Strangers No More ***1/2

40 minutes

Country of origin: USA

Directors: Karen Goodman and Kirk Simon

Plot: A powerful account of a school in Tel Aviv where displaced and suffering
children are welcomed. Many have suffered through poverty, political turmoil,
even genocide. But in the nurturing atmosphere of Bialik-Rogozin, they begin to
find their potential.

This deeply moving portrait of youthful resilience and adult humanitarianism
can't help but inspire audiences. And the yearning faces and grateful reactions
of the children will warm the hardest hearts.

Sun Come Up ***1/2

38 minutes

Country of origin: USA/Papua New Guinea

Director: Jennifer Redfearn

Plot: The film traces a tribe of South Pacific islanders who must leave their
homeland because climate change is causing the gradual sinking of their
ancestral home. A contingent of young islanders sets out in search of a
community that will take them in.

A stirring portrait of determination and a fascinating approach to humanizing
the repercussions of climate change.

The Warriors of Qiugang ***

39 minutes

Country of origin: USA

Director: Ruby Yang

Plot: Cancer and death are rampant in this village in central China in the wake
of chemical companies that located plants in the area. The water and air are
being poisoned, and the residents decide to fight. The film follows their brave
efforts over the course of three years.

An inspiring account of the power of patient protest and also a cautionary tale
of corporate greed.

BUSINESS CULTURE BROUGHT TO BROOKS;
As undergraduates are pushed towards business courses rather than the liberal
arts. Douglas Coupland suggests a new approach for literature

BYLINE: DOUGLAS COUPLAND

SECTION: THE GUARDIAN FEATURES PAGE; Pg. 21

LENGTH: 705 words


LITERARY WORK

Heart Of Darkness

Joseph Conrad

PLOT

Civilised and primitive cultures

clash on primitive culture's turf.

Primitive culture wins.

BUSINESS LESSON & AUTHOR

Younger, hungrier, less-calcified

staff may resort to unusual self-

advancement techniques.

LITERARY WORK

Madame Bovary

Gustave Flaubert

PLOT

Bored wife Emma empties the family

coffers to fund trips to Rouen

for romantic dalliances.

BUSINESS LESSON & AUTHOR

Business travel by employees is

necessary but requires judicious

monitoring.

LITERARY WORK AND AUTHOR

The Grapes Of Wrath

John Steinbeck

PLOT

Displaced Oklahoma dirt farmers

enter the non-lucrative mid-1930s

California citrus industry.

BUSINESS LESSON

Hungry workers are unstable

workers. Is your employee cafete-

ria up to scratch?

LITERARY WORK AND AUTHOR

Lord Of The Flies

William Golding

PLOT

In the absence of order, the major-

ity of schoolboys stranded on an

island revert to animal behaviour.

BUSINESS LESSON

Keep employees busy at all times.

LITERARY WORK AND AUTHOR

Vanity Fair

William Thackeray

PLOT

Class and money roller-coastering

in early nineteenth-century Lon-

don. Many characters marry for-

security.

BUSINESS LESSON

Cause for reflection on the mini-

mum-wage issue. Guaranteed in-

comes can prevent countless flawed

life and career decisions.

LITERARY WORK AND AUTHOR

Wuthering Heights

Emily Bronte

PLOT

Heathcliff, angered by certain

events, exacts revenge from ten-

ants, friends, and relatives via

cruelty and mind games. Becomes a

ghost in the end.

BUSINESS LESSON

If you have a complaint with a staff

member, healthy discussion rather

than scheming is the way to pro-

mote positive change.

LITERARY WORK AND AUTHOR

Sons And Lovers

D.H. Lawrence

PLOT

A mother's ambitions for her two

sons warps their development.

First son dies; second messed up.

BUSINESS LESSON

Don't overburden employees with

unrealistic goals.

Pygmalion

George Bernard Shaw

PLOT

Professor Higgins alters the ward-

robe and social skills of Cockney

flower merchandiser Eliza Doolit-

tle, ensuring her social success

BUSINESS LESSON

A skilled image consultant is a

crucial link to the career chain of

any ambitious executive.

LITERARY WORK AND AUTHOR

The Sun Also Rises

Ernest Hemingway

PLOT

The complicated love lives of Amer-

ican expatriates in 1920s Paris;

many lovely travelogue descrip-

tions of Spain.

BUSINESS LESSON

Trips abroad make ideal employee

bonus incentives. Is your company

hooked up with a frequent flyer

programme?

Hermann Hesse

PLOT

Hary Haller's notebook showcases

the schism between bourgeois and

rebellious tastes. Much talk of

music.

BUSINESS LESSON

Gentle tunes in the workplace can

ease job dissatisfaction and increase

productivity.

Ken Kesey

PLOT

Metaphorical battle between Big

Nurse (Authority) and an asylum

inmate (the individual). Authority

wins.

Employee sedation: scourge or

bonanza?

Isaac Asimov

Often whimsical speculation on the

role robots can play in our physical

and emotional lives.

BUSINESS LESSON

Machines are only as good as the

stupidest person who works with

them.

Edward Albee

spouses George and Martha reveals

the sham and drudgery of their

lives.

As a manager, it is your role to

temper inter-employee squabbles

judiciously.

Margaret Atwood

PLOT

Metaphor-rich exploration of fe-

male and Canadian national auton-

omy and identity.

BUSINESS LESSON

Free trade may bring your firm un-

expected bonuses.

                         The Age (Melbourne, Australia)

                            October 8, 2005 Saturday
                                 First Edition

Bush hails 10 al-Qaeda failures;
Enemy is wounded, says President

BYLINE: MICHAEL GAWENDA, WASHINGTON With WASHINGTON POST

SECTION: NEWS; International News; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 928 words


THE United States and its allies have thwarted 10 serious attacks by al-Qaeda,
including three inside the US, since the September 11 onslaught, according to
President George Bush.

Mr Bush said five other attempts by al-Qaeda to identify targets in the US or
"infiltrate operatives into the country" had also been thwarted.

"Because of this steady progress the enemy is wounded," he said.

"But the enemy is still capable of global operations."

Although most of the plots were previously reported in some form, a few were
revealed for the first time in Mr Bush's Thursday speech to the Washington-based
National Endowment for Democracy.

The White House offered scant information beyond the location and general date
of each reported plot - making it difficult to know how serious or advanced they
were, or what role the US Government played in preventing them.

The three plots targeting US territory included the case of Jose Padilla,
arrested after allegedly exploring the possibility of a "dirty bomb" attack, and
plans to use hijacked planes to attack the west coast in mid-2002 and the east
coast a year later.

Two sources familiar with intelligence information said the west coast plot
targeted the Library Tower, the tallest building in Los Angeles, and involved
Malaysian militants and Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, the alleged mastermind of the
September 11 attacks, captured in 2003.

The seven foreign plots included plans to strike London's Heathrow Airport, to
hit ships in the Persian Gulf region, to attack Westerners in Pakistan and to
set off multi-target explosions in Britain.

Mr Bush's speech was the most detailed he has given on the war on terror since
his re-election last November.

He focused on organisations that want to establish a "radical Islamic empire"
across the globe, referring by name - which he rarely does - to Osama bin Laden.

He also quoted the Iraq-based terrorist Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, who called
Americans "the most cowardly of God's creatures", and offered a direct rebuttal.

"Let's be clear," he said. "It is cowardice that seeks to kill children and the
elderly with car bombs and cuts the throat of a bound captive and targets
worshippers leaving a mosque."

Mr Bush referred to the recent attacks in London and Bali, and said that while
the bombings seemed random, "they serve a clear ideology, a set of beliefs that
are evil but not insane".

He conceded that al-Qaeda had evolved into a much looser network of terror
groups, which often acted autonomously but were united in their ambition to
overthrow moderate governments and establish a radical Islamic empire from Spain
to Indonesia.

Iraq, Mr Bush said, was now the main front in the war on terror, and the US
would not pull out. "Having removed a dictator and aided free peoples, we will
not stand by as a new set of killers, dedicated to the destruction of our own
country, seizes control of Iraq by violence," he said.

It was the most uncompromising statement on Iraq that Mr Bush has made for some
time, virtually committing American forces to the country until there was a
"complete victory".

He rejected the idea that extremism had been strengthened by the Iraq war,
taking issue with analysts who believe that the country has become a "melting
pot for jihadists from around the world", as the State Department's annual
report on terrorism put it this year. Leading Democrats said the speech had not
faced the most pressing issue facing the Bush Administration: a way out of Iraq
for US forces.

House minority leader Nancy Pelosi said Mr Bush was wrong to suggest Iraq was
the central front in the war on terror.

"The Administration has totally mismanaged the war in Iraq, and the President
has still not put forth a strategy for success there," she said. -- With
WASHINGTON POST

THE FOILED PLOTS

THE 10 al-Qaeda plots disrupted since the September 11 attacks, according to the
White House, were:

· WEST COAST AIRLINER In mid-2002, the US disrupted a plot to attack targets on
the west coast, including the Library Tower, the tallest building in Los
Angeles, using hijacked airliners. "The plotters included at least one major
operational planner involved in planning the events of 9/11."

· EAST COAST AIRLINER In mid-2003, the US and another country disrupted a plot
to attack targets on the east coast using hijacked commercial planes.

· JOSE PADILLA In May 2002, a plot that involved blowing up apartment buildings
in the United States was disrupted. One plotter, Padilla, also discussed the
possibility of using a "dirty bomb" in the United States.

· BRITISH URBAN TARGETS In mid-2004, the US and "another country" disrupted a
plot that involved urban targets in Britain and using explosives against a
variety of sites.

· KARACHI In the spring of 2003, the US and "another country" disrupted a plot
to attack Westerners at several targets in Karachi, Pakistan.

· HEATHROW AIRPORT In 2003, the US and "several partners" disrupted a plot to
attack London's Heathrow Airport using hijacked commercial airliners. The
planner for the attack was by a "major 9/11 operational figure".

· BRITAIN In the spring of 2004, the US and "partners" disrupted a plot to
conduct large-scale bombings in Britain.

· ARABIAN GULF SHIPPING In late 2002 and 2003, the US and "a partner nation"
disrupted a plot by al-Qaeda operatives to attack ships in the Arabian Gulf.

· STRAITS OF HORMUZ In 2002, the US "and partners" disrupted a plot to attack
ships in the Straits of Hormuz at the mouth of the Persian Gulf.

· TOURIST SITE In 2003, the US and "another country" disrupted a plot to attack
a tourist site outside the US.

LOAD-DATE: June 18, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                            October 8, 2005 Saturday
                              Late Edition - Final

Antiterrorism Officials Reveal New Details of 2002 Terror Plot

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

SECTION: Section A; Column 4; National Desk; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 440 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7


Government counterterrorism officials gave new details on Friday of what the
White House said was a foiled 2002 plot to fly hijacked airplanes into targets
on the West Coast, but their account suggested that the Bush administration
might not have understood the dimensions of the plot until two major terror
suspects were caught in 2003.

Both suspects, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and Riduan Isamuddin, better known as
Hambali, had been involved in plans for such an attack, they said.

President Bush referred obliquely to the planning in a speech on Thursday, when
he said the United States and its partners had stopped three potential attacks
on American soil, and seven more around the world. The White House cited it
later Thursday in a list of the 10 failed plots.

While several of those alleged plots had been disclosed before, officials said
that the 2002 effort had not been publicized until now. Another foiled plot, the
White House said, was aimed at East Coast cities in 2003.

The plan to attack Los Angeles appears to have grown out of a larger plan for
attacks on both coasts, not just New York and Washington, on Sept. 11, 2001.

As described by investigators on Friday -- in an account that parallels the
findings of the commission that investigated the 9/11 attacks -- Khalid Shaikh
Mohammed, the architect of the 9/11 plan, was told to delay parts of the broader
plan until later.

It is not clear how far any subsequent planning against Los Angeles advanced
after the attacks of Sept. 11, or exactly how it was headed off during the broad
international campaign against terrorists that ensued.

''It basically got subcontracted out to Jemaah Islamiyah,'' Mr. Isamuddin's
radical Islamic group based in Indonesia, said a senior counterterrorism
official, who had read an account of Mr. Mohammed's interrogation after his
capture in Pakistan in 2003. ''They found a pilot, and some others to overpower
the plane. But it never came together.'' One apparent target was the Library
Tower in Los Angeles, now known as the U.S. Bank Tower, but three
counterterrorism officials said they believed there were other targets in mind
as well.

All the officials interviewed about the plots declined to speak on the record,
because the White House had declassified a very limited amount of information to
substantiate Mr. Bush's statements. But a senior administration official
familiar with the case said the administration knew ''the plot had been
disrupted before'' Mr. Mohammed was captured in Pakistan in 2003. Mr. Isamuddin
was arrested that year in Thailand. ''But we didn't understand the details at
that time,'' the official said.

URL: http://www.nytimes.com

LOAD-DATE: October 8, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
