                             Windsor Star (Ontario)

                             April 23, 2013 Tuesday
                                 Final Edition

Plot to derail via train thwarted; Plan inspired by al Qaeda, two arrested

BYLINE: Dalson Chen, The Windsor Star And Postmedia News; With Files From The
Canadian Press

SECTION: NEWS; Dalson Chen; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 754 words


Two men supported by the terrorist group al Qaeda have been arrested and will
appear in court today for a plot to derail a Via passenger train, say the RCMP.

Investigators believe the two accused were in the process of targeting a route
in the Toronto area, officials told a news conference Monday.

"Had this plot been carried out, it would have resulted in innocent people being
killed or seriously injured," said Assistant Commissioner James Malizia of the
RCMP.

Chief Supt. Jennifer Strachan of the RCMP said the plan was interrupted "in the
planning stages."

Charged are: Chiheb Es-seghaier, 30, of Montreal, and Raed Jaser, 35, of
Toronto.

The suspects are not Canadian citizens but have been in the country legally for
a "considerable period of time."

They face an array of terrorism-related charges including: Conspiring to carry
out a terrorist attack and conspiring to murder persons for the benefit of a
terrorist group.

Investigators believe the two accused were receiving "direction and guidance"
from "al Qaeda elements" based in Iran, said Malizia. Officials said the plot
does not appear to be state-sponsored.

Esseghaier is from Tunisia, while Jaser is from the United Arab Emirates,
according to a senior law enforcement official and confirmed by Hussein Hamdani,
a Muslim community activist who attended a private RCMP de-briefing for leaders
in the Muslim community.

Esseghaier is an academic who conducted research in the area of nanotechnology.

Hamdani said authorities were first alerted to the alleged plot by a member of
the Muslim community.

Details about the plan are not being released.

Reuters reported the alleged plot targeted a passenger train arriving in Toronto
from New York City. The train that travels it is known as the Maple Leaf and is
operated in conjunction with Amtrak.

Chief Supt. Gaetan Courchesne of the RCMP said the execution of the plot was
"not imminent," but the plot represented "a real threat to kill people, to hurt
people," and damage the Canadian economy.

Officials at the news conference would not answer questions on how the suspects
entered in the country.

RCMP said the arrests were the result of an extensive and complex investigation
code-named Project Smooth.

A silver propeller plane carrying an alleged suspect touched down at
But-tonville Municipal Airport at 3: 20 p.m. on Monday. Two uniformed RCMP
officers emerged, followed by two other men carrying laptop bags. The apparent
accused appeared accompanied by another officer. He was in handcuffs and
shackles, blue jeans and sneakers, and wearing a windbreaker. He did not respond
to a reporter's shouted questions.

The suspect was bundled into a black Chevy Suburban with tinted windows and
whisked from the tarmac.

The arrests come at a time of heightened public concern over terrorism following
the bombings in Boston as well as recent revelations over the involvement of
radicalized Canadian youths in overseas terrorist groups.

Public Safety Minister Vic Toews said the investigation was an example of solid
police work and co-operation among the RCMP, CSIS and other police.

"Our government will continue to be vigilant and take the steps necessary to
protect Canadians and their families, and our allies who share our common
values," said Toews.

"Canadians can be assured that our government will stand firm in our commitment
to protecting this country from terrorists and the fear they hope to generate."

David Jacobson, the U.S. ambassador to Canada, issued a statement congratulating
the RCMP.

"These arrests were the result of extensive cross-border co-operation, which is
the hallmark of our relationship.

"Dedicated professionals on both sides of the border brought these arrests to
fruition, and I thank them for their service and hard work.

"This is an example of the United States and Canada working together to protect
our citizens. It underscores the fact that we face serious and real threats, and
that security is a shared responsibility. We all need to remain vigilant in
confronting threats and keeping North America safe and secure."

Along with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, the investigation involved the
efforts and co-operation of the Canadian Security Intelligence Service, the
Canada Border Services Agency, the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation and
police agencies in Toronto and Montreal.

The RCMP encouraged members of the public to bring "any suspicious activities"
to the attention of authorities via the National Security Information Network
(1-800-420-5805 or email nsin_ risn@rcmp-grc.gc.ca).

LOAD-DATE: April 23, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Monday, leaves Toronto's Union Station - the heart of Via Rail travel. The RCMP
say they have foiled a plot to derail a Via train.; Chris Young, The Canadian
Press;  RCMP officers stand outside a Toronto home of one of the two men accused
of plotting a terror attack on a rail target Monday. Details are not being
released.;

                              Late Edition - Final

Lincoln In Peril

SECTION: Section BR; Column 0; Book Review Desk; LETTERS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 407 words


To the Editor:

Greg Tobin mentions several cinematic depictions of Lincoln in his review of
Daniel Stashower's ''Hour of Peril: The Secret Plot to Murder Lincoln Before the
Civil War'' (Feb. 17), but he might have noted the 1951 movie ''The Tall
Target,'' which is also about an attempt to assassinate Lincoln on the way to
his first inauguration.

Dick Powell plays a New York City police detective who breaks up the plot. The
filmmakers borrowed his name from the New York police superintendent who helped
protect Lincoln -- John Kennedy.

STEVEN A. KINGNew York

To the Editor:

''The Hour of Peril'' gives too much credit to Allan Pinkerton for persuading
Lincoln to travel through Baltimore clandestinely to avoid the assassination
plot. In fact, upon hearing all the details of the plot provided by Pinkerton,
Lincoln was not convinced. It was a visit that same evening, Feb. 21, 1861, by
the son of Senator William H. Seward, that caused the president-elect to travel
earlier than scheduled, and in disguise, through Baltimore to Washington.
Seward's son provided corroborative information on the plot supplied to Seward
by Charles P. Stone, the inspector general of the District of Columbia. Stone
obtained the information from his own investigation of secessionist
organizations in both Baltimore and Washington. He had used experienced
detectives borrowed from the superintendent of the New York City Police.

Lincoln's uncertainty about Pinkerton's reporting may well have been based on
Pinkerton's well-known habit of embellishing his capabilities and achievements.
He and Lincoln had worked in the same railroad business circles, Pinkerton as a
detective and Lincoln as an attorney. A further indicator of Lincoln's distrust
of Pinkerton's professionalism was his subsequent rejection of Pinkerton's offer
to serve as the Union's intelligence chief a few months later.

KENNETH A. DAIGLERWashington

To the Editor:

Greg Tobin's review of ''The Hour of Peril'' lauds Allan Pinkerton as a ''real
hero'' for developing intelligence that suggested an assassination plan was
afoot. Soon thereafter, in 1862, Pinkerton provided terrible intelligence to
Gen. George McClellan, grossly overestimating the size of Confederate forces he
faced at the Seven Days' Battles on the Virginia peninsula. This encouraged
McClellan's caution, resulting in a humiliating and damaging Union defeat, and
made a hero out of Robert E. Lee.

RICH McINTYRESun Valley, Idaho

URL: http://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/03/books/review/lincoln-in-peril.html

LOAD-DATE: March 3, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Letter

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company


                              95 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 January 15, 1995, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

HERS;
Exit Laughing

BYLINE: By PATRICIA VOLK;   Patricia Volk is a writer who lives in New York.

SECTION: Section 6;  Page 21;  Column 1;  Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1063 words


MY MOTHER CALLS TO TELL ME she doesn't want the plots. At first I think she's
saying plotz.

"We live in Florida now," she says. "It doesn't make sense to be buried in
Westchester."

The family plot. My grandmother loved it. "The view!" Nana would say, visiting
it Sundays. "Have you ever in your life seen such a view?"

"Anyway, I've decided," Mom says. "I'm signing them over to you."

"I have to be buried by myself?"

"There are four plots," she says firmly. "You have two. Your cousin Joan has
two."

"Joanie? I only see her Thanksgiving!"

We laugh. A week later, the deed to Plot 034, Section 24 comes in the mail.

Down in Florida over Christmas, my mother takes me shopping. She's discovered
it's easier to drop bombs in the car when she's looking straight ahead. "You got
my letter?" she says, tooling down Palmetto.

"If this is about the plots again, Ma, I don't want the plots. I've decided. I'm
getting cremated."

"What?"

I remind her of the last time Dad took me to see his father's grave in Brooklyn.
Jacob Volk's stone was listing. The plot was overgrown. Swastikas were sprayed
all over the place, and every piece of glass that protected the photographs on
the headstones was smashed. I remind her how somebody had Granny Ethel exhumed
and moved next to Great-Aunt Ettie, who was buried with two decks of cards so
they could play in the afterlife.

"I'm going to be cremated, Ma. No one's going to vandalize my grave."

"Still," she says, "the thought of it. . . ."

I tell her about my friend Madeline, who keeps her parents in matching urns in
the basement. She waves to them every time she does the wash.

My mother cracks up. What I really want to say is: You can't die until I can't
make you smile.

"I checked out the local crematorium down here," she says a few weeks later. "I
asked the fellow if I could see how it's done. He said no one had ever asked him
that before. I had to explain I didn't want to actually watch, I just wanted to
make sure the place was nice. You know me -- I like people to be comfortable."
We howl.

Saul Bellow calls death "the dark side of the mirror that allows it to reflect
life." This is no surprise coming from the man who wrote "Mr. Sammler's Planet."
But that's Saul Bellow, and these are my parents. I've always had my parents. I
can't imagine not being able to pick up the phone and talk to them. Should I be
trying to? Why is my mother thinking about death so much? Just because she's in
her 70's? She just got her master's and has a nice practice, so what's with all
this death talk?

I check out the books on my night stand. There's Ellen Currie's "Moses
Supposes," which opens with a story about a man who suspects his father is
suicidal. There's the insomniac's companion, the "1989 Guinness Book of World
Records," which lists 10 categories under Death. (Tonga has the lowest death
rate.) There's "A Doctor's Visit," by Chekhov, whose death in Badenweiler,
Germany, at age 44 is fictionalized in the last book, "Where I'm Calling From,"
by Raymond Carver. What's going on? All these books about death? Everything I'm
reading now is about death?

I go into the living room and look at the shelf where I keep the books that
churn my heart. There's Nathanael West, Dostoyevsky, Virginia Woolf, William
Kennedy, Louise Erdrich, Don DeLillo, Joyce Cary, Toni Morrison and Bruce
Chatwin. So I look at my Paris-in-the-30's shelf, and there's Hemingway, Joyce,
Fitzgerald, Jean Rhys, Ford Maddox Ford and Gertrude Stein. So I look at my
Southern shelf, and there's O'Connor, Welty, McCullers, all of Walker Percy and
Faulkner. Is it possible that death informs everything? Are we born, as Beckett
wrote, "astride the grave"? I decide to find one book, any book, that doesn't
have to do with death. There are two: "Basic Italian" and "The Films of Mae
West."

Studying the slim, chestnut-haired 20-year-old in the photo Mom has always kept
on her dresser, I ask if Dad still looks like that to her.

"He seems just like the day I met him," she says.

Sitting on his patio, overlooking a lake, my father says: "This isn't a bad last
view, is it? This isn't a bad way to go."

"Where'ya going?" I say.

Knock wood, ward off the evil eye, I can't picture anything happening to them.
They both love their work. They both play killer tennis. They've both had
run-ins with scary things, but what does that mean? Most people I know would be
dead if it wasn't for modern medicine.

"We're not afraid to die," they've told me. "There comes a time when you're
ready. We couldn't have imagined that at your age either."

Sometimes I see myself at my father's funeral. Gripping both sides of the
lectern, I pause the way Dad would. I develop eye contact. Then I launch into
the one about the man who tells his wife he wants his ashes scattered in
Bloomingdale's so he can be sure she'll come visit. The idea that something
could happen to them won't seem real until it has to. Why should it? What good
does it do to taint the present with the inevitable?

The elevator door slams. I get the mail. There's a letter from the university I
went to asking to be remembered in my will. There's a bulletin from the Authors
Guild; they'd like something too. There are bills, magazines -- and what's this
from Florida?

RE: Florida Statute 765.05 -- Living Wills

I, Audrey Volk, willfully and voluntarily make known my desire that my dying not
be artificially prolonged under the circumatances set forth below. . . .

I consider the misspelling. Is this document valid? I'm supposed to let my
mother go?

I punch her number. "Ma? I got your present today."

Silence.

"I wanted to get you a Hallmark card. Something appropriate like:

Your living will means lots to me.

A gift that suits me to a T.

Or maybe:

You gave me life!

I help you die!

You're as sweet as

Apple pie!"

We laugh. Hurtling toward the apocalypse, we gasp for air. After we hang up, I
start flipping through the magazines. Right there, in a column called What's
Hot, is an item about a man in the town my parents moved to. He's bringing
mummification back. Prices go from $7,700 for your basic linen wrap to $150,000
for a jeweled sarcophagus. I send it off. Mom will get a kick out of it. I can
hear her laughing now. Meanwhile, know anyone interested in prime Westchester
real estate, one six-hundredth of an acre, nicely landscaped, riv vu?

LOAD-DATE: January 15, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Drawing

                              July 28, 2006 Friday

Farm Briefs

SECTION: MONEY; Pg. C2

LENGTH: 294 words


Field day set

FLANAGAN - The Flanagan Agriculture Advisory Committee will hold its 2006
Flanagan FFA Field Day on Aug. 7. This year's events will be at the Gary Collins
family plot, located south of Graymont, south of the intersection of roads 800E
and 1400 North on the west side of road 800 E.

The 2006 Flanagan FFA plot program includes three locations, with 46 varieties
from 23 companies included in each plot.

The event begins at 6 p.m. at the Collins plot, with a tour of the plot
varieties. Dealers and/or district representatives from the companies
represented will be on hand to review their varieties. At 7:15 p.m. at the
Collins shop, there will be a short program by Steve Schwoerer on the High Trail
Wind Farm in McLean County. Dinner will be served at 8 p.m.

For more information contact Dan Faber at (815) 796-2291.

Lindgren wins

ATLANTA - At the 2006 American Gelbvieh Junior Association Prairie Classic,
Jessica Lindgren of Atlanta earned Champion Bred and Owner Balancer Female with
JLNG Sugar Creek Debbie, a March heifer sired by WFF Forever Right Time.

She also received the 2006 Earl Buss Memorial Scholarship.

The event was held July 9-14 at Sioux Falls, S.D.

Moritz places fourth

Justin Moritz of Piper City placed fourth in the 40th annual National Junior
Angus Showmanship Contest held July 14-15 in conjunction with the National
Junior Angus Show in Indianapolis, Ind.

Junior Angus exhibitors from 26 states competed for the title of top showman
during the event. The contest was sponsored in part by the American Angus
Auxiliary and Andis Clippers.

                              97 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                     May 25, 1996, Saturday, Final Edition

Vegetable Vigilante; Gardener Roots Out a Pilferer, but Pinching Of Produce
Remains a Problem at Area Plots

Patricia Davis, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A01

LENGTH: 1168 words


For more than two years, Pat Grebe tried to catch the thieves stealing
vegetables from her community garden plot in Reston. Hoping to nab them
red-handed, she booby-trapped her eggplants, smearing them with a mixture of
Vaseline and red food-coloring. When that didn't work, she went undercover.

Finally, after hiding with her camera in the bushes at Baron Cameron Park for
hours at a time, Grebe, a computer programmer, got the evidence she needed. It
was an inside job. A park official confronted Grebe's gardening neighbor, shown
in the photographs picking someone else's mint, and evicted the woman and her
husband from their plot.

But the plot thickens.

"It started all over again, although this time it was worse than before," said
Grebe, 37. "They dug up my dahlias. They dug up my herb plants. They even dug up
someone's rosebushes. Then they started taking things that took time. They took
my black-eyed peas."

Now, as a new growing season begins, Grebe and her fellow gardeners are
preparing for the worst. Fences around garden plots have grown taller this year,
locks and chains stronger.

But Reston is not the only place to suffer purloined peppers and pilfered
potatoes. As community gardens have sprouted all over the Washington area, as
waiting lists for garden plots have grown by the hundreds, a new kind of crime
has cropped up: plant-napping.

Although some community gardeners suffer only the occasional vandalism -- the
kid teeing off on tomatoes with a golf club, the sweaty soccer player swiping a
watermelon -- others have seen all their hard labor lost.

It happened to Scott Ray last summer when he invited friends to his Capitol Hill
home for a big pan of homemade eggplant Parmesan. When Ray, a federal
prosecutor, went to harvest the Italian eggplants in his community garden, he
discovered that his whole crop was gone.

"It was heartbreaking," Ray said. "What was amazing was how the thief waited
until they were just at the peak of ripeness. I knew that because I had checked
them the night before. They came in under the cover of darkness. I was totally
shocked and appalled that someone would steal vegetables. That is low."

Jim Dewing, who recently stepped down after 10 years as gardening coordinator
for the Fairfax County park system, watched his turf grow to 800 plots. And the
number of missing-vegetable reports kept climbing.

"They'll call saying, 'Somebody cleaned out my tomatoes or dug up all my
potatoes or picked all my peas,' " Dewing said. "Last season was the worst. I'm
sure there are few things that anger you more than getting ready to harvest and
seeing your garden stripped clean."

The gardening empire in Fairfax is the largest in the Washington area, but
community garden programs also are booming in Arlington, Montgomery and Prince
George's counties, Alexandria and Washington.

In Fairfax, it's one of the best deals in town: $ 30 a year to rent a piece of
some of the most expensive real estate in the nation. Most people cultivate the
20-by-30-foot plots as a hobby, Dewing said, but many others rely on their plots
as their main source of food.

When the county began letting people work in the plots year-round about two
years ago, Dewing noticed that people "sort of adopted them as their own,"
adding personal touches such as windmills and bird feeders.

After many of the 32 plots at Baron Cameron Park were raided last year, Dewing
tightened the gardening rules, spelling out that "renters may not trespass on,
pick vegetables from, or otherwise affect, alter or disturb other garden plots."
Mesh fences, used before to keep out four-legged animals, were allowed to reach
new human heights of up to six feet.

One of the victims at Baron Cameron was an elderly man who donates his
vegetables to a local fire station, other gardeners recalled. He lost his giant
zucchini, the one he was going to enter in a contest.

"I came out that morning and he was really brokenhearted," said Mark Wayt, a
construction worker who drives in from Loudoun County to the Reston park. "It
was pumpkin-size."

"More like a watermelon," said his wife, Donna Wayt, a phone company employee,
looking up from her digging in the blazing sun.

Gardeners are not just sitting back on their rototillers, though. When Mark Wayt
discovered a row of beans missing, he confronted the suspect, telling her that
he had found some footprints and was calling the police to have them analyzed.
He was bluffing, but the woman admitted she'd been in his garden -- just
looking, she said.

Gary Hofmaster, 60, has more trouble with potato beetles than two-legged
predators at his plot in Baron Cameron. That's because he harvests his
vegetables as soon as they shoot out of the ground, said Hofmaster, a Defense
Mapping Agency employee. And he hides some plants, such as squash, in his corn.

Paul Kovalsky, who after two years on a waiting list finally landed a plot in
the Woodburn community garden in Annandale, said he already has been warned by
his neighbors that his vegetables might be lifted.

"That's one of my fears. But if people are that desperate, they can have it,"
said Kovalsky, 49, who was digging in his garden this week in his dress shirt
and tie after work.

Athena McCorkle, who recently took over Dewing's coordinator job, said an
informal Garden Watch has sprung up throughout Fairfax. Gardeners call her to
report sightings of strangers in their neighbors' plots.

Gina Roman, the garden-plot coordinator for Gaithersburg, which has 81 plots and
no vacancies, also urges gardeners to keep an eye out for each other.

"The gardeners will call me and say they had a nice green pepper that they were
just babying along and someone took it the next day," Roman said. "The
temptation is always there for someone to pluck that red, ripe tomato."

So far, they haven't seen anything quite like what happened last year at Baron
Cameron in Fairfax, where whole rows of vegetables were stripped and dormant
rosebushes yanked out, root balls and all.

Grebe and other gardeners went to Dewing to see what could be done to stop it.
He was sympathetic but told them he would need evidence before he could take any
action. So Grebe headed to the bushes with a camera.

She waited there after work and on weekends, watching for the fellow gardener
she suspected was helping herself to others' ripe vegetables. The gardeners had
noticed a pattern. When the suspect's plot was harvested, so were theirs.

Late last summer, Grebe caught the woman on film in three gardens. She took the
photographs to Dewing -- "she had a whole boatload," he said -- and he took
action. She returned to her cabbage and her squash, thinking her ordeal was
finally over. But the raids on her plot resumed in the fall, and this time Grebe
has no idea who's responsible.

"They take your biggest, they take your best and you're left with whatever they
can't carry," Grebe said. "This year, instead of a fence, I wanted to put land
mines in."


LOAD-DATE: May 28, 1996May 25, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo, james m. thresher, Pat Grebe plants flowers at her Reston
community plot, where she resorted to surveillance to catch a thief.  Pat Grebe
works her plot in the community garden at Baron Cameron Park, in Reston, where a
six-foot fence is designed to keep out vegetable thieves.

                           Edmonton Journal (Alberta)

                     January 4, 2000 Tuesday Final Edition

Two Algerians arrested as bomb plot investigated: Authorities search for
connections to Ahmed Ressam

SOURCE: New York Times News Service

SECTION: World; Pg. A5

LENGTH: 394 words

Two Algerians, one in Brooklyn, N.Y., and the other in Seattle, have been
arrested in the continuing investigation of a terrorist bomb plot.

The new arrests came amid indications that federal authorities are focusing
their efforts on a network of Algerians in New York, Seattle and Boston,
officials said Monday.

The Brooklyn man, Abdelwahib Hamdouche, was taken into custody Saturday night at
Kennedy International Airport as he was preparing to leave for Paris on a KLM
flight, officials said.

Hamdouche, 34, a naturalized French citizen, was held as a material witness in
the bomb plot investigation, and it is believed that he was ordered to remain in
custody after a closed hearing Monday in U.S. District Court in Manhattan.

In Seattle, authorities said they had arrested another Algerian man, Abdel Hakim
Tizegha, on charges of entering the country illegally. He is believed to be an
associate of a man charged last week in the bomb plot, law enforcement officials
said, but he has not been accused of any direct role.

The new arrests on both coasts stem from what the authorities said was a bomb
plot foiled in Seattle last month after the arrest of Ahmed Ressam, an Algerian
linked to a terrorist group. Ressam was charged with trying to smuggle powerful
explosives and sophisticated timing devices in a car he was driving across the
Canadian border near Seattle.

While the scope of the investigation into the plot appeared to be growing, many
details of the case remained murky Monday. It was not clear why the authorities
believed Hamdouche was a witness. It was also not known why he had been released
without being charged after he was taken into custody last Thursday during a
raid in Brooklyn in which another Algerian, Abdel Ghani, was arrested on charges
of being an accomplice in the bomb plot.

A criminal complaint accused Ghani of having knowledge of "a terrorist network
of Algerian nationals" that also included Ressam, and said that he had planned
to travel with Ressam to Chicago to raise money for the group.

After Monday's closed hearing, neither federal prosecutor, David N. Kelley, nor
Hamdouche's lawyer, Mitchell A. Golub, would comment.

Federal Magistrate Judge Michael H. Dolinger refused a request by The New York
Times to open the session, and afterward, he would not say why he had conducted
it in secret.

                              99 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                   USA TODAY

                            February 20, 2017 Monday
                                 FIRST EDITION

Are you ready for the Oscars?

SECTION: LIFE; Pg. 2D

LENGTH: 552 words


Still working your way through the Academy Awards best-picture nominees? USA
TODAY's watched them all to help you prioritize. The Oscars are Sunday  (ABC, 7
p.m. ET/4 PT).

ARRIVAL

****

Plot: A linguistics expert (Amy Adams) is tasked with deciphering messages from
alien visitors.

Director: Denis Villeneuve

Rating: PG-13

Upside: It's a supremely crafted, well-acted and thought-provoking exploration
of humanity.

Downside: Most every other recent sci-fi movie looks pedestrian in comparison.

FENCES

***1/2

Plot: A Pittsburgh garbage

man (Denzel Washington) finds success at work but increasing tension at home.

Director: Denzel Washington

Rating: PG-13

Upside:  Washington and co-star Viola Davis give powerhouse, award-ready
performances.

Downside: It's more filmed play than movie, so it doesn't feel cinematic in
scope.

HACKSAW RIDGE

***

Plot: A devout young man

(Andrew Garfield) enlists in the Army during World War II yet won't touch a gun.

Director: Mel Gibson

Rating: R

Upside: Gibson's latest is a brutally intense and elegantly crafted war drama.

Downside: The film wrestles with overt preachiness and

military-movie clichés.

HELL OR HIGH WATER

***

Plot: Two West Texas brothers (Ben Foster, Chris Pine) brazenly rob the branches
of a bank foreclosing on their family's land.

Director: David Mackenzie

Rating: R

Upside: An excellent Jeff Bridges is in his element as a Texas Ranger pursuing
the crooks.

Downside: The Western noir could be a little more subtle in its exploration of
modern economic decline.

HIDDEN FIGURES

***1/2

Plot: Three mathematicians (Taraji P. Henson, Octavia Spencer and Janelle Monáe)
overcome racial and gender inequality to help America in the space race.

Director: Theodore Melfi

Rating: PG

Upside: The film  has a strong cast as well as heady themes of civil rights.

Downside: The space drama sometimes takes the focus off the three stars'
magnetic chemistry.

LION

***1/2

Plot: Two decades after being separated  from his family, a young Australian man
(Dev Patel) plots a path back home to India.

Director: Garth Davis

Rating: PG-13

Upside: Patel and newcomer Sunny Pawar give strong performances as older and
younger versions of Saroo Brierley.

Downside: The ending couldn't be more emotionally manipulative, though it's
forgivable.

MANCHESTER  BY THE SEA

****

Plot: A handyman (Casey Affleck) is forced to confront a past tragedy when he's
named sole guardian of his nephew (Lucas Hedges).

Director: Kenneth Lonergan

Rating: R

Upside: Affleck and Hedges are tops among an all-around extraordinary cast.

Downside: Parents will find one scene hard to watch because of the subject
matter.

MOONLIGHT

****

Plot: A three-act character study that follows the life of a gay black man from
struggling child to intimidating adult.

Director: Barry Jenkins

Rating: R

Upside: The drama is supremely well-acted and beautifully captures the intimate
evolution of its main character.

Downside: The middle act, while very good, doesn't rise to the exceptional
levels of the film's beginning and end.

LA LA LAND

****

Plot: An aspiring actress (Emma Stone) and a jazz pianist (Ryan Gosling) fall in
love while trying to make their dreams come true.

Director: Damien Chazelle

Rating: PG-13

Upside: The movie revisits the Hollywood musical in joyous and dazzling fashion.

Downside: Not for grinches who don't like good tunes and Broadway-style
showstoppers.

                                   USA TODAY

                      July 2, 1993, Friday, FIRST EDITION

U.S. reportedly will detain Muslim cleric

BYLINE: Jack Kelley; Sandra Sanchez

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 362 words


Justice Department officials have decided to take Sheik Omar Abdel-Rahman into
custody but will not charge him in connection with a plot to bomb U.N.
headquarters and other sites, media reports said.

"The pressure has been building," says William Lewis, George Washington
University Middle East expert. "He's more than just a force of agitation."

Rahman, 55, is a blind Islamic cleric. Some of his followers were charged with
the Feb. 26 World Trade Center bombing and last month's plot to bomb the United
Nations and other New York landmarks. He'll be held on immigration charges, ABC,
CBS and The Associated Press reported. Justice officials refused comment.

Other news reports say government investigators have secretly recorded tapes
indicating Rahman had prior knowledge of the bombing plots.

U.S. officials let Rahman into the country in 1990 by mistake. He was granted
permanent residency in April 1992, but that was revoked in March 1992. He's
appealing.

Nine people have been arrested in the plot, and the sheik has acknowledged that
the man the FBI says was the group's ringleader acted as his interpreter.

Also Thursday, a prosecutor said the nine considered bombing the George
Washington Bridge. - Jack Kelley

LOTTO MANIA: Michigan's School Aid Fund got a bonus as no one came forward to
claim an $ 18 million Lotto jackpot - the largest unclaimed prize since the
state's lottery began in 1972. The winning ticket was purchased July 1, 1992, at
a 7-Eleven store in Hillsdale. In Florida, the winner of a $ 29.1 million
jackpot has not come forward. The winner has 180 days from last Saturday's
drawing to turn in the ticket. And Georgia officials reported first-day sales of
a lottery that started Tuesday reached $ 10 million.

LIFE 'LESSONS': William Kennedy Smith, acquitted of rape in 1991, says his life
is back to normal. "I think I have more perspective - it's so easy to lose,"
Smith told the Albuquerque Journal. "I do take lessons from my experiences, but
I try not to get wrapped up in an endless cycle of analysis." Also, The
Washington Post reports Smith's lawyer, Roy Black, is dating Lea Haller, a juror
from the trial.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Nationline

THE NATION; FROM USA TODAY'S NATIONAL NEWS NETWORK

                      Copyright 1993 Gannett Company, Inc.


                             101 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             The Gazette (Montreal)

                              July 9, 2010 Friday
                                 Final Edition

Three found guilty in suicide bomb plot; Rare third trial. Britons linked to
cell targeting U.S. flights

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A18

LENGTH: 327  words

DATELINE: LONDON


Three Britons were convicted yesterday of plotting to murder hundreds of people
in suicide bombings after being recruited by an Al-Qa'ida-inspired cell bent on
blowing up transatlantic airliners bound for North America.

The three men, who recorded martyrdom videos threatening waves of attacks
against Britain and the United States, worked with the gang that planned to
bring down planes with homemade liquid bombs.

Their conviction follows one of Britain's biggest counter-terrorism
investigations and a series of trials around a plot that prosecutors said could
have been on the same scale as the 9-11 attacks.

Twelve people have now been convicted in connection with the plot that led to
extra security checks at airports worldwide and tight restrictions on passengers
carrying liquids onto planes.

The three convicted yesterday had faced two previous trials in 2008 and 2009. A
jury at their first trial failed to agree a verdict. They were acquitted at the
second trial of knowing that the plot was targeting planes.

Prosecutors made the unusual decision to push for a third trial where the three
faced a broader charge of conspiracy to murder, replacing the previous charge of
plotting to kill people on airliners.

Ibrahim Savant, Arafat Waheed Khan and Waheed Zaman were convicted by a jury at
Woolwich Crown Court, east London, and will be sentenced today. They face a
maximum sentence of life imprisonment.

The court heard how the plot involved smuggling liquid bombs in soft drink
bottles onto planes bound for North America. A team of suicide bombers planned
to assemble and detonate the hydrogen peroxide devices in mid-air.

The plot's ringleader, Abdulla Ahmed Ali, identified seven flights to San
Francisco, Toronto, Montreal, Washington, New York and Chicago that left London
within 21/2 hours of each other. Ali was jailed for life last September.

In the latest trial, the jury rejected the men's defence that the plot was part
of an elaborate publicity stunt.

LOAD-DATE: July 9, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Crime

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


 Copyright 2010 The Gazette, a division of CanWest MediaWorks Publication Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                             102 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                   USA TODAY

                             August 6, 2013 Tuesday
                                 CHASE EDITION

Top al-Qaeda leaders tied to terror threat;
Analyst: Group likely to return to disrupted plot

BYLINE: Oren Dorell and David Jackson, USA TODAY,

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5A

LENGTH: 786 words


The shutdown of U.S. embassies and a warning to American tourists came in
response to an intercepted message between top al-Qaeda figures about a possible
weekend attack, U.S. officials said. Some terror analysts say the plot may still
be active.

News organizations reported that electronic communications were intercepted
between Ayman al-Zawahri, who succeeded Osama bin Laden as the head of al-Qaeda,
and Nasir al-Wuhayshi, the head of al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP).

The intercept was significant and surprising, because it's rare that top
al-Qaeda leaders are caught discussing a specific plot or the timing, officials
said. Zawahri was in Pakistan and Wuhayshi in Yemen, but the intercepts did not
reveal the specific location or target.

The U.S. shut down 20 embassies and consulates in the Middle East and Africa
through Saturday.

The Obama administration's decision may have disrupted an al-Qaeda terrorist
plot, but that doesn't mean the terrorists will abandon their plans for good, a
terrorism expert says.

"These types of plots -- they get disrupted, and sometimes the hit squads are
called up. Sometimes they get folded into another operation in the future," said
Thomas Joscelyn, a terrorism analyst at the Foundation for the Defense of
Democracies. In the long term, however, "al-Qaeda doesn't give up on plans," he
said.

The Oct. 12, 2000, suicide bombing of the USS Cole occurred after a failed
attempt against the USS The Sullivans in January of that year. The destruction
of the twin towers of the World Trade Center in 2001 came after a previous
attempt to destroy one of the World Trade Center buildings in 1993, with a truck
bomb.

"When they have plans on the books, if they think they're good plans, they come
back to them," Joscelyn said.

The State Department said the closures of embassies and consulates were out of
an "abundance of caution" and not an "indication of a new threat."

White House spokesman Jay Carney said the U.S. faces "an ongoing threat from
al-Qaeda and its affiliates," and he singled out AQAP.

Carney said that although al-Qaeda has been "diminished" as a global force,
"affiliate organizations ... have strengthened."

In the U.S., New York City said it was increasing security at some landmarks and
houses of worship in response to he warnings. Some airports, such as Boston's
Logan Airport, boosted security, but other major airports, including Atlanta and
San Francisco, said they have not.

The Transportation Security Administration had not implemented or requested new
security measures, according to airline officials.

For the United States to shut down so many diplomatic facilities over such a
large geographical area means U.S. intelligence officials believe the plans they
came across "had some likelihood of success, meaning there's been surveillance,
reconnaissance, (and) teams have infiltrated to where they need to be," said
Mark Jacobson, a senior fellow at the German Marshall Fund. "So, if it's this
serious, this is something that's been in the works for a while," said Jacobson,
former deputy NATO representative in Afghanistan from 2009 to 2011.

The New York Times reported Monday that the closures were in response to
intercepted communications between Zawahri and Wuhayshi. At the request of
senior U.S. intelligence officials, the Times said it had withheld their
identities from an article posted online Friday and published Saturday. However,
McClatchy Newspapers disclosed the names Sunday, and the Times then followed
suit after the Obama administration dropped its objections.

"This was significant because it was the big guys talking, and talking about
very specific timing for an attack or attacks," one unnamed U.S. official told
the Times.

Citing a U.S. intelligence official and a Middle East diplomat, the Associated
Press reported Monday that Zawahri's message was picked up several weeks ago.
The threat appeared initially aimed at targets in Yemen but was expanded to
include U.S. or other Western sites abroad.

Intelligence sources told NBC News that Zawahri and Wuhayshi "wanted to do
something big" this past Sunday, an Islamic holiday commemorating the 27th night
of Ramadan and the day the Quran was revealed to the prophet Mohammed.

CBS News carried a similar report, also pegged to unidentified sources, that the
pair were discussing "something big" connected to Ramadan, which ends Thursday.

The new embassies ordered to shut down through Saturday include facilities in
central and east Africa, including the capitals of Burundi and Rwanda.
Authorities also closed a third site in Saudi Arabia.

A worldwide travel alert remains in effect until Aug. 31.

Contributing: Charisse Jones in New York; Sarah Lynch in Cairo; the Associated
Press

LOAD-DATE: August 6, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

            Intelligencer Journal/New Era (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

                             March 29, 2013 Friday

Garden Plots Available To Rent At Lancaster County Central Park

SECTION: B; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 152  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


The Lancaster County Department of Parks and Recreation again is renting garden
plots for the season, which will run from April 15 through Oct. 15.

The public can apply for a plot at the park office, 1050 Rockford Road, or call
299-8215. Office hours are weekdays from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.

County residents can select either a 20-foot-by-20-foot or 20-foot-by-40-foot
plot. Renters pay a one-time fee of $20 for a small plot and $25 for a larger
plot.

The garden plots are along Farm View Drive just off Golf Road in Lancaster
County Central Park.

Gardeners of all skill levels can rent garden plots to grow their own flowers
and vegetables. The plots are ideal for gardeners with limited space at home and
for groups looking for a summer project. Organic plots also are available. These
are plots that have been free of pesticides and herbicides for several years.

For more information, visit lancastercountyparks.org.

LOAD-DATE: March 30, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2013 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                             104 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                 Ottawa Citizen

                      January 4, 2004 Sunday Final Edition

Hijack plot targeted U.S. nuclear sites: Informant's warning of attacks led to
terror alert, flight cancellations

SOURCE: The Times, London, The Washington Post with files from The Associated
Press

BYLINE: David Leppard and Dipesh Gadher

SECTION: News; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 1135 words

A Sept. 11-style suicide terrorist plot to hijack several passenger jets
simultaneously and crash them into high-profile American targets has been
uncovered by security services.

New York City, Washington, D.C., and nuclear power stations on the country's
East Coast are said to have been among the terrorists' potential targets, the
Times of London is reporting today. The plot explains the grounding of 10
U.S.-bound flights across the world over the seasonal break.

According to a senior intelligence source, an informant tipped off authorities
the weekend before Christmas. He claimed that Islamic extremists intended to
hijack flights operated by British Airways, Air France and AeroMexico. The Times
reports that the plot was hatched by al-Qaeda, the terror group behind the Sept.
11, 2001, attacks on the United States.

The informant said that as well as targeting Washington, D.C., New York City and
Los Angeles, the terrorists were planning to launch a strike on an oil terminal
in Valdez, Alaska. The informant named specific routes and flight numbers,
including British Airways 223, as part of the hijack plot. A CIA assessment of
the information subsequently identified nuclear plants on the East Coast as
possible targets.

It is understood that intercepts of communications between known terrorist
suspects also suggested the significant risk of an attack.

Detailed security checks were conducted on all U.S.-bound flights operated by
the three carriers after the intelligence emerged about the alleged plot. All
passenger lists were cross-checked against an FBI watchlist of known terrorist
suspects.

As a result, 10 U.S.-bound flights were grounded: two British Airways flights to
Washington, D.C., two AeroMexico flights from Mexico City to L.A., and six Air
France flights from Paris to L.A.

At least three other flights were escorted into American airports by F16 fighter
jets, and one Mexican airliner was even forced to turn back in mid-air. British
Airways also grounded two flights to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, which were due to fly
on Dec. 31 and yesterday. It is understood these cancellations related to
separate intelligence relating to a potential surface-to-air missile attack on a
British carrier.

Flight 223, British Airways' service to Washington, D.C., was finally given
security clearance to fly yesterday after being cancelled for two days running.

Flight 223 finally lifted off from Heathrow Airport just after 1 p.m. EST
yesterday -- more than three hours late, the airline said. British Airways said
the last-minute delay in the flight -- which had earlier received the all-clear
from Britain's Department for Transport -- was due to security checks.

Yesterday, intelligence sources yesterday confirmed the cancellation of the 10
U.S.-bound services was triggered by information provided by an informant
"outside the U.S." The warning was of an imminent attack on American soil.

On the same weekend the intelligence was received from the informant, U.S.
Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge raised the security threat faced by U.S.
citizens to "code orange," the second-highest level. He said the country faced
the risk of a terror strike which "could either rival or exceed" Sept. 11, 2001.

All passengers lists on the jets believed to be potential targets were checked.
The port of Valdez was put on high alert and the transfer of oil to tankers was
subsequently suspended.

Some of the passengers listed on Air France flights to L.A. appeared to match
suspects on the terror watchlist and six flights were cancelled on Christmas Eve
and Christmas Day. One person who had a similar name to a Tunisian terrorist
turned out to be a five-year-old child.

However, French security officials insisted the decision to ground the planes
was taken on the basis of "significant intelligence." One of the passengers who
failed to turn up for the flight was a trained pilot from the Middle East who
has since fled and cannot be traced, according to U.S. intelligence sources.

Checks on British passenger lists revealed other apparent matches with names on
the terror watchlist, but none is thought to have been confirmed. Matches are
not uncommon because of the similarity of many Arabic names.

Yesterday, passengers checking in for BA flight 223 to Washington Dulles airport
said they were not deterred by the security alert surrounding the service. One
passenger, Ralph Hodgson, 58, said: "I've absolutely no worries at all ... about
getting on this flight. I think if anything's going to happen, if your number's
called, then your number's going to be called."

But the passengers were forced to endure hours of security checks yesterday.
Beyond the check-in counter and immigration control, Flight 223's roughly 100
transit passengers also underwent extraordinary scrutiny. Before they entered
the transit terminal, all were segregated, their names and passport numbers
taken down by an airline security officer.

Then about 90 minutes before they were supposed to leave, passengers were told
to go to Gate 11, which was guarded by four transit police officers with Uzi
submachine-guns. Two more officers arrived with springer spaniels to check for
explosives.

For the next hour, the dogs and the armed police walked among the passengers.
The crowd, for the most part, appeared relaxed, even jovial. People posed for
pictures, while a Sunday Telegraph reporter who had bought a ticket for the
flight moved from group to group conducting interviews. A Washington Post
reporter was also on the flight.

At around 3 p.m., the scheduled departure time, officials announced that all
transit passengers had to be re-interviewed. Each family was checked by another
airline security officer, holding a list of names. A group of young Middle
Eastern-looking people who appeared to be students seemed to come in for extra
questioning. About 30 minutes later, passengers began to board. At this late
moment, police took from the line one man, a Kenyan, who had no ticket. He told
them he had been transferred to the flight.

After about three dozen passengers were on board, three security guards appeared
and checked all the rest-rooms and the mid-cabin door, opposite from the entry
area. Then other passengers started trickling in again.

At about 4:45, when the plane was about two-thirds full, the captain announced
that everybody had been cleared and the door was shut. Another 30 minutes
passed, during which time the captain said he was waiting for clearance from
U.S. officials. "We just can't push this along," he said. "We are just waiting
as you are."

An hour and 15 minutes later, he reported that clearance had finally come
through. The plane pushed back and took off about 20 minutes later, scheduled
for arrival at about 9:10 p.m., Washington time.

LOAD-DATE: January 4, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: News

SEPT.  2

A Walk in the Woods

Stars: Robert Redford, Nick Nolte, Emma Thompson

Director: Ken Kwapis

Plot: Redford portrays travel writer Bill Bryson, who hikes the 2,200-mile
Appalachian Trail with his old friend (Nolte).

SEPT. 4

Before We Go

Stars: Chris Evans, Alice Eve, Mark Kassen

Director: Chris Evans

Plot: Evans' directorial debut follows two strangers (Evans and Eve) stuck in
New York City; they grow into  trusted confidants when a night of unexpected
adventure takes place.

Break Point

Stars: Jeremy Sisto, David Walton, J.K. Simmons

Director: Jay Karas

Plot: Two estranged brothers come together to make a miracle run at a Grand Slam
tennis tournament.

Dirty Weekend

Stars: Matthew Broderick, Alice Eve

Director: Neil LaBute

Plot: LaBute's dark comedy focuses on work colleagues (Broderick and Eve)
discovering each other's secrets during a business layover in Albuquerque.

Steve Jobs:  The Man in the Machine

Director: Alex Gibney

Plot: Documentary offers a critical examination of the iconoclastic genius and
barbed-tongued tyrant who was the Apple CEO.

The Transporter Refueled

Stars: Ed Skrein, Ray Stevenson, Loan Chabanol

Director: Camille Delamarre

Plot: The Transporter franchise moves on without Jason Statham but keeps the hot
cars, the hot women and a bank heist as Frank Martin (Skrein) outruns a Russian
kingpin.

SEPT. 11

The Perfect Guy

Stars: Michael Ealy, Sanaa Lathan, Morris Chestnut

Director: David M. Rosenthal

Plot: After a breakup with her boyfriend (Chestnut), Leah Vaughn (Lathan) meets
the seemingly perfect guy (Ealy), who is actually a psycho.

Director: Leslye Headland

they meet by chance 12 years after hooking up.

the success formula he lost after 1999's 'The Sixth Sense' with a tale of two
kids sent to their creepy grandparents' Pennsylvania farm.

Plot: The French director follows a Beijing student, who views the effect of the
Chinese cultural revolution on the nomadic herdsmen of Inner Mongolia and wild
wolf packs.

Plot: Ray (Fanning) realizes she isn't meant to be a girl and decides to
transition to male while her family deals with the fallout.

Director: Scott Cooper

Plot: Billed as the true story of notorious gangster Whitey Bulger of South
Boston, who becomes an FBI informant to take down the Mob.

Captive

Director: Jerry Jameson

Plot: Based on a true story, a single mother (Mara) taken hostage in her own
apartment uses the Rev. Rick Warren's 'The Purpose Driven Life' to gain freedom
from her captor (Oyelowo).

Maze Runner:  The Scorch Trials

Director: Wes Ball

Plot: Franchise continues in this sequel to 2014's 'Maze Runner,' which has the
surviving Gladers facing a new, desolate landscape.

SEPT. 25

A Brave Heart:  The Lizzie Velasquez Story

Director: Sara Hirsh Bordo

Plot: A documentary following the journey of 26-year-old, 58-pound Velasquez,
who has a rare condition that prevents her from gaining weight, as she journeys
from cyberbullying victim to anti-bullying activist.

who take their humanitarian protest from New York to the Amazon jungle only to
be taken prisoner by the

indigenous tribe they came to save.

Mendelsohn, Sienna Miller

Thornton, Anthony Mackie

she's recruited by a flailing Bolivian presidential candidate.

                             Daily News (New York)

                            August 26, 2006 Saturday
                              SPORTS FINAL EDITION

EARLY OUT FOR capo's son? He spied for FBI on terror plots

BYLINE: BY NANCIE L. KATZ DAILY NEWS STAFF WRITER

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 450 words


A DECADE AGO, a jailed mobster handed the FBI chilling details on alleged plots
to blow up airliners - including bomb formulas he got from cellmate Ramzi
Yousef, mastermind of the 1993 World Trade Center attack.

Now Colombo crime family soldier Gregory Scarpa Jr. is hoping that effort and
other undercover work he's done for the feds behind bars will win him early
release from prison, the Daily News has learned.

Dozens of secret FBI memos are part of Scarpa's appeal to Brooklyn Federal Court
Reena Raggi to reduce his 40-year prison term for murder conspiracy.

Among the intelligence Scarpa, 54, gleaned from Yousef were instructions on how
to make a peroxide-based liquid explosive, court records show.

Vilem Petr, a professor at the Colorado School of Mines, said Yousef's potion
appears similar to explosives that were part of the foiled terror plot to blow
up airliners in Britain.

Scarpa's work for the FBI included point-by-point directions, with diagrams,
from Yousef on evolving terror plots and ways to blow up airliners.

Yousef was also serving time for the 1995 so-called Bojinka plot to blow up 11
airliners over the Pacific. He tested a liquid concoction on a Philippines
jetliner, killing a passenger. British officials said the recent plot mirrored
Bojinka.

Much of that intelligence predated 9/11 and the arrest of alleged shoe-bomber
Richard Reid, who tried to blow up a U.S-bound jet from Paris.

But FBI and federal prosecutors have insisted that none of the information
provided by Scarpa, whose late father was a Colombo family capo and a longtime
FBI informant, was credible.

Brooklyn U.S. Attorney Roslynn Mauskopf urged the judge to deny Scarpa's
request. She said there was no "direct or causal connection between the Yousef
information and terrorist activity."

At Scarpa's 1999 sentencing, Raggi rejected his pleas for leniency, branding his
work with Yousef "part of a hoax."

In new court papers, he begs Raggi for an "honest review and appropriate
corrective action."

He cites reports handed to the 9/11 Commission and Congress by private
investigators Angela Clemente and Stephen Dresch that back him up.

Scarpa also wants credit for tipping off the FBI last year about explosives
agents found hidden in the Kansas home of Oklahoma City bomber Terry Nichols.
The two are now imprisoned together in Colorado.

Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.), who chairs the Oversight and Investigations
Subcommittee of the House International Relations Committee, had pushed the FBI
to follow up on Scarpa's tip on Nichols.

He said he thought Scarpa's earlier work seemed " worthy of very close analysis
. . . especially after they found that stash of explosives in Terry's house."

nkatz@nydailynews.com

LOAD-DATE: August 27, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                        Copyright 2006 Daily News, L.P.


                             107 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               The Times (London)

                            August 11, 2006, Friday

Sophisticated plot has hallmark of al-Qaeda, says US security boss

BYLINE: Tom Baldwin in Washington

SECTION: OVERSEAS NEWS; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 555 words


President Bush said yesterday that the plot to set off multiple explosions in US
aircraft should serve as "a stark reminder that this nation is at war with
Islamic fascists who will use any means to destroy those of us who love
freedom".

The President is always ready to tell his "fellow citizens" -as he did yesterday
on a brief visit to Wisconsin -that "it is a mistake to believe there is no
threat to the United States of America".

Michael Chertoff, the US Homeland Security Secretary, wasted even less time in
telling reporters at a breakfast-time press conference that the plan "was
suggestive of al-Qaeda" -a view confirmed with greater certainty by officials
speaking privately. However, with the fifth anniversary of the September 11
attacks looming and a new Oliver Stone film on the destruction of the World
Trade Centre being released this week, the nerves of many American voters are
already frayed and they do not require much prompting to worry about terrorism.

Although reports that Mr Bush was woken at his ranch in Texas yesterday morning
by a call from Tony Blair were denied by the White House, the two leaders had
been in regular touch -as recently as Sunday -about British police efforts to
track and capture those behind the aircraft plot.

American authorities were told about a fortnight ago of an "accelerating plan"
to target US airlines flying from Britain to Los Angeles, Washington and New
York.

One official was quoted yesterday as saying that British authorities would not
have arrested the suspects "if they hadn't thought these guys were ready to go -
the trip line had been reached -they dropped the hammer when they did because
they thought they were out of time".

Mr Chertoff said that the plan was as "sophisticated as any we have seen in
recent years", adding: "This plot was well advanced. In other words, they had
accumulated and assembled the capabilities that they needed, and they were in
the final stages of planning.

"The terrorists planned to carry the components of the bombs, including liquid
explosive ingredients and detonating devices disguised as beverages, electronic
devices or other common objects," he said.

It is not known if the alleged terrorists had gone so far as to book seats, but
an FBI source told The Times last night that he believed that the terrorists had
been examining routes but not specific flights.

Mr Chertoff drew comparisons with the Operation Bojinka plot in 1995 by Khalid
Sheikh Mohammed, the mastermind behind 9/11, in which improvised bombs using
liquid in contact lens solution containers would have been detonated on a dozen
flights over the Pacific.

America has issued an unprecedented red alert on all flights to or from Britain,
while raising to orange -the level below -the risk status of all other passenger
aircraft.

Mr Chertoff said: "This is a precaution against any members of the plot who may
still be at large. Given the amount of planning and effort that was put into
this plot, I think it would be a little bit risky to assume that everything is
shut down and the threat has gone."

Federal air marshals are being sent to Britain to provide "expanded mission
coverage" for flights to and from the US. Mr Chertoff emphasised that passengers
should not cancel flights, saying: "We are screening out people who want to do
harm to innocent travellers."

LOAD-DATE: August 11, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved


                             108 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Calgary Herald (Alberta)

                            July 11, 2007 Wednesday
                                 Final Edition

Montreal mob boss linked to alleged plot to kill U.S. judge

BYLINE: Paul Cherry, CanWest News Service

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A10

LENGTH: 563  words


Montreal mob boss Frank Cotroni and high-ranking U.S. mobsters were once
investigated for an alleged plot to assassinate the top judge in America,
according to newly released FBI documents.

The investigation into the alleged plot to assassinate Chief Justice Warren
Burger began in December 1981, after an informant came forward with information
of a jailhouse plot. It ended 15 months later with no charges being laid.

Instead, the FBI dispatched agents to warn the heads of Mafia families in the
U.S. that any attempt to assassinate Burger "would be responded to with the full
force and resources of the (Department) of Justice and the FBI."

The documents were obtained by the Montreal Gazette through the U.S. Freedom of
Information Act.

Access to Cotroni's FBI record was requested after he died of cancer on Aug. 17,
2004, at the age of 72. He was one of three brothers who controlled illegal
rackets in Montreal for decades while they operated as a branch office for the
Bonanno crime family in New York.

In April 1979, after serving four years of a 15-year sentence for cocaine
trafficking in the U.S., Cotroni was paroled and released from a federal
penitentiary in Lewisburg, Penn. Two years later, the informant, who apparently
served time at Lewisburg with the Montreal mobster, told the FBI that Cotroni
and other Mafiosi discussed killing Burger and a U.S. district court judge based
in New Jersey.

The earliest reference to the FBI investigation among the documents is a
"priority" teletype communique warning of the alleged plot. It was sent on Dec.
18, 1981, from an FBI field office in Seattle, Wash., to the FBI's director and
five FBI offices in the eastern U.S.

The message concluded with a plan to advise Burger of the suspected plot and to
pursue leads "on a very discreet basis" by investigating the backgrounds of the
suspects.

The FBI documents reveal no motive for the alleged plot. But, as the top U.S.
judge, Burger might have been considered a target as a means to intimidate the
American justice system.

Cotroni, described in the FBI documents as "the boss of the Montreal (La Cosa
Nostra) family and an associate of the Bonanno LCN family," is listed as a
suspect throughout the investigation.

Phil Rastelli, the head of the Bonanno crime family in New York until he died in
1991, and Joseph Gambino, a captain in the Gambino crime family, are also listed
as suspects.

Agents tried to figure out how to investigate the plot while most of the
suspects were still behind bars. The penitentiary in Lewisburg had no private
rooms where investigators could interview suspects without other inmates
noticing.

Cotroni was back in Montreal at that point, but the documents indicate the FBI
did not plan to question him. One possible reason was that by February 1982 the
FBI was investigating a major drug smuggling operation headed by Cotroni.

The assassination plot investigation was further frustrated by a reluctance, on
the part of the U.S. district attorney's office in Seattle, to let the informant
be interviewed by FBI agents.

The FBI decided the best way to proceed was to warn some of the suspects and the
heads of most of the Mafia families in the eastern U.S. that they were aware of
the assassination plot.

Eventually agents brought what little information they had to a prosecutor who
decided no charges could be laid. The investigation then ended quietly.

LOAD-DATE: July 11, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:
Photo: Herald Archive; FBI documents claim Montreal mob boss Frank Cotroni was
investigated over an alleged assassination plot. ;

                             109 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                        Progressive Media - Company News

                          February 26, 2014 Wednesday

Adding multimedia Porter & Plot exposes the undiscovered world of unique wine
regions through small-lot offerings

SECTION: DRIED FOOD; United States of America

LENGTH: 315 words



HIGHLIGHT: Fine wine is often seen as a luxury only fully understood by experts,
leaving the average consumer feeling lost and overwhelmed.


Porter & Plot aims to bring clarity to the perplexing wine world through their
line of limited-production wines, launching on February 26, 2014. Their product
portfolio will feature a diverse collection of small-lot wines, each typically
1,000 cases or less, that showcase the distinct land on which they originate.
Smaller AVA wines are currently hard to find for most wine consumers and are
rarely available for under $20 - something Porter & Plot aims to change.

The name Porter & Plot embodies the brand's mission to be a reliable and
consistent purveyor of small lot wines, historically the domain of high-end
shops and importers. The porter, or gatekeeper, guides consumers through plots,
or unique regions, helping them to understand the diversity and distinct
expression of land that each wine reflects. The brand will feature numerous
wines with the aim to continually bring consumers new regions and varietals each
vintage, as opposed to attempting to replicate a popular wine the next year.

Porter & Plot's philosophy is all about discovery and attention to details - not
just what type of wine it is, but also its origin. Their first selections --
which include a 2013 Columbia Valley Pinot Gris, 2012 Edna Valley Single
Vineyard Pinot Noir and a 2013 Costières de Nîmes - are drinking experiences
that are refined and complex, yet priced to be enjoyed every day for less than
$20. The offering proves that wine drinkers, whether new or experienced, never
have to settle for less knowing they have a great porter.

Porter & Plot will introduce their first three varietals through interactive
tastings in New York, San Francisco, and Los Angeles where tastemakers, experts,
and wine drinkers eager to learn more will get the first taste. Each event will
walk tasters through a journey that exposes them to a full sensory experience,
guiding them through a whole new way to enjoy wine.

                             111 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          Sunday Telegraph (Australia)

                              July 9, 2006 Sunday
                                 State Edition

US foils plot to bomb tunnels

BYLINE: DANIEL TROTTA

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 29

LENGTH: 422  words


US authorities thwarted a plot to attack New York's mass transit system later
this year, leading to the arrest in Lebanon of a plotter who confessed.

The plot targeted a rail tunnel linking New York and New Jersey.

The FBI and the Department of Homeland Security said a ''terrorist network'' was
disrupted.

Lebanese sources previously had confirmed the arrest of Asem Hammoud -- also
identified as Amir al-Andalousi -- ''who is a suspect in a plot to bomb a tunnel
in New York'', a government source said.

Lebanon's Interior Ministry said the plan targeted tunnels under the Hudson
River, which separates Manhattan from New Jersey.

''After questioning he confessed ... that he was planning to travel to Pakistan
for four months training and that the date for the attack was decided to be late
in 2006,'' the ministry said.

The alleged plot was ''a big terrorist operation against metro tunnels in New
York City under the Hudson River'', it said.

There are several tunnels connecting Manhattan and New Jersey under the Hudson
River -- the Lincoln and Holland tunnels for cars and buses, as well as tunnels
for subway trains from New Jersey and commuter and regional trains.

The intent was to flood the Wall St financial district, but experts said a blast
inside would not have flooded Lower Manhattan.

Wall St is about 3km from the tunnel, which is dug under bedrock and firmly
reinforced with concrete and steel.

The months-old plot was uncovered by monitoring Internet chat rooms. The report
was published on the first anniversary of the London suicide bombings, which
claimed 52 lives.

It was the second recent domestic threat authorities have said they broke up in
the early stages, following the arrest of seven people last month on suspicion
of a plan to attack the Sears Tower in Chicago.

''We have disrupted a terrorist network that was in the planning stages of an
attack against the transportation system in the New York-New Jersey area.

''A significant development in this investigation was the arrest of a key
suspect by Lebanese authorities. This investigation is ongoing,'' the FBI and
the Department of Homeland Security said.

They also suggested the network was linked to al-Qaeda, and the Daily News
reported it was linked to Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the al-Qaeda leader in Iraq who
was killed recently by US forces.

''We know al-Qaeda continues to have an interest in attacking the United States.
At this point in time, there is no specific or credible information that
al-Qaeda is planning an attack on US soil,'' the US statement said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                             112 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                  The National

                           October 12, 2011 Wednesday

Two Iranians charged over alleged major terror attack on US

LENGTH: 636  words


Manssor Arbabsiar and Gholam Shakuri, an alleged member of a secret Iranian
military unit, are charged with plotting to kill the Saudi ambassador to the
United States as part of a major attack.

WASHINGTON // Two Iranians have been charged over plans to kill the Saudi
ambassador to the United States as part of a major terror attack in a "plot
directed by elements of the Iranian government" .

The plan called for the assassination of Ambassador Adel Al Jubeir in an
explosives attack, which could have killed many other people and would have been
just "the opening act" in an attack on US soil, Justice Department officials
said.

Manssor Arbabsiar, a 56-year-old naturalised US citizen holding both Iranian and
US passports, and Gholam Shakuri, an alleged member of a secret Iranian military
unit, are charged with plotting the attacks, said officials.

The US Attorney General, Eric Holder, who held a news conference yesterday after
the alleged plot was unveiled, said that the US will hold Iran responsible for
any terrorist actions tied to the plot, which he said was sponsored by the
Iranian government. He called the conspiracy a "flagrant" violation of
international law.

He said the two men were connected to the secretive Quds Force, a division of
Iran's elite Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps that has carried out operations
in other countries. Mr Holder said that money in support of the plot had been
transferred through a bank in New York, but that the men had not yet obtained
any explosives.

Mr Shakuri remains at large. Mr Arbabsiar was arrested on September 29 at New
York's John F Kennedy International Airport and was to make his initial
appearance yesterday before in federal court in Manhattan. He faces a maximum
potential sentence of life in prison if convicted of all the charges.

"The criminal complaint unsealed today exposes a deadly plot directed by
factions of the Iranian government to assassinate a foreign ambassador on US
soil with explosives," Mr Holder said.

"Through the diligent and coordinated efforts of our law enforcement and
intelligence agencies, we were able to disrupt this plot before anyone was
harmed. We will continue to investigate this matter vigorously and bring those
who have violated any laws to justice."

Mr Holder said the plot was "conceived, sponsored and directed from Iran."

News reports said the plot also included a bomb and subsequent bomb attacks on
the Saudi and Israeli embassies in Washington.

The case, called Operation Red Coalition, began in May when an Iranian-American
from Corpus Christi, Texas, approached a US informant seeking the help of a
Mexican drug cartel to assassinate the Saudi ambassador, according to
counter-terrorism officials.

The Iranian-American thought he was dealing with a member of a Mexican drug
organisation, according to documents.

The US said Mr Arbabsiar allegedly conspired with Mr Shakuri, a member of Iran's
"Quds Force", described as "the most secret of the Iranian regime's numerous
military organisations" by the Iran Terror Database.

The United States will contact governments worldwide to brief them on the
alleged plot, Mr Holder said. "One thing that we will be doing is getting in
touch with other of our allies and nations around the world to make them aware
of what it is that was thwarted here," he said.

The US president Barack Obama was first briefed on the development in June, and
ordered his aides to fully support the investigation, an official said.

FBI Director Robert Mueller said: "It reads like the pages of a Hollywood
script. We send a clear message that any attempts on American soil will not be
tolerated."

The two men are charged with five counts including conspiracy to murder a
foreign official and conspiracy to use a weapon of mass destruction. They may
face as much as life in prison if convicted.

                             113 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                              The Pioneer (India)

                              July 9, 2010 Friday

UK's airline bomb plotters convicted

LENGTH: 449  words

DATELINE: London


London, July 9 -- Three Muslim men have been found guilty of plotting to murder
hundreds of people in the longest-running terrorism trial in Britain's history.
The men had been recruited in 2006 by the ringleader of the airline bomb plot.

The three men were among eight tried in connection with an Al Qaeda-inspired
plot to detonate homemade liquid bombs on transatlantic jets.

Ibrahim Savant, Arafat Khan and Waheed Zaman, all from east London, were
convicted of conspiracy to murder by a jury at Woolwich Crown Court.

Last year a jury had cleared the trio of their role in targeting aeroplanes, but
were put on trial again to face charges of conspiracy to murder.

A Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) spokesman said the jury found all three men
guilty on Thursday. They face life imprisonment.

The verdicts come nearly four years after the police and MI5 smashed the largest
ever terrorist plot in the UK. Counter-terrorist police and the security
services spent more than &#163;35 million foiling the plot and bringing Ali and
the others to justice.

The arrest of the gang in August 2006 sparked tight restrictions on carrying
liquids on to aircraft which initially caused travel chaos.

The head of the plot, Abdulla Ahmed Ali, had planned to target seven
transatlantic airliners with a co-ordinated strike by suicide bombers.

The plot involved smuggling liquid bombs in drinks bottles on to planes bound
for North America. The hydrogen peroxide devices would have been assembled and
detonated in mid-air by a team of suicide bombers.

Ali singled out seven flights to San Francisco, Toronto, Montreal, Washington,
New York and Chicago that departed within two and a half hours of each other. If
successful, the explosions could have exceeded the carnage of the September 11
attacks.

The jury rejected the defence of Ali, Sarwar, and Hussain that the plot was an
elaborate publicity stunt.

Prosecutors said that 'martyrdom videos' recorded by the trio proved they were
willing to sacrifice their lives, even if at the time of their arrest there was
insufficient evidence to prove they had known what the targets would be.

In a statement, the Crown Prosecution Service's head of counter-terrorism, Sue
Hemming, said, "The charges against these men were so serious that, following
two previous trials where juries could not reach verdicts, the director of
public prosecutions decided that the evidence must be properly tested before a
jury for a third time.

"The verdicts demonstrate that the Crown Prosecution Service was right to pursue
a third trial." Published by HT Syndication with permission from Pioneer. For
more information on news feed please contact Sarabjit Jagirdar at
htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement,
please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com
