                             114 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                 therecord.com

                             April 2, 2009 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

Gift of cemetery plot means blues legend will rest near home

BYLINE: Terry Pender, RECORD STAFF

SECTION: FRONT; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 594  words

DATELINE: KITCHENER


Mel Brown, the legendary bluesman from Mississippi, who called this city home
for the past 20 years, will be buried in a donated cemetery plot in the area.

The interment will be a strictly private affair for family and close friends and
the location of the famed blues guitarist's grave will not be made public until
afterwards.

Brown was born in Jackson, Miss. on Oct. 7, 1939 and died on March 20 in St.
Mary's Hospital from emphysema-related complications.

After living in Los Angeles, Nashville, Hawaii, New York and Austin, Brown
settled on Cameron Street in downtown Kitchener with his longtime wife Miss
Angel.

In a lasting sign of profound respect and affection, a cemetery plot was given
to Miss Angel so Brown could be buried here.

"Mel wanted to be buried in Kitchener," said Andrew Galloway, president of
Electro-Fi Records.

Galloway worked with Brown and Miss Angel during the past 10 years as the blues
master released several CDs on the Electro-Fi label.

"Somebody through a friend of a friend, somebody who has a cemetery just outside
of town heard about it and just gave Miss Angel a plot for him," Galloway said.

"You guys always made him feel so welcome. He always appreciated that. Kitchener
was home to him," Galloway said.

Hundreds of people are expected to attend the funeral service that begins
Saturday at 1 p.m. in the Gig Music Hall at 137 Ontario St., N.

"It's open to the public, that's why Miss Angel moved it to the Gig Theatre, so
as many people as possible could be there," Galloway said.

There will, of course, be music.

Mel Brown's band The Homewreckers and Shawn Kellerman will do a number, Diana
Braithwaite and Chris Whiteley, Steven Strongman and Julian Fauth will also
perform.

"Miss Angel really wants to focus on it being a celebration of Mel's life and
how much he loved being in Kitchener," Galloway said.

A few years ago Brown travelled with Miss Angel back to Mississippi for an
extended visit with her family.

While there Miss Angel introduced Brown to the pastor of the local Baptist
church she had attended while growing up. Brown wasn't big on religion but he
was taken with the Rev. Bobby Bowen. He came back to the church to play organ
and work with the choir, and didn't miss a Sunday service during his visit.

"Mel got to know him and they got on very well and he is coming up to do the
service," Galloway said.

Since his death, national news organizations, including The Globe and Mail, CTV
National News and Saturday Night Blues on CBC Radio carried detailed stories
about Brown's life and music. This coming Saturday CBC Radio's Big City Small
World will have a segment on Brown.

The funeral service will be broadcast live on the web at
www.popularminority.com.

After the funeral service and reception at the Gig Music Hall on Saturday, the
downtown business association has organized a Mel Brown Commemorative Blues Jam
to be held from 4 to 8 p.m. at Bobby O'Brien's at 125 King St., W.

"We wanted to do something in memory of Mel," said Moya Spruce of Tri-City Music
and the Kitchener Downtown Business Association.

Following the jam, the Grand River Blues Society will stage A Tribute to Billie
Holiday, which begins at 8 p.m. in the Gig Music Hall as well.

Tickets are $20 for the tribute, which is the society's annual fundraiser for
its Blues in the School Program. They can be purchased at the Orange Monkey in
Waterloo, Encore Records in Kitchener, MacAulays Music in Cambridge and Ground
Floor Music in Guelph or on www.ticketscene.ca.

"It's going to be a full day of blues in the core," Spruce said.

tpender@therecord.com

LOAD-DATE: April 2, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo: IAN WILLMS, RECORD FILE PHOTO , Mel Brown, who died March 20,
will be buried in a plot near Kitchener.

                     Sunday News (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

                             March 11, 2007 Sunday

Garden plots available;
Bonsai event Master Gardener

BYLINE: Sunday News Staff

SECTION: G; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 458  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA




The public is invited to rent garden plots such as the one shown above at
Lancaster County Central Park.

The Lancaster County Department of Parks and Recreation has garden plots
available for rent April 15 through Oct. 15; applications are currently being
accepted.

Lancaster County residents may select either a 20x20-foot plot, $16, or 20x40,
$20. The garden area is located off Farm View Drive, just off Golf Road in
Lancaster County Central Park.

Gardeners of all skill levels are welcome to grow their own flowers and
vegetables. Organic plots are also available; these plots have been free of
pesticides and herbides for more than three years.

The Parks Department and Penn State Cooperative Extension Master Gardeners
Program will also offer a variety of garden workshops; sessions will be held
from 7 to 8 p.m., unless otherwise noted, at the Environmental Center, off
Eshelman Mill Road in Central Park.

The workshops include:

"Garden Preparation and Vegetable/Plant Selection," Tuesday, March 20; attendees
may bring a soil sample and purchase an analysis kit.

"Garden Layout and Staking," 9:30 to 10:30 a.m. Saturday, April 21, at the
garden plots off Farm View Drive; will cover special planting methods for
potatoes, tomatoes and root crops.

"Intermediate Pruning," Tuesday, May 15; includes tools and techniques for
perennials.

"Landscaping," Tuesday, June 19; with site analysis and how to select the right
plant for the right place.

There is a $1 fee per workshop session. Those who rent a garden plot at Central
Park may attend free of charge; preregistration is required.

Call the parks office, 299-8251, to register for a plot or workshop.n

Lancaster Bonsai Society will hold its inaugural Spring Symposium 8:30 a.m. to 9
p.m. Saturday, March 24, and 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Sunday, March 25, at the Courtyard
by Marriott-Lancaster, 1931 Hospitality Drive.

The event will feature the following:

A lecture and demonstration by David Easterbrook, curator at the Montreal
(Canada) Botanical Gardens.

Lectures by bonsai authority Jim Doyle, owner of Nature's Way Nursery,
Harrisburg.

A raffle of the featured demonstration tree, bonsai plants and supplies.

An exhibit of the LBS bonsai trees.

A bonsai marketplace.

Registration is required; $70 for both days; $50 for Saturday only; $30 for
Sunday only. See www.lancasterbonsai.com or call Jeff Howe, LBS president,
295-5403.n

The Penn State Master Gardener Symposium will be held from 8 a.m. to 3:30 p.m.
Saturday, March 17, at the Farm and Home Center, 1383 Arcadia Road.

The cost for the all-day event is $52.

Seating is limited, and registration will be accepted on a first-come,
first-served basis.

For information, call the Lancaster County Cooperative Extension Office at
394-6851 or e-mail srw12@psu.edu.n

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *

   El Maniel International, Inc. (El Maniel), incorporated on July 24, 2007, is
a development-stage company. The Company focuses on its projects in the gold
business, including but not limited to trading, prospecting, developing and
expanding its mining claims located in Papua New Guinea of Australasia and Ghana
of West Africa.

   The Company's projects in Papua New Guinea include the Misima project and the
Enga project. The Misima project has a total land area of 108 acres. The Misima
alluvial gold mining claim is located at the Bulpat Creek of Misima Island,
which is located in the Milne Bay Province of Papua New Guinea. The alluvial
Enga project is located at the Timun River of Enga Province in Papua New Guinea
which has a conservative estimated gold reserve of around 270,000 ounces.

   The Company's projects in Ghana, West Africa include gold business domain-
plot A and plot B, gold business domain-plot C and gold business domain-plot D1.
The gold business domain-plot A and plot B totaling 200 acres of alluvial gold
mining claims are situated in the gold belt of the Western Region of Ghana, West
Africa, which is known as the Ashanti Gold Belt, is located in Ghana's Golden
Triangle. The gold business domain-plot C is a 25 acres of alluvial gold mining
claim, which is also known as Kumasko Project is situated in the Upper Denkyira
District, Bosomase, Ghana, West Africa. The gold business domain-plot D1 is a 50
acres gold mining claim situated approximately 80 kilometers North of Accra in
the Kibi-Winneba Basin of the Eastern Region of Ghana under the Kibi-Winneba
gold belt.

                                US Official News

                            February 17, 2017 Friday

Perfect Pacing in Plot-Driven Fiction: A Fiction Writing Workshop

LENGTH: 607  words

DATELINE: New York



 Augusta: The State of Maine has issued the following news release:



        February 18

     USM's Glickman Library, Portland

     February 18, 2017

     Categories: Classes/Workshops, Community Events, Lectures/Literary



 Event Details



     February 18, 2017

     10:30 am - 4:30 pm

     $65-125

     $65 MWPA Member / $125 Nonmember

     Get Tickets



 Venue



     USM's Glickman Library

     314 Forest Ave, Room 318

     Portland, ME 04101



 Event Description



 From cozy mystery to thriller, science fiction to historical romance, and every
plot-driven fiction in between, authors must be able to draw the reader in from
the outset of a story and maintain tension throughout.

Ideally, this should be done without sacrificing character development or
writing quality. In this day-long workshop designed for new writers as well as
veteran authors with a completed novel or work in progress, attendees will gain
a better understanding of how structure supports effective pacing in plot-driven
fiction, and learn how to apply this understanding to their own work.
Participants will explore three-act structure; the strategic placement of plot
points and action beats; and how plot can positively impact character
development for the reader. Morning Session: Participants will look at three-act
structure, first applying it to two well-known works and then examining their
own works-in-progress to determine how the structure applies. Through exercises
and discussion, attendees will track the plot points in their own work before
breaking for lunch. Afternoon Session: Participants will look at the beginnings
of plot-driven novels, focusing on how action drives the narrative from the
outset, the introduction of the protagonist, and exposition in the first act.
Attendees will have an opportunity to share the first chapter of their own novel
or work in progress and to receive feedback from the instructor and fellow
participants; sharing is not required. The workshop will then close with a final
writing exercise. + SUGGESTED READING (NOT REQUIRED) The Hunger Games by Suzanne
Collins Huckleberry Finn by Mark Twain *This is a full-day workshop and there is
not an option to register for either just the morning session or just the
afternoon session. Instructor Jen Blood is the award-winning author of the
bestselling Erin Solomon Mysteries, as well as the 5-Day Fiction writing guides
Creating Complex Characters and Perfect Pacing: Thriller Edition. She is owner
of Adian Editing, providing expert editing of plot-driven fiction for
independent and traditionally published authors around the world, and has led
seminars on writing, publishing, and marketing for authors in conferences
throughout New England. Jen holds an MFA in Creative Writing/Popular Fiction
from the University of Southern Maine, is a regular blogger with Maine Crime
Writers, and is on the board of directors of Sisters in Crime New England. Her
articles on writing and publishing have appeared on award-winning websites
including The Creative Penn, Janice Hardy's Fiction University, and The Crime
Fiction Collective. VISIT jenblood.com  ADVANCE REGISTRATION REQUIRED All MWPA
workshops require advanced registration. We accept registration by phone, mail,
and online via PayPal. We cannot guarantee registration in the final 24-hours
before a workshop, and can rarely accommodate day-of registration.

 Event presented by:



     Maine Writers & Publishers Alliance

     (207) 228-8263

     info@mainewriters.org

     http://mainewriters.org/

              San Gabriel Valley Tribune (San Gabriel Valley, CA)

                          September 7, 2005 Wednesday

Armenians' citizenship upheld

BYLINE: Jennifer English, City News Service

SECTION: WORLD NEWS

LENGTH: 404 words


An appellate panel Tuesday upheld a Los Angeles judge's decision to grant
citizenship to a pair of Armenian immigrants who two decades ago were involved
in a plot to bomb the office of a Turkish diplomat.

The decision in favor of Los Angeles school principal Viken Yacoubian and Santa
Monica hedge fund manager Viken Hovsepian comes after years of legal struggling
between the men and immigration officials, a battle that began around the time
of their convictions in the plot.

The wrangling was punctuated five years ago, when the same judge who had
presided over their criminal trials opted to administer the oath of citizenship.

Last year, a government appeal led the same 11-judge panel of the 9th U.S.
Circuit Court of Appeals to order that U.S. District Judge Mariana Pfaelzer re-
evaluate her decision to grant the men citizenship this time taking into account
the plot that led to their 1984 convictions.

The panel found Tuesday that in re-examining the issue, Pfaelzer properly
weighed the men's involvement in the plot, for which they were convicted of
helping to get dynamite transported on a passenger airliner from Los Angeles to
Boston. The FBI argued that the bomb plot could have killed thousands of people.

In the judge's order, she described two men who had "completely reformed,'
Tuesday's opinion states.

When the plot was intercepted by the FBI in 1982, Yacoubian and Hovsepian were
linked by authorities to the Justice Commandos of the Armenian Genocide, a group
seeking revenge against Turkey for atrocities committed against Armenians.

The dynamite was carried onto the plane by a co-conspirator as part of a plot
targeting the Turkish consul general's office in Philadelphia. The
co-conspirator was arrested upon landing in Boston, court papers show.

Yacoubian, who was a teen at the time of the crime, is now married and the
principal of Rose and Alex Pilibos Armenian High School in the Little Armenia
area of Los Angeles, according to Tuesday's ruling.

Hovsepian is also married and has a doctorate in international relations, the
court papers state.

Both men "continue to reject the use of violence to express a political view;
both regret their actions in 1982,' the 9th Circuit ruling states.

Following their convictions, Yacoubian was sentenced to three years in prison
and 1,000 hours of community service. Hovsepian was ordered to serve six years.
CNS-09-6-2005 13:47

LOAD-DATE: September 7, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                            The Independent (London)

                             July 8, 2006 Saturday
                                 First Edition

'Plot to flood New York' foiled

BYLINE: By David Usborne

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 37

LENGTH: 235 words


American intelligence officials say they have foiled a terror plot to blow up at
least one of New York's major road tunnels.

Elsewhere, the plot was described as an attempt to flood the financial district
and to do to lower Manhattan what Hurricane Katrina did last August to New
Orleans.

The alleged conspiracy was apparently in its infancy when it was uncovered by
anti-terror agents of the FBI monitoring internet chat rooms. "This is one
instance where intelligence was on top of its game and discovered the plot when
it was just in the talking phase," confirmed US Senator Charles Schumer.

"We have disrupted a terrorist network in the planning stages of an attack,"
said a statement released by the FBI and Department of Homeland Security.

The statement added that a "key suspect" connected to the case, Amir Andalousli,
had been arrested by the authorities in Lebanon. A Lebanese official said the
suspect's real name was Assem Hammoud and he was connected to al-Qa'ida. It is
thought that other overseas arrests have also been made.

First reports of the investigation said the main target was the Holland tunnel,
in lower Manhattan, and the aim was to cause water from the Hudson river to rush
into Wall Street. Because the river is lower than Manhattan, the plan was most
unlikely to work.

Two weeks ago, authorities announced the arrests of seven men suspected of
plotting to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago.

                             120 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                             Daily News (New York)

                            June 19, 2013 Wednesday
                          SPORTS FINAL REPLATE EDITION

Snooping KOd plot vs. stock exchange: feds

BYLINE: BY JOSEPH STRAW NEW YORK DAILY NEWS

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 295 words


WASHINGTON - Federal officials thwarted a plot to blow up the New York Stock
Exchange because of the government's controversial Internet and phone snooping
programs, officials revealed Tuesday.

Testifying before the House Intelligence Committee, officials said the snooping
helped to prevent "potential terrorist events over 50 times since 9/11." They
said 10 of those events had some connection to the U.S.

FBI Deputy Director Sean Joyce said one of those 10 threats involved the plot to
blow up the stock exchange, which was uncovered in 2008.

Joyce testified that National Security Agency surveillance of a terror operative
in Yemen revealed communications with Kansas City, Mo., auto parts dealer Khalid
Ouazzani.

The FBI began direct surveillance of Ouazzani "and identified his
co-conspirators."

"We were able to disrupt the plot, we were able to lure some individuals to the
United States, and we were able to effect their arrest," Joyce said.

The plot had been previously disclosed. Tuesday marked the first time officials
said that it was uncovered through the surveillance programs detailed this month
by NSA contract employee Edward Snowden.

Ouazzani pleaded guilty in May 2010 to charges of conspiracy to provide material
support to a terrorist organization, bank fraud and money laundering. He was not
charged with the alleged plot against the stock exchange. A Brooklyn resident,
Sabirhan Hasanoff - who pleaded guilty last year to aiding Al Qaeda - cased the
stock exchange on orders from masters overseas, according to a sentencing memo.

However, an unnamed FBI source quoted in court documents questioned the foreign
terrorists' interest in striking the exchange.

NSA Director Gen. Keith Alexander testified his agency's programs are subject to
strict oversight.

                             121 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        The International Herald Tribune

                             July 8, 2006 Saturday

Terror plot foiled in N.Y., FBI says

BYLINE: John O'Neil

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 394 words

DATELINE: NEW YORK


A plot by a ''terrorist network'' to attack the transportation system in the New
York and New Jersey area was disrupted in its planning stages, federal officials
said Friday.

One man has been arrested by Lebanese officials in connection with the plot,
according to a statement issued jointly by the FBI and the Department of
Homeland Security.

A senior Lebanese security official told The Associated Press that the suspect,
Assem Hammoud, was a member of Al Qaeda and had confessed to the plot. The
official said that Hammoud was known to the group involved in the plot by an
alias, Amir Andalousli.

But the statement issued by federal officials Friday said that while ''Al Qaeda
continues to have an interest in attacking the United States,'' there is ''no
specific or credible information that Al Qaeda is planning an attack on U.S.
soil.''

The plot was first reported Friday by The Daily News, which said that Hammoud
and others were planning to detonate a bomb in the Holland Tunnel in the hope of
flooding Lower Manhattan.

But a law enforcement official said that the tunnel was not the target of the
plot, and Representative Peter King of New York, chairman of the House Committee
on Homeland Security, said that he ''would agree'' with that assessment. In a
televised interview discussing the investigation, Senator Charles Schumer of New
York referred to the Lincoln Tunnel rather than the Holland.

King and Schumer each said that the plot had been caught in its early stages.
King said that he had been informed of the investigation by the FBI and the New
York City Police Department nine months ago.

In a televised interview on CNN, Schumer said the plot had not gotten beyond the
talking stage.

The statement issued by the FBI and the Department of Homeland Security said the
investigation was ''ongoing'' and was being conducted with the help of security
forces in Lebanon and ''other foreign law enforcement and intelligence
partners.''

An FBI official in New York declined to comment on the matter. A spokesman for
the Police Department said that there had been no recent change in security
levels at the tunnels.

As far as the hope of flooding Manhattan, Schumer noted that the plot could not
have worked because the tunnels lie well below ground level. ''It makes no sense
whatsoever,'' he said. ''They don't seem to be the brightest bulbs in the
terrorist lot.''

                             Daily News (New York)

                            February 10, 2006 Friday
                              SPORTS FINAL EDITION

W REVEALS HIJACK PLOT TO HIT L.A. CRITICS HIT TIMING, SUBSTANCE OF PREZ COMMENTS
ON TERROR TARGET

BYLINE: BY JAMES GORDON MEEK and KENNETH R. BAZINET DAILY NEWS WASHINGTON BUREAU
With Michael McAuliff

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 457 words


WASHINGTON - President Bush detailed a terrorist plot yesterday that would have
used shoe bombers and a hijacked plane to knock down the tallest building on the
West Coast.

The plot to strike a Los Angeles skyscraper has been mentioned before, but Bush
released additional details yesterday.

The timing of his remarks and the seriousness of the plot were questioned,
however, by officials ranging from the mayor of Los Angeles to counter-terrorism
experts.

The President's comments come as he is under fire even by members of his own
party for his domestic eavesdropping program. Bush didn't contend that the
eavesdropping busted up the L.A. plot, but his remarks served as a stark
reminder of the menace from terrorists.

"We now know that in October 2001, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed - the mastermind of
the Sept. 11 attacks - had already set in motion a plan to have terrorist
operatives hijack an airplane using shoe bombs to breach the cockpit door, and
fly the plane into the tallest building on the West Coast," Bush said.

"We believe the intended target was [Library] Tower in Los Angeles, Calif.
Rather than use Arab hijackers as he had on September the 11th, Khalid Shaikh
Mohammed sought out young men from Southeast Asia, whom he believed would not
arouse as much suspicion," Bush added.

The attack was foiled, he said, when a plotter was arrested in Asia.

Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa, a Democrat, was taken aback by Bush's
statements.

"I'm amazed that the President would make this [announcement] on national TV and
not inform us of these details through the appropriate channels," the mayor
said. "I don't expect a call from the President - but somebody."

"We should have been aware of all the details much before today," Villaraigosa
said.

The White House claimed it gave California officials a heads-up about the
speech.

Other Democrats, including Sen. Hillary Clinton (D-N.Y.), have claimed Bush is
following a strategy of highlighting the terror threat to counter criticism of
his eavesdropping program and of the war in Iraq.

A Clinton source yesterday questioned "the timing of the speech."

Several counterterrorism officials were surprised that Bush claimed the "West
Coast plot" was "set in motion."

"There was no definitive plot. It never materialized or got past the thought
stage," said a senior counterterrorism official, who has worked at the CIA and
the FBI.

In June 2004, FBI Deputy Director John Pistole refused to characterize it as an
advanced plot.

Bush's top counterterrorism adviser, Frances Townsend, said the critics don't
"truly understand what the timeline was."

She said the West Coast plot was "blessed" in October 2001 by Osama Bin Laden,
but Townsend admitted little else is known about it.

jmeek@nydailynews.com

over tower in L.A., but experts cast doubt on whether the danger was real.

               National Post (f/k/a The Financial Post) (Canada)

                           September 15, 2009 Tuesday
                                National Edition

2006 Plot draws life sentences; Liquid Bombs

BYLINE: Robin Millard, Agence France-Press; with files from The Daily Telegraph

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. A14

LENGTH: 575  words

DATELINE: LONDON


Three British Muslims were sentenced yesterday to life in prison for plotting to
blow up transatlantic airliners with liquid bombs in al-Qaeda-inspired suicide
attacks on the scale of 9/11.

Judge Richard Henriques said the plot was "the most grave and wicked conspiracy
ever proven within this jurisdiction," as he passed sentence at the top-security
Woolwich Crown Court in southeast London.

"The intention was to perpetrate a terrorist outrage that would stand alongside
the events of Sept. 11, 2001, in history," he said.

The plot, which was foiled in August 2006, triggered the wide-ranging rules now
in place on carrying liquids aboard commercial aircraft.

Abdulla Ahmed Ali, the 28-year-old ringleader, was sentenced to life
imprisonment, with a minimum 40-year term.

The plot's "chemist and quartermaster" Assad Sarwar, 29, must spend a minimum of
36 years behind bars, while fellow plotter Tanvir Hussain, 28, Ali's right-hand
man, must serve at least 32 years.

The trio were told they may never be released.

The counter-terrorism operation to foil the London based plot was the biggest
ever in Britain, costing £35-million ($63-million).

"There is every likelihood that this plot would have succeeded but for the
intervention of the police and the security service," the judge said. "A massive
loss of life would almost certainly have resulted."

The plotters targeted seven flights from London's Heathrow airport to Toronto,
Montreal, New York, Washington, Chicago and San Francisco. The jets would have
exploded in mid-air simultaneously, prosecutors said.

Some of the men recorded "martyrdom videos" featuring threats to the West of
waves of terrorist attacks.

"This was a viable and meticulously planned conspiracy and I conclude it was
imminent," Mr. Justice Henriques said. The plot was "an act of revenge inspired
by extremist Islamic thinking," aimed at the "governments of several allied
forces in Iraq and Afghanistan."

The tighter security measures and restrictions on liquids now seen on flights
worldwide are "entirely attributable to this conspiracy."

The six-month trial was peppered with evidence that the gang was frequently in
communication with al-Qaeda linked figures in Pakistan.

The judge said emails showed "the ultimate control of this conspiracy lay in
Pakistan," saying the plot was run, monitored and funded from there.

They included a coded email sent by Ali to his controller in Pakistan showing
the attack was "imminent." The email was sent to a Birmingham-born man called
Rashid Rauf on Aug. 6, 2006, days before the group's arrest.

On Sept. 7, a jury found Ali, Sarwar and Hussain guilty of conspiracy to murder
by blowing up transatlantic airliners.

Prosecutors said they plotted to drill holes in the bottom of plastic drinks
bottles, drain the contents and inject liquid explosive with a syringe before
sealing the holes with glue. That way the bottle tops would remain unopened.

The home-made liquid explosive was to be concocted from hydrogen peroxide and
Tang, a soft drink available in powdered form.

When mixed with such an organic material at an appropriate strength, hydrogen
peroxide has explosive qualities.

The bottles would be detonated using the substance HTMD, concealed in regular AA
1.5-volt batteries.

The judge said the gang had other targets in their sights, including power
installations.

"You had within your contemplation a campaign of bombing which would have a
devastating effect upon this country," he said.

LOAD-DATE: September 15, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

airliners bound for North America. ;

                             Daily News (New York)

                              SPORTS FINAL EDITION

PLOT SENDS PREZ HOPEFULS RUSHING FOR MICROPHONES

BYLINE: BY CELESTE KATZ DAILY NEWS STAFF WRITER With Adam Lisberg

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 285 words


CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa - The alleged plot to blow up Kennedy Airport reverberated on
the campaign trail here yesterday, as Democratic presidential candidates faced
questions about U.S. vulnerability.

The specter of terrorists igniting an inferno at JFK could increase the 2008
campaign's focus on security, a topic former mayor Rudy Giuliani made a
signature issue. Giuliani has assailed the Democrats as weak on protecting
America.

But the Dems, trying to build support here and distinguish themselves in a
crowded field on the eve of a major New Hampshire debate today, emphasized the
need for a brawny anti-terrorism program.

The JFK incident "raises the seriousness of the ongoing threats that we face and
how we have to remain vigilant and do a good job in securing and defending
ourselves, and I view that as my highest responsibility as a senator and when
I'm President," said Sen. Hillary Clinton (D-N.Y.), the Democratic front-runner.

Some skeptics suggest such plot foilings are played up to distract attention
from problems elsewhere, such as in Iraq - even when the derailed plots were
nowhere close to being executed.

But, Clinton said, "I take all of these plots seriously, unless proven
otherwise. There's no reason to be second-guessing."

Former North Carolina Sen. John Edwards, among others, used the alleged plot to
criticize the Bush administration.

As for Giuliani's warnings about Democratic weakness, Edwards sniped, "Giuliani,
Sen. (John) McCain and others are trying to be bigger, badder versions of George
Bush. They're Bush on steroids" - something he says Americans don't want.

To the disappointment of some in the crowd of over 1,000, Illinois Sen. Barack
Obama wasn't there.

                           Palm Beach Post (Florida)

                              March 6, 2005 Sunday
                                 FINAL EDITION

WHEN IT COMES TO MOVIES, LOOK TO S. FLA. FOR A BLOCKBUSTER PLOT

BYLINE: Frank Cerabino

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. 1C

LENGTH: 447 words


Movies that won't be coming to a theater near you:

Title: Snideways

Plot: Palm Beach County commissioners try bonding with each other by taking a
meandering tour through California's wine country.

Production pitfalls:

Should have used grape juice instead of real wine. If you think they're nasty to
each other when they're sober, you haven't seen anything yet.

Capsule review:

I laughed, I cried, I hoped there would not be a sequel.

Title:

The Sea Inside

Plot:

Palm Beach County residents, paralyzed with fear from last year, remortgage
their homes to install hurricane-proof windows.

Production pitfalls:

Way over budget.

Capsule review:

I laughed, I cried, I called the insurance company.

Title:

Are We There Yet?

Plot:

Family road trip becomes marred by traffic tie-ups on I-95.

Production pitfalls:

None. Road conditions allowed stationary scenes on I-95 to be shot without
needing to close the roadway.

Capsule review:

I laughed, I cried, I reminded myself to get off at Hypoluxo next time.

Title: Being Trump

Plot: A legal thriller about one man's pursuit of full payment from an alleged
billionaire.

Production pitfalls: Everybody in the crew forced to write a letter of apology
for working on the movie.

Capsule review: I laughed, I cried, I got paid upfront.

Title: Paper Clips

Plot:

A documentary about how a Palm Beach County public school collects paper clips
to make up for budget cuts from Tallahassee.

Production pitfalls:

Shooting schedule interrupted because of FCAT preparation.

Capsule review:

I laughed, I cried, I wrote my state representative.

Title:

Finding Neverland

Plot:

Scripps scientists travel to a magical place in Palm Beach County where people
seem to never grow up.

Production pitfalls:

Set location issues created delays.

Capsule review:

I laughed, I cried, I found myself living in a science ghetto.

Title:

Racing Gripes

Plot:

Florida Gov. Jeb Bush campaigns against slot machines and dog and horse racing
tracks in Miami-Dade and Broward counties.

Production pitfalls:

Movie not expected to make a fraction of what the slot machines would bring in.

Capsule review:

I laughed, I cried, I suggested a new referendum to put slot machines on the
bullet train.

Title:

Because of Publix

Plot:

Sequel to movie about a boy and his incredibly intuitive dog, whose name was
sold by Winn-Dixie because of recent financial problems with the supermarket
chain.

Production pitfalls:

Motorized cart accident on Aisle 4.

Capsule review:

I laughed, I cried, I said, "Plastic."

Title:

Star Wars: Episode III, Revenge of the Caterers

Plot:

A social season runs amok in Palm Beach.

Production pitfalls:

Too many people using the force.

Capsule review:

I laughed, I cried, I stayed away from the shellfish.

frank_cerabino@pbpost.com

LOAD-DATE: April 25, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

NOTES:  Ran all editions.

DOCUMENT-TYPE: COLUMN

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                Intelligencer Journal (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

                          February 25, 2009 Wednesday

County Offers Garden Plot Rentals

SECTION: B; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 255  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Lancaster County Department of Parks and Recreation has garden plots available
for rent April 15 through Oct. 15. Renters can apply for a plot as early as
Monday.

Lancaster County residents can select either a 400- or 800-square- foot plot.
Renters pay a one-time fee of $18 for a small plot and $23 for a larger plot.

The garden plots are located off Farm View Drive just off Golf Road in Lancaster
County Central Park.

The plots are ideal for gardeners with limited space at home and great for
groups looking for a summer project.

Organic plots are also available. These are plots that have been free of
pesticides and herbicides for more than three years.

Additionally, the parks department and Penn State Cooperative Extension Master
Gardeners Program are offering garden workshops from 7 to 8:30 p.m. in the
Lancaster County Environmental Center off Eshelman Mill Road.

Workshop dates and topics are:

  March 18, introduction to vegetable gardening.

  April 16, introduction to flower gardening.

  May 19, designing container gardens.

Participants will learn about site selection, soil preparation and plant
selection

There is a $1 fee per workshop, but those who rent a garden plot in Central Park
may attend free of charge.

Pre-registration is required to attend workshops.

To register for a garden plot or workshop, visit the park office in Central Park
located off Chesapeake Street, from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. weekdays or call
299-8215.

For more information about other nature and recreation programs, visit
www.co.lancaster.pa.us/parks.

LOAD-DATE: February 25, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2009 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.


                             127 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Contra Costa Times (California)

                            March 27, 2008 Thursday

Fascinating stories from history emerge in 'Mountain View Cemetery"

BYLINE: By Nilda Rego Correspondent

SECTION: COLUMNISTS; Opinion

LENGTH: 721 words


In 1899, Annie and Paul Glud needed money to help finance the home for destitute
children they were running in Oakland.

Annie did have an untapped asset, and so she used it. She published her own life
story.

She was born Annie Hundley in Kentucky in 1853. Her father enlisted in the Union
Army when the Civil War started, and Annie went with him. She took her brother's
name, donned boys' clothes and passed herself off as a drummer boy for the
entire war.

Not only was she a drummer boy, but she was General Ulysses S. Grant's drummer
boy, and the future president ordered the words "Tommy Hundley, Grant's drummer
boy" printed on her drum.

This is just one of the compelling stories Dennis Evanosky tells in his latest
book, "Mountain View Cemetery." The book is the second in his series "History Is
All Around Us." His first was "Oakland's Laurel District," which appeared last
year, and his next one will be "Alameda's Architectural Treasure Chest," due out
in September.

Evanosky has been a docent at Mountain View Cemetery in Oakland for 11 years,
and received the Oakland Heritage Alliance Partners in Preservation Award for
restoration work on the cemetery's Grand Army of the Republic plot. Part Four of
the cemetery book is devoted to the GAR plot, and the role that Evanosky and his
friends played in renovating it.

He writes that in 2003, he and Eric Kos decided it was time for a face-lift for
the 106-year-old plot. "We began by numbering, naming and researching all the
plot's inhabitants; Phil Moser and Julia Park Tracey joined us." They cleaned
the headstones and uncovered some that they hadn't known existed. Kos mapped the
plot. With the help of Mountain View staffers, they also restored the four
12-pound boat howitzers that are located in the plot.

While working on this project, Evanosky came across the story of Obediah
Summers, a black Civil War veteran who was not buried in the GAR plot, but in
what was known as the unendowed area of the cemetery.

When Summers died in 1896, his family buried him in Plot 39, one of the
cemetery's unendowed areas, which meant the families took full responsibility
for lot maintenance. Over the years, family members died or moved away, and
these unendowed gravesites became overgrown with weeds and bushes. Summers'
gravesite was lost.

Evanosky and his friends searched the cemetery records, and with the cemetery
staff, found Summers' resting place. His granddaughter, Myrna Adams, then
petitioned the cemetery to move Summers to the GAR plot, and in 2005, this was
done.

Summers was born a slave in 1844 in Missouri. In 1864, he enlisted in Company A,
18th Regiment, U.S. Colored Infantry. He fought in the Battle of Nashville.

After the war, he became a preacher and moved to Marysville. In 1890, he moved
to Oakland, built and preached at the Old Bethel Church on 15th Street. He also
served the California State legislature as its first African-American chaplain.

Evanosky's book is easy to read, and besides the fascinating stories, it
includes more than 100 photographs and maps.

He tells how cemeteries changed over the years from the rural or garden cemetery
to the lawn cemetery and finally to the memorial park.

Evanosky is an admitted tapophile, which he indicates means a lover of
cemeteries. He challenges the reader in the pages of his introduction:

"If I told you the city of Oakland has more than 200 acres full of monuments
with wonderful, fascinating stories, would you be interested in visiting?" he
writes.

"If I asked if you'd like to learn more about architecture in an outdoor
park-like setting or if you'd like to meet the people who have shaped our past
and continue to shape our world today, would you still be interested." He then
asks if it would make a difference if the 200 acres were a cemetery.

Evanosky says his purpose in writing the book was to get more people interested
in Mountain View. After reading it and looking at its "then and now" photos, I
would have to say I can't wait to get to that fascinating place at the end of
Piedmont Avenue in Oakland, with his book to guide me. The book is available at
the Contra Costa County History Center, 610 Main St., Martinez; Books Inc.; and
at local bookstores in Alameda and Oakland. It can also be found online.

Nilda Rego's Days Gone By appears Sundays in A&E. Reach her at
nildarego@comcast.net .

LOAD-DATE: April 1, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved

                           Manila Times (Philippines)

                            August 12, 2006 Saturday

MURDER IN THE SKIES

LENGTH: 573 words


THE British discovery of a plot to blow up several aircraft in flight to the
United States using liquid explosives smuggled in hand-carried luggage reminds
us that terrorism remains active and that its perpetrators will go to great
lengths to wreak more horrendous destruction to lives and property.

The British police said they have arrested 21 people in London, Thames Valley
and Birmingham after months of surveillance. They warned that an attack was
imminent and the government has raised its security alert to the highest level.
So has the US Department of Homeland Security whose head said that the plan was
"well advanced" and "suggestive" of a plot by the al-Qaeda terrorist network,
the gang that carried out the September 11 attack on the United States.

Worrisome is the information that there could be other parts of the conspiracy
that have not been discovered and that it has global dimensions. For the
Philippines, this could mean that al-Qaeda operatives here could be hatching
plots similar to, or in connivance with, the London terror-mongers.

The new terrorist plot is bad news for governments, the airline industry,
passengers and aviation-related businesses. Tighter security, fewer passengers
and government regulations could increase fares. Passengers will have to live
with more delays and inconvenience. Airport retail sales will surely suffer.
Higher fares will hurt thousands of Filipinos traveling for work. The damage to
the airline industry, national and regional economies could be costly.

Overriding these concerns is the issue of safety in air travel. The airline plot
is premised on organized suicides to kill thousands simultaneously. The scheme
called for blowing up as many as 10 jetliners at the same time as they flew to
the US. The discovery does not mean the plot will not be carried out.

The threat remains. The possibility that copycats would mimic the idea also
exists.

In Manila the international airport authority has banned passengers bound for
the US from carrying on board liquids or gels of any size, including
toothpaste, hair gel, beverages, shampoo, suntan lotion and cream.

The Philippine government should do more than upgrade security. It should
improve intelligence gathering and strengthen intelligence sharing with foreign
governments. The low regard the foreign intelligence community gives Manila
showed in 1995 when the US intelligence agency played down a major terrorist
plot in Manila.

In 1995 Manila police officers responded to a fire in an Ermita apartment where
they discovered a plot to crash a plane into CIA building in Virginia, bomb US
passenger jets over the Pacific and to assassinate Pope John Paul II on a visit
to Manila.

Ramzi Yousef and Abdul Hakim Murad, who were renting the apartment, were found
in possession of bomb-making materials and a laptop loaded with information. The
al-Qaeda plot was masterminded by Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, who proceeded to
engineer the 9/11 attacks in New York City and Washington, D.C.

The US intelligence agency made little use of the information obtained from the
raid. Yousef was later caught in Pakistan.

President Arroyo should call her advisers on public safety to review the
situation and consider what steps Manila could take to aid the global drive on
terrorism, improve security at the airports and crush domestic terrorism.
Congress should pass the antiterrorism bill after removing provisions that
violate human rights.

                              LNP (Lancaster, PA)

                              March 7, 2016 Monday

Central Park Garden Plots Available Now;
Any Lancaster County Resident Can Apply For Plot, Which Costs Less Than $30

BYLINE: Ad Crable

SECTION: A; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 222  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


ACRABLE@LNPNEWS.COM

Thinking spring, the Lancaster County Department of Parks and Recreation has
opened rentals for garden plots in Lancaster County Central Park.

Plots will again be available for the public from April 15 through Oct. 15.
Those interested may apply for a plot at the park office at 1050 Rockford Road,
Lancaster, or call 299-8215. Office hours are Monday through Friday from 8:30
a.m. to 5 p.m.

Anyone living in Lancaster County may rent the plots. They come in two sizes: 20
feet by 20 feet or 20 feet by 40 feet. Renters pay a one-time seasonal fee of
$22 for a small plot and $27.50 for a larger plot.

The garden plots are located off Farm View Drive just off Golf Road in Central
Park.

Gardeners of all skill levels can rent garden plots to grow their own flowers
and vegetables. The plots are ideal for gardeners with limited space at home or
groups looking for a summer project.

County park naturalist Lisa J. Sanchez, also a Central Park gardener, says,
"Being involved in a community garden plot program provides an opportunity to
meet people and to share gardening techniques, plants and food.

"It's a great idea to grow your own food and choose what you want to plant.
Watching birds and other wildlife in their outdoor habitat is a plus."

For more information about plot rentals, visit www.lancastercountyparks.org.

                             130 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 January 4, 2000, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

2 New Arrests In Investigation Of Bomb Plot

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN WEISER

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 880 words


Two Algerians, one in Brooklyn and the other in Seattle, have been arrested in
the continuing investigation of a terrorist bomb plot. The new arrests came amid
indications that federal authorities are focusing their efforts on a network of
Algerians in New York, Seattle and Boston, officials said yesterday.

The Brooklyn man, Abdelwaheb Hamdouche, was taken into custody Saturday night at
Kennedy International Airport as he was preparing to leave for Paris on a KLM
flight, officials said. Mr. Hamdouche, 34, a naturalized French citizen, was
held as a material witness in the bomb plot investigation, and it is believed
that he was ordered to remain in custody after a closed hearing yesterday in
Federal District Court in Manhattan.

In Seattle, the authorities said they had arrested another Algerian man, Abdel
Hakim Tizegha, on charges of entering the country illegally. He is believed to
be an associate of a man charged last week in the bomb plot, law enforcement
officials said, but he has not been accused of any direct role.

The new arrests on both coasts stem from what the authorities said was a bomb
plot foiled in Seattle last month after the arrest of Ahmed Ressam, an Algerian
who has been linked to a terrorist group.

Mr. Ressam was charged with attempting to smuggle powerful explosives and
sophisticated timing devices in a car he was taking on a ferry across the
Canadian border near Seattle.

While the scope of the investigation into the plot appeared to be growing, many
details of the case remained murky yesterday. It was not clear why the
authorities believed Mr. Hamdouche was a witness. It was also not known why he
had been released without being charged after he was taken into custody last
Thursday during a raid in Brooklyn in which another Algerian, Abdel Ghani, was
arrested on charges of being an accomplice in the bomb plot.

A criminal complaint accused Mr. Ghani of having knowledge of "a terrorist
network of Algerian nationals" that also included Mr. Ressam, and said that he
had planned to travel with Mr. Ressam to Chicago to raise money for the group.

After yesterday's closed hearing, neither a federal prosecutor, David N. Kelley,
nor Mr. Hamdouche's lawyer, Mitchell A. Golub, would comment or even describe
the proceeding.

A federal magistrate judge, Michael H. Dolinger, refused a request by The New
York Times to open the session, and afterward, he would not say why he had
conducted it in secret.

The arrest of Mr. Hamdouche, who lived in the same building as Mr. Ghani,
appeared to be a tactical move seeking to compel his presence before a federal
grand jury or for questioning by federal agents.

The authorities may be hoping to see if Mr. Hamdouche can tell them anything
about Mr. Ghani, and whether he might cooperate in the investigation. In order
for Magistrate Dolinger to detain Mr. Hamdouche, the government had to show that
he was material, or valuable, to the investigation, and that he was a risk to
flee or be unavailable.

No one would say if Mr. Hamdouche had been ordered held, but he did not leave
the courtroom with his defense lawyer as the hearing ended.

The new arrests indicated that law enforcement authorities are continuing to
reel in friends and associates of Mr. Ressam and Mr. Ghani, although the high
degree of secrecy imposed on the case has made it difficult to learn precisely
what the authorities suspect of each man.

The criminal complaint filed against Mr. Tizegha yesterday in federal district
court in Seattle, for example, makes no mention of the bomb plot, nor did
prosecutors discuss any link in a hearing.

But law enforcement officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity said Mr.
Tizegha was believed to have been a longtime friend of Mr. Ghani, and may have
spent time with him in Seattle when Mr. Ghani went there in mid-December to meet
Mr. Ressam. The plot was interrupted when an immigration agent questioned Mr.
Ressam at the border and the explosives were discovered in his car, the
government has charged.

The complaint in Seattle against Mr. Tizegha says he entered the United States
illegally as a stowaway on a ship in 1993, and lived in Boston, where he
formally applied for political asylum.

After his asylum request was rejected, he was ordered deported in 1997, and he
lost an appeal in June of last year. He then disappeared from view of the
authorities, the complaint said, until his arrest the day before Christmas in
Bellevue, Wash., on immigration charges.

His roommate, who was interviewed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation,
revealed that Mr. Tizegha had moved to Seattle in the winter of 1998, and then
went to Vancouver, British Columbia, to apply for refugee status in Canada, the
complaint said.

Last November, he sneaked back into the United States, crossing the border
through the woods at Blaine, Wash., to avoid contact with immigration agents,
the complaint said. The authorities say he then caught a bus in Bellingham,
Wash., which he rode to Seattle. Later, after his arrest, he made a phone call
and asked his roommate to burn the bus ticket he had used to travel to Seattle,
the complaint said.

A federal magistrate judge in Seattle ordered Mr. Tizegha held pending a bail
hearing on Wednesday.

                          Reading Eagle (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            April 24, 2010 Saturday

Good Morning Reader: Unclaimed plots dot cemeteries in the county

BYLINE: Jason Brudereck, Reading Eagle, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 493 words


Apr. 24--Many people know that local and state governments have millions of
dollars worth of unclaimed money that is owed to taxpayers. It's also relatively
well-known that state lotteries have tons of cash that goes unclaimed. But there
is one other prize that many don't know they are owed. And so, you may have
already won a fabulous ... grave? Yes. There are dozens, perhaps hundreds, of
unused grave sites in Berks County that have been bought and gone unused for
decades. The owners and the descendants of those owners have the right to use
those burial plots, but many have not.

So in 1992, the state Legislature made it legal for cemeteries to follow a
process to declare such plots abandoned after 50 years.

"A cemetery is supposed to contact the owner or any known family member by
registered letter and then, if no one responds, advertise the intent to declare
the plot abandoned," said Sandra Burkhart Stief, historian and superintendent at
Aulenbach's Cemetery, an institution established in 1853 on the Reading-Mount
Penn border.

If someone responds to the letter or ad claiming a site with proof, the plot
can't be declared abandoned for another 50 years and, if an owner or heir
surfaces within 30 years of a plot being abandoned, the cemetery has to provide
a free replacement plot, according to the law.

The law is important now more than ever with so many cemeteries struggling to
get enough funds to maintain their grounds and graves, said Christopher M.
Winters, executive assistant to state Rep. Thomas R. Caltagirone, a Reading
Democrat who was instrumental in creating the law.

Cemeteries could either resell the plots or find descendants to use them, for
which cemeteries can then collect a burial fee, Stief said.

At Aulenbach's, a plot is $350, with $250 going toward perpetual care, and
burial is $800, with half going to the excavation company.

In some cases of unused graves, such as when an epidemic wiped out entire
families, there may be no heirs left, Winters said.

Among the thousands of graves at Aulenbach's, there are an unknown number of
plots that could be declared abandoned.

About 20 belong to the Brumbach family, relatives of which visited the cemetery
from Missouri last year and intended to spread information about the plots among
the family.

"Now they know they can be buried with their ancestors," Stief said.

So if you think you have an ancestor who had a burial plot somewhere, contact
that cemetery.

Or if you run a cemetery with plots that have gone unused for half a century,
look into declaring them abandoned, Stief said.

To see more of the Reading Eagle, or to subscribe, go to
http://www.readingeagle.com. Copyright (c) 2010, Reading Eagle, Pa. Distributed
by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                  Times Colonist (Victoria, British Columbia)

                           December 13, 2012 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

Singer Bieber alleged target of mutilation/murder plot

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A12

LENGTH: 192 words

DATELINE: TORONTO


Police in New Mexico are reported to be investigating a macabre plot to mutilate
and kill Canadian pop star Justin Bieber.

The claims of a murder-for-hire plot targeting the singer have not been
confirmed.

A New Mexico media outlet cited unnamed investigators for its report, while the
Toronto Star said Lt. Robert McDonald of the New Mexico State Police told the
newspaper Bieber was a target in a plot that involved three others.

The Canadian singer's management, asked to comment on the reports, released a
statement saying only that they take "every precaution to protect and ensure the
safety of Justin and his fans."

KRQE News in New Mexico reported that police have arrested two men in the United
States in connection with a plot to murder and castrate Bieber.

The alleged plot - which KRQE News says was planned right down to the paisley
tie that would be used to strangle victims - was reportedly foiled after the
would-be hit men were arrested in Vermont on outstanding warrants last month
before any of the killings were carried out.

The station reports that the two men were outed to police by the person who came
up with the plot in the first place.

                       Evening Chronicle (Newcastle, UK)

                           September 8, 2009 Tuesday

Terrorists Guilty Of Plotting To Bring Terror To The Skies

BYLINE: Chris Ward

SECTION: A; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 513 words


THREE Islamic extremists have been convicted over a suicide bomb plot to blow up
transatlantic airliners.

The al Qaeda-inspired terror cell planned to detonate home-made liquid bombs on
flights bound for North American cities.

Abdulla Ahmed Ali, Assad Sarwar and Tanvir Hussain were yesterday found guilty
of conspiracy to murder.

The case followed the largest counter-terrorism operation in the UK.

Sue Hemming, head of the Crown Prosecution Service Counter Terrorism Division,
said: "These men wanted to bring down several aircraft, indiscriminately killing
hundreds of innocent people   perhaps more if they had succeeded in activating
their devices while over cities.

"This was a calculated and sophisticated plot to create a terrorist event of
global proportions."

If the plot had been successful, the explosions could have exceeded the carnage
of the September 11 attacks in New York.

Counter-terrorist police and the security services spent more than £35m foiling
the plot and bringing Ali and the others to justice.

The arrest of the gang in August 2006 sparked tight restrictions on carrying
liquids on to aircraft, which initially caused travel chaos.

Jurors deliberated for more than 50 hours at the end of a six-month trial at
Woolwich Crown Court.

British-born Ali, 28, of Walthamstow, east London, was inspired by the July 7
bombers and Osama bin Laden. He even considered taking his baby son on his
suicide mission.

He planned to smuggle home-made bombs disguised as soft drinks on to passenger
jets. Ali singled out flights to San Francisco, Toronto, Montreal, Washington,
New York and Chicago that departed within two-and-a-half hours of each other.

Police believe an al Qaeda bombmaker was responsible for the liquid bomb design,
concealed within 500ml Oasis or Lucozade bottles.

Ali used cash to buy a £138,000 flat in Walthamstow and converted it into a bomb
factory. It was also used as a location to record suicide videos.

On his arrest, Ali was found to be carrying an elaborate blueprint for the plot
scrawled in a pocket diary.

Airport security arrangements and details of flights were also discovered on a
computer memory stick.

Along with Ali, Sarwar 29, of Walton Drive, High Wycombe, and Hussain, 28, of
Nottingham Road, Leyton, will be sentenced for the airline plot on Monday.

The trio were convicted of conspiracy to murder in the first trial last year but
retried, along with five other men, for the airliner plot after the jury failed
to reach verdicts on those charges.

The jury failed to reach a verdict on Umar Islam, 31, of Bushey Road, Plaistow,
in connection with the  plot. But he was convicted of conspiracy to murder and
will also be sentenced next week.

Three others   Ibrahim Savant, 28, of Denver Road, Stoke Newington, Arafat
Waheed Khan, 28, of Farnan Avenue, Walthamstow, and Waheed Zaman, 25, of Queen's
Road, Walthamstow   were found not guilty and the jury failed to reach verdicts
on charges of conspiracy to murder.

Donald Stewart-Whyte, 23, of High Wycombe, was found not guilty of both
conspiracy to murder on aircraft and conspiracy to murder.

                             134 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                The New York Post

                           September 25, 2016 Sunday

Couldn't spy straight Abe Lincoln's favorite detective agency was inept,
thuggish and let Jesse James get away

BYLINE: MICHAEL RIEDEL

SECTION: All Editions; Pg. 44

LENGTH: 701 words


In February 1861, President-elect Abraham Lincoln was scheduled to travel
through Baltimore by train on his way from Harrisburg, Pa., to Washington, DC.
Shortly before his departure, Lincoln was told of an assassination plot on his
life.

Hatched by Southern sympathizers, the plan was to cause a commotion on the
platform of the Baltimore train station. In the confusion, an assassin would try
to get close to Lincoln and kill him. Lincoln dismissed the report, but he was
eventually persuaded to switch trains in the dead of night. He was then spirited
secretly into the capital.

The man who uncovered the plot? Allan Pinkerton, founder of the now-infamous
Pinkerton's National Detective Agency. His services to Lincoln that night would
draw him close to the US government, allowing Pinkerton - armed with government
contracts and support - to build his agency into a sprawling empire of
espionage, protection, intimidation and even violence.

But was that empire built on a fantasy? Pinkerton may have cooked up the Lincoln
assassination plot to further his career, according to a new book, "Inventing
the Pinkertons" by S. Paul O'Hara.

"There is very little evidence of the plot. It's all based on hearsay," says
O'Hara. In fact, there was as much bungling - including attempts to catch train
robber Jesse James - as boasting in the Pinkerton spy trade. "But," O'Hara
points out, "perhaps better than any other businessman at the time, Pinkerton
understood the power of perception, publicity and branding."

By the end of the Civil War, during which his agency spied on the Confederacy
for Lincoln, Pinkerton and his logo - the all-seeing eye - were famous
throughout America. A "Pinkerton detective" was thought to be a moral guardian
of law and order, even though Pinkerton's business was, says O'Hara, "fairly
disastrous. He screwed up a lot of cases, and much of his spying during the
Civil War was questionable at best."

A barrel maker by trade, Pinkerton was born in Glasgow, Scotland. He was a
radical leftist, agitating for workers' voting rights. When the authorities
struck back, Pinkerton fled to Illinois. An accidental discovery of a ring of
counterfeiters gave him a taste for spying.

His method was to surround a suspect with agents who posed as drinking buddies.
When the suspect finally unburdened himself, the Pinkertons were there to hear
it.

One of the agency's top employees, Kate Warne, was often deployed to befriend
the wife of a suspect in the belief that women couldn't keep secrets. But a lot
of bad guys sleep well at night. And not all women blab. So Pinkerton's methods
hardly made him the 1800s version of Columbo.

Where he did score was with the railroads, which made him one of the richest men
in America. After the Civil War, the railroads became mighty monopolies and
needed to protect trains from robbers, like the crafty Jesse James.

"James outfoxed him all the time," says O'Hara. On Jan. 25, 1875, Pinkerton
agents descended on James' farmhouse in Missouri in the middle of the night. The
plan was to catch him fast asleep. Alas, for all of Pinkerton's vaunted
intelligence-gathering abilities, nobody bothered to tell him James wasn't home.

By the end of the 19th century, many working-class Americans had come to despise
the railroads, which drove farmers off their land and employed Pinkerton men to
infiltrate and bust up unions.

Allan Pinkerton died in 1884. His sons, raised in privilege, aligned the company
even more closely with big business. Soon, armed Pinkertons "became part of
every [worker] strike, shooting into crowds, protecting capitalism," says
O'Hara.

They overplayed their hand during the Homestead Strike of 1892, in Pennsylvania.
Pinkerton men attacked striking steel workers, leaving several dead and injured.

The company staggered along, providing "private security" until it was bought in
1999 by Securitas, a Swedish security conglomerate. Now, the Pinkerton Web site
boasts offices "all over the world." It works in corporate risk management and
mobilizes agents to help clients after natural disasters such as hurricanes
Katrina and Sandy.

At least the Pinkerton all-seeing eye isn't a black one anymore.

LOAD-DATE: September 27, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Pinkerton detectives "screwed up a lot of cases" spying for the
government - but they cashed in protecting the railroads.

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                            March 20, 2010 Saturday
                                  Mich Edition

HOME & GARDEN BRIEFS

SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. D2

LENGTH: 545 words


Tribune needs info for annual guide

Information for the 2009 Farmers Market Guide is being gathered, and a
publication date of May 17 has been set.

Managers of farmers markets in the northwest Indiana and southwest Michigan
areas should send information - including hours, dates, location, phone number
and details about vendors - to Karen Rallo, Features Department, South Bend
Tribune, 225 W. Colfax Ave., South Bend, IN 46626; or e-mail Krallo@sbtinfo.com

Also include a daytime phone number for office use.

Deadline is May 7. No information will be taken over the phone.

Community garden needs gardeners

ELKHART - Elkhart Community Gardens has plots available for those who don't have
land of their own to garden.

Choose a plot to grow your own flowers, vegetables and herbs. There are plots
available at all three community garden locations: Airport Garden, County Road
7; Hudson/Sterling garden, corner of York and Bar streets and a garden at the
Elkhart Environmental Center, 1717 E. Lusher Ave.

Gardeners of all skill levels are welcome and groups such as the Boy Scouts,
Girl Scouts, 4-H, service groups, and school clubs, are encouraged to rent a
plot.

Volunteers are also needed for the annual Spring Garden Prep and Kickoff Day
from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. April 10 at Airport Community Garden.

For information or to register for a plot, contact Megan Kolaczyk at (574)
293-5070.

Natural lawn care program April 10

ELKHART - A healthy lawn means having a balance of a variety of different types
of grasses, forbs and other plants. Learn more about lawn maintenance when the
program "Natural Lawn Care" takes place 3 p.m. April 10 at Elkhart Environmental
Center, 1717 E. Lusher Ave.

Ericka Soumare from the Elkhart County Purdue Cooperative Extension will share
tips and techniques about having a healthy, environmentallyfriendly lawn.

Natural lawn care creates healthy turf by restoring soil quality and using
proper maintenance practices without synthetic fertilizers and pesticides.

Register for the program by calling (574) 293-5070.

Fernwood hosts garden sale

NILES - A Gardener's Rummage Sale will take place during regular visiting hours
March 27 at Fernwood Botanical Garden and Nature Preserve, 13988 Range Line
Road.

Donated garden-related items will be for sale, including garden books,
decorative containers, garden tools, trellises, wheelbarrows, garden carts,
garden ornaments, birdhouses, birdbaths, feeders, garden furniture and more.

If you plan on donating items to be resold, please do not include power
equipment, plant material, pesticides, or plastic production containers.

Items for donation to the sale will be accepted up until 5 p.m. Sunday.

Admission to the sale is free. For information, contact Ruth Semones at the Root
Seller at (269) 422-1849, or Steve at Fernwood at (269) 695-6688.

Club offers garden party suggestions

GRANGER - The Granger Garden Club will host the program "Garden Tea Party Ideas
Featuring Herbs and Unusual Perennials," 9:15 a.m. April 7.

The program will feature Ester Benedict of Benedict's Nursery.

Guests are asked to wear a garden hat to the free presentation in the meeting
room at St. Pius X Church, 52553 Fir Road. Entrance to the meeting area can be
accessed through the courtyard area at the back of the church.

                             136 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                  Daily Record

                             July 8, 2006, Saturday

TERROR PLOT TO FLOOD NEW YORK;
POLICE SMASH BID TO BLOW UP TUNNELS

BYLINE: By Rachel Williams

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 383 words


TERRORISTS planned to blow up a tunnel and flood New York's financial district.

The FBI yesterday said they had smashed a plot to attack the city's transport
networks.

One suspect, said by a senior Lebanese security official to be a member of
al-Qaeda, was arrested in Lebanon over the claims.

FBI agents uncovered the plot as they monitored internet chat rooms used by
extremists.

A New York newspaper said their target was the Holland Tunnel, between Manhattan
and New Jersey.

Sources said they wanted to cause as much damage as Hurricane Katrina did in New
Orleans.

In a joint statement, the FBI and the Department of Homeland Security said: "We
have disrupted a terrorist network that was in the planning stages of an attack.

"At this point in time, there is no specific or credible information that
al-Qaeda is planning an attack on US soil."

Authorities in Lebanon acted on a US request to arrest a suspect identified as
Amir Andalousli.

A Lebanese official said the Beirut native, real name is Assem Hammoud, admitted
the plot after his arrest a month ago.

Other arrests are believed to have been made elsewhere. New York congressman
Peter King said cops had monitored a plot to attack New York's transport system
for at least eight months.

He said: "There was nothing imminent. It was being monitored for a long period
of time."

Experts said it was unlikely the Wall Street area could be flooded because it is
above the level of the Hudson River.

The Holland Tunnel is also protected by bedrock, concrete and cast-iron steel.

Last month, seven men were arrested, accused of planning to blow up Chicago's
Sears Tower.

Meanwhile, footage of 7/7 suicide bomber Shehzad Tanweer was broadcast on the
internet yesterday.

The images, different from those shown on Al-Jazeera on Thursday, showed the
22-year-old, of Beeston, Yorkshire, accusing his country of declaring war on
Islam.

He said: "Britons continue to oppress our mothers and children, brothers and
sisters."

Glancing down at his text, he added: "I tell every British citizen to stop your
support to your lying British government and to the so-called war on terror.

"And ask yourselves why would thousands of men be ready to give their lives for
the cause of Muslims?"

Tanweer killed seven people and himself on a train at Aldgate.

WALK OF COURAGE: PAGES 8&9

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                US Official News

                            March 1, 2017 Wednesday

Head Line: US Federal Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture (Minnesota)
Issues Solicitation for "Forest Inventory and Analysis (FIA) Data Collection
Services, Black Hills National Forest Intensification and Acceleration Plots"

LENGTH: 334  words

DATELINE: New York


WASHINGTON: Department of Agriculture, Forest Service officer has issued
requirement for "Forest Inventory and Analysis (FIA) Data Collection Services,
Black Hills National Forest Intensification and Acceleration Plots"

Solicitation No: AG-3604-S-17-0012

Notice Type: Solicitation
Posted Date: February 28, 2017

Description: The USDA Forest Service, Northern Research Station intends to
initiate a Request for Proposal (RFP) procurement action and award a negotiated,
Firm-Fixed Price incentive contract for data collection of intensified and
accelerated plots on the Black Hills National Forest. The Contractor shall
provide inventory data to the USDA Forest Service, Northern Research Station's
Forest Inventory and Analysis (FIA) Unit. This data will be collected from
predetermined forest inventory plots randomly located on the Black Hills
National Forest in South Dakota. This contract will not include plots on the
Black Hills National Forest in Wyoming. The protocols for this effort, including
the inventory plot design, are outlined and described in the following Field
Guides:


\x95 NRS Regional P2 Field Guide Version 7.1
The acquisition will be solicited using the procurement process prescribed in
Part 12, Commercial Items, of the Federal Acquisition Regulations (FAR), in
conjunction with the policies and procedures for solicitation, evaluation and
award prescribed in Part 13, Simplified Acquisition Procedures; and Part 15,
Contracting by Negotiation. A Firm-Fixed-Price contract will be awarded for a
Base Period (from approximately May 1, 2017 to October 31, 2017); and one (1)
six-month Option Period from approximately May 1, 2018 to October 31, 2018 to
the offeror whose offer, conforming to the solicitation, falls within the
competitive price range.

Set Aside: Total Small Business

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 115

Contact Details: 1992 Folwell Avenue - Acquisition Management St. Paul,
Minnesota 55108

Point of Contact(s): Maria T. Evans mtevans@fs.fed.us Phone: 610-557-4040

                                US Official News

                            February 6, 2017 Monday

Head Line: US Federal Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture (Minnesota)
Issues Solicitation for "Forest Inventory and Analysis (FIA) Data Collection
Services, Black Hills National Forest Intensification and Acceleration Plots"

LENGTH: 501  words

DATELINE: New York


WASHINGTON: Department of Agriculture, Forest Service officer has issued
requirement for "Forest Inventory and Analysis (FIA) Data Collection Services,
Black Hills National Forest Intensification and Acceleration Plots"

Solicitation No: AG-3604-S-17-0012

Notice Type: Presolicitation
Posted Date: February 6, 2017

Description: The USDA Forest Service, Northern Research Station intends to
initiate a Request for Proposal (RFP) procurement action and award a negotiated,
Firm-Fixed Price incentive contract for data collection of intensified and
accelerated plots on the Black Hills National Forest. The Contractor shall
provide inventory data to the USDA Forest Service, Northern Research Station's
Forest Inventory and Analysis (FIA) Unit. This data will be collected from
predetermined forest inventory plots randomly located on the Black Hills
National Forest in South Dakota. This contract will not include plots on the
Black Hills National Forest in Wyoming. The protocols for this effort, including
the inventory plot design, are outlined and described in the following Field
Guides:


\x95 NRS Regional P2 Field Guide Version 7.1
The acquisition will be solicited using the procurement process prescribed in
Part 12, Commercial Items, of the Federal Acquisition Regulations (FAR), in
conjunction with the policies and procedures for solicitation, evaluation and
award prescribed in Part 13, Simplified Acquisition Procedures; and Part 15,
Contracting by Negotiation. A Firm-Fixed-Price contract will be awarded for a
Base Period (from approximately May 1, 2017 to October 31, 2017); and one (1)
six-month Option Period from approximately May 1, 2018 to October 31, 2018 to
the offeror whose offer, conforming to the solicitation, falls within the
competitive price range.
The Government will award the contract resulting from this solicitation to the
responsible offeror whose proposal, conforming to the RFP will be the Best Value
to the Government. The award may be made to a superior offeror which is not the
lowest offered price, but which is significantly more technically advantageous
than the lowest offer so as to justify the payment of a higher price. The
evaluation factors listed in descending order of importance are: Factor 1 -
Experience and Qualifications of Contractor and Key Personnel; Factor 2 - Past
Performance; Factor 3 - Capability to Perform; and Factor 4 - Cost. Factors 1
and 2 are of equal weighting; Factors 1, 2, and 3 are significantly more
important than price; however price will contribute substantially to the
selection decision. Award of the contract will be made as a whole to the offeror
whose proposal conforms to all requirements of the specifications and is the
"greatest value" to the Government, cost and other factors considered.

Set Aside: Total Small Business

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 115

Minnesota 55108

                             140 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)

                              June 14, 2002 Friday
                                  Late Edition

Dirty bomb alert was over the top, White House admits

BYLINE: Gay Alcorn, Herald Correspondent, in Washington

SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 456 words


Faced with accusations that the dirty bomb plot announced this week was
exaggerated for political purposes, the White House is now acknowledging that
the threat was minimal.

An alarmed Bush Administration has reprimanded the Attorney-General, John
Ashcroft, over his remarks, according to a leak to the USA Today newspaper.

Mr Ashcroft, in announcing the detention of Abdullah al Muhajir, said that
authorities had "disrupted an unfolding terrorist plot to attack the United
States by exploding a radioactive dirty bomb".

The next day, the Deputy Defence Secretary, Paul Wolfowitz, softened this,
saying: "I don't think there was actually a plot beyond some fairly loose talk
and [Muhajir's] coming in here obviously to plan further deeds."

The White House has released no evidence of a dirty bomb plot, saying only that
Muhajir had suggested to al-Qaeda leaders in Pakistan and Afghanistan a
radioactive attack and conventional strikes. He was then allegedly sent to the
US to scout for targets.

Law enforcement officials told USA Today they doubted whether Muhajir, a US
citizen who was born Jose Padilla, had the equipment or know-how to develop a
dirty bomb, in which conventional explosives are wrapped with radioactive
material.

Mr Ashcroft also appeared to overstate the likely impact of such a bomb, saying
it could cause "mass death and injury". Experts assured jittery Americans that
the number of deaths would probably be small, and that the greatest impact would
be panic.

Administration officials rejected suggestions by some Congress members that the
timing of Mr Ashcroft's announcement had been designed to bolster President
George Bush's proposal for a new Department of Homeland Security and to
neutralise criticism of the FBI and the CIA.

"These very few people who want to make such an outlandish political accusation
represent the most cynical among the most partisan," the White House spokesman,
Ari Fleischer, said. "And they're not to be taken seriously."

The announcement of Muhajir's arrest at O'Hare Airport in Chicago on May 8 was
delayed for more than a month.

The Democratic majority leader in the Senate, Tom Daschle, said there "may have
been a rush to bring it before the news media" to counter the recent criticism
of the CIA and FBI for failing to anticipate the September 11 attacks.

The Democrats are very cautious about criticising the popular President over his
handling of the war on terrorism, for fear of a public backlash.

The White House has declared Muhajir an enemy combatant, meaning he is denied
the right to a lawyer or a trial, and can be held until hostilities end.

The US does not believe that it has enough evidence to prove the dirty bomb
charge and is fearful of compromising intelligence sources.
