                                   USA TODAY

                      July 30, 1993, Friday, FINAL EDITION

FBI probing bombings, riot plot

BYLINE: Margaret L. Usdansky

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 420 words


The FBI is investigating possible links between the West Coast bombings of NAACP
offices and a synagogue and a plot to incite a Los Angeles race riot, agents
said Thursday.

"We are certainly trying to determine whether there is a connection," said FBI
Special Agent Tom Griffin of the bureau's Sacramento office.

Three supremacists were arrested Wednesday in connection with the July 20
bombing of an NAACP office in Tacoma, Wash.

Thursday, a federal grand jury in Los Angeles indicted Christopher David Fisher,
Christian and Doris Nadal and Christopher Berwick on charges of manufacturing,
possessing and selling firearms in connection with the race riot plot.

NAACP Executive Director Benjamin Chavis urged White House officials Thursday to
make "a coordinated federal effort" to investigate possible links among all the
events.

Chavis said the NAACP has placed security guards at its major branches and is
"on its highest alert since 1963" when civil rights leader Medgar Evers was
killed in Mississippi.

Arrested for the Tacoma bombing were Jeremiah Knesal, 19, of Auburn, Wash.,
Wayne Wooten, 19, of Tacoma and Mark Kowaalski, 24, of Miami.

Knesal and Wooten were arrested by Salinas, Calif., police for shoplifting. They
were charged Thursday in San Jose federal court with making and possessing
illegal explosives.

Knesal and Wooten were part of a planned terror campaign against Jewish
organizations and military facilities, the FBI said.

Despite the arrests, Chavis expressed concern over the possibility of a much
larger conspiracy.

"It appears to be a very well-organized right-wing movement," he said.

On July 8, a fire was started outside the NAACP office in San Francisco.

On July 15, the FBI announced the arrests of eight suspects in an unsuccessful
plot to bomb a Los Angeles church in order to ignite a race riot.

Then came the firebombing in Tacoma, causing minor damage to the NAACP office.

Monday, a bottle with a gasoline-soaked rag caused a fire on the lawn of
Congregation B'Nai Israel in Sacramento. Also, a firebomb destroyed the NAACP's
office, less than a mile away.

Griffin said investigators are concerned about the "similarity in the targets"
and the close timing of the events.

Thursday, Sacramento NAACP chapter president Nate White said he hoped to rebuild
the office despite threats from an unidentified caller to a local TV station to
bomb the site again.

"The NAACP is not a building. The NAACP is a movement, and you can't kill a
movement," White said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO, b/w, AP

                             142 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                  Asian Image

                                  July 8, 2010

Three found guilty of airline plot

SECTION: UK NEWS (UK)

LENGTH: 283 words


Three men were found guilty of conspiring to murder hundreds of people in a
terrorist attack.

Ibrahim Savant, Arafat Waheed Khan and Waheed Zaman were convicted by a jury at
Woolwich Crown Court.

The three men were among eight tried in connection with an al Qaida-inspired
plot to detonate homemade liquid bombs on transatlantic jets.

They were cleared by a jury of their role in targeting aeroplanes but put on
trial again to face charges of conspiracy to murder.

A Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) spokesman said the jury found all three men
guilty.

Savant, of Denver Road, Stoke Newington, Khan, of Farnan Avenue, Walthamstow,
and Zaman, of Queen's Road, Walthamstow, will be sentenced tomorrow.

Abdulla Ahmed Ali, of Walthamstow, Assad Sarwar, of High Wycombe, and Tanvir
Hussain, of Leyton, were found guilty of the airline bomb plot last year.

The al Qaida-inspired plot led by Ali involved smuggling liquid bombs in drinks
bottles on to planes bound for North America.

The hydrogen peroxide devices would have been assembled and detonated in mid-air
by a team of suicide bombers.

Ali singled out seven flights to San Francisco, Toronto, Montreal, Washington,
New York and Chicago that departed within two and a half hours of each other.

If successful, the explosions could have exceeded the carnage of the September
11 attacks.

Counter-terrorist police and the security services spent more than £35 million
foiling the plot and bringing Ali and the others to justice.

The arrest of the gang in August 2006 sparked tight restrictions on carrying
liquids on to aircraft which initially caused travel chaos.

The jury rejected the defence of Ali, Sarwar, and Hussain that the plot was an
elaborate publicity stunt.

                             143 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 July 17, 1997, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

Lawyer Challenges Testimony Linking Gigante to Gotti Plot

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

SECTION: Section B; Page 2; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 506 words


A lawyer for Vincent Gigante, the man the Government says is chief of the
Genovese crime family, showed yesterday that a witness's testimony linking Mr.
Gigante to a plot to kill another mob boss was not mentioned in a Government
report of the witness's original account to the F.B.I.

The discrepancy and others like it were brought up in an attempt by Mr.
Gigante's defense to undercut the testimony that the witness, Alphonse D'Arco, a
former mobster turned Government informer, provided against Mr. Gigante during
his two days on the stand in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

Mr. Gigante is on trial there on murder and racketeering charges, accused of
ordering seven killings and conspiring in several other murder plots that were
not carried out. One failed plot, the prosecution charges, was a conspiracy to
kill John Gotti, then the boss of the Gambino crime family.

Mr. D'Arco testified Tuesday that in 1990 he had agreed to help kill Mr. Gotti
with a remote-control bomb. He said he had not dealt with Mr. Gigante in the
plot but with another top mobster, Vittorio Amuso, then head of still another
Mafia family, the Lucchese group. Mr. Amuso, Mr. D'Arco testified, had said at
the time that Mr. Gigante knew about the plot, thus suggesting that Mr. Gigante
sanctioned it.

But in cross-examining Mr. D'Arco yesterday, the defense lawyer produced a
Federal Bureau of Investigation report of a 1993 interview with Mr. D'Arco that
does not quote him as saying he had been told that Mr. Gigante knew of the plot.
Confronted with the report by the lawyer, Michael A. Marinaccio, Mr. D'Arco
insisted that the report was wrong because he had told the agents who
interviewed him about Mr. Amuso's statement regarding Mr. Gigante.

That became a refrain: in various instances when Mr. Marinaccio produced F.B.I.
reports of Mr. D'Arco's accounts that differed from his trial testimony, Mr.
D'Arco responded that the reports were wrong or incomplete.

"I can't be responsible for what they wrote down," he said.

Mr. D'Arco, 64, said he hoped his prosecution testimony in this and earlier
Mafia trials would help him avoid a life sentence for the killings he has
participated in.

Today, in what lawyers in the case said appeared to be a first in the Federal
courts, a former Genovese family associate named Peter Savino is to testify by
closed-circuit television. He is suffering from advanced cancer, and Judge Jack
B. Weinstein has agreed with the prosecution's contention that Mr. Savino is too
ill to travel to the Brooklyn court from an undisclosed out-of-state location in
the witness protection program. He will be seen and heard on television monitors
in the courtroom as he answers questions from a prosecutor and defense lawyer in
the courtroom.

One defense lawyer, Steven R. Kartagener, said it appeared that Mr. Savino would
be the first adult witness to testify this way in a Federal criminal trial. The
judge cited instances in which previously recorded testimony has been played in
Federal trials.

LOAD-DATE: July 17, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                     Sunday News (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

                              March 1, 2009 Sunday

Rent A Garden Plot

SECTION: G; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 251  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


The Lancaster County Department of Parks and Recreation has garden plots
available for rent April 15-Oct. 15. Renters can apply for a plot as early as
Monday, March 2.

Lancaster County residents can select either a 20-by-20-foot or 20-by-40-foot
plot. Renters pay a one-time fee of $18 for a small plot, $23 for a larger plot.
The garden plots are located off Farm View Drive just off Golf Road in Lancaster
County Central Park.

Gardeners of all skill levels can rent garden plots to grow their own flowers
and vegetables. Organic plots are also available. These are plots that have been
free of pesticides and herbicides for more than three years.

Additionally, the Lancaster County Department of Parks and Recreation, and Penn
State Cooperative Extension Master Gardeners Program are offering a variety of
garden workshops. Sessions take place from 7-8:30 p.m. and will be held in the
Lancaster County Environmental Center off Eshelman Mill Road in Central Park.

Workshop dates and topics will be discussed at 7 p.m. Tuesday, March 18, and
will be launched that date with an introduction to vegetable gardening.
Participants can learn about site selection, soil preparation and plant
selection.

There is a $1 fee per workshop, but those who rent a garden plot in Central Park
may attend free of charge. Preregistration is required to attend workshops. To
register for a garden plot or workshop, visit the park office between 8:30
a.m.-5 p.m. Monday-Friday, in Central Park, off Chesapeake Street, or call
299-8215.

LOAD-DATE: March 2, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved


                             145 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             The New Zealand Herald

                           February 18, 2014 Tuesday

Feds want shoe bomb plotter to testify

SECTION: NEWS; World

LENGTH: 714 words


NEW HAVEN, Connecticut (AP) Federal prosecutors want a man convicted in a failed
2001 shoe bomb plot to bring down an airplane to testify at the sentencing of
two British citizens who pleaded guilty in Connecticut to supporting terrorists
through websites.

The testimony reflects an effort by prosecutors to show that Babar Ahmad, one of
the two men facing sentencing in Connecticut, had an active role in sending
recruits to terrorism training camps beyond appealing for support on the
websites.

Prosecutors say the witness is expected to testify that Ahmad sent him to
Afghanistan to train for violent jihad and that he ultimately moved on from
Ahmad and came under the mentorship and training of al-Qaida members who
prepared him for the shoe bomb plot. The man also is expected to testify that he
saw nearly two dozen others that Ahmad sent from the United Kingdom to train in
Afghanistan, and he would describe camping trips and training exercises that
Ahmad organized in England to groom recruits for violent jihad abroad,
prosecutors said.

"Ahmad"s conduct went beyond cyberspace and included real world effects and
consequences flowing from the criminal activity, regardless of the media used to
plan, coordinate and execute some of the conduct," prosecutors wrote in court
papers last week, citing his efforts to send people to Afghanistan to train for
violent jihad and emails discussing night vision goggles and safe routes into
Afghanistan.

Ahmad"s attorneys say they"ll respond in court objecting to the request to have
the man testify by a videotaped deposition.

Prosecutors didn"t name the man they want to testify, but his description
matches that of Saajid Badat, a British citizen whose videotaped testimony was
shown at the 2012 New York City trial of a man convicted in a foiled plot to
attack the New York City subway system in 2009. A spokesman for the prosecutors
declined to comment to The Associated Press on the witness"s identity.

Badat was convicted in London in a plot to down an American Airlines flight from
Paris to Miami with explosives hidden in his shoes. He said at that trial that
he refused a request to testify in person in the U.S. because he remains under
indictment in Boston on charges he conspired with failed shoe bomber Richard
Reid and has been told he"d be arrested if he set foot in the United States.

Prosecutors said the man they want to testify at Ahmad"s sentencing had
testified by videotape at the trial for the foiled subway plot, was indicted in
Massachusetts on charges related to the shoe bomb plot, refuses to testify in
the U.S. and expects to be arrested upon arrival in the country.

Reid was caught aboard a plane with explosives; Badat backed out.

Badat was sentenced to 13 years in prison. But British authorities later said
that in 2009, a judge secretly reduced his sentence to 11 years to reward him
for his cooperation in terror investigations.

Ahmad and Syed Talha Ahsan pleaded guilty in December to terrorism charges.
Ahmad admitted he sought recruits, cash and equipment such as gas masks for the
Taliban regime in Afghanistan through the websites.

The two men, who were living in Britain at the time, faced charges in
Connecticut because authorities said they used an Internet service provider in
the state to run one of the websites.

A prosecutor said Ahsan traveled to Afghanistan with Ahmad"s assistance to fight
and attend a training camp run by al-Qaida, but Ahsan didn"t admit that.

The cooperating witness, believed to be Badat, is expected to testify that Ahmad
originally recruited and radicalized him before sending him to the camp in
Afghanistan. He said he took an explosives training class with Ahsan and stayed
at a safe house in Kandahar in January 2001 during which Osama bin Laden visited
the location multiple times, prosecutors said.

Prosecutors acknowledge that Ahmad and Ashan will dispute his testimony.

"Accordingly, it is important for the court to hear from the witness to make its
own assessment, to understand the full scope and nature of the defendants"
conduct supporting terrorists, and ultimately, to resolve significant
anticipated factual disputes in connection with sentencing," prosecutors wrote.

Ahmad faces up to 25 years in prison and Ahsan faces up to 15 when they are
sentenced in July.

LOAD-DATE: February 18, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                     Copyright 2014 The New Zealand Herald
                              All Rights Reserved


                             146 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                       MX

                            February 10, 2006 Friday
                               Melbourne Edition

LA tower was next jettarget

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 337  words


PLOT DETAILS

US President George W. Bush today disclosed new details of a thwarted al-Qaida
plot to use shoe bombs to hijack an airliner and fly it into a Los Angeles
building.

As critics questioned the legality of Bush authorising a domestic spying
program, the President used declassified details of a previously disclosed plot
to show the threat of terrorism has not abated.

Bush said that in early 2002 the US and its allies thwarted a plot to use bombs
hidden in shoes to breach the cockpit door of a plane and fly it into the
tallest building in LA.

But he named the wrong building.

''We believe the intended target was Liberty Tower in Los Angeles, California,''
Bush said.

White House aides later said he meant Library Tower.

The 310m Library Tower is now known as US Bank Tower, but locally it is still
mostly called by the old name because of its proximity to the city's central
library.

Last October, the Bush administration had disclosed the plot to attack targets
on the West Coast using hijacked planes, saying this was among 10 disrupted
al-Qaida plots.

Bush today said that in October 2001, Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, the operational
mastermind of the September 11 attacks that year, had set in motion a plot for
another attack inside the US to hijack a plane and fly it into the tallest
building on the US west coast.

''Rather than use Arab hijackers as he had on September 11, Khalid Sheikh

Mohammed sought out young men from South-East Asia he believed would not arouse
as much suspicion,'' Bush said.

Mohammed was captured in Pakistan in March 2003 and has since been held at an
undisclosed location.

In his speech, Bush praised the efforts of Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf
in fighting terrorism.

Bush has been fighting criticism of his decision to authorise the National
Security Agency to eavesdrop without court warrants inside the US on
international emails and phone calls placed to and from people with suspected
ties to terrorism.

He has said it is a necessary tool for preventing another attack on the US.

                             Sydney MX (Australia)

                            February 10, 2006 Friday
                                  SYD Edition

LA tower was next jettarget

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 337  words


PLOT DETAILS

US President George W. Bush today disclosed new details of a thwarted al-Qaida
plot to use shoe bombs to hijack an airliner and fly it into a Los Angeles
building.

As critics questioned the legality of Bush authorising a domestic spying
program, the President used declassified

details of a previously disclosed plot to show the threat of terrorism has not
abated.

Bush said that in early 2002 the US and its allies thwarted a plot to use bombs
hidden in shoes to breach the cockpit door of a plane and fly it into the
tallest building in LA.

But he named the wrong building.

''We believe the intended target was Liberty Tower in Los Angeles, California,''
Bush said.

White House aides later said he meant Library Tower.

The 310m Library Tower is now known as US Bank Tower, but locally it is still
mostly called by the old name because of its proximity to the city's central
library.

Last October, the Bush administration had disclosed the plot to attack targets
on the West Coast using hijacked planes, saying this was among 10 disrupted
al-Qaida plots.

Bush today said that in October 2001, Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, the operational
mastermind of the September 11 attacks that year, had set in motion a plot for
another attack inside the US to hijack a plane and fly it into the tallest
building on the US west coast.

''Rather than use Arab hijackers as he had on September 11, Khalid Sheikh
Mohammed sought out young men from South-East Asia he believed would not arouse
as much suspicion,'' Bush said.

Mohammed was captured in Pakistan in March 2003 and has since been held at an
undisclosed location.

In his speech, Bush praised the efforts of Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf
in fighting terrorism.

Bush has been fighting criticism of his decision to authorise the National
Security Agency to eavesdrop without court warrants inside the US on
international emails and phone calls placed to and from people with suspected
ties to terrorism.

He has said it is a necessary tool for preventing another attack on the US.

                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

                 March 31, 1994 Thursday MORNING FINAL EDITION

HOW TO FIND A LITTLE PLOT OF GARDEN TO CALL YOUR OWN

BYLINE: Mercury News Staff Report

SECTION: GARDEN; Pg. 3D

LENGTH: 376 words


FOLKS who want to garden, but have no space to call their own, can get their
hands on community garden plots.

Some plots are open at local gardens for San Jose residents. For details on
obtaining a plot, call John Dotter, garden programs supervisor, at (408)
277-2575.

Santa Clara also has a new community garden with 50 plots available at 1840
Benton St. This is the site of the Educational Options campus, which includes
the Santa Clara Unified School District's adult school. It's the old Wilson
Junior High School.

When a resident signs up for Santa Clara gardening classes, which start next
week, the gardener is also assigned a 5-foot-by-20-foot plot for growing flowers
and vegetables. For information, call Educational Options at (408) 984-6220.

A WILD MONTH: Coyote Point Museum in San Mateo will launch April Wildflower
Month with a special show Saturday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Attractions include
tours, slide shows, lectures and demonstrations, co-sponsored by the museum and
California Native Plant Society.

In the coming month, docents will lead Wildflower Habitat garden tours at 1 p.m.
each Saturday and Sunday to identify flowers and share landscaping tips using
native plants.

Also scheduled: Cindy Nelson of City Worms, on worm composting, 1 p.m. April 16;
beekeeper Tom von Tersh, on bee history and beekeeping, 1 p.m. April 23; John
Steiner of San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge, on butterfly gardening, 1
p.m. April 24.

California Native Plant Society members also will hold wildflower tours at San
Bruno Mountain, 10 a.m. April 10, and at Edgewood Park in Redwood City, 9:30
a.m. April 30. Cost for the tours is $3 for museum and CNPS members, $8 for
non-members.

For details and registration for any of the programs, call the museum at (415)
342-7755.

FLOWERS WITH CLASS: Bob Will, one of the top flower experts in the Bay Area,
will be teaching a class, "Floral Design for Beginners," starting Monday at
Foothill College in Los Altos Hills.

The class, which includes plant information, will run from 6 to 9 p.m. Mondays
for 10 weeks. Will is a longtime instructor with Foothill's Ornamental
Horticulture department who really knows his flowers. For more information, call
(415) 949-7402.

LOAD-DATE: October 25, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

NOTES: Send Getting Out items to Garden Editor Joan Jackson at 750 Ridder Park
Drive, San Jose 95190; or fax (408) 920-5244. Or call the California Relay
Service, 1-800-735-2922, and tell the operator that you wish place a TDD call to
Joan Jackson at (408) 920-5518.

                             149 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                  Guardian.com

                          September 29, 2011 Thursday

FBI faces entrapment questions over Rezwan Ferdaus bomb plot arrest

BYLINE: Paul Harrisguardian.co.uk

LENGTH: 1111 words

ABSTRACT

Sting operation to arrest physics graduate, 26, raises concerns that US Muslims
might be targeted using entrapment techniques

FULL TEXT

The dramatic arrest of a man in Massachusetts accused of plotting to crash
explosive-filled miniature airplanes into the US Capitol and the Pentagon has
sparked fresh concerns that the FBI might be using entrapment techniques aimed
at Muslims in America.

Rezwan Ferdaus, a 26-year-old US citizen and physics graduate who lived at home
with his parents in Ashland, near Boston, was the target of an FBI sting in
which he bought a miniature aircraft that he planned to outfit as a flying bomb.

However, some legal organisations and Muslim groups have questioned whether
Ferdaus, whose activities were carried out with two undercover FBI agents posing
as terrorists, would have been able to carry out such a sophisticated plot if
left to his own devices. In numerous previous cases in the US, the FBI has been
accused of over-zealousness in its investigations and of entrapping people into
terror plots who might otherwise not have carried out an attack.

"It deeply concerns us. It is another in a pattern of high-profile cases. Would
this person have conceived or executed this plot without the influence of the
FBI?" said Heidi Boghosian, president of the National Lawyers Guild.

The Council on American-Islamic Relations also expressed its concern and
wondered if more details would later emerge at trial that showed the full scale
of the FBI involvement in setting up the sting. "There is a big, big difference
between a plot initiated by the FBI and a plot initiated by a suspect, and it
seems this might have been initiated by the FBI," said Ibrahim Hooper, CAIR's
director of communications.

The lengthy affidavit filed by prosecutors against Ferdaus details an elaborate
plot in which he repeatedly expressed his desire to kill Americans and his
support for Islamic jihad. The affidavit showed he came up with a detailed plan
of attack and even scouted his targets in Washington in person. He also built
mobile phone "detonators" that he supplied to undercover FBI agents posing as
al-Qaida terrorists and expressed his pleasure when told him they had been used
to kill American soldiers in Iraq.

However, it also contains some areas of concern. Few details are given as to how
Ferdaus came to the attention of the FBI. Mention is only made of a co-operating
witness, known as CW, who met Ferdaus in December 2010 and soon began recording
his conversations.

No details are given as to CW's identity, but it is mentioned that he or she has
a criminal record and has served time in prison. That raises the prospect that
the CW may have had some ulterior motive to bring an alleged terror suspect to
the attention of the FBI or could be an unreliable witness.

Another potential area of concern is a meeting on 19 April 2011, when the
undercover agents met with Ferdaus and questioned the "feasibility" of his plan.
That raises the prospect that the FBI agents were somehow goading Ferdaus into
more action. "Ferdaus responded in a defensive manner that he had made
progress," the affidavit stated.

At the same meeting the undercover agents also gave financial assistance for
Ferdaus to travel to Washington on a scouting trip: a fact that raises the
question of whether he would have made the trip without that financial help. The
undercover agents also supplied thousands of dollars in cash for Ferdaus to buy
the F-86 Sabre miniature plane to be used in an attack.

Another portion of the affidavit also details Ferdaus's enthusiasm for making
mobile phone detonation devices that he believed were being sent to Iraq and
used by terrorists. Ferdaus suggested sending a box of 50 mobile phones to war
zones where terrorists were in need of them. He even wanted to set up a sort of
workshop to produce up to 30 of the devices a week.

"Ferdaus indicated that he could write instructions or make a video on how to
construct the cell phone detonation devices," the affidavit said. Such an
apparently outlandish idea that hinges on the idea that Islamic terrorists are
desperately short of cheap mobile phones might suggest Ferdaus was, to some
extent, a fantasist rather than a genuine threat.

However, some legal experts said that the case against Ferdaus appeared
compelling, especially as he frequently and repeatedly indicated his desire and
willingness to carry out terrorist attacks against Americans. In trying to mount
a successful defence of entrapment it is vital to prove that a suspect has no
pre-disposition to the crime they are accused of doing. In the Ferdaus case that
would seem to be difficult, lawyers said.

"He took the weaponry and agreed to do it. That demonstrates a propensity and
willingness to do it," said Anthony Barkow, a former terrorism prosecutor and
executive director of the Center on the Administration of Criminal Law at New
York University.

Barkow defended the FBI investigation and said that the US authorities took
careful steps to avoid the issue of entrapment. "The Justice Department is very
aware of this issue," he said.

Certainly the affidavit against Ferdaus paints a compelling picture of a man
hellbent on waging jihad in America and eager to take the guns and explosives
eventually supplied to him by the undercover FBI agents. He repeatedly states in
recorded conversations that he is happy for Americans to die and that the idea
for the attack was his own. "That's excellent," Ferdaus said when told one of
his phone detonators had been used overseas and had killed Americans.

The prosecution case also reveals how Ferdaus ordered the plane and rented a
storage facility in which to keep it and then took delivery from the FBI agents
of 25 pounds of C-4 explosives, three grenades and six AK-47 rifles. It also
shows Ferdaus explaining how he had become convinced that he needed to attack
America after viewing jihadist websites online. "I just can't stop; there is no
other choice for me," he said of his decision to launch the attacks.

Prosecutors have staunchly defended the FBI operation. "Our top priority is to
protect our nation from terrorism and national security threats," said US
attorney Carmen Ortiz.

FBI officials have also said the investigation was carried out responsibly and
to head off a real threat. "We have an obligation to take action to protect the
public whenever an individual expresses a desire to commit violence. A committed
individual, even one with no direct connections to, or formal training from, an
international terrorist organization, can pose a serious danger to the
community," said Richard DesLauriers, Special Agent in Charge of the FBI's
Boston Division

LOAD-DATE: September 29, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                       Copyright 2011 Guardian Unlimited
                              All Rights Reserved


                             150 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 May 13, 1984, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

GREENBURG AND WHITE PLAINS RESIDENTS TAKE TO THE FIELDS

BYLINE: By TOM CALLAHAN

SECTION: Section 11WC; Page 27, Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1068 words


ON workdays Henry Hamrick can be found behind a desk in New York City as an
engineer. But on Saturdays and Sundays he can be found toiling in the soil of
Greenburgh School District 7 as a farmer.

''I enjoy getting my hands dirty and watching something I have planted grow,''
he says of his weekend work. ''I find it a total diversion from the hours I
spend sitting behind a desk all week.''

Mr. Hamrick is one of many residents of the county getting the opportunity to
grow their own vegetables and produce on public land. Community farms or gardens
exist in Greenburgh and White Plains, and a bill before the County Board of
Legislators would make county land available to any weekend farmer interested on
working a plot.

''The Farm,'' as it is called in Greenburgh, is on two-and-one-half acres of
School District 7 land divided into two sites consisting of 270 plots of 12 by
18 feet. An ad hoc committee of volunteers assigns the plots each spring to 120
school district residents for a $2 fee. Those who farmed in previous years are
offered their plots back, with the rest of the land given to new farmers or
those who wish additional plots.  During weekdays, the first site appears
deserted; it is located in a small clearing besides a road traveled mostly by
school buses where the trees and brush have been pushed back. Individual plots
are marked off by small chicken wire fences or sticks in the ground.

But on weekends during the late spring and summer months, this land is filled
with people such as Roslyn Bain who, with her husband, Milo, has been farming in
Greenburgh since the program started in 1976.

''We've been doing it all these years because we like gardening and working in
the soil,'' Mrs. Bain said. ''Plus we get a supply of fresh vegetables. We used
to garden around our house but there isn't enough sunlight available there now,
so The Farm is perfect.''

Mrs. Bain has found that many of the people who originally took plots on school
district land have kept them every year, while others quickly learned the
difficulties of gardening and dropped out.

''Most people,'' she said, ''leave their plot only when they retire or move out
of the area. We do get a lot of new people, though, and most of them stay on.
But there are a few who will work their plots only until the weather gets hot
and then they quit right before they get the results.''

The idea for the Greenburgh program began with Myrna Youdelman and what she
described as her frustration with the lack of nutritional awareness in the
Greenburgh schools: ''One day while coming out of school I looked at all the
gorgeous land around there and knew we could make a farm and grow our own good
food.''

While most participants are happy to get fresh food, they have also come to see
The Farm as an important community meeting place.

''The camaraderie among people is amazing,'' said Mrs. Youdelman, who had her
own plot until a knee injury two years ago forced her to give it up. ''If people
were planting seeds in their own backyard and had a few left over, they wouldn't
think of going across the street to share them with a neighbor. But on The Farm
everybody shares and cooperates because they have the same interest.''

Mr. Hamrick, who learned the basics of gardening during his upbringing in West
Virginia, agreed: ''Everybody knows one another out there, and it's a great way
to meet your neighbors and people in the community who you never see anywhere
else.''

While he conceded that there were occasional problems with vandalism - and
woodchucks in the surrounding woods that raid the plots at night - he added,
''people seem to come back every year despite the setbacks.''

Like Greenburgh, White Plains has two sites for its community garden, one on the
old Baldwin Farm off Hall Avenue and the other on the New York Hospital property
off Bryant Avenue. The White Plains Department of Recreation and Parks handles
the program and offers free plots to anyone with a city recreation
identification card.

The White Plains community garden has been in existence for eight years and now
has 90 farmers, with 20 more on a waiting list for plots. The city creates
additional plots each year to meet the demand.

''People benefit tremendously from this program,'' said Patti Carter, a White
Plains recreation supervisor. ''I find in the recreation area we deal mostly
with athletic programs or cultural and art programs. But the garden attracts a
completely different group of people than the ones we see at our other programs.
I'm happy we can offer it.''

Miss Carter, who works a plot of her own, said that the garden attracts a wide
variety of people, with most falling into the 25- to 40-year old age group.
''The program is convenient for people,'' she added. ''There are 90 farmers but
I don't see many people around when I go out to my own plot. One of the nice
things is that people can come out whenever they feel like it.''

County Legislator Paul J. Feiner, Democrat of Greenburgh, is the sponsor of a
bill to open up county land for vegetable and produce plots. He suggested that
such a program would benefit the county's image as well as the citizen's dinner
table.

''I feel,'' he says, ''that this could be the most popular program the County
Recreation Department has ever run. It's inexpensive but highly visible. You
have to let people know that the county government exists and this recreation
program would do that.''

Mr. Feiner would like to see the county start with one of its own test programs
and, if that is successful, expand it to a network of farm plots countywide. His
plan would also request that participants tithe, or give back, 10 percent of
their crop for programs for the elderly or for charities.

Those working their own public plots are enthusiastic about the possibility of a
county program. ''I feel certain,'' Mr. Hamrick said, ''that this would work on
a countywide basis. You would find a lot of people who would want plots, and it
really doesn't take much land to satisfy them, only a few acres.''

Everybody should have this opportunity,'' Mrs. Bain added. ''I'm sure that the
response in other communities would be as great as it is in Greenburgh.''

But right now the main concern of these weekend farmers is clearing off their
plots, planting the seeds, and providing the many long weeks of tender loving
care needed to get a good crop.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: photo of Frank Grasso with leek grown at the Community Farm; photo of
residents working their plots at the site

                   Copyright 1984 The New York Times Company


                             151 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                 Irish Examiner

                           September 8, 2009 Tuesday

Three convicted of bomb plot to blow up airliners

SECTION: WORLD

LENGTH: 523 words


The al-Qaida-inspired terror cell planned to detonate homemade liquid bombs
onboard flights bound for major north American cities.

Abdulla Ahmed Ali, Assad Sarwar and Tanvir Hussain were found guilty of
conspiracy to murder by detonating the bombs on airliners following the largest
ever counter-terrorism operation in Britain.

Sue Hemming, head of the Crown Prosecution Service Counter Terrorism Division,
said: "These men wanted to bring down several aircraft in a short space of time,
indiscriminately killing hundreds of innocent people   perhaps more if they had
succeeded in activating their devices while over cities.

"This was a calculated and sophisticated plot to create a terrorist event of
global proportions and the jury concluded that Ali, Sarwar and Hussain knew what
the target was."

British Home Secretary Alan Johnson said: "I am pleased that the jury has
recognised that there was a plot to bomb transatlantic flights and that three
people have been convicted of that plot.

"This case reaffirms that we face a real and serious threat from terrorism."

Counter-terrorist police and the security services spent more than £35 million (
39m) foiling the plot and bringing Ali and the others to justice.

The arrest of the gang in August 2006 sparked tight restrictions on carrying
liquids on to aircraft which initially caused travel chaos.

Yesterday's guilty verdicts will come as a relief to Government ministers who
endured heavy criticism for introducing the draconian luggage restrictions.

Jurors deliberated for more than 50 hours at the end of a six-month trial at
Woolwich Crown Court.

It will also be seen as a vindication of the decision to retry Ali after he was
found guilty of conspiracy to murder last September. The previous jury failed to
reach verdicts on the airline plot. British-born Ali, 28, of Walthamstow, east
London, was inspired by the July 7 bombers and Osama bin Laden and considered
taking his baby son on his suicide mission.

He planned to smuggle homemade bombs disguised as soft drinks on to passenger
jets run by United Airlines, American Airlines and Air Canada.

The hydrogen peroxide devices would have been assembled and detonated in mid-air
by a team of suicide bombers.

Ali singled out seven flights to San Francisco, Toronto, Montreal, Washington,
New York and Chicago that departed within two-and-a-half hours of each other.

Police said the plot was drawn up in Pakistan with detailed instructions passed
to Ali during frequent trips to its lawless border with Afghanistan.

They believe a mystery al-Qaida bombmaker was responsible for the ingenious
liquid bomb design, concealed within 500ml Oasis or Lucozade bottles.

Surveillance teams watched Ali on his return to Britain as he assembled his
terror cell, gathered materials and identified targets.

Undercover officers looked on as he used cash to purchase a £138,000 flat in
Forest Road, Walthamstow.

They planted a secret bug that revealed it had been converted into a bomb
factory where Ali met others to construct the bombs.

The flat was also used as a location for Ali and others to record suicide videos
threatening further attacks against the West.

LOAD-DATE: September 8, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

            Intelligencer Journal/New Era (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

                             April 5, 2014 Saturday

Parks Department Is Renting Garden Plots

BYLINE: Ad Crable

SECTION: B; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 254  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Staff Writer

acrable@lnpnews.com

As sure a sign as any that spring really has overtaken a stubborn winter, the
Lancaster County Department of Parks and Recreation is again renting garden
plots to the public at Lancaster County Central Park.

The garden season runs from April 15 through Oct. 15. The public can apply for a
plot at the park office located at 1050 Rockford Road, or call 299-8215. Office
hours are Monday through Friday from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.

County residents can select either a 20-foot-by-20-foot plot or a
20-foot-by-40-foot plot. Renters pay a one-time fee of $22 for a small plot and
$27.50 for a larger plot.

The garden plots are located off Farm View Drive just off Golf Road in Central
Park.

Gardeners of all skill levels can rent garden plots to grow their own flowers
and vegetables. They are ideal for gardeners with limited space at home and
great for groups looking for a summer project.

County park naturalist Lisa J. Sanchez, a longtime Central Park gardener, says,
"Being involved in a community garden plot program provides an opportunity to
meet people and to share gardening techniques, plants and food. It's a great
idea to grow your own food - to choose what you want to plant. Watching birds
and other wildlife in their outdoor habitat is an added plus."

Organic plots are also available. These spaces have been free of pesticides and
herbicides for several years. Organic plots may be rented over the winter months
as well.

For more information about plot rentals, visit lancastercountyparks.org.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                                   InfoWorld

                                 March 20, 1989

Plotview Upgrade Adds Unlimited Plot File Size

BY BOB PONTING

SECTION: SOFTWARE; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 207 words


Ajida Technologies Inc. is scheduled to ship this month an enhanced version of
its Windows plot-preview utility that adds support for unlimited plot file size,
choices of pen colors and widths, and clipboard support to export metafiles as
well as bit maps.

Plotview, Release 2.0 lets users view, print, cut, and paste from plot files in
Hewlett-Packard Graphics Language format.

Because the program is a utility designed to run under Microsoft Windows, users
can produce a plotter file with one Windows application and easily open another
window to preview the plot and print it on any graphics printer supported by
Windows, according to David Berkovec, Ajida's marketing manager.

The product can scale, rotate, zoom, and scroll plots on-screen.  The new
version can display any size plot file, and lets users transfer portions of the
plot in Metafile vector format through the Windows clipboard to other Windows
applications, Berkovec said.

Plotview 2.0 will cost $ 79, up from $ 59 for the previous version.  Registered
users who acquired Plotview in 1988 can upgrade to Release 2.0 for $ 35, and
those who bought it this year can upgrade for $ 25.

Ajida Technologies Inc., 613 Fourth St., Santa Rosa, CA 95404; (707) 545-7777.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Illustration, The Windows-based plot-preview utility Plotview now
supports metafiles, larger plots, and more varieties of pen colors and widths.

                             154 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       St. Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                           September 23, 2008 Tuesday

CHRIS NISKANEN: North Dakota hunting lands are disappearing

BYLINE: Pioneer Press

SECTION: OUTDOORS; Chris Niskanen; Columnists

LENGTH: 659 words


JAMESTOWN, N.D. -- At first I thought we were lost.

With map in hand, I was giving a friend directions to a piece of private land
opened to hunters under North Dakota's Private Lands Open To Sportsmen (PLOTS)
program. We were hunting sharp-tailed grouse near Jamestown last week, and the
detailed PLOTS booklet in my lap showed we should be driving past an accessible
piece of land listed on the map.

But the telltale triangular PLOTS signs were missing, and the field was planted
with corn.

"Another one bites the dust," I said of the hunting area.

It was obvious the landowner decided not to renew his PLOTS contract and saw a
better deal by planting a crop in his field. During three days of hunting in
North Dakota, it was one of many PLOTS fields I noticed have disappeared in
North Dakota, one of the most popular destinations for Minnesota sportsmen.

Moreover, I remembered the same field used to be planted in grass under the
Conservation Reserve Program, so not only was the 300 acres no longer open to
hunting, but any habitat benefits for pheasants or ducks disappeared when the
plow hit the ground.

Nonresident hunters visiting North Dakota might find a lot of their favorite
hunting areas are AWOL this year.

"It's been a race by landowners to get the (PLOTS) signs down,'' said Randy
Kreil, wildlife division chief for the North Dakota Game and Fish Department. In
other words, some landowners are bailing on the PLOTS program as soon as they
can.

Last fall, the North Dakota wildlife agency hit its benchmark of enrolling 1
million acres into the PLOTS program, which pays landowners a small fee to open
their land to hunters. A similar program in South Dakota is called the Walk-In
Program. Efforts to get such a program off the ground in Minnesota have failed
repeatedly.

Kreil said the state has lost about 30,000 acres of PLOTS since last year, but
the number appears far larger than that. Of the 1 million acres in PLOTS, about
400,000 acres were enrolled in the federal CRP program, which in North Dakota is
being gutted by high commodity prices and low federal rental rates for
landowners. Many of the highest quality PLOTS land for bird hunting were also
CRP acres. Last year, North Dakota lost more than 400,000 acres of CRP.

CRP losses so far "are just the beginning," Kreil said. Before last year, North
Dakota had 3.2 million acres of CRP, but the current forecast calls for the
state to lose another 1 million acres by 2012. "Last year's losses don't seem so
bad, compared to what the dramatic changes you see coming down the road," Kreil
said.

Anyone who has hunted North Dakota in recent years knows how valuable the PLOTS
program is.

Granted, not all PLOTS acres provided the best hunting habitat, in my
experience, but these areas provided access to private lands and alleviated
hunting pressure on state and federal lands. The PLOTS guide booklet, available
at retail outlets throughout the state, is an invaluable resource to finding
these lands, but this year's guide warns hunters to do more "preseason homework
than previous years" because PLOTS lands are disappearing.

Don't expect this year's booklet to accurately reflect the changes, either.
Kreil said many landowners were dropping out of the program as the booklet was
being printed. I found last week that many tracts were listed in the map, but
the roadside PLOTS signs were gone and the land wasn't accessible any longer.

You'll find other changes as well. Because of a drought in North Dakota, many
landowners hayed their PLOTS and CRP lands, resulting in a poor habitat for fall
hunting.

Drought conditions also are plaguing many wetlands in North Dakota. Some shallow
potholes are dry, while deeper ones have pulled far away from the shoreline.

Kreil said North Dakota has been attracting far fewer waterfowl hunters than in
past years, and with the drought, loss of PLOTS lands and high gas prices, he
predicts even fewer nonresidents will be hunting North Dakota this year.

LOAD-DATE: September 24, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                     Copyright 2008 St. Paul Pioneer Press
                              All Rights Reserved


                             155 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                   Inland Valley Daily Bulletin (Ontario, CA)

                            December 12, 2003 Friday

Plots near Roy Rogers on eBay;
Cemetery auctions sites near famous cowboy

BYLINE: JACOB QUINN SANDERSSTAFF WRITER

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 622 words


APPLE VALLEY - Roy Rogers lies here under crisp green grass, behind a short gate
and near a pond over which a bronze eagle hovers as sentinel. Next to the movie
cowboy is his wife and co-star, Dale Evans, just as she should be.

But this final resting place is hardly peaceful. Not this week.

Six cemetery plots near the graves of Rogers and Evans landed onthe auction Web
site eBay this week, ranging in price from $13,200 to $90,000. The National
Enquirer published a story, and the executive director of the High Desert
Executives' Association sent out a press release.

"I'm the head of this family and no one asked me," Roy"Dusty" Rogers Jr. said in
a telephone interview from his office at the family's museum in Branson, Mo.
"It's distasteful. It's disrespectful of Mom and Dad. To do this on eBay is just
ridiculous."

Bold-faced type on the eBay postings reads: "Many otherproperties are available,
but the areas next to Roy and Dale are selling out quickly. Don't miss this
opportunity!"

Chet Hitt, who owns Sunset Hills Memorial Park and Mortuary,where Rogers and
Evans are buried, said in an interview he put the plots up for auction with the
family's permission. He ordered the auctions stopped Friday after speaking with
Dusty Rogers. No one bid on the plots.

"I know Chet real well," Dusty said. "I'm not trying to stophim from doing
business. But come on."

Roy Rogers died July 6, 1998, at age 86. Evans died Feb. 7, 2001;she was 88.

Open since 1995, Sunset Hills is still in the process of buildingthe Roy
Rogers-Dale Evans Sunset Chapel. Some of the money from the auctions, Hitt said,
would have gone toward the construction.

Hitt sold the plot directly across from Rogers and Evans lessthan 3 feet from
their front gate in 2002 to Max Hurlbut, 64, of Bellingham, Wash. The
transaction had nothing to do with a Web site, just boyhood interest.

"I grew up cap pistol in hand," Hurlbut said in a telephoneinterview from his
home. "I grew up watching Roy Rogers, and westerns were very popular."

Hurlbut spent 25 years with the Los Angeles Police Department andlater took
police jobs in Alaska and Arizona, including a stint as town marshal in
Tombstone, inspired in part by those westerns.

Hurlbut visited Victorville last year to see the Roy Rogers-DaleEvans Museum it
moved to Branson this year and thought a stop at their graves would add
something.

"One day I dropped by the cemetery and found it was closed," hesaid. "There was
a fellow working nearby, and it was Chet. We talked, and I thought I might like
to be buried there."

Hitt said Hurlbut's purchase gave him the idea to market theplots as a chance to
spend eternity within spitting distance of the King of the Cowboys. Auctioning
the plots on eBay, he said, was just a natural extension of that marketing.

"It worked for us to a degree," he said. "We didn't get bidson eBay, but we got
a lot of phone calls and 2,900 hits on our Web site."

The largest of the plots up for auction can hold six caskets butcould be
modified to accommodate 12. The price: $90,000 or, as the posting said, "only
$7,500 per person for a family of 12."

A second plot, for $30,000, features year-round flowering plantsand a granite
bench.

Four other plots are simpler and, at 35 feet from Rogers andEvans, the farthest
away. They were also the cheapest: $13,200 each.

Hurlbut's plot has room for four and a view to rival the onewhere Rogers and
Evans lie.

He declined to say how much he paid.

"Chet is one of the rare fellows in business who is as good ashis word," Hurlbut
said. "I got a deal on the plot I bought. I couldn't say no, especially when
being right there next to Roy didn't cost any extra."

                      The Gold Coast Bulletin (Australia)

                             March 16, 2007 Friday
                                  Main Edition

Sinister bid to sheik the world

SECTION: FOCUS; Pg. 25

LENGTH: 515  words


TOP al-Qaeda operative Khalid Sheikh Mohammed has claimed responsibility for
some 31 separate terror attacks or plots. They are (omitting one plot which was
censored from the US Defence Department transcript):

1. The 1993 bombing of the World Trade Centre in New York City.

2. The September 11, 2001 attacks on the New York World Trade Centre and the
Pentagon in Washington.

3. A 'shoe bomber' operation to bring down two US commercial planes.

4. The October 2002 attack on US soldiers on Kuwait's Faylahkah Island.

5. The 2002 Bali nightclub bombings which killed more than 200 people, including
88 Australians.

6. A plan for a 'second wave' assault on major US landmarks in the wake of the
September 11 attacks, with targets including the Library Tower in Los Angeles,
Sears Tower in Chicago, Plaza Bank building in Seattle and the Empire State
Building in New York.

7. Plots to attack US military vessels and oil tankers in the Straits of Hormuz,
the Strait of Gibraltar and in Singapore.

8. A plan to blow up the Panama Canal.

9. An assassination attempt against ex-US president Jimmy Carter, as well as
other former presidents.

10. A plot to blow up suspension bridges in New York.

11. A plan to burn fuel trucks beneath or around the Chicago Sears Tower in
order to destroy it.

12. An operation to destroy Britain's Heathrow Airport and London's Canary Wharf
and Big Ben.

13. A planned attack on nightclubs in Thailand targeting US and British
nationals.

14. A plot targeting the New York Stock Exchange and other US finance industry
targets.

15. A plan to use planes flying from Saudi Arabia to attack and destroy
buildings in Elat, Israel.

16. Planned attacks aimed at destroying US embassies in Australia, Indonesia and
Japan.

17. Planned attacks on Israel's embassies in Australia, India, Azerbaijan and
the Philippines.

18. An attack on an Israeli El-Al flight from Bangkok.

19. Sending several 'mujahideen' into Israel to survey 'strategic targets'.

20. The deadly November 2002 suicide bombing of a hotel in Mombassa, Kenya,
frequented by Israelis.

21. The failed attempt to down an Israeli jet taking off from Mombassa airport
with an SA-7 surface-to-air missile on the same day as the hotel bombing.

22. A plot to attack US targets in South Korea, such as US bases and nightclubs
frequented by US soldiers.

23. Providing the financial support for a plan to attack US, British and Jewish
targets in Turkey.

24. Surveillance undertaken for a plan to attack US nuclear power plants.

25. A plot to attack NATO headquarters in Europe.

26. The 1995 'Bojinka Operation' in which attackers planned to bring down 12 US
passenger flights flying between mostly Pacific rim airports.

27. An assassination attempt planned against then US president Bill Clinton
during a mid-1990s trip to the Philippines.

28. A separate plot to kill Pope John Paul II while he visited the Philippines.

29. Plans to assassinate Pakistan President General Pervez Musharraf.

30. An attempt to attack a US oil company operating in Sumatra, Indonesia, that
Mohammed said was 'owned by the Jewish former (US) secretary of state Henry
Kissinger'.

                                The New York Post

                              July 9, 2006 Sunday

DEEP CREEPS; PATH SCHEME'S JUST ONE OF MANY KNOWN PLOTS: POL

BYLINE: DEBORAH ORIN, NILES LATHEM and ALEX GINSBERG

SECTION: Metro; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 393 words


The chilling conspiracy to blow up PATH trains under the Hudson River revealed
earlier this week is just one of several credible plots targeting New York,
House Homeland Security Committee Chairman Rep. Peter King said yesterday.

"This is not all New York has to worry about -  there are certainly things out
there,"' said King (R-L.I.).

Law-enforcement sources told The Post that the feds have hundreds of open terror
investigations in the New York area.

Department of Homeland Security spokesman Russ Knocke wouldn't confirm that
there were other plots New York should be concerned about.

King declined to discuss other plots, but said the revelation of the PATH train
plot shows why it was "insanity" for the department to cut New York's
anti-terror funds by $80 million -  especially when the agency knew of the
tunnels threat.

DHS sent more money instead to low-risk cities like Louisville and Omaha in
Nebraska -  where cows outnumber people -  to buy high-tech equipment and
rejected New York's request for money to be used for personnel and overtime.

"That was the most infuriating thing," said King.

"We knew this [PATH] plot was out there and the NYPD was laying out money, using
personnel to combat it. The NYPD tried to anticipate in any reasonable way that
this plot could be anticipated.

"They were thinking outside the box, but that requires boots on the ground. I
knew that for Ray Kelly to have a good chance to defeat this plot he had to have
personnel, boots on the ground."

He added that the foiled PATH train tunnel attack had to be taken into
consideration along with countless other factors that determine funding.

"There is a tremendous amount of intelligence information that is out there," he
said. "And there are any number of threats that could be made. The formula
involves millions upon millions of data points."

New York can make up for some of the lost money through other funding sources,
including a $1 billion Commerce Department program to fund radio
interoperability, King said.

Last week, just before the PATH plot was revealed, the New York area got a
bigger share of separate railroad security money.

"This is proof positive that there has to be a change in thinking at DHS," said
King. "New York is the only city that was devastated twice and has had any
number of other plots against it. It's insanity."

more ongoing terror investigations. (Jeff Day)

Garden Plots Available At Park

SECTION: D; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 150  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Garden plots are again available for the public to rent at Lancaster County
Central Park.

Plots either 20-by-20 feet or 20-by-40 feet are available from April 15 through
Oct. 15. The plots cost $18 for the smaller ones and $23 for the larger ones.
The plots are located off Farm View Drive, just off Golf Road in the park.

The Lancaster County Department of Parks and Recreation is renting the plots
now. Apply at the parks office at 1050 Rockford Road Monday through Friday from
8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.

Gardeners of all skill levels can rent garden plots to grow flowers and
vegetables. They have been popular with gardeners with limited space at home and
with groups looking for a summer project.

Organic plots also are available. These plots have been free of pesticides and
herbicides for more than three years.

For more information, call the parks office at 299-8215 or visit
www.lancastercounty

parks.org.

                     Deseret Morning News (Salt Lake City)

                              June 19, 2006 Monday

Was cyanide plot too paltry?

BYLINE: Michael McAuliff New York Daily News

LENGTH: 452 words


WASHINGTON -- Al-Qaida decided not to launch a deadly cyanide gas plot in New
York's subways because it wouldn't have killed enough people, according to the
author whose bombshell book revealed the frightening scheme.

"Al-Qaida's thinking is that a second-wave attack should be more destructive and
more disruptive than 9/11," writer Ron Suskind said in an interview with Time
magazine. "Why? Because that would create an upward arc of terror. . . . That
fear and terror is a central goal of the al-Qaida strategy."

News of the 2003 plot to use homemade cyanide bombs, the details of which have
been confirmed by the New York Daily News, was first revealed Friday in excerpts
from Suskind's book "The One Percent Doctrine."

The plot, purportedly masterminded by al-Qaida's ringleader in Saudi Arabia,
Yusuf al-Ayeri, involved planting crude but effective cyanide canisters around
the subway system before the start of the Iraq war.

Sen. Pat Roberts, chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, wouldn't
confirm that al-Qaida's No. 2 leader, Ayman al-Zawahiri, called off the attack
just 45 days before its execution because it would not be spectacular enough.
But Roberts, R-Kan., said the premise that Zawahiri pulled the plug "was
correct."

"I think, when any terrorist considers an attack, they also consider the public
reaction," Roberts said on CNN's "Late Edition" Sunday.

City and federal officials learned of the plot from an al-Qaida mole dubbed
"Ali" and beefed up security around the subways in hopes of heading off the
strike, which could have killed hundreds.

The plot "underscores the stupidity" of the Homeland Security Department
slashing the city's anti-terror funding by 40 percent, said Sen. Charles
Schumer, D-N.Y.

Rep. Pete King, R-N.Y., chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee,
agreed.

"It's just madness that (the Homeland Security Department) cut New York City's
funding by 40 percent," said King, who will put department officials on the hot
seat before his committee Wednesday.

If Zawahiri did squash the gas attack because it wouldn't be deadly enough, that
boosts the argument that federal authorities should not be spreading security
dollars around the country in places such as Louisville, Ky., and Omaha, Neb.,
which saw major hikes in funding. Only in places such as New York and Washington
can terrorists hope to raise the ante from Sept. 11, King said.

"Some of these other cities just aren't going to get hit," he said.

When President Bush learned the cyanide plot had been nixed, according to
Suskind, Bush said: "This is bad enough. What does calling this off say about
what else they're planning? . . . What could be the bigger operation Zawahiri
didn't want to mess up?"

LOAD-DATE: June 19, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                 Copyright 2006 The Deseret News Publishing Co.

                               The New York Times

               December 7, 1986, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

NORTHEAST JOURNAL

SECTION: Section 1; Part 3, Page 66, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 884 words


Worcester Bans Cheer With Spirits

HOLIDAY cheer in Worcester, Mass., will not include liquor for city workers at
office parties, according to City Manager William J. Mulford.

Liquor at any time in the workday was banned by Mr. Mulford in a directive Nov.
26 to all city employees in this older industrial city of 165,000 people. The
order forbids drinking even so much as a beer or a glass of wine on lunch and
other breaks.

Violators are subject to penalties, including dismissal, under a new two-year
contract with Local 495 of the Service Employees International Union. The
prohibition includes department heads.

One, Robert Moylan, assistant public works commissioner, said enforcing the ban
had not been discussed, but he said, ''It's not meant to be a witch hunt.''

Mr. Mulford acted to stem the city's liability for on-the-job mishaps, according
to Demitrios M. Moschos, a lawyer who negotiated the contract and wrote the
prohibition. Mr. Moschos said municipal employees cannot be held liable for
job-related accidents, but the city can.

He said city workers had been in accidents that might be attributable to
alcohol, injuring people and damaging property. City employees have generally
reacted quietly. No Room for Bush In Maine Plot VICE President Bush has been
welcome in Kennebunkport, Me., for many summers, but now the town has told him
that extending his stay for eternity may be more difficult.

Mr. Bush inquired recently about buying a plot in the coastal resort town's
Arundel Cemetery, but was told that none were available. ''The plots are all
sold,'' said the town clerk, Charles Gould. ''Whether it's George Bush or Joe
Blow, it doesn't matter. There's not an available plot for sale.''

The developed portion of the cemetery takes up about three-quarters of its 9.6
acres. The remaining two acres are wooded and uncleared, and Mr. Bush, who has
summered in the town since he was a child, has now added his name to a list of
about 10 residents hoping to secure a plot in that section.

The question of whether the town will develop the wooded section has ignited a
debate. The cemetery was founded in 1893 by a local association that cared for
it until about 15 years ago. Now a group of five residents, led by a local
genealogist, Natalie Johnson, is urging the town to assume management and clear
the wooded area for new plots.

Plots in the town are at a premium, Mrs. Johnson said.

''I will be buried there with my first husband, and my second husband's wife is
there, so we are taken care of, but a lot of other people would like to have
places there too,'' she said. She added that with three other town cemeteries
full, the town was running out of burial places. ''Last year, quite a few had to
go to Kennebunk, the next town,'' she said, ''but if everyone continues to go up
there, what will happen?''

The matter will be discussed at a selectmen's meeting on Dec. 11. The chairman
of the board of selectmen, Joseph Finn, says the town is prohibited from
spending money on private property - he believes the cemetery is owned by heirs
of the association -and acceptance of the cemetery as a gift would have to be
approved by the town at a town meeting in March. Vermont School's Unhappy
Holiday IN October the insurer of the East Hill School in Andover, Vt.,
gradually reduced and finally dropped the school's liability insurance, terming
the school a high risk, and no other carrier could be found. The students had to
leave, but schooling went on.

Two students from a high school conducted classes for seven young East Hill
students, including four children of Guatemalan refugees, at the nearby Weston
Priory. Other classes met at a private home. Older students studied
independently.

The headmaster, Dick Bliss, founded the school 30 years ago as an alternative,
he says, to inadequate public schools and expensive private schools. He runs it
as a small farm with the help of teachers whose pay is their keep and a small
stipend and with students who work in the fields and barn.

Tuition is based on ability to pay. The 10 boarding students at East Hill pay
about $6,000 a year while the average day student pays $300 a year. Alumni,
according to Mr. Bliss, include children of the novelist Alexander Solzhenitsyn,
who lives in Cavendish, Vt., and the grandchildren of the social activist
Dorothy Day.

Mr. Bliss said he was determined that the crisis would not force him out of
business. ''These students are not statistics,'' he said. ''They are 30 very
specific kids.''

Mr. Bliss took his complaint to state legislators, consumer groups and the State
Banking and Insurance Commission. ''I talked to anyone who would listen,'' he
says.

Several underwriters lost interest when they learned that the students chop wood
and stoke wood stoves, drive tractors, milk cows and cook meals - all ''high
risk'' activities.

The headmaster said he finally persuaded the Rhulen Agency of Monticello, N.Y.,
of his belief that ''the more responsibility you give to people, the lower the
risk.'' He says no one has ever filed a claim against the school.

The agency got him an insurer, but the premiums are up, from $1,200 to $5,600,
or one-twelfth of the school's annual $60,000 operating budget. Mr. Bliss said
he hopes he does not have to raise the tuition.

Community Garden needs sponsors, donations

SECTION: Pg. 5

LENGTH: 617 words


COLUMN: Neighbors

GRAFTON - The Grafton Garden Club is looking for sponsors to donate money or
materials for the newly created Community Garden at 48 Old Westboro Road. The
garden needs one ton of lime; hay or stones for the pathways between the plots;
an electric fence around the garden (approximately 500 feet perimeter) including
solar panels and battery; a wheelbarrow and a lawnmower.

To make a donation, call Michael at (508) 887-5600. For more information, go to
garden.graftongardenclub.org.

The Board of Selectmen recently approved the club's proposal for a garden. The
club is now accepting applications from residents to rent 20-by-20-foot plots to
grow vegetables, herbs, flowers and short fruiting bushes. Applications are
available at garden.graftongardenclub.org, by e-mailing
info@graftongardenclub.org or by calling Michael at (508) 887-5600. Applications
and plot fees are due April 15 and should be sent to P.O. Box 453, Grafton, MA
01519-0453. Plot assignments will be mailed out by the end of April and planting
starts in May.

Northbridge students in DECA event

NORTHBRIDGE - Twenty-three Northbridge High School students recently competed in
the 51st annual Massachusetts DECA State Competition in Boston. The students
were: Nick Abraham, Mike Barkin, Julie Broderick, Denise D'Amico, Hayden
Dorfman, Natasha Farrington, Cynthia Feen, Lauren Gallant, Sadie Green, Matt
Kane, Mitch Kelley, Allison Kosciak, Ashley LeBlanc, Evan MacIntosh, Ryan
Masterson, Gabrielle Mello, Thomas Murphy, John O'Brien, John Perro, Jordan
Pimentel, Kirsten Ropiak, Brianna Scherer and Kraig Spencer.

The team of Sadie Green, Ashley LeBlanc and Brianna Scherer placed second in the
Financial Operation Research Event, qualifying to compete in the International
DECA Competition in Louisville, Ky., in April. The team worked closely with
UniBank of Whitinsville on their project.

Allison Kosciak and Gabbi Mello will be attending the Leadership Development
Academy in Louisville.

Nick Abraham, Mike Barkin, Julie Broderick, Denise D'Amico and Allison Kosciak
placed in the top 10 of their categories. Nick Abraham received two third place
medals for his role playing effort. And, Mike Barkin received a first place
medal for his score on his marketing test.

Allcare Medical celebrates 10 years

MILLBURY- Allcare Medical Supply, 30 Grafton St., is celebrating 10 years in
business. Bill Fredericks, president and CEO, started Allcare on April 1 of 2000
with no clients and no staff. The company now provides home medical equipment to
thousands of patients in the Blackstone Valley and throughout Massachusetts. An
invitation-only dinner is planned at O'Connor's restaurant in Worcester for
staff, family and friends who helped contribute to their success.

Students chosen for science competition

NORTHBRIDGE - High School juniors Shanise Perez and Jessica Donati have been
selected to participate in the Future Research Scientist Competition hosted by
the Center for Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine at the University of
Massachusetts in Worcester.

The students will have the opportunity to work as research scientists in a
state-of-the-art laboratory. The competitors will complete a DNA fingerprinting
analysis at the Rose Gordon facility in Shrewsbury and will present their
findings in a poster competition on May 1. The grand prize includes a spot in
the center's Biology Boot Camp summer internship program as well as a donation
of laboratory equipment from Bio-Rad to the winner's science department.
