                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                             March 18, 2005 Friday
                          FIVE STAR LATE LIFT EDITION

PEOPLE NEWS/GOSSIP/SCOOPS

BYLINE: FROM NEWS SERVICES

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A2

LENGTH: 567 words


LETTERMAN'S SON A TARGET OF PLOT? Authorities say it was a plot to kidnap David
Letterman's toddler son and nanny from the talk-show host's Montana home. On
Thursday, they arrested Kelly A. Frank, 43, and charged him with felony
solicitation, theft and obstruction.

The plot was uncovered, according to the Montana Department of Corrections, when
someone whom Frank had approached about the plan informed local police. A
spokesman said Frank had been working as a painter at Letterman's 2,700-acre
ranch west of Choteau, Mont., and apparently confided in an acquaintance this
month of his plan to kidnap Letterman's son and nanny and hold them for $5
million ransom.

Authorities say Frank is charged with felony theft for overcharging Letterman
for painting and obstruction for lying to investigators who first contacted him
about the alleged plot.

Letterman's girlfriend, Regina Lasko, gave birth to their son on Nov. 3, 2003.
Letterman said the boy, his first child, was named after his late father, Harry
Joseph Letterman.

LIL' KIM CONVICTED: Rap diva Lil' Kim (aka Kimberly Jones) could be the next
celebrity cellmate in the Big House. She was convicted Thursday of lying to a
federal grand jury to protect friends involved in a shootout outside a New York
City radio station. She and her assistant were both convicted of perjury and
conspiracy but acquitted of obstruction of justice. They each face up to 20
years in prison; sentencing was set for June 24.

ANOTHER "BREAK UP" FOR JEN: Jennifer Aniston's next film project will be "The
Break Up." But don't get your hopes up. It's not about her breakup with Brad
Pitt. The Hollywood Reporter says it's a comedy that will co-star Vince Vaughn.
The title, at least, should be worth some buzz.

LONG LIVE THE KING: Raspy-voiced gabmeister Larry King is showing no signs of
easing up. Daily Variety reports that King, 71, has renewed his contract with
CNN to continue his "Larry King Live" show through 2009. And who could blame
him? It's hard to walk away from a $7 mil-a-year gig.

PAIRINGS & PARTINGS: Boris Kodjoe and Nicole Ari Parker, who starred in the
Showtime series "Soul Food," are new parents. Parker gave birth to the couple's
first child, Sophie Tei-Naaki Lee Kodjoe, on Saturday. They plan to wed in May.
. . . The husband of "Monk" co-star Traylor Howard wants out of their marriage.
Christian Navarro, a wine merchant, filed for divorce Tuesday. They were married
in April 2003 but have been separated since May 1.

DID SOMEBODY SAY BIRTHDAY CAKE? It wasn't a honky-tonk hoedown gone bad that
caused all the trouble for Nashville cops early Wednesday morning. This time,
the ruckus started at a birthday bash hosted by Young Buck, the rapper who's
charged with stabbing a man during a melee at the Vibe Awards in LA in November.
Police say they were called to The Trap nightclub after 700 people tried to rush
the building despite shotgun-carrying security guards. About 30 officers
responded and three people were arrested on minor charges. Young Buck (aka David
Darnell Brown), a Nashville native who turned 24 on Tuesday, wasn't charged in
the incident.

DONALD, MEET YOUR DOUBLE: ABC has found the man who would be Donald Trump. That
would be Justin Louis, currently starring in Lifetime's "MISSING" and before
that, the NBC sitcom "Hidden Hills." He'll play the Trumpster in the biopic
"Ambition," set for a May telecast. -- Compiled by Ray Jordan

                             182 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Brattleboro Reformer (Vermont)

                              June 8, 2007 Friday

Freakin' overblown

BYLINE: Reformer.com

SECTION: EDITORIALS

LENGTH: 500 words


"JFK TERROR PLOT" screamed the front pages of the New York tabloids on Sunday
morning.

Yet another terrorist plot was foiled, we were told. This time it was a plan to
blow up the fuel tanks and pipelines at New York's Kennedy Airport and
incinerate the borough of Queens in the process.

But it only took a couple of days before we learned that the so-called plot had
little chance of succeeding, that the so-called plotters had no explosives or
financial backing to carry out the attack and that the chief source of
intelligence for law enforcement agencies was a convicted drug dealer who
infiltrated the so-called terror cell in exchange for a lighter sentence.

None of the would-be attackers had ties to Iraq, Iran or any other country in
the Middle East. They had no ties to al-Qaida or any other terrorist group.

Of course, none of this got the big screaming headlines that the initial news of
the arrests did. But it's been par for the course in the alleged global war on
terror that the Bush administration is waging.

We've seen the pattern time and time again. The most absurd and improbable plots
get hyped into the next 9/11 by the administration, aided by a compliant media
that can't resist a seemingly juicy story.

Certainly, every lead needs to be investigated and people who might be plotting
some sort of attack should be arrested. But not all threats are created equal
and too many of them have been blown out of proportion.

Remember the guys who were going to use a blowtorch to take down the Brooklyn
Bridge? The "Lackawanna Six," the Yemen-Americans allegedly linked to al-Qaida?
Jose Padilla and the "dirty bomb" that never was? The "Seas of David" group in
Miami that wanted to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago? All of these were hyped
into major plots, and in every case, there was far more talk than action.

Even the recent "plot" to attack Fort Dix in New Jersey, while slightly more
plausible, had an extremely low probability of success. Unless the six guys are
Sylvester Stallone, Chuck Norris, Bruce Willis, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Steven
Seagal and Jean-Claude Van Damme -- in character, of course -- they are not
going to infiltrate an Army base.

The irony of the terrorism hype is that it helps the terrorists. After all, the
whole point of terrorism is to terrorize. And if people are running around
afraid that swarthy Arabic men are going to blow them to bits, well, the
terrorists have won.

On Monday, New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg offered the best advice for
Americans -- "Get a life."

"There are lots of threats to you in the world," Bloomberg said. "There's the
threat of a heart attack for genetic reasons. You can't sit there and worry
about everything. You have much greater chance of being hit by lightning than
being struck by a terrorist."

Instead of freaking out at every hint of a threat, Americans should take a deep
breath and recognize that there is nothing to worry about -- except from
politicians who want to manipulate our fears to carry out their policies.

LOAD-DATE: June 8, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


   Copyright 2007 MediaNews Group, Inc. and New England Newspaper Group Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved

Control Data Corp. has added Shazam from the University of British Columbia,
Premini from K & H Computer Systems, Ltd. and three Plot 10 graphics development
applications from Tektronix, Inc. to the Control Data Network Operating/Virtual
Environment software base for users of its Cyber 180 computer systems.

Premini is a project-management application for setting goals and scheduling
resources, according to the vendor.

The Plot 10 applications include the Plot 10 Graphical Kernal System, the Plot
10 Interactive Graphics Library and the Plot 10 Terminal Control System.

Shazam costs $900. Premini costs $20,000, and the Plot 10 applications cost from
$7,000 to $25,000.

                             184 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                           Ledger (Lakeland, Florida)

                          September 9, 2000, Saturday

GRAVE PLOT PRICES TO RISE; HAINES CITY RESIDENTS FLOCKING TO SAVE MONEY.

BYLINE: AMBER SMITH The Ledger

SECTION: East Polk; Pg. F1

LENGTH: 356 words


HAINES CITY -- Residents have been swarming to City Hall to purchase cemetery
plots before city commissioners more than double the prices.

City commissioners have agreed to raise the prices of cemetery plots at the two
city-owned cemeteries, Forest Hill and Oakland. Costs will rise from $ 150 per
plot to $ 360 for residents, while nonresidents will see prices rise from $ 300
to $ 720 per plot.

"We sold 95 plots in all of last year and I've sold 53 plots in the past two
weeks," said City Clerk Cherry Dowdy. "Everyone seems to want to get their lots
before the prices go up. I've probably had 25 calls in the past week asking when
the rates are going up."

Commissioners have not yet set the date when the prices will rise. Dowdy said
she thought the issue might be on the agenda for the Sept. 21 commission
meeting.

"I don't know if the commissioners will want the new prices to take effect
immediately or if they will wait until Oct. 1," Dowdy said.

In Haines City, residents are actually given the deed to their cemetery plot.
The city maintains the cemetery by mowing and trimming weeds.

Dowdy said people can either pick out their own plots or the city can pick them
out for them.

"Most people like to pick out their own spots," she said. "They come in and make
an appointment to go out and look at the lots and then after they pay for them,
I make out a deed and send it off to Bartow to be recorded."

Dowdy said residents can also buy plots in bulk by buying a lot.

A lot actually has room for eight plots. Anyone buying a lot is charged per plot
.

"I had one family that bought 11 plots and then decided to go ahead and buy
three more. That's probably the most I have sold at one time," she said.

Dowdy said the city has been in charge of selling the plots since the late
1920s.

"I've got an old book that has entries from 1927 in it," she said.

Dowdy said she doesn't expect the rush on the plots to slow down any time soon.

"I was joking that I need to go out and pick out my plot, too," Dowdy said.

Anyone interested in buying a plot or a lot can call Dowdy at City Hall at
421-3650.

LOAD-DATE: September 11, 2000

                             185 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             El Paso Times (Texas)

                            June 20, 2012 Wednesday

Fabens woman's reserved cemetery plot used to bury another person

BYLINE: By Ramón Rentería \ El Paso Times

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 580 words


Maria Rivera scraped together $1,200 to reserve a cemetery plot next to her
husband, Lorenzo, a humble cotton gin retiree known as "El Guero."

Rivera, 85, just recently learned the plot she had reserved at Our Lady of
Guadalupe Parish Cemetery in Fabens was mistakenly used to bury someone else.

Rivera, a Fabens homemaker and mother of four adult children, thought she had
taken an important step toward fulfilling her husband's fondest wish: that they
be buried next to each other after more than 60 years of marriage.

Now, Rivera is upset and disenchanted. Her family and church officials cannot
agree on how the situation, the result of a clerical error, should be fixed.

Church officials acknowledged they made a mistake, but say the family made extra
demands and rejected their offer to reserve a spot for Maria Rivera at another
nearby plot.

Lorenzo Rivera Sr. died in May from diabetes-related complications. He was 87.

The Rivera family went to the cemetery on Father's Day to pay their respects to
Lorenzo and discovered the plot previously reserved for Maria Rivera is now
occupied by 19-year-old Eber Antonio Gonzalez, who died recently.

Maria Rivera declined to be interviewed in detail, but her children and
grandchildren say the experience has left her angry.

"At this point, it looks like they (church officials) are not going to do the
right thing," said Joy Mahmood, 38, a workers' compensation insurance adjuster
in California and one of Lorenzo and Maria Rivera's nine grandchildren. "The
whole family is devastated."

Mahmood claims the church is unwilling to move her grandfather to another plot
or to dig him up and make the grave deeper so his wife can be buried in the same
grave, like the double-decker graves at Fort Bliss National Cemetery.

The Catholic parish in Fabens operates the cemetery about 30 miles east of El
Paso.

Whether the family or the church will foot the bill for a headstone and whether
Maria Rivera should be reimbursed is also in dispute.

"What irks me is that my grandmother used her savings to pay for this up front,"
Mahmood said. "I think we're being reasonable."

Lorenzo Rivera's children and grandchildren described him as a humble Mexican
immigrant who became a naturalized United States citizen. He loved to garden,
rooted for the San Francisco 49ers and loved the American flag on the pole in
his front yard. He built a three-bedroom house for his family in Fabens.

"They don't make men like him anymore," Mahmood said.

All front doors to the church and rectory were locked on Tuesday.

The Rev. Tonio Mena, pastor of Our Lady of Guadalupe Parish, declined to comment
via telephone.

Norrine Stitt, 75, a lifelong Fabens resident who works as a volunteer at the
church, said by phone that the Rivera family has been unwilling to compromise
with the church.

"It was an honest mistake," she said. "We tried to compromise by reserving a
spot at the head of their father so they would be together. But they wanted us
to dig the body out and put it another place. We can't do that."

Larry Rivera Jr., 59, one of Maria and Lorenzo Rivera Sr.'s sons, said he is
hopeful the family can resolve the dispute without going to court.

Maria Rivera is not sure any solution that is hammered out between her relatives
and church officials is going to make her or the family happy.

"Ya no le hace, tierra es tierra. (It doesn't matter, earth is earth)," she said
in a brief telephone conversation.

Ramcn Renterca may be reached at rrenteria@elpasotimes.com; 546-6146.

LOAD-DATE: June 21, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Lorenzo Rivera's grave is at right at Our Lady of Guadalupe Parish Cemetery in
Fabens.
Larry Rivera, Jr. stood before the grave of his father, Lorenzo Rivera, Tuesday
at the Fabens Cemetery.

                             186 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            January 23, 2015 Friday

Wisconsin: Sustainable Development Institute Completes Installation of Forest
Monitoring Plots

LENGTH: 397  words

DATELINE: Madison


College of Menominee Nation's, The State of Wisconsin has issued the following
News release:

Over the past two years, eight students and two crew leaders worked under the
guidance of the Director of the Center for First Americans Forestlands and with
the support of scientists from UW Green Bay and the Smithsonian Institute to
delineate, survey, and census three - one hectare climate change forest
monitoring plots. One plot located on the East side of the College of Menominee
Nation (CMN) Keshena campus is considered a training plot. The other two plots
are located in the northern region of the Menominee Indian Reservation, and are
considered long-term forest monitoring plots. The plots can be used for a
variety of activities ranging from casual discussions, to structured "outdoor"
classroom tasks, to advanced research which includes monitoring various
ecological aspects of the forest to measure the impacts of climate change. The
training plot at CMN is part of a larger outdoor learning exhibit termed "The
Learning Path," which extends for about a half mile along the East side of the
Keshena campus. The plots were installed using an advanced tree census protocol
developed by Dr. Richard Condit.

The installation of these plots was funded partially through the financial and
technical assistance of the Smithsonian Institute. The plot work is a component
of a larger three-year project funded primarily through a USDA-NIFA Tribal
Research Grant Program titled, "Measuring the Pulse of the Forest." The NIFA
project essentially has two primary components; Forest-based ecological data
collection (Plot Installation), and cultural assessment of the forest resource
related to climate change. Chris Caldwell, Director, SDI, has been the principle
investigator of the cultural piece of this project, working in conjunction with
Michigan St. University and other project partners to build capacity in this
context. Dean Fellman, Director, Center for First Americans Forestlands, has
been working with the Smithsonian Institution and other partners to build
research capacity through the plot installation. The report available here is
focused on the forest plot work, and was issued as both a courtesy and condition
of the assistance Smithsonian provided.

                              LNP (Lancaster, PA)

                             March 16, 2015 Monday

Here's A Sign Of Spring;
Public Garden Plots Now Available For Rent Public Garden

BYLINE: Ad Crable

SECTION: A; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 282  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


ACRABLE@LNPNEWS.COM

If you are desperately seeking some kind of sign that spring is just around the
corner, here's one: The public garden plots in Lancaster County Central Park are
now available for rent.

The plots have been a popular source for green thumbs since the 1970s. More
recently, organic plots have been added that are free of pesticides and
herbicides for several years.

The gardening season is from April 15 through Oct. 15.

"Being involved in a community garden plot program provides an opportunity to
meet people and to share gardening techniques, plants and food," observes Lisa
Sanchez, a park naturalist.

"It's a great idea to grow your own food, to choose what you want to plant.
Watching birds and other wildlife in their outdoor habitat is an added plus."

The plots are ideal for gardeners with limited spaces at home or for groups
looking for a summer project, Sanchez says.

The gardening area is located along Farm View Drive, just off Golf Road, and is
in a high, open area in the park.

To rent a plot, call the Central Park office at 299-8215 or go in person to the
office at 1050 Rockford Road from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday through Friday. For
more information, visit lancastercountyparks.org.

You must be a Lancaster County resident to rent a plot.

Available are plots 20 feet by 20 feet for $22 or plots 20 feet by 40 feet for
$27.50.

n Now available to rent in Lancaster County Central Park

n Located along Farm View Drive, just off Golf Road

n Season is from April 15 through Oct. 15

                                The Denver Post

                           August 16, 2006 Wednesday
                                 FINAL EDITION

THE OPEN FORUM - Letters to the editor

SECTION: DENVER & THE WEST; Pg. B-06

LENGTH: 1241 words


FasTracks and the rising cost of materials Re: "Soaring costs drive RTD to put
plans on fast track," Aug. 9 news story.

Regarding the upward trend of global construction material prices, RTD general
manager Cal Marsella said, "Nobody could have seen this coming."

Actually, many people saw this coming and voiced their concerns during the
FasTracks campaign in 2004. The voters approved the $4.7 billion budget while
the price of steel nearly doubled in 2004. Many of us at the FasTracks public
hearings urged RTD to revise its cost estimates to account for the construction
materials price increase.

Soon, the original $4.7 billion budget will be exhausted. RTD will be forced to
reduce the scope of the project or ask the taxpayers for another tax increase.
The Gold Line Rail or the U.S. 36 Corridor Bus Rapid Transit could face dramatic
reductions because the allocated funding for the projects, with earlier
completion goals, will most likely be over budget, resulting in reductions in
the project scope of the later-completing projects.

Bret Egan, Arvada

----------------------------------------

Airplane terror plot foiled by British intelligence

I heartily commend the British for their extraordinary efforts in foiling the
terrorist plot to destroy U.S.-bound airliners. Since September 2001, liberals
have attempted to discredit the Bush administration for its efforts to fight the
war on terror. Liberal Democrats whine about NSA eavesdropping of terrorist
plots in favor of civil rights. The state of Connecticut is rejoicing at the
recent defeat of Sen. Joe Lieberman, who supports the war in Iraq. Anti-war
protesters are demanding terrorists' rights in Lebanon.

The London plot is a wake-up call to all of us. As we have witnessed, this
diabolical and sinister enemy will stop at nothing to achieve its purpose. Yet,
in spite of it all, there are those who just don't get it.

Brian Stuckey, Denver

...

Letter-writer Richard Becker attempts to use the foiling of an alleged terrorist
plot in Britain as justification for spying on ordinary U.S. citizens here (Aug.
12 Open Forum). This conclusion is based on two false premises. This activity
occurred in Britain, not in the U.S. I don't know what constitutional
protections Brits have, nor do I care, because I am not British. And it has not
been reported what methods were used to uncover this alleged plot. Furthermore,
the people involved in this alleged plot hardly seem like "ordinary citizens" to
me, if indeed they were citizens at all.

Meanwhile, it should be clear that the terrorists are not from (or even in)
Iraq, although we continue to punish Iraqis by waging our "war on terror" in
their country.

Joe Felice, Aurora

---------------------------------------- Legal rights for same-sex partners in
Colo. Re: "Gay and lesbian issues to dominate the ballot again," Aug. 9 Al
Knight column.

In the latest of his series of columns opposing basic legal rights for committed
same-sex couples, Al Knight seems to believe that the best way to beat
Referendum I is to call the measure something it simply isn't.

Knight, who has written three columns on this issue but has yet to contact our
campaign to learn the facts about it, wants readers to believe that Referendum I
is indistinguishable from gay marriage. That's just factually wrong.

In fact, even the most prominent supporters of a state constitutional amendment
to ban gay marriage have repeatedly stated publicly that Referendum I isn't gay
marriage, that voters can vote for both, and the two can co-exist. And national
proponents of gay marriage have also pointed out that Referendum I falls short
of gay marriage. So, on this point - that Referendum I is not gay marriage -
these two opposing groups agree.

Even more importantly, Knight ignores the simple, essential and common-sense
protections and responsibilities that Referendum I grants. It's just basic
fairness to ensure that Coloradans have the right to visit a sick partner in a
hospital. Or to ensure that couples can make end-of-life decisions and funeral
arrangements for each other. Or that they can leave their property to their
partner without onerous tax consequences.

These are the basics. And today, thousands of Colorado couples are denied these
fundamental protections that legally empower them to take care of each other.

No matter how opponents of basic legal rights try to confuse the facts, the
facts are clear. Referendum I isn't gay marriage. It's basic legal rights.

Sean Duffy, Denver

The writer is executive director of Coloradans for Fairness Issue Committee, the
statewide group promoting Referendum I.

----------------------------------------

Political invective

Re: "Perlmutter starts with an insult," Aug. 10 David Harsanyi column.

David Harsanyi takes congressional candidate Ed Perlmutter to task for a
"sanctimonious assertion," to wit: "that sometimes you have to take your kids to
college." This was directed to a childless and unmarried Republican opponent,
Rick O'Donnell. What nonsense. Harsanyi claims to be a fan of "invective in
politics." Just imagine if Perlmutter were unmarried and childless: there'd be a
flurry of Republican-style invective implying that, at Perlmutter's age, being
unmarried and childless is a sure sign that he's a ponce. If Harsanyi likes
invective, he must love Ann Coulter's poisonous ranting from the extreme right -
she makes Perlmutter seem like a Christian (a real one, not re-born).

Scott Mock, Boulder

----------------------------------------

Immigration and wages

Re: "Who's taking whose jobs?" Aug. 14 editorial.

In your editorial, the crux of the whole thing is captured in a single
statement: "The study didn't examine the impact of immigrant labor on wage
levels." Without wage information, the entire Pew Hispanic Center study is
worthless.

I would like to see a study about these "jobs Americans don't want" include a
thorough analysis of pay scales and at what point Americans do want these jobs.
I suspect such a study would find that Americans don't want these jobs at the
current low pay rate being offered, which is often below the minimum wage.

It is time to stop attempting to justify importing cheap, illegal labor with
dubious studies like this one. The jobs that no one wants would be happily
filled by eager workers if the pay was enough to live on. Yes, that might mean
we all pay a little bit more for some things, but it would be well worth it to
provide meaningful employment for our fellow Americans.

Connie Szeflinski, Boulder

----------------------------------------

Daily news plus history

Re: "Cuba's Colorado connection," Aug. 8 Ed Quillen column.

I never miss Ed Quillen's column, and I thought last Tuesday's was especially
timely. It was an interesting bit of history that most of us did not know.

It is nice to read the paper and actually learn something of historical
interest, as well as the daily events.

B.E. Martin, Denver

---------------------------------------- Cartoon depictions of President Bush

I frequently see cartoons by Mike Keefe and others that depict President Bush as
a donkey-eared moron.

These smack of childish behavior that all of us have seen in school. Namely,
when bullies don't like someone, mean and vicious name-calling and other
assaults often happen.

I defend the right to characterize newsworthy people in many different ways
through cartoons. So why not emphasize his manly chest or his grin? At least
those are real characteristics of the president.

Bob Bamford, Aurora

                             189 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                      Monterey County Herald (California)

                           December 28, 2010 Tuesday

British court charges 9 in embassy terror plot

BYLINE: The Monterey County Herald

SECTION: WORLD

LENGTH: 599 words


LONDON (AP)   Nine men suspected of plotting attacks on the U.S. Embassy and the
London Stock Exchange were charged with terrorism-related crimes Monday and
jailed until their next court appearance.

A dozen men were arrested last week in London, Cardiff and Stoke-on-Trent in
central England in the largest British anti-terror raid in two years. Three were
released without charge. The arrests came at a time of heightened anxiety about
terror plots in Europe.

British officials have released few details, but U.S. State Department spokesman
Mark Toner said the American Embassy in London was among the alleged plot's
possible targets.

"(We) are obviously taking suitable security precautions," Toner told reporters
in Washington.

U.K. officials have previously said that possible targets included the Houses of
Parliament in London and shopping areas elsewhere in the U.K. Others on the
potential target list included the London Stock Exchange as well as political
and religious figures, the BBC reported, citing court proceedings.

A spokeswoman for Britain's Crown Prosecution Service said she could provide no
comment or confirmation of what was said in court Monday, a national holiday in
Britain.

Although the arrests occurred Dec. 21, a security official said last week that
this latest conspiracy didn't appear to be timed for the holidays.

It also wasn't linked to a larger European plot uncovered in the fall involving
a Mumbai-style shooting spree in cities across Britain, France or Germany, or to
last week's suicide bombing in Sweden, he said.

He spoke on condition of anonymity because the investigation was ongoing.

The suspects are expected back in court Jan. 14 on a variety of terror-related
charges including conspiracy to cause explosions.

Europe has been the target of numerous terror plots by Islamist militants. The
deadliest was the 2004 Madrid train bombings, when shrapnel-filled bombs
exploded, killing 191 people and wounding about 1,800.

Britain's terror alert has remained unchanged at "severe" while Germany upped
its terror alert Nov. 17 in response to an increased threat from Islamic
extremists.

Since the 2005 suicide bombing attacks on London's transportation network that
killed 52 commuters, there have been a number of other alleged terror plots in
Britain.

In April 2009, 12 men were detained over an alleged al-Qaida bomb plot in the
northern city of Manchester. All were subsequently released without charge and
ordered to leave Britain. One of them, Abid Naseer, was later re-arrested at the
request of the U.S., which says he was involved a plot to bomb the New York City
subway. He is in jail awaiting extradition.

In 2006, U.S. and British intelligence officials thwarted one of the most
dramatic plots yet made public, a plan to explode nearly a dozen trans-Atlantic
airliners.

The nine men in the latest alleged plot are: Gurukanth Desai, 28, Omar Sharif
Latif, 26, and Abdul Malik Miah, 24, from Cardiff, Mohammed Moksudur Rahman
Chowdhury, 20, and Shah Mohammed Lutfar Rahman, 28, from London, and Nazam
Hussain, 25, Usman Khan, 19, Mohibur Rahman, 26, and Abul Bosher Mohammed
Shahjahan, 26, from Stoke-on-Trent.

The decision to charge them was announced early Monday, with police saying that
the conspiracy started Oct. 1 and continued until Dec. 20, the day of the
arrests.

The men are also accused of preparing for acts of terrorism, downloading and
researching materials and methods for acts of terrorism, and carrying out
reconnaissance missions and testing incendiary material.


Associated Press Writer Matthew Lee in Washington contributed to this report.

LOAD-DATE: December 28, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved


                             190 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                     The Journal Record (Oklahoma City, OK)

                          February 11, 2004 Wednesday

Legislation to allow unused burial plots to be resold approved by Okla. House
committee

BYLINE: Journal Record staff

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 255 words


Legislation that would allow abandoned, unused burial plots to be sold again has
been approved by a state House committee.

Rep. Elmer Maddux said that in his predominantly rural district, some cemetery
plots were sold years ago and apparently have been forgotten. Some of the
abandoned plots are more than 75 years old, the Mooreland Republican told
members of the House Committee on the Judiciary. "The lots are just sitting
there," he said.

House Bill 2504 by Maddux would establish guidelines under which an abandoned
burial plot could revert to private or public cemetery use. The plot could not
be claimed unless 75 years or more had passed since the last recorded activity
on the space and a "reasonable search for heirs and beneficiaries" had been
conducted.

The cemetery would be required to send a letter of notice to the last known
address of the property owner of record. Committee members amended the measure
to provide for instances where an address is not available. Cemetery owners also
would be required to publish a description of the abandoned space for three
weeks.

If no person can prove ownership of the burial space within one year of the
publication, the burial space would be deemed abandoned and ownership would
transfer to the cemetery.

HB 2504 stipulates that if a person were to come forward with a legitimate claim
to a burial space after it had been sold or used by the cemetery, the claim
would be resolved by having the cemetery issue "an equal burial space in an
equivalent location."

LOAD-DATE: February 11, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Government activity

                             191 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Hobart Mercury (Australia)

                            July 14, 2010 Wednesday
                                  1 - Edition

Life in jail for airline bomb plot

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 21

LENGTH: 253  words


THREE men from London have been jailed for life for plotting mass murder in a
conspiracy to blow up transatlantic flights using liquid bombs.

Ibrahim Savant, Arafat Waheed Khan and Waheed Zaman will serve at least 20 years
in jail over the plot that led to strict rules about carrying liquids on
commercial flights.

The sentences mark the end of a long-running series of trials over the largest
terror plot ever foiled in Britain.

The process has cost more than $51.44 million.

Savant, 29, Khan, 29, and Zaman, 26, were tried last year in connection with the
2006 plot to blow up seven transatlantic flights using liquid explosives.

They were cleared of specifically targeting airlines, but prosecutors tried them
again this year on charges of conspiracy to murder, based on "martyrdom videos"
they recorded threatening attacks on Western targets.

They were found guilty on Thursday at the high-security Woolwich Crown Court.

In passing sentence, judge Timothy Holroyde called the trio "foot soldiers" in
the operation, who did not know their intended targets and took no part in its
planning or in assembling the explosives.

The liquid bomb plot targeted seven flights from London to San Francisco,
Toronto, Montreal, Washington, New York and Chicago that departed within
two-and-a-half hours of each other.

The plan was to smuggle explosives made of hydrogen peroxide onto the planes in
soft drink bottles. Refilled batteries would carry the chemical detonator, with
the bombs set off using a charge from a light bulb filament.

LOAD-DATE: July 13, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                             192 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          Reading Eagle, Pennsylvania

               Distributed by Knight/Ridder Tribune News Service

                            March 1, 2006 Wednesday

Officials make graveyard discovery: No one is sure why more than 500 people from
Montgomery County are buried in plots that were supposed to go to Berks County
veterans.

BYLINE: Mary E. Young, Reading Eagle, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 374 words


Mar. 1--Records at a Montgomery County cemetery show that more than 500
Montgomery residents are buried in plots donated to Berks County veterans, Berks
Commissioner Thomas W. Gajewski Sr. said Tuesday.

Gajewski said that he, assistant county Solicitor Christine M. Sadler and
Controller Sandy Graffius made the discovery last week when they visited the
Limerick Garden of Memories Inc. to determine what happened to 830 plots donated
to the Berks veterans affairs office more than 20 years ago.

Cemetery officials had claimed that only 270 plots were unused but would not
provide information over the telephone about who was buried in the other 560
plots, Gajewski said.

He said no plots have been transferred since 1996 when a new owner took over the
cemetery.

A card system used before then shows the names and addresses of who is buried in
the plots, but provides no information on who authorized the cemetery to
transfer the plots to those people or if they were veterans, Gajewski said. A
few of the people were from Boyertown, but the rest were from Montgomery County,
he said.

"Why would Berks give plots to people from outside Berks County before we would
give them to Berks County veterans?" Gajewski asked.

More information may be available from Berks and Montgomery records, death
certificates and funeral homes, he said.

"I don't know if we're ever going to get any answers because this is old," he
said. "But I don't want to just accept their word that it's 270 (remaining). I
want to go beyond that. We're talking a difference of several hundred plots."

Commissioner Mark C. Scott said the system used by the cemetery also prevents
the county from learning if any of the remaining plots have been transferred to
people who still are alive.

Apparently, Commissioner Judith L. Schwank said, a system to transfer the plots
to veterans had never been set up.

Five men from New York and one man from New Jersey donated the plots, but no
information has been found to show why they chose Berks.

Business News. For information on republishing this content, contact us at (800)
661-2511 (U.S.), (213) 237-4914 (worldwide), fax (213) 237-6515, or e-mail
reprints@krtinfo.com.

                             193 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                 Sunday Express

                              June 3, 2007 Sunday

Three held in JFK airport terror plot;
Fourth suspect still on run over plan to kill thousands by blowing up jet-fuel
tanks

BYLINE: By Aidan Harrison

SECTION: NEWS; 2

LENGTH: 580  words


THREE people were arrested yesterday over an alleged terror plot to blow up New
York's JFK airport.

A fourth suspect is still on the run over the plan to plant explosives in
jet-fuel tanks and pipelines which, if detonated, would have destroyed the
airport, killing thousands.

One of three arrested men was caught boasting that the bombing would wreck "the
whole of Kennedy" and cause more damage than the September 11 terror attacks,
law enforcement officials said yesterday.

New York district attorney Rosslyn Mauskopf said they had foiled "one of the
most chilling plots imaginable".

She added: "The devastation that would have been caused had this plot succeeded
is just unthinkable."

Police said investigations had been helped by an informant who recorded
conversations with the suspects.

One of them, Russell Defreitas, forecast "the whole of Kennedy" would be hit,
allegedly saying: "Any time you hit Kennedy, it is the most hurtful thing to the
United States. To hit John F Kennedy, wow . . . They love John F Kennedy like
he's the man . . . If you hit that, this whole country will be mourning. You can
kill the man twice. Even the Twin Towers can't touch it. This can destroy the
economy of America for some time."

The main 40-mile pipeline they targeted takes fuel from a facility in Linden,
New Jersey, to the airport. Other lines service LaGuardia Airport and Newark
Liberty International Airport.

Defreitas, a former cargo worker at JFK and a US citizen, was arrested in
Brooklyn.

Abdul Karir, a Muslim imam, Guyanan citizen and former member of the Guyanan
parliament, was arrested in Trinidad and Tobago, along with fellow suspect
Kareem Ibrahim.

Police said Karir, who left the Guyanan parliament last year, was arrested on
suspicion of trying to secure money for "terrorist operations". The fourth man
was named as Abdel Nur, also a citizen of Guyana.

The FBI described Karir and Nur as associates of Jamaat Al Muslimeen, which was
behind a deadly coup attempt in Trinidad in 1990.

The plot tapped into an international network of Muslim extremists from the
United States, Guyana and Trinidad, the agency added.

New York police commissioner said Raymond Kelly said: "Once again terrorists
have had New York in the crosshairs. Once again, law enforcement agencies have
joined forces to stop them."

But he added that the involvement of a Caribbean link was a "worrying
development".

Mr Kelly described Defreitas as "a self-radicalised New Yorker who was born and
raised in Guyana, but came to New York to live and work, before plotting to
betray his adopted country with a catastrophic attack".

The conspiracy allegedly began in January last year, but investigators insisted
the men were arrested before any risk to the public was posed.

FBI spokesman Richard Kolko added: "There is no threat to air safety or the
public related to this plot."

John F Kennedy International Airport is the busiest airport in the US, handling
more than 100,000 passengers every day and 41million per year.

The arrests mark the latest in a series of alleged homegrown terrorism plots
targeting highprofile American landmarks.

A year ago, seven men were arrested in the early stages of a plot to blow up the
Sears Tower in Chicago and destroy FBI offices and other buildings.

A month later, authorities broke up a plot to bomb underwater New York City
train tunnels to flood lower Manhattan.

And six people were arrested a month ago in an alleged plot to attack the Fort
Dix military installation in New Jersey.

                             194 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                     Nanaimo Daily News (British Columbia)

                             July 8, 2006 Saturday
                                 Final Edition

Tunnel terror plot foiled: Officials use Internet eavesdropping to find suspects
in alleged bombing plan

BYLINE: Sheldon Alberts, CanWest News Service

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. B8

LENGTH: 708  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


WASHINGTON -- U.S. law enforcement officials on Friday said they had foiled a
terror plot to blow up commuter-train tunnels linking New York City to New
Jersey, including those leading to Lower Manhattan, the site of the Sept. 11,
2001, attacks on the World Trade Center.

At a news conference in New York, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said it
had identified eight suspects in an emerging plot apparently designed to disrupt
the U.S. economy by flooding the financial district in Lower Manhattan.

Lebanese security officials, working in concert with the FBI, have arrested a
man in Beirut identified as an al-Qaida operative and mastermind of the plan,
the officials said.

"We believe we intercepted this group early in the plotting and that in fact the
plan has largely been disrupted," said Mark Mershon, assistant director of the
FBI's New York field office. "The plotting for this attack had matured to a
point where it appeared that the individuals were about to move forward. They
were about to go to a phase where they would attempt to surveil targets,
establish a regimen of attack and acquire the resources necessary to effectuate
the attacks."

Mershon, calling the bombing plot "the real deal," said the suspects wanted to
launch a suicide bomb attack in the PATH commuter trains linking the city to its
New Jersey suburbs.

"The plan involved martyrdom, explosives and some of the tubes that connect New
Jersey to Manhattan," he said, without specifying specific targets.

The disclosure of the alleged plot came on the first anniversary of the attack
on London's Underground that killed 52 people.

It is the third alleged North American bomb plot authorities said they have
disrupted in the last two months. In June, 400 police officers conducted a
series of raids, under Canada's Anti-terrorism Act, and arrested 17 suspects in
southern Ontario.

Two weeks ago, the FBI said it had stopped a plan by suspects in Miami to blow
up Chicago's Sears Tower, though several terror experts have questioned whether
those alleged plotters had posed a serious security threat.

Mershon said several foreign intelligence agencies had aided the U.S. in the New
York investigation, but declined to say whether Canadian authorities were
involved or if any of the suspects had ties to Canada.

"Just because of the nature of the investigation, I'll refrain from making any
specific comments on it," Public Safety Minister Stockwell Day said when asked
Friday about a possible Canadian connection. "As that investigation continues to
unfold we'll see where they've all come from but because its ongoing at this
time I prefer not to comment.

"One thing that we know is that people who plan these despicable deeds, they
know no boundaries. These are terrorists without borders."

An earlier check with a federal official to determine if there was a Canadian
connection to the New York plot generated a: "No comment."

However, the source said it was a popular question on Friday.

According to the FBI's Mershon, law enforcement and intelligence agents had been
monitoring "a group of al Qaida followers" for almost a year prior through
discussions the suspects held on Internet chat rooms.

The plot was identified by intelligence officials who determined the suspects
were using code words to describe their plans to attack tunnels, officials said.

"It had not reached anything close to being operational," said New York police
commissioner Ray Kelly. But the suspects' desire to attack commuter trains
carrying hundreds of thousands of passengers each day shows "that New York still
remains in the cross-hairs of the terrorists."

Lebanese authorities said they had arrested 31-year-old Assem Hammoud and
obtained a confession from him swearing allegiance to Osama bin Laden and
revealing his hopes to carry out the attacks in New York this October or
November.

"After questioning he confessed ... that he was planning to travel to Pakistan
for four months' training and that the date for the attack was decided to be
late in 2006," the Lebanese interior ministry said in a statement.

Hammoud had been carrying out a "religious order from Osama bin Laden" and was
instructed to disguise his Islamic militancy in Beirut and lead a modern
lifestyle, the Lebanese statement said.

LOAD-DATE: July 8, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

plot to bomb the tunnel by monitoring Internet chat rooms.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                              May 13, 2007 Sunday
                                 THIRD EDITION

ARTS NEWS BRIEFS

BYLINE: CONTRIBUTORS: David bonetti, Kevin johnson, SARAH BRYAN MILLER, judith
newmark

SECTION: A&E; Pg. F2

LENGTH: 815 words


'Menopause' will close

After a 63-week run at the Playhouse at West Port Plaza, "Menopause The Musical"
will end its St. Louis run. The last performance is Sunday, May 20, at 5:30 p.m.

The show - a spoof about the "change" that features parodies of hit Baby Boomer
songs - sold more than 82,000 tickets. Tom Clyde, producing owner of the
Playhouse, said he plans to open another show in June.

During its last week, "Menopause" will play at 7:30 Tuesday-Friday, at 4 p.m.
and 7:30 p.m. Saturday and at 2 p.m. and 5:30 p.m. on May 20. Tickets, $33, are
available by calling 314-469-7529, or 314-534-1111. For more information, visit
www.playhouseatwestport.com online. (JN)

Workshop will focus on plot development

A workshop to help playwrights develop plot will be presented by First Run
Theatre on Saturday at DeSmet Jesuit High School, 233 North New Ballas Road.

David Crespy will lead the workshop, "New Machinations: Exploring Plot in Your
Play." An associate professor in the theater department at the University of
Missouri-Columbia, Crespy is co-chair of the Mid America Theatre Conference
Playwriting Symposium.

Crespy will introduce writers to techniques including plot card, plot outlines,
plot treatment and dream work. Writers are invited to bring short plays or play
segments to work on, as well as play ideas that they want to dramatize.

The workshop, which runs from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. (with a lunch break), costs $20.
Actors also are invited to the workshop to help as readers and to give
critiques; there is no admission charge for actors.

To register, call 314-352-5114, or visit www.firstruntheatre.com online. (JN)

Landmarks Association announces awards

The Landmarks Association of St. Louis will give awards to 11 architectural
rehab projects judged to be "most enhanced." The award ceremony and reception
takes place 5:30-7 p.m., Monday, at the Lucas School House, one of the winners,
1220 Allen Avenue. Admission is $25 at the door.

The winners, in no particular order, are:

- Neighborhood Gardens Apartments (1935), Biddle and Seventh streets

- Majestic Stove Lofts (1895-1913), 21st Street between Washington Avenue and
Delmar Boulevard

- Salena Dairy (1884-1920), 2919-21 Salena Street

- Field School Lofts (1900), 4466 Olive Street

5. Bowood Farms (1916-23), 4621 Olive Street

- Soulard Market Apartments (1899-1906), Carroll and South Eighth streets

- Marquette Building (1913), 314 North Broadway

- Tower-Manley House (1889), 1520 South Grand Boulevard

- Russell Place (1880 to the present), 2800 block of Russell Boulevard

- North Market Place Apartments (1870-1910), various addresses

- Lucas School House (1886), 1220 Allen Avenue (DB)

Craft Alliance expanding to Grand Center

Craft Alliance, whose main facility is on Delmar Boulevard in University City,
will open a satellite location in the developing Kranzberg Cultural Arts Center
in Grand Center.

The new art center, which will house a black box theater and cabaret in addition
to Craft Alliance, will be located in the former Woolworth's Building at the
corner of Grand Boulevard and Olive Street. The building's main tenant will be
Big Brothers Big Sisters.

Craft Alliance will have 5,700 square feet of space. It will feature a gallery,
education studios and studios for resident artists.

The cost of the project is expected to top $800,000; $500,000 has been raised.
(DB)

Fergie concert will be high tech

Black Eyed Peas singer Fergie is set to kick off her first solo tour, and the
Pageant is one of her stops, with a June 11 show.

The "Fergalicious" singer is touring with a twist that's being described as one
of the most innovative ever for the concert industry. Her Verizon VIP tour
incorporates wireless technology from top to bottom, beginning with tickets to
the show.

Tickets will not be sold to the concert. Fans who arrive at the Pageant flash
their picture message tickets sent to their Verizon Wireless handsets. Picture
message tickets are available by downloading V Cast Fergie content, downloading
a Fergie song on V Cast Music, attending Verizon Wireless stores events, through
radio promotions, by purchasing a Motorola handset, and more.

Green screen technology will allow fans to "dance" with Fergie in a video,
creating video messages that can be sent to their phones. One green screen
winner will join Fergie on stage during the concert's finale. Fergie will also
send fans text messages thanking them for attending. (KCJ)

Gala nets $550,000 for Opera Theatre

Opera Theatre of St. Louis' Japanese-themed spring gala, held Saturday, May 5,
did well for the company: It netted $550,000, all earmarked for professional
development and education programs.

"The combined expenses for those budget categories are in $800,000-plus range,"
said general director Charles MacKay. "They don't produce income per se. This is
our flagship fundraiser of the year, to pay for programs that are really central
to our mission." (SBM)

                             196 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                 The Oklahoman

                            April 21, 2004 Wednesday
                                  City Edition

Key witness links Nichols to plot ;
Michael Fortier again admits he might have stopped bombing

BYLINE: Nolan Clay, Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 845 words

DATELINE: McALESTER


McALESTER -- Bomber Timothy McVeigh revealed he and Terry Nichols planned to
blow up the Oklahoma City federal building, the prosecution's star witness
testified Tuesday.

Michael Fortier, 35, admitted again Tuesday that he might have stopped the
bombing had he gone to the police.

"I didn't think Tim was going to go through with it," Fortier said. "I thought
he was going to Colorado to find people more like him and that the bombing was
just not going to happen."

Fortier is the 113th witness to testify so far at Nichols' state murder trial.
He implicated Nichols in key parts of the bomb plot. He will be questioned by a
defense attorney today.

He told jurors McVeigh revealed Nichols helped buy ammonium nitrate fertilizer
at Kansas stores and helped steal explosives from a Kansas rock quarry as part
of the plot.

He said McVeigh claimed Nichols alone stole guns from an Arkansas man to finance
the plan.

Fortier said he first learned of the plot in September 1994 in a letter from
McVeigh.

"He told me that him and Terry had decided to take some type of positive action,
and he wanted to know if I wanted to help," Fortier said.

His soft-spoken testimony repeated in less detail what he said at McVeigh's
federal trial and Nichols' federal trial in Denver in 1997. Fortier said he no
longer remembers all of what McVeigh said.

He met McVeigh and Nichols in 1988 when all three joined the U.S. Army. They
were stationed together at Fort Riley, Kan. Fortier described McVeigh as a close
friend and Nichols as an acquaintance.

He said McVeigh often stayed with him in his trailer home in Kingman, Ariz., in
1993 and 1994. He said the two sometimes used crystal methamphetamine and
marijuana together.

Fortier is serving a 12-year federal sentence for not warning authorities about
the bombing, for helping McVeigh move and sell stolen guns and for lying to FBI
agents after the April 19, 1995, bombing.

He pleaded guilty in August 1995 after striking a plea agreement that required
him to testify at both the federal and state trials.

He said he refused McVeigh's demands in the weeks before the attack to help mix
the bomb. He said McVeigh complained Nichols was backing out.

"I argued with him about whether I would join him in his quest for the bombing,"
Fortier said. "He became upset ... He called me some names. And I said, 'No.'"

He said McVeigh pointed out the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building on Dec. 16,
1994, on a trip from Arizona to Kansas to pick up the guns Nichols had stolen.

He said McVeigh told him "that was the building they were planning on blowing
up." Fortier also recalled McVeigh claimed Nichols was either going to help
stash the getaway car beforehand or be in it ready to drive away.

He and Nichols never discussed the bombing. However, he said, Nichols was
present two times when McVeigh showed him explosives.

The first time, he said, McVeigh showed him a cardboard box of explosives in
October 1994 in a narrow storage shed in Kingman. He recalled Nichols "was
moving in and out of the storage unit."

"I do remember him taking a spare tire out of the unit and throwing it in the
back of his truck," Fortier said.

He testified Nichols was present again a few days later when McVeigh took
explosives from Nichols' pickup. He recalled McVeigh pulled from the pickup's
cab a milk jug of ammonium nitrate fertilizer and fuel. He said McVeigh also
showed him a sausage- like explosive at the back of the pickup.

"Tim asked me if I wanted to go out to the desert to explode these items. I
said, 'No,'" Fortier said.

He said McVeigh later revealed that Nichols robbed a man named Bob in Arkansas.
He said McVeigh related that Nichols sneaked through the woods and confronted
the man with a shotgun. He said McVeigh also described Nichols as wearing
camouflage clothes and a black ski mask.

The testimony matched in part what jurors heard earlier about the Nov. 5, 1994,
robbery from Roger E. Moore, the victim. Moore, a gun collector who lived near
Royal, Ark., sometimes went by the name Robert Miller.

The FBI found some of Moore's guns in Nichols' home in Herington, Kan., after
the bombing.

Fortier said McVeigh explained the bomb would be made of ammonium nitrate
fertilizer and fuel mixed in 55- gallon drums inside a Ryder truck.

Fortier said McVeigh targeted the Murrah Building because he believed that was
"where the orders for the burning of Waco came out of."

Fortier said McVeigh was angry after Branch Davidians died in a fire during an
FBI raid on their religious compound near Waco, Texas, on April 19, 1993.
Fortier testified McVeigh deliberately chose the second anniversary of that
tragedy for the bombing.

"He thought that was what it was going to take to get people's attention,"
Fortier said.

Fortier's appearance was different than in the federal trials. Then, he wore a
suit and tie and had short hair. Tuesday, he wore blue jeans, white sneakers and
a green-and-white plaid shirt. His hair was shoulder length. He (Fortier) and
Nichols never discussed the bombing. However, he said, Nichols was present two
times when McVeigh showed him explosives.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Tuesday after his first day of testimony. - BY STEVE SISNEY, THE OKLAHOMAN

                           Edmonton Journal (Alberta)

                            July 11, 2007 Wednesday
                                 Final Edition

Mob boss suspected in '80s plot to kill top U.S. judge; FBI documents name
Montreal's Cotroni

BYLINE: Paul Cherry, CanWest News Service

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A12

LENGTH: 391  words


Montreal mob boss Frank Cotroni and high-ranking U.S. mobsters were once
investigated for an alleged plot to assassinate the top judge in America,
according to newly released FBI documents.

The investigation into the alleged plot to assassinate Chief Justice Warren
Burger began in December 1981, after an informant came forward with information
of a jailhouse plot. It ended 15 months later with no charges being laid.
Instead, the FBI dispatched agents to warn the heads of Mafia families in the
U.S. that any attempt to assassinate Burger "would be responded to with the full
force and resources of the Justice (department) and the FBI."

The documents were obtained by the Montreal Gazette through the U.S. Freedom of
Information Act.

Access to Cotroni's FBI record was requested after he died of cancer Aug. 17,
2004, at the age of 72. He was one of three brothers who controlled illegal
rackets in Montreal for decades while they operated as a branch office for the
Bonanno crime family in New York.

In April 1979, after serving four years of a 15-year sentence for cocaine
trafficking in the U.S., Cotroni was paroled and released from a federal
penitentiary in Pennsylvania.

Two years later, the informant, who apparently served time at Lewisburg with the
Montreal mobster, told FBI that Cotroni and other Mafiosi discussed killing
Burger and a New Jersey district court judge.

The earliest reference to the FBI investigation is a "priority" teletype
communique warning of the alleged plot. It was sent on Dec. 18, 1981, from an
FBI field office in Seattle, Washington, to the FBI's director and five FBI
offices in the eastern U.S.

The message concluded with a plan to advise Burger of the suspected plot and to
pursue leads "on a very discreet basis" by investigating the backgrounds of the
suspects.

The FBI documents reveal no motive for the alleged plot. But as the top U.S.
judge, Burger might have been considered a target as a means to intimidate the
American justice system.

Cotroni, described in the FBI documents as "the boss of the Montreal (La Cosa
Nostra) family and an associate of the Bonanno LCN family," is listed as a
suspect throughout the investigation. Also listed as suspects are Phil Rastelli,
the head of the Bonanno crime family in New York until he died in 1991, and
Joseph Gambino, a captain in the Gambino crime family.

                     The Santa Fe New Mexican (New Mexico)

                              July 9, 2010 Friday

IN BRIEF

BYLINE: NEW MEXICAN WIRE SERVICES

SECTION: MAIN; Pg. A-2

LENGTH: 908 words


In brief

Federal gay marriage ban ruled unconstitutional

BOSTON -- The federal law banning gay marriage is unconstitutional because it
interferes with the right of a state to define the institution and therefore
denies married gay couples some federal benefits, a federal judge ruled Thursday
in Boston.

U.S. District Judge Joseph Tauro ruled in favor of gay couples' rights in two
separate challenges to the Defense of Marriage Act, known as DOMA, a 1996 law
that the Obama administration has argued for repealing. The rulings apply to
Massachusetts but could have broader implications if they're upheld on appeal.

The state had argued the law denied benefits such as Medicaid to gay married
couples in Massachusetts, where same-sex unions have been legal since 2004.

Tauro agreed and said the act forces Massachusetts to discriminate against its
own citizens in order to be eligible for federal funding in federal-state
partnerships.

Bomb arrests in Norway linked to N.Y terror plot

OSLO -- Three suspected al-Qaida members were arrested Thursday in a Norwegian
bomb plot linked to the same terrorist planners behind thwarted schemes to blow
up New York's subway and a British shopping mall.

The alleged Norwegian plot, underscoring changing al-Qaida tactics in the decade
since the 9/11 attacks, was said to involve powerful peroxide bombs similar to
ones aimed for detonation in New York and Manchester, England.

All three plans were organized by Saleh al-Somali, al-Qaida's former chief of
external operations, who had been in charge of plotting attacks worldwide,
Norwegian and U.S. officials believe. Al-Somali was killed in a CIA drone
airstrike last year, but officials say the three plots had already been set in
motion by the time of his death.

Thursday's arrests suggested how decentralized and nimble al-Qaida has become
since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks in the United States. The terror group has
recently focused on smaller-level attacks that don't require the intricate
planning that it took to hijack airplanes and fly them into buildings in New
York and Washington.

Last year, when the FBI and CIA thwarted the suicide attack in the New York
subway, officials called it the most dangerous plot since 9/11. And in the past
two days, revelations about the related plots in England and now in Norway have
illustrated the terror group's multi-country scope.

Mel Gibson investigated in alleged domestic violence

LOS ANGELES -- Mel Gibson is being investigated in a possible domestic violence
incident involving his ex-girlfriend earlier this year, sheriff's officials said
Thursday.

The Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department listed the actor-director as a
potential suspect in the alleged attack on Russian singer Oksana Grigorieva at
an undisclosed location in Malibu.

The two have been involved in a nasty custody dispute over their infant daughter
-- the subject of a confidential court case.

Sheriff's spokesman Steve Whitmore said detectives interviewed Grigorieva on
Monday. She has been the only person interviewed so far.

Whitmore declined to disclose further details of the investigation or any
potential evidence. "We're in the process of verifying, verifying, verifying,"
Whitmore said. "All the allegations that have been put forth will be thoroughly
investigated."

Iran stoning sentence for adultery draws outrage

LONDON -- The case of an Iranian woman sentenced to death by stoning drew
international outrage after her lawyer's blog posts sparked a global campaign to
save her life, and British media reported late Thursday that the stoning would
not occur.

The Iranian Embassy in London said that Sakineh Mohammadi Ashtiani would no
longer face death by stoning, according to Channel 4 News and The Guardian
newspaper. A message seeking comment from the embassy was not immediately
returned, and it was not immediately clear if Ashtiani still faced death by
other means.

"According to information from the relevant judicial authorities in Iran, she
will not be executed by stoning punishment," the embassy said in the statement
reported by Channel 4 News and The Guardian.

Ashtiani's face, framed in a black chador, stared from the front page of The
Times of London on Thursday, while The Guardian carried an interview with
Ashtiani's children -- 22-year-old Sajad and 17-year-old Farideh -- who
described the sentence as a nightmare. Protests are planned in front of the
Iranian Embassy over the weekend.

Egypt discovers tombs dating back 4,300 years

SAQQARA, Egypt -- Egyptian archaeologists on Thursday unveiled a newly-unearthed
double tomb with vivid wall paintings in the ancient necropolis of Saqqara near
Cairo, saying it could be the start for uncovering a vast cemetery in the area.

The tomb includes two false doors with colorful paintings depicting the two
people buried there, a father and a son who served as heads of the royal
scribes, said Abdel-Hakim Karar, a top archaeologist at Saqqara.

"The colors of the false door are fresh as if it was painted yesterday," Karar
told reporters.

Humidity had destroyed the sarcophagus of the father, Shendwas, while the tomb
of the son, Khonsu, was robbed in antiquity, he said.

Also insribed on the father's false door was the name of Pepi II, whose 90-year
reign is believed to be the longest of the pharaohs. The inscription dates the
double tomb to the 6th dynasty, which marked the beginning of the decline of the
Old Kingdom, also known as the age of pyramids.

New Mexican wire services

SECTION: LIFE; Pg. D1

LENGTH: 342 words


Stake out a plot

Bloomington Parks and Recreation will open registration Wednesday for the
Community Gardens for Bloomington residents. Proof of residency will be required
(such as a driver's license or tax bill). Non-resident registration will begin
Thursday. The garden plots are on the southwest corner of Hershey and Ireland
Grove roads, with eight plots 12 by 30 feet for $15 each and 38 plots 25 by 30
feet for $30 each. The plots will be plowed prior to opening. Renters are
responsible for any additional soil preparation. Water is available at the site.
For more information call (309) 434-2260

.

Ward off spiders

Q: Is there any way to discourage spiders from building webs in places like
corners?

A: Ohio State University entomologist Susan C. Jones recommends destroying the
webs as soon as they're built. Often the spiders will move elsewhere if their
webs are destroyed continually. You can remove the webs with a duster, vacuum
cleaner or broom. Outdoors, you can discourage web-building by making an effort
to avoid attracting the insects that spiders feed on, Jones said. Use yellow bug
lights, or avoid outdoor lighting as much as possible.

- Mary Beth Breckenridge, Akron Beacon Journal

DVDs not universal

Q: I got a DVD in Italy. It won't work now that we're home. What can we do to be
able to view the DVD?

A: The problem is the formatting. In Europe, DVDs use the PAL format, while in
the United States it's NTSC. The respective DVD players don't recognize the
other's discs. There are two things you can do, said Jessica Mattson of Token
Media in Minneapolis.

- Computers don't care about the format. You can play the DVD on your computer
to view the video.

- The DVD can be transferred to NTSC format and then played on your DVD player.
The cost is about $40 for a one-hour DVD or $55 for two hours.

- Karen Youso, Star Tribune (Minneapolis)

                               The New York Times

                August 18, 1993, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

Sudanese Deny Any Tie To Bomb Plot

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL,  Special to The New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 2; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 477 words

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 17


The Sudanese Mission to the United Nations today denied any role in a plot to
bomb the U.N. headquarters and other targets in New York last June.

The denial came after a State Department official said Monday that the United
States has evidence that the Sudan played a role in the plot, although he would
not give details. The evidence is one reason Washington has decided to place the
Sudan on a list of terrorist nations, he said. A law-enforcement official,
though, today said there was no "hard evidence" of Sudanese government
involvement, just possible indications of involvement on tapes made by a
Government informer.

A report Monday on ABC News linked two Sudanese diplomats here to the bomb plot
and said the mission was under F.B.I. surveillance.

In a statement, the Sudanese Mission said it "categorically refutes as baseless
any allegation or suggestion relating to the involvement of the mission or its
staff in the so-called New York bombing plot."

Federal and city law-enforcement officials arrested eight men in the
metropolitan area in June and charged them in the bombing plot. Five of them,
including Siddig Ibrahim Siddig Ali, who was described by Federal authorities as
the ringleader, were born in the Sudan but had permanent resident status here.

'Outrageous and Malicious'

In taped conversations with a Government informant, Mr. Siddig Ali spoke of
contacts in the Sudanese Government and discussed using a van from the Sudanese
mission to carry a bomb into the U.N. headquarters.

ABC News identified the two Sudanese as Siraj Yousif, counselor to the mission,
and Ahmed Mohammed, the third secretary. Both are Sudanese intelligence officers
posing as diplomats, ABC said.

Reached at the mission, Mr. Yousif characterized the ABC report about him as
"outrageous and malicious," and criticized the television news team for using
only 50 seconds of the 20-minute interview he gave.

They reached "ridiculous conclusions," he said, and "they managed to block out
completely the Sudanese point of view.

"There is not a scintilla of evidence connecting me or the Sudanese Government
to the bomb plot," he said. Mr. Yousif scoffed at reports that he was an
intelligence officer.

Filmed Scene Is Disputed

Television footage of what ABC News called "terrorist training camps" in the
Sudan, he said, were actually "popular defense camps" where young Sudanese men
took their military training. "It is not the army but paramilitary or civil
defense forces," he said. "It is not secret; it is open. ABC people did not
discover anything."

In its statement, the mission said that the Sudan "strongly condemns as criminal
and unjustifiable all acts, methods and practices of terrorism" and said that
the news reports were meant to "smear the image of the Sudan at the expense of
fairness, justice and objectivity."

LOAD-DATE: August 18, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

 According to the abstract published by the UK Intellectual Property Office on
its website " Propeller blade pitch altering assembly10 having a spider hub 12
comprising a hub 14 and a set of arms 16 circumferentially about the hub and
projecting radially from the hub 14, wherein the set of arms 16 receive a set of
blades 20 such that a blade root 22 is rotationally mountable into an arm 16
included in the set of arms 16. A crosshead 42, located within the hub is
axially moveable relative to the hub and attaches to a torque tube 44 via a
motion converter 46. The torque tube connects at a first end to the blade root
22. When the crosshead is moved axially, the motion converter, preferably
comprising a needle bearing located in a channel, converts the axial motion to a
rotational one, rotating the torque tube and altering the pitch of the
propeller"

 The patent was filed on  06 July 2016  under Application No.  GB1611757.4
