                                   USA TODAY

                      July 19, 1993, Monday, FINAL EDITION

L.A. church stands tall // Hate-crime plot fails to intimidate congregation

BYLINE: Sally Ann Stewart

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 463 words

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES


Every Sunday at First African Methodist Episcopal Church, the pews are crowded,
the choir is rocking and the prayers are heartfelt.

But Sunday - in the wake of last week's foiled bombing and massacre plot by
white supremacists - worship services at the oldest black church in the nation's
second-largest city took on a special aura.

"You can feel the excitement in the people," said Yvonne Wallace, 27, a
teacher's aide who sat in the packed balcony during the 8 a.m. service. "We had
the shock of finding out that someone was trying to kill a whole congregation .
. . but we're still here, so we're joyous."

Last week, federal and state officials arrested eight white supremacists, saying
they planned to bomb the church to start a race war.

Christopher David Fisher, 20, manager of a Long Beach sandwich shop, has been
charged with leading the plot, which called for killing well-known blacks,
including Rodney King and First AME Senior Minister Cecil Murray.

One of the accused - whose name is not public because he's under 18 - is
scheduled to be arraigned today in Long Beach.

Members of the Fourth Reich Skinheads say they were entrapped by overzealous FBI
agents who infiltrated the group and secretly videotaped skinheads airing their
opinions about race.

Sunday, even before the sky-blue-robed choir walked in, church members were on
their feet, clapping and cheering. Everyone seemed to sing the refrain of the
hymn - Study war no more - a bit louder than usual. More than the usual 2,500
showed up for each of the three services.

Security was stepped up.

State Treasurer Kathleen Brown was there for the first service. Mayor Richard
Riordan and District Attorney Gil Garcetti - who grew up in the neighborhood -
attended the 10 a.m. service.

"Today is one of those days we say thanks that we are here," Brown told
worshipers. "We must stand against racism, stand against hatred, stand against
violence . . . We shall overcome."

Church members - who have a history of social activism - already were thinking
that way, said Charles Hedges, 69, a retired New York City social services
worker, who attends First AME when here.

"People here refuse to be intimidated," Hedges said.

Choir member Deberah Cousin, 45, said she sang with extra feeling: "We've had a
blessing. Things could have come out a lot differently."

As the congregation clapped, Murray pointed to a banner, using the Hebrew word
for peace: "In spite of all . . . God's Shalom."

"Hate groups cannot succeed unless love groups give permission," Murray said.
"You and I are a love group."

That's the way church members always have felt, said Terrell Harris, who was in
charge of security Sunday.

"We'll carry on like always. It's going to be hard to forget, but we'll carry
on."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: EAR PHOTO, color, Gamma-Liaison; PHOTOS, b/w, Bob Riha Jr.,
Gamma-Liaison (3)

THE NATION

                      Copyright 1993 Gannett Company, Inc.


                             203 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

                January 31, 2001 Wednesday MORNING FINAL EDITION

CLERK'S TIP FOILS COLLEGE BOMB PLOT 14,000 DE ANZA COLLEGE STUDENTS ARE
EVACUATED HOURS BEFORE A STUDENT WAS ALLEGEDLY PREPARED TO CARRY OUT A PLOT THAT
POLICE CALL 'AN ELABORATE PLAN FOR MASS MURDER.' BOMBS, GUNS AND SUICIDE TAPE
FOUND, POLICE SAY

BYLINE: RODNEY FOO AND DANIEL VASQUEZ, Mercury News

SECTION: FRONT; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 1657 words


A De Anza College student who San Jose police said spent two years carefully
scripting a mass killing on the Cupertino campus was arrested just hours before
he allegedly planned to carry out his plot Tuesday, thanks to a tip from an
alert drugstore photo lab clerk.

Inside the modest North San Jose home of Al Joseph DeGuzman, 19, police found an
arsenal of pipe bombs, explosives using timers, booby-trap devices, rifles and
sawed-off shotguns, a sketch of the campus and a timeline for an attack that was
supposed to hit the college at 12:30 p.m. Tuesday.

Police say the campus was evacuated about 9 a.m. after they spent hours sorting
through evidence obtained through a search warrant based on the photos first
spotted by the store clerk and determined that De Anza was the target.

Police found what they described as an apologetic audio tape that apparently was
meant to be played after the intended massacre and a journal with passages that
expressed sympathy for the two Columbine High School students who shot and
killed 13 others before killing themselves in Littleton, Colo., in 1999.

"This was an elaborate plan for mass murder," said San Jose police Deputy Chief
Michael Miceli.

While police began to piece the plot together Tuesday, all De Anza classes were
canceled and 14,000 students were evacuated as bomb squads combed the 65
buildings and 112 acres in a fruitless search for any munitions that might have
been planted there.

According to police, that master plan was apparently under way and thwarted just
hours before DeGuzman could get started. His nemesis turned out to be a stranger
-- a Longs drugstore photo clerk, whose father is a police officer.

"She saw photos of guns, pipe bombs and a guy holding a gun," said Rubens
Dalaison, San Jose police spokesman.

'Call 911'

The woman immediately called her father, who was off duty. After hearing a quick
description, the officer told his daughter, "Hang up the phone and call 911
now!"

The emergency call came in at 6:02 p.m., and within minutes a police dispatcher
had gotten the information from the clerk, including DeGuzman's name taken from
a roll of film, and sent a patrol officer who was already near the Longs store
on Berryessa Road.

Meanwhile, the clerk who had just gotten off the phone with police looked up
from her counter and saw DeGuzman in line to retrieve his photos.

"She knew what to do, she began asking questions," said Dalaison. The stall
worked and the clerk pointed out DeGuzman just as the first officer walked into
the store.

DeGuzman walked away from the line and tried to get lost in the store but was
caught quickly, said police.

When confronted with the photographs, Dalaison said, DeGuzman admitted they were
his and the arsenal was toys. "It's just sugar in them," he told police.

The explanation didn't fly.

DeGuzman would not talk to police and would not allow them to search the home he
shared with his parents, authorities said.

Police detained DeGuzman and obtained a search warrant at 11 p.m. Mondayfor the
student's Flickinger Avenue home. His family did not know about their son's
bomb-making, police said.

Fifteen minutes later officers were knocking on the doors of neighbors on
Flickinger Avenue and evacuating people to a nearby school.

Officers did not immediately go into the Independence High School graduate's
room, fearing that bombs might be rigged to go off.

It was about 2:30 a.m. when they finally got inside and found the bombs: some
already stashed in a satchel, timing devices, two rifles, and two sawed-off
shotguns with pistol grips.

DeGuzman was booked into the Santa Clara County Jail on suspicion of the
manufacture or possession of a disguised weapon, possession of a destructive
device, intent to make a destructive device without a permit, and possession or
manufacture of an explosive device.

The guns were purchased legally in San Jose at a firearms store and a sporting
goods store. Police believe the suspect modified the shotguns himself.

The bombs were sophisticated -- some had mercury switches, some could be
triggered with a remote device -- but their components could be purchased easily
at stores.

The blueprints for the bombs were culled off the Internet, said Sgt. Mike
Fernandez of the San Jose police bomb squad.

The array of bombs was "mind-boggling," Miceli said. "You wouldn't think one
person would have all these bombs and all this destruction in one room."

Already faced with a home-made bomb-designer and manufacturer, it was just after
4:30 a.m. when police finally realized what they were up against: a bomber who
was prepared.

As much as the explosives and guns, DeGuzman's writings and tape recording he
left for posterity were equally disturbing. Fernandez said he believed DeGuzman
intended to end his life after the alleged attack or during it.

"The tape recording we found was just bone-chilling," Miceli said. "In my 30
years of law enforcement, I can't describe it any other way."

The clerk who saw the pictures was praised for her bravery by police chief Bill
Lansdowne and San Jose Mayor Ron Gonzales.

DeGuzman's decision to take pictures of himself and also leave a tape recording
follows a familiar pattern, Fernandez said.

"It's not uncommon, bombers do stuff like this," Fernandez said. "They want that
final glory or something for memory, for the press, for the public."

DeGuzman's journal indicated he'd been building up to the attack for two years.
Late Tuesday, investigators found Web sites, reportedly belonging to DeGuzman,
that expressed anger at the school.

His writings expressed sympathy for the gun-wielding students who fatally shot
12 students and a teacher before killing themselves at Columbine High School in
Littleton, Colo. Some of the bombs found at DeGuzman's home also had
similarities to those at Columbine, said Fernandez, who would not go into
detail.

On the pages were carefully plotted plans that gave instructions and a timeline
for the attack on the cafeteria at 12:30 p.m. when it would have been full of
students.

"If you know the cafeteria out there at 12, 12:30 p.m., it would have been a lot
of people who would have been killed," Miceli said.

DeGuzman's parents never went into his bedroom, said Fernandez. "He was an adult
and they gave him his privacy."

Police are concerned that the plans refer to "we" and also refers to snipers. An
ongoing investigation is trying to determine if others were also in on the
alleged scheme or helped DeGuzman, although police believe he probably acted
alone.

The plans gave instructions for DeGuzman to leave the house at 4:30 a.m. and
head for the suburban college where he would plant bombs at various locations.

Sgt. Doug Rogers, a spokesman for the Santa Clara County Sheriff's Department,
said school officials were not notified until 9 a.m. because it took authorities
all night to sift through DeGuzman's arsenal and determine that he planned to
target the campus that day.

"It's an act of rage, it's irrational," De Anza College President Martha Kanter
said. "All you can do is be rational in response."

Faced with evacuating the equivalent of a small city, college officials
immediately triggered a plan intended mainly for earthquakes and other natural
calamities. They evacuated 14,000 people in 40 minutes by putting out universal
voice messages on the campus phone network and sending deans to interrupt
classes. Some students were ushered so quickly off the campus that they could
not retrieve their cars and milled about at nearby cafes for hours.

Jim McCarthy, dean of library services, instructed about 2,000 students to leave
the library.

"I was shocked how quickly they got out," McCarthy said. "Usually, they joke
around and think it's a drill. But there was something in the tone of our voices
that told them it was serious."

By 7 p.m., Kanter said, the search was concluded and nothing was found. "They've
gone through the school and we're safe."

Soon after the bombs were found, police called in the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco
and Firearms, and the FBI.

The campus, which is usually open from 5:30 a.m. to 11 p.m., was closed for all
events, including a 7:30 p.m. appearance at the Flint Center by Queen Noor of
Jordan -- the late King Hussein's wife.

Cardboard signs were posted around the perimeter of the school reading "Campus
closed: open tomorrow." The campus was scheduled to reopen at 5:30 a.m. today.

Reaction of students

That the campus would be the target of a bombing attack was stunning to some
students.

"I'm shocked because I never thought it would happen right here at De Anza,"
said Fred Turpeo, 33, who was headed to a computer lab. "I always hear it on the
news happening somewhere else."

Student Bruce Bravo, added, "You figure you only have to worry about this stuff
in Third World countries. But it's a new millennium. People get shot in class."

Beth Grobman Burruss, chairwoman of De Anza's journalism department, said she
was startled by the threat.

"In my mass communications class, we talk about the Columbine incident and talk
about whether it could ever happen at De Anza." she said. "My students generally
say they don't think so because there's such a different attitude at high school
than at college. And my students think Columbine happened because all of the
high school pressures and cliques."

Gonzales, who canceled his own press conference about downtown development to
meet with police and reporters Tuesday, expressed concern about the intended
attack but relief about the young woman's act in helping capture the suspect.

Given the intricate plans and the arsenal DeGuzman was allegedly able to
covertly prepare, police and other authorities were quick to thank the woman who
stopped everything with a phone call.

"We have to say this was a gift," said Dalaison, "and the gift came from this
woman who probably saved lives."

LOAD-DATE: December 1, 2001

CHAIN OF EVENTS THAT LED TO ARREST
Map and timeline below trace events that led to the arrest of Al DeGuzman and
the evacuation of De Anza College:
MONDAY
About 6 p.m.: 18-year-old clerk at Longs drugstore calls her father, a police
officer who is off duty, about photos of guns and bombs.
6:02 p.m.: Clerk calls 911.
6:07 p.m.: Police dispatcher starts entering information into police computer.
About this time Al DeGuzman walks into store and gets in photo line. Clerk knows
police are on the way and stalls DeGuzman with questions.
6:10 p.m.: Officer arrives at store and clerk points out DeGuzman.
DeGuzman says the photos are his but guns and bombs are toys.
11 p.m.: Police obtain search warrant.
11:15 p.m.: Police start evacuating neighborhood around Flickinger Avenue home.
......................................................................
TUESDAY
2:30 a.m.: Police enter DeGuzman's room.
About 4:30 a.m.: Police discover detailed sketches and tape of a confession.
9 a.m.: Police start evacuating De Anza College in Cupertino.
7 p.m.: Search ends at De Anza College.

                            Dayton Daily News (Ohio)

                            February 20, 2017 Monday

ARE YOU READY FOR OSCAR? START WITH TOP PIC PICKS;
Still working your way through the Academy Awards best-picture nominees? USA
TODAY's Brian Truitt watched them all to help you prioritize. The Oscars are
Sunday (ABC, 7 p.m. ET/4 PT).;
AWARDS SEASON

SECTION: ; Pg. Z7

LENGTH: 567 words


HOPPER STONE, SMPSP Katherine Johnson (Taraji P. Henson) aimed high.

Ashton Sanders is Chiron, a boy who comes to age.

Mia (Emma Stone) and Seb (Ryan Gosling) sing and dance their way to true love.

Denzel Washington and Viola Davis.

LA LA LAND

eeee

PLOT: An aspiring actress (Emma Stone) and a jazz pianist (Ryan Gosling) fall in
love while trying to make their dreams come true. DIRECTOR: Damien Chazelle
RATING: PG-13 UPSIDE: The movie revisits the Hollywood musical in joyous and
dazzling fashion. DOWNSIDE: Not for grinches who don't like good tunes and
Broadway-style show-stoppers.

ARRIVAL

eeee

PLOT: A linguistics expert (Amy Adams) is tasked with deciphering messages from
alien visitors. DIRECTOR: Denis Villeneuve RATING: PG-13 UPSIDE: It's a
supremely crafted, well-acted and thought-provoking exploration of humanity.
DOWNSIDE: Most every other recent sci-fi movie looks pedestrian in comparison.

FENCES

eeeg

PLOT: A Pittsburgh garbage man (Denzel Washington) finds success at work but
increasing tension at home. DIRECTOR: Denzel Washington RATING: PG-13 UPSIDE:
Washington and co-star Viola Davis give powerhouse, award-ready performances.
DOWNSIDE: It's more filmed play than movie, so it doesn't feel cinematic in
scope.

HACKSAW RIDGE

eeeE

PLOT: A devout young man (Andrew Garfield) enlists in the Army during World War
II yet won't touch a gun. DIRECTOR: Mel Gibson RATING: R UPSIDE: Gibson's latest
is a brutally intense and elegantly crafted war drama. DOWNSIDE: The film
wrestles with overt preachiness and military-movie clichés.

HELL OR HIGH WATER

eeeE

PLOT: Two West Texas brothers (Ben Foster, Chris Pine) brazenly rob the branches
of a bank foreclosing on their family's land. DIRECTOR: David Mackenzie RATING:
R UPSIDE: An excellent Jeff Bridges is in his element as a Texas Ranger pursuing
the crooks. DOWNSIDE: The Western noir could be a little more subtle in its
exploration of modern economic decline.

HIDDEN FIGURES

eeeg

PLOT: Three mathematicians (Taraji P. Henson, Octavia Spencer and Janelle Monáe)
overcome racial and gender inequality to help America in the space race.
DIRECTOR: Theodore Melfi RATING: PG UPSIDE: The film has a strong cast as well
as heady themes of civil rights. DOWNSIDE: The space drama sometimes takes the
focus off the three stars' magnetic chemistry.

LION

eeeg

PLOT: Two decades after being separated from his family, a young Australian man
(Dev Patel) plots a path back home to India. DIRECTOR: Garth Davis RATING: PG-13
UPSIDE: Patel and newcomer Sunny Pawar give strong performances as older and
younger versions of Saroo Brierley. DOWNSIDE: The ending couldn't be more
emotionally manipulative, though it's forgivable.

MANCHESTER BY THE SEA

eeee

PLOT: A handyman (Casey Affleck) is forced to confront a past tragedy when he's
named sole guardian of his nephew (Lucas Hedges). DIRECTOR: Kenneth Lonergan
RATING: R UPSIDE: Affleck and Hedges are tops among an all-around extraordinary
cast. DOWNSIDE: Parents will find one scene hard to watch because of the subject
matter.

MOONLIGHT

eeee

PLOT: A three-act character study that follows the life of a gay black man from
struggling child to intimidating adult. DIRECTOR: Barry Jenkins RATING: R
UPSIDE: The drama is supremely well-acted and beautifully captures the intimate
evolution of its main character. DOWNSIDE: The middle act, while very good,
doesn't rise to the exceptional levels of the film's beginning and end.

                           Palm Beach Post (Florida)

                              June 24, 2013 Monday
                                 FINAL EDITION

To get trust, give details

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. 8A

LENGTH: 503 words


President Barack Obama and security officials defending the government's secret
spying programs are inching toward credibility. Sometimes, it comes in bizarre
ways. For example, German Chancellor Angela Merkel last week filled in details
that President Obama had left sketchy.

The administration, though, still needs to provide clear examples of the
programs' successes and prove that oversight is adequately protecting Americans'
civil liberties. Gen. Keith Alexander, director of the National Security Agency,
told Congress last Tuesday that sifting through phone records and Internet data
had foiled 50 terrorist plots at home and abroad since Sept. 11, 2001. But he
and other security officials provided scant details to show that the plots had a
realistic chance of success or that data mining of phone records and Internet
contacts were essential to uncovering the plots.

In one example, an FBI official said Internet contact between an extremist in
Yemen and a man in Kansas City thwarted a plot to bomb the New York Stock
Exchange. In the actual case, the man pleaded guilty in 2010 to money
laundering, bank fraud and providing support to a terrorist organization. But he
was not charged with attempting to blow up the NYSE.

Members of Congress did not press for details. The next day, President Obama, in
Europe for the G-8 summit, repeated the claim of 50 plots foiled but was
similarly vague. Chancellor Merkel then revealed that in 2010 Germany had used
the information to convict four Islamic militants of plotting strikes against
U.S. targets in her country. That sounds like a solid success.

Still, there is good reason to wonder if the Obama administration is hyping the
surveillance programs leaked by Edward Snowden. Skeptics will recall the
"Liberty City Seven," arrested in 2006 and portrayed as members of a Miami-based
terrorist cell intent on blowing up the Sears Tower in Chicago. Although several
eventually were convicted of terrorism-related offenses, the trials showed they
were egged on by undercover agents and would not have been capable of
sophisticated attacks.

How many of the "50 terror plots" were like that?

Of course, security officials claim that most details have to remain secret.
It's bad enough, in their view, that Mr. Snowden alerted terrorists that their
communications could be detected. Every additional nugget of information
potentially helps terrorists avoid capture.

Americans could be more trusting that the sweeping surveillance programs are
effective and necessary had Congress shown diligent oversight. Instead, members
of Congress skipped briefings. Few raised concerns. Some who did allege that
security officials lied to them. Meanwhile, the required judicial oversight
appears just as flimsy, with reports that judges serving on the secret Foreign
Intelligence Surveillance Court rejected only 11 of 39,000 requests for
surveillance.

Trust is eroded when Americans get more details from Germany's leader than from
our own.

Jac Wilder VerSteeg for The Post Editorial Board

LOAD-DATE: July 18, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Editorial

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                 Copyright 2013 The Palm Beach Newspapers, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved

                       Sarasota Herald Tribune (Florida)

                           January 9, 2013 Wednesday

Eat Near: Garden plots

BYLINE: COOPER LEVEY-BAKER , Correspondent

SECTION: E; ARCHIVES; Pg. E18

LENGTH: 592 words


There are many reasons why Bruce Fehr enjoys working the land at North
Sarasota's Bayou Oaks Community Garden. The cheap fresh produce eight months out
of the year. The confidence in knowing exactly what you're putting in your body.
The relationships with knowledgeable gardeners growing veggies in neighboring
plots.

But, at times, it's so much simpler than all that: "It's just nice seeing stuff
grow."

Fehr is a volunteer, and he donates his time managing Bayou Oaks' 18 different
plots, while also tending to his own fruit and vegetables. The Bayou Oaks land
is one of six community gardens currently up and running, with another two (the
65-plot Culverhouse Community Garden and the Bee Ridge Community Garden)
scheduled to open soon. Culverhouse will start this spring, while Bee Ridge is
slated to debut in the summer or fall.

Stacy Spriggs, the community and school gardens coordinator for Sarasota
County's University of Florida/IFAS extension office, says there is an "amazing
amount of interest in gardening in Sarasota," and that passion is what's driving
the community garden program's success and expansion. Both the Culverhouse and
Bee Ridge gardens emerged from "internal interest" within nearby neighborhoods,
she says. Her job is to simply help realize those green thumbers' dreams.

Local interest must run high: Spriggs' position, created just last year, is the
only one of its kind in the entire state of Florida. Countywide, there are
around 200 garden plots total.

At Bayou Oaks, the waiting list to snag a plot is up to around 12 months these
days, and Fehr says only one or two plots turn over in a typical year. Those
interested in using the available land must pay a $30 deposit and an annual fee
of $30, and that's pretty much it. The rest is up to the gardener -- although
Fehr jokes that pretty much everybody at the garden will offer you some advice,
whether you want it or not.

Fehr has been gardening his entire life ("I don't remember not gardening"), and
moving from northern Wisconsin to Sarasota 16 years ago was an easy change. He
says getting stuff to sprout here is no sweat. "There are just no big problems
here," he says.

Different plot tenants use different methods, so while not everything that comes
from Bayou Oaks is 100 percent organic, it certainly could be. "Very few
pesticides or herbicides are used here," he says.

Fehr's personal bounty is overflowing this time of year. He doesn't can or
freeze anything, so he ends up giving away a good chunk of his food. About the
only vegetables he buys at the supermarket are salad greens in the lean months.
Other tenants donate their surplus goods to friends or neighbors, and some of it
even ends up at Carr's Corner Cafe, just a few blocks west. "There are so many
people around here who will take it," Fehr says.

Community gardens aren't just about healthy eating, according to Spriggs. They
help revitalize neighborhoods, forge social bonds and encourage physical
exercise. But, like Fehr says, sometimes, in the middle of our sprawl-clogged
suburbia, it's just nice to see plants thriving. I can get on board with that.

Interested in learning more about, or even participating in, the University of
Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences' community garden program?
Visit sarasota.ifas.ufl.edu.

This is the 16th entry in Eat Near, a regular column dedicated to all the lovely
food that folks on the Suncoast grow, raise, kill or craft. If you have an idea
for someone/thing to feature, email me at eatnearsrq@gmail.com or hit me up on
Twitter: @LeveyBaker.

LOAD-DATE: December 11, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Bruce Fehr waters his raised plot of produce at Bayou Oaks Community
Garden. HERALD-TRIBUNE ARCHIVE / 2008 / E. SKYLAR LITHERLAND

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2013 Sarasota Herald-Tribune Co.
                              All Rights Reserved

                           Ledger (Lakeland, Florida)

                          September 9, 2000, Saturday

RESIDENTS RUSH TO BUY CEMETERY PLOTS; THEY ARE TRYING TO AVOID A PRICE INCREASE
THAT MAY DOUBLE RATES.

BYLINE: AMBER SMITH The Ledger

SECTION: Metro; Pg. B3

LENGTH: 322 words


This article is repeated in another section in some editions.

HAINES CITY -- Residents have been swarming to City Hall to purchase cemetery
plots before city commissioners more than double the prices.

City commissioners have agreed to raise the prices of cemetery plots at the two
city-owned cemeteries, Forest Hill and Oakland. Costs will rise from $ 150 per
plot to $ 360 for residents, while nonresidents will see prices rise from $ 300
to $ 720 per plot.

"We sold 95 plots in all of last year and I've sold 53 plots in the past two
weeks," said City Clerk Cherry Dowdy. "Everyone seems to want to get their lots
before the prices go up. I've probably had 25 calls in the past week asking when
the rates are going up."

Commissioners have not yet set the date when the prices will rise. Dowdy said
she thought the issue might be on the agenda for the Sept. 21 commission
meeting.

"I don't know if the commissioners will want the new prices to take effect
immediately or if they will wait until Oct. 1," Dowdy said.

In Haines City, residents are actually given the deed to their cemetery plot.
The city mows and trims weeds.

Dowdy said people can either pick out their own plots or the city can pick them
out for them.

"Most people like to pick out their own spots," she said. "They come in and make
an appointment to go out and look at the lots and then after they pay for them,
I make out a deed and send it off to Bartow to be recorded."

Dowdy said residents can also buy plots in bulk by buying a lot.

A lot actually has room for eight plots. Anyone buying a lot is charged per plot
.

"I had one family that bought 11 plots and then decided to go ahead and buy
three more. That's probably the most I have sold at one time," she said.

Dowdy said she doesn't expect the rush on the plots to slow down any time soon.

"I was joking that I need to go out and pick out my plot, too," Dowdy said.

LOAD-DATE: September 11, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

             Copyright 2000 Lakeland Ledger Publishing Corporation

                                   USA TODAY

                   September 11, 1998, Friday, FINAL EDITION

WEEKEND PREVIEW

BYLINE: Eddie Timanus

SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 13C

LENGTH: 1775 words


Times p.m. Eastern

No. 1 Ohio State (1-0) vs. Toledo (1-0)

-- Time: 12:30. Line: OSU by 37. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: After passing road test, Buckeyes at home vs.
in-state opponent.

-- Plots and subplots: QB Joe Germaine used all his weapons as
OSU's offense amassed 549 yards at West Virginia. Ohio State's
depth will take over this game, but Rockets could keep it close
early. Toledo RB Wasean Tait, who set Mid-American Conference
rushing record in 1995, is back after devastating knee injury
kept him out almost two seasons. He joins Dwayne Harris, who ran
for 1,278 yards last year.


No. 2 Florida State (1-0) at N.C. State (1-0)

-- Time/TV: 3:30/ABC. Line: FSU by 25. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Seminoles look to maintain their Atlantic Coast
Conference stranglehold and remain in national title picture.
Wolfpack try for historic upset.

-- Plots and subplots: Remember Torry Holt? FSU coach Bobby Bowden
certainly does. The Wolfpack flanker had five TD receptions in
last year's meeting, and FSU showed vulnerability in its pass
defense in win vs. Texas A&M. Wolfpack need better performance
from defense that allowed 361 rushing yards to Ohio.

No. 3 Nebraska (2-0) at California (1-0)

-- Time/TV: 7/Fox Sports Net. Line: Nebraska by 23. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Cornhuskers face first of two Pac-10 challengers.
Key Top-10 clash with Washington looms in two weeks in Lincoln.

-- Plots and subplots: Though Nebraska's rushing average is down
by more than 100 yards a game from last season's lofty 398, nobody
is panicking; Huskers' passing numbers are up to 192 yards a game.
California QB Justin Vedder and WR Dameane Douglas could have
success against Nebraska's secondary.

No. 4 Florida (1-0) vs. Northeast Louisiana (1-0)

-- Time: 6. Line: Florida by 44. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Gators get one more tuneup before showdown with
Tennessee in Knoxville.

-- Plots and subplots: Gators QB Jesse Palmer and his talented
but youthful receiving corps should benefit from second outing.
Doug Johnson (shoulder surgery) could see his first action of
season at QB. Northeast Louisiana QB Andre Vige is NCAA's No.
2-rated passer after first career start vs. Nicholls State.

No. 5 Kansas State (1-0) vs. Northern Illinois (0-1)

-- Time: 12:30. Line: K-State by 49. Turf: Artificial.

-- The stakes: Wildcats put another easy "W" in the books before
Texas comes to Manhattan.

-- Plots and subplots: K-State coach Bill Snyder again should
have opportunity to utilize his roster. Michael Bishop now holds
QB rushing record at KSU with 591 career yards. Northern Illinois'
19-game losing streak isn't likely to end. QB Frisman Jackson
and WR Justin McCareins hooked up for three TDs in Huskies' loss
to Western Michigan.

No. 6 UCLA (0-0) vs. No. 22 Texas (1-0)

-- Time/TV: 3:30/ABC. Line: UCLA by 10. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Longhorns try to erase memories of last year's
catastrophic "Rout 66" game (66-3 loss) against Bruins.

-- Plots and subplots: RB Ricky Williams, with 215-yard outing
under his belt, paces Texas offense as it tries to keep up with
UCLA QB Cade McNown, nation's passing-efficiency leader last season.
Texas also got solid performance from QB Richard Walton last week,
but 483 yards surrendered by Longhorns defense to New Mexico State
is concern.

No. 8 LSU (0-0) vs. Arkansas State (0-1)

-- Time: 8. Line: LSU by 45. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: LSU begins with warm-up for Auburn. Indians lost
at Minnesota on final play; repeat is asking a lot.

-- Plots and subplots: Tigers TB Kevin Faulk makes his opening
salvo in Heisman Trophy race. His workload could increase with
backup Rondell Mealey (foot) out. Scrappy Arkansas State is led
by QB Cleo Lemon, who forged tie at Minnesota passing for TD and
two-point conversion.

No. 9 Penn State (1-0) vs. Bowling Green (0-1)

-- Time: Noon. Line: Penn State by 38. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Lions put coach Joe Paterno's preseason concerns
to rest last week in his 299th victory. His 300th should come
easier.

-- Plots and subplots: Offensive line lived up to expectations
as QB Kevin Thompson and TB Cordell Mitchell settled into starting
roles. Things don't figure to improve for Bowling Green's offense
-- held to 56 total yards by Missouri -- against Nittany Lions,
who allowed 9 rushing yards.

No. 11 Notre Dame (1-0) at Michigan State (0-2)

-- Time/TV: 8/ABC. Line: ND by 7. Turf: Artificial.

-- The stakes: Irish follow their huge home win with test against
desperate Spartans.

-- Plots and subplots: RB Autry Denson will be focus of Spartans
defense; MSU has been thrashed in ground game in '98 but limited
Denson to 59 yards last season. QB Jarious Jackson, who only attempted
10 passes in Michigan victory, might be asked to throw more. Irish
surrendered more than 300 yards passing, but Spartans have only
managed 282 yards by air in two games.

No. 12 Virginia (1-0) vs. Maryland (1-0)

-- Time: Noon. Line: Virginia by 281/2. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Cavaliers hope to challenge Florida State for
ACC supremacy. Terrapins in need of breakthrough win.

-- Plots and subplots: Cavaliers' one-two combination of QB Aaron
Brooks and RB Thomas Jones will try and take control quickly.
Virginia's defensive front was as good as advertised in limiting
Auburn to 18 rushing yards. Terrapins need huge game from QB Ken
Mastrole.

No. 13 Georgia (1-0) at South Carolina (1-0)

-- Time/TV: 6/ESPN2. Line: Georgia by 5. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Georgia could be factor in SEC East race but must
defeat Gamecocks.

-- Plots and subplots: Anthony Wright is back at QB after knee
injury cut 1997 season short. His top WR is Zola Davis, who will
challenge Georgia's excellent secondary, anchored by CB Champ
Bailey and SS Kirby Smart. Bulldogs freshman QB Quincy Carter
tops NCAA passing chart, generating 235 yards on only 12 completions
in first start.

No. 14 Michigan (0-1) vs. No. 18 Syracuse (0-1)

-- Time/TV: 3:30/ABC. Line: Michigan by 101/2. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Down the road, both will count on difficult non-conference
schedules to bolster their Bowl Championship Series positions.
Both need this win.

-- Plots and subplots: Michigan's excellent secondary against
Orangemen's deep receiving corps is game's most intriguing matchup,
but outcome could hinge on which run defense improves the most.
Problems in Michigan's kicking game might tip scales to Orangemen
in close finish.

No. 15 Ariz. State (0-1) at Brigham Young (0-1)

-- Time/TV: 9/ESPN2. Line: ASU by 61/2. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: The Sun Devils' opening defeat and desire to avenge
last season's loss to BYU bodes, but Cougars can be dangerous
at home.

-- Plots and subplots: BYU's blitzing defense will try to bother
QB Ryan Kealy, but Cougars probably don't have answer for Sun
Devils RB J.R. Redmond. Cougars would seemingly prefer high-scoring
affair but won last year's meeting 13-10. BYU must avoid falling
behind early as it did at Alabama.

No. 16 Colorado (1-0) vs. Fresno State (0-0)

-- Time: 3. Line: Colorado by 22. Turf: Artificial.

-- The stakes: Buffs have winnable games on slate until Oct.
10, when Kansas State comes calling. Fresno could benefit from
CU letdown.

-- Plots and subplots: Colorado QB Mike Moschetti more than justified
coach Rick Neuheisel's decision to start him. He could put up
more big numbers as WRs Marcus Stiggers and Darrin Chiaverini
test Bulldogs inexperienced CBs. QB Billy Volek is back for Fresno
State.

No. 17 Wisconsin (1-0) vs. Ohio (0-1)

-- Time: 12:30. Line: Wisconsin by 16. Turf: Artificial.

-- The stakes: Injury-depleted Wisconsin comes home to meet upset-minded
Bobcats.

-- Plots and subplots: Injury news is mixed for Wisconsin; star
RB Ron Dayne (ankle) has been cleared to start, but backup Eddie
Faulkner (shoulder) will not play. But key personnel for Wisconsin
this week are defenders who must shut down Ohio's triple option
that nearly toppled Kansas State last year and N.C. State last
week.

No. 19 Texas A&M (0-1) vs. Louisiana Tech (0-2)

-- Time: 8:30. Line: A&M by 22. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Aggies' tough pre-conference slate continues as
QB Tim Rattay brings his aerial show to College Station.

-- Plots and subplots: Louisiana Tech's statistics are a study
in extremes. Rattay, aided by WR Troy Edwards, amassed 1,050 yards
passing before Labor Day, but Bulldogs have netted minus 7 rushing
in two games. Tech's defense that has surrendered 120 points must
improve quickly to have any chance against A&M.

No. 21 Arizona (1-0) at Stanford (0-1)

-- Time: 3:30. Line: Arizona by 8. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Wildcats hope for fast start in Pac-10 competition.
Cardinal can make up for disappointing start by pulling upset
at home.

-- Plots and subplots: Stanford's young defense was victimized
in opening-day loss to San Jose State. Look for good competition
between Cardinal WR Troy Walters and Arizona CB Chris McAlister,
whose 100-yard kickoff return set tone for Wildcats in Hawaii.

No. 23 So. California (1-0) vs. San Diego State (0-1)

-- Time: 10:30. Line: USC by 19. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Trojans are back in the poll and hope to stay.
Former Trojans coach Ted Tollner makes first return visit to USC.

-- Plots and subplots: Despite shaky start in Pigskin Classic,
Mike Van Raaphorst remains Trojans starting QB.. TB Chad Morton
is a game-breaker. Aztecs will count on DE Kabeer Gbaja-Biamila
to lead another strong defensive effort; San Diego stayed with
Wisconsin for three quarters.

No. 25 Missouri (1-0) vs. Kansas (0-1)

-- Time/TV: 3:30/ABC. Line: Missouri by 16. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Tigers seek to improve on turnaround '97 season.
Kansas hopes to avoid second Big 12 loss.

-- Plots and subplots: Missouri QB Corby Jones picked up where
he left off, producing 245 total yards by land and air, exceeding
his 1997 average of 231. There are signs of improvement by Jayhawks.
Freshman WR Byron Gasaway helped QB Zac Wegner to career-best
228 yards passing in 38-28 loss to Oklahoma State.

Rest of the Top 25

No. 7 Tennessee, No. 10 Washington, No. 20 West Virginia and No.
24 North Carolina are idle.

-- Lines by USA TODAY sports analyst Danny Sheridan.

                             209 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                  June 11, 2002 Tuesday Five Star Lift Edition

"DIRTY BOMB" PLOT IN U.S. IS THWARTED, ASHCROFT SAYS;
 MAN ARRESTED MAY 8 AT O'HARE IS PLACED IN MILITARY CUSTODY

BYLINE: Karen Branch-Brioso Post-Dispatch Washington Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 953 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Federal officials thwarted a radioactive-bomb plot by a U.S. citizen trained by
the al-Qaida terrorism network, Attorney General John Ashcroft said Monday -- a
day after transferring the man to military custody.

Brooklyn, N.Y., native Jose Padilla, 31, has been in government custody for a
month. Federal law enforcement officials detained him May 8 as he arrived at
Chicago O'Hare International Airport on a flight from Pakistan.

Ashcroft said Padilla -- known since the early 1990s by his Muslim name of
Abdullah Al Muhajir -- had met with senior Al-Qaida officials in Pakistan and
Afghanistan, where he "trained with the enemy, including studying how to wire
explosive devices and researching radiological dispersion devices."

"We have disrupted an unfolding terrorist plot to attack the United States by
exploding a radioactive 'dirty bomb,'" Ashcroft said Monday from Moscow, where
he was meeting with law enforcement officials.

Ashcroft said Padilla was designated an "enemy combatant." He is being held at
the Naval Consolidated Brig in Charleston, S.C., where he was moved Sunday.

A "dirty bomb" is a conventional explosive to which radioactive material is
added. The resulting explosion would not have the impact of a nuclear bomb but
would generate immediate panic, as well as potential long-range health risks,
experts said.

At a Justice Department news conference, FBI Director Robert Mueller said the
plot "was in the discussion stage." Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Wolfowitz said
Padilla "had indicated some knowledge of the Washington, D.C., area" but said
his target was far from set: "There was not an actual plan. We stopped this man
in the initial planning stages."

Padilla, as a U.S. citizen, cannot now be tried by the military commissions that
President George W. Bush envisioned in a November exec utive order to deal with
those charged with terrorism crimes. Bush reserved such tribunals for
noncitizens. But Bush could change his regulation so citizens could be tried
before a tribunal. And military law experts disagree over whether he could be
court-martialed.

Last year, Padilla met "on several occasions" with senior al-Qaida officials in
Afghanistan and Pakistan, Ashcroft said. Justice Department officials would not
confirm whether the meetings took place before or after the terrorist attacks of
Sept. 11. Ashcroft said the CIA, FBI and U.S. military were tracking Padilla's
movements and were waiting for him at O'Hare when he returned to the United
States.

The Associated Press reported that Padilla was detained with two other men in
Pakistan but then was permitted on the flight to the United States, as two U.S.
agents covertly followed him onto the plane.

At a time when the FBI and CIA are the subject of congressional scrutiny for
failures to share information that could have prevented the Sept. 11 attacks,
Ashcroft praised the organizations for working together to prevent Padilla from
acting on his alleged plot. Wolfowitz and Mueller echoed the praise.

"I commend the FBI, the CIA and other agencies involved in capturing Abdullah Al
Muhajir before he could act on his deadly plan," Ashcroft said. "Because of the
close cooperation among the FBI, the CIA, Defense Department and other federal
agencies, we were able to thwart this terrorist."

Wolfowitz made it clear that prosecution was not the government's primary goal.

"Our No. 1 priority is to defend the American people from future attacks," he
said. "To do that, we must root out those who are planning such attacks. We must
find them. We must stop them. And when we have them in our control, we must be
able to question them about plans for future attacks."

A military law expert said that dubbing Padilla an "enemy combatant" could
provide a significant advantage to government interrogators, both in their
ability to detain him for significant periods and to hold him with limited
access to an attorney.

"If you're going to keep him with the federal courts system, at some reasonable
point, you have to either move forward with the charges or release him," said
John Hutson, dean of the Franklin Pierce Law Center in New Hampshire. "If he's
an enemy combatant, then basically you can hold onto him until the end of the
hostilities - until the war is over, so to speak. . . . They can interrogate
him. He does not have a right to a lawyer. If you leave him in the (federal
courts) system, he has a right to counsel, and court-provided counsel if he
can't afford counsel of his own."

Padilla had a lawyer when he was being held under a sealed government order -
presumably under a material witness warrant, a Justice official said. Neither
Justice Department nor Pentagon officials would say Monday whether Padilla now
has access to a lawyer.

"He was being held under the authority of a federal judge, and he had legal
representation in connection to that," Deputy Attorney General Larry Thompson
said.

In a similar case, the federal government argued just last week that another
U.S.-born detainee held as an "enemy combatant" has no right to a lawyer. Yaser
Esam Hamdi, 21, was born in Louisiana but lived most of his life in Saudi
Arabia. He was being held at Guantanamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba with hundreds of
other such combatants seized during the military operation in Afghanistan - but
sent to a Norfolk, Va., naval brig after his birthplace was discovered.

A U.S. District Court judge ordered that Hamdi must be given access to a lawyer;
a Justice Department appeal is pending.

The Justice Department suggested that Hamdi, who grew up in Saudi Arabia, may
have renounced his U.S. citizenship at some point. But Padilla has spent almost
all of his life in the United States.

LOAD-DATE: June 13, 2002

LANGUAGE: English

NOTES: WAR ON TERROR; Reporter Karen Branch-Brioso E-mail:
kbranch@post-dispatch.com Phone: 202-298-6880

GRAPHIC: MAP, PHOTO, GRAPHIC; (1) Photo headshot - (Jose) Padilla; U.S. citizen
is native of Brooklyn, N.Y.; (2) Post-Dispatch Graphic/Chart With Map -
Spreading radiation and terror; Source: AP; A "dirty bomb" made up of 100 pounds
of conventional explosives and radioactive material would cause relatively
little physical damage. The concern is the deaths from radiation exposure that
would be caused by its fallout. The area affected if such a bomb were detonated
in downtown St. Louis:; Blast area: 300 feet; Fallout area: 2/3 of a mile; (Map
of downtown St. Louis showing epicenter and locations of America's Center,
Savvis Center, Busch Stadium, and the Arch);

                          The Decatur Daily (Alabama)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             June 24, 2008 Tuesday

BRIEF: Cost of plot rises from $250 to $500 in historic cemetery

BYLINE: Deangelo McDaniel, The Decatur Daily, Ala.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 273 words


Jun. 24--HARTSELLE -- The cost of burials in the city's historic cemetery is
going up.

Hartselle leaders agreed during their Monday work session to increase the cost
of a plot from $250 to $500.

"When you look at the lifetime maintenance cost to the city, the city is still
losing money," Mayor Dwight Tankersley said.

The Cemetery Board supported the increase.

"I think it's a good move," Edna Carol Weeks said.

Reasonable price

Hartselle's $500 fee is about in the middle when compared to surrounding
municipalities.

Decatur, for example, charges $250 for a plot, and Athens charges $300.

Cullman, however, charges $550, and Moulton charges $800 in the part of the
cemetery for flat markers.

The cost in Moulton includes the city opening and closing the grave. Hartselle
does not open graves.

Tankersley said the existing cemetery has only a few plots remaining.

Growing, changing

The city is expanding the cemetery, and the cost to do so is about $220 per plot
. The expansion will add 244 lots.

Because of potential legal expenses, Hartselle is changing how people are buried
in the city cemetery.

In the past, people have purchased plots and received a deed.

In the future, people will buy the right to be buried but not receive a deed.

To see more of The Decatur Daily, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.decaturdaily.com Copyright (c) 2008, The Decatur Daily, Ala.
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

                 January 4, 2000 Tuesday MORNING FINAL EDITION

BOMB-PLOT PROBE RESULTS IN MORE ARRESTS

BYLINE: Mercury News Wire Services

SECTION: FRONT; Pg. 11A

LENGTH: 181 words


Two Algerians, one in Brooklyn, N.Y., and the other in Seattle, have been
arrested in the continuing investigation of a terrorist bomb plot. The new
arrests came amid indications that federal authorities are focusing their
efforts on a network of Algerians in New York, Seattle and Boston, officials
said Monday.

The Brooklyn man, Abdelwahib Hamdouche, was taken into custody Saturday night at
Kennedy International Airport, officials said. Hamdouche, 34, a naturalized
French citizen, was held as a material witness in the bomb plot investigation.

In Seattle, the authorities said they had arrested another Algerian man, Abdel
Hakim Tizegha, on charges of entering the country illegally. He is believed to
be an associate of a man charged last week in the bomb plot, law enforcement
officials said, but he has not been accused of any direct role. The new arrests
stem from what authorities said was a bomb plot foiled in Seattle last month
after the arrest of Ahmed Ressam, an Algerian who has been linked to terrorists.
Ressam was charged with trying to smuggle explosives.

                   Turtle Mountain Star (Rolla, North Dakota)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                August 26, 2013

Private land hunting guide now available

BYLINE: Turtle Mountain Star staff

LENGTH: 277  words


The North Dakota Game and Fish Department's Private Land Open To Sportsmen (
PLOTS) Guide for 2013 is now available online at the Department's website,
gf.nd.gov. In addition, PLOTS Guides will be available at most license vendors
throughout the state in early September.

The guide will feature about 760,000 PLOTS acres. Because the guide is printed
in mid-August, some PLOTS tracts highlighted in the guide may have been removed
from the program since the time of printing. There will also be some PLOTS
tracts where the habitat and condition of the tract will have changed
significantly. Conversely, Game and Fish may have added new tracts to the
program after the guide went to press.

To minimize possible confusion, Game and Fish will update PLOTS map sheets
weekly on its website.

The PLOTS Guide features maps highlighting these walk-in areas, identified in
the field by inverted triangular yellow signs, as well as other public lands.

In addition, a one-page advertisement announces a photo contest for the cover of
the 2014 PLOTS Guide. From end-of-day hunting shots, to scenic action or
landscape shots, the Game and Fish Department wants to feature hunter photos on
the cover and elsewhere in the guide that showcase North Dakota's strong hunting
heritage.

PLOTS Guides are free, and available at county auditor offices and license
vendors in the state; by walk-in at the Game and Fish Department's Bismarck
office; and at district offices in Riverdale, Harvey (Lonetree), Willis-ton,
Dickinson, Jamestown and Devils Lake.

The guides are not available to mail, so hunters will have to pick one up at a
local vendor, or print individual maps from the website.

                             213 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                  July 18, 1993, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

MAN IN NEW JERSEY IS CHARGED IN PLOT TO KILL MUBARAK

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1362 words


An Egyptian immigrant who lives in New Jersey was charged in a Federal complaint
yesterday with conspiring to kill President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in a "suicide
mission" during his visit to the United States in early April and, when that
plot unraveled, with planning to try again in September.

The complaint detailed an elaborate plan by the suspect, Abdo Mohammed Haggag,
and at least 10 others to carry out the attack at a hotel in Manhattan, dressing
in hotel uniforms so that they could blend in and move close to Mr. Mubarak. The
complaint said the conspirators believed they had been betrayed by a "leak" that
caused Mr. Mubarak to change his plans, though it remained unclear last night
whether Mr. Mubarak had planned to visit New York.

The charges against Mr. Haggag, who was arrested by Federal agents on Friday
evening, appeared to provide another layer of details to the amorphous
conspiracy to bomb a series of landmarks in New York City, including the United
Nations and the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels, and to assassinate prominent
political figures.

Those figures, including Mr. Mubarak and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York,
were mentioned as targets, but the plots were not fully described when the
authorities smashed a loosely organized ring of militant Muslims late last month
after swooping down on a suspected bomb factory in Queens.

Two others named but not formally charged in the complaint yesterday, Siddig
Ibrahim Siddig Ali and Clement Rodney Hampton-El, are among 11 suspects who have
now been charged in that bombing plot. Officials have also said that Mr. Siddig
Ali masterminded the plot and that both men took part in the preparations for
the bombing of the World Trade Center on Feb. 26, which killed six people.

A senior law-enforcement official said that the United States Attorney would
seek other indictments within the next month against the suspects arrested in
the second plot that could provide more details of the other targets and
methods. The official, however, declined to specify what the new charges would
be.

Began Last Year

"All I can tell you is that there is more than enough information in the
indictments," the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "Obviously,
there is common people and it's a common time frame. You can deduce from that
what you will."

Like the other conspirators in the two bombing plots, Mr. Haggag, 34, is a
follower of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the radical Muslim cleric, and lived
next-door to him in an apartment building in Jersey City until the cleric was
detained by immigration authorities.

The charges against Mr. Haggag illustrated once again the complicated network of
loosely interlocking small groups of Muslim militants in Brooklyn and New Jersey
who were followers of Mr. Abdel Rahman, worshipped at the same mosques and
traveled in the same circles.

Yesterday's complaint, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, also
revealed that in addition to a confidential informant who provided information
on the plot to blow up New York landmarks, the authorities relied on an
individual described as a "cooperating witness" to shed light on the plot to
kill Mr. Mubarak.

A senior law-enforcement official said yesterday that the witness was one of the
defendants arrested in the second bombing plot who had now agreed to assist the
Government's investigation.

According to the complaint, Mr. Haggag, also known as Abdel Al-Rahman Haggag,
began plotting late last year with Mr. Siddig Ali and Mr. Hampton-El and others
to kill Mr. Mubarak. Mr. Mubarak has faced vehement opposition in Egypt and
abroad from radical Muslim groups aligned against his secular Government and its
ties to the West.

Mr. Haggag, the complaint charged, met with Mr. Siddig Ali and Mr. Hampton-El on
several occasions beginning late last year to discuss the plot, including a
meeting with several others in Brooklyn.

At the same time, Mr. Siddig Ali and others conducted surveillance at the New
York hotel, not identified in the complaint, where the suspects believed Mr.
Mubarak planned to stay as part of his official visit to the United States. At
another meeting, the complaint said, Mr. Hampton-El "agreed to make weapons and
munitions available to them."

'Suicide Mission'

The complaint said Mr. Siddig Ali told the others involved in the plot that the
attack "would be a 'suicide mission,' " or in other words, "that there would be
a high likelihood that the conspirators would be killed during its execution,
since the area around the hotel would be filled with law enforcement and other
security personnel."

According to the complaint, Mr. Siddig Ali later explained that the attack had
been postponed "because of a 'leak' which caused President Mubarak to alter his
plans."

Mr. Mubarak arrived in Washington on April 4, but did not go to New York. An
aide to the Egyptian president told The Associated Press yesterday that he had
not planned to visit New York at the time.

The details of the plot appeared to have emerged to investigators only after the
witness -- said to be one of the suspects arrested late last month -- agreed to
cooperate with prosecutors in late June.

The witness told investigators of a series of conversations with Mr. Haggag and
the other suspects, detailing the assassination plot and revealing that the
conspirators hoped to try again when Mr. Mubarak returned to New York for the
opening of the General Assembly of the United Nations. As a result, officials
are concerned about the security arrangements should Mr. Mubarak attend the
session, one official said.

At one point, Mr. Haggag accused Mr. Siddig Ali of being an informant and thus
"responsible for the failure to carry out the mission" to kill Mr. Mubarak, the
complaint said. At a meeting with the cooperating witness on May 6 at his
apartment on Fairfield Avenue in Jersey City, Mr. Haggag asked that the witness
check his apartment for surveillance devices because he had been approached by
Government agents.

Widens Network

The arrest of Mr. Haggag widened the network of suspects -- all interconnected
to Mr. Abdel Rahman and the mosques where he preached frequently -- who wanted
to punish the United States for its support of Israel and secular Arab
governments, like Egypt's. In one Federal complaint, Mr. Siddig Ali told the
Government's informant in the cases that the bombing of the trade center was a
message that "we can get you anytime."

Mr. Haggag has lived in a four-story yellow-brick apartment building at 115
Fairview Avenue in Jersey City for about three years, according to the
building's superintendent, Ernesto Rosado. His apartment is next to the one on
the fourth floor where Sheik Rahman lived until he turned himself in on July 2.

Mr. Rosado said that it was Mr. Haggag who first brought the cleric to the
building and later helped make arrangements for him to rent it. He went on to
say that Mr. Haggag visited his neighbor frequently.

Mr. Haggag's lawyer, David H. Weiss, said his client, who was born in Cairo and
has lived in the United States for at least eight years, had a close
relationship with the cleric and often worshipped at the Al-Salaam mosque, only
a few blocks away. Mr. Weiss said that Mr. Haggag worked at Prudential-Bache in
Manhattan and that he had a wife and two children, who are now living in Egypt.
"He's been sending them money for a year and a half," he said.

Bail Hearing Delayed

Mr. Haggag was led in a courtroom in the Federal Courthouse in Manhattan
yesterday afternoon, handcuffed and wearing a striped shirt and khaki pants.
Bearded and wearing glasses, he spoke softly to his lawyer or sat quietly, his
head resting on his hands crossed as if in prayer.

The prosecutor, Andrew C. McCarthy, requested that Magistrate Judge Kathleen A.
Roberts deny bail to Mr. Haggag because of the danger he posed to the community
and the risk of flight. Judge Roberts ordered Mr. Haggag to appear in court
again on Tuesday morning for a bail hearing.

When asked after the hearing how Mr. Haggag would plead, Mr. Weiss responded,
"Today, he is planning to plead not guilty."

LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo: Siddig Ibrahim Siddig Ali, who was charged last month with
conspiring to bomb several New York sites, at the Metropolitan Correctional
Center last week. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times) (pg. 31)

Chart: "An Assassination Plot"

Excerpts from charges filed yesterday alleging a plan to kill Egyptian President
Hosni Mubarak.

In or about late 1992, ABDO MOHAMMED HAGGAG, a/k/a "Abdel Al-Rahman Haggag
("HAGGAG"), and Siddig Ibrahim Siddig Ali ("Siddig Ali"), among others,
discussed a plan to murder Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak when President
Mubarak came to New York in early 1993.

Between late 1992 and early 1993, Siddig Ali, among others, conducted
surveillance at a hotel in Manhattan.

Between late April 1993 and late June 1993, Siddig Ali and HAGGAG, among others,
engaged in several conversations with a cooperating witness ("CW") regarding a
plan begun in late 1992 to murder Hosni Mubarak, the President of Egypt. In the
course of these conversations, the CW was advised, among other things, that
Siddig Ali and HAGGAG had met with Clement Rodney Hampton-El in Brooklyn, who
had agreed to make weapons and munitions available to them.

On or about May 13, 1993, Siddig Ali informed the CW that HAGGAG, Ali and
several others had received training for a secret mission.

On or about May 18 and May 19, 1993, in the course of continuing to plan a
series of bombings, Siddig Ali explained to the CW, among other things, that ten
members of his group had made elaborate arrangements to attempt to murder
arrangements to attempt to murder Egyptian President Hosni Murarak during
President Mubarak's visit to the United States in late March to early April
1993.  Those plans included, among other things, secretly obtaining information
about President Mubarak's itinerary, surveillance conducted at a hotel in
Manhattan in order to determine where various assailants would be stationed,
obtaining weapons and explosives to carry out the plot, and obtaining uniforms
so that some members of the conspiracy could appear to be hotel workers and thus
get close to President Mubarak.

Siddig Ali explained, among other things, that members of the conspiracy
understood the mission would be a "suicide mission," i.e., that there would be a
high likelihood that the conspirators would be killed durings its execution,
since the area around the hotel would be filled with law enforcement and other
security personnel.

Siddig Ali further explained that the plan had been postponed because of a
"leak" which caused President Mubarak to alter his travel arrangements.

Siddig Ali has learned about this "leak," he said, because Haggag had been
interviewd by American law enforcement agents. Siddig Ali later suggested that
the plan to murder President Mubarak would be carried out in September 1993.

Both Haggag and Siddig Ali claimed credit for designing the murder plan. and
Haggag accused Siddig Ali of being a Government informant and, thus, responsible
for the failure to carry out the mission. (pg. 31)

                        Facts on File World News Digest

                                October 28, 2004

Terrorism;
No Evidence of Election-Timed Attack

SECTION: Pg. 841D1

LENGTH: 401 words


There was no credible evidence of an attack by the Al Qaeda terrorist network
timed to coincide with or disrupt U.S. presidential elections in November,
according to senior U.S. counterterrorism officials cited in the October 23
Washington Post and the October 24 New York Times. The newspaper articles
concluded that although Al Qaeda likely continued to plan attacks against the
U.S., there was no evidence of a specific plot. Bush administration security
officials since May had warned of an ongoing major Al Qaeda terrorist plot to
strike the U.S. before the November 2 elections. [See 2004 India-Pakistan
Relations: Singh, Musharraf Meet in New York; 2004 Eight Charged in Britain For
Plotting U.S. Attacks; Allegedly Targeted Financial Institutions; Other
Developments]

According to the Post, Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) Director Robert
Mueller 3rd and John McLaughlin, then acting director of central intelligence,
September 15 during their daily briefing with President Bush had discussed new
intelligence about an election-timed plot. Mueller and McLaughlin had reportedly
brandished evidence suggesting that Al Qaeda operatives had entered the U.S.
However, a primary informant who had provided the intelligence had later been
discredited, the Post reported.

According to the Times, senior counterterrorism officials based in eight
European and Middle Eastern countries had also seen no evidence of an
election-timed plot aimed at the U.S. Most of the U.S. and foreign security
officials cited in both accounts apparently believed that Al Qaeda plots
typically gestated over long periods and were not typically timed to coincide
with specific events.

Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge in August had issued a warning involving
five financial services buildings in the Northeastern U.S., and British
authorities in August had arrested and charged eight men in connection with the
plot. However, unidentified officials now believed that the men were targeting
London's Heathrow International Airport and not buildings in the U.S., according
to the Times.

The Homeland Security Department terrorist threat level for the vast majority of
the U.S. remained at yellow, or elevated, the middle level of the five-colored
threat barometer. However, the threat level remained at orange, or high, for the
financial services sector in New York City, northern New Jersey and Washington,
D.C.

LOAD-DATE: November 3, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             215 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        The Augusta Chronicle (Georgia)

                             August 21, 2016 Sunday
                                  ALL EDITION

PLANNING CAN HELP FOOD PLOTS

SECTION: NEWS TIMES; Tripp Williams columnist; Pg. O08

LENGTH: 848 words


Labor Day weekend is usually spent traveling to the beach for the last time or
the mountains for the first time, or maybe this year driving to Atlanta to watch
Georgia take on North Carolina in the 2016 Chick-fil-A Kickoff Game. While
others are planning these activities, there will be a handful of us that will be
spending this holiday planting fall food plots. Planting food plots is an
effective way to increase the return on investment. However, the cost involved
with food plots can be substantial, and proper planning can help avoid waste and
disappointment.

Some causes of food plot failure, such as weather factors, cannot be controlled.
Many can be avoided with proper planting, planting technique, and maintenance.
Some common reasons for food plot failure that can be avoided are highlighted
below.

Wrong plant for location: One of the first decisions to be made when planning a
plot is where the planting will be located. For many, choices are limited based
on the amount of open land available. Careful consideration should be given to
the chosen area's soil, sunlight, and drainage. These factors weigh heavily on
the type of plant that will thrive. Every seed species and blend has specific
conditions under which it will perform best. Match the land's qualities with
compatible food plot plant requirements. For example, a plant that requires
all-day sunlight and dry soil is not compatible in a shaded field that has poor
drainage.

Lack of a soil test: Without a soil test, it is impossible to know exactly what
your food plot needs in terms of lime or fertilizer. This simple and inexpensive
step still gets overlooked often enough to make it one of the primary culprits
for food plot failure. Soil testing cost is $9.00 in Columbia County. Please
contact the Extension Office for information on how to take a sample, or visit
aesl.ces.uga.edu/soil/Georgia.htm for more information.

Improper Planting Technique: While many food plot pitfalls can be avoided in the
planning phase, sometimes even the best laid plans still result in disappointing
results. This is often because of improper planting technique. One of the
biggest challenges facing the average land manager is lack of the necessary
equipment. The fact is that many don't own a tractor and all the key implements
necessary for farming. This leaves the options of renting, borrowing, or
improvising on equipment. It seems the latter often wins out, and the result is
a poorly prepared seedbed with less than ideal germination or intense weed
competition that eventually chokes out the plot. A properly prepared seedbed
needs one or more herbicide treatments followed by thoroughly disking or tilling
the area. If a no-till drill is available, the seed may be drilled directly into
the herbicide-treated field.

Lack of Maintenance: Before the food plot is established, deer browsing on
plants can have negative effects on plant establishment, survival and
productivity. Try implementing a fertilizer deterrent. Milorganite is a
slow-release, organic fertilizer produced from human sewage. The trade name,
Milorganite, was derived from MILwaukee ORGAnic NITrogEn, as it is the treated
byproduct of the Milwaukee, Wis., waste

treatment plant. This product is often used for soil amendments rather than a
fertilizer because of the low nitrogen/phosphorus/potassium values of 6-2-0, but
it does a great job keeping the deer out for at least 30 days at the rate of 240
pounds per acre. Also install an exclusion cage. The simple device prevents deer
and other animals from eating what's inside the cage. It's only a few square
feet, which acts as a control and by observing how much and what kind of forage
grows inside and comparing it with the rest of the food plot; you can see how
much forage is being produced and how heavily the deer are browsing the plot.

Once a food plot is established, the biggest threat quickly becomes competition
from weeds. Weeds can be extremely aggressive and quickly take over a great
planting. Depending on seed mix used, occasional mowing and herbicides, when
applicable, are the best ways to control weeds. For example, mowing is an
important management tool for clover plantings. Not only will two to three
mowings per year help control weeds in the plot, it also thickens the legumes
and helps to maintain high protein levels. Be sure not to cut it below four to
six inches, and don't mow during periods of hot, dry weather. Applying the
proper herbicides can also be key to controlling unwanted weeds and maintaining
a healthy food plot. Whether planting Roundup Ready Soybeans, brassicas, or a
white clover mix, there are specific herbicides that will target the undesirable
weeds in the plot. It is critical to know exactly what herbicide and how much
before sowing the first seed.

Food plots can be rewarding for wildlife managers or weekend warriors if
properly prepared. Avoiding these pitfalls can result in a rewarding food plot
year after year.

Tripp Williams, Columbia County's agriculture and natural resource extension
agent, can be reached at (706) 541-4011 or trippj@uga.edu

LOAD-DATE: September 27, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Williams mug

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

                          September 25, 2014 Thursday

The Wire: Holder resigning; terror warning; Ebola quarantine; U.-Va. case; saved
by jackpot

BYLINE: By Karl Kahler kkahler@mercurynews.com

SECTION: BREAKING; News

LENGTH: 335 words


Eric Holder stepping down as attorney general

Eric Holder is stepping down after six years as the nation's first black
attorney general, and conservatives across the nation are undoubtedly saying
it's about time. The White House said President Barack Obama would announce
Holder's resignation later Thursday. Obama has not made a final decision on a
replacement for Holder, who was to remain on the job until a new attorney
general is confirmed. Possible candidates who have been discussed by the
administration include Solicitor General Don Verrilli, California Attorney
General Kamala Harris, Massachusetts Gov. Deval Patrick, Deputy U.S. Attorney
General James Cole and Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse. Holder, the fourth
longest-serving AG in American history, was a lightning rod for criticism from
the right over his role in a botched gunrunning probe dubbed Fast and Furious,
in a failed plan to try terrorism suspects in New York City and in a perceived
failure to hold banks accountable for the near-meltdown of the nation's economy.

Iraqi PM warns of subway terror plot against U.S., Paris

The Iraqi prime minister warned Thursday of a terrorist plot to attack subways
in the United States and Paris, but U.S. officials said they cannot confirm the
plot. Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi told journalists in New York at the U.N.
General Assembly meeting that he was told of the plot by Baghdad, and that it
was the work of foreign fighters of the Islamic State group in Iraq. "Today,
while I'm here I'm receiving accurate reports from Baghdad that there were
arrests of a few elements and there were networks from inside Iraq to have
attacks ... on metros of Paris and U.S.," al-Abadi said, speaking in English.
"They are not Iraqis. Some of them are French, some of them are Americans. But
they are in Iraq." Asked if the attacks were imminent, he said, "I'm not sure."
Asked if the attacks had been thwarted, he said, "No." U.S. officials said they
could not confirm details of the plot.

                                 Ottawa Citizen

                     November 3, 2002 Sunday Final Edition

Five arrested in alleged plot to kidnap former Spice Girl: Victoria Beckham 'in
absolute shock' upon learning of $12M plan

SOURCE: The Sunday Telegraph; with files from Reuters and The Associated Press

BYLINE: Daniel Foggo, David Bamber and Adam Lusher

SECTION: News; Pg. A6

LENGTH: 454 words

DATELINE: LONDON

LONDON -- Five people were arrested yesterday over a plot to kidnap Victoria
Beckham, the pop star and wife of soccer star David Beckham.

"Four men and a woman have been arrested for offences of theft and conspiracy to
kidnap," said a Scotland Yard spokesman.

The five -- believed to be Romanians and Albanians -- were held by the
Metropolitan Police Serious and Organized Crime Squad. The plot was discovered
after a gang was infiltrated by reporters from the tabloid News of the World.

A Scotland Yard spokesman said the arrests were made after police raids at two
addresses -- in London and Surrey.

If either of her two sons were with her, the tabloid said, the kidnappers would
seize them, too. They planned to take their captives to a house in Brixton,
South London, and demand the equivalent of $12 million ransom, the paper
reported.

"I'm stunned by what has happened today," the paper quoted Victoria Beckham
saying.

"It's clear these people were serious and that, of course, has scared the life
out of me. ... I'm in absolute and total shock."

When the police swooped, Ms. Beckham was in Manchester with her husband, who was
playing in Manchester United's Premiership soccer match against Southampton.

It is believed that she was informed of the plot and the arrests as the match
began, although her husband was not told until after the game.

This is the second time a plot to abduct Ms. Beckham has been revealed.

In January 2000, gangsters tried to snatch her and Brooklyn, then eight months
old, and hold them at a house in Hampstead, London.

Scotland Yard detectives were tipped off about the plot, and assigned a team of
officers to protect the Beckhams at their home in Hertfordshire. The family was
taken to a secret location and Ms. Beckham's parents were also moved. No arrests
were made over that plot.

In the latest case, the five suspects were being held at unnamed police
stations.

In September, it was reported that Ms. Beckham, 27 -- who rose to pop stardom as
"Posh Spice" with the Spice Girls -- and her husband had hired five former
members of the special forces to protect them. They have also built high fences
around the five-acre grounds of their home.

In March 2000, Ms. Beckham received a death threat, which was sent to her
parents' home, two days before she was due to perform on stage with the Spice
Girls at the Brit Awards show. No arrests were ever made.

During a rehearsal, a red laser light appeared on her chest and she was bundled
off stage.

A fire-escape door was found wedged open, and it was feared that a potential
assassin had been at the venue in London. In her autobiography, Ms. Beckham
confessed that she had been terrified by the experience.

LOAD-DATE: November 3, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Colour Photo: Ian Waldie, Reuters; Victoria Beckham, shown in this file
photo, was informed before her husband, David's soccer game yesterday of the
plot to kidnap her. This is the second such plot to be uncovered in recent
years.
