                             218 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                April 7, 2003 Monday Five Star Late Lift Edition

NEWS BRIEFS

SECTION: NORTH POST ; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 565 words


BRIDGETON

Council approves permit for physical therapy

The Bridgeton City Council has approved a special-use permit for Signature
Foundation Rehabilitation Services to operate a physical therapy center at 3431
Bridgeland Drive, near DePaul Health Center.

The nonprofit center will rely on referrals from private physicians, most of
whom work at DePaul, said Stephen Lozier, administrator for Signature
Foundation.
 Lozier said the center is a new concept for the area. "No one else is doing it
in St. Louis," he said.

Lozier said the center will initially be staffed with one therapist and one
assistant. But if demand increases, he plans to expand it. Plans are also in the
works to open other locations, in Manchester and South County.

MARYLAND HEIGHTS

City will provide first community gardenThe city of Maryland Heights is
providing space for its first community garden for residents.

The garden, which will feature 15-foot by 15-foot plots, will be situated south
of Maryland Heights Centre on McKelvey Road, and available on a first-come,
first-served basis. The application fee for each plot is $10.

The plots, which may be used for vegetables or flowers, will be assigned by the
parks and recreation staff at a meeting at 7 p.m. on April 24 at the Maryland
Heights Centre, 2344 McKelvey Road.

The city will till and stake out the garden plots and provide a water source and
trash bins. Residents will be responsible for their own tools, hoses and
maintenance of their plots, which will not be fenced. The city holds no
responsibility for loss because of pilfering. There are no age requirements, but
residents must be able to maintain the garden throughout the growing season.

Anyone wishing to apply for a plot or obtain more information may call JoAnn
Eng-Hellinger at 314-434-1915.

NORTH COUNTY

Barrington Downs plan gets tentative permission

The St. Louis County Council last Tuesday tentatively granted Kemp Co.
permission to build 30 houses in the last major undeveloped area of the
Barrington Downs subdivision.

The houses would be on 6.2 acres on the northwest corner of Old Halls Ferry Road
and Grand National Drive in north St. Louis County.

Kemp originally proposed 34 houses for the site. Some residents said the lots
would be too small compared with the rest of the subdivision.

The developer also changed lot sizes on the edge of the development to match
adjacent lots, and the houses would be a similar size. Kemp would name the main
street in its development Saratoga, to retain the horse-racing theme of
Barrington Downs.

ST. LOUIS

St. Nicholas will host bone-marrow drive

St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church, at 4967 Forest Park Avenue, St. Louis will
host a bone-marrow drive from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. on Saturday.

People from 18 through 60 in good general health may to participate. It involves
watching a video, answering a medical questionnaire and having a small amount of
blood drawn.

After tissue typing is done in the lab, the information goes into the National
Bone Marrow Registry. Those of various ethnic origins are especially encouraged
to participate because their tissue types are unique to members of their groups.

There is no charge to participate; contributions to defray the $25 test cost
will be accepted.

Questions may be directed to Christina Papulis at 636-256-0366 and Sylvia
Nicozisin at 314-872-3185

LOAD-DATE: April 7, 2003

LANGUAGE: English

                             219 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                    Scotsman

                            September 7, 2009 Monday

Islamic extremist guilty of airline bomb plot

LENGTH: 677 words



HIGHLIGHT: ISLAMIC extremist Abdulla Ahmed Ali was today found guilty of
conspiring to murder thousands in an unprecedented airline bomb plot.


The 28-year-old was the leader of an east London al Qaida-inspired terror cell,
a Woolwich Crown Court jury found.

He planned to detonate home-made liquid bombs in suicide attacks on
transatlantic aircraft bound for major north American cities.

Ali was responsible for the most complex and daring British-based terrorist
conspiracy in modern times.

With thousands killed in the air and on the ground, the explosions would have
exceeded the carnage of the September 11 attacks.

Counter terrorist police, the security services and prosecutors spent more than
£35 million foiling the plot and bringing Ali to justice.

The arrest of the gang in August 2006 sparked tight restrictions on carrying
liquids on to aircraft that led to travel chaos.

The guilty verdict will come as an enormous relief for Government ministers who
endured heavy criticism for introducing the draconian luggage restrictions.

It will also be seen as a vindication of the decision to retry Ali after he was
found guilty of conspiracy to cause explosions last September. The previous jury
failed to reach verdicts on the airline plot.

British-born Ali, of Walthamstow, was inspired by the July 7 bombers and Osama
bin Laden and considered taking his baby son on his suicide mission.

He planned to smuggle home-made bombs disguised as soft drinks on to passenger
jets run by United Airlines, American Airlines and Air Canada.

The hydrogen peroxide devices would have been assembled and detonated in mid-air
by a team of suicide bombers.

Ali singled out seven flights to San Francisco, Toronto, Montreal, Washington,
New York and Chicago that departed within two-and-a-half hours of each other.

Authorities on both sides of the Atlantic would have been left powerless to stop
the destruction once the first bomb exploded.

Police said the plot was drawn up in Pakistan with detailed instructions passed
to Ali during frequent trips to its lawless border with Afghanistan.

They believe a mystery al Qaida bombmaker was responsible for the ingenious
liquid bomb design, concealed within 500ml Oasis or Lucozade bottles.

Surveillance teams watched Ali on his return to Britain as he assembled his
terror cell, gathered materials and identified targets.

Undercover officers looked on as the unemployed former shop worker used cash to
purchase a £138,000 second-floor flat in Forest Road, Walthamstow.

They planted a secret bug that revealed it was converted into a bomb factory
where Ali met others to construct the bombs.

The flat was also used as a location for Ali and others to record suicide videos
threatening further attacks against the West.

In his video Ali warned the British public to expect "floods of martyr
operations" that would leave body parts scattered in the streets.

Ali was watched as he used public phone boxes, mobile phones and anonymous email
accounts to keep in touch with mystery terrorist controllers in Pakistan.

On his arrest, he was found to be carrying an elaborate and damning blueprint
for the plot scrawled in a battered pocket diary.

Airport security arrangements and details of flights, including the seven
highlighted services, were discovered on a computer memory stick in another
pocket.

Along with Ali, Assad Sarwar 29, of Walton Drive, High Wycombe, and Tanvir
Hussain, 28, of Nottingham Road, Leyton, were also found guilty of involvement
in the airline bomb plot today.

But Ibrahim Savant, 28, of Denver Road, Stoke Newington, Arafat Waheed Khan, 28,
of Farnan Avenue, Walthamstow, Waheed Zaman, 25, of Queen's Road, Walthamstow,
were found not guilty of the airliner plot.

The jury failed to reach a verdict on Umar Islam, 31, of Bushey Road, Plaistow,
of the airliner plot.

But Islam was convicted of conspiracy to murder.

Donald Stewart-Whyte, 23, of Hepplewhite Close, High Wycombe, was found not
guilty of both conspiracy to murder on aircraft and conspiracy to murder.

Ali, Sarwar and Hussain were convicted of conspiracy to murder in the first
trial but retried, along with the five other men, for the airliner plot after
the first jury failed to reach verdicts on those charges.

                             220 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                   USA TODAY

                             March 21, 2006 Tuesday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Agent warned FBI about Moussaoui, hijack plan

BYLINE: Kevin Johnson

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 532 words


ALEXANDRIA, Va.--The FBI agent who arrested confessed al-Qaeda conspirator
Zacarias Moussaoui testified Monday that three weeks before the Sept. 11, 2001,
attacks, the agent warned his supervisors that Moussaoui likely was part of a
plot to take over a commercial jet using small knives to subdue the crew.

The testimony by Special Agent Harry Samit in Moussaoui's sentencing trial shed
new light on how the U.S. government failed to seize upon a range of clues that
suggested the 9/11 plot was unfolding.

Samit said Monday that he wrote at least 70 pages of memos during the three
weeks before the attacks expressing concern that Moussaoui was involved in a
hijacking plot, but the Minnesota-based agent said his superiors never acted on
the repeated warnings.

Samit's warnings included an Aug. 18, 2001, memo in which he unsuccessfully
sought permission from FBI headquarters to search the belongings of Moussaoui, a
French citizen who had been arrested on immigration charges.

The agent's warnings proved to be a forecast of the Sept. 11 attacks, in which
19 suicide hijackers used box cutters and utility knives to take over four jets
in attacks that killed nearly 3,000 people in New York City and Shanksville,
Pa., and at the Pentagon.

Samit's testimony is key in Moussaoui's trial, which is being held to determine
whether the al-Qaeda operative -- who has pleaded guilty to terrorism conspiracy
-- should be executed or receive a life sentence. The U.S. government says that
the Sept. 11 attacks could have been prevented if Moussaoui had warned agents
about the plot, and that he should be executed because he didn't.

Moussaoui claims he was part of another plot and didn't know about the one for
9/11. Samit's testimony appeared to support the defense's contention that
authorities had many clues about a possible hijacking plot and failed to act on
them.

Samit testified that before the attacks, FBI officials in Washington refused to
support his search requests despite Samit's increasingly "desperate" attempts to
learn more about Moussaoui, who had raised suspicions among his instructors
while training as a flight student.

"God help us all if the next terrorist incident involves this kind of plan," an
investigative associate identified in court only as "Cathy" wrote a frustrated
Samit on the day before the attacks.

Samit's FBI superiors at the time did not believe he had enough evidence to
support a warrant for either a criminal or intelligence investigation. Since
then, the USA Patriot Act has made it easier for federal authorities to obtain
such warrants in terrorism investigations.

Samit's testimony marked the resumption of Moussaoui's trial, which U.S.
District Judge Leonie Brinkema had suspended for nearly a week after learning
that a government lawyer had violated court rules by leaking court transcripts
to help coach upcoming government witnesses.

Brinkema responded by ruling that prosecutors could not present evidence that
aviation authorities could have helped avert the 9/11 attacks if Moussaoui had
told agents about the plot. The judge later amended her ruling to allow aviation
witnesses who were not tainted by the actions of government lawyer Carla Martin.


LOAD-DATE: March 21, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: NEWSPAPER

                             221 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             Windsor Star (Ontario)

                           December 13, 2012 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

'Kill Justin Bieber' plot foiled, U.S. report; TV station reveals grisly alleged
plan

SECTION: ARTS; Pg. C9

LENGTH: 377 words


Two would-be assassins from New Mexico are being implicated in a bizarre plot to
kill Canadian pop megastar Justin Bieber.

KRQE News 13 in Albuquerque, the state's largest city, reported the alleged
scheme Wednesday.

The television station said it was part of a plan to strangle and castrate the
Ontario-born singer and three other people.

Detectives quoted by the station say Mark Staake, 41, and his nephew Tanner
Ruane, 23, had begun hatching their plot at the state prison near Las Cruces.

In prison, Staake met Dana Martin, a convicted killer serving two life sentences
for raping and killing a 15-year-old girl in Vermont in 2000.

Police say Martin recruited Staake, who in turn recruited his nephew, to carry
out four murders when Staake was paroled from prison last month.

He gave orders to strangle the victims with a paisley tie - Martin's calling
card.

Ruane was to be in charge of castrating the victims.

Mastermind Martin, 45, told detectives that the sinister centrepiece of the plan
was killing and castrating Bieber - and his bodyguard - following the teen's
concert at Madison Square Garden in New York City.

KRQE News 13 reported that Martin is obsessed with the singer, who's currently
in the early stages of a huge world tour, and even has a tattoo of the Stratford
superstar on his leg.

An affidavit from the New Mexico State Police says Staake believed he could
track the star, whom they identify only as J.B., through the press and said
Martin wanted the high-profile target dead so he would become even more infamous
from behind bars.

Staake and Ruane were caught in Vermont at a border crossing coming in from
Canada, the Associated Press said. Police say they were lost and looking for
directions, but when border agents checked Staake's details they discovered a
warrant for his arrest.

After searching the men's car, police say they found evidence of the men's plan,
including "murder tools" and names and addresses of the intended victims and
their families.

WPTZ.com in Burlington, Vt., said Ruane described how his role in the murders
would to be castrate the victims with a pair of hedge clippers.

"I was going to go 'Snip, Snip,' " said investigator Clinton Norris of the New
Mexico state police, quoting a jailhouse recording of Ruane to Martin.

                             222 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)

                              June 4, 2007 Monday
                                 First Edition

The terrorist plotters who wanted to make September 11 look small

BYLINE: Mark Coultan Herald Correspondent in New York and agencies

SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 721 words


IT WAS a plot worthy of a disaster movie. Destroy New York's largest airport in
a dastardly explosion.

Unfortunately for the alleged plotters, not only was the idea outlandish and
highly unlikely to succeed, but authorities had been recording the conversations
of the plotters for the past 18 months.

The plot, in the words of one of the alleged ringleaders, would have caused
"greater destruction than in the September 11 attacks", and devastated the
American economy.

Four men are alleged to have planned to blow up fuel pipelines, fuel tanks, and
buildings at John F. Kennedy International Airport.

The FBI said the suspects had conducted surveillance of the airport using
photographs and satellite images downloaded from Google Earth. One of the men,
Russell Defreitas, was a retired cargo handler at the airport. Another was Abdul
Kadir, a former mayor of a Guyanese town and a former member of the Guyanese
Parliament.

He was arrested in Trinidad after a plane bound for Venezuela, in which he was a
passenger, was turned around. His wife has denied he was involved in any
terrorist plot. He is said to have been helping Defreitas, 63, to plan the
attack and secure financing for it.

Defreitas, who sells books on street corners and exports broken air-conditioners
to Guyana, was arraigned in a Brooklyn court and denied bail.

A third man, Kareem Ibrahim, was arrested in Trinidad. A fourth, Abdel Nur, is
still at large and believed also to be in Trinidad.

Defreitas was recorded by an FBI informant as allegedly saying that JFK Airport,
which handles 45 million passengers a year, was targeted because it would put
"the whole country in mourning".

"It's like you can kill the man twice," Defreitas allegedly said.

He has also boasted that he had been taught to make bombs in Guyana.

A lawyer, Roslynn Mauskopf, said it was one of the most chilling plots
imaginable. "The devastation that would be caused had this plot succeeded is
just unthinkable."

But experts cast doubt on the practicalities of the plot. The airport is fed by
a series of pipelines which supply jet fuel and heating oil. In many cases the
pipes are under the tarmac and are laid to the gates where planes park.

Sabotaging one part of the system would be highly unlikely to lead to a chain
explosion. Also jet fuel does not produce an explosive force unless it is under
pressure or vaporised. The pipelines and tanks have safety valves, which would
contain any mishap.

The alleged plotters are said to have travelled repeatedly to Guyana and
Trinidad in recent months, seeking to obtain the blessing and financial backing
of an extremist Muslim group based in Trinidad and Tobago called Jamaat
al-Muslimeen.

The alleged plot is the latest to originate with Americans or in the US, and to
target the US, as opposed to plots instituted by al-Qaeda in the Middle East.

All the plots were closely monitored by intelligence agencies almost from their
inception, and all were stopped long before they could be implemented. In many
cases, the suspects are alleged to have expressed an intention to attack
targets, but lacked the financing, training and means to do so.

The latest plot has been under surveillance since at least January last year. A
year ago seven men were arrested in what officials said were the early stages of
a plot to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago and destroy FBI offices.

Last year, authorities claimed to have stopped a plot to flood New York City
train tunnels and lower Manhattan, by blowing up tunnels under the Hudson River.

And recently six people were arrested in an alleged plot to unleash a bloody
rampage at Fort Dix in New Jersey.

All of these plots displayed amateurism. The New Jersey suspects were arrested
after they had footage of what looked like a training exercise copied to a DVD
at a local store.

OTHER RECENT PLOTS AGAINST THE U.S.

May 8, 2006

Six suspected Islamic radicals were charged with plotting to attack the Fort Dix
army base in New Jersey with rocket-propelled grenades and automatic weapons.

June 23

Seven men were charged with conspiring to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago and
the FBI building in Miami in a mission they hoped would be "just as good or
greater" than September 11.

July 7

US officials said they had thwarted a foreign-based plot to stage a suicide
bombing of a rail tunnel in New York later in the year.

                             223 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)

                              June 4, 2007 Monday
                                 First Edition

The terrorist plotters who wanted to make September 11 look small

BYLINE: Mark Coultan Herald Correspondent in New York and agencies

SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 721 words


IT WAS a plot worthy of a disaster movie. Destroy New York's largest airport in
a dastardly explosion.

Unfortunately for the alleged plotters, not only was the idea outlandish and
highly unlikely to succeed, but authorities had been recording the conversations
of the plotters for the past 18 months.

The plot, in the words of one of the alleged ringleaders, would have caused
"greater destruction than in the September 11 attacks", and devastated the
American economy.

Four men are alleged to have planned to blow up fuel pipelines, fuel tanks, and
buildings at John F. Kennedy International Airport.

The FBI said the suspects had conducted surveillance of the airport using
photographs and satellite images downloaded from Google Earth. One of the men,
Russell Defreitas, was a retired cargo handler at the airport. Another was Abdul
Kadir, a former mayor of a Guyanese town and a former member of the Guyanese
Parliament.

He was arrested in Trinidad after a plane bound for Venezuela, in which he was a
passenger, was turned around. His wife has denied he was involved in any
terrorist plot. He is said to have been helping Defreitas, 63, to plan the
attack and secure financing for it.

Defreitas, who sells books on street corners and exports broken air-conditioners
to Guyana, was arraigned in a Brooklyn court and denied bail.

A third man, Kareem Ibrahim, was arrested in Trinidad. A fourth, Abdel Nur, is
still at large and believed also to be in Trinidad.

Defreitas was recorded by an FBI informant as allegedly saying that JFK Airport,
which handles 45 million passengers a year, was targeted because it would put
"the whole country in mourning".

"It's like you can kill the man twice," Defreitas allegedly said.

He has also boasted that he had been taught to make bombs in Guyana.

A lawyer, Roslynn Mauskopf, said it was one of the most chilling plots
imaginable. "The devastation that would be caused had this plot succeeded is
just unthinkable."

But experts cast doubt on the practicalities of the plot. The airport is fed by
a series of pipelines which supply jet fuel and heating oil. In many cases the
pipes are under the tarmac and are laid to the gates where planes park.

Sabotaging one part of the system would be highly unlikely to lead to a chain
explosion. Also jet fuel does not produce an explosive force unless it is under
pressure or vaporised. The pipelines and tanks have safety valves, which would
contain any mishap.

The alleged plotters are said to have travelled repeatedly to Guyana and
Trinidad in recent months, seeking to obtain the blessing and financial backing
of an extremist Muslim group based in Trinidad and Tobago called Jamaat
al-Muslimeen.

The alleged plot is the latest to originate with Americans or in the US, and to
target the US, as opposed to plots instituted by al-Qaeda in the Middle East.

All the plots were closely monitored by intelligence agencies almost from their
inception, and all were stopped long before they could be implemented. In many
cases, the suspects are alleged to have expressed an intention to attack
targets, but lacked the financing, training and means to do so.

The latest plot has been under surveillance since at least January last year. A
year ago seven men were arrested in what officials said were the early stages of
a plot to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago and destroy FBI offices.

Last year, authorities claimed to have stopped a plot to flood New York City
train tunnels and lower Manhattan, by blowing up tunnels under the Hudson River.

And recently six people were arrested in an alleged plot to unleash a bloody
rampage at Fort Dix in New Jersey.

All of these plots displayed amateurism. The New Jersey suspects were arrested
after they had footage of what looked like a training exercise copied to a DVD
at a local store.

OTHER RECENT PLOTS AGAINST THE U.S.

May 8, 2006

Six suspected Islamic radicals were charged with plotting to attack the Fort Dix
army base in New Jersey with rocket-propelled grenades and automatic weapons.

June 23

Seven men were charged with conspiring to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago and
the FBI building in Miami in a mission they hoped would be "just as good or
greater" than September 11.

July 7

US officials said they had thwarted a foreign-based plot to stage a suicide
bombing of a rail tunnel in New York later in the year.

                               Right Vision News

                             August 16, 2009 Sunday

Life for terror trio

LENGTH: 378  words

DATELINE: Pakistan


Pakistan, Sept. 16 -- Three British Muslims have been sentenced to life in jail
for plotting to blow up transatlantic airliners with liquid bombs in Al
Qaeda-inspired suicide attacks on the scale of September 11.Judge Richard
Henriques said the plot was 'the most grave and wicked conspiracy ever proven
within this jurisdiction', as he passed sentence at the Crown Court in
London.'The intention was to perpetrate a terrorist outrage that would stand
alongside the events of September 11, 2001, in history,' he said.The plot,
foiled in August 2006, triggered the wide-ranging rules now in place on carrying
liquids aboard commercial aircraft.Ringleader Abdulla Ahmed Ali, 28, was
sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum 40-year term.The plot's 'chemist'
Assad Sarwar, 29, must spend a minimum of 36 years behind bars, while fellow
plotter Tanvir Hussain, 28, Ali's right-hand man, must serve at least 32
years.The counter-terrorism operation to foil the London-based plot was the
biggest ever in Britain, costing '35 million ($58 million).Henriques said:
'There is every likelihood that this plot would have succeeded but for the
intervention of the police and the security service.'A massive loss of life
would almost certainly have resulted and if the detonation was over land, the
number of victims would have been even greater still.'The plotters targeted
seven flights from London's Heathrow airport to New York, Washington, Chicago,
San Francisco, Toronto and Montreal.The flights, operated by United Airlines,
American Airlines and Air Canada, were to have been simultaneously destroyed in
mid-air.'This was a viable and meticulously planned conspiracy,' Henriques
said.The plot was 'an act of revenge inspired by extremist Islamic thinking',
aimed at 'governments of several allied forces in Iraq and Afghanistan', he
added.The tighter security measures and restrictions on liquids now seen on
flights worldwide are 'entirely attributable to this conspiracy'.The judge said
a trail of emails 'establish beyond question' that the plot was controlled,
monitored and funded from Pakistan.

                                US Official News

                           February 14, 2013 Thursday

USPTO Published Patent application of INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES
CORPORATION titled as "SELECTING SURVEY QUESTIONS"

LENGTH: 204  words

DATELINE: ALEXANDRIA, Va


United States Patent and Trademark Office has received an application no.
20130034840, on February 07, 2013, by INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES
CORPORATION, titled as "SELECTING SURVEY QUESTIONS" for the registration of
patent.

Inventors:  Burton; Mary C.; (Springfield, IL) ; Nair; Deepa R.; (Atlanta, GA) ;
Schmidt-Wesche; Birgit; (Pound Ridge, NY) ; Shupp; Lauren; (Blacksburg, VA) ;
Sohn; Peter; (Chelmsford, MA)
Assignee:  INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES CORPORATION
Armonk
NY

According to the abstract released by the U.S. Patent & Trademark Office: "For
selecting survey questions, a response module receives responses to first
questions relating to at least two qualities of at least two characteristics. A
plot module generates a scatter plot of the at least two qualities for each
characteristic. A selection module selects second questions targeted to
characteristics with characteristic plot values for the at least two qualities
in a specified region of the scatter plot."

The Patent was filed on August 3, 2011 under application No. 20130034840

For more information please visit: http://www.uspto.gov/. In case of any query
regarding this article or other content needs please contact:
editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                             226 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                             Daily News (New York)

                          November 17, 2001, Saturday

OSAMA-LINKED ALGERIAN FACES BOMB PLOT RAP

BYLINE: By GREG B. SMITH DAILY NEWS STAFF WRITER

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 340 words

An Algerian man has been charged with aiding terrorists trained in Osama Bin
Laden's camps in a thwarted plot to blow up Los Angeles International Airport on
the eve of the millennium.

Samir Ait Mohamed, 32, who has been in custody in Canada since last summer on
immigration violations, was charged in a complaint unsealed yesterday with
helping in the plot to set off a suitcase bomb at LAX.

Mohamed became the sixth Algerian charged in the plot, which failed when Ahmed
Ressam was caught Dec. 14, 1999, driving a rental car with explosive chemicals
into rural Washington State.

Mohamed was charged by Manhattan U.S. Attorney Mary Jo White in a criminal
complaint filed last month. White's office is overseeing the plot investigation.

He was charged with agreeing to get Ressam hand grenades and machine guns to
commit bank robberies. Mohamed knew the robberies were to raise money for
unspecified terrorist attacks on America, the complaint alleges.

Mohamed also linked Ressam up with Mokhtar Haouari, an Algerian living in
Montreal, to get fake credit cards to help pay for Ressam's terrorist plot,
prosecutors alleged. Haouari was convicted.

Ressam was convicted and agreed to cooperate with the government. He says he
told Mohamed he was trained in explosives in a Bin Laden camp in Afghanistan and
that "the U.S. would be the best target for a terrorist act."

When Ressam was caught, the FBI found a map with LAX and two other targets
circled. Ressam told them he had spent hours testing out his plot, placing
suitcases in different spots at airports to see whether they would be left
alone.

A week before the New Year's 2000 celebration, Ressam was caught in tiny Port
Angeles, Wash., on a ferry from Canada.

An Algerian living in Brooklyn, Abdelghani Meskini, was arrested there Dec. 29,
1998. He pleaded guilty and agreed to cooperate with the FBI. Another Algerian
accused of helping Ressam is being held in Algeria, while another remains in
custody in London. Both are charged in the U.S. and face extradition.


LOAD-DATE: November 17, 2001

                             227 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               The Times (London)

                             July 8, 2006, Saturday

FBI foils al-Qaeda plot to flood Wall Street

BYLINE: Tim Reid in Washington

SECTION: OVERSEAS NEWS; Pg. 44

LENGTH: 362 words


A PLOT by foreign terrorists to bomb underground train and road tunnels in New
York with the aim of flooding the Wall Street financial district has been
thwarted, the FBI said yesterday.

The main target of the Islamic extremists, one of whom is an al-Qaeda member and
under arrest in Beirut, was the Holland Tunnel, the main road link between
Manhattan and New Jersey that runs under the Hudson River. It carried almost 35
million vehicles in 2005.

The alleged plot was discovered during monitoring of internet chat rooms used by
extremists. It also involved bombing the New York subway.

Mark J. Mershon, the assistant director in charge of the FBI's New York field
office, said that there were eight principal players in the plot. Three were in
custody abroad and six nations had been involved in the investigation, he added.

None of the plotters had ever been in the US or obtained materials to stage an
attack.

The FBI added that the plotters had discussed driving vehicles laden with
explosives into several tunnels around Manhattan and then blowing them up.

Mr Mershon said that the plot would have involved "martyrdom, explosives" in
some of the tunnels that connected New Jersey and Manhattan. Earlier, FBI
officials said that information gleaned from the internet suggested that Abu
Musab al-Zarqawi, the former leader of al-Qaeda in Iraq who was killed by a US
bomb last month, had agreed to back the plot financially. But there was no
evidence that any money was sent or explosives bought.

One suspect, a Lebanese native, known as Amir al-Andalousi and an al-Qaeda
member, was arrested in Beirut a month ago on the request of US authorities.
Lebanese officials said that his real name was Assem Hammoud, and that he had
confessed.

"He was planning to travel to Pakistan for four months' training and that the
date for the attack was decided to be late 2006," the Lebanese Interior Ministry
said in a statement.

FBI officials said that the plot had been in its planning stages. The timetable
for the attack was October or November. It was also pointed out that any plan to
flood Wall Street would have failed because Lower Manhattan lies above the level
of the Hudson River.

                                The New York Post

                              July 24, 2005 Sunday

REAL TO REEL SEX - BIG-SCREEN LOVE DOESN'T ALWAYS REQUIRE ACTING

BYLINE: SARA STEWART

SECTION: All Editions; Pg. 89

LENGTH: 576 words


TWO actors actually have sex - a lot of it - in Michael Winterbottom's new film,
"9 Songs," which opened Friday in New York and Los Angeles. This doesn't
necessarily make for a great plot, but it has snagged major attention for an
otherwise tiny art-house flick.

"9 Songs" is hardly the first non-porn film to cause a stir with explicit
material. From mainstream classics like "The Postman Always Rings Twice" to
indie stinkers like "The Brown Bunny," even a totally unsubstantiated rumor of
real on-screen sex guarantees a place of infamy for any movie not relegated to
the "adult" category.

For many of those films, it's the only reason to watch. If you're in search of
big-screen boinks, add these titles to your DVD collection.

Title: "Last Tango in Paris'' (1972)

Plot: A man and woman have an anonymous affair in a Paris apartment

Couple: Marlon Brando and Maria Schneider

Rating: X (original 1972 director's cut) and R (studio's 1982 re-release)

Claim to fame: The stars and director Bernardo Bertolucci were indicted and then
acquitted in Italy for making pornography

Did they really do it?: No

****

Title: "Don't Look Now'' (1973)

Plot: A traumatized couple travels to Venice to get over their dead daughter

Couple: Donald Sutherland and Julie Christie

Rating: R

Claim to fame: The steaminess of the film's lone sex scene, with full-frontal
Sutherland, incited much debate about whether or not it was real

Did they really do it?: Unclear

****

Title: "In the Realm of the Senses'' (1976)

Plot: A Japanese man has an affair with one of his servants

Couple: Tatsuya Fuji and Eiko Matsuda

Rating: X

Claim to fame: Was groundbreakingly explicit for its time; sparked debate about
art vs. porn; became Madonna's favorite romance

Did they really do it?: Yes

****

Title: "The Postman Always Rings Twice'' (1981)

Plot: A drifter has an affair with the wife of a roadside caf[#x201a] owner

Couple: Jack Nicholson and Jessica Lange

Rating: R

Claim to fame: The erotic thriller, one of the first of its era, featured a
tabletop sex scene rumored to be more than just good acting

Did they really do it?: No

****

Title: "Wild Orchid'' (1990)

Plot: A lawyer and a millionaire embark on a steamy affair in Rio

Couple: Mickey Rourke and Carre Otis

Rating: R

Claim to fame: Dating at the time, Rourke and Otis snuck some seriously X-rated
material into this R-rated romp

Did they really do it?: The persistent rumor has never been confirmed by all
parties involved

****

Title: "Romance'' (1999)

Plot: A schoolteacher grows bored with her boyfriend and seeks out other men

Couple: Rocco Siffredi and Caroline Ducey

Rating: R (theatrical), unrated (uncut version)

Claim to fame: French director Catherine Breillat cast a porn star, Siffredi, in
order to ensure an on-screen erection

Did they really do it?: Yes

****

Title: "The Brown Bunny" (2004)

Plot: A man drives across the country, meeting girls along the way

Couple: Vincent Gallo and Chloe Sevigny

Rating: NR

Claim to fame: Explicit oral sex scene is the only interesting thing about
Gallo's pretentious film

Did they really do it?: Yes (though some rumors have claimed the existence of a
"stunt penis")

****

Title: "9 Songs" (2005)

Plot: In between and during rock concerts, a young couple has lots of sex

Couple: Kieran O'Brien and Margo Stilley

Rating: Unrated

Claim to fame: Film consists of nothing but actual sex scenes and concert
footage

Did they really do it?: Yes

can't save the story.

                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                             August 11, 2006 Friday

Terror plot: Copycat plot

BYLINE: Owen Bowcott

SECTION: GUARDIAN HOME PAGES; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 224 words


The genesis of plans to detonate bombs simultaneously on a number of civilian
airliners goes back to the so-called Bojinka plot by Islamist fundamentalists in
the mid-1990s.

The foiled operation has similarities to attacks planned in the Philippines and
organised by two prominent jihadi figures: Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and Ramzi
Yousef.

KSM, as he is known in US intelligence circles, was the mastermind behind the
September 11 attacks on New York and Washington. Yousef was the alleged
organiser of the underground bombing of New York's World Trade Centre in 1993.
"Bojinka" reportedly means "loud bang" or "explosion" in Serbo-Croat, a term
supposedly adopted by KSM after fighting in the Balkans.

The two jihadists moved to the Philippines in 1994 to develop their plans to
strike at the United States. The operation they proposed relied on smuggling
liquid-based explosives on board scheduled passenger services. The aim was to
bring down as many as a dozen flights, killing up to 4,000 on board planes bound
for Los Angeles, San Francisco, Honolulu and New York.

The plot was foiled when a fire broke out in an Manila apartment, which had been
converted into a bomb factory.

Chief Superintendent Rodolfo Mendoza, a Philippine police intelligence officer
who helped uncover Bojinka, said al-Qaida had to be considered as a suspect in
the UK plot.

LOAD-DATE: August 11, 2006

                             230 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                  Guardian.com

                             April 16, 2012 Monday

Tarantino reveals plot for Django Unchained

BYLINE: Ben Childguardian.co.uk

LENGTH: 467 words

ABSTRACT

Ben Child: The plot expands on the story revealed in leaks from bloggers
claiming to have read Tarantino's screenplay

FULL TEXT

Spoiler alert: This news story reveals the details of the plot of Django
Unchained.

Quentin Tarantino has revealed the synopsis for his much discussed forthcoming
film Django Unchained, billed as a western set in the deep south in the period
just prior to the American civil war.

The plot rundown expands on the backstory revealed in numerous leaks from
bloggers claiming to have read Tarantino's screenplay last year, most of whom
gave a positive verdict. It confirms that the film will begin with German-born
bounty hunter Dr King Schultz (Christoph Waltz) freeing the title character and
helping to train him in combat so that he can return to the plantation where his
wife is incarcerated in the hope of liberating her.

The synopsis reads: "Set in the South two years before the Civil War, Django
Unchained stars Academy award-winner Jamie Foxx as Django, a slave whose brutal
history with his former owners lands him face-to-face with German-born bounty
hunter Dr King Schultz (Academy award-winner Christoph Waltz). Schultz is on the
trail of the murderous Brittle brothers, and only Django can lead him to his
bounty. The unorthodox Schultz acquires Django with a promise to free him upon
the capture of the Brittles - dead or alive.

"Success leads Schultz to free Django, though the two men choose not to go their
separate ways. Instead, Schultz seeks out the South's most wanted criminals with
Django by his side. Honing vital hunting skills, Django remains focused on one
goal: finding and rescuing Broomhilda (Kerry Washington), the wife he lost to
the slave trade long ago.

"Django and Schultz's search ultimately leads them to Calvin Candie (Academy
award-nominee Leonardo DiCaprio), the proprietor of "Candyland," an infamous
plantation where slaves are groomed by trainer Ace Woody (Kurt Russell) to
battle each other for sport. Exploring the compound under false pretenses,
Django and Schultz arouse the suspicion of Stephen (Academy award-nominee Samuel
L Jackson), Candie's trusted house slave. Their moves are marked, and a
treacherous organisation closes in on them. If Django and Schultz are to escape
with Broomhilda, they must choose between independence and solidarity, between
sacrifice and survival ..."

Django Unchained began filming in California in January before shifting to
Wyoming and Louisiana. The cast also features Don Johnson as another plantation
owner, Spencer "Big Daddy" Bennett, The Wire's Michael K Williams, Walton
Goggins of the TV series Justified and rapper RZA. The film's title is a riff on
the 1966 Sergio Corbucci spaghetti western Django, though it is not known how
much of the storyline will be borrowed from its predecessor.

LOAD-DATE: April 16, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                       Copyright 2012 Guardian Unlimited
                              All Rights Reserved

                              The Nation (AsiaNet)

                            August 12, 2006 Saturday

THE LONDON PLOT

BYLINE: IKRAMULLAH

LENGTH: 665 words


By Thursday noon, the UK hatched plot designed to blow up a number of planes
over the Atlantic, flying out of London and heading for various destinations in
the USA, was flashed by the electronic media, all over the world. The execution
of this holocaust, described as imminent, is said to have been foiled by very
close cooperation and timely coordination among the intelligence agencies of
Pakistan Britain and USA. The vital information about the terror plan to
simultaneously blow up many flights in mid air by terrorists through explosives
in their hand baggage was immediately passed on to MI 5 in London, as a result
of many arrests were made in Pakistan and Britain. On Friday morning, the bone
chilling details of the plot were front-page story of all newspapers in Pakistan
and indeed the rest of the world.

It is too early to say anything about the mastermind behind this deadly plot.
Experts on terrorism in Europe and the West believe that had this plot met with
a success, the consequent deaths and damage, both physical and psychological
would have been far greater than the 9/11 catastrophe. According to British and
American home security experts the London plot, if implemented, would have
rocked Europe and America beyond repair, shaking the confidence of the man in
the street in the competence and ability of their governments to handle the war
against terror in a successful manner. Almost over $3 trillion have so far been
spent on wiping out terrorism and making this earth a safe and secure place for
the present and future generations.

Islamabad has claimed a key role in thwarting the plot, which according to
Scotland Yard's Deputy Commissioner Paul Stephenson would have caused "untold
death and destruction on flights between Britain and the United States."
Interior Minister Aftab Ahmad Khan Sherpao and foreign office spokesperson
Tasneem Aslam both confirmed timely sharing of intelligence with Britain and
USA, leading to the arrests of many suspects in Pakistan and Britain.

Soon after the arrest of suspected terrorists involved in the terrorist plot,
the US Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff declared that the plot bore
the hallmarks of Usama Bin Laden's Al-Qaeda network. President Bush has labelled
the terrorists as "Islamic fascists." The White House has said that Mr Bush had
known about the foiled plot as early as Sunday last. British PM Tony Blair,
while continuing his holidays in the Caribbean, shares and supports the views of
President Bush.

There is nothing new in this consistency of the British foreign policy. What is
new and disturbing is, that in spite of solemn declaration by Bush and Blair
that terrorists have no religion or faith, they have both linked the London plot
with Islamic fascists, and then narrowed down the mastermind to Usama Bin
Laden's Al-Qaeda network. If Usama is still kicking hard in Afghanistan, Iraq
and many others "evil" states like Syria, Iran and Lebanon, should one presume
that the Al-Qaeda backbone is not yet fully broken as claimed by some?

The London plot further proves that Al-Qaeda is active on the British soil. The
war against international terrorism is proving counter-productive if one looks
at the recent state terrorism by Israel against innocent women and children in
Palestine and Lebanon. The root causes of injustice and double standards have to
be identified and a line has to be drawn while defining struggle for
independence and brutal terrorism in its naked form.

Muslims all over the world are disgusted with the present state terrorism
demonstrated during the past few weeks in Palestine and Lebanon. The tragedy in
Lebanon represents also a global failure and complacency of the highest order,
which must be attended to side by side with the acts of terrorism such as the
plot hatched by British citizens in UK. It is unfair to link it with Islam or
Islamic fascism. Terrorism or fascism have no religion and should not be linked
with any faith. E-mail: ikramullah@nation.com.pk

LOAD-DATE: December 6, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Acts of Terror

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                           Copyright 2006 The Nation
                              All Rights Reserved


                             232 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         The Age (Melbourne, Australia)

                           February 11, 2006 Saturday
                                 First Edition

Bush links Hambali to LA plot;
Arrest thwarted attack on skyscraper

BYLINE: MARK COULTAN, NEW YORK CORRESPONDENT, NEW YORK; With MARK FORBES

SECTION: NEWS; International News; Pg. 19

LENGTH: 442 words


A PLOT by key figures in Jemaah Islamiah to hijack a civilian airliner using a
shoe bomb and fly it into the tallest skyscraper in Los Angeles was thwarted
when Thailand arrested one of the operatives, according to President George
Bush.

In a speech on Thursday, he said that in October 2001, the mastermind of the
September 11 attacks, Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, had planned to hijack an aircraft
using shoe bombs to blast open the cockpit door and then fly into a building.

"We believe the intended target was Liberty Tower in Los Angeles, California,"
he said. In fact, the building he was referring to is the US Bank Tower,
commonly known as the Library Tower.

Mr Bush said Mohammed tapped a terrorist named Hambali, the operational leader
of Jemaah Islamiah, who in turn recruited several key operatives who had been
training in Afghanistan.

Once the operatives were recruited, he said, they met Osama bin Laden and then
began preparations.

Both Hambali and Mohammed have since been caught and are in United States
custody.

Last year Mr Bush made reference to 10 instances in which plots against the US
or its allies had been thwarted.

The Los Angeles plot has been well known for several years. It was previously
reported that the original plan for September 11 involved attacks on both the
east and west coasts, but this was aborted as being too ambitious.

The 9/11 commission reported that Mohammed had originally planned a bigger
attack involving as many as 10 aircraft on both coasts.

When Hambali was captured in August 2003, an Administration official said that
"al-Qaeda tasked Hambali shortly after September 11th with recruiting pilots to
participate in additional hijackings inside the United States".

But an Asian terrorism expert has played down Mr Bush's comments. Rohan
Gunaratna, head of terrorist research at the Institute for Defence and Strategic
Studies in Singapore, said intelligence reports confirmed that a leading JI
member, Hambali, was asked to assist with hijack plots. But the plans to target
California never progressed past "the very early stages", he said.

Instead, al-Qaeda focused on hijacking planes to hit landmarks in South-East
Asia. These plots disintegrated with the arrest of leading members.

Mr Bush revealed new details of the plot as he continued to justify wire-tapping
of Americans without warrants. There was no suggestion that wire-tapping in the
US provided any intelligence about the Los Angeles plan.

The speech appeared to be designed to prove that the US was making headway in
the war on terror. With his approval ratings faltering, national security is
seen as the President's strongest issue. -- With MARK FORBES

               National Post (f/k/a The Financial Post) (Canada)

                             July 8, 2006 Saturday
                                Toronto Edition

FBI foils plot to flood Manhattan: Arrest made in plan to bomb commuter trains

BYLINE: Sheldon Alberts, with files from James Gordon, CanWest News Service;
Ottawa Citizen

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. A14

LENGTH: 563  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


WASHINGTON - U.S. law enforcement officials said yesterday they had foiled a
plot to blow up commuter-train tunnels linking New York to New Jersey, including
those leading to Lower Manhattan, site of the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation said it had identified eight suspects in an
emerging plot apparently designed to disrupt the U.S. economy by flooding New
York's financial district.

Lebanese security officials, working with the FBI, have arrested a man in Beirut
identified as an al-Qaeda operative and the plan's mastermind.

"We believe we intercepted this group early in the plotting and that in fact the
plan has largely been disrupted," said Mark Mershon, assistant director of the
FBI's New York field office.

"The plotting for this attack had matured to a point where it appeared that the
individuals were about to move forward. They were about to go to a phase where
they would attempt to surveil targets, establish a regimen of attack and acquire
the resources necessary to effectuate the attacks."

Calling the bombing plot "the real deal," Mr. Mershon said the suspects wanted
to launch a suicide bomb attack on PATH commuter trains. "The plan involved
martyrdom, explosives and some of the tubes that connect New Jersey to
Manhattan," he said, without giving any detail.

It is the third alleged North American bomb plot authorities said they have
disrupted in the past two months.

In June, 400 police officers arrested 17 suspects in Southern Ontario.

Two weeks ago, the FBI said it had stopped a plan by a group in Miami to blow up
Chicago's Sears Tower, though several terror experts have questioned whether
those alleged plotters had posed a serious security threat.

Mr. Mershon said several foreign intelligence agencies had helped the United
States in the latest investigation, but declined to say whether Canadian
authorities were involved or if any of the suspects had ties to Canada.

Officials in Ottawa were similarly close-mouthed.

"Just because of the nature of the investigation, I'll refrain from making any
specific comments on it," said Stockwell Day, the Public Safety Minister.

"As that investigation continues to unfold we'll see where they've all come from
but because it's ongoing at this time, I prefer not to comment.

"One thing that we know is that people who plan these despicable deeds, they
know no boundaries."

Mr. Mershon said law enforcement and intelligence agents had been monitoring "a
group of al-Qaeda followers" for almost a year through discussions in Internet
chat rooms.

Intelligence agents discovered the suspects were using code words to describe
their plans to attack tunnels, officials said.

"It had not reached anything close to being operational," said Ray Kelly, the
New York police commissioner.

But the plotters' desire to attack commuter trains shows "that New York still
remains in the crosshairs of the terrorists."

Lebanese authorities said they had arrested Assem Hammoud, 31, at the end of
April.

The man had admitted under interrogation to being the plan's mastermind and
pledged allegiance to Osama bin Laden, Mr. Mershon said. He also said he hoped
to carry out the attacks in New York in October or November.

A report in the New York Daily News said the group had received pledges of
financial aid from Jordanians with ties to Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, leader of
al-Qaeda in Iraq who was killed last month.

QUIRKY WORLD ... Triple twins come up trumps with top results

SECTION: WORLD

LENGTH: 544 words


Ripon Grammar School s Louisa and Katharine Chatterton achieved 22 A* and A
grades, closely followed by Lorcan and Molly Gallagher with 21 top grades and
boarding brothers Harry and George Stratford with 15.

Katharine, who is considering going to drama school after A-levels in maths,
French, English literature, and religious education, said:  We re very
independent and have different ways of working but when we got sick of being
inside revising we started going on walks and taking flash cards and reciting
facts to each other.

Grave error

USA: A Rhode Island town is asking a court to decide whether the bodies of two
men buried in the wrong plots should be exhumed and moved.

The town of Tiverton filed a complaint for declaratory judgment in Superior
Court. In October, 65-year-old Lewis Chadwick Jr was placed in the wrong family
plot at the town-operated Pocasset Hill Cemetery.

In March, 87-year-old Raymond Murray, who was supposed to be buried in that plot
, died. He was buried in Mr Chadwick s plot. His family wants him moved to the
correct plot. Mr Chadwick s family opposes any move.

Dodo sale

England: A near-complete skeleton of a dodo is expected to reach more than
£500,000 ( 585,000 in November.

The 95% finished composite skeleton is the first to come up for sale in nearly
100 years, having been painstakingly assembled by a private collector since the
1970s.

The dodo became extinct in around 1680 and the vast majority of bones were found
in the Mare aux Songes swamp in south-east Mauritius in the 19th century. It
will be sold by Sussex-based natural history specialists Summers Place Auctions
on November 22.

Super-beero

USA: Do superheroes drink beer?

WIVB-TV in Buffalo reports that police in western New York say they re looking
for a man who was wearing a Batman costume and a Captain America mask when he
walked out of a convenience store on Tuesday with two 18-packs of beer without
paying for them.

The man, described by police as in his 20s, apparently made his getaway on foot.

Roadkill stew

USA: Thieves coming across dead moose on Alaska roads are stealing the
carcasses, making away with hundreds of kilogrammes of meat that normally goes
to a programme run by state troopers that gives it to the needy and others
willing to butcher the carcasses.

Two moose killed recently by cars or trucks were to be picked up by the
trooper-sponsored programme that alerts the Alaska Moose Federation so carcasses
can be quickly delivered to recipients. But federation drivers could not find
the two dead moose in July and August when they went to roadkill sites between
Anchorage and Denali National Park, said the federation s director, Don Dyer.

Moose killed on the road are the property of the state in Alaska, and the thefts
hurt Alaskans who like moose meat and who depend on wild game to supplement
their diets, said Mr Dyer.

Sometimes there will be 10 people waiting for this moose to be delivered. Then
we have to call them up and say  sorry, this moose has been stolen .

Roadkill moose provide plenty of food because adult bulls weigh up to 750kg,
yielding more than 250kg of meat each. Alaska s cold weather allows residents to
use roadkill meat as food because carcasses stay fresh long enough for them to
be retrieved and butchered rapidly.

                                   USA TODAY

                      June 28, 1993, Monday, FINAL EDITION

Terrorist probe leads to Pennsylvania farm

BYLINE: Robert Davis

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2A

LENGTH: 269 words


The probe into a suspected terrorist plot in New York City extended to a
Pennsylvania farm over the weekend, when FBI agents and Navy divers searched
woods and a pond for evidence of explosives.

The FBI is investigating whether farm owner Kelvin Smith - a Muslim who runs a
shooting range and gun shop on the property northwest of Harrisburg - is linked
to the New York plot. Smith denies involvement.

And a Black Muslim group called Fuqra, suspected of 16 bombings and six murders
since 1979, is getting a closer look.

Officials say Clement Rodney Hampton-El, the only U.S.-born suspect among eight
arrested in New York Thursday, is a member of Fuqra.

He was to provide explosives for the planned New York attack, officials say.

An FBI memo lists Jews, Hindus, Buddhists, Hare Krishnas, other Muslims and the
U.S. government among Fuqra foes.

Reaction to the plot:

Secretary of State Warren Christopher, on ABC's This Week With David Brinkley,
said worldwide visa operations must be computerized "to try to keep these people
from getting into the United States."

Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, refused to speculate
on NBC's Meet the Press what might happen if the New York suspects were found to
be sponsored by another country. But he warned "they will not achieve any of
their objectives through the use of this horrible means of policy."

Rep. Pat Schroeder, D-Colo., of the House Armed Services Committee, said on
CBS's Face the Nation, "We've got to approach (terrorism) properly so that we
don't break the world into two new forces where it's them and us."

                        Lancaster New Era (Pennsylvania)

                             March 6, 2007 Tuesday

Itching to dig? Sign up for garden plot

BYLINE: Lancaster New Era Staff

SECTION: B; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 356  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Now that most of the snow has washed away, it's not silly to plan to rent a
garden plot at Lancaster County Central Park.

The Lancaster County Department of Parks and Recreation has garden plots
available for rent April 15 through Oct. 15. Renters can apply now.

Lancaster County residents can select either a 20-foot-by-20-foot or 20-by-40
plot. Renters pay a one-time fee of $16 for a small plot and $20 for a larger
plot. The garden plots are located off Farm View Drive, just off Golf Road in
Central Park.

Gardeners of all skill levels can rent garden plots to grow their own flowers
and vegetables. They are ideal for gardeners with limited space at home and
great for groups looking for a summer project.

Organic plots also are available. These are plots that have been free of
pesticides and herbicides for more than three years.

Additionally, the Lancaster County Department of Parks and Recreation and Penn
State Cooperative Extension Master Gardeners Program are offering a variety of
garden workshops. Most sessions take place from 7-8 p.m. and are held in the
Lancaster County Environmental Center off Eshelman Mill Road in Central Park.

Workshop dates and topics are: Tuesday, March 20, garden preparation and
vegetable/plant selection. Attendees may bring a soil sample and purchase an
analysis kit for a small fee.

Saturday, April 21, 9:30-10:30 a.m., meet at the garden plots off Farm View
Drive for garden layout and staking. The topic will be special planting methods
for potatoes, tomatoes and root crops.

Tuesday, May 15, intermediate pruning, including perennials, tools and
techniques.

Tuesday, June 19, landscaping with site analysis and the right plant for the
right place.

There is a $1 fee per workshop session, but those who rent a garden plot in
Central Park may attend free of charge and pre-registration is required.

To register for a plot or workshop, call 299-8215, or visit the park office in
Central Park, located off Chesapeake Street, Monday through Friday, 8:30 a.m.- 5
p.m.

For garden plot rules and regulations or extended garden workshop topics and
dates July through October, visit www.co.lancaster.pa.us/parks.

                             237 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                  Daily Record

                           February 10, 2006, Friday

L.A. BOMB PLOT;
US REVEAL AL-QAEDA PLAN TO BRING DOWN SKYSCRAPER

BYLINE: By Ryan Parry

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 434 words


PRESIDENT Bush told last night how al-Qaeda tried to use suicide hijackers to
blow up the tallest building on the US west coast.

He said terrorists from southeast Asia planned to use shoe bombs to blast open
the cockpit doors of an airliner. And he claimed that once the fanatics were in
control of the jet, they would have crashed it into the 1018ft Library Tower in
Los Angeles.

Bush said the 2002 plot, which was foiled by a foreign government, showed that
al-Qaeda were still a real danger.

He insisted: "We cannot let the fact that America hasn't been attacked in
four-and-a-half years lull us into the illusion that the threats to our nation
have disappeared. They have not."

Critics accused Bush of trying to frighten voters into backing his controversial
anti-terror policy of allowing US citizens to be kept under secret surveillance
without the consent of the courts.

Bush had referred to the LA plot before, but gave more details in a speech at
the National Guard Memorial Building in Washington.

He said the attack was planned by 9/11 mastermind Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, who
began working on it in October 2001.

Bush claimed that Mohammed worked closely with a south-east Asian extremist
called Hambali.

Hambali was allegedly operations chief of Jemaah Islamiyah, the Islamic terror
group with close links to al-Qaeda who murdered 202 people in the Bali bomb
attacks of 2002.

Bush said Hambali recruited south-east Asians for the LA plot because they were
less likely than Arabs to arouse suspicion.

Four hijackers were found and sent to meet Osama bin Laden.

Bush said the target of the plot was the "Liberty Tower" in downtown Los
Angeles. Aides quickly gave out the skyscraper's correct name, the Library
Tower.

The skyscraper, since renamed the US Bank Tower, has 73 floors and more than
1.3million square feet of office and retail space.

Bush said the plot was derailed when a south-east Asian nation arrested a key
al-Qaida operative. The White House refused to name the country or the terrorist
held.

The president said: "The west coast plot shows we face a relentless and
determined enemy that requires unprecedented cooperation from other nations.

"It took the combined efforts of several countries to break up this plot. By
working together, we stopped a catastrophic attack on our homeland."

Hambali and Khalid Sheikh Mohammed are both now in American custody. They are
being held in secret prisons outside the US and have allegedly faced harsh
interrogation methods.

Bush has been heavily criticised for allowing US citizens to be subjected to
eavesdropping and surveillance without court warrants.

Fence Post

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 487 words


Winfield should be proud of its schools

I'm proud to say that I live in Winfield for any number of reasons, and
education is always at the top of the list. The performance of our schools
contributes to increases in our property values, personal pride and the overall
spirit of the Village. For most people searching for a community to raise a
family in, a major consideration is the performance of the public school system
and how well those schools prepare kids for higher education. These results are
a reflection of the community, the school administration, teachers, students,
and parent involvement. The children of Winfield attend schools serviced by
school districts 33, 34, 94, 200, and, in addition, St John the Baptist Catholic
School. Few communities with a population of approximately 9,000 have so many
excellent schools to work with. Winfield residents have much to be grateful for,
not least of all the high standards and excellent results of our schools.

Tony Reyes

Winfield

president, West Chicago High School District 94

Garden plot carping getting tiresome

It is getting tiresome to listen to the continuing carping of Naperville's
garden plots supporters about the "unfairness" of the park district's reasonable
compromise plan for relocating some of the plots farther south. They say the
land is to be used for "all the residents." Seems to me that use by about only
600 residents, many of them the same year after year, isn't "all the residents"
more like an exclusive little club -- once you're in, you're in. How long do
people get to keep plots? How long do they? Their complaints sound like a
typical entitlement or ownership mentality: It's mine now.

Ball and practice fields will be used by many more people that the garden plots
being moved, and the groups using them will change every year, unlike the plots.
And the number of plots isn't decreasing; no one is losing their opportunity (at
public expense, remember) to have a plot, just a different location. So the real
complaint is clear: I don't want to move; I don't want to change. We all have to
make adjustments; it's a fair plan and I hope the city council doesn't start
second-guessing a lot of hard work and micromanaging it, but approve it and get
on.

Kent Schielke

Naperville

Carlin good choice for county board

I enjoyed the article "Schillerstrom to cooperate with board in filling vacant
seat" and I believe that David Carlin would be the perfect appointee to the
DuPage County Board. Board President Bob Schillerstrom would be hard pressed to
find someone who could bring as much energy and expertise to fill the seat.
Carlin brings a fresh face to a beleaguered Republican party-along with
conservative principals to a board that has lost its way. His exceptional tenure
as a trustee of the College of DuPage gives him the credentials and leadership
skills to fill the seat-and help get our county back on track.

Rafael Rivadeneira

Elmhurst

                              KTLA-TV, Los Angeles

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              June 24, 2011 Friday

FBI: L.A. Man Arrested in Plot to Attack Seattle Military Recruiting Station

BYLINE: KTLA-TV, Los Angeles

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 327 words


June 24--SEATTLE, Wa -- A Los Angeles man is one of two suspects accused in a
plot to use machine guns and grenades in an attack on a military recruiting
station in Seattle that also houses a daycare, the U.S. Justice Department said
Thursday.

According to a federal complaint, Abu Khalid Abdul-Latif, aka Joseph Anthony
Davis, 33, of Seattle, and Walli Mujahidh, aka Frederick Domingue, Jr., 32, of
Los Angeles, took possession of machine guns that they purchased and planned to
use in an attack on the Military Entrance Processing Station on East Marginal
Way, Seattle.

The MEPS is where each branch of the military screens and processes enlistees.
In addition to housing many civilian and military employees, the building houses
a federal daycare center.

Agents were tipped off to the plot by someone the men tried to recruit as a
participant.

Law enforcement began monitoring Abdul-Latif and Mujahidh, including the weapons
transactions.

Agents even disabled the suspect's weapons so they posed no risk to the public.

The defendants initially planned an attack on Joint Base Lewis-McChord, but
later changed targets.

Since early June, the conspirators were captured on audio and videotape
discussing a violent assault on the Military Entrance Processing Station.

Abdul-Latif and Mujahidh are charged by complaint with conspiracy to murder
officers and employees of the United States, conspiracy to use a weapon of mass
destruction (grenades), and possession of firearms in furtherance of crimes of
violence.

Abdul-Latif is also charged with two counts of illegal possession of firearms.

Both Abdul-Latif and Mujahidh face potential sentences of life in prison if
convicted of the charges.

To see more of KTLA-TV, go to http://www.ktla.com/. Copyright (c) 2011, KTLA-TV,
Los Angeles Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more
information about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information
Services (MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.

                        Townsville Bulletin (Australia)

                            August 12, 2006 Saturday

The New Terror It's happening again Mid-air bomb plan rocks air travellers

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 743  words


AUTHORITIES in Britain and Pakistan quizzed more than 30 terror suspects
yesterday as an increasingly global dimension emerged to an alleged plot to blow
up as many as a dozen US-bound aircraft, possibly within days.

The Bank of England identified and froze the accounts of 19 of the 24 men
arrested in Britain, and Pakistan said it had helped uncover the plot with the
arrests last week of seven people, including two Britons of Pakistani origin.

The conspiracy -- which US officials said was the most serious since the
September 11, 2001, attacks -- involved terrorists smuggling seemingly innocuous
liquids in drinks bottles or other containers for assembling into bombs aboard
US-bound planes from Britain.

Chaos at British and foreign airports eased 24 hours after Britain went on
maximum alert before dawn over what one police chief called a plan to commit
'mass murder on an unimaginable scale'.

Hundreds of flights were cancelled and while airlines began yesterday to make up
the backlog, passengers were warned of delays and disruption amid heightened
security measures.

US officials estimated up to 10 planes were targeted in an operation they said
bore the imprint of Osama bin Laden's al-Qaeda terror network.

While Britain's domestic Press Association quoted senior police sources as
saying they believed up to nine planes were due to have been blown up, other
British media said between five and 12 planes were to be used.

The Independent newspaper said anti-terrorism officers staged raids to arrest
the 24 suspects, mostly believed to be of Pakistani origin, 'after it emerged
that the plotters might be ready to strike within 48 hours'.

A US intelligence official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the alleged
plot had targeted United Airlines, American Airlines and Continental Airlines
flights to New York, Washington and Los Angeles, and possibly other major hubs
such as Boston and Chicago.

According to The Washington Post, the first whiff of the alleged plot came after
the July 2005 suicide bombings on London's transit system, when a member of the
Muslim community tipped off British intelligence about the suspicious activities
of an acquaintance.

The vague tip led investigators to a well-coordinated and long-planned plot to
bomb multiple US-bound trans-Atlantic flights, a senior European intelligence
official said.

London's Metropolitan Police was brought into the investigation in December,
British media reported. Pakistani officials were also brought in.

A senior Pakistani government official said one of the two Britons was arrested
in the southern city of Karachi and the other in the eastern city of Lahore.

''The pair were key members of the Britain-based network of militants. The
arrests in Pakistan were made prior to the action in London,'' the official
said.

''They were in full knowledge of the plot to blow up the airlines, and the
information was passed on to Britain and US intelligence,'' the official added.

US President George W Bush was informed as early as Sunday of the inquiry, the
White House said.

Deputy Commissioner Peter Clarke, head of the London police's anti-terror
branch, said yesterday that police had taken 'urgent action' because the
operation had reached a 'critical point', but did not elaborate.

British Prime Minister Tony Blair's Downing St office told The Guardian daily
that he would not have left for his holiday in Barbados had he known how quickly
the situation would develop.

In announcing the freezing of the accounts, the Bank of England, Britain's
central bank, also identified 19 of the suspects.

All of those named appeared to be of Muslim origin, and were aged between 17 and
35.

US Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff indicated on Thursday that bombs
had been recovered at the homes of the arrested suspects, while The Times
reported yesterday, citing unidentified British government sources, that a
'martyrdom video', seemingly recorded by someone planning on becoming a suicide
bomber, was found at one of the homes raided by police.

British police declined to comment on what had been found.

Britain and the United States raised their threat levels, with the ensuing
higher levels of security causing severe delays at British airports, forcing
many airlines to cancel flights, and wreaking havoc on the global air traffic
network.

The security alert in Britain was raised to 'critical' -- the highest of five
levels -- from 'severe'.

Just when you thought it

was safe -- Page 41

                             241 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           December 15, 2016 Thursday

Study Finds Switchgrass Can Improve Soil Quality on Eroded Farms

LENGTH: 362  words

DATELINE: New York



 Atlanta: Growing Georgia has issued the following news release:



  The loss of fertile topsoil from agricultural fields is an economic problem
for modern farmers. When runoff water washes topsoil from agricultural fields in
areas with claypan soils under the topsoil, including parts of Missouri, Iowa,
Kansas, Illinois, Oklahoma and Texas, farmers are often left with an exposed
subsoil clay layer that creates difficult conditions for growing crops.





 Now, a study from the University of Missouri College of Agriculture, Food and
Natural Resources has found that switchgrass, which is a perennial plant and
used commonly for biofuel, improves soil quality and can be grown on farms that
have lost fertile topsoil. Stephen Anderson, the William A. Albrecht
Distinguished Professor of Soil Science at MU, says that switchgrass may be a
good option for farmers who have challenges with growing other crops, provided a
good market is available for switchgrass.



 "Once a farm loses its topsoil due to erosion, the soil recovers very slowly,"
Anderson said. "Switchgrass can be grown efficiently on eroded claypan soils;
farmers who have lost their topsoil may want to consider growing this hardy
plant. Switchgrass can be harvested and sold as a biomass crop for ethanol
production or as fuel for power plants. While demand depends on the current
market for biomass crops, this could be an answer for these farmers who
otherwise have challenges obtaining good economic returns growing grain crops on
eroded land."



 For their study, Anderson and lead author Syaharudin Zaibon, a doctoral
candidate at MU, examined farming plots with varying levels of topsoil, which
were established in 2009. Each plot had varying amounts of topsoil ranging from
extra topsoil to no topsoil. Corn, soybeans and switchgrass were grown on each
plot, and after five years, the researchers examined the soil density and water
permeability of each plot. They found that the switchgrass had improved the soil
quality of the plots with little or no topsoil on which it grew.





 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com
