                             242 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Star-News (Wilmington, NC)

                           September 8, 2009 Tuesday
                                  1ST Edition

Britain convicts 3 in airliner bomb plot

BYLINE: John F. Burns; New York Times News Service

SECTION: Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 814 words


Transatlantic routes | At least 7 jets were targeted for a single day

LONDON | After two trials and the largest counterterrorism investigation in
Britain's history, three men were found guilty Monday of plotting to bomb at
least seven trans-Atlantic airliners on a single day with liquid explosives
smuggled aboard in soft-drink bottles and detonated by devices powered with AA
batteries.

The convictions came three years after the global airline industry was thrown
into chaos by the plot. The bombers' plan to drain plastic soft-drink bottles
with syringes and refill them with concentrated hydrogen peroxide, a bleaching
agent also used as a propellant for rockets, led to new measures prohibiting
passengers from carrying all but small quantities of liquids and creams onto
flights.

With those measures still in force and causing backups at airport security
checkpoints around the world, the police and intelligence agencies in Britain
and the United States had waited anxiously for verdicts in the six-month trial
at Woolwich Crown Court in London, where eight men were accused of conspiracy to
stage the airliner bombings.

Prosecutors said the plot could have killed at least 1,500 people aboard the
targeted planes, which by that measure would have made it second only to the
Sept. 11 attacks as the most serious terrorist plot in modern history.

"Apart from massive loss of life, these attacks would have had enormous
worldwide economic and political significance," John McDowall, Scotland Yard's
counterterrorism chief, said after the verdicts.

In Washington, the Obama administration praised the verdict on Monday.

"British authorities have worked diligently to investigate and prosecute those
involved in the 2006 aviation plot," Mike Hammer, a National Security Council
spokesman, said in an e-mail message. "We congratulate them on those efforts and
extend our thanks to the British government for seeing these efforts through to
today's conclusion."

Last year, a trial failed to reach verdicts on the airliner-bombing charges
against the defendants then being tried.So the stakes were especially high in
the second trial for the main agencies involved in uncovering the London plot,
including Scotland Yard and Britain's intelligence agencies MI5 and MI6, as well
as the CIA, the National Security Agency and the FBI, among American agencies
involved.

The significance was all the greater because there have been no trials yet for
any of those directly involved in the Sept. 11 attacks.

After arrests in the liquid-explosives case were made in August 2006, documents
found at the plotters' homes and on a computer memory stick belonging to the
plot ringleader showed that they had earmarked airline schedules for seven
flights leaving London for New York, Washington, Chicago, San Francisco,
Montreal and Toronto, with aircraft operated by American Airlines, United
Airlines and Air Canada. Evidence at the trial showed the plot aimed to detonate
the bombs nearly simultaneously, with the aircraft over the Atlantic.

The plotters' intent, intelligence officials said, was to show that security
measures adopted after Sept. 11 were insufficient to foil the kind of
low-technology,  "asymmetric" attacks favored by Islamic extremists in their war
with the West.

Evidence at the London trial showed that several of the plotters, like those of
Sept. 11, had traveled to Pakistan and Afghanistan for indoctrination and
training by extremist groups linked to al-Qaida.

The jury found three men guilty of conspiring to kill passengers and crew
members aboard the flights: Abdulla Ahmed Ali, 28, named by prosecutors as the
plot's ringleader; Tanvir Hussain, 28; and Assad Sarwar, 29, who was identified
at the trial as the  "quartermaster" of the plot, responsible for acquiring the
explosives, detonators and other equipment and assembling them at a  "bomb
factory" in a London suburb.

A total of eight men were in the dock during the six-month trial. Four of the
eight - Ibrahim Savant, 28; Arafat Waheed Khan, 28; Waheed Zaman, 25; and Donald
Stewart-Whyte, 23 - were found not guilty of plotting to bomb the airliners. The
eighth man, Umar Islam, 31, was found guilty of an alternative charge of
conspiracy to commit murder, the charge on which Ali, Hussain and Sarwar were
convicted at the first trial that ended in September 2008.

The jury in the second trial failed to reach a verdict on the charge of
conspiracy to commit murder in the case of Savant, Khan and Zaman. It acquitted
Stewart-Whyte, who was said by defense lawyers at the trial to have converted
from Christianity to Islam only four months before his arrest.

The Crown Prosecution Service, responsible for filing charges in criminal cases,
said after the verdicts that it would review the jury's failure to reach
verdicts in the three cases of conspiracy to commit murder, and decide whether
to seek a third trial in the case.

LOAD-DATE: February 5, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             243 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)

                           October 29, 2008 Wednesday
                                 First Edition

Skinheads plotted to kill Obama;
THE RACE FOR POWER

BYLINE: ANNE DAVIES WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT with the Telegraph, London; The
Washington Post

SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; International News; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 568 words


INVESTIGATORS in Tennessee have thwarted a plot to assassinate Senator Barack
Obama and kill 102 other black Americans in a spree fuelled by white supremacist
ideology.

In court records unsealed on Monday, federal agents said they had disrupted
plans by Daniel Cowart, 20, and Paul Schlesselman, 18, to rob a gun shop and
target a predominantly black high school, shooting 88 blacks and decapitating
another 14.

The number 88 is white supremacist shorthand for Heil Hitler - the H is the
eighth letter in the alphabet. The significance of 14 lies in a 14-word mantra:
"We must secure the existence of our people and a future for white children."

Agents said the two skinheads told investigators their final act would be an
attempt to kill Senator Obama. The two "planned to drive their vehicle as fast
as they could towards Obama, shooting at him from the windows", according to an
affidavit filed in a federal court in Jackson, Tennessee, by an agent for the
Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives.

But it was not clear how advanced the plot was and how they thought they would
get within reach of the candidate, who has security equalling that accorded to
the President, George Bush.

The Obama camp had no comment on the plot. It was the third such incident: a
similar plot was uncovered in Denver during the Democrat National Convention.

Secret Service agents began protecting Senator Obama, the first black
presidential nominee of a major party, on May 3 last year, three months after he
announced he was running for the Democratic nomination, the earliest Secret
Service protection has been authorised for a candidate.

The Republican candidate, John McCain, has meanwhile ratcheted up his rhetoric
against Senator Obama, claiming that a radio interview in 2001, recorded when he
was a state senator in Illinois, confirms he is a "socialist" with dangerous
plans to redistribute wealth.

Speaking about civil rights decisions of the Supreme Court, Senator Obama had
said the court did not pursue redistributive change in trying to instil greater
equality.

The issue of poverty among minorities as a consequence of years of segregation
was a cause Martin Luther King jnr had taken up when he was assassinated in 1968
in Memphis, Tennessee.

Although his remarks were heavily analytical and academic, Senator Obama spoke
warmly of the notion of redistributing wealth, suggesting there were vehicles
other than the courts to achieve this.

"One of the ... tragedies of the civil rights movement was because the civil
rights movement became so court-focused, I think there was a tendency to lose
track of the political and community organising and activities on the ground
that are able to put together the actual coalition of powers through which you
bring about redistributive change," he said. "In some ways we still suffer from
that."

The comments were first uncovered by Fox News but Senator McCain has seized on
them to brand Senator Obama the "great redistributionist-in-chief". In The
Washington Post, the Fact Checker column noted: "With very few exceptions, all
American politicians, including both presidential candidates, are in favour of a
progressive income tax system and welfare policies, such as Medicare and social
security, that 'redistribute wealth'.

"Barack Obama is more enthusiastic about 'spreading the wealth around' than his
Republican rival. But that does not make him 'a socialist'."

LOAD-DATE: October 28, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: "I'm asking you to believe" ... Obama supporters sing the
American national anthem during a rally at the Mellon Arena in Pittsburgh on
Monday. Photo: AP/David Guttenfelder

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             244 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       Austin American-Statesman (Texas)

                             October 7, 2005 Friday

President touts 10 plots foiled Bush: 10 al Qaeda plots foiled;
Democrats assail assertion Iraq is a central front in war on terrorPresident
pushes Iraq case, says U.S., allies disrupted terror plans

BYLINE: Ken Herman, WASHINGTON BUREAU

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 878 words


WASHINGTON -- President Bush said Thursday that the war in Iraq is a crucial
front in a battle against terrorists seeking "a radical Islamic empire that
spans from Spain to Indonesia."

"Some might be tempted to dismiss these goals as fanatical or extreme," he said.
"Well, they are fanatical and extreme, and they should not be dismissed."

Bush, who spoke shortly before a terror alert was declared for New York City's
subways, said the United States and allied nations had "disrupted" at least 10
"serious al Qaeda terrorist plots" in the United States and abroad since the
Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

Bush also mentioned disrupting at least five other al Qaeda efforts to "case
targets in the United States or infiltrate operatives into our country."

"Because of this steady progress, the enemy is wounded," Bush told the National
Endowment for Democracy, "but the enemy is still capable of global operations."

On Thursday evening, the White House released a list of the 10 alleged plots,
including three that would have involved targets in the United States. Two of
the U.S. plots involved plans to use hijacked airplanes to attack the West Coast
in mid-2002 and the East Coast in mid-2003. The third was the case of Jose
Padilla, a former Chicago gang member who converted to Islam and is accused of
plotting to detonate a radioactive "dirty bomb" in a U.S. city. Padilla, whose
plot never materialized, was designated an enemy combatant by Bush and is being
held without criminal charge at a Navy prison in South Carolina.

Counterterrorism officials said the 2002 airliner plot had been led by Khalid
Sheikh Mohammed, the alleged mastermind of the Sept. 11 hijackings who was
captured in Pakistan in 2003. The Sept. 11 commission said in its report last
year that Mohammed originally had envisioned a broader operation in which as
many as 10 aircraft would be crashed into targets on both coasts. But it
previously hadn't been disclosed publicly that he had envisioned such an attack
on the West Coast in 2002.

Bush's speech came as senior government officials described a warning from one
senior al Qaeda leader to another that attacks on civilians and videotaped
executions could jeopardize their broader cause. The warning from second-ranking
al Qaeda chief Ayman al-Zawahiri to Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the top militant
leader in Iraq, was in a 6,000-word letter, dated early July, that was obtained
by U.S. forces in Iraq, the official told The New York Times.

Bush used Thursday's speech to renew his effort to link the Iraq war with the
Sept. 11 attacks. "We still remember a proud city covered in smoke and ashes, a
fire across the Potomac, and passengers who spent their final moments on Earth
fighting the enemy," he said. "We still remember the men who rejoice in every
death, and Americans in uniform rising to duty."

He said Muslim radicals have targeted Iraq, much as they had taken over
Afghanistan before the Sept. 11 attacks.

"The terrorists regard Iraq as the central front in their war against humanity,"
Bush said, "and we must recognize Iraq as the central front in our war on
terror."

Top Democrats said that Bush was striving to make a connection that doesn't
exist and that the president's speech did nothing to assuage their doubts about
the Iraq war.

"The president continued to falsely assert there is a link between the war in
Iraq and the tragedy of September 11, a link that did not and does not exist,"
said Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid, D-Nev.

Reid charged that Bush's "mishandling of the war in Iraq has made us less safe,
and Iraq risks becoming what it was not before the war: a training ground for
terrorists."

On the House side, Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., said Bush is wrong in
portraying the war in Iraq as a central front in the war on terrorism.

"The president went into Iraq on the basis of a false premise, without a plan,
and has totally mismanaged the war in Iraq. And now he's trying to justify his
actions with a series of excuses that are not reasons for us to be there,"
Pelosi said.

Bush defended his Iraq policy, and challenged those who claim that the war in
Iraq has caused increased extremism: "I would remind them that we were not in
Iraq on September the 11th, 2001, and al Qaeda attacked us anyway. The hatred of
the radicals existed before Iraq was an issue, and it will exist after Iraq is
no longer an excuse."

kherman@coxnews.com.

Additional material from The New York Times and The Associated Press.

(box)

Thwarted attacks

The White House says these 10 alleged al Qaeda plots were foiled by the United
States and its allies in the past four years:

* Three reputed plots in the United States, including the alleged dirty bomb
plan that Jose Padilla has been accused, but not charged, in and two plans that
would've used hijacked airliners. One plan targeted the West Coast in mid-2002
and the other the East Coast in mid-2003.

* Three plots within Britain, including one with multiple urban targets and one
that would've using hijacked airliners to attack Heathrow Airport.

* Two attempts to bomb ships in the Arabian Gulf and the Straits of Hormuz.

* A 2003 plot to attack Westerners in Karachi, Pakistan.

* A 2003 plot to attack a tourist site outside the United States.

- The Associated Press

LOAD-DATE: October 7, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Security was heightened at New York subways Thursday after city
officials said they had received information about threat aimed at the city's
transit system. Federal officials later downplayed the threat.
President Bush reiterated Thursday that the Iraq war was part of the broader
worldwide war on terrorism. 'The terrorists regard Iraq as the central front in
their war against humanity,' he said.

                             245 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                 Sunday Mirror

                              June 3, 2007 Sunday
                                 Scots Edition

BID TO BLOW UP JFK FOILED

BYLINE: BY RUPERT HAMER DEFENCE CORRESPONDENT

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 396 words


TERROR cops last night foiled a bold plot by suspected al-Qaeda terrorists to
blow up JFK airport in New York.

Four people were arrested and charged with conspiring to attack the airport by
planting explosives in the major jet fuel tanks and pipeline.

One of the suspects was a former cargo worker at the airport, who was also an
exmember of Guyana's parliament.

FBI sources said the plot never got beyond the planning stages but has raised
renewed fears of "home grown" terror cells.

One suspect was arrested in New York while others were now in custody in a
Caribbean country.

According to a statement by the US Justice Department, a suspect said in a
recorded conversation that the attacks would result in the destruction of "the
whole of Kennedy".

The plot was foiled well before it came to fruition and the FBI said there was
no threat to the public.

The law enforcement authorities said the investigation was helped by an
informant, who recorded talks with the suspects.

The plot, which dated from January 2006 to the present, tapped into an
international network of Muslim extremists from the United States, Guyana and
Trinidad.

The arrests mark the latest in a number of terror plots targeting high-profile
landmarks, including the arrest of seven men a year ago in what was called early
stages of a plot to blow up Sears Tower in Chicago.

Meanwhile, a series of security lapses have been uncovered at Birmingham
International Airport.

In one shocking image, Job Masih is caught snoozing as he was supposed to be
guarding a boarding gate.

Other security guards at the airport have also been shamed for boozing and
reading on duty. It's been revealed some even secured their jobs despite
criminal convictions.

The catalogue of security errors is exposed in a TV investigation.

The findings have been described as the most damning evidence ever into the
state of British airport security.

And the head of US Homeland Security, Bennie Thompson, has called for all
transatlantic flights from Birmingham airport to be stopped immediately.

In a six-month probe into security firm ICTS, employee Colin Cross turned
whistleblower to reveal how thousands of passengers' lives are put at risk every
day.

Several ICTS staff have been suspended. A spokesman said: "The allegations have
been taken very seriously. Investigations were launched immediately."

Terror In The Skies is on ITV1 tomorrow at 9pm.

LOAD-DATE: June 3, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Target: New York's JFK Airport

                             246 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                  July 25, 1993, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

A Wife Frets After Arrest Of Husband In Bomb Plot

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY,  Special to The New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 36; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 552 words

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, July 24


About two hours after Matarawi Mohammed Said Saleh was arrested at a barbecue on
the Jersey Shore on Thursday night, ending his month as a fugitive, he
telephoned his wife, Stephanie, from jail to profess his love and his innocence.

"He just told me to take care of the baby and take care of myself," she said
today in her apartment here, trying to comfort their crying, 5-month-old son,
Omar. "He was telling me he loves me so much. He even swore to God to me he
didn't do it. It's hard not to believe him."

But, she said, she is having doubts about her husband's disavowal of any role in
the reported plot by Muslim militants to blow up the United Nations building,
the Holland and Lincoln tunnels and a Manhattan office building housing F.B.I.
offices.

Mrs. Saleh said that before the late-night call on Thursday, she had last talked
to her husband on June 27 -- three days after the first F.B.I. arrests in the
plot.

She said she last saw him on June 25, when they were together in a motel
"somewhere" on the Jersey Shore, and he drove away in her car. He called her
that night and on the next two nights, she said, but she did not know where he
went after that.

"If he didn't do anything, why didn't he just come here and stay?" she said.
"When you hear everything on TV, it makes you have second thoughts. Why did he
take off? Why was he hiding?"

11th Suspect

The F.B.I. has identified Mr. Saleh, 44, an Egyptian who immigrated here in the
early 1980's, as the 11th member of the foiled bomb plot. He is being held
without bail in Manhattan.

Acquaintances here said Mr. Saleh often spoke of himself as a professional scuba
diver and marine welder. His wife, a 24-year-old native of Allentown, Pa., said
he talked of doing both years ago in Europe.

But, she said, since she met him here in September 1991, she had known him only
to sell clothing, sneakers and electronic equipment at a flea market in Union
City, N.J..

A Federal law-enforcement official said on Friday that it was believed that Mr.
Saleh had recently worked on a marine-welding project in the Caribbean. The
official gave no other details. But Mrs. Saleh said that before this month, her
husband had not been away for any extended periods.

Mrs. Saleh, whose maiden name is Singley, said she and Mr. Saleh were married in
November 1991 in the Jersey City home of an imam who preached at the Al Salam
mosque on Kennedy Boulevard here. She described her husband as a devout Muslim
who worshiped at the mosque, where several other suspects in the foiled bomb
plot, as well as other Muslims charged in the bombing of the World Trade Center
in February, also prayed.

Mrs. Saleh said she knew several of the suspects "by sight," including Siddig
Ibrahim Siddig Ali, described as the mastermind of the plot.

Federal authorities said yesterday that they believed Mr. Saleh had spent the
last month in New York City, Jersey City and elsewhere in New Jersey.

When arrested at a seaside motel in North Wildwood, N.J., Mr. Saleh was with a
friend, Ashraf Mohammed, 31; Mr. Mohammed's wife, Evelyn Cortez of Jersey City;
her three children, and a woman whom the authorities have not identified.

Ms. Cortez is Mr. Saleh's former wife. They were married during the 1980's and
he is the father of her 5-year-old son, Tony.

LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1993 The New York Times Company


                             247 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                          December 14, 2016 Wednesday

Switchgrass may be a good option for farmers who have lost fertile topsoil

LENGTH: 544  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: American Association for the Advancement of Science has issued the
following news release:



 The loss of fertile topsoil from agricultural fields is an economic problem for
modern farmers. When runoff water washes topsoil from agricultural fields in
areas with claypan soils under the topsoil, including parts of Missouri, Iowa,
Kansas, Illinois, Oklahoma and Texas, farmers are often left with an exposed
subsoil clay layer that creates difficult conditions for growing crops. Now, a
study from the University of Missouri College of Agriculture, Food and Natural
Resources has found that switchgrass, which is a perennial plant and used
commonly for biofuel, improves soil quality and can be grown on farms that have
lost fertile topsoil. Stephen Anderson, the William A. Albrecht Distinguished
Professor of Soil Science at MU, says that switchgrass may be a good option for
farmers who have challenges with growing other crops, provided a good market is
available for switchgrass.





 "Once a farm loses its topsoil due to erosion, the soil recovers very slowly,"
Anderson said. "Switchgrass can be grown efficiently on eroded claypan soils;
farmers who have lost their topsoil may want to consider growing this hardy
plant. Switchgrass can be harvested and sold as a biomass crop for ethanol
production or as fuel for power plants. While demand depends on the current
market for biomass crops, this could be an answer for these farmers who
otherwise have challenges obtaining good economic returns growing grain crops on
eroded land."



 For their study, Anderson and lead author Syaharudin Zaibon, a doctoral
candidate at MU, examined farming plots with varying levels of topsoil, which
were established in 2009. Each plot had varying amounts of topsoil ranging from
extra topsoil to no topsoil. Corn, soybeans and switchgrass were grown on each
plot, and after five years, the researchers examined the soil density and water
permeability of each plot. They found that the switchgrass had improved the soil
quality of the plots with little or no topsoil on which it grew.



 "Claypan layers have lower water permeability, making it more difficult for
plants to receive water and for farmers to obtain good economic returns from
grain crops when the silt loam topsoil is lost from these areas," Anderson said.
"This lower permeability prevents oxygen and water from seeping into the eroded
soil. We found that over a number of years, the switchgrass was able to
increase, or improve, the water permeability into this eroded soil, leading to
an 11 percent higher water saturation than the areas where corn and soybeans
were grown. This study shows that not only can switchgrass grow in these eroded
claypan soil areas, but it actually can improve the soil over time, potentially
opening the door for better production of grain crops subsequently grown in
those areas."



 This study was published in the Soil Science Society of America Journal.
Additional authors include Newell Kitchen, soil scientist with the USDA-ARS
Cropping Systems and Water Quality Unit and an adjunct professor at MU, and
Samuel Haruna, a doctoral student at MU.





 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: December 14, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2016 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                                US Official News

                          December 14, 2016 Wednesday

Switchgrass may be a good option for farmers who have lost fertile topsoil

LENGTH: 544  words

                             249 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               Right Vision News

                             July 10, 2010 Saturday

United States charges men in NY, Britain bomb plots

LENGTH: 485  words

DATELINE: NEW YORK


NEW YORK, July 10 -- The United States charged five men on Wednesday with
plotting to bomb New York City's subway system and attack an unidentified target
in Britain under orders from al Qaeda leaders in Pakistan.Another two men -
Najibullah Zazi and Zarein Ahmedzay - have already pleaded guilty to the New
York subway bomb plot, which authorities foiled in September and described as
the most serious threat to New York since the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks.

Adnan El Shukrijumah, Adis Medunjanin, Abid Naseer, Tariq Ur Rehman, and a fifth
man known as "Ahmad," were charged on Wednesday with 10 counts, including
conspiracy to use weapons of mass destruction and to commit murder in a foreign
country. Medunjanin, who attended a New York high school with Zazi and Ahmedzay,
was arrested in January and has pleaded not guilty to charges related to the
subway plot. New charges on Wednesday accused him of trying to crash his car
into another car in New York in a last bid to carry out a suicide attack. The
indictment said Shukrijumah, who is accused of being an al Qaeda operations
leader, and Ahmad "recruited and directed ... Adis Medunjanin, Najibullah Zazi
and Zarein Ahmedzay to conduct a terrorist attack in the United States."

The New York plot was linked to the British plot by Ahmad, prosecutors said.
Ahmad, an accused al-Qaeda facilitator in Peshawar, Pakistan, communicated with
Zazi about the New York plot and with Naseer about a British plot, they said.
Naseer and Rehman were among 12 men detained on terrorism charges after a raid
in northwest England in April 2009. Officials said they found surveillance
photos of public areas in Manchester, but authorities did not have enough
evidence to charge the men and they were released.

Naseer was arrested again in England on Wednesday and is awaiting extradition to
the United States. Rehman, Shukrijumah and Ahmad are still at large.

The FBI has long said that Saudi Arabian native Shukrijumah, who has a Guyanese
passport, was a threat to the United States and there is a $5 million reward for
his capture. Shukrijumah has also been linked by U.S. authorities to other
terrorism suspects, including a group of men accused of planning to bomb fuel
pipelines at New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport. U.S. prosecutors
also said Saleh al-Somali, al Qaeda's head of international operations, and
Rashid Rauf, a British al Qaeda militant suspected of being the ringleader of a
2006 plot to blow up airliners over the Atlantic, helped plan the failed New
York subway attack. Both are believed to be dead. No explosives were found in
the New York case, but Zazi admitted receiving bomb-making and weapons training
from al Qaeda in Pakistan's Waziristan region bordering Afghanistan Published by
HT Syndication with permission from Right Vision News. For more information on
news feed please contact Sarabjit Jagirdar at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement,
please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                             250 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                      July 2, 1990, Monday, FIRST EDITION

U.S. reportedly will detain Muslim cleric

BYLINE: Jack Kelley; Sandra Sanchez

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 549 words


Justice Department officials have decided to take Sheik Omar Abdel-Rahman into
custody but will not charge him in connection with a plot to bomb U.N.
headquarters and other sites, media reports said.

"The pressure has been building," says William Lewis, George Washington
University Middle East expert. "He's more than just a force of agitation."

Rahman, 55, is a blind Islamic cleric. Some of his followers were charged with
the Feb. 26 World Trade Center bombing and last month's plot to bomb the United
Nations and other New York landmarks. He'll be held on immigration charges, ABC,
CBS and The Associated Press reported. Justice officials refused comment.

Other news reports say government investigators have secretly recorded tapes
indicating Rahman had prior knowledge of the bombing plots.

U.S. officials let Rahman into the country in 1990 by mistake. He was granted
permanent residency in April 1992, but that was revoked in March 1992. He's
appealing.

Nine people have been arrested in the plot, and the sheik has acknowledged that
the man the FBI says was the group's ringleader acted as his interpreter.

Also Thursday, a prosecutor said the nine considered bombing the George
Washington Bridge. - Jack Kelley

LOTTO MANIA: Michigan's School Aid Fund got a bonus as no one came forward to
claim an $ 18 million Lotto jackpot - the largest unclaimed prize since the
state's lottery began in 1972. The winning ticket was purchased July 1, 1992, at
a 7-Eleven store in Hillsdale. In Florida, the winner of a $ 29.1 million
jackpot has not come forward. The winner has 180 days from last Saturday's
drawing to turn in the ticket. And Georgia officials reported first-day sales of
a lottery that started Tuesday reached $ 10 million.

LIFE 'LESSONS': William Kennedy Smith, acquitted of rape in 1991, says his life
is back to normal. "I think I have more perspective - it's so easy to lose,"
Smith told the Albuquerque Journal. "I do take lessons from my experiences, but
I try not to get wrapped up in an endless cycle of analysis." Also, The
Washington Post reports Smith's lawyer, Roy Black, is dating Lea Haller, a juror
from the trial.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO, b/w, AP

TYPE: Nationline

THE NATION; FROM USA TODAY'S NATIONAL NEWS NETWORK

                             251 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                          The Decatur Daily (Alabama)

                            October 30, 2005, Sunday

Grave problem

BYLINE: By Officials want to

LENGTH: 585 words



Following a price hike earlier this year for opening and closing graves at
Decatur City Cemetery, officials are preparing a request to nearly triple the
cost of a burial plot.

An adult plot would go from $ 250, including perpetual care, to $ 700, and an
infant plot would go from $ 100, including perpetual care, to $ 200, Parks and
Recreation Director Jeff Dunlap said. The increases require Decatur City Council
approval.

Earlier this year, the Parks and Recreation Board changed the charges for
opening and closing graves at the city cemetery from $ 165 on weekdays and $ 200
on weekends to prices ranging from $ 100 to $ 500. Those fees didn't require
council approval.

Dunlap said officials began discussing a price increase last year.

The last increase was 25 years ago. The cemetery has more than 2,000 plots for
sale and space to accommodate another 1,000 plots. At the current rate of sales,
it won't be full for more than 50 years, but officials said they need to begin
now to build the fund used to pay for perpetual care, including maintenance of
the graves, lawn care and driveways.

"It's not going to be that long before we're sold out, and there's no more money
coming in for the cemetery," cemetery clerk Jeannine Hill said.

"Perpetual care has to pay for maintenance," Dunlap said. "The city has to
maintain it for eternity."

A survey showed that the new prices would still be cheaper than area cemeteries,
officials said. Huntsville has nine cemeteries. Maple Hill charges $ 1,000 to $
1,900 per plot and $ 395 to $ 450 to open and close graves. Roselawn in Decatur
charges $ 795 to $ 1,495 for a plot and $ 645 to $ 695 to open and close.
Burningtree charges $ 995 for a plot and $ 795 to open and close.

Mayor Don Kyle said he's not sure when the new rates will be introduced or
whether he can get the council to support them. However, the rates need to
increase to help take pressure off the city operating budget, he said.

The cemetery fund contains about $ 610,000 in 2005. Interest raised $ 18,000 for
maintenance. Plot sales and grave openings and closings generated another $
37,000, but the annual maintenance cost is roughly $ 175,000 and must be
supplemented by tax funds.

"We're at a point where even if we sold all the remaining lots with the
increased fee, there still wouldn't be enough in the fund to maintain the
cemetery without general fund subsidies every year," Kyle said. "People were
buried there for years without perpetual care deposits."

There's no way to charge enough to ever end the city subsidy, but the city needs
to charge rates similar to other cemeteries to reduce the subsidies, Kyle said.

"We need to face the reality of the cost of operating the cemetery," he said.
"Private operators have to charge enough to fund perpetual care 100 percent. We
couldn't charge enough for the remaining lots to maintain the cemetery. That old
cemetery is extremely high maintenance because of the variety of shapes and
sizes and positions of the old-fashioned headstones."

                             252 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Pasadena Star-News (California)

                            August 10, 2006 Thursday

British authorities thwart terrorist plot to blow up several aircraft to U.S.

SECTION: BREAKING

LENGTH: 1351 words


LONDON - British authorities said Thursday they thwarted a terrorist plot to
simultaneously blow up several aircraft heading to the U.S. using explosives
smuggled in hand luggage, averting what police described as "mass murder on an
unimaginable scale."

Police arrested 21 people, saying they were confident they captured the main
suspects in what U.S. officials said was a plot in its final phases that had all
the earmarks of an al-Qaida operation. President Bush called it a "stark
reminder" of the continued threat to the United States from extremist Muslims.

Officials raised security to its highest level in Britain suggesting a terrorist
attack might be imminent and banned carry-on luggage on all flights. Huge crowds
backed up at security barriers at London's Heathrow airport as officials
searching for explosives barred nearly every form of liquid outside of baby
formula.

U.S. Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff said the terrorists planned to
use liquid explosives disguised as beverages and other common products and set
them off with detonators disguised as electronic devices.

The extreme measures at a major international aviation hub sent ripples
throughout the world. Heathrow was closed to most flights from Europe, and
British Airways canceled all its flights between the airport and points in
Britain, Europe and Libya. Numerous flights from U.S. cities to Britain were
canceled.

Washington raised its threat alert to its highest level for commercial flights
from Britain to the United States amid fears the plot had not been completely
crushed. The alert for all flights coming or going from the United States was
also raised slightly.

Two U.S. counterterrorism officials said the terrorists had targeted United,
American and Continental airlines. They spoke on condition of anonymity because
of the sensitivity of the case.

A U.S. intelligence official said the plotters had hoped to target flights to
major airports in New York, Washington and California.

British Home Secretary John Reid said the 21 people were arrested in London, its
suburbs and Birmingham following a lengthy investigation, including the alleged
"main players" in the plot. Searches continued in a number of locations.

The British Broadcasting Corp. said police were evacuating homes in High
Wycombe, a town 30 miles northwest of London, near one of the houses being
searched. Police refused to confirm the report or to discuss any details of the
searches.

Bush said during a visit to Green Bay, Wis., that the foiled plot was a "stark
reminder that this nation is at war with Islamic fascists." Despite increased
security since Sept.

11, he warned, "It is a mistake to believe there is no threat to the United
States of America."

While British officials declined to publicly identify the 21 suspects, French
Interior Minister Nicolas Sarkozy said in Paris that they "appear to be of
Pakistani origin." He did not give a source for his description, but said French
officials had been in close contact with British authorities.

The suspects were "homegrown," though it was not immediately clear if they were
all British citizens, said a British police official who spoke on condition of
anonymity because of the sensitivity of the case. Police were working closely
with the South Asian community, the official said.

The suicide bombing assault on London subway trains and a bus on July 7, 2005,
was carried out by Muslim extremists who grew up in Britain.

The police official said the plotters intended to simultaneously target multiple
planes bound for the United States.

"We think this was an extraordinarily serious plot and we are confident that
we've prevented an attempt to commit mass murder on an unimaginable scale,"
Deputy Police Commissioner Paul Stephenson said.

Prime Minister Tony Blair, vacationing in the Caribbean, briefed Bush on the
situation overnight. Blair issued a statement praising the cooperation between
the two countries, saying it "underlines the threat we face and our
determination to counter it."

White House spokesman Tony Snow said Bush also had been briefed by his aides
while at his ranch in Crawford, Texas, where he has been on vacation.

"We do believe the plot involved flights from the U.K. to the U.S. and was a
direct threat to the United States," Snow said. While Snow called the plot a
serious threat, he assured Americans that "it is safe to travel."

Chertoff, the homeland security chief, said the plot had the hallmarks of an
operation planned by al-Qaida, the terrorist group behind the Sept. 11 attack on
the United States.

"It was sophisticated, it had a lot of members and it was international in
scope. It was in some respects suggestive of an al-Qaida plot," Chertoff said,
but he cautioned it was too early in the investigation to reach any conclusions.

It is the first time the red alert level in the Homeland Security warning system
has been invoked, although there have been brief periods in the past when the
orange level was applied. Homeland Security defines the red alert as designating
a "severe risk of terrorist attacks."

"We believe that these arrests (in London) have significantly disrupted the
threat, but we cannot be sure that the threat has been entirely eliminated or
the plot completely thwarted," Chertoff said.

He added, however, there was no indication of current plots within the United
States.

Chertoff said the plotters were in the final stages of planning. "We were really
getting quite close to the execution phase," he said, adding that it was unclear
if the plot was linked to the upcoming fifth anniversary of the Sept. 11 terror
attacks.

A senior U.S. counterterrorism official said authorities believe dozens of
people possibly as many as 50 were involved in the plot. The official spoke on
condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the situation.

The plan involved airline passengers hiding masked explosives in carry-on
luggage, the official said. "They were not yet sitting on an airplane," but were
very close to traveling, the official said, calling the plot "the real deal."

Passengers in Britain faced delays as tighter security was hastily enforced at
the country's airports and additional measures were put in place for all
flights. Laptop computers, mobile phones, iPods, and remote controls were among
the items banned from being carried on board.

Liquids, such as hair care products, were also barred on flights in both Britain
and the U.S.

In the mid-1990s, officials foiled a plan by terrorist mastermind Ramzi Youssef
to blow up 12 Western jetliners simultaneously over the Pacific. The alleged
plot involved improvised bombs using liquid hidden in contact lens solution
containers.

Huge lines formed at ticket counters and behind security barriers at Heathrow
and other airports in Britain.

Ed Lappen, 55, a businessman from Boston, who was traveling with his wife and
daughter to Russia, found himself unable to travel further. "We're safe, we're
OK," he said at Heathrow. "Now my daughter is going to get a shopping trip in
London." Hannah Pillinger, 24, seemed less concerned by the announcement. "Eight
hours without an iPod, that's the most inconvenient thing," she said, waiting at
the Manchester airport.

Most European carriers canceled flights to Heathrow because of the massive
delays created after authorities enforced strict new regulations banning most
hand baggage.

Tony Douglas, Heathrow's managing director, said the airport hoped to resume
normal operations Friday, but passengers would still face delays and a ban on
cabin baggage "for the foreseeable future."

Security also was stepped up at train stations serving airports across Britain,
said British Transport Police spokeswoman Jan O'Neill. At London's Victoria
Station, police patrolled platforms with bomb-sniffing dogs as passengers
boarded trains carrying clear plastic bags.

Margaret Gavin, 67, waiting to board a train, said she wasn't scared. "Why
should I change my life because some idiots want to blow something up?" she
said.

Associated Press writers Lara Jakes Jordan in Washington and Matt Moore in
Frankfurt, Germany, contributed to this report.

LOAD-DATE: August 11, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             253 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                            The Daily Star (Lebanon)

                           October 12, 2011 Wednesday

U.S. ties Iran to foiled plot to assassinate Saudi ambassador

LENGTH: 710 words


The Obama administration Tuesday accused Iranian agents of being involved in a
plan to assassinate the Saudi ambassador to the United States.

WASHINGTON: The Obama administration Tuesday accused Iranian agents of being
involved in a plan to assassinate the Saudi ambassador to the United States.

Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said the thwarted plot would further
isolate Tehran.Two people, including a member of Iran's special operations unit
known as the Quds Force, were charged in New York federal court. Justice
Department officials say they were working with a person they thought was an
associate of a Mexican drug cartel to target the Saudi diplomat, Adel al-Jubeir.
But their contact was an informant for the Drug Enforcement Agency who told U.S.
authorities about all their planning.

FBI Director Robert Mueller said many lives could have been lost in the plot to
kill the ambassador with bombs in the U.S. But Preet Bharara, the U.S. attorney
in Manhattan, said no explosives were actually placed and no one was in any
danger because of the informant's cooperation with authorities.

Attorney General Eric Holder said the U.S. would hold Iran accountable. Clinton
told the Associated Press the Treasury Department soon would put more people
under sanctions. She also predicted the plot would further isolate Iran.

Holder said the plot was a flagrant violation of U.S. and international law.

"We will not let other countries use our soil as their battleground," Bharara
said at a press conference in Washington with Holder and FBI Director Robert
Mueller.

Holder later added the United States would contact governments worldwide to
brief them on the alleged plot.

"One thing that we will be doing is getting in touch with other of our allies
and nations around the world to make them aware of what it is that was thwarted
here," he said.

Iran rejected the U.S. claims, with IRNA, the official Iranian news agency,
calling the accusations "America's new propaganda scenario" against the Tehran
government. It did not elaborate.

Alizreza Miryusefi, the press attache at Iran's mission to the United Nations,
said Tuesday that the accusation was "totally baseless" and that a full
statement would be issued shortly.

Manssor Arbabsiar, a 56-year-old U.S. citizen who also holds an Iranian
passport, was charged along with Gholam Shakuri, whom authorities said was a
Quds Force member and is still at large in Iran.

Justice Department officials say Arbabsiar approached the DEA informant in
Mexico to ask about his knowledge of explosives for a plot to blow up the Saudi
Embassy in Washington. But through subsequent conversations in English, secretly
recorded for U.S. authorities, Arbabsiar offered $1.5 million for the death of
the ambassador, perhaps at a purported favorite restaurant of his despite the
possibility of mass casualties.

Asked whether the plot was given the blessing of the top echelons of the Iranian
government, Holder said the Justice Department was not making that accusation.
Arbabsiar did not know he was trying to hire a DEA informant to carry out the
plot, prosecutors said. Posing as an associate of a Mexican drug cartel, the
informant met with Arbabsiar several times in Mexico, authorities said. The
price tag was $1.5 million and Arbabsiar made a $100,000 down payment wired from
an overseas account.

Arbabsiar was arrested Sept. 29 at New York's John F. Kennedy International
Airport. He was scheduled to appear in federal court Tuesday. Prosecutors said
he faces up to life in prison if convicted.

Prosecutors said Arbabsiar has confessed to his participation in the murder plot
.

President Barack Obama was first briefed on the plot in June, said White House
spokesman Tommy Vietor.

"The disruption of this plot is a significant achievement by our intelligence
and law enforcement agencies, and the president is enormously grateful for their
exceptional work in this instance and countless others," Vietor said.

Saudi Arabia branded the plot "despicable," saying it violated "The principles
of humanity."

"The Royal Embassy of Saudi Arabia would like to express its appreciation to the
responsible agencies of the U.S. government for preventing a criminal act from
taking place," the Saudi Embassy in Washington said in a statement.

LOAD-DATE: October 17, 2011

                             254 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             Daily News (New York)

                             June 17, 2004 Thursday
                              SPORTS FINAL EDITION

THE PLOT AL QAEDA HAD EVEN BIGGER PLANS

BYLINE: BY HELEN KENNEDY DAILY NEWS STAFF WRITER

SECTION: NEWS; DAILY NEWS SPECIAL REPORT; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 1062 words


WASHINGTON - If he couldn't hit the World Trade Center, hijacker Mohamed Atta
planned to turn the nose of his giant passenger jet down into the canyons of
Manhattan and plow the plane into the streets. That revelation was just part of
yesterday's terrifying 9/11 Commission report detailing for the first time the
original dimensions of the plot.

As spectacular and deadly as the attacks turned out to be, they originally were
going to be much, much bigger:

Ten planes crashing at once in New York, Washington, Los Angeles and Seattle,
possibly targeting the Capitol building while Congress was in session, Seattle's
Space Needle and unnamed nuclear plants.

And amid all the carnage and hysteria, a TV network would have gotten a phone
call from one of the hijacked planes, still aloft. On board, mastermind Khalid
Shaikh Mohammed would denounce U.S. Mideast policies as all the men aboard were
being killed.

Based on previously secret interrogations of Mohammed, the commission's report
detailed a plot that took years of planning, that was nearly sunk by squabbling
and would-be hijackers who got cold feet. The plan eventually was scaled down,
even though it still resulted in the most devastating attack on U.S. soil.

An early part of the plan - pushed hard by Osama Bin Laden - was to carry out
the plot when Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon was visiting the White House
in the early summer of 2001.

The report portrayed Bin Laden as antsy and demanding, always trying to move up
the date of the attacks and hit more targets.

Earlier, Bin Laden wanted the hijackings carried out in mid-2000, incensed by
Sharon's visit to the Temple Mount in Jerusalem.

"The Al Qaeda leader wanted to punish the United States for supporting ­Israel,"
the report says flatly - a far more concrete reason for the attacks than has
been profferred until now.

The hijackers were not ready, though.

Some had just arrived in the United States, others still were on the way. The
pilots still were learning to fly.

Mohammed kept putting Bin Laden off. He told interrogators he never bothered to
tell Atta or the other ­pilots about the pressure from Bin Laden "because he
knew they would move forward when they were ready."

The wheels had been in motion for years by then.

Mohammed, a jihadist since the age of 16, had been thinking about using planes
as weapons since 1994, when he plotted with his nephew Ramzi Yousef, the
mastermind of the 1993 World Trade Center bombing, to blow up a dozen planes
­simultaneously over the Pacific.

In 1996, he went to Afghanistan to meet with Bin Laden and pitch a new idea:
crashing 10 hijacked planes into buildings.

It took Bin Laden until 1999 to give the okay. He summoned Mohammed back to
Kandahar to give him four men eager to martyr themselves and draw up a list of
targets. There was some argument: Bin Laden preferred hitting the White House,
Mohammed the Capitol.

(As late as two days before Sept.11, 2001, the target had not been fixed.

But the report said Atta chose the second week of September so that the Congress
would be in session.)

Early scenarios included also flying planes into American targets in Japan,
­Singapore or Korea and blowing up planes in midair over the Pacific as jets
were crashing in the U.S.

Coordination between so many time zones finally was deemed too difficult. And
Bin Laden personally scrapped Mohammed's idea of piloting one of the planes
himself, killing all the men, landing it and holding a press conference.

Training began. Mohammed taught some of the operatives basic English and showed
them how to make travel reservations, use the Internet and encode
communications.

"They also used flight simulator computer games and analyzed airline schedules
to figure out flights that would be in the air at the same time," the report
said.

The first hijackers to arrive in the U.S. - Nawaf Alhazmi and Khalid Almihdhar -
landed in Los Angeles on Jan. 15, 2000.

But they were lousy students. They enrolled at three different language schools
but never went to class and were dismal failures at flying school.

There were other setbacks.

At least nine would-be hijackers - Bin Laden originally envisioned 26 - failed
to get into the U.S.

Squabbling between the group leader, Mohamed Atta, and pilot Ziad Jarrah got so
bad that Jarrah almost packed up and went home. He was different from the
others: He drank beer, frosted his hair, went to nightclubs and had a serious
girlfriend in Hamburg.

Khalid Mohammed began to groom another jihadist, Zacarias Moussaoui, who is in
custody - to take Jarrah's place. ­Mohammed messaged a coordinator to send "the
skirts" to "Sally" - code for money for Moussaoui.

In the end, they convinced Jarrah, pilot of Flight 93, which crashed in
Pennsylvania, to go through with it.

Back in Afghanistan, Bin Laden was fending off Taliban leader Mullah Mohammed
Omar, who did not want any attacks inside the United States, fearing
retaliation.

In the last week before the attacks, as the teams were gathering in place, Atta
flew back and forth for final meetings.

On Sept. 7, he went from Fort Lauderdale to Baltimore to meet with the team that
would crash Flight 77 into the Pentagon. They were staying at a hotel in Laurel,
Md., and filling their final days with workouts at a nearby gym.

Zooming north through Maryland on ­I-95 to his team's staging area in Newark,
Jarrah got busted for speeding just after midnight on Sept. 9.

That day, Atta flew to Boston to check in with the team heading for Flight 175,
which crashed into the south tower.

He then drove to Portland, Maine, with one of his henchmen. The two men would
take a commuter flight back to Boston on the day of the attacks to throw off
suspicion at Logan Airport before boarding Flight 11, which crashed into the
north tower.

The detour almost cost them the connection in Boston. As it was, their luggage
never made it onto the doomed plane.

The bags, found later, contained a folding knife and pepper spray - "presumably
extra weapons the two conspirators decided they didn't need," the report said.

hkennedy@edit.nydailynews.com

GRAPHIC. the 10 targets.

Washington Seattle Space Needle

California Unspecified target in Los Angeles.

Jets leaving from these Asian cities would explode in midair:

Bangkok, Thailand Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

WASHINGTON D.C. CIA offices FBI offices White House Capitol building

Unspecified nuclear power plants

New York World Trade Center

of Manhattan if he couldn't hit the Trade Center. Osama Bin Laden wanted to
punish the U.S. for its support of Israel. Mastermind Khalid Shaikh Mohammed
planned personally to commandeer one of 10 hijacked jets and kill the men on
board. Bin Laden wanted to carry out the plot when Israeli Prime Minister Ariel
Sharon was at the White House in early summer 2001. The Seattle Space Needle was
a potential target.

                             255 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                              Chicago Daily Herald

                           January 25, 2014 Saturday

DuPage County in 60 seconds

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 418 words


Bee hives at garden plots:

Naperville Park District is working with a local beekeeper to bring four
honeybee hives to the community garden plots on West Street this summer. Brad
Wilson, director of recreation, said the bees will help with pollination of
vegetables and fruits gardeners grow at their plots. The park district also
plans to use the hives to educate residents and gardeners about the role of
honeybees in the growth of crops and about colony collapse disorder, which is
decreasing honeybee populations. Priority registration for previous gardeners
ends Feb. 7 and new gardeners can begin applying for plots Feb. 24. For details
about the park district's garden plots and the honeybees, call (630) 848-5040 or
visit napervilleparks.org/gardenplots.

West Chicago Sister Cities:

Guest speaker David Sabathne will discuss the relationship between West Chicago
and Taufkirchen, Germany, when the West Chicago Sister Cities group meets at 7
p.m. Feb. 6 at the Western DuPage Chamber of Commerce, 306 Main St., West
Chicago. His presentation will explore what links the two cities and what makes
them different. Sabathne was born and raised in West Chicago and is president
and CEO of the Western DuPage Chamber of Commerce. He was a city councilman when
Sister Cities began and took his first trip to Germany in 2001. For details on
the group, visit www.westchicagosistercities.com

Route 59 section closing:

Route 59 is expected to temporarily close for short periods of time overnight
Saturday into Sunday as electric contractors remove and install overhead power
lines that cross the road between Jefferson and Aurora avenues. A detour will be
posted directing drivers to North Aurora Road, Ogden Avenue and Aurora Avenue to
get around the closure. Also as part of a nearly $90 million project to widen
and resurface Route 59, access to LaSalle Avenue from the state road closed
Thursday and is expected to remain closed for one or two weeks. A detour map is
available at naperville.il.us/route59expansion.aspx.

Hanover Twp. hiring event:

Hanover Township hosts a hiring event for Harbor Freight Tools, a retailer of
auto and power tools, from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Wednesday at the township hall, 250
S. Route 59, Bartlett. The California-based company is looking for more than 40
employees for its Hanover Park location, slated to open in spring. One-on-one
job counseling also is available to residents at the township's Elgin and
Hanover Park offices. For details, call (630) 540-9085 or visit htjobs.org.

LOAD-DATE: January 25, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2014 Paddock Publications, Inc.


                             256 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


            The Fayetteville Observer (Fayetteville, North Carolina)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             April 9, 2013 Tuesday

Gardeners tending their own plots at Fayetteville Community Garden

BYLINE: Catherine Pritchard, The Fayetteville Observer, N.C.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 333 words


April 09--fat robins are working the grounds at the Fayetteville Community
Garden.

Gardeners are, too -- though they can be harder to see in the middle of a
weekday.

But there are unmistakable signs of their presence -- freshly turned earth in
some of the 20-foot-by-20-foot plots, drying piles of weeds, and the end of
winter crops, such as cabbages and gone-to-seed broccoli, in a few plots tended
by green-thumbed gardeners year round.

It will all give way as the weather warms to flowers and vegetables and herbs --
and gardeners.

The purpose of the 5-acre, city-owned garden -- at Vanstory and Mann streets off
Old Wilmington Road -- is to encourage healthy eating and bring the community
together.

The garden's 94 plots are rented on an annual basis for $25, and renters are
given first shot at renewing their lease each year. Then other would-be
gardeners are allowed to rent. Only 14 plots remained unrented Friday, according
to the Fayetteville-Cumberland Parks and Recreation Department, which oversees
the garden.

Working together

Garden members are expected to display some commitment, and not just to their
own plots. Members are expected to contribute at least eight hours of their time
to helping maintain the garden over the growing season. They can expect to spend
at least five hours a week tending their own plots in the spring, slightly less
in summer as plantings flourish, and perhaps 3 1/2hours a week during harvest,
according to the Parks and Recreation Department, which provides gardeners with
guidelines and literature.

The rewards can be satisfying and delicious.

The garden is organic and doesn't permit the use of insecticides, fungicides,
herbicides or synthetic fertilizers.

For more information, call 433-1547.

Staff writer Catherine Pritchard can be reached at pritchardc@fayobserver.com or
486-3517.

Fayetteville Observer (Fayetteville, N.C.) at www.fayobserver.com Distributed by
MCT Information Services

-at-Fayetteville-Community-Garden-0409-20130409

JOURNAL-CODE: FY

                             257 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


            The Fayetteville Observer (Fayetteville, North Carolina)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             April 9, 2013 Tuesday

Gardeners tending their own plots at Fayetteville Community Garden

BYLINE: Catherine Pritchard, The Fayetteville Observer, N.C.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 333 words


April 09--Fat robins are working the grounds at the Fayetteville Community
Garden.

Gardeners are, too -- though they can be harder to see in the middle of a
weekday.

But there are unmistakable signs of their presence -- freshly turned earth in

by green-thumbed gardeners year round.

It will all give way as the weather warms to flowers and vegetables and herbs --
and gardeners.

the garden.

Working together

Garden members are expected to display some commitment, and not just to their
own plots. Members are expected to contribute at least eight hours of their time
to helping maintain the garden over the growing season. They can expect to spend
at least five hours a week tending their own plots in the spring, slightly less
in summer as plantings flourish, and perhaps 3 1/2 hours a week during harvest,
according to the Parks and Recreation Department, which provides gardeners with
guidelines and literature.

The rewards can be satisfying and delicious.

The garden is organic and doesn't permit the use of insecticides, fungicides,
herbicides or synthetic fertilizers.

For more information, call 433-1547.

Staff writer Catherine Pritchard can be reached at pritchardc@fayobserver.com or
486-3517.

                               The Washington Post

                    January 4, 2000, Tuesday, Final Edition

Algerian Arrested Dec. 24 Probed for Bomb Plot Links

David A. Vise; Lorraine Adams, Washington Post Staff Writers

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A02

LENGTH: 566 words


Federal agents are investigating whether there is a link between an Algerian man
charged with immigration violations yesterday and a bomb plot apparently foiled
last month in Washington state by the FBI and immigration officials, U.S.
officials said last night.

Abdel Hakim Tizegha, who was arrested on Dec. 24 and charged in federal court in
Seattle yesterday, traveled between Washington state and Canada last month. He
entered the United States from Canada, according to the FBI, by sneaking through
the woods and crossing the border on foot around Nov. 30.

It is not clear what role, if any, Tizegha had in a plot to carry out terrorist
attacks related to millennial celebrations in the United States. While he knew
others who allegedly were part of a terrorist scheme that revolved around an
organization known as the Armed Islamic Group, his relationship to that group
and to any plot has not been determined, officials said.

In mid-December, another Algerian, Ahmed Ressam, was arrested with a car full of
powerful explosives and timing devices while traveling from Canada into
Washington state. Last week, Abdel Ghani, an Algerian with links to the
terrorist group, was arrested in Brooklyn. Ghani had traveled to Seattle to meet
Ressam, but never made contact after Ressam was arrested and their plans to
carry out a bombing were stymied, according to U.S. officials.

Officials know that Tizegha was a friend of Ghani and had contact with Ressam.
Detaining him on immigration charges will enable U.S. officials to question
Tizegha further about the alleged plots.

The court filing yesterday said Tizegha unsuccessfully attempted to flee when he
was arrested on Christmas Eve in Seattle. At the time, he already was facing
deportation charges for earlier immigration violations. In 1993, the complaint
alleged, Tizegha entered the United States illegally as a stowaway on a ship and
then applied for political asylum in Boston. His request was reviewed and denied
and ultimately, he was ordered to leave the U.S. last summer, which he did.

Since his Dec. 24 arrest, Tizegha called his roommate from the INS detention
facility and asked him to destroy a bus ticket showing he had gone from
Bellingham, Wash., to Seattle. The roommate told the FBI that he complied with
the request to destroy the ticket.

Last week, U.S. law enforcement officials arrested people in New York and Boston
and questioned dozens of others nationwide in an effort to disrupt a possible
network of Algerians suspected of planning terrorist attacks. In addition,
officials disclosed that a Canadian woman arrested last month trying to cross
the border into Vermont, Ressam and the Algerian arrested last week in Brooklyn
were all linked to the same terrorist organization.

The group had false passports, aliases and a plan to leave a rented car filled
with explosives at a drop-off point in Seattle, where another member of the
network would take charge of the vehicle, officials allege. FBI officials said
they had not identified any specific U.S. city or site that was to have been the
focus of the attack.

Also yesterday, another suspect was arrested in New York, according to a U.S.
official. The man was linked to the bomb smuggling scheme and appeared in
Manhattan federal court during a secret proceeding in which papers were filed
under seal, the Associated Press reported.

                             259 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                  November 29, 1995, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION

A dozen of the films Hollywood will unwrap

BYLINE: Tom Green

SECTION: LIFE; Pg. 6D

LENGTH: 806 words


'Father of the Bride Part II'

-- Stars: Steve Martin, Diane Keaton, Martin Short.

-- Plot: Incredibly, both daughter and mother are expecting simultaneously, and
Martin copes badly.

-- Prospects: A happy, healthy, bouncing box-office bonanza seems assured for
this sequel, thanks to a zillion video rentals of the original.

-- Release date: Dec. 8.

'Heat'

-- Stars: Al Pacino, Robert De Niro, Val Kilmer.

-- Plot: Los Angeles-based psychological thriller in which a tough cop (Pacino)
tracks down a hardened criminal (De Niro) and his cronies.

-- Prospects: A test of holiday moviegoers' interest in crime yarns. The movie
is also long. Though they have just two scenes together, superstars Pacino and
De Niro clash onscreen for the first time.

-- Release date: Dec. 8.

'Sense and Sensibility'

-- Stars: Emma Thompson, Alan Rickman, Kate Winslet, Hugh Grant.

-- Plot: A Jane Austen comedy of manners in which a soon-to-be-single woman
(Thompson) falls for a shy guy (Grant).

-- Prospects: This one's going for the Howards End crowd, and the early buzz is
very good. Directed by Ang Lee (The Wedding Banquet).

-- Release date: Dec. 13.

'Othello'

-- Stars: Laurence Fishburne, Irene Jacob, Kenneth Branagh.

-- Plot: The scheming Iago (Branagh) lies to Othello (Fishburne) that his wife
Desdemona (Jacob) has been unfaithful.

-- Prospects: Purists will be offended that the movie excises a good portion of
Shakespeare's dialogue, but Fishburne is one fine actor.

-- Release date: Dec. 14.

'Cry, the Beloved Country'

-- Stars: James Earl Jones, Richard Harris.

-- Plot: In apartheid South Africa, a black man's son kills the son of a white
man.  Somehow these men find peace.

-- Prospects: It's hoped that formidable actors Jones and Harris will draw
moviegoers to this latest adaptation of Alan Paton's 1930s saga.

-- Release date: Dec. 15.

'Jumanji'

-- Stars: Robin Williams, Kirsten Dunst, Bonnie Hunt, David Alan Grier.

-- Plot: A kid trapped in a jungle board game for 26 years must finish the game
to avert lethal consequences.

-- Prospects: Must overcome that title (from a children's book by Chris Van
Allsburg). This special-effects movie features crocodiles, baboons, giant
spiders, a monsoon and such. Williams is not at full throttle.

-- Release date: Dec. 15.

'Sabrina'

-- Stars: Harrison Ford, Julia Ormond, Greg Kinnear.

-- Plot: A beauty is romanced by an older guy to keep her from his playboy
brother.

-- Prospects: Based on Billy Wilder's 1954 romance, this is reportedly a
faithful remake. Of course, there's no Audrey Hepburn, Humphrey Bogart or
William Holden.

-- Release date: Dec. 15.

'Nixon'

-- Stars: Anthony Hopkins, James Woods, Paul Sorvino, Ed Harris, Madeline Kahn.

-- Plot: Everybody knows the story of Richard M. Nixon and Watergate. Presumably
director Oliver Stone will mine the man's psyche.

-- Prospects: Stone plus a first-rate cast suggest a movie of merit, perhaps
even controversy. Hopkins' Nixon is not exactly a mirror image, which may annoy
some viewers.

-- Release date: Dec. 20.

'Grumpier Old Men'

-- Stars: Jack Lemmon, Walter Matthau, Sophia Loren, Ann-Margret, Daryl Hannah.

-- Plot: The two men fought for widow Ann-Margret in Grumpy Old Men; in this
sequel, Lemmon is married to her.  The new wrinkle: Loren has moved to Wabasha,
Minn., and is threatening to turn the fishing hole into a ristorante.

-- Prospects: Revisiting their surprise '93 hit, these legends are likely to
exchange equally sharp barbs.

-- Release date: Dec. 22.

'Sudden Death'

-- Stars: Jean-Claude Van Damme, Powers Boothe.

-- Plot: At the Stanley Cup hockey finals, the bad guys have captured not only
the vice president but also Van Damme's little girl. The latter is a big
mistake.

-- Prospects: The stunts are a bit of a wow and there's violence galore, which
means the testosterone crowd should flock to this one.

-- Release date: Dec. 22.

'Waiting to Exhale'

-- Stars: Whitney Houston, Angela Bassett, Lela Rochon, Loretta Devine.

-- Plot: Simple story of four women searching for the right man. Most of their
relationships are with two-timers and assorted other louts.

-- Prospects: The studios should breathe easy because this film, based on the
Terry McMillan best seller, taps into unmined material with a smokin' cast.
Houston's first film since The Bodyguard should pack them in.

-- Release date: Dec. 22

'Dead Man Walking'

-- Stars: Susan Sarandon, Sean Penn.

-- Plot: A nun overcomes her own fears when she fights for the life and soul of
a murderer on death row.

-- Prospects: Tim Robbins (fresh from The Shawshank Redemption) directs this
grim prison drama. Besides the strong cast, the film also has a title song by
Bruce Springsteen and a star-packed soundtrack.

-- Release date: Dec. 29.

LOAD-DATE: November 30, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO, b/w, Nicola Goode, Twentieth Century Fox; PHOTO, b/w, Brian
Hamill, Paramount Pictures; PHOTO, b/w, Frank Connor, Warner Bros.; PHOTO, b/w,
Sidney Baldwin, Hollywood Pictures; PHOTO, b/w, Clive Coote, Columbia Pictures

HOLIDAY MOVIES; Toy Story has already got the box office ringing, but Mr. Potato
Head isn't the only star among films still due for the holiday season. USA
TODAY's Tom Green samples a dozen upcoming releases generating interest in
Hollywood:

                             260 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                      Monterey County Herald (California)

                           January 29, 2009 Thursday

Tired cliches abound in 'New in Town'

BYLINE: By RICK BENTLEY McClatchy Newspapers

SECTION: REVIEWS

LENGTH: 423 words


It's bad enough when a movie uses a worn-out plot gimmick. "New In Town"
multiplies the disappointment by resorting to a string of familiar film cliches.

The result is such a dull, unimaginative and poorly photographed movie that, if
"New in Town" were to move into the house next door to you, it would be time to
change ZIP codes.

Renee Zellweger plays Lucy Hill, an executive who is rapidly moving up the
corporate ladder. She's sent to New Ulm, a small town in Minnesota, to take
control of one of the company's factories. She's supposed to cut the staff to
make the operation more profitable.

Her thick corporate skin is pierced by the good-natured locals and a single-dad
widower, Ted Mitchell (Harry Connick Jr.).

Writer Ken Rance and C. Jay Cox have pieced together a movie with no
imagination, no jokes and a complete void of any chance their characters will
show chemistry. And it is all played out through stale plot devices.

First plot gimmick: Hill is smart enough to become a force in her Florida-based
company. But, she is not smart enough to look at the Weather Channel to know
that it is going to be cold in Minnesota in winter. Giving her that much
intelligence would have meant forgoing all of the jokes about her stomping
through the snow in high heels.

Second plot gimmick: New Ulm, Minn., must be the home for all "Fargo"
impersonators, don't cha know. "New In Town" uses the old trick of making
everyone in town so down-to-Earth and homespun you just have to like them.
Hollywood must not know that detestable people also live in small towns.

Third plot gimmick: Does anyone really believe the factory is in serious
trouble? That would be like putting a puppy on a railroad track and not yanking
it away before the train arrives. The old Hollywood chestnut of whether the new
high-falootin' boss will get a heart has all the tension of a coffee commercial.

Fourth plot gimmick: The best-looking guy in town can't get a date until an
outsider shows up. Hill wins over Mitchell by giving his daughter fashion tips.

Fifth plot gimmick: The ending is so trite and hackneyed it might make your
teeth hurt.

The only good thing that can be said about "New In Town" is that it has set a
high bar for all of the bad movies to come in 2009. GO!

'NEW IN TOWN' ·Featuring:Renee Zellweger, Harry Connick Jr. and J.K. Simmons;
directed by Jonas Elmer. ·Where:Century Cinemas in Monterey, Maya Cinemas in
Salinas, Century 14 in Salinas, Green Valley in Watsonville ·Rating:PG for adult
themes and mild language ·Running time: 1 hour, 36 minutes

LOAD-DATE: January 30, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                             261 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Lowell Sun (Massachusetts)

                             August 11, 2006 Friday

Experts: Plan shows al-Qaida committed

BYLINE: By EVAN LEHMANN, Sun Washington Bureau

SECTION: TODAY'S HEADLINES

LENGTH: 712 words


WASHINGTON -- The foiled terror attack in London showcases the effectiveness of
tighter security measures enacted after Sept. 11, 2001, but also reveals
al-Qaida's undiminished determination to stun the world with spectacular
strikes, analysts warn.

Unraveling a month before the fifth anniversary of 9/11, the London plot had the
markings of Osama bin Laden's terror group and was a louder echo of past
attacks, they said.

The use of liquid explosives and the deployment of multiple teams to just as
many targets was an attempt to exploit weaknesses in security systems hardened
in the last five years while aiming for a stunning impact, the analysts said.

"I see an al-Qaida operation. It has the simultaneous (and) coordinated
attacks," said Marius Deeb, a professor of Middle East and Islamic studies for
the School of Advanced International Studies at John Hopkins University.

Twenty-four suspects were caught by British police before they were able to
carry out a sophisticated attack on 10 airliners bound for New York, Washington,
D.C. and California. The intent was "mass murder," British officials said.

U.S. Homeland Security chief Michael Chertoff said the plot is indicative of
al-Qaida but offered no evidence and stopped short of assigning blame to the
extremist group. British officials also did not definitively name al-Qaida as
the plot's source.

Deeb said parallels between past attacks, including those in Madrid, London and
the United States, and the latest plot left "no doubt" that the operatives had
received training, planning and financing from the highest levels of al-Qaida.

"Bin Laden and (his lieutenant Ayman) al-Zawahiri were behind it," he said.
"There's no mavericks here. There's no loners. They're all very well-organized."

Michael O'Hanlon, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said, "I think
it's a little scary that al-Qaida or its affiliates still have the ability to
mount this kind of attack."

The plot's disruption showed increased operational expertise by security
agencies, yet it also revealed shortcomings, he said.

"It reinvigorates the case for homeland-security efforts for data-sharing on
suspected terrorists" among nations, O'Hanlon said.

The plot is a "magnification" of the failed attempt by shoe-bomber Richard Reid,
said Gerry Leone, a former first assistant U.S. attorney in Boston who was the
lead prosecutor in that case.

"It's the same plot. It's just more people, more planes and a different way to
avoid detection based on what terrorists have learned since 2001," said Leone,
who is running unopposed for Middlesex district attorney.

Reid, who was trained in Afghanistan and financed by al-Qaida, tried to light a
fuse attached to plastic explosives in his shoe in December 2001 aboard an
American Airlines flight carrying 197 people from Paris to Miami. He's serving
life in prison.

Leone said the 9/11 attack was presaged by a 1993 attack on the World Trade
Center that killed six people. "It's a terrifying analog," he said.

"Splendid" security saved thousands of lives in the latest plot, but other
attacks will eventually succeed, warned Terrance Downes, executive director of
the program on Homeland Security at Middlesex Community College in Lowell.

"It's naive to expect any government anywhere is going to be able to absolutely
protect the public," he said. "Governments have to be right 100 percent of the
time, and terrorists only have to be right 1 percent of the time.

"It is going to be a prolonged struggle that will be marked with periodic
terrible events, like what was planned in Britain," Downes added.

Airport security is already being adjusted. Liquids have been banned temporarily
from airline passenger cabins.

Wristwatches, cell phones and other electronic devices that could be used to
trigger bombs could be banned next, said retired Air Force Lt. Gen. Tad
Oelstrom, director of the National Security Program at Harvard's Kennedy School
of Government.

But determined terrorists will find the next weakness in security systems, and
exploit them, he warned.

"There will be something else," Oelstrom said. "The fact that we've isolated or
zeroed in on liquid explosives (means) there will be another iteration out there
that becomes a threat."

Evan Lehmann's e-mail address is elehmann@lowellsun.com .

LOAD-DATE: August 11, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
