                         Hartford Courant (Connecticut)

                            January 23, 2009 Friday
                               FINAL - 5 EDITION

CEMETERY PLOTS: THESE DAYS, PRICES TO DIE FOR;
DIRT CHEAP

BYLINE: ANN MARIE SOMMA asomma@courant.com

SECTION: MAIN; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 377 words


What price for your mother's plot?

James Hill will take $5,500, and he's got it up for sale on craigslist.

Hill inherited the double plot - worth $7,000 - at Willowbrook Cemetery in
Westport when his mother died eight years ago. She's buried elsewhere, and he
doesn't need it because it's likely he'll be cremated.

"Right now, it's just a piece of paper in my drawer. I would rather see the
zeros in my bank account," said Hill, 45, who works as a free-lancer in the
media service business.

As the economy continues to falter, forcing people to be more creative in their
efforts to make money, the resale of cemetery plots on the Internet is on the
rise.

William Matto, a superintendent at Pine Grove Cemetery in Ansonia, said Pine
Grove frowns upon plot holders reselling grave sites, but many people get around
it by saying they are giving the plot away.

Matto understands that times are tough, but resold plots generally lose a
quarter of their value. It's better to hold onto them, he said.

"Sooner or later, you will use the grave," Matto said.

Matto said single plots at Pine Grove sold for $550 six years ago. Today they
sell for $800.

Baron Chu, who owns plotbrokers.com, a Los Angeles-based cemetery plot website,
said calls have increased tenfold since 2008, mainly from cash-strapped people
who have lost their jobs or are facing foreclosure.

"Originally, the calls were for selling, but after we had the local news do a
story on us, more people are buying plots because they'll pay 20 to 40 percent
below retail," said Chu, who is licensed by the state to sell plots in
California.

Chu said a woman who was laid off and on the verge of homelessness after facing
a foreclosure recently sold her plot on his site. The money she made allowed her
to pay for three months of rent.

Plotbrokers is set up like a real estate database and Chu's clients are mostly
the children of elderly parents, those who have moved out of state or opted for
cremation, and anyone in need of cash.

"Who isn't worried about the economy?" Chu said.

The only call Hill has received since advertising his mother's plot on
craigslist a week ago was from an Internet burial site interested in listing the
plot. He hasn't followed up on the offer.

"Whoever buys this is getting a bargain," Hill said.

LOAD-DATE: January 23, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                  Copyright 2009 The Hartford Courant Company
                              All Rights Reserved


                             263 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                        Calgary Herald (Alberta, Canada)

                        January 4, 2000, Tuesday, FINAL

Two more arrests in U.S. terror plot

BYLINE: Knight Ridder

SECTION: News; A9

LENGTH: 335 words

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES


Two more Algerian men have been arrested in the continuing investigation into
alleged smuggling of explosives over the border from Canada in an apparent bomb
plot, officials said Monday.

The first, seized Dec. 24 in Seattle, made a court appearance Monday to face
immigration charges.

No mention of a bombing plot was made in the four-page complaint against Abdel
Hakim Tizegha or in court, but citing confidential sources, the Seattle Times
reported authorities suspect Tizegha was involved in a plan by terrorists to
strike targets in the United States.

The second, Abdelwahib Hamdouche, was taken into custody Saturday night at New
York's Kennedy International Airport as he was preparing to leave for Paris,
officials said. Hamdouche, 34, a naturalized French citizen who was living in
Brooklyn, was held as a material witness in the bomb plot investigation, and it
is believed he was ordered to remain in custody after a closed hearing Monday in
U.S. District Court in Manhattan.

The suspected plot has triggered a far- reaching investigation and an aggressive
effort -- including a sweep last week in which authorities questioned and
detained dozens of people in New York, Boston, San Francisco and Houston -- to
avert a terrorist attack in the U.S.

Tizegha was charged with illegally re-entering the U.S. after being ordered to
leave the country and for eluding authorities who were seeking to question him.

Tizegha's detention by the Immigration and Naturalization Service followed the
arrest of Ahmed Ressam, who was picked up by U.S. Customs Service agents in Port
Angeles, Wash., as he drove off a ferry from Canada on Dec. 14. Authorities said
Ressam's vehicle contained bombmaking materials, including hundreds of pounds of
the chemical urea, a military liquid explosive and sophisticated timing devices

The Issue

Cross-border smuggling of explosives

- What's New:

Two more Algerian men arrested

- What's Next:

Police look for connection to extremist faction

                Intelligencer Journal (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

                             May 10, 2006 Wednesday

Central Park gardens available

BYLINE: Intelligencer Journal Staff

SECTION: M; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 190  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Garden plots are available for rent from Lancaster County Department of Parks
and Recreation.

County residents can select a 20-by-20-foot or 20-by-40-foot plot for a one-time
fee of $16 for a small plot and $20 for a larger plot. They have access to the
garden through Oct. 15.

Organic plots are also available. These are plots that have been free of
pesticides and herbicides for more than three years.

The parks department and Penn State Cooperative Extension Master Gardeners
Program plan garden workshops. Dates and topics are: June 6, butterfly
gardening; July 11, herb gardening; Aug. 8, roses; Sept. 12, basic container
gardening; and Oct. 3, basic pruning.

Garden workshops will be held from 7 to 8 p.m. at the Lancaster County
Environmental Center off Eshelman Mill Road in Lancaster County Central Park.

There is a $1 fee per workshop session, which is waived for garden plot renters.
Preregistration is required.

For information on a garden or to register for a plot or workshop, call 299-8215
or visit the office located off Chesapeake Street, weekdays between 8:30 a.m.
and 5 p.m. Also, visit the Web site www.co.lancaster.pa.us/parks.

                            Dayton Daily News (Ohio)

                              March 3, 2014 Monday

Greene

SECTION: LOCAL & STATE; Pg. B3

LENGTH: 357 words


FAIRBORN WSU hosts health plan disease outbreak study

Professionals will have the chance to practice their response plans for a
disease outbreak at a Public Health Grand Rounds, "A One Health Approach to
Disease Outbreak: A Public Health Emergency Response," March 21, 9 a.m. to 2
p.m., at the Madison Lakes Learning and Conference Center, 581 Olive Road, in
Dayton.

The format will be a facilitated tabletop exercise of a disease outbreak.
Participants will analyze their response plans to collaboratively assess a
complex public health investigation involving multiple agencies and
jurisdictions. They will identify existing gaps in their response plans, the
university said.

The event is for public health professionals, educators, emergency personnel and
veterinarians.

Advance registration is required. Space is limited. A nonrefundable registration
fee of $20 includes materials and lunch. The registration deadline is March

14. To register, go to
http://nursing.wright.edu/nursing-institute/training#tab=one-health-approach.
For more information, contact Cyneca Reed at the Center for Global Health at
937-258-5555 or cyneca.reed@wright.edu STAFF

REPORT

BEAVERCREEK Parks & Trails offering public garden plots

The Greene County Parks & Trails is offering community garden plots for local
gardeners at Karohl Park, 2940 Hohl Drive.

Plots are 20-by-20 feet. Garden plots are available on a first-come, first-serve
basis, with each plot costing $25.

The garden plots can be reserved as a single plot or in multiple units. All
plots are plowed and staked off into sections.

For more information or to reserve a garden plot, call 937-562-6440 or emailing
abotkin@co.greene.oh.us

STEVEN MATTHEWS

CEDARVILLE Carillon Brass to perform 'Bach's Lunch '

Carillon Brass will perform a free "Bach's Lunch" concert at noon March 14 at
the Cedarville University Dixon Ministry Center Recital Hall, 251 N. Main St.

The band is a quintet from the Dayton Philharmonic Orchestra created as an
outreach program to bring classical music to community schools.

Attendees can pack a lunch for the event, and water is the only liquid permitted
in the facility. MEREDITH WHELCHEL

                                 Sunday Mirror

                              June 3, 2007 Sunday
                                 3 Star Edition

BID TO BLOW UP JFK FOILED

BYLINE: BY RUPERT HAMER DEFENCE CORRESPONDENT

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 416 words


TERROR cops last night foiled an audacious plot by suspected al-Qaeda terrorists
to blow up JFK airport in New York.

Four people were arrested and charged with conspiring to attack the airport by
planting explosives in the major jet fuel tanks and pipeline.

One of the suspects was a former cargo worker at the airport, who was also an
ex-member of Guyana's parliament.

FBI sources said the plot never got beyond the planning stages but has raised
renewed fears of "home grown" terror cells in the US.

One suspect was arrested in New York while others were now in custody in a
Caribbean country.

According to a statement by the US Justice Department, a suspect said in a
recorded conversation that the attacks would result in the destruction of "the
whole of Kennedy".

The plot was foiled well before it came to fruition and the FBI said there was
no threat to the public.

The law enforcement authorities said the investigation was helped by an
informant, who recorded conversations with the suspects.

The plot, which dated from January 2006 to the present, tapped into an
international network of Muslim extremists from the United States, Guyana and
Trinidad.

The arrests mark the latest in a number of terror plots targeting high-profile
landmarks, including the arrest of seven men a year ago during what was called
the early stages of a plot to blow up Sears Tower in Chicago.

Meanwhile, a series of security lapses have been uncovered at Birmingham
International Airport.

In one shocking image, Job Masih is caught snoozing as he was supposed to be
guarding a boarding gate.

Other security guards at the airport have also been shamed for boozing and
reading on duty. It's been revealed that some even secured their jobs despite
having criminal convictions.

The catalogue of security errors is exposed in a TV investigation.

The findings have been described as the most damning evidence ever into the
state of British airport security.

And the head of US Homeland Security, Bennie Thompson, has called for all
transatlantic flights from Birmingham airport to be stopped immediately.

In a six-month probe into security firm ICTS, employee Colin Cross turned
whistleblower to reveal how thousands of passengers' lives are put at risk every
day.

He said: "The public have a right to know what really goes on."

Several ICTS staff have been suspended. A spokesman said: "The allegations have
been taken very seriously. Investigations were launched immediately."

Terror In The Skies will be shown on ITV1 tomorrow at 9pm.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Target... New York's JFK airport

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             267 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Contra Costa Times (California)

                            December 15, 2008 Monday

Grave concern: Council to consider expanding cemetery

BYLINE: By Robert Jordan Valley Times

SECTION: MY TOWN; Alameda; News; Local

LENGTH: 506 words


PLEASANTON   Julie and Bob Phillips were both born in Oakland, but spent the
past 37 years making Pleasanton their home.

The couple has been married 46 years and raised four daughters here, including
their youngest who was married in their backyard. Now with all their children
living in the Modesto area, the Phillips have no plans of leaving the city and
hope to be buried here in the future.

"My heart and my history is here," said Phillips. "My life is here and anything
that means anything to me is here."

The Phillips are counting on the city council to approve a plan to expand
Pleasanton Pioneer Cemetery, so they can call this town of just over 70,000
their final resting place.

Tonight the council will decide whether or not to allow an additional 200
full-size, double-depth plots and 200 smaller double-niche plots for cremains at
the cemetery located on the south side of town.

The expansion would give the cemetery room for 800 more bodies.

The revenue from the new plots is expected to bring in $1.95 million. Of that
money, $1.18 million would be used to install the new vaults and cremains plots
and to upgrade the entire irrigation system.

Under the proposed plan, the city would advance $190,000 from its capital
improvement reserves for surveying, plot verification and pre-installation of
the first 200 full-sized vaults. The money would be repaid to the reserve from
plot sales. A full-sized plot is expected to cost $3,400   that price does not
include the double-depth vault nor the burial services fees for two individuals.
Cremain niche plots are expected to cost $1,700   that price also does not
include the vault or other burial fees.

The upgrades to the irrigation system and other landscaped improvements wouldn't
take place until after all the plots and cremation niches are sold.

The additional plots would increase the city's maintenance cost of the cemetery
from $75,400 to $85,000 annually.

Phillips doesn't have qualms talking about her final resting place. With a
background in hospice care, Phillips is familiar with death.

"People think it's gross to talk about buying plots," she said. "But I have
worked with death and dying and want to call Pleasanton my final resting place."

Interest in the cemetery expansion isn't limited to the Phillips.

Fan Ventura, who works for the city's Parks and Community Services department,
said 34 resident families have expressed interest in purchasing plots and 11
nonresident families from as far a way as Auburn, Murphys, Oakdale and Vacaville
have also called inquiring about the expansion.

The Parks and Recreation Commission unanimously approved the plan back in
October and forwarded the item to the council, which continued the item at the
Dec. 2 meeting.

Pleasanton acquired the cemetery in early 2007 and since then has contracted
with Catholic Funeral Cemetery Services for burial services.

Reach Robert Jordan at rjordan@bayareanewsgroup.com or 925-847-2184.If you go

     ·    WHAT: Pleasanton City Council meeting WHEN: 7 p.m. today WHERE:
          Council chamber, 200 Old Bernal Ave.

                                The Denver Post

                      February 16, 2001 Friday 1ST EDITION

Foiled plots provide example Columbine victims note lessons

BYLINE: By Kevin Simpson, Denver Post Staff Writer,

SECTION: DENVER & THE WEST; Pg. B-02

LENGTH: 384 words


Recently foiled plots for alleged Columbine-style shootings  across the country
demonstrate how schools and police should react  to threatening information,
according to legal briefs to be filed  today by injured Columbine victims.

Although the observation is basically a footnote to broader  legal arguments in
the suit against Columbine educators and  Jefferson County law enforcement, the
coincidence was impossible  for Jim Cederberg, attorney for injured student
Richard Castaldo  and lead author of the brief, to ignore.

One alleged plot involved a student at a San Jose, Calif.,  junior college and
another involved students at a Fort Collins  middle school. Both were discovered
by authorities before they  could unfold.

'Anecdotally, we point out that although these defendants  say, 'What could we
do about it, how could we sniff it out?'  that's exactly what they're doing in
other places,' Cederberg said.

'The information that started the follow-up that led to the  discovery of the
California and Fort Collins plots was a lot less  than the stuff available on
(killers Eric Harris and Dylan  Klebold) in the beginning.'

The lawsuit, which also includes claims by injured students  Sean Graves, Lance
Kirklin and Mark Taylor, hinges in part on the  educators' and law enforcement's
failure to act despite evidence  that a violent plot was in the works.

'You're up late, you get up the next morning, pick up the  newspaper, and here's
another one,' Cederberg said. 'And you  think, 'That's what I'm talking about.''

He typed the footnote: 'As this Brief is being written, the  Denver Post reports
disruption of a Columbine 'copy cat' plot at a  middle school in Fort Collins by
vigilant school and law  enforcement officials.'

In its motion to dismiss the case, attorneys for Columbine  High School
principal Frank DeAngelis, six teachers and the  Jefferson County School
District claimed that a federal appeals  court has ruled that public schools
aren't required to protect  students from each other.

A hearing has been set for April 27.

In all, nine wrongful-death and negligence lawsuits filed by  about 20 families
of those injured and killed at Columbine in  April 1999 are pending in federal
court.

                             269 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                             Daily News (New York)

                             July 8, 2010 Thursday
                              SPORTS FINAL EDITION

SWEET DEAL FOR SUBWAY PLOTTER CANARY. ZAZI MAY GET VISA, END UP IN U.S. WITNESS
PROTECTION

BYLINE: BY JOHN MARZULLI and LARRY McSHANE DAILY NEWS STAFF WRITERS With Alison
Gendar

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 455 words


THE CONFESSED subway suicide bomber could wind up in the federal witness
protection program - living side by side with Americans he wanted dead.

Najibullah Zazi's cooperation with the feds was key to a new indictment
yesterday that tied his plan to blow up subways in Times Square and Grand
Central stations to a foiled plot in England.

The Afghan immigrant's singing could earn him a coveted "S" visa, given only to
aliens who provide critical information on terror organizations, officials
revealed.

The new indictment implicates a top Al Qaeda terrorist: Adnan Shukrijumah, now
tied to four different plots to hit New York, was accused of recruiting Zazi and
two other men as bombers.

There is a $5 million bounty for Shukrijumah, a 34-year-old Saudi-born man with
Brooklyn ties who is a leader in Al Qaeda's "external operations" program
dedicated to attacking the U.S. and the West, the feds said.

The Brooklyn Federal Court case also linked Zazi, who grew up in Queens and was
living in Colorado, with a foiled April 2009 bombing in Manchester, England,
exposing Al Qaeda's far-reaching tentacles.

The two plots were "directly related," federal officials said - and a law
enforcement source said it showed how terrorism in the 21st century had changed.

"It is a lot easier for homegrown terrorists . . . to meet high-ranking,
hard-core operatives, and offer themselves as tools to inflict casualties," the
source told the Daily News. "And the word from Al Qaeda is, 'Welcome, we need
you to do your part.' "

Zazi and a second man, Zarein Ahmedzay, pleaded guilty in the New York plot this
year and agreed to cooperate with authorities.

A third suspect, Adis Medunjanin, faced new terror charges in the new indictment
- including an allegation that he tried to kill himself and other drivers by
crashing his car on the Whitestone Expressway in Queens.

"We love death," he reportedly told a 911 operator before the Jan. 7 wreck.

Federal Judge Raymond Dearie agreed yesterday to unseal the cooperation
agreements. Medunjanin's co-defendants - Zazi, who was the New York plot's
pointman, and Ahmedzay - both apparently may get a sweet deal.

Zazi and Ahmedzay could have their life sentences reduced and enter the witness
protection program if the Justice Department agrees with prosecutors'
recommendations. Zazi could also receive the "S" visa.

In the Manchester plot, two men were arrested in April but never charged.

Tariq Ur Rehman was deported to Pakistan; suspect Abid Naseer, was rearrested
yesterday in England on the U.S. charges.

The new indictment asserted Zazi and Naseer were in Peshawar, Pakistan, at the
same time in November 2008, and used the same e-mail account to communicate with
an Al Qaeda middleman.

lmcshane@nydailynews.com

subway plot was linked to foiled attack in England. Photo by Reuters

                                   USA TODAY

                              June 4, 2007 Monday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Papers: Con was key in foiling JFK plot

BYLINE: Richard Willing

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 447 words


A convicted drug dealer seeking a reduced sentence helped thwart an alleged plot
to blow up fuel tanks and destroy New York City's Kennedy International Airport,
papers filed in the case say.

The paid informant, described in a criminal complaint unsealed Saturday as "the
Source," made four surveillance trips to the airport in January with Russell
Defreitas, a former Kennedy Airport cargo handler who was the plot's alleged
leader, the complaint says. The informant also recorded conversations,
downloaded airport images from Google Earth and traveled with Defreitas, 63, to
Guyana to enlist the aid of an armed radical Muslim group, Jamaat al Muslimeen,
legal papers charge.

Defreitas and three other men, two Guyanese and a citizen of Trinidad, were
charged with conspiring to destroy the airport by blowing up fuel lines, fuel
tanks and terminal buildings. Two of the three were in custody in Trinidad, and
the third still was being sought.

The case is at least the fifth time in two years in which the U.S. government
has relied on paid informants, some recruited by police, to bring
terrorism-related charges against U.S.-based Muslims, according to federal court
records.

FBI spokesman John Miller said taking down al-Qaeda-inspired plots is getting
more difficult. "When you're looking at inspired-through-the-Internet, homegrown
extremists, well, they can pop up anywhere," he told ABC News on Sunday.

The informant tactic has resulted in four convictions, but raises questions
about civil liberties and entrapment, says University of Richmond law professor
Carl Tobias, who has written on terror and the law.

Authorities first learned of the plot in January 2006, the charging papers say.
The informant, who had worshiped with Defreitas at a Brooklyn mosque, contacted
Defreitas in July 2006 and was gradually let in on the plot.

Defreitas, a native of Guyana and a naturalized U.S. citizen, told the informant
that he had become radicalized in the early 1990s, the papers say. Working at
Kennedy Airport, he said he saw missiles being shipped to Israel and decided he
"wanted to do something that will get those bastards," according to a transcript
quoted in the legal papers. Exploding the airport's fuel tanks, Defreitas said,
"can destroy the economy of America for some time."

Kenneth Wainstein, assistant attorney general for National Security at the
Justice Department, compared the plot to the arrest last month of six New
Jersey-based Muslims charged in a plan to attack Fort Dix in New Jersey.

The cases, Wainstein said, highlight that the threat to the USA is no longer
confined to attacks from overseas. The "terrorist threat we face" has an
"evolving nature," he said.

                                  The Express

                             June 24, 2006 Saturday
                                U.K. 1st Edition

FBI foil plot to bomb Sears Tower

BYLINE: By Marco Giannangeli

SECTION: NEWS; 15

LENGTH: 380  words


FEDERAL agents have foiled an alleged terrorist plot which would have seen
America's tallest building destroyed as part of a mission "greater than 9/11",
it emerged yesterday.

Chicago's Sears Tower - the tallest building in the world until 2004 - was one
of a list of targets that included the FBI offices in Florida.

News of the plot comes just days after revelations by the US intelligence
service that Al Qaeda terrorists had targeted London's Canary Wharf as part of a
separate plot.

Seven men were arrested on Thursday after federal agents surrounded a warehouse
in Miami, Florida. Inside, they found a "military boot camp" used to train
Islamic terrorists, according to official reports.

The leader of the group, identified as Narseal Batiste, is accused of recruiting
and training other members "for a mission to wage war against the United States
government".

Batiste is said to have met an FBI agent posing as an Al Qaeda representative on
several occasions last December asking for guns, radios, vehicles and 50,000
dollars (GBP 39,739) in cash to help him build an "Islamic army to wage jihad".

In February 2006, Batiste allegedly told the Al Qaeda representative that he and
five soldiers were planning a "full ground war" against the US that would be
"just as good or greater than 9/11".

The seven men have been charged with conspiring to "maliciously damage and
destroy by means of an explosive" the FBI building in Miami Beach and the Sears
Tower in Chicago.

Five of the men were born in America, one is a legal immigrant and one is from
Haiti and living in the US illegally.

Neighbours living near the warehouse yesterday told how the men had actively
tried to recruit others in the area.

"They seemed brainwashed, " said Tashwan Rose, 29. "They said they had given
their lives to Allah." Batiste and the six other suspects - named as Patrick
Abraham, Stanley Grant Phanor, Naudimar Herrera, Burson Augustin, Lyglenson
Lemorin and Rotschild Augustine - were due to appear at a Miami court last
night.

FBI deputy director John Pistole said: "Today's announcement marks yet another
important victory in the war on terrorism. It is also, however, a grim reminder
of the persistent threat that exists here at home and underscores the need for
continued vigilance and cooperation."

                        Contra Costa Times (California)

                    January 5, 2000 Wednesday FINAL EDITION

TWO MORE ALGERIANS JAILED;
POTENTIAL TIES TO BOMB PLOT
ONE MAN FIRST WAS HELD AS A MATERIAL WITNESS, THE OTHER ON CHARGES OF ILLEGALLY
TRYING TO ENTER THE U.S. AT SEATTLE

BYLINE: Benjamin Weiser

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A08

LENGTH: 583 words

DATELINE: NEW YORK


NEW YORK - Two Algerians, one in Brooklyn, N.Y., and the other in Seattle, have
been arrested in the continuing investigation of a terrorist bomb plot.

The new arrests came amid indications that federal authorities are focusing
their efforts on a network of Algerians in New York, Seattle and Boston,
officials said Monday.

The Brooklyn man, Abdelwahib Hamdouche, was taken into custody Saturday night at
Kennedy International Airport as he was preparing to leave for Paris on a KLM
flight, officials said.

Hamdouche, 34, a naturalized French citizen, was held as a material witness in
the bomb plot investigation, and it is believed he was ordered to remain in
custody after a closed hearing Monday in U.S. District Court in Manhattan.

In Seattle, the authorities said they had arrested another Algerian man, Abdel
Hakim Tizegha, on charges of entering the country illegally.

He is believed to be an associate of a man charged last week in the bomb plot,
law enforcement officials said, but he has not been accused of any direct role.

The new arrests stem from what the authorities said was a bomb plot foiled in
Seattle last month after the arrest of Ahmed Ressam, an Algerian who has been
linked to a terrorist group. Ressam was charged with trying to smuggle powerful
explosives and sophisticated timing devices in a car he was driving across the
Canadian border near Seattle.

While the scope of the investigation into the plot appeared to be growing, many
details of the case remained murky Monday.

It was not clear why the authorities believed Hamdouche was a witness.

It also was not known why he had been released without being charged after he
was taken into custody Thursday during a raid in Brooklyn in which another
Algerian, Abdel Ghani, was arrested on charges of being an accomplice in the
bomb plot.

A criminal complaint accused Ghani of having knowledge of "a terrorist network
of Algerian nationals" that also included Ressam, and said he had planned to
travel with Ressam to Chicago to raise money for the group.

Federal Magistrate Judge Michael H. Dolinger refused a request by the New York
Times to open the session, and afterward he would not say why he had conducted
it in secret.

The arrest of Hamdouche, who was a roommate of Ghani, appeared to be a tactical
move by investigators seeking to compel his presence before a federal grand jury
or for questioning by federal agents.

The authorities may be hoping to see if Hamdouche can tell them anything about
Ghani, and whether he might cooperate in the investigation.

In order for Dolinger to order Hamdouche's detention, the government had to show
he was material, or critical, to the investigation, and that he was a risk to
flee or be unavailable.

No one would say if Hamdouche had been ordered held, but he did not leave the
courtroom with his defense lawyer as the hearing ended.

The new arrests indicated that law enforcement authorities are continuing to
reel in friends and associates of Ressam and Ghani, although the high degree of
secrecy imposed on the case has made it difficult to learn precisely what the
authorities suspect of each man.

The criminal complaint filed against Tizegha on Monday in federal district court
in Seattle, for example, makes no mention of the bomb plot, nor did prosecutors
discuss any link in a hearing.

But law enforcement officials who spoke on condition of anonymity said Tizegha
was believed to have been a longtime friend of Ghani.

                             273 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                The Irish Times

                             August 11, 2006 Friday

Plot aimed at US,says White House

BYLINE: Oliver Burkeman in New York

SECTION: WORLD; Terror Alert; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 504 words


US reaction The White House yesterday framed the terrorist plot, apparently
thwarted in the UK, as a direct attack on the US. American officials tightened
airport security nationwide in response to the news from London.

With officials describing the plot as the greatest terrorist threat to the US
since September 11th, George Bush called the arrests a "stark reminder" that the
country was "at war with Islamic fascists who will use any means to destroy
those of us who love freedom, to hurt our nation".

Speaking in Wisconsin, the president said: "It is a mistake to believe there is
no threat to the United States of America."

US Muslim groups criticised Mr Bush's description of the foiled plot as a "war
with Islamic fascists", saying the term could inflame anti-Muslim tensions. "We
believe this is an ill-advised term and we believe that it is counterproductive
to associate Islam or Muslims with fascism," said Nihad Awad, executive director
of the Council on American-Islamic Relations advocacy group.

Delays grew at airports after homeland security officials banned all liquids and
gels from aircraft cabins, except for baby formula and medicines.

Federal security officials were focusing on John F Kennedy airport in New York,
Dulles airport outside Washington, and Los Angeles International airport as the
probable destinations of the aircraft involved, they told state-level officials
privately.

A spokesman described officers at the US Northern Command in Colorado as "a
little bit more vigilant" than normal.

Additional armed air marshals had left the US for London yesterday, where they
were to join US-bound flights, mingling unidentified with passengers, the
homeland security department said. One of the carriers reportedly targeted in
the plot, American Airlines, cancelled several flights to London, blaming delays
at Heathrow.

US officials emphasised a suspected link with al-Qaeda. The homeland security
secretary, Michael Chertoff, called the disrupted plans "suggestive of an
al-Qaeda plot", while Robert Mueller, the FBI director, said the scheme "had the
earmarks of an al-Qaeda plot". A senior counter-terrorism official told the
Associated Press that up to 50 people might have been connected to the
conspiracy.

Alberto Gonzales, the attorney general, suggested there might be prosecutions in
the US, although there had been no arrests or evidence of plotting on American
soil.

By Wednesday, Mr Chertoff said, the potential attackers "had accumulated and
assembled the capabilities they needed, and were in the final stages of planning
for execution".

Citing the British legal system as a reason for withholding further information,
officials painted a picture of close collaboration between British and American
investigators that had been stepped up in the last two weeks. Mr Chertoff said
that was when Washington had received the first definitive clues that the plot
would target American planes specifically.

But there was still uncertainty, he said, "about whether the British have
scooped up everybody".

                               The New York Times

                             June 28, 2001 Thursday
                              Late Edition - Final

Prosecutors Promise Chilling Glimpse of Millennium Bomb Plot

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS

SECTION: Section B; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 636 words


Federal prosecutors in Manhattan opened their case against a terrorism suspect
yesterday by describing a plot by Algerians to strike American targets during
the millennium celebrations at the end of 1999.

The plan collapsed, they said, as the Algerians turned to inexperienced
expatriates to carry out a scheme to bomb the Los Angeles airport.

In his opening statement at the trial of Mokhtar Haouari, the third defendant
tried in connection with the aborted plot, Joseph F. Bianco, an assistant United
States attorney, promised a "rare and chilling glimpse into the inside world of
terrorists."

The prosecutors have not argued that Mr. Haouari, 32, a former Montreal
shopkeeper, is an important figure in that world; Mr. Bianco depicted Mr.
Haouari as a lower-level recruit to an Islamic terrorist network.

Mr. Haouari's lawyer, Daniel J. Ollen, called his client "a semiretired con man
and a two-bit thief" but insisted that there was no evidence that he was a
terrorist.

Among the four Algerians charged in the aborted plot, Mr. Haouari now stands
alone.

Mr. Bianco confirmed that the would-be bomber, Ahmed Ressam, who was convicted
in April of smuggling explosives into Washington State from Canada, would
testify against Mr. Haouari. Another man identified as an accomplice, Abdel
Ghani Meskini, has also agreed in a plea agreement to testify for the
government. The fourth person charged, Abdelmajid Dahoumane, is being held in
Algeria.

In the courtroom yesterday, the prosecutor motioned toward Mr. Haouari and told
the jury that Mr. Ressam had "turned to this man" as the plot faltered.

Mr. Haouari, a slightly built man who had been silently taking in the
proceedings through a French interpreter, cursed, in English, bringing a
smoldering admonition from Judge John F. Keenan of United States District Court.

Mr. Haouari's lawyer, Mr. Ollen, disparaged Mr. Meskini and Mr. Ressam, "both
desperate men," as liars and terrorist operatives. He noted that Mr. Ressam had
decided to cooperate with the government only as his sentencing approached. The
sentencing, originally scheduled for today, has been postponed to July 25.

Mr. Ollen was even harsher with Mr. Meskini, who pleaded guilty in March and
testified at Mr. Ressam's trial in Los Angeles. Mr. Ollen said that Mr. Meskini,
whom he called "a thief, a liar, a con man, a hustler and a punk," became a
government informer after he arrived in Montreal as a stowaway and was
threatened with deportation. But his information, Mr. Ollen said, was
fabricated.

Prosecutors have described Mr. Haouari, Mr. Meskini and Mr. Ressam as young
expatriates who supported themselves with a combination of petty crime and small
retail businesses. In the prosecutors' account, Mr. Haouari knew Mr. Meskini in
Algeria and met Mr. Ressam later through Algerian friends in Canada.

Mr. Bianco said that Mr. Ressam trained in Afghanistan at a camp for jihad
fighters and that Mr. Haouari was eager to follow. Mr. Ressam recruited the
young shopkeeper, Mr. Haouari, when other compatriots who were supposed to plan
bombings in the United States were arrested, Mr. Bianco said.

Mr. Haouari is charged with conspiracy to commit a terrorist act and with
providing cash, false immigration documents and counterfeit credit cards to
co-conspirators. He has pleaded not guilty.

The prosecution says he enlisted his old friend Mr. Meskini, who was living in
Brooklyn, to go to Seattle with money and documents and help Mr. Ressam. Mr.
Ressam was arrested by border agents, however, before reaching Seattle.

Mr. Bianco said that Mr. Ressam would recount "an evil and chilling plan
involving death, destruction and explosion" that was meant to kill hundreds at
the Los Angeles airport. He said that Mr. Ressam would also describe the
operation of terrorist training camps in Afghanistan.

                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                         MAY 4, 1999 Tuesday SF EDITION

CREMATION RATES ON THE RISE AS FAMILIES BECOME MORE MOBILE, MANY PEOPLE ARE
CHOOSING AN ALTERNATIVE TO THE TRADITIONAL BURIAL. SOME CREMATIONS CAN BE JUST
AS EXPENSIVE.

BYLINE: Dianna Marder, INQUIRER STAFF WRITER

SECTION: FEATURES MAGAZINE: LIFESTYLE; Pg. F01

LENGTH: 1739 words


When Anne Wernick died suddenly in June, her husband, Steve, recalls, the family
was torn about the proper place for a burial.

The family plot at Sunset Memorial Park in Philadelphia's Somerton section
consisted of just two grave sites - one was occupied by Anne's mother and the
other was reserved for her father.

Anne, 36, had been estranged from her husband, and he was of a different
religion. Buying plots for the two of them did not make sense, and burying her
alone - even in the same cemetery as her mother - seemed out of the question.

So instead of buying any plot at all, the family chose cremation - and buried
Anne's remains on top of her mother's casket.

Anne's family, like a growing number of Americans, needed another burial option,
and cremation made it possible. That's one reason cremation rates are on the
rise nationally and in this region.

In Pennsylvania, the rate doubled in the last decade and is expected to nearly
double again by 2010. New Jersey's cremation rate is nearly twice as high as
Pennsylvania's and still growing, according to the Cremation Association of
North America (CANA).

Cremation is being used increasingly as American society becomes more mobile.
Fewer families own family plots or know where they want to be buried.

At the beginning of this century, young couples bought cemetery plots early in
their marriages - and needed them to bury children who died in infancy. But
those patterns changed, and the emerging generation no longer has a family plot.

They may not even have family nearby. Today, the cargo holds of jets taking off
from Florida's airports are loaded with human remains - bodies of the elderly
being shipped home for burial in the northern cities of their youth. The Fort
Lauderdale airport ships more bodies than any other in the world, according to
Jim Caudill, of the Fred Hunter funeral home in Florida.

Shipping a body from Fort Lauderdale costs a minimum of $1,600, and then there
are the funeral and burial costs back home, while cremated remains can be sent
by mail. And, as Anne Wernick's situation illustrates, many cemeteries will
allow the burial of cremated remains in an already occupied grave.

For some people, cost is the primary attraction of cremation. In this region,
cremation can cost as little as $360.

The Roman Catholic Church has sanctioned cremation since 1963. In 1989, the City
of Philadelphia began using cremation rather than in-ground burial for the dead
who could not be identified or went unclaimed by their families.

Islamic and Jewish laws prohibit cremation. And many Jews, even if they are not
Orthodox, reject cremation because it hearkens to the crematoriums used by the
Nazis.

In other cultures, cremation has long been preferred. Hinduism and Buddhism
permit it. Japan has a 90 percent cremation rate. There, family and friends
often gather in another room during the cremation process and take home the
remains.

There are nonprofit memorial societies in almost every state that operate almost
as buying clubs that help families get dramatic discounts for cremations as well
as for what is known in the industry as "full-body burials." In addition, there
are for-profit cremation societies that charge slightly more.

Anne Wernick's case shows that cremation can cost just as much or more than
in-ground burial if the family selects extras. Wernick's funeral and burial cost
$7,272.40 - and only $240 of that was the cost of actual cremation.

The death-care industry has responded to the cremation trend by discouraging the
practice of scattering remains and encouraging in-ground burial of cremated
remains - a step that often raises costs dramatically.

The remains can legally be buried in backyards, but a 1997 CANA survey showed
that 40 percent of families now prefer a cemetery. So, cemeteries are selling
sites beside creeks, under rose bushes and beside old oak trees - premium
locations that go for as much as $25,000.

And the range of more elaborate cremation-related products grows every year.

There are urns that double as humidors or jewelry boxes for display on the
bureau. Lockets and other keepsake styles make it possible for each member of
the family to have part of the loved one with them always. Cast bronze urns
resemble books for the shelf or cowboy boots that can sit by the fireplace for
$1,425.

One manufacturer sells its products with an additional gift for the family - a
tree planting program carried out through the U.S. Forest Service.

For those who still prefer scattering, the cost can be enhanced as well.

A company called Hawaii Aerial Scattering offers to scatter cremated remains
over the Pacific, "for those who always had a wish to visit Hawaii."

Another company, Celebrate Life, will load cremated remains into specially
designed fireworks shells and set them off over your favorite body of water to
the strains of "Somewhere Out There" or "Wind Beneath My Wings." Only $3,200.

And the spending doesn't stop there.

The industry encourages traditional funeral services to precede cremation - with
embalming, a viewing with an open casket, a service in the church or funeral
home with the body present - all this in addition to the purchase of an urn, a
vault to bury it in, and an engraved tombstone.

Industry officials say they have a duty to make families understand that they
may later regret not adding these trappings.

"We need to remind people of the importance of ritual," James Russell, of Watts
Vaults & Monument Co. in Iowa, said at a conference of the Cremation Association
of North America in August. He tells families: "The funeral without a body is
like a wedding without a bride."

"We tell families scattering is irreversible," said Vickie Zimmerman, of the
Wilbert Co., which sells caskets and urns. Her presentation on Countering
Consumer Resistance was the focus of a workshop at the CANA convention.

The funeral industry has even found a way to make money on cremations that
happened fifty years ago. The family that scattered remains long ago can now buy
an engraved plaque on the cemetery grounds - even though the remains are not at
that location.

"The survivors need a place to go, a permanent place of remembrance," said
Christine Hunsaker, of Service Corporation International. "And we're able to
provide that."

It is not necessary to go through a traditional funeral home to arrange for
cremation.

Elva Osborn, who died in a nursing home at age 84, leaving no survivors, left
instructions that her long-time boss, attorney Stanton Oswald, make arrangements
through the Cremation Society of Pennsylvania.

"Cost was not the motivating factor for Elva," Oswald said. "She had saved
enough for a fancy funeral. She just didn't want it."

The total cost for Elva's direct cremation in December 1997, including the
scattering of her remains over the Arizona desert, was $985. It would have cost
$200 less if Elva had paid $35 to become a member of the for-profit Cremation
Society before her death.

Dale Auer, a licensed funeral director, owns the Cremation Society of
Pennsylvania, which sounds like a nonprofit but is not.

Auer's company performs about 1,200 cremations a year. And 22,000 other people
have paid his $35 membership fee to ensure their future cremations by the
company - at a $200 discount.

At the time of death, their survivors will call a toll-free number and arrange
to sign the necessary forms.

Then the body will be removed from the place of death to Auer's Harrisburg
location, where it is refrigerated during a 24-hour waiting period before it is
cremated. No casket purchase is necessary.

Auer's is not the only company that specializes in direct cremation. In
Westville, N.J., William Stiefel runs a similar business called Associated
National Cremation Service, which charges $750. As the name implies, Stiefel's
business is national and, like Auer, he offers a travel insurance program that
covers the cost of transporting the body if death occurs in another state or
overseas.

Similar direct cremation businesses are listed in most telephone directories.

"We're the same as a funeral home," Auer said, "with no high overhead."

For More Information "Reflections," a booklet explaining the Roman Catholic
Church's views on cremation, is available through the National Conference of
Catholic Bishops by calling 1-800-235-8722. The group is also on the Internet at
www.nccbuscc.org

The following are businesses listed in the Philadelphia area Yellow Pages that
specialize in simple cremation:

Cremation Society of Pennsylvania, headquarters in Harrisburg and offices in
King of Prussia. 1-800-722-8200.

Delaware Valley Cremation Society, in the former Frankford Arsenal complex in
Philadelphia. Direct cremation is $755; less for public assistance recipients.
215-569-9110.

Associated National Cremation Service, in Westville, N.J. 1-800-999-6333.
Cremation Specialists, Media. 610-532-2308.

1-800-CREMATION and 1-800-FUNERAL are separate businesses that operate referral
networks similar to the medical and dental referral services. They are aimed at
relocating retirees who have never used a funeral home in their new communities,
and out-of-state family members making arrangements for retirees.

Options raise the price Anne Wernick's funeral and burial totaled $7,727.40. Of
that, only $240 was the cost of the cremation.

The family spent $1,495 for the casket Anne's body lay in during the viewing,
$325 for a one-piece urn-vault - a relatively new device that serves as both urn
and grave liner suitable for burial - and $810 to dig the grave.

A routine, 10-line death notice that ran for two days in The Inquirer cost the
family $225 - almost as much as the crematorium's fee.

Sunset Memorial Park, where Anne was buried, is owned by Stewart Enterprises -
one of three international conglomerates that dominate the industry.

Stewart also owns the Kirk & Nice Funeral Home, which has a chapel on the
grounds of Sunset, but families are free to use any other funeral director. The
Wernick family called Dunn-Givnish in Langhorne, the firm that had handled the
funeral of Anne's mother years before.

The biggest part of Anne Wernick's funeral bill - more costly than the casket -
was the professional services fee of $1,575 charged by Dunn-Givnish.

LOAD-DATE: October 22, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Why funeral costs stay so high

                                US Official News

                              March 9, 2015 Monday

USPTO Published Patent application of Adobe Systems Incorporated titled as
"CONFIGURABLE ANIMATED SCATTER PLOTS"

LENGTH: 248  words

DATELINE: ALEXANDRIA, Va


United States Patent and Trademark Office has received an application no.
20150067566, published on March 05, 2015, by Adobe Systems Incorporated, titled
as "CONFIGURABLE ANIMATED SCATTER PLOTS" for the registration of patent.

Inventors:  Baarz; Ryan S.; (Provo, UT) ; Cowan; Cameron R.; (Provo, UT)
Assignee:  Adobe Systems Incorporated
San Jose
CA

According to the abstract released by the U.S. Patent & Trademark Office: "In
embodiments of configurable animated scatter plots, a data visualization
interface includes a charting region to display data points in a scatter plot
format. A scatter plot application is implemented to receive a request to
display the data visualization interface at a client device, and initiate a
display of the data points in a scatter plot in the charting region of the data
visualization interface at the client device. The scatter plot application is
implemented to then recursively update the display of the data points based on
sequential data for each of the data points effective to animate a progression
of the data points in the scatter plot over a time duration. The next sequential
data is obtained for each of the data points and the display of each of the data
points in the scatter plot is updated at a respective position based on the next
sequential data."

The Patent was filed on August 30, 2013 under application No. 20150067566

contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                             277 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             Windsor Star (Ontario)

                             July 8, 2006 Saturday
                                 Final Edition

Terrorist plot against N.Y. subway foiled: FBI says it has identified eight
suspects

BYLINE: Sheldon Alberts, CanWest News Service

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A6

LENGTH: 528  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


WASHINGTON - U.S. law enforcement officials on Friday said they had foiled a
terror plot to blow up commuter-train tunnels linking New York City to New
Jersey, including those leading to Lower Manhattan, the site of the Sept. 11,
2001, attacks on the World Trade Center.

At a news conference in New York, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said it
had identified eight suspects in an emerging plot apparently designed to disrupt
the U.S. economy by flooding the financial district in Lower Manhattan.

Lebanese security officials, working in concert with the FBI, have arrested a
man in Beirut identified as an al-Qaida operative and mastermind of the plan,
the officials said.

"We believe we intercepted this group early in the plotting and that in fact the
plan has largely been disrupted," said Mark Mershon, assistant director of the
FBI's New York field office. "The plotting for this attack had matured to a
point where it appeared that the individuals were about to move forward. They
were about to go to a phase where they would attempt to surveil targets,
establish a regimen of attack and acquire the resources necessary to effectuate
the attacks."

Mershon, calling the bombing plot "the real deal," said the suspects wanted to
launch a suicide bomb attack in the PATH commuter trains linking the city to its
New Jersey suburbs.

"The plan involved martyrdom, explosives and some of the tubes that connect New
Jersey to Manhattan," he said, without specifying specific targets.

The disclosure of the alleged plot came on the first anniversary of the attack
on London's Underground that killed 52 people.

It is the third alleged North American bomb plot authorities said they have
disrupted in the last two months. In June, 400 police officers conducted a
series of raids, under Canada's Anti-terrorism Act, and arrested 17 suspects in
southern Ontario. Two weeks ago, the FBI said it had stopped a plan by suspects
in Miami to blow up Chicago's Sears Tower, though several terror experts have
questioned whether those alleged plotters had posed a serious security threat.

According to the FBI's Mershon, law enforcement and intelligence agents had been
monitoring "a group of al-Qaida followers" for almost a year prior through
discussions the suspects held on Internet chat rooms.

The plot was identified by intelligence officials who determined the suspects
were using code words to describe their plans to attack tunnels, officials said.

"It had not reached anything close to being operational," said New York police
commissioner Ray Kelly. But the suspects' desire to attack commuter trains
carrying hundreds of thousands of passengers each day shows "that New York still
remains in the cross-hairs of the terrorists."

Lebanese authorities said they had arrested 31-year-old Assem Hammoud and
obtained a confession from him swearing allegiance to Osama bin Laden and
revealing his hopes to carry out the attacks in New York this October or
November.

"After questioning he confessed ... that he was planning to travel to Pakistan
for four months training and that the date for the attack was decided to be late
in 2006," the Lebanese interior ministry said in a statement.

LOAD-DATE: July 8, 2006

                             278 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                  May 20, 1995, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

Oklahoma City Building Was Target Of Plot as Early as '83, Official Says

BYLINE: By JO THOMAS and RONALD SMOTHERS

SECTION: Section 1;  Page 6;  Column 1;  National Desk

LENGTH: 1680 words


Twelve years before the Federal Building in Oklahoma City was bombed, a group of
white supremacists with close ties to the neo-Nazi group Aryan Nations drew up a
plan to bomb the same building in much the same way, according to evidence
gathered in the late 1980's by a Federal prosecutor.

The plot, conceived at the end of October 1983, called for parking a van or a
trailer in front of the Federal Building and blowing it up with rockets
detonated by a timer, the prosecutor, Steven N. Snyder, recalled in a recent
interview.

In a strange coincidence, Richard Wayne Snell, an Oklahoma man identified by a
Government witness as a participant in that plan, was executed in Arkansas this
April 19, the day of the actual bombing. He was 64 years old, called himself a
prisoner of war and had been convicted of two murders.

Although no evidence links Mr. Snell to last month's bombing or to either of the
suspects now charged with it, his impending execution had been protested by
right-wing paramilitary groups, which called him a patriot and termed the
Federal Government "the Beast."

Timothy J. McVeigh, the prime suspect in the Oklahoma City blast, has never
mentioned Mr. Snell, and Federal officials who investigated Mr. Snell on other
charges say they consider it unlikely that he or his supporters were involved.
Mr. Snyder -- who gathered evidence of the 1983 plot, including Mr. Snell's role
in it, while preparing for trial of a sedition case against a group of white
supremacists -- declined to say whether he had brought the similaries between
the 1983 plans and the bombing last month to the attention of investigators in
Oklahoma City.

Although evidence of an earlier plot does not itself demonstrate any links
between those identified as plotters then and those accused now, it does suggest
that the idea of bombing this particular Federal building could have been a
subject of discussion among small extremist groups for more than a decade.

The only links between Mr. McVeigh and people identified as the earlier
conspirators are extremely tenuous. Mr. McVeigh once got a traffic ticket in the
Fort Smith, Ark., area, where some of them lived, and several months ago his
sister Jennifer subscribed to The Patriot Report, a newsletter published there.

The details of the 1983 plan came from James D. Ellison, the founder of the
Covenant, the Sword and the Arm of the Lord, an anti-Semitic paramilitary group
that now appears to be defunct but once flourished in northern Arkansas.

Mr. Ellison's account first came to light when Mr. Snyder, an assistant United
States attorney in Fort Smith, interviewed him in preparation for his role as
the principal prosecution witness against 14 other white supremacists, including
10 charged with plotting to overthrow the Government by force. The trial was
held in 1988, and all the defendants were acquitted.

In addition to Mr. Snell, who was already on death row, the defendants included
Richard Girnt Butler, chief of the Aryan Nations, a neo-Nazi umbrella
organization for white supremacist groups that is based in Hayden Lake, Idaho;
Robert E. Miles, a former Ku Klux Klansman who headed the Mountain Church of
Jesus Christ the Saviour in Cohoctah, Mich., and Louis Ray Beam Jr., former
grand dragon of the Texas Ku Klux Klan and "ambassador at large" of the Aryan
Nations.

According to notes Mr. Snyder took before the trial, Mr. Ellison said he
attended a meeting of extremist groups in Hayden Lake in July 1983 and told them
of the death of Gordon Kahl, a member of yet another right-wing group, the Posse
Comitatus.  Mr. Kahl was a tax protester who fled North Dakota in early 1983
after a shootout with Federal agents and was subsequently shot to death in a gun
battle with agents in Smithville, Ark.

"Kahl was the catalyst that made everyone come forth and change the
organizations from thinkers to doers," Mr. Ellison said, according to Mr.
Snyder's notes.

In late-night meetings, Mr. Ellison told Mr. Snyder, the leaders at Hayden Lake
discussed how to topple the Government, using as a sourcebook "The Turner
Diaries," an extremist novel that envisions the Government's overthrow by
rightists who then systematically kill Jews and blacks. Mr. Ellison told Mr.
Snyder that he himself had volunteered to assassinate Federal officials in
Arkansas.

According to Mr. Snyder's notes, Mr. Ellison told him that the Ellison
organization had discussed plans to bomb Federal buildings and the Dallas office
of a Jewish organization.

At the 1988 trial of the 14 white supremacists, Mr. Ellison testified that in
October 1983, Mr. Snell and Steve Scott, an associate, "asked me to design a
rocket launcher that could be used to destroy these buildings from a distance."

"On one of the trips when I was with Wayne," Mr. Ellison said of Mr. Snell, "he
took me to some of the buildings and asked me to go in the building and check
the building out. This kind of thing."

And before the trial, Mr. Ellison told the prosecutor that at Mr. Snell's
request he had entered the Federal Building in Oklahoma City to gauge what it
would take to damage or destroy it.

Afterward, he testified in court, he made preliminary sketches and drawings.
Rocket launchers were to be "placed in a trailer or a van so that it could be
driven up to a given spot, parked there, and a timed detonating device could be
triggered so that the driver could walk away and leave the vehicle set in
position, and he would have time to clear the area before any of the rockets
launched."

"And I was asked to make it so it would fit in either a trailer or a van or a
panel truck," Mr. Ellison continued.

"Ellison," Mr. Snyder recalled, "said that Snell was bitter toward the
Government because of the I.R.S. And I think these were agents from the Oklahoma
City office, and they had taken him to court, and his property had been seized
by the F.B.I. and other agents in a raid. But you can't be sure about any of
this, because a Federal raid, to a lot of these people, is any time the postman
brings the mail."

In 1984, a black state trooper stopped Mr. Snell for a traffic violation near De
Queen, Ark. Mr. Snell shot the trooper, Louis Bryant, as he approached the
vehicle, then shot him again as he lay on the ground, killing him. Mr. Snell
always contended afterward that he had killed the officer in self-defense.

Mr. Snell fled and was chased to Broken Bow, Okla., where he was wounded in a
gun battle with the authorities before he was subdued. In his car, the police
found a gun that had been used the previous year in the robbery and murder of
William Stumpp, a Texarkana pawnbroker. Mr. Snell was convicted of both murders
and sentenced to death in the Stumpp case.

Mr. Snell always denied that murder, but Mr. Ellison said at the sedition trial
that Mr. Snell had killed Mr. Stumpp because he believed -- wrongly, as it
turned out -- that Mr. Stumpp was Jewish.

Mr. Ellison himself became a Government witness after plenty of trouble with the
law. On April 19, 1985 -- 10 years to the day before the Oklahoma City bombing
-- a heavily armed force of 200 state and Federal officers surrounded his remote
mountain compound on the shores of Bull Shoals Lake in northern Arkansas. A
four-day siege ended when he was persuaded to surrender by Robert G. Millar, who
is still the spiritual leader of an armed apocalypic sect in Elohim City, a
rural compound near Muldrow, Okla.

Three months later, on July 17, Mr. Ellison was convicted of racketeering
charges. And two months after that, he was sentenced to 20 years in prison. The
following year, he agreed to become a Government witness.

The defense at the sedition trial contended that Mr. Ellison had farbricated the
conspiracy. Having listened for seven weeks, an all-white jury acquitted all the
defendants.  Afterward, one juror announced that she had fallen in love with one
of the defendants and planned to marry him.

After the trial, Mr. Ellison went to prison, entered the Federal witness
protection program and eventually ended up living on parole in Jasper, Fla.,
midway between Tallahassee and Jacksonville. He later left the witness program,
finished his parole on April 21, two days after the Oklahoma City bombing, and
was last seen that day in Jasper with two women, driving a car with Oklahoma
plates.

From his prison cell in Varner, Ark., Mr. Snell began publishing a periodic
newsletter, The Seekers, which told of the "war to establish righteousness," a
war in which he considered himself a P.O.W.

The Militia of Montana, which rallied to Mr. Snell's cause in the March issue of
its publication, Taking Aim, reminded its readers that his execution was set for
April 19.

"If this date does not ring a bell for you then maybe this will jog your
memory," the newsletter said. "1.  April 19, 1775: Lexington burned; 2. April
19, 1943: Warsaw burned; 3. April 19, 1992: The fed's attempted to raid Randy
Weaver, but had their plans thwarted when concerned citizens arrived on the
scene with supplies for the Weaver family totally unaware of what was to take
place; 4. April 19, 1993: The Branch Davidians burned; 5. April 19, 1995:
Richard Snell will be executed -- unless we act now!!!"

The action suggested in a note written by Mary Snell, his wife, and published by
the newsletter, was to flood the Arkansas Governor's office with letters.

As his execution approached, Mr. Snell was frequently visited by Mr. Millar, who
shared Mr. Snell's final hours, witnessed his execution and took his body to
Elohim City the next day for burial.

Mr. Snell watched televised reports of the Oklahoma City bombing on the very day
he died, Mr. Millar said, and was appalled by what he saw.

Mr. Snell's last words, however, were threatening. He addressed them to Gov. Jim
Guy Tucker just as he was strapped to a gurney for execution by lethal
injection.

"Governor Tucker, look over your shoulder," witnesses quote him as saying.
"Justice is coming. I wouldn't trade places with you or any of your cronies.
Hail the victory. I am at peace."

LOAD-DATE: May 22, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

the Oklahoma City bombing, was identified by James D. Ellison, below, as a
conspirator in a virtually identical plot 12 years ago. (Photographs by
Associated Press)

                             280 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                   Inland Valley Daily Bulletin (Ontario, CA)

                             August 20, 2006 Sunday

Airport world tough - again

BYLINE: By Mason Stockstill, Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 641 words


ONTARIO - It's a new world at the airport --again.

National Guard troops with guns searching passengers. Increasingly longer lines
to check baggage. And -- gasp --no bottled water.

Ever since the nation's terror alert was raised Aug. 10 following a foiled
terror plot involving flights from the United Kingdom to the United States,
passengers at airports here have had to readjust themselves to a new set of
standards for air travel. Photo Galleries:
  Ontario International Airport on High Alert after Terror Plot
  Terror plot defeated
  LAX on High Alert, Friday 08/11

Related Articles:
  At ONT, travelers put up with more security
  New airport rules will have varying effects on businesses
  British foil plot to kill thousands in jetliners over Atlantic
"All we have is a planning forecast of seven to 30 days," said Maj. Dan Markert
of the California National Guard, adding that individual airports have most of
the say on how long troops will remain.

The National Guard is assisting with security efforts at seven airports
throughout the state, including Ontario International Airport. The other
airports are in Los Angeles, San Francisco, San Jose, San Diego, Orange County
and Burbank.

Likewise, there's no official timetable for how long the new restrictions on
liquids and gels in carry-on baggage will remain in place.

The Transportation Security Administration has altered the ban several times --
for example, non-prescription liquid medicines are now allowed, as long as it's
less than four ounces.

The restrictions have prompted more travelers to check baggage on their flights,
rather than simply carrying everything they need with them into the cabin.

Southwest Airlines doesn't have an official tally, but spokeswoman Whitney
Eichinger said passengers checking bags are up about 25 percent.

"That's been the feel from our groups who are working most closely with our
bags," Eichinger said. Southwest is the largest carrier in terms of passengers
at ONT.

Because of long lines to check in baggage and the potential for more scrutiny
during the passenger screening process, airlines are advising travelers to
arrive at the airport two hours prior to their departures.

The new airport procedures are reminiscent of the changes across the country and
the world in the weeks and months following the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist
attacks.

Prior to 9/11, passenger screening ranged from strict to nonexistent, and people
without plane tickets could walk freely throughout airports' terminal and gate
areas.

But it's more than just the higher level of security that's changed in the
aftermath of the recent arrests in Britain. Many travel industries are now
taking steps to pick up the slack in terms of what travelers can and can't bring
with them.

For example, Avis rental cars at 25 U.S. airports now come with free packets of
toothpaste and mouthwash --which many travelers had to discard at airports after
they were banned in carry-on bags.

"It's the least we can do after a long day of travel and losing products that
you've paid for," said Tonia Elrod, a spokeswoman for Procter & Gamble, the
Cincinnati-based maker of household products that donated the items.

Additionally, some high-end hotel companies are adding similar complimentary
items to their usual offerings of shampoo and soap.

Wyndham Hotels & Resorts, for example, began giving customers free bottled water
and contact lens solution. Omni Hotels has stocked up on cosmetics, including
hair gel and moisturizers.

"We were saying, 'Our guests are going to be arriving at the end of a very
stressful day,' " said Omni spokeswoman Christine Connelly. "In terms of the
cost, it's not about the money. It's about doing the right thing."

The Associated Press contributed to this report.

Mason Stockstill can be reached by e-mail at mason.stockstill@dailybulletin.com,
or by phone at (909) 483-9354.

LOAD-DATE: August 22, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                      Copyright 2006 MediaNews Group, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                             281 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                   USA TODAY

                          December 22, 2010 Wednesday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Follow the Israeli model

BYLINE: Asra Q. Nomani

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8A

LENGTH: 445 words


America is at war in Afghanistan and Iraq, but we face a battle front closer to
home: our airports and airliners.

In 1998, after a foiled plot by 9/11 mastermind Khalid Sheikh Mohammed to bomb
U.S.-bound jets, Osama bin Laden urged Muslims to down U.S. and Israeli jets in
"pitiless and violent" attacks. Since then, we've had a series of
al-Qaeda-inspired plots, including three schemes against Los Angeles and New
York airports, "shoe bomber" Richard Reid, the Christmas 2009 "underwear bomber"
and the recent air-cargo bomb attempt. And, of course, the plot we will never
forget, on Sept. 11, 2001.

Sadly, to me, as an American Muslim, there is one common denominator to these
plots: The perpetrators are all Muslim.

As a nation, we need to be less politically correct and more pragmatic in
assessing threats. It's a painful choice, but we should follow the Israeli model
and allow profiling based on religion, race, ethnicity, gender, national origin
and age, as part of a wider screening strategy that includes behavioral
profiling. Profiling makes sense whether it involves screening white Christian
extremists to find those intent on bombing abortion clinics or Muslims to find
al-Qaeda operatives targeting airliners.

The Justice Department has said that because of the "incalculably high stakes
involved" in preventing "catastrophic events," such as jet attacks, airport
screeners "may consider race, ethnicity, and other relevant factors."

There are several ways to implement this strategy:

*Ensure that profiling is limited to threat assessment, not harassment or
discrimination.

*Have passengers input into a database vital information -- Social Security,
driver's license or passport numbers -- when they make an airline reservation to
clearly establish identities, travel patterns and, when possible, other elements
as part of pre-screening. Let fliers voluntarily add more data, such as race,
religion, ethnicity and national origin, to the database. Let security officials
access that database for use in secondary screening at the airport.

*Train a larger cadre of professional screeners in identity and behavioral
profiling so they can respectfully use both to identify people for extra
screening.

With an honest national conversation about the threat from a small, radicalized
group of Muslims, I believe we can marginalize and defeat their interpretation
of Islam. And, I hope, soon see a day when Muslims will no longer be a part of
the threat profile.

Asra Q. Nomani, a former Wall Street Journal reporter who covered airlines, is
the author of Standing Alone: An American Woman's Struggle for the Soul of
Islam. She teaches journalism at Georgetown University.

LOAD-DATE: December 22, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: NEWSPAPER

                             282 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                    August 26, 1993, Thursday, FINAL EDITION

Sheik indicted in bombing

BYLINE: Bruce Frankel

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 366 words

DATELINE: NEW YORK


Muslim Sheik Omar Abdel-Rahman was charged Wednesday with leading the terrorist
organization that bombed the World Trade Center.

He also is accused of plotting to blow up the United Nations and conspiring to
kill Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak.

The sweeping 30-page federal indictment comes six months after the Feb. 26 Trade
Center blast that killed six and injured more than 1,000.

It also charged imprisoned El Sayyid Nosair in the plots, and charged him again
in the 1990 assassination of militant Rabbi Meir Kahane.

Nosair, acquitted on state murder charges in the slaying, is serving a 22-year
sentence on related weapons charges.

The indictment charges 15 people - including Abdel-Rahman and three other new
suspects - with participating in a terrorist cell that has carried out bombings
and murders and plotted against government and military installations in the USA
and abroad since 1989.

Arraignment is scheduled today in Manhattan under heavy police protection. The
indictment says Abdel-Rahman:

"Provided instruction regarding whether particular acts of terrorism were
permissible or forbidden.

"Served as a mediator" of internal disputes.

Ordered others to find out if authorities had infiltrated the terrorist
organization.

"This is the closest I've ever seen to using the criminal justice system to
indict a religious group for religious teachings," said Ron Kuby, a lawyer in
William Kunstler's office, which is representing two suspects and represented
Nosair at trial.

Abdel-Rahman's immigration lawyer, Barbara Nelson, said there's no basis for the
indictment.

Rahman, 55, has been held in a federal prison since an immigration judge ordered
him deported in July.

"The bigger the balloon, the easier it's going to be to puncture," said Kenneth
Wasserman, whose client Clement Rodney Hampton-El is charged with supplying
firearms, explosives and expertise.

Experts say the new indictment is based on hundreds of hours of tape recordings
made by informant Emad Salem.

"The tapes pretty clearly show that the sheik had command and control of the
organization's plans to kill Mubarak," says Vincent Cannistraro, ex-CIA
counterterrorism operations chief.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO, color, AP

See related story; 03A

                      Copyright 1993 Gannett Company, Inc.


                             283 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                The New York Post

                             April 10, 2012 Tuesday

Family's grief over treacherous 'plot'

BYLINE: Jennifer Gould Keil and Kieran Crowley

SECTION: All Editions; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 282 words


The grief-stricken family of a Wall Street executive was stunned after his death
to find that the cemetery plot he had bought for himself 29 years ago was
occupied.

Richard Schultz's widow and children were told that his plot at a Long Island
cemetery had accidentally been sold by their synagogue to someone else.

"It was a weird, surreal experience to have him die, and this just made
everything stranger," said Schultz's daughter Cynthia Hornig.

Now, her mother, widow Judith Schultz, is seeking $25,000 from the synagogue.
She filed suit in Suffolk State Supreme Court on Friday.

Schultz, the founder, president and CEO of Triad Securities, had the foresight
to buy four adjoining plots in 1983 for $1,800 from the Dix Hills Jewish Center,
which had deeds to the plots located at the New Montefiore Cemetery.

He buried his mother in one plot after her death in 1994 and his father in
another in 2006 - and thought the two remaining plots would be kept vacant for
him and his wife.

But when Schultz, who is from Manhattan, died of cancer in January, family
members found the spaces had been sold to other people.

"They said we had no plots," Hornig said.

"My father planned to rest in all eternity next to his wife and his parents.
Instead that space beside my grandparents was occupied by strangers."

The synagogue offered another plot for Schultz, but it was a distance away and
near the Southern State Parkway, she said.

"Not only did the synagogue not help, but they were downright rude - and my
mother was a founding member of the synagogue!" Hornig said.

Schultz's family eventually found another plot in the same cemetery, next to
Judith Schultz's parents.

LOAD-DATE: April 10, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Taken: Cynthia Hornig with dad Richard Schultz.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             284 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           The Mercury (South Africa)

                           September 15, 2009 Tuesday
                                   E2 Edition

Trio get life in jail for plot to follow up 9/11

SECTION: Pg. 5

LENGTH: 259 words


LONDON: Three British Muslims were sentenced yesterday to life in jail for
plotting to blow up transatlantic airliners with liquid bombs in
al-Qaeda-inspired suicide attacks on the scale of September 11.

Judge Richard Henriques said the planned "terrorist outrage" was "the most grave
and wicked conspiracy ever proven within this jurisdiction", as he passed
sentence at the top-security Woolwich Crown Court in southeast London.

"The intention was to perpetrate a terrorist outrage that would stand alongside
the events of September 11, 2001, in history," he said.

Ringleader Abdulla Ahmed Ali, 28, was sentenced to life imprisonment with a
minimum 40-year term.

The plot's "quartermaster" Assad Sarwar, 29, must spend a minimum of 36 years in
jail, while fellow plotter Tanvir Hussain, 28, said to have been Ali's
right-hand man, must spend at least 32 years behind bars.

The plot, foiled in August, 2006, triggered the wide-ranging rules now in place
on carrying liquids aboard commercial aircraft. The counter-terrorism operation
to foil the plot was the biggest in Britain, costing £35 million (R440m).

Henriques said: "I'm satisfied that there is every likelihood that this plot
would have succeeded but for the intervention of the police and the security
service.

"A massive loss of life would almost certainly have resulted."

The plotters targeted seven flights from London's Heathrow airport to New York,
Washington, Chicago, San Francisco, Toronto and Montreal.

The evidence included 26 000 exhibits. Police examined 14 000 gigabytes of data.
- Sapa-AFP
