                                   USA TODAY

                    October 16, 1998, Friday, FINAL EDITION

WEEKEND PREVIEW

BYLINE: Eddie Timanus

SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 13C

LENGTH: 2019 words


Times p.m. Eastern

No. 1 Ohio State (5-0) vs. Minnesota (2-3)

* Time/TV:

 Noon/ESPN.  * Line: Ohio State by 38 1/2.  * Turf:
Grass.

 * The stakes: Homecoming weekend in Columbus finds one
Ohio State alumnus, Minnesota coach Glen Mason, hoping to spoil
the party as the Buckeyes' quest for the Fiesta Bowl continues.


* Plots and subplots:A supreme defensive effort will be
required to keep Minnesota in the game. Gophers safety Tyrone
Carter will have a busy day helping against tailback Michael Wiley
and in coverage against wide receivers Dee Miller and David Boston.
Minnesota's offensive line is overmatched against Buckeyes linebackers
Andy Katzenmoyer and Jerry Rudzinski.

No. 2 UCLA (4-0) vs. No. 12 Oregon (5-0)

* Time/TV: 3:30/ABC.  * Line:UCLA by 10 1/2. * Turf: Grass.

 * The stakes: Huge. After their triumph in Tucson, Ariz.,
the Bruins return home to meet the Ducks, another unbeaten Pac-10
rival, in this collision of two of the USA's top three scoring
teams.

 * Plots and subplots: UCLA quarterback Cade McNown's 54%
completion rate has raised eyebrows, but he has made plays when
needed. Oregon quarterback Akili Smith has been on fire, as has
tailback Reuben Droughns. UCLA tailback Jermaine Lewis has been
reinstated by coach Bob Toledo. A high-scoring affair could turn
on key turnover. The Bruins' defense has 11 takeaways to the Ducks'
seven.

No. 3 Kansas State (5-0) vs. Oklahoma State (2-3)

* Time/TV: 3:30/ABC.  * Line:Kansas State by 21.
 * Turf: Artificial.

 * The stakes:The Wildcats, the new Big 12 North favorites,
continue their league slate against the struggling but dangerous
Cowboys.

 * Plots and subplots: An intriguing matchup between the
Wildcats' attack and the Cowboys' defense, both predicated on
speed. Oklahoma State linebacker Kenyatta Wright and his group
of effective run stoppers must pay attention to running back Eric
Hickson while containing quarterback Michael Bishop. Cowboys quarterback
Tony Lindsay and running back Nathan Simmons must establish a
ground game.

No. 5 Florida (5-1) vs. Auburn (1-4)

* Time/TV: 3:30/CBS.  * Line:Florida by 20. * Turf: Grass.

 * The stakes:Life in the Southeastern Conference gets
no easier for the faltering Tigers as they visit the Swamp, where
the Gators haven't lost a conference game since Auburn's visit
in 1994.

 * Plots and subplots:Injuries to starting quarterback
Jesse Palmer (broken collarbone) and tailback Terry Jackson (ankle)
will require Doug Johnson and Robert Gillespie, respectively,
to step up for the Gators. Coach Terry Bowden is considering Florida-like
quarterback shuffle with Ben Leard and Gabe Gross in effort to
jump-start Auburn's stagnant offense. No. 6 Virginia (5-0)
at No. 25 Georgia Tech (4-1)

* Time/TV: 3:30/ABC.  * Line:Virginia by 2 1/2.
 * Turf: Grass.

 * The stakes:Tech's victory at North Carolina State set
up this showdown with the Cavaliers for the outright Atlantic
Coast Conference lead.

 * Plots and subplots:This clash of strength features the
Yellow Jackets, the conference's top-scoring team, against the
Cavaliers, the stingiest scoring defense. Pivotal matchup pits
Tech quarterback Joe Hamilton and receiver Dez White against strong
safety Anthony Poindexter and UVa's tough secondary. The role
of running back Phillip Rogers will increase for the Yellow Jackets
with the loss of Charles Wiley to a season-ending knee injury.
The Cavaliers will try to control tempo with running back Thomas
Jones, the ACC's leading rusher.

No. 7 Florida State (5-1) vs. Clemson (2-4) * Time/TV:
6/ESPN2.  * Line:Florida State by 28.  * Turf: Grass.

 * The stakes:Though no longer invincible, the Seminoles
have not lost an Atlantic Coast Conference game at home since
joining the league. The Tigers, struggling but coming off a win,
will give it a shot.

 * Plots and subplots:Quarterback Chris Weinke has grown
more comfortable with the Seminoles' offense, making use of wide
receiver Peter Warrick. Clemson quarterback Brandon Streeter also
is coming off his best game against Maryland, but FSU's swarming
defense will pose more problems. The Tigers' defense is averaging
3.5 sacks.

No. 8 Nebraska (5-1) vs. Kansas (2-4) * Time/TV: 7/FSN.
 * Line:Nebraska by 35.  * Turf: Artificial.

 * The stakes:Catching Nebraska on the rebound in Lincoln
is a tough assignment for the Jayhawks, but they nearly upended
'Huskers-killer Texas A&M two weeks ago.

 * Plots and subplots:Nebraska's rushing game has slipped
to an unfamiliar third place in the Big 12. Quarterback Bobby
Newcombe and I-back DeAngelo Evans seek improved production against
a run defense that ranks last in the conference. Quarterback Zac
Wegner and his wide receiver tandem of Harrison Hill and Termaine
Fulton are Kansas' best chance to keep pace.

No. 9 Wisconsin (6-0) at Illinois (2-4) * Time/TV: Noon/ESPN2.
 * Line:Wis. by 20 1/2.  * Turf: Artificial.

 * The stakes:The Badgers try to keep pace in the Big Ten
as they visit rebuilding Illinois.

 * Plots and subplots:Keeping Wisconsin tailback Ron Dayne
from scoring is hard enough, but quarterback Mike Samuel has seven
rushing touchdowns to Dayne's six. The Illini must make Samuel
beat them with his arm, but wide receiver Chris Chambers is reliable
as well for the Badgers. Quarterback Kurt Kittner and running
back Rocky Harvey, both freshmen, continue on-the-job training
in Illinois' offense.

No. 10 Virginia Tech (5-0) vs. Temple (0-6) * Time: 1.
 * Line:Virginia Tech by 35 1/2.  * Turf: Grass.

 * The stakes: The Owls and next week's trip to Alabama-Birmingham
stand between the Hokies and a Halloween showdown with West Virginia.

 * Plots and subplots: The Hokies aren't flashy, but the
formula of strong defense and special teams is working again for
coach Frank Beamer. Nick Sorensen will start at quarterback for
Tech, which will run a low-risk attack with running back Lamont
Pegues. Temple will try to counter with running back Stacey Mack.

No. 11 Penn State (4-1) vs. Purdue (3-3) * Time/TV: 3:30/ABC.
 * Line:Penn State by 8 1/2.  * Turf: Grass.

 * The stakes:The Nittany Lions' defense gets another test
as the Boilermakers and quarterback Drew Brees blow into Happy
Valley.

 * Plots and subplots:Brees' arm was, remarkably, still
attached last week after a record-setting 83 pass attempts. But
success hinges on Purdue establishing running back J. Crabtree's
running game to offset Penn State's pass rush led by linebacker
Brandon Short and defensive end Brad Scioli. .

No. 13 Texas A&M (5-1) at Baylor (2-3) * Time: 7. * Line:Texas A&M by 6 1/2.  *
Turf: Grass.

 * The stakes:For the second time this season, Baylor hosts
the team that toppled No. 2 the previous week. The Aggies hope
to avoid North Carolina State's fate.

 * Plots and subplots:The Aggies' newest weapon, fullback
Ja'Mar Toombs, will be asked for another big performance to exploit
the Bears' run defense. Baylor must counter with tailback Darrell
Bush to control the ball.

No. 14 Georgia (4-1) vs. Vanderbilt (0-5) * Time: 12:30.
 * Line:Georgia by 27 1/2.  * Turf: Grass.

* The stakes: The winless Commodores could be in for a
long day as the Bulldogs look to get the offense back in high
gear.

 * Plots and subplots:Georgia coach Jim Donnan plans to
address the ground-game problems after a poor showing against
Tennessee. Look for big numbers from running back Olandis Gary
against the Commodores' defense. Vandy's offense has fared little
better with freshmen starting at quarterback, David Wallace, and
tailback, Rodney Williams.

No. 16 Arkansas (5-0) at South Carolina (1-5) * Time: 1.
 * Line:Arkansas by 7.  * Turf: Grass.

 * The stakes:The Razorbacks, in the Southeastern Conference
West driver's seat, visit the hard-luck Gamecocks, trying to get
over the hump for a conference victory.

 * Plots and subplots:South Carolina has lost three games
by five or fewer points. The Gamecocks will need more touchdowns
from a rushing attack led by Troy Hambrick to get over the hump.
But Arkansas defends the run well. The Razorbacks use running
backs Chris Chukwuma and Madre Hill to keep the defense rested.

No. 17 Arizona (5-1) at Oregon State (4-2)

* Time: 4.  * Line:Arizona by 8 1/2.  * Turf:
Artificial.

 * The stakes:The Wildcats will need a lot of help to reach
the Rose Bowl but still could play in a major bowl. Oregon State
needs two more wins to end its 27-year string of losing records.

 * Plots and subplots:The Wildcats' reliance on quarterbacks
Ortege Jenkins and Keith Smith has led to problems picking up
ground yardage when needed. Arizona will prevail if running back
Trung Canidate gets rolling early, but Oregon State defensive
end Inoke Breckterfield won't make it easy. Beavers quarterback
Terrance Bryant has produced more than 1,200 yards but only four
touchdown passes.

No. 18 Colorado (5-1) vs. No. 23 Texas Tech (6-0)

* Time: 1:30.  * Line:Colorado by 5 1/2.  *
Turf: Artificial.

 * The stakes: Another week, another unbeaten Big 12 opponent
coming to Boulder. Both teams will have much to say about who
meets in the conference final.

 * Plots and subplots:After a tough outing against K-State,
Colorado quarterback Mike Moschetti hopes to regain his timing
against a Tech defense strong at stopping the run. Red Raiders
running back Ricky Williams always draws attention, but the Buffs
must be aware of quarterback Rob Peters and his top wide receiver,
Donnie Hart.

No. 19 Missouri (4-1) vs. Oklahoma (2-3)

* Time: 2.  * Line:Missouri by 16 1/2.  * Turf:
Grass.

 * The stakes:The Tigers try to keep pace in the Big 12
North. The Sooners and embattled coach John Blake must regroup
from a demolition by archrival Texas.

 * Plots and subplots:Tailback Devin West and quarterback
Corby Jones pace Missouri's ground game, which ranks second nationally
behind Air Force. Oklahoma running back De'Mond Parker needs 33
yards rushing to move into fifth place in school history.

No. 21 LSU (3-2) vs. Kentucky (4-2)

* Time/TV: 9/ESPN2.  * Line:LSU by 10.  * Turf:
Grass.

 * The stakes:The Tigers look to end their two-game slide.
The Wildcats need a quality win to enhance their bowl credentials.

 * Plots and subplots: Quarterback Herb Tyler's efficient
passing gives LSU's offense more balance than last year, when
tailback Kevin Faulk and Co. ran roughshod over the Wildcats.
Kentucky quarterback Tim Couch counters with his aerial assault
featuring wide receiver Craig Yeast and using running back Anthony
White (44 catches) as his possession receiver.

No. 22 Syracuse (3-2) at Boston College (3-2) * Time/TV:
3:30/CBS.  * Line:Syracuse by 13.  * Turf: Artificial.

 * The stakes:BC must win to stay in the Big East race.
The Orangemen, entertaining major-bowl thoughts, can't afford
another stumble.

 * Plots and subplots: Syracuse quarterback Donovan McNabb
will be without wide receiver Quinton Spotwood (knee) for the
remainder of the season, leaving Kevin Johnson as his top deep
threat. BC running back Mike Cloud and quarterback Scott Mutryn
can produce against Syracuse's defense, but the Eagles must play
a turnover-free game.

No. 24 Tulane (4-0) vs. Louisville (3-3) * Time/TV: 3:30/FSN.
 * Line:Tulane by 16.  * Turf: Artificial.

 * The stakes:Having dethroned Southern Miss, the Green
Wave are in fine shape atop the Conference USA, but obstacles
remain.

 * Plots and subplots: This game's marquee matchup of quarterbacks
features Chris Redman's prolific aerial assault for Louisville
against Shaun King's controlled efficiency for Tulane.

Rest of the Top 25No. 4 Tennessee, No. 15 W. Virginia and
No. 20 Notre Dame are idle.

                     The Journal Record (Oklahoma City, OK)

                            November 5, 2013 Tuesday

Public Service Company of Oklahoma sues to purchase BNSF plot

BYLINE: D. Ray Tuttle

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 516  words


Public Service Company of Oklahoma plans to spend $17 million on revamping and
expanding its downtown electric substation to meet future power demands of the
growing Brady District and northwest downtown.

However, the utility has been stymied because its neighbor will not sell a
parcel of land to allow for growth.

PSO, a unit of Ohio-based American Electric Power, operates the substation at
First Street between Cheyenne Avenue and Denver Avenue. The half-acre plot is
owned by Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railroad. The landlocked electric utility
has reached out to BNSF to purchase the plot.

So far Burlington Northern has not been willing to sell, according to the
petition, with the railroad rebuffing the utility's repeated requests.  On
Friday, PSO filed a lawsuit in Tulsa County District Court seeking to force the
railroad to sell the plot.

"PSO has made diligent and repeated efforts to acquire the property," according
to the petition. "It is necessary for a public purpose that PSO exercise the
right of eminent domain to appropriate and acquire fee simple title to such
lands by condemnation. "

The Fort Worth, Texas-based railroad told PSO that the railroad is not required
to sell to the utility, said Toney D. Foster, an attorney with the
Claremore-based law firm of Taylor, Burrage, Foster, Mallett, Downs, Ramsey and
Russell, in an interview with The Journal Record. The law firm represents PSO.

The BNSF claims that PSO does not fall into the railroad's narrow criteria in
order to sell, Foster said.

"They claim they have a limited right of way and need that land for railroad
purposes," Foster said.

Filing a lawsuit was the last option for PSO, Foster said.

BNSF continues to evaluate the safety and operational effects of a large
electrical substation within 50 feet of its operation, said Joe Faust,
spokesman.

"BNSF looks forward to reaching a mutually agreeable solution with PSO regarding
this project," Faust said.

PSO expected to begin the expansion in January 2016, said Stan Whiteford, PSO
spokesman. The project would last through December 2018.

"It is a significant redesign and rebuild of that substation," Whiteford said.
"It would give us improved reliability downtown and account for continued load
growth in the area. "

The expansion would add another transformer to accommodate the anticipated
demand for power, Whiteford said. A transformer steps the power down from a
transmission level of thousands of volts to distribution-level voltage, or
household-level voltage, of 120 volts.

There is a need for a substation expansion, Whiteford said, because of the
continued development in the area.

"PSO wants to get out ahead of the forecasts and be able to handle local growth
happening in that area - buildings, new hotels being built and being planned,
new living spaces," Whiteford said.  "There is just so much new growth being
anticipated in the area. "

The case was assigned to Tulsa County District Court Judge Mark Barcus.

http://www.journalrecord.com/be-the-first-to-know/ Click here for more from this
resource.

                              Chicago Daily Herald

                             March 29, 2011 Tuesday
                                   D1 Edition

DuPage County in 60 seconds

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 303 words


You can rent a garden plot:

Community garden plots are available for rent at Oakhurst Forest Preserve, 1680
Fifth Ave., on the east side of Aurora. The 5-acre site features 250 plots that
are available to community gardeners each growing season. The season rental fee
is $15 per plot, with no limit on the number of plots that can be rented. A map
is available at foxvalleyparkdistrict.org. Plot reservations are taken at the
Eola Community Center, 555 S. Eola Road, or by calling (630) 851-8990.

Scholarships available:

To help architecture students of today become the designers of tomorrow, the
Northeast Illinois Chapter of The American Institute of Architects is offering
three scholarships of up to $1,000 each. Applicants must be U.S. citizens and
enrolled for the 2011-12 school year in an accredited architecture program at a
school within the National Architectural Accrediting Board's West Central or
East Central regions. They also must be permanent residents of the chapter's
service area, which includes DuPage, Kane and Kendall counties, as well as Cook
County, except for the area within the city limits of Chicago and the areas
south of I-55 or east of the Edens Expressway. Past winners are ineligible.
Applications and two letters of recommendation must be submitted by 5 p.m. April
29. Application forms are available at www.aianei.org/Scholarships.html.

Woodridge man enters plea:

Michael Gardner of Woodridge pleaded not guilty Monday to felony charges of
false impersonation of an attorney and theft by deception. Gardner, 53, is
accused of swindling thousands of dollars from a Naperville family by acting as
their attorney. His next court appearance is scheduled for 9 a.m. May 2. Gardner
faces up to five years in prison if convicted of the most serious charge, which
also is punishable by probation.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Michael Gardner

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             309 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                              The Washington Post

                             August 13, 2006 Sunday
                                 Final Edition

Terrorists or Teens?

BYLINE: Dahlia Lithwick

SECTION: Outlook; B02

LENGTH: 1110 words


At first blush, it's just outrageous. Across the country, teenagers are being
tried as terrorists for plots to shoot their enemies in the lunchroom. In many
cases, they have been charged under terrorism laws intended to keep us safe from
al-Qaeda, not from anguished Goths with dreams of grandeur.

Prosecutors say that angry young men amassing guns and bombs really is
terrorism; that the students killed in 1999 at Columbine High School are as much
terrorism victims as the workers killed in the World Trade Center in 2001.
Defense lawyers say these prosecutions are overblown; they allow prosecutors to
claim  huge victories against terrorism when they've just put a pimply misfit
behind bars.

As is often the case, the truth lies somewhere in the middle. There is a
difference between terrorists and teenagers, and using stiff anti-terrorism laws
to ratchet up penalties and punish juveniles as adults obscures an important
distinction. As Michael Greenberger, a law professor at the University of
Maryland, recently told USA Today, charging troubled teenagers as terrorists
"cheapens the war on terror." There's a profound difference between
fundamentalist Islamic terrorism, domestic terrorism such as Timothy McVeigh's
bombing in Oklahoma City and juvenile plots to shoot the cool kids in study
hall. Charging all three classes of offenders as terrorists only serves to blur
the already porous legal definition of terrorism. It suggests that the lonely
kid who posts bomb threats on his MySpace page is the moral equivalent of
Mohamed Atta.

But that lonely kid can prove to be a lethal kid, and, as Columbine's Eric
Harris and Dylan Klebold, and D.C. sniper Lee Boyd Malvo, proved, the fact that
you're in high school hardly matters when you've fatally shot someone. While
it's clear that we shouldn't be using terrorism laws to prosecute teenage death
threats, the striking parallels between fundamentalist terrorists and alleged
school shooters offer  intriguing insight into the policy strategies for
addressing both.

The annual crop of Columbine wannabes flourished yet again this year. And where
they once may have been charged with conspiracy or attempted assault, they are
now charged as terrorists. Which probably rules out college.

In April  --  timed, as ever, to coincide with the anniversary of the Columbine
killings  --  a string of disturbing plots emerged: Four New Jersey students,
ages 14 to 16, were charged with first-degree terrorism  on suspicion of
plotting to massacre at least 17 people during lunchtime at Winslow Township
High School on April 20, seven years to the day after Columbine. None of the
students had been able to obtain weapons. In Kansas City, Mo., two 17-year-olds
were charged with making terrorist threats in an alleged plot to use guns and
explosives against Platte County R-3 High School, also timed to coincide with
the Columbine anniversary.

In Michigan, prosecutors are deciding whether to file terrorism charges against
a 16-year-old Oxford boy accused of stockpiling homemade bombs, napalm and
blueprints of his high school in his parents' basement. Also in Michigan, Andrew
Osantowski, 18, of Macomb County was sentenced to at least 41/2 years in prison
in June after a jury found him guilty of terrorism and making terrorist threats
in a plot to massacre students at his suburban Detroit high school. Amassed in
his home were an AK-47, pipe bombs, a Nazi flag, printed material about Adolf
Hitler and a schematic diagram of his school.

One of the striking similarities in all these school shooting plots is this lack
of originality. There's always the stupid Nazi flag. There's always the school
schematic. There's usually a pornographically detailed written plan. It's as
though the same adolescent drive to own the same style of Nikes as all the other
kids animates a need to plot the exact same killing spree. And perhaps that is
the parallel between the 9/11 terrorists and these would-be school shooters  --
their fundamental passivity, failure of imagination and willingness to be led
without thought.

There's another telling similarity between suicide bombers and teenage would-be
suicide-shooters: A Secret Service study undertaken in response to the rash of
school shootings in the late 1990s found that of the 41 teenage shooters studied
--  ranging in age from 11 to 21 and with little commonality in family
background, income or intelligence  --  the  only common links were depression
and suicidal tendencies. Moreover, like suicide bombers, school shooters see
themselves as victims. The report indicated that more than two-thirds of the
school shooters felt persecuted or bullied. The motive for the shooting often
was revenge. In that sense, too, school shooters could be compared to
terrorists; they feel victimized and despairing, they hunger for revenge and
they need to have their lives matter, even if only in hindsight.

One of the most pathetic details that emerged with last month's release of
nearly 1,000 pages of previously confidential diary entries, notes and
schoolwork of the two Columbine shooters was this: Sandwiched between the hatred
and loneliness and alienation was a simple yet acute longing for girlfriends. As
Newsweek reported, Klebold, 17 at the time, lamented, "I don't know what I do
wrong with people (mainly women) it's like they set out to hate & ignore me."
This is not unlike the longings of the fundamentalist suicide bomber, whose
religious beliefs often lead to a complicated mix of desire for and loathing of
women.

Certainly, there are differences between disaffected Goths and suicide bombers.
The role that religion plays in the minds of the latter group cannot be
underestimated. More broadly, teenagers are teenagers, and they are not
criminally culpable in the way an adult might be, even when their attacks are as
lethal. And because teenage boys with grudges are fundamentally different from
men with liquid explosives, we should resist the temptation to use terrorism
laws to prosecute them; even when those laws offer the prospect of longer
sentences and trial in adult court.

Still, it may well be the case that the best legal analogy we have for teenagers
plotting a repeat of Columbine in this country is religious terrorism. In both
cases, the offenders are alienated and grandiose, bitter and vengeful. And
although we shouldn't use laws fashioned for terrorists to try high-schoolers
with homemade bombs, we should consider the parallels between them in fashioning
laws to deter and punish both.

dahlia.lithwick@hotmail.com

</body>Dahlia Lithwick covers legal affairs for Slate, the online magazine at
www.slate.com.

                December 7, 2000, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

Suspect in New Year's Terror Plot Is Arrested in Algeria

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER

SECTION: Section A;  Page 3;  Column 1;  Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 941 words


A fugitive charged with plotting terrorist attacks in the United States over the
New Year's holidays last winter has been quietly arrested in Algeria, Clinton
administration officials said yesterday.

Officials said that Abdelmajid Dahoumane, a 33-year-old Algerian sought by
American and Canadian authorities for almost a year, was arrested in Algeria
less than two months ago. Last April, the United States and Canada offered up to
$5 million for information leading to his arrest and conviction.

In an indictment issued last January, prosecutors for the United States
attorney's office in Seattle accused Mr. Dahoumane of being an accomplice of
Ahmed Ressam, an Algerian indicted for plotting a "terrorist act" in the United
States.

The plot was foiled on Dec. 14, 1999, when border agents in Port Angeles, Wash.,
arrested Mr. Ressam as he tried to cross the Canadian border in a car loaded
with explosives and four homemade detonators.

According to officials, Mr. Dahoumane and Mr. Ressam shared a hotel room in
Vancouver, Canada, during the month before Mr. Ressam's attempt to cross the
border and may have made the explosives together. Officials said they believed
that several members of the Algerian group had been members of the Armed Islamic
Group in Algeria, whose members have killed thousands of their fellow countrymen
in that country's civil war.

Officials said that the Algerian police have been questioning Mr. Dahoumane not
only about his activities with Mr. Ressam before the millennial celebrations in
Canada and the United States, but also about his possible links to a terrorist
network believed to be headed by Osama bin Laden -- whom the United States has
accused of the 1998 bombing of two embassies in Africa in which more than 200
people died -- or at least his knowledge of the network.

American officials suspect that Mr. bin Laden's group was involved in assisting
Mr. Ressam and his alleged conspirators with attempted terrorism in the United
States and with a separate bombing plot in Jordan. But officials said that
information collected so far about Mr. bin Laden's possible involvement in the
American plot was inconclusive.

According to administration officials, Mr. Dahoumane has not provided much
information either about the millennium bombing plot or whatever ties to Mr.
Laden's group he may have had.

A State Department spokesman declined to comment today on whether the United
States had sought Mr. Dahoumane's extradition. Law enforcement officials
declined today to confirm his legal status.

Mr. Ressam is scheduled to stand trial in March in Los Angeles. Abdel Ghani
Meskini and Mokhtar Haouari, two other alleged accomplices in the case, will be
tried in New York later next year on charges of conspiring to support a
terrorist group and to conceal support for Mr. Ressam.

American investigators have been repeatedly frustrated in their efforts to find
out what the Algerians intended to blow up in the United States and when they
planned to act. A year into the investigation, American officials and
investigators said, they were still uncertain how many bombs Mr. Ressam and his
colleagues had been planning to detonate or their exact itinerary in the United
States.

Neither Mr. Ressam nor the other Algerians indicted in Seattle or New York have
shed light on such critical issues as what if any assistance they received from
Mr. bin Laden's group, which is based in Afghanistan, officials said.

Early in the investigation, American and Canadian investigators uncovered what
they believed were links between Mr. bin Laden and the Algerians charged with
plotting the terrorist attack in the United States. Last January, for instance,
authorities in Mauritania, at the request of the United States, detained
Mohambedou Ould Slahi, a brother-in-law of one of Mr. bin Laden's lieutenants.
Officials suspected that Mr. Slahi had traveled to Canada to direct Mr. Ressam
and his Algerian group in Canada in their effort to enter the United States to
commit terrorism.

But Mr. Slahi was eventually released and disappeared after the American
officials decided that they lacked sufficient evidence to charge him with a
crime and to request his extradition.

Officials said they had no specific evidence that Mr. bin Laden set the American
bombing plot in motion. But investigators said they had found several ties
between members of the American bombing plot and Mr. bin Laden's worldwide
network.

Officials disclosed, for example, that one of the men charged in the American
millennium bombing case had a roommate who was associated with an Islamic
charity that prosecutors said played a role in the embassy bombings in Africa,
with which Mr. bin Laden has been charged.

Middle Eastern and American officials say they believe that one of Mr. bin
Laden's lieutenants, Abu Zubaydah, helped coordinate a terrorist plot that was
aimed at Western and Israeli tourists in Jordan late last December. Officials
said that they believed that the same lieutenant was also in contact with the
Algerian group, some of whose members were charged in the bombing plot aimed at
the unspecified targets in the United States. But it is still not clear whether
Mr. Zubaydah played an active role in that plot, these officials say.

Last January, a federal grand jury in Seattle charged Mr. Dahoumane with
crossing a national boundary and conspiring among other things to "destroy or
damage structures, conveyances or other real or personal property."

Officials said that while both Mr. Ressam and Mr. Dahoumane entered the United
States from Canada, they traveled separately.

                             311 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                      July 22, 1988, Friday, Final Edition

D.C. Travel Agent Denies He Had Role in Alleged Plot to Kill Col. North

BYLINE: Caryle Murphy, Sandra Evans, Washington Post Staff Writers

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A10

LENGTH: 945 words


A lawyer for Mousa Hawamda denied yesterday that his client was involved in an
alleged assassination plot against former White House aide Oliver L. North and
called allegations that Hawamda, who runs a District travel agency, is a Libyan
intelligence agent "ludicrous."

"I know nothing about" the alleged plot against North, said attorney Ray Hanna.
The allegations surfaced Wednesday when U.S. Attorney Henry E. Hudson asked a
federal magistrate in Alexandria to detain Hawamda, along with five other men,
without bond on a charge of violating the administration's trade embargo against
Libya.

Hanna described Hawamda, a 42-year-old naturalized citizen from Jordan who runs
the Manara Travel Agency on K Street NW, as a family man with two children.

He said that his client was subpoenaed in 1985 before an Alexandria federal
grand jury investigating allegations that some Libyans here planned to kill
Libyans opposed to the government of Col. Moammar Gadhafi. No charges were ever
brought.

Hudson declined yesterday to elaborate on his allegations. The U.S. magistrate
in Alexandria has scheduled a detention hearing for the men today and a grand
jury in Alexandria will begin hearing testimony Monday on the trade embargo
violations and the alleged assassination plan.

Those subpoenaed for the grand jury include Richard Shadyac, a former attorney
for the McLean-based Peoples Committee for Libyan Students, as well as several
employees of the committee.Three of the men charged Wednesday are members of the
committee, which provides financial support for Libyan students in the United
States.

Shadyac and State Department officials expressed skepticism about the alleged
plot to kill North, who helped organize the U.S. bombing of Libya in April 1986.

"If they have evidence of a plot against North, charge these people in
accordance with the American way," Shadyac said. "Don't hold them without bail
based on unsubstantiated allegations."

Several State Department officials, cautioning that they had not seen the
prosecutor's evidence, said similar allegations went back several years and that
no charges had been brought at that time, seeming to indicate that the evidence
was not sufficient.

The American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee suggested that "phantom plots to
assassinate Oliver North" were attempts "to vindicate" the former aide by
placing "him in a sympathetic role as the victim."

Hudson may have to lay out more details of the alleged plot at the hearing today
before U.S. Magistrate Leonie Brinkema, who will determine whether the six men
should be detained without bond until their trial. A preliminary hearing on the
merits of the case is scheduled for Thursday.

The six men, and two other Libyans arrested Tuesday night in Denver and Ann
Arbor, Mich., are accused of using student funds that came to the committee in
McLean to support anti-American activities and for travel by nonstudents to
Libya.

Hudson cited the assassination plot against an unnamed government official at
Wednesday's hearings after Brinkema pressed him for a reason to detain Hawamda
and the others without bond until today's hearing. Sources later named North as
the target of the alleged plot.

An FBI affidavit filed in Alexandria alleges Hawamda is a Libyan intelligence
operative who received $ 35,000 from Mohamed Madjoub, identified as a top Libyan
intelligence officer, to start up Manara Travel "to serve Libyan foreign
intelligence gathering activities."

However, in a sworn deposition in connection with a 1982 civil suit in D.C.
Superior Court, Hawamda said he began Manara with a $ 60,000 investment from a
Lebanese business partner named Admed Mourad. Manara was incorporated in the
District in September 1980, with Hawamda as president, according to corporate
records.

Hawamda acknowledged he had no previous travel business experience, but hoped to
get clients from the 75,000 Arab students here at the time. The Libyan
government became his biggest client in April 1981, he said. He claimed to have
lost much of that business, however, when the government learned it could get
cheaper tickets by buying directly from Pan American Airways.

Hawamda, who told Brinkema Wednesday that he holds U.S. and Jordanian passports,
said he came to the United States in the early 1970s to study physics at San
Jose State University, where he obtained a master's degree. In 1976 he entered
Georgetown University, where he received a PhD in nuclear physics in 1982, he
said.

Before starting the travel agency, his only employment in this country was as a
car salesman and as a teaching assistant at Georgetown for five years, he said.

The Peoples Committee for Libyan Students was set up in 1981 to distribute
Libyan government funds to its students here after the Libyan Embassy was
ordered closed. According to court documents, the eight men were involved in a
scheme to use student funds to finance trips to Libya for nonstudents and to
finance anti-U.S. demonstrations here.

Hawamda helped the illegal diversion by making "false billings" from Manara for
airline tickets, saying they were issued to Libyan students, the affidavit
stated. Under the trade embargo, the committee could use money from Libya only
for students' expenses.

All the committee's employees have been subpoenaed to appear before the grand
jury next week, according to an employee who declined to identify himself. He
said the FBI searched the offices Wednesday, taking student financial documents
and equipment. The seized papers were "no big deal," he said. "We have nothing
to hide."

Staff writers Evelyn Hsu and David Ottoway contributed to this report.

                             312 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              November 3, 1984, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

PAPERS SHOW DRUG LINK TO SUSPECT IN ALLEGED PLOT AGAINST HONDURAN

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

SECTION: Section 1; Page 9, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 764 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 2


A Miami man named as a central figure in an alleged plot to overthrow the
Government of Honduras was already under investigation in a drug-smuggling case,
according to affidavits made public today.

The suspect, Faiz J. Sikaffy, a Honduran national living in Miami, was linked by
the Federal drug-enforcement officials to the smuggling of cocaine and marijuana
into Florida and Louisiana before his arrest Thursday on charges of conspiring
to assassinate President Roberto Suazo Cordova of Honduras.

Mr. Sikaffy, 48 years old, who has imported agricultural goods and operated
fishing boats since he left Honduras two years ago, was one of eight people
arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with the alleged
plot against Dr. Suazo Cordova.

He and three others named in the conspiracy today were ordered held without bond
by a Federal Magistrate in Miami. The others are Gerard Latchinian, 46, Manual
Binker, 48, and Robert Kurtz. All except Mr. Kurtz were charged with conspiracy
to commit murder.

Profits From Smuggling

Mr. Kurtz and four others were accused of smuggling drugs to help finance the
plot. Bond for the four others was set at $100,000 to $500,000.

The bureau also named a Honduran General, Jose Abnegado Bueso Rosa, the military
attache in Chile, in the plot. The United States was seeking to extradite
General Bueso Rosa from Chile to face murder conspiracy charges, and United
Press International quoted Jaime Del Valle, the Foreign Minister of Chile, as
saying that the extradition request was passed on to the Chilean Supreme Court
today for a ruling.

Documents containing bureau affidavits were presented at the bond hearings. They
included details of the two-month undercover investigation that led to the
charges.

''Once the assassination had occurred, Latchinian advised he had a choice among
three generals to assume power, all of whom were frends of his,'' Eduardo M.
Sanchez, a bureau agent said in a statement.

''The purpose of the assassination was to create turmoil and the best of three
generals would take over the reins of office,'' Mr. Sanchez stated. ''Latchinian
claimed that only General Bueso knew of the plot.''

According to the investigation, General Bueso Rosa, had traveled to Miami on
several occasions to discuss the progress of the alleged assassination plot with
his Honduran associates here.

Until a shakeup of the Honduran military staff in March, General Bueso Rosa had
been Army chief of staff under the top military commander, Gen. Gustavo Alvarez
Martinez. After the shakeup, General Bueso Rosa was reassigned to Chile and
General Alvarez, who was ousted from his post, moved to the Miami area.

The Government of Honduras has said that General Alvarez is also linked to the
alleged plot, and The Associated Press reported that the Attorney General of
Honduras, Elizabeth Chiuz Sierra said she would seek extradition from the United
States of General Alvarez and the eight men arrested Thursday to face charges of
high treason and related crimes in Honduras.

Interviewed today, General Alvarez said he was ''surprised'' by news of the
plot.

''This is not the way to fix things,'' he continued. ''In these things it is
necessary to have patience even though one feels being treated unjustly.''

Reaction in Honduras

News of the charges caused a sensation in Honduras. Some Hondurans, however,
doubted that an assassination of Dr. Suazo Cordova could bring down the
Government; a military council holds ultimate power in the country.

''I say it's prepostrous because even if they could physically eliminate the
President it would not have made the Government fall,'' Jaime Rolando Rosenthal
Oliva, publisher of El Tiempo newspaper, said in a telephone interview.

In documents entered by the F.B.I. in court today, agents stated that Mr.
Latchinian had said that Mr. Skikaffy was contacted recently by a man he
identified as the ''chief of police of Honduras'' to give advice on how to
dispose of 2,320 pounds of cocaine in the United States.

F.B.I. informers also reported that seafood processing plants operated by Mr.
Sikaffy in Louisiana were covers for the importation of marijuana, the documents
related, and other testimony stated that boats used in Mr. Sikaffy's fleet were
engaged in smuggling activities.

Mr. Sikaffy told a bureau informer ''that he had borrowed money several times
from the 'mob' and that he was in the drug trade to pay off these debts and
finance the ouster of the current government of his country,'' a bureau agent
stated.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                             313 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Contra Costa Times (California)

                            January 31, 2010 Sunday

Valley Life: Where's a good plot when you need one?

BYLINE: By Penny Warner Columnist

SECTION: MY TOWN; Alameda; Contra Costa; News; Local

LENGTH: 539 words


DON'T YOU JUST want to slap the next person who blurts out the overused phrase,
"Get a life!"?

I have a life. In fact, with writing and teaching and baby-sitting
grandchildren, I have more than enough lives.

Truth is, what I need right now is a plot. Not a cemetery plot, a story plot. A
plot is similar to a life, but it's fiction and has a deadline   although I
suppose you could argue that life does, too.

I'm glad I have a life because writing a column every couple of weeks requires
it. If I don't experience something interesting, then I have nothing to write
about. But when writing fiction, that's   to use another overused phrase
"another story."

Making stuff up is much like being a good liar, only you have to lie for about
300 pages. And for that, you need a plot.

After writing two books in my new mystery series, I need a plot for my third.
I've already poisoned a bride, drowned a socialite, bludgeoned a philanthropist,
and creatively murdered several other fictional characters. I've got the murder
stuff down. What I need now is a cleverly twisting story full of red herrings,
misdirection, and cliffhangers.

And it has to sound like real life.

Therein lies the problem. While I have "a life," it doesn't include mayhem,
malice or murder. Living here in the valley, while it has its ups and down like
any valley, is mostly peaceful and pleasant.

If I want drama, I turn on the TV and watch shows like "The Mentalist,"
"Castle," and "Criminal Minds." Sometimes these shows give me ideas for my own
plots. But I have to be careful I don't steal the stories outright. That could
lead to courtroom drama of another kind.

At book signings, I'm often asked, "Where do you get your plots?" My fellow
writers usually give a witty response, like "At the plot store" or "Walmart."
But the truth is, plots are difficult to come by, especially when your amateur
sleuth isn't a police officer or attorney or private detective. Plots just seem
to fall into their laps.

In my new series, my protagonist is a party planner. Only problem is, so many
people have been dropping dead at her parties, she's going to be out of business
soon. That's called the "Jessica Fletcher Syndrome."

Remember how Jessica Fletcher, in "Murder She Wrote," was always tripping over
dead bodies in quaint little Cabot Cove? It's a wonder there was anyone left in
the town. So who's going to hire Presley Parker to host a party when inevitably
one or more of the guests will be found dead in the punchbowl? In real life, her
"Killer Parties" business wouldn't last the party season.

But luckily, writing fiction isn't like real life. You can make up anything you
want. That's called plotting. And now I'm right back where I started this
lament.

Maybe I should take a break from the world of fiction and get back to real life
by throwing a party, with finger foods (not literally) and chocolates
(poison-free). And, what the heck, signed copies of "How to Host a Killer
Party."

I just hope no one falls facedown in the punch bowl. I'd like to keep fiction
and real life separate as much as possible.

Contact Penny Warner at www.pennywarner.com . Join her Monday, Feb. 8 from 7 to
9 p.m. for a book-release party at Peasant and the Pear restaurant, 267 Hartz
Ave., Danville.

                                Plus Patent News

                            January 23, 2017 Monday

Becton, Dickinson and Company applies for US Patent titled as "SYSTEM AND METHOD
FOR ADJUSTING CYTOMETER MEASUREMENTS"

LENGTH: 237 words

DATELINE: New York


ALEXANDRIA, Va: United States Patent and Trademark Office has received an
application no. 20170016828 for US Patent, published on January 19, 2017, by
Becton, Dickinson and Company, titled as "SYSTEM AND METHOD FOR ADJUSTING
CYTOMETER MEASUREMENTS"  for the registration of patent.



Inventors: Xu; Heng; (Castro Valley, CA) ; Yan; Ming; (Pleasanton, CA)

Applicant: Becton, Dickinson and Company   Franklin Lakes   NJ   US

According to the abstract released by the U.S. Patent & Trademark Office:
"Methods and systems for operating a flow cytometer can include forward scatter
values, side scatter values, and fluorescence intensity values for events of an
unstained sample and associating the fluorescence intensity values with forward
scatter-side scatter side scatter plot regions. Methods and systems for
operating a flow cytometer can also include measuring forward scatter values,
side scatter values, and fluorescence intensity values for events of a stained
sample, determining forward scatter-side scatter plot locations for the events
of the stained sample, and for each event of the stained sample, subtracting the
fluorescence intensity value associated with the forward scatter-side scatter
plot region that contains the forward scatter-side scatter plot location of the
stained sample event from the measured fluorescence intensity value of the
stained sample event at that forward scatter-side scatter plot location."

                             315 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Sunday Times (Perth, Australia)

                              July 9, 2006 Sunday
                                 Street Edition

8 linked to tunnel plot

SECTION: Pg. 37

LENGTH: 435  words


NEW YORK: The FBI says it has identified eight

al-Qaida followers involved in a plot to attack the transit system in New York
and three of them have been taken into custody overseas.

''We believe we have what I'll call eight principal players and we have them
largely identified,'' Mark Mershon, head of the FBI's New York office, said.

Three have been arrested, but only one -- a Lebanese national described as the
''mastermind'' of the plot and a disciple of al-Qaida leader Osama bin Laden --
has been formally charged, Mr Mershon said.

He said the man had confessed ''his adherence to the philosophy of al-Qaida, his
swearing of allegiance to Osama bin Laden and the fact that he was the
mastermind of this plot and it was to play out later this year, October or
November of '06''.

Earlier, the FBI said it had foiled a terror plot to attack mass-transit targets
in New York, including tunnels.

''We have disrupted a terrorist network that was in the planning stages of an
attack against the transportation system in the New York-New Jersey area,'' it
said in a joint statement with the Department of Homeland Security.

News of the plot was broken on Friday by a New York newspaper, which cited
counter-terrorism officials in identifying the chief target as the Holland
Tunnel, the main road link between Manhattan and New Jersey that runs under the
Hudson River.

Pete King, chairman of the House of Representatives' Homeland Security
Committee, suggested it was part of a series of planned attacks.

''There certainly are and have been serious plots against the New York City
transit system,'' he said.

Mr King said investigations by federal and New York officials had been going on
for nine or 10 months and

involved plans of ''very excruciating'' detail.

The alleged conspirator

arrested at the request of US officials was identified by a diplomatic source in
Beirut as Assem Hammoud.

Lebanon's interim Interior Minister, Ahmed Fatfat, said a Lebanese citizen had
been detained ''six weeks ago'' on suspicion of being ''the leader of a network
operating on the internet''.

According to the newspaper report, the plot had received a pledge of financial
support and assistance from Jordanian associates of al-Qaida chief Abu Musab
al-Zarqawi before he was killed by a US air strike in Iraq last month.

It was unclear whether the aid was actually delivered.

The 2.4km Holland Tunnel, which is used by thousands of cars and trucks daily,
is

already operating under tight security.

New York Senator Charles Schumer said the plot had been uncovered at an early
stage and suggested the conspirators may not have posed a major threat.

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                            November 13, 2005 Sunday
                              Correction Appended

Agriculture Briefs

BYLINE: Telegraph Herald Staff

SECTION: Agriculture; Pg. b7

LENGTH: 525 words


Cattlemen's group will hold banquet

The Dubuque County Cattlemen's Association will hold its annual banquet and
queen crowning Friday at the Dubuque County Fairgrounds ballroom.

A char-grilled ribeye steak dinner will be served 6 to 8 p.m.

Entertainment will be provided by KDTH radio station.

Tickets are $12 at the door. Packages of frozen ribeye steaks will be given away
to all who attend.

Drainage seminar planned in Elizabeth

ELIZABETH, Ill. - Agriculture producers and landowners can learn about drainage
and decision aids for design at the Advances in Agricultural Drainage seminar
from 1:30 to 3:30 p.m. Tuesday at the University of Illinois County Extension
Office in Elizabeth.

The seminar is intended to give participants the tools to start making informed
decisions about the need and value of improving surface and subsurface drainage.

The cost is $3 per person. To register, call 815/858-2273.

Detailed results offered for harvested plots

ELIZABETH, Ill. - Detailed results of the 2005 Jo-Carroll Extension Unit soybean
variety, corn hybrid and corn silage plots that were recently harvested are now
available at both the Elizabeth and Mount Carroll Extension offices.

Jo Daviess County plots included the conventional corn plot, hosted by Wayne
Simmons, of Stockton, where 52 entries averaged 213.6 bushels per acre with a
range of 191.1 bushels to 243.8 bushels. The no-till corn plot, hosted by Howard
Sincox, of Apple River, had 40 entries that averaged 219.6 bushels per acre with
a range of 188.3 bushels to 245.7 bushels. The no-till soybean plot, also hosted
by Sincox, had 45 entries that averaged 71.5 bushels with a range from 64
bushels to 78 bushels.

For more information about the program, contact Mark Maidak, Jo-Carroll Unit
Leader, at 815/858-2273.

New Web site to focus on distillers grain

URBANA, Ill. - The University of Illinois Extension has created a new Web site
dedicated to distillers grain, a valuable commodity for corn and livestock
producers.

The web address for the site, titled, "Distillers Feeds: Using Illinois
ByProduct Feeds in Livestock Feeding Programs," is
http://ilift.traill.uiuc.edu/distillers.

The site contains a list of Midwestern distillers grain sources and contacts for
current prices and byproduct availability, as well as other valuable information
on the topic.

The Illinois Council on Food and Agricultural Research funded the Web site,
seeking to assist livestock producers in successfully incorporating wet and dry
distiller grain in their feeding program.

Johanns: Ballots mailed for committee elections

SPRINGFIELD, Mo. - Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns announced last week that
the Farm Service Agency county committee elections officially began with the
mailing of ballots.

Agricultural producers, who participate or cooperate in any FSA program and are
of legal voting age, can vote.

Any eligible voters who have not received a ballot should contact their county
FSA office.

All ballots must be completed and returned to the voter's FSA office or
postmarked by Dec. 5. Newly elected committee members and alternates take office
Jan. 1.

LOAD-DATE: November 14, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CORRECTION-DATE: November 15, 2005

CORRECTION:

Headline: Agriculture Briefs

Published: 11-13-2005

The Dubuque County Cattlemen's Association held its annual banquet on Friday,
Nov. 11. A story on Page 7B Sunday said the banquet would be held Nov. 18.

                  Copyright 2005 Woodward Communications, Inc.


                             317 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

               January 13, 1994, Thursday, DAILY: TORONTO EDITION

KERRIGAN PLOT PROBED: NBC says bodyguard confessed to planning attack on skater

BYLINE: Associated Press

SECTION: SECTION 4, INSIDE SPORT; Pg. 43

LENGTH: 359 words

DATELINE: New York, NY


Tonya Harding's bodyguard confessed to participating in a plot to injure Olympic
figure skating rival Nancy Kerrigan, NBC News reported last night.

The report on the show ''Now'' with Tom Brokaw and Katie Couric also quoted the
unidentified sources as saying the weapon had been recovered in Detroit, from a
dumpster behind the ice rink where Kerrigan was attacked last Thursday after
practice.

Earlier yesterday, the Portland Oregonian reported that the FBI was
investigating allegations that Harding's husband, Jeff Gillooly, and her
bodyguard, Shawn Eric Eckardt, were involved in the attack.

In Detroit, deputy police chief Benny Napoleon said no arrest would be announced
last night.

''There is nothing else I can say at this time,'' he said.

Regarding the NBC report that Eckardt had confessed, Napoleon said, ''It is an
ongoing investigation. I'm not in a position to discuss that.''

Both NBC and the Oregonian said Harding had no knowledge of the alleged plot.
NBC said authorities expected to arrest four people late yesterday or this
morning on federal charges.

The Oregonian reported that Gillooly and Eckardt hired a ''hit man'' to carry
out the attack. The story was based on information from a man who said he heard
a tape of a conversation in which the plot to injure Kerrigan was discussed.

NBC said, according to its sources, authorities don't have the tape. The sources
said the tape was destroyed by one of the suspects after the Oregonian report
appeared.

According to the NBC sources, Harding's husband and the bodyguard arranged for a
hit man from Arizona to attend a meeting in Portland.

NBC said the alleged plot came to light because the bodyguard taped the meeting
and later played the tape for a friend, a minister.

According to the Oregonian, a minister named Eugene C. Saunders told a private
investigator that he had listened to the tape. The two men then went to
authorities.

When Harding was asked Tuesday night about rumors her husband was involved in
the attack, she replied: ''I can't believe it. I mean, why does someone want to
discredit me? I just don't understand.''


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:  Photo: Reports said yesterday that the husband and bodyguard of Tonya
Harding conspired to take Nancy Kerrigan out of the U.S. national championships.

Photo: Nancy Kerrigan

                             318 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        The International Herald Tribune

                            November 2, 2009 Monday

For U.S., terrorists may be thinking small;
Recently foiled plots point to switch from the spectacular to the doable

BYLINE: David Johnston and Eric Schmitt

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 689 words

DATELINE: Washington

ABSTRACT

American intelligence officials are increasingly concerned that extremist groups
in Pakistan linked to Al Qaeda are planning operations that are harder to detect
but more likely to succeed.

FULL TEXT

After disrupting two recent terrorism plots, American intelligence officials are
increasingly concerned that extremist groups in Pakistan linked to Al Qaeda are
planning smaller operations in the United States that are harder to detect but
more likely to succeed than the spectacular attacks they once emphasized, senior
counterterrorism officials say.

The two cases - one involving two Chicago men accused this week of planning an
attack on a Danish newspaper that published cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad,
the other a 24-year-old Denver shuttle bus driver indicted in a plot to use
improvised explosives - are among the most serious in years, the officials said.

In both, the officials said, the main defendants are long-term residents of the
United States with substantial community ties who traveled to Pakistan's tribal
areas, where they apparently trained with extremist groups affiliated with Al
Qaeda.

The authorities have been struck in the Denver and Chicago plots by the central
roles played by men who seemed to have been more security-conscious and better
organized and trained than many of those involved in terrorism cases brought
since 2001, including a surge of arrests in recent weeks. A number of those
arrested were young men inflamed with militant zeal but few skills to carry out
an attack.

Some officials said that while the Chicago and Denver cases stood out from
lower-level terrorism prosecutions in the United States, it was not new for
would-be terrorists to travel to Pakistan and other training grounds and return
home to engage in militant activity. They said the activities of Najibullah
Zazi, the Denver man, closely resembled the methodology of the Madrid train
bombings in 2004 and the London Underground bombings in 2005.

A case last year suggests that young men from the United States are also finding
their way to Pakistan to fight American forces. Bryant Neal Vinas, 26, grew up
on Long Island in New York and worked as a truck driver for the Long Island Rail
Road, a commuter line that runs into New York City, before going to Pakistan. He
made contact with a Qaeda group and took part in a rocket attack on an American
base in Afghanistan before being captured in Pakistan and brought back to the
United States last November. Since then, Mr. Vinas has cooperated with the
authorities, helping to identify other extremists who trained for operations in
the West.

The model of young men who have lived for years in the United States before
traveling overseas and connecting with militant Islamist groups is not confined
to Pakistan. In October 2008, for example, a Somali-American teenager from
Minneapolis carried out a suicide bombing in northern Somalia.

Government counterterrorism analysts said it was significant that the Chicago
and Denver cases involved plots that seemed less ambitious than the World Trade
Center and Pentagon attacks or suspected plots of the past, like those aimed at
Los Angeles International Airport or the Sears Tower in Chicago.

Western intelligence officials believed that Al Qaeda's leadership concentrated
on spectacular, mass-casualty attacks to build its credibility in the Islamic
world. American analysts said the difficulty of carrying out such grandiose
plots offered a measure of protection to the United States.

J. Patrick Rowan, a former top lawyer in the Justice Department's national
security division, said the recent cases could mean shifting away from
large-scale plots. ''There has always been a view that Al Qaeda wants to
duplicate or do something even more substantial than 9/11,'' Mr. Rowan said.

''The hypothesis has been that they have focused their resources on carrying out
a spectacular attack and decided not to pursue lesser plots,'' he said. ''These
cases would seem to undercut that hypothesis and suggest they might be
rethinking their strategy, which is obviously worrisome because smaller
operations may be harder to detect and stop.''

LOAD-DATE: November 2, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                  Copyright 2009 International Herald Tribune
                              All Rights Reserved


                             319 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                             320 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                              The Washington Post

                             March 5, 2015 Thursday
                                Suburban Edition

Pakistani man guilty in failed New York City bomb plot

SECTION: A-SECTION; Pg. A03

LENGTH: 553 words

New York

Pakistani man guilty in failed bomb plot

A Pakistani man was found guilty Wednesday in a failed al-Qaeda bomb plot after
a New York trial that featured spies in disguise and evidence from the raid on
Osama bin Laden's compound.

Abid Naseer, 28, was arrested in 2009 in Britain on charges he was part of a
terror cell plotting to blow up a shopping mall in Manchester, England. The
charges were dropped after a British court found there wasn't enough evidence,
but U.S. prosecutors later named him in an indictment alleging a broader
conspiracy that included a failed plot to attack the New York City subway. He
was arrested again and extradited to the United States in 2013.

Naseer acted as his own lawyer, often referring to himself in the third person
and portraying himself as a moderate Muslim who was falsely accused.

Five British MI5 secret agents testified wearing disguises - one wore a fake
beard and thick black glasses - and the trial marked the first time documents
recovered in the 2011 Navy SEAL raid against bin Laden's compound were used as
trial evidence.

- Associated Press

UTAH

Mormon Church backs LGBT bill

Utah lawmakers introduced a landmark bill Wednesday that would bar
discrimination against gay and transgender individuals while protecting the
rights of religious groups and individuals.

The measure has a rare stamp of approval from the Mormon Church and stands a
high chance of passing in Utah, where the church is based and many state
lawmakers and the Republican governor are members.

Members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints joined LGBT rights
activists, bipartisan lawmakers and Utah's Republican lieutenant governor in
unveiling the bill at a news conference.

The proposal would prohibit discrimination based on gender identity and sexual
orientation when it comes to housing or employment. Religious organizations
would be exempt from the requirement, as would Boy Scouts of America, which has
a ban on gay adult Scout leaders.

- Associated Press

CALIFORNIA

Man killed by police was to be deported

U.S. authorities had tried to deport a homeless man fatally shot by police this
week in Los Angeles but had to release him after authorities in his native
Cameroon failed to provide a travel document, a U.S. immigration official said
Wednesday.

The man, known by his street name "Africa," was killed by police Sunday in a
videotaped encounter on Los Angeles's skid row in which police said he grabbed
for an officer's holstered gun as police tried to arrest him as a robbery
suspect.

Convicted of armed bank robbery and other charges in 2000, the man had been
ordered deported from the United States in 2013 while still in federal prison,
according to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement spokeswoman Virginia Kice.

But less than a year before the fatal shooting, he was released because
authorities could not obtain a Cameroonian travel document for him.

A 2013 Supreme Court order limits the amount of time a person ordered removed
can be held awaiting deportation.

Immigration officials initially sought a travel document from France because the
man claimed French citizenship, but French officials informed them he was a
Cameroon national, Kice said.

The French Consulate in Los Angeles confirmed that the man stole a Frenchman's
identity and was not a French citizen.

- Reuters

                             321 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                              The Washington Post

                              May 10, 2013 Friday
                                 Met 2 Edition

Minnesota gets closer to gay marriage; Tunisian man is charged in terrorism plot

SECTION: A-SECTION; Pg. A03

LENGTH: 720 words

minnesota

Vote puts state closer to gay marriage

A pivotal vote Thursday in the Minnesota House positioned that state to become
the 12th in the country to allow same-sex marriages and the first in the Midwest
to pass such a law out of its legislature.

The 75 to 59 vote was a critical step for the measure, which would allow
same-sex weddings beginning this summer. It's a startling shift in the state,
where just six months earlier voters turned back an effort to ban them in the
Minnesota Constitution. The state Senate plans to consider the bill Monday, and
leaders expect it to pass there, too. Gov. Mark Dayton (D) has pledged to sign
it into law.

Four of the House's 61 Republicans voted for the bill, while two of its 73
Democrats voted against it.

- Associated Press

national security

Tunisian man is charged in terror plot

A Tunisian man accused of radicalizing a Canadian resident charged in a plot to
derail a train has been charged with trying to stay in the United States
illegally to build a terrorism cell for international acts of terrorism, such as
poisoning a water system with bacteria, authorities said Thursday.

Law enforcement authorities had watched Ahmed Abassi since he arrived in the
United States from Canada in mid-March and arrested him April 22 at John F.
Kennedy International Airport, authorities said. Abassi met regularly with an
undercover FBI agent and met with another Tunisian citizen who was later
arrested in Canada in the plot to derail the train, they said.

Prosecutors, in a letter submitted to a U.S. District Court judge in Manhattan,
said Abassi had radicalized Chiheb Esseghaier, who is charged in Toronto with
conspiring with al-Qaeda members in Iran to derail a train that runs between New
York City and Montreal.

- Associated Press

military

3 officers relieved of duty after deadly accident

Three U.S. Marine Corps officers have been relieved of command after an
explosion during a training exercise at a Nevada munitions depot in March killed
seven fellow Marines, a military spokesman said Thursday.

The officers will be reassigned to new duties and do not face any allegations of
criminal wrongdoing, said 1st Lt. Oliver David, a public affairs officer at Camp
Lejeune, N.C., where the men are based.

The blast at the Hawthorne Army Depot in western Nevada was among the deadliest
military training accidents on U.S. soil in recent years.

The three officers removed from their duties are Lt. Col. Andrew McNulty, Capt.
Kelby Breivogel and Chief Warrant Officer 3 Douglas Derring.

- Reuters

montana

Deal is reached in university probe

Federal officials reached agreements with the University of Montana in Missoula
after a year-long investigation into mishandled sexual assault reports on campus
that require the university to revise policies and adequately respond to
allegations, federal officials said Thursday.

Investigators heard from women who were assaulted then unfairly belittled,
disbelieved or blamed for speaking up about what was done to them, said Justice
Department Deputy Assistant Attorney General Roy Austin Jr.

The investigation began after 11 assaults involving university students were
reported in an 18-month period.

- Associated Press

Diesel truck accident shuts I-81: A section of Interstate 81 near Harrisburg,
Pa., was expected to remain closed in both directions for the next several days
after a tanker truck fully loaded with diesel fuel overturned Thursday morning
and exploded into flames, sending black smoke billowing into the sky. Officials
said the crash occurred on an on-ramp to Route 22-322. Police said the driver of
the truck was treated at a hospital for minor injuries.

Wash. state courts computers hacked: The Washington state Administrative Office
of the Courts was hacked in February, and up to 160,000 Social Security numbers
and 1 million driver license numbers might have been accessed during the data
breach of its public Web site, officials said Thursday.

Arias sentencing postponed: The next phase of the Jodi Arias murder trial was
postponed Thursday. The trial will resume Wednesday. The Phoenix jury was
scheduled to return to the courtroom to decide whether Arias should be eligible
for the death penalty for killing her one-time boyfriend, Travis Alexander, on
June 4, 2008. The jury convicted Arias on Wednesday of first-degree murder.

Head Line: US Federal Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture (Minnesota)
Issues Solicitation for "Forest Inventory and Analysis (FIA) Data Collection
Services, Mid-Atlantic Urban Plots"

LENGTH: 216  words

DATELINE: New York


WASHINGTON: Department of Agriculture, Forest Service officer has issued
requirement for "Forest Inventory and Analysis (FIA) Data Collection Services,
Mid-Atlantic Urban Plots"

Solicitation No: AG-3604-S-17-0009

Notice Type: Solicitation
Posted Date: January 26, 2017

Description: The USDA Forest Service, Northern Research Station intends to
initiate a Request for Proposal (RFP) procurement action and award a negotiated,
Firm-Fixed Price incentive contract for an annual forest inventory data
collection effort in urban areas of Philadelphia, PA, Baltimore, MD, Dover, DE
and NJ (most likely Trenton). The Contractor shall provide inventory data to the
USDA Forest Service, Northern Research Station's Forest Inventory and Analysis
(FIA) Unit. This data will be collected from predetermined urban forest
inventory plots randomly located across the urban areas of Philadelphia, PA,
Baltimore, MD, Dover, DE, and NJ. The protocols for this effort, including the
inventory plot design, are outlined and described in the following Field Guides:

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 115

Contact Details: 1992 Folwell Avenue - Acquisition Management St. Paul,
Minnesota 55108

Point of Contact(s): Maria T. Evans, Contract Specialist mtevans@fs.fed.us
Phone: 610-557-4237; 610-557-4040

                             324 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                 July 24, 1993, Saturday, INTERNATIONAL EDITION

More arrests in New York terror plot

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 341 words


The FBI tracked down a man wanted in connection with an alleged plot to blow up
the United Nations building and busy New York City commuter tunnels. Agents
arrested the Egyptian man in southern New Jersey. Another Egyptian was jailed
for allegedly harboring the wanted man. Matarawi Mohammed Saleh, 44, also known
as Wahid, was arrested in North Wildwood. Ashraf Mohammed, 31, was arrested for
allegedly harboring Saleh. Also: A U.S. plan to offer up to $ 2 million for
information about a missing suspect in the World Trade Center bombing has been
stymied by a dispute over which agency should put up the money. Unidentified
officials told The New York Times the dispute between the State Department and
the FBI may have cost the U.S. a chance to catch the suspect, Ramzi Ahmed
Yousef, before he fled to Iraq soon after the Feb. 26 bombing. He is the subject
of an international manhunt. By Keith Srakocic, AP

ALASKA LAWSUIT: Saying lucrative development has been precluded protected
federal lands in his state, Alaska Gov. Walter Hickel announced a $ 29 billion
lawsuit against the U.S. government. The lawsuit seeks compensation for what
Hickel said were promises broken after Alaska became a state in 1959 - pledges
that 90% of the royalties from oil drilling, mining and other resource
extraction on federal lands would be pumped into the state treasury.

ALSO . . .

SHIPPING FINE: The owner of a Chinese freighter was slapped a $ 1 million fine
in Washington state's largest penalty related to an oil spill. The fine was
issued to China Ocean Shipping Co. which was found to have been responsible for
a 1991 collision with a Japanese vessel.

DEATHS . . .

WASHINGTON: Gen. Roscoe Robinson Jr., the first black to become a four-star Army
general and the second black four-star general in the military, died at age 64.

LOS ANGELES: James Andrew "Scott" Salmon, an acclaimed choreographer, was killed
in an automobile accident. He was 50. Salmon was nominated for a Tony Award in
1988 for Broadway hit, La Cage Au Folles.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Nationline

FROM USA TODAY'S NATIONAL NEWS NETWORK

                             325 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                            April 20, 2013 Saturday

Garden plots for rent at fairgrounds

SECTION: DAKOTA WIRE; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 90 words


The Burleigh County Extension Office has community garden plots available for
rent at the Missouri Valley Complex (old fairgrounds), 3715 E. Bismarck
Expressway.

There are 126 garden plots measuring 20 feet by 20 feet available for $25 per
plot. Plots are available on a first-come, first-served basis and gardeners
supply their own gardening equipment and hoses. Water is available.

If you are interested in renting a garden plot, stop by or contact the NDSU
Extension Burleigh County office at the Missouri Valley Complex or call
701-221-6865.

                             326 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                  Times Colonist (Victoria, British Columbia)

                           October 12, 2011 Wednesday
                                 Final Edition

U.S. says Iran backed plot to kill Saudi ambassador; Two Iranians accused;
Tehran denies charge

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A9

LENGTH: 278  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON/NEW YORK


The United States accused Iran Tuesday of backing a plot to kill the Saudi
ambassador to Washington, escalating tensions with Tehran and stirring up a
hornet's nest in the Gulf, where Saudi Arabia and Iran have long jostled for
power.

U.S. authorities said they had broken up a plot by two men linked to the Iranian
government to assassinate Saudi Ambassador Adel al-Jubeir. One was arrested last
month while the other was believed to be in Iran.

Iran denied the charges. Saudi Arabia called the plot "a despicable violation of
international norms, standards and conventions."

Revelation of the alleged plot, and the apparent direct ties to the Tehran
government, had the potential to further inflame tensions in the Middle East.

U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton called the plot a "blatant violation" of
international norms. She expressed hope that countries that have hesitated to
enforce existing sanctions on Iran would now do so.

FBI director Robert Mueller told reporters the convoluted plot, involving drug
cartels in Mexico, big payments of money and an attempt to kill the ambassador
in a Washington restaurant, could have been material for a Hollywood movie.

U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder pointed to the Islamic Revolutionary Guard
Corps, which is the guardian of Iran's 32-yearold revolution, and the Quds
force, its covert arm.

U.S. officials identified the two alleged plotters as Gholam Shakuri, who is a
member of the Quds force, and Manssor Arbabsiar, who was arrested on Sept.

29 when he arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport from Mexico.

Arbabsiar, 56, a naturalized U.S. citizen, made a brief appearance in a
Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday.

LOAD-DATE: October 12, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Shaun Heasley, Reuters; Saudi Ambassador Adel al-Jubeir was the alleged
target.;

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
