                              All Rights Reserved


                             327 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Cape Argus (South Africa)

                          September 20, 2008 Saturday
                                   e1 Edition

Want to invest in American property?;
Bargain-priced plots generating interest

SECTION: PROPERTY; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 746 words


Group 3 Properties' launch of 84 bargain-priced US plots on September 10 has
generated a great deal of interest among South African investors, with buyers
booking 37 units within days, according to the company's Chris Tapsell, who has
partnered with an American property developer to offer these plots to South
Africans.

Tapsell says published articles about the plots have resulted in "a phenomenal
number of calls" from people intrigued by the low prices, which start from $8
000 (about R59 000). Most of the properties, averaging about 930m², are priced
at $12 000 (about R85 000) each.

"Several callers could not believe that we are offering the plots at these
prices and asked, 'What's the catch?' There is no catch: this is a genuine
opportunity to invest in the American property market at an affordable price,
and we can back it up with erf numbers and copies of title deeds," he says.

"We can also pinpoint the exact location and show digital photographs of each
plot to prospective buyers via Google Earth on a widescreen television at our
Tyger Valley offices. Alternatively, we can provide Google Earth subscribers
with the information required to locate the plots on their home computers,
enabling them to see and measure the actual distance to the beach (about 9.5km),
as well as the nearest convenience shopping centres, golf courses and other
facilities in the area."

Tapsell says the plots are available at these special prices simply because Jeff
Ricketts, a long-established developer in Tampa Bay, Florida, bought this parcel
of land from a bankrupt entity, and the municipality has provided subsidies
during the American economic downturn to encourage more rapid development of the
town of North Port, just outside popular city of Tampa Bay.

"The plots we are offering are currently assessed at about $37 000 each. The
cheapest plot being offered by estate agents in North Port at present is $21 000
- about R174 000 at the current rate of exchange."

Tapsell has been involved in property in South Africa for several years and his
developments include four apartment blocks at the upmarket Tyger Valley
Waterfront in Cape Town. He established a business relationship with Ricketts
during his recent four-month visit to America. Since then Group 3 Properties has
sold a number of luxury apartments in two Tampa Bay developments that Ricketts
has built.

Both companies have focused on this area because Tampa Bay has a thriving
economy, and has become the technical and financial hub of America's
southeastern region. In addition, its proximity to Disney World, Sea World,
Universal Studios and other tourist attractions, together with its
all-year-round summer season and sandy, white beaches have made it a popular
destination for millions of visitors each year.

Tapsell says Group 3 Properties has turned some of its attention to the US
market while there is a temporary lull in South Africa, because the company is
finding exceptional value in America at present. He believes that with the
dollar likely to strengthen against the rand - the rate of exchange has already
risen from R7.60 to R8.26 to the dollar during the past week - the plots
represent a good rand hedge for South African investors.

His view is that the property market in America, which has been depressed for
several years, is now bottoming out and should start to appreciate.

"The stock markets rose recently when the American government bailed out two of
the country's biggest mortgage lenders, Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae, putting
liquidity back into the US market. Once the elections are completed, and if the
anticipated withdrawal of troops from Iraq, which costs American taxpayers
billions of dollars a day, goes ahead, I believe there will be more stability
and a swing back to a positive outlook in the America economy."

Tapsell says South Africans who have already bought US plots from his company
range from middle-income earners, such as teachers, to wealthy property
investors.

"Buyers say they want to purchase these plots because it's an inexpensive way to
enter the property market in a first-world country, and they also like the fact
that the rates and taxes are low: about $350 a year," he says. "Most are looking
at holding their plots for three to five years - there is no time limit within
which buyers have to build - and then selling their assets and bringing the
money back to South Africa."

For more information, contact Chris Louwrens of Group 3 Properties on 083 287
5627.

LOAD-DATE: September 20, 2008

                     Sunday News (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

                              March 2, 2008 Sunday

Short Subjects Garden plots Spinal disabilities

BYLINE: Sunday News Staff

SECTION: G; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 248  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


The Lancaster County Department of Parks and Recreation has garden plots
available for rent from April 15 through Oct. 15; applications will be accepted
beginning Monday, March 3.

Lancaster County residents can select either a 20-by-20-foot plot ($18) or a
20-by-40-foot plot ($23) at Farm View Drive off of Golf Road in Lancaster County
Central Park.

Gardeners of all skill levels are welcome to grow their own flowers and
vegetables. Organic plots, free of pesticides and herbicides for more than three
years, are also available.

Garden workshops will be conducted by the parks department and Penn State
Cooperative Extension's Master Gardeners program.

There is a $1 fee per workshop session; those who rent one of the garden plots
may attend free of charge.

Preregistration is required to attend the workshops.

For details on the workshops, including times and dates, as well as the garden
plots, call the park office, 299-8215.

United Spinal Association, headquartered in Jackson Heights, N.Y., is offering a
new publication, "What Is SCI/D?" This three-page online pamphlet is a general
introduction to spinal-cord injury, as well as other disorders and diseases that
affect the spinal cord.

General information about amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, more commonly referred
to as ALS; multiple sclerosis or MS; post-polio; spina bifida; transverse
myelitis and syringomyelia is also included.

To download a copy of "What Is SCI/D?" please go to
http://www.unitedspinal.org/pdf/what_is_scid.pdf.

                             329 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                            Belfast Telegraph Online

                      February 17, 2014 Monday 6:57 PM GMT

UK bomb plotter may give evidence

SECTION: WORLD

LENGTH: 704 words


US federal prosecutors want a man convicted in a failed 2001 shoe bomb plot to
bring down an aircraft to testify at the sentencing of two British citizens who
pleaded guilty in Connecticut to supporting terrorists through websites.

The testimony reflects an effort by prosecutors to show that Babar Ahmad, one of
the two men facing sentencing in Connecticut, had an active role in sending
recruits to terrorism training camps beyond appealing for support on the
websites.

Prosecutors say the witness is expected to testify that Ahmad sent him to
Afghanistan to train for violent jihad and that he ultimately moved on from
Ahmad and came under the mentorship and training of al Qaida members who
prepared him for the shoe bomb plot.

The man also is expected to testify that he saw nearly two dozen others that
Ahmad sent from the United Kingdom to train in Afghanistan, and he would
describe camping trips and training exercises that Ahmad organised in England to
groom recruits for violent jihad abroad, prosecutors said.

"Ahmad's conduct went beyond cyberspace and included real world effects and
consequences flowing from the criminal activity, regardless of the media used to
plan, co-ordinate and execute some of the conduct," prosecutors wrote in court
papers, citing his efforts to send people to Afghanistan to train for violent
jihad and emails discussing night vision goggles and safe routes into
Afghanistan.

Ahmad's lawyers say they'll respond in court objecting to the request to have
the man testify by a videotaped deposition.

Prosecutors didn't name the man they want to testify, but his description
matches that of Saajid Badat, a British citizen whose videotaped testimony was
shown at the 2012 New York City trial of a man convicted in a foiled plot to
attack the New York City subway system in 2009. A spokesman for the prosecutors
declined to comment to on the witness's identity.

Badat was convicted in London in a plot to down an American Airlines flight from
Paris to Miami with explosives hidden in his shoes. He said at that trial that
he refused a request to testify in person in the US because he remains under
indictment in Boston on charges he conspired with failed shoe bomber Richard
Reid and has been told he'd be arrested if he set foot in the United States.

Prosecutors said the man they want to testify at Ahmad's sentencing had
testified by videotape at the trial for the foiled subway plot, was indicted in
Massachusetts on charges related to the shoe bomb plot, refuses to testify in
the US and expects to be arrested upon arrival in the country.

Reid was caught aboard a plane with explosives; Badat backed out.

Badat was sentenced to 13 years in prison. But British authorities later said
that in 2009, a judge secretly reduced his sentence to 11 years to reward him
for his co-operation in terror investigations.

Ahmad and Syed Talha Ahsan pleaded guilty in December to terrorism charges.
Ahmad admitted he sought recruits, cash and equipment such as gas masks for the
Taliban regime in Afghanistan through the websites.

The two men, who were living in Britain at the time, faced charges in
Connecticut because authorities said they used an internet service provider in
the state to run one of the websites.

A prosecutor said Ahsan traveled to Afghanistan with Ahmad's assistance to fight
and attend a training camp run by al-Qaida, but Ahsan didn't admit that.

The co-operating witness, believed to be Badat, is expected to testify that
Ahmad originally recruited and radicalised him before sending him to the camp in
Afghanistan. He said he took an explosives training class with Ahsan and stayed
at a safe house in Kandahar in January 2001 during which Osama bin Laden visited
the location multiple times, prosecutors said.

Prosecutors acknowledge that Ahmad and Ashan will dispute his testimony.

"Accordingly, it is important for the court to hear from the witness to make its
own assessment, to understand the full scope and nature of the defendants'
conduct supporting terrorists, and ultimately, to resolve significant
anticipated factual disputes in connection with sentencing," prosecutors wrote.

Ahmad faces up to 25 years in prison and Ahsan faces up to 15 when they are
sentenced in July.

AP

LOAD-DATE: February 18, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication

JOURNAL-CODE: WEBBELT

                             330 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                             Daily News (New York)

                           September 21, 2009 Monday
                              SPORTS FINAL EDITION

FEDS UNSURE IF THEY KO'D PLOT

BYLINE: BY JAMES GORDON MEEK in Washington and ROCCO PARASCANDOLA and ALISON
GENDAR DAILY NEWS STAFF WRITERS

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 708 words


FEDERAL AGENTS from Denver and New York to Pakistan are still racing to solve an
Al Qaeda bomb plot, unsure whether the arrest of three suspects has put the
terror gang out of business.

"They're still looking," a senior counterterror official told the Daily News. As
to whether they have identified all the conspirators, "nobody knows the answer
for sure," the official said.

FBI arrest documents showed prime suspect Najibullah Zazi, 25, an Afghan,
visited the city from Colorado on the 9/11 anniversary carrying a laptop with
bomb-making notes he wrote. Specific attack plans or targets remain unknown, a
Justice Department statement said.

Zazi was collared in Aurora, Colo., near Denver, by the FBI on Saturday night
and was charged with lying about the bomb notes. He'll likely soon be slapped
with tougher terrorism charges, sources said.

Also nabbed for lying to feds was Flushing mosque Imam Ahmad Wais Afzali, 37, an
NYPD snitch who the FBI says alerted Zazi and his father, Mohammed, 53, after
cops quizzed him about the son.

The senior official said the feds believe the plot is now "compromised" and
would be "hard to bring forward."

"We think we have a pretty good handle on the threat, but we'd know a lot more
if Afzali hadn't tipped them in the beginning," another insider said.

The source added that court papers released yesterday reveal only a "sliver" of
the conspiracy.

"The FBI is investigating several individuals in the U.S., Pakistan and
elsewhere, relating to a plot to detonate improvised explosive devices in the
U.S.," the Justice Department said.

The Zazis will appear in court today in Denver as Afzali comes before a federal
judge in Brooklyn.

The FBI said Zazi admitted last week that Osama Bin Laden's goons trained him in
"weapons and explosives" last year at an Al Qaeda camp in Pakistan's war-torn
Pashtun tribal areas, prosecutors say.

The case erupted last week when New York-based agents raided several Queens
apartments that Zazi visited on the eve of the 9/11 anniversary after driving
all night from Colorado. He flew back Sept. 12.

The FBI found an electronic "black scale" and batteries in the flat with Zazi's
fingerprints. Scales can be used to measure chemicals for hydrogen
peroxide-based explosives, which the feds suspect was the purpose.

On a laptop in Zazi's impounded rental car, the NYPD found photographic copies
of handwritten notes on making bomb fuses, U.S. officials disclosed.

Zazi, a Pashtun, used an e-mail address to send the images to himself under the
alias "Kado Khan" - an 18th-century Afghan executed for plotting to kill a
Pashtun tribal king.

Just before Zazi's New York trip, the FBI got a flurry of secret foreign
intelligence warrants approved to wiretap calls, a source said.

Police sources said probers still have up to eight suspects in New York and
several in Denver under watch in what Assistant Attorney General David Kris
called "an ongoing and fast-paced investigation" of the first Al Qaeda cell
uncovered in the U.S. since 9/11.

The FBI and NYPD grew alarmed that Zazi and his pals might be planning an
imminent attack when they found backpacks and cell phones in an apartment. They
also learned Afzali and other Zazi associates tried to rent a 26-foot U-Haul
truck the day before Zazi got to Queens.

The feds still don't know whether the chosen weapon was a truck bomb or backpack
bombs.

Zazi has repeatedly denied being a terrorist. The court documents confirm that
he offered to admit to the feds that he visited the Al Qaeda camps, as first
reported by The News on Friday.

Al Qaeda has long sought operatives with "clean" passports who can travel easily
into the U.S., as Zazi did for years after visiting Pakistan. His most recent
trip was in January, the FBI said.

GRAPHIC: KEY REVELATIONS

According to FBI documents:

Najibullah Zazi admitted getting "weapons and explosives" training by Al Qaeda
in Pakistan's tribal areas a year ago.

The feds fear improvised explosive devices were, or are, in the making.

Zazi wrote notes on making explosives, which he photographed and e-mailed to
himself in December.

He allegedly lied about the notes to the FBI.

His fingerprints were on a "black scale" found in a Queens apartment, which
could be used to measure out explosives.

jmeek@nydailynews.com

LOAD-DATE: September 21, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: GRAPHIC;INFOGRAPHIC, Mohammed (above) and son Najibullah (inset) Zazi
are arrested by FBI in Aurora, Colo., Saturday night after probe that also
touched Flushing, Queens. Photos by AP

                             331 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                  The Guardian

                     January 19, 2017 Thursday 9:00 AM GMT

Details of plot to murder archbishop Óscar Romero revealed in new book;
Matt Eisenbrandt's Assassination of a Saint details the plot to murder the El
Salvadorian archbishop that sparked a civil war and offers an explanation

BYLINE: Nina Lakhani

SECTION: WORLD NEWS

LENGTH: 695 words


The assassination of the archbishop Óscar Romero as he celebrated mass in March
1980 remains one of the most notorious political murders of the 20th century.
The murder plunged El Salvador into a full-blown civil war which eventually left
80,000 dead and 8,000 disappeared.

Romero is still one of Latin America's most revered figures; his canonization -
the final step to sainthood - is imminent. But almost four decades after his
murder, the killers remain free.

Related:  Civil war still a bitter memory as El Salvador prepares to beatify
Romero

A new book detailing the plot to murder the archbishop casts a spotlight on that
impunity, unveiling previously unreported details of the conspiracy to kill
Romero and offers an explanation: a refusal by El Salvador's authorities and
politicians to take on the country's powerful elites.

"There are clear [evidential] threads on who gave the original order and who
paid for the murder that any concerted investigation in El Salvador would
absolutely be able to gather enough evidence to prosecute those involved," said
author Matt Eisenbrandt.

Assassination of a Saint is the first book to detail the plot to kill Romero and
probe the roles played by the wealthy business owners, politicians and military
death squad commanders who felt threatened by the archbishop's outspoken
criticism of the country's military dictatorship.

Eisenbrandt was part of a team of crusading human rights lawyers from the San
Francisco-based Centre for Justice and Accountability (CJA) who used an obscure
American law, the Alien Torts Act, to successfully bring a civil case against
one of the conspirators in Fresno, California, in 2004.

Former air force captain Álvaro Saravia admitted to participating in the plot,
and remains the only person held responsible for Romero's murder in a court of
law.

Saravia remains at large, but Eisenbrandt's book includes interviews with other
witnesses and accomplices of the crime, as well as previously unknown
information from the investigation which led to the 2004 lawsuit, including
details of the network of supporters who bankrolled the massacre of civilians
considered communist subversives.

That included the Miami-based Salvadoran businessmen who funneled money to the
death squads operated by Roberto D'Aubission - founder of the Arena party and
named by the Fresno court as the "mastermind" of the Romero assassination.

One of the book's most gripping sections is the testimony of a mole from a
leftwing guerrilla group who during the 1980s worked at the Arena party
headquarters. The rebel spy obtained access to a list of prominent financial
donors funding death squads and also saw a "blacklist" of union leaders,
teachers and others who were later killed. "Many of the top [party] leaders
spoke with great pride about the activities of the death squads," she said.

The infiltrator is one of several witnesses not named for fear of reprisals.

"Romero was allegedly murdered for $200 and life is still cheap in El Salvador;
Romero's murder remains a dangerous topic," said Eisenbrandt.

This month marks 25 years since peace accords which brought an end to the
12-year civil war, but the deal failed to bring peace to El Salvador. A 1993
amnesty law guaranteed impunity for perpetrators, and enabled the criminal
networks formed by business, military and political elites to remain intact.

Related:  Central America's rampant violence fuels an invisible refugee crisis

Last year the supreme court declared the amnesty law unconstitutional but no one
has ever been arrested for Romero's murder - or for any other war crime.
Meanwhile death squads have reportedly re-emerged in recent years, contributing
to murder rates which have made El Salvador one of the world's most dangerous
countries.

Blame can no longer be laid solely at Arena's door. The ruling FMLN - founded by
former leftwing guerrillas - has shown no interest in prosecuting the case since
winning power in 2009.

"We have to assume that for political reasons the FMLN also doesn't want anyone
to delve into questions that might go to the very foundations of Salvadoran
society," said Eisenbrandt.

LOAD-DATE: January 19, 2017

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: WEBGNS

                              All Rights Reserved


                             332 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                   USA TODAY

                           September 7, 2006 Thursday
                                 FINAL EDITION

'High-value' detainees among transfers to Gitmo

BYLINE: Richard Willing

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 1201 words


Prisoners the Bush administration has slated for trial by military tribunal at
Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, include three al-Qaeda operatives the CIA lists as
"high-value terrorist detainees."

Until recently, they had been held at undisclosed locations after being captured
by U.S. or Pakistani forces in 2002 or 2003.

They include:

Abu Zubaydah

Key allegations against him: Organized aborted "millennium" bomb plots in Jordan
and Los Angeles in late 1999. Helped move al-Qaeda operatives in Sudan, Iran and
Afghanistan.

Nationality: Palestinian; grew up in Saudi Arabia

Captured: In Faisalabad, Pakistan, after a gunfight with CIA and Pakistani
forces, March 2002

His story: In a biography released Wednesday, the CIA said Zubaydah is an
al-Qaeda operative who specialized in forging documents and tapping a network of
donors in Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.

In November 2001, Zubaydah allegedly helped move terror leader Abu Musab
al-Zarqawi and 70 Arab fighters from Afghanistan to Iran. Later, al-Zarqawi and
his fighters formed the backbone of al-Qaeda's insurgency against the U.S.
military in Iraq. Al-Zarqawi was killed there in June. In the mid-1990s,
Zubaydah sent graduates of al-Qaeda's camps in Afghanistan to fight with Muslims
in Bosnia and Chechnya. He later allegedly conducted explosives training at a
camp where several Westerners were taught, including convicted 9/11 conspirator
Zacarias Moussaoui. Zubaydah allegedly trained Ahmad Ressam, who was convicted
in the failed millennium plot that targeted Los Angeles International Airport.

After Zubaydah resisted interrogation after his capture, the CIA got permission
from the Justice Department to use a "new interrogation program." Zubaydah soon
began providing what the CIA described as "accurate and timely actionable
intelligence." The information helped lead to the capture of alleged 9/11
plotter Ramzi Binalshibh and the disruption of an unspecified plot to attack the
United States.

Khalid Sheikh Mohammed

Key allegation against him: The high-ranking al-Qaeda member is accused of
conceiving the Sept. 11 attacks, recruiting and supervising the hijackers.

Nationality: Born in Pakistan's Baluchistan province near the Iranian border and
grew up in Kuwait

Education: Mechanical engineering degree from North Carolina A&T, 1986

Captured: Pakistan, March 2003

His story: He's the most prominent captive in the war on terrorism. A CIA
biography released Wednesday said Mohammed, known in FBI documents as "KSM," is
"one of history's most infamous terrorists."

After college, Mohammed allegedly joined an Islamic "holy war" against the USA.
He allegedly helped his nephew, Ramzi Yousef, plan to bomb 11 U.S. airliners
over the Pacific Ocean in 1995. The plot ended after liquid bomb material
detonated in a Philippines safe house. Yousef was caught and Mohammed went into
hiding. In August, British officials alleged that KSM's plan -- to smuggle
liquid explosives onto jets -- had been revived by British and Pakistani
terrorists.

In 2000, while allegedly assembling the 9/11 plot from Pakistan, Mohammed helped
form an alliance between al-Qaeda and Jemaah Islamiyah, Southeast Asian Muslim
extremists.

After U.S.-led forces attacked al-Qaeda strongholds in Afghanistan in 2001,
Mohammed allegedly launched plots aimed at the USA that were foiled. These
included a plan to hijack a jet over the Pacific and crash it into a West Coast
skyscraper, and a plot to blow up gas stations and bridges in New York.

Ramzi Binalshibh

Key allegation against him: Hamburg roommate of 9/11 lead hijacker Mohamed Atta,
he allegedly assisted the 9/11 plot from Germany and Yemen and was a key aide to
Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, the accused mastermind of the attacks on America.
Initially was to have piloted a fourth hijacked jet on 9/11.

Nationality: Yemeni

Captured: Pakistan, September 2002

His story: After his capture, Binalshibh told interrogators about his embrace of
a fundamentalist form of Islam and how he became a key player in the 9/11
attacks, according to a biography released Wednesday by the CIA and the 9/11
Commission report.  While on a student visa in Germany in 1997, he met Atta,
Marwan al-Shehhi and Ziad Jarrah. Those three later would pilot the jets that
hit the World Trade Center and crashed in Shanksville, Pa. Binalshibh told
interrogators he pledged allegiance to Osama bin Laden in Afghanistan in 1999,
and he later went with Atta to meet Mohammed in Pakistan. In the original 9/11
plot, Binalshibh said, he was to have piloted another hijacked jet.

In early 2000, Binalshibh made the first of what would be four unsuccessful
attempts to get a U.S. visa. The CIA biography describes Binalshibh as the
"primary communications intermediary" between the hijackers and Mohammed before
the attacks. He communicated with Atta by e-mail and telephone and met with him
twice in Europe in 2001 for what the CIA called "in-depth briefings" on the
plot's progress. Binalshibh also allegedly helped transfer money to the
hijackers. He left Germany just before the 9/11 attacks and later joined
Mohammed in Karachi.

11 others moved to Guantanamo

Other terror suspects who have been moved to Guantanamo Bay, and the U.S.
government's allegations against them:

*Mustafa Ahmad al-Hawsawi (Saudi Arabia): Key aide to alleged 9/11 mastermind
Khalid Sheikh Mohammed who managed money used to finance the Sept. 11 attacks.

*Hambali (Indonesia): A leader of the Islamic extremist group Jemaah Islamiyah,
he had ties to al-Qaeda and Mohammed. Hambali allegedly helped plan the 2002
bombings in Bali that killed more than 200 people; he also has been linked to
the bombing of the Jakarta Marriott hotel in 2003.

*Majid Khan (Pakistan): Former Baltimore resident was an associate of Mohammed;
he is accused of researching possible attacks on U.S. gas stations and water
reservoirs.

*Lillie (Malaysia): Key aide to Hambali; allegedly helped move al-Qaeda funds to
assist bombing of the Jakarta Marriott. Allegedly slated to be a suicide
operative in an attack on Los Angeles that was never carried out.

*Ali Abd al-Aziz Ali (Kuwait): Lieutenant to Mohammed and a cousin to Ramzi
Yousef, who is serving a life sentence for masterminding the 1993 bombing of the
World Trade Center. Ali, a computer programmer, allegedly helped transfer money
and arrange travel for the 9/11 hijackers.

*Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani (Tanzania): Al-Qaeda operative allegedly specialized in
forging documents and passports.

*Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri (Saudi Arabia): Former al-Qaeda operations chief on the
Arabian Peninsula, he allegedly was the key planner of the bombing of the USS
Cole in Yemen in 2000.

*Abu Faraj al-Libi (Libya): Al-Qaeda leader and paramilitary commander in
Pakistan and Afghanistan with alleged direct ties to Osama bin Laden.

*Zubair (Malaysia): Top aide to Hambali in Jemaah Islamiyah; was allegedly
designated to take part in the canceled attack on Los Angeles.

*Walid Bin Attash (Saudi Arabia): Al-Qaeda operative and former bodyguard to bin
Laden; allegedly supervised some terrorist training in Afghanistan.

*Gouled Hassan Dourad (Somalia): Head of Mogadishu-based terror network that
supported al-Qaeda in Somalia.

Source: Office of the Director of National Intelligence

LOAD-DATE: September 7, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: NEWSPAPER

                             333 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                             Daily News (New York)

                              July 10, 2015 Friday
                          SPORTS FINAL REPLATE EDITION

Feds defused ISIS plots vs. U.S. on Fourth

BYLINE: BY BILL HUTCHINSON

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 227 words


SEVERAL ISIS-inspired terror plots aimed at killing people in the U.S. on the
the Fourth of July were thwarted by the feds, FBI Director James Comey said
Thursday.

At least 10 would-be mass killers, including two New York City men, were
arrested in the weeks leading up to the nation's birthday on charges linked to
their association with ISIS, the feds said.

"I do believe our work disrupted efforts to kill people, likely in connection
with July 4," Comey told reporters at FBI headquarters in Washington.

He declined to give details of any specific plot, but some of them were "very
serious efforts to kill people in the United States," he said.

Among those arrested prior to the holiday was ISIS wannabe Fareed Mumuni, 21, of
Staten Island, who attempted to stab a federal agent with a large kitchen knife
when his home was raided June 17.

Mumuni's arrest came a day after his alleged terror partner, Munther Omar Saleh,
20, of Queens was charged with plotting an attack against targets in the city.

On May 7, "Saleh emailed himself information from the Internet regarding the
construction of a pressure cooker bomb" like those used in the deadly 2013
Boston Marathon attack, according to a complaint filed in Brooklyn Federal
Court. Mumuni confessed to discussing with Saleh how to construct a pressure
cooker bomb and plans to travel to the Middle East to join ISIS.

LOAD-DATE: July 10, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: NLVL

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             334 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            January 31, 2012 Tuesday

USA plot against Syria aims to deal blow to resistance front - Iran leader

LENGTH: 272 words


Iran's leader Ayatollah Seyyed Ali Khamene'i has said: "The main aim of the
USA's plot in Syria is to deal a blow to the resistance front in the region,"
Mehr News Agency reported on 31 January. In a meeting with the secretary-general
of the Palestinian Islamic Jihad, Ramadan Abdallah, on the same day, Ayatollah
Khamene'i referred to "the developments over the past year and the Islamic
awakening" saying: "If the Islamic nation in various countries is committed to
diligence, resistance and trust in God, God's promise of victory will definitely
be fulfilled as we have witnessed [its realization] over the past year."

Elsewhere in his remarks, he touched on the conditions in Syria saying: "If we
look at the issue of Syria from a comprehensive viewpoint, the USA's plot
against Syria is quite clear; unfortunately, certain foreign and regional
countries have been involved in this plot."

The Iranian leader continued: "The USA's main goal is to deal a blow to the
resistance front in the region, because Syria supports the Palestinian
resistance and Lebanon's Islamic resistance."

He added: "If Syria promises the Americans that it would stop its support for
the Palestinian and Lebanese resistance, all issues will be resolved. Syria's
only offence [in the eye of the West] is its support for the resistance
[movement]."

Concerning Iran's stance on Syria, Ayatollah Khamene'i said: "The Islamic
Republic will support all reforms which are in the interest of the Syrian
people, and it is against the interference of the USA and its followers in
Syria's domestic issues."

Source: Mehr news agency, Tehran, in Persian 1639 gmt 31 Jan 12

                        Lancaster New Era (Pennsylvania)

                               May 5, 2006 Friday

Garden plot rentals still available

BYLINE: Lancaster New Era Staff

SECTION: A; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 102  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Garden plots are still available for rent in Lancaster County Central Park.

Each year, the Lancaster County Department of Parks and Recreation rents plots
of 20 feet by 20 feet for $16 and plots of 20 feet by 40 feet for $20. Organic
plots also are available that have been free of pesticides and herbicides for
more than three years.

Gardeners of all skill levels can rent garden plots to grow their own flowers
and vegetables. To rent a plot or for more information, call the parks office at
299-8215 or visit the park office, located off Chesapeake Street, between 8:30
a.m. and 5 p.m., Mondays through Fridays.

LOAD-DATE: May 6, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             336 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Capital (Annapolis, MD)

                             August 27, 2012 Monday

Cape St. Claire gardeners prepare for Harvest Spaghetti Dinner

BYLINE: WENDI WINTERS, For Capital Gazette

SECTION: A; Pg.11

LENGTH: 1071  words


It's been a long time since the rolling lands at historic Goshen Farm in Cape
St. Claire have been utilized as farmland. Behind the ancient house, now
encircled by cyclone fencing to deter vandals, another fence made of rustic,
recycled wooden pickets loops around a lush, green garden.

The Goshen Farm Sharing Garden consists of 54 10-by-10 plots rented by area
residents who've tilled the soil, enriched it with compost and planted a
cornucopia of herbs, tomatoes, cucumbers, carrots, lettuces, string beans,
squash, melons, peppers, corn and zinnias.

One plot has been tended by a first-grade class from Cape St. Claire Elementary
School. "The children learned where their food comes from and how it looks while
it's growing," commented the garden's founder and organizational Earth Mother,
Nicole Neboshynsky.

This is the first year the garden has been sprouting. It took a year to acquire
electricity and water, and work out the details. "We have plot renewals coming
up in October for the 2013 growing season," said Nicole. "We've learned a lot
about what to change or do differently next year."

Walking through the verdant garden, Nicole pointed out gardeners have been
assisting each other. They will water a plot when its tenant is out of town, or
pluck the produce so it doesn't rot on the vine. "We've had tons of tomatoes
this year," she smiled.

On Sept. 22, the gardeners will celebrate their debut year with their first
Harvest Spaghetti Dinner. There will be two sessions - at 5 and 7 p.m. - at the
Cape St. Claire United Methodist Church, 855 Chestnut Tree Drive.

Several gardeners are pooling their harvested tomatoes and other veggies grown
in the garden to create a fresh, yummy, homemade spaghetti sauce, which will be
served with pasta, bread and a variety of potluck side dishes. Admission is $5.
Seating is limited and must be reserved at www.goshenfarm.org/community-garden.
All the funds raised will go toward the Maryland state capital campaign grant to
restore the Goshen Farmhouse.

"We're already making some of the sauce now so we'll have enough," said Nicole.
"It takes 12 pounds of tomatoes to make one gallon of sauce."

Trader Joes, Sam's Club and the Outback Steakhouse are donating additional food
items or gift cards to the dinner.

If you'd like to visit the Goshen Farmhouse, one of the few remaining examples
of a colonial-era farmhouse in Anne Arundel County, members of the Goshen Farm
Preservation Society are hosting an open house from 1 to 4 p.m. Sept. 15. The
site is located at 1422 Cape St. Claire Road - follow the signs. There will be
tours, walking paths, Goshen Farm books and T-shirts for sale, plus
refreshments. Admission is free. For information, visit
http://goshenfarm.org/2012/08/open-house.

Great 8

Last year, Jan Sullivan, a personal trainer and owner of Core Connection in
Annapolis, was inspired to join the Great 8 Foundation's 500-mile bicycle
fundraising ride through eight states from Massachusetts to Maryland after
reading about it in this column.

Just days before the Great 8 Foundation ride began, Jan teamed up with locals
Glenn Drake of Cape St. Claire, an Army retiree and partner in the Crownsville
firm Drake-Kinzer Wealth Management; and retired Marine and former Navy
basketball player "Big Dave" David Bethel of Severn, employed by Lockheed
Martin.

The trio raised an astonishing $43,000 of the $157,000 total raised by all 16
riders involved the grueling project.

The trio is training again for this year's ride, which has grown to 20 riders
from several states and a 2012 goal of $200,000.

The MS Great 8 Foundation ride begins outside Portland, Maine, on Oct. 7, and
ends in Times Square in New York City on Oct. 14. In between, the bicyclists
will pedal through eight states in eight days.

A fourth Marylander is joining them this year, making it a quartet: estate
planner Edward Jackson is from Baltimore. The Maryland group's goal is $32,000,
but they hope to soar past last year's results.

The foursome is motivated by family members who've battled MS - Multiple
Sclerosis - still a devastating, incurable disease.

For Edward, he's doing it for his ex-wife who has MS. Jan's father struggled
with it for 45 years before passing away in 1992. Jan has been involved in MS
fundraising since 1985. Dave's daughter Ashtyn, a 7th grader at Arundel Middle
has an aunt with MS. Glenn's mother-in-law is an MS sufferer.

"We ride to bring awareness, halt MS's advance, find a cure and find out 'why,'"
boomed Big Dave. "We want to know 'What's the cause and what's the cure,'" added
Jan. "We want to raise awareness as we are raising money to fund a cure," stated
Glenn.

Off the training trail, the group is holding a fundraiser at 7 p.m. Sept. 13 at
Level Small Plates, 69 West St. in Annapolis. Twenty percent of the evening's
proceeds benefit MS Great 8 Foundation efforts.

For the Great 8 bike ride fundraiser, minus credit card service charges, 100
percent of the funds raised by the four from Maryland will be given to area MS
Chapters and spent locally on MS research and support for MS sufferers.

For more information or to donate, visit www.msgreat8.org or email
cycling@msgreat8.org On the website, click on Glenn, Dave, Jan or Edward's names
to contribute.

Golf tournament

If you are teed off at the shopworn condition of the Broadneck High field house,
you can do something about it - and have fun at the same time.

Tee off with your friends during the 22nd annual Broadneck high School Athletic
Boosters Golf Tournament on Sept. 28 at Compass Pointe Golf Course on its
South/West Course. It's located at 9010 Fort Smallwood Road in Pasadena.

Registration is 7:30 a.m. with a modified shotgun start at 8:30 a.m. The cost is
$125 per golf, $400 per foursome, $75 per coaches and teachers. In addition to
trophies and prizes for winners in various categories, the fee includes
complimentary bag service, a pre-golf continental breakfast, driving range,
beverage carts, a post-golf buffet dinner and more.

Net proceeds go to the Boosters Club's Field House restoration fund.

Gold medalist

Congratulations! Kaitlyn Karnbach - an eighth-grader at Magothy River Middle
School and daughter of Cape St. Claire firefighter I/EMT Charles Karnbach -
returned last week from the 2012 Acro Gymnastic Nationals in Detroit.

A student at 1st Class Gymnastics, Kaitlyn and partners Kylie Sarno of
Crownsville and Abbey Cohen of Glen Burnie won gold medals competing in the
Level 5 trio event.

                             337 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             July 14, 2001 Saturday

Ex-Montrealer guilty of terrorism charge

BYLINE: PAUL KORING

SECTION: INTERNATIONAL NEWS; Pg. A8

LENGTH: 603 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Mokhtar Haouari was convicted on terrorism and fraud charges yesterday, the
second Montreal-based Algerian émigré found guilty of involvement in a foiled
plot to blow up the Los Angeles airport during the millennium celebrations.

Mr. Haouari, who disrupted his trial with a violent head-banging incident that
left him dazed and the jury shocked, showed no emotion as the verdict was read.

His lawyer, Daniel Ollen, said later that his client was "very disappointed" and
that an appeal was planned.

Mr. Haouari, 32, faces up to 85 years in prison if he gets the maximum sentence
on every charge. Sentencing was set for Oct. 17.

Although the federal jury in New York convicted Mr. Haouari of conspiracy in the
terrorist plot, he was acquitted of aiding and abetting terrorism.

A key difference in the two charges is that the conspiracy count didn't require
he have actual knowledge of the plot.

He was also convicted of four fraud charges.

The defence made no effort to dispute a mass of evidence presented by the
prosecution that covered years of systematic bank and credit-card fraud schemes.

Although the defence conceded that Mr. Haouari "was a criminal," his lawyer
contended that he had no knowledge that Ahmed Ressam, another Algerian who lived
in Montreal, was assembling explosives and planning to plant a bomb at the Los
Angeles airport in December of 1999.

It took the three-man, nine-woman jury less than two days of deliberations to
reach a verdict that seemed to accept, at least partly, the defence argument
that Mr. Haouari was unaware of Mr. Ressam's mission when he gave him money,
furnished him with a fake Quebec driver's licence and arranged for another
Algerian, Abdel Ghani Meskini, to meet with Mr. Ressam in Seattle.

Outside the court, several jurors said they believed the government had failed
to prove Mr. Haouari knew what Mr. Ressam was planning.

Mr. Haouari, who was arrested in Montreal in January of 2000 after a massive
investigation on both sides of the border, didn't fight extradition to the
United States.

Both Mr. Ressam and Mr. Meskini, who have been convicted for their roles but
made deals to co-operate with prosecutors to get their sentences reduced,
testified against Mr. Haouari during his two-week trial.

The sentencing dates for the two men were postponed until after they had
testified.

Although investigators believe they know the names and roles of several others
involved in the plot, only Abdel Majid Dahoumane is in custody. Mr. Dahoumane,
who is accused of having helped Mr. Ressam gather the explosive materials in
Vancouver, was arrested this year in Algeria but it remains unclear whether he
will be handed over to U.S. authorities.

Although Mr. Ressam testified at length during Mr. Haouari's trial, detailing
his terrorist training in Afghanistan and his fervour in waging a jihad (holy
war) against the United States, no clear link was established between the plot
to bomb the Los Angeles airport and Osama bin Laden.

Nonetheless, the Saudi fugitive financier is widely believed to be behind the
millennium plot.

The Montreal-based plot was thwarted when a U.S. customs officer decided to
search Mr. Ressam's rental car at Port Angeles, Wash., when the Algerian drove
off a ferry from Victoria.

Inside the car, officers found a trunkload of explosives, four timing devices
and various false identity papers.

A few days earlier, Jordanian authorities had made a series of arrests in
another alleged millennium plot.

Both have been linked to Mr. bin Laden, as were the almost simultaneous bombings
of two U.S. embassies in East Africa in 1998.

LOAD-DATE: September 21, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Illustration

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved


                             338 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       Austin American-Statesman (Texas)

                            August 16, 2005 Tuesday

Muslim group must hurry to establish cemetery;
Pflugerville burial ground is only one of its kind in Travis County

BYLINE: Karem Said, AMERICAN-STATESMAN STAFF

SECTION: METRO/STATE; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 817 words


Eight members of Austin's Muslim community are breaking ground in a Pflugerville
cemetery in a bid to extend their Central Texas roots.

Led by President Mohsin Lari, Muslim Community Support Services is building the
only Islamic burial ground in Travis County, plot by plot.

The group has sold 188 plots to local Muslims but must sell 12 more by Saturday
to satisfy a contract signed in December 2000 with Cook-Walden/Capital Parks
Funeral Home.

If they fall short, they will lose their claim to 300 additional plots in
Cook-Walden's cemetery -- and their dream of a common resting place for future
generations of local Muslims.

So far, only 10 people are buried in the 188 plots in Cook-Walden's far
northeast corner, where a paved road transitions to gravel and a modest hedge
marks the Muslim enclave.

Lari, 53, was born and raised in Pakistan and moved to Austin in 1994 after
living in Boston for 17 years. Soft-spoken and concise, the software quality
assurance manager is hardly an effusive salesman.

His group has relied on an e-mail campaign boosted with fliers, phone calls and
word-of-mouth at local mosques.

The organization does inter-religious work, offers a scholarship to
college-bound Muslims and provides support for refugees and battered women.

But Lari and three friends created the organization in 1999 to establish a
cemetery near their homes.

"That's required by our religion," Lari said. "You have to be buried in a Muslim
cemetery."

They sold a whopping 35 plots last month, but Lari fears that they've exhausted
their market of older buyers.

"The problem is that most of the community is young, and they don't think about
death," Lari said.

At $1,150 a plot, some prospective buyers are reluctant to sink money into land
that could be hard to sell should they leave Austin, Lari said.

Plus, local Muslims have another option: a free, Muslim-only cemetery in Lytton
Springs, about 25 miles from downtown Austin in Caldwell County. About 100
people are buried at the thirty-year-old cemetery owned by the Masjid Khadijah
Bint Khwailid mosque on Manor Road.

"You don't pay a dime," funeral director Issa Kamara said.

Lari said his group wanted a Muslim cemetery closer to Austin.

"If we died, our kids would not be able to visit us that often," Lari said of
his wife and their three daughters.

Cook-Walden's Pflugerville cemetery also includes a Jewish section for Austin's
Congregation Beth Israel, and a new Catholic section was created with oversight
from the Diocese of Austin.

For Muslims with doubts about sharing a cemetery with other faiths, the
Muslim-only cemetery in Lytton Springs is religiously unassailable. The
cemetery's managers recently sent an e-mail emphasizing this point to an
extensive list of Muslims, making Lari's job that much harder.

Yet Muslims are often buried in separate sections of public cemeteries. Sayyid
Syeed, secretary for the Islamic Society of North America, said it's unrealistic
for Muslims to oppose mixed cemeteries such as Cook-Walden's.

"Here in Indianapolis, and all over the country . . . we cannot afford to have
entire Muslim cemeteries," he said, adding that many cemeteries have Muslim
sections, like the one at Cook-Walden.

There, the budding Muslim section is laid out according to Islamic custom, with
the graves positioned so the souls of the dead can face Mecca on the Day of
Judgment.

Lari said his group chose to work with Cook-Walden because the funeral home was
the most flexible about grave position and another essential custom: Muslims are
not buried in caskets but in white cloths.

The group did compromise on a requirement by the cemetery that isn't part of
Islamic burial tradition: Each grave must have a headstone.

If Muslim Community Support Services can't sell the 12 remaining plots,
Cook-Walden might sell the land to non-Muslims, an encroachment that might upset
some Muslim plot owners.

So Lari has asked Cook-Walden for an extension. He's also targeted a few wealthy
Muslims for no-interest loans to purchase the remaining plots. As the deadline
approaches, he's still hopeful he can persuade Muslims to follow Ali Khataw's
example of planning for their afterlives.

Khataw and his father have purchased 20 plots in the Cook-Walden section, more
than they need for their extended family. They've donated six plots to
low-income Muslims, and they plan to donate five more.

Khataw moved from Pakistan to Austin -- where, he said, his "American roots
start" -- in 1980 to open an engineering firm.

He said he supports the cemetery project because his religion encourages regular
visits to family graves.

"When you go to a graveyard, it makes you realize a person's insignificance. How
small a person is," he said.

Khataw said that taking his children to the cemetery will educate them about
life and death.

"It's opened up a new avenue," he said. "It's good for the family."

ksaid@statesman.com; 445-3851

LOAD-DATE: August 16, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Mohsin Lari says his group, Muslim Community Support Services, was
founded in 1999 with the goal of creating an Islamic cemetery nearer the
members' homes. It is a goal realized at Cook-Walden/Capital Parks Cemetery in
Pflugerville.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                  Copyright 2005 The Austin American Statesman


                             339 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                            December 14, 2012 Friday

Danish historian finds unknown Andersen fairy tale

SECTION: WIRE; Pg. A6

LENGTH: 896 words


ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (AP) - An imprisoned man whose infatuation with Justin Bieber
included a tattoo of the pop star on his leg has told investigators in New
Mexico he hatched a plot to kill the singer, according to documents filed in a
New Mexico court.

An affidavit filed in Las Cruces said Dana Martin told investigators he
persuaded a man he met in prison and the man's nephew to kill Bieber, along with
Bieber's personal bodyguard and two others not connected to the pop star.

The plot contained several gruesome details. Investigators say the plotters
wanted to castrate two of the victims with hedge clippers before traveling to
New York City to find Bieber. The targets of the castration plot were not
connected to Bieber, authorities say, and it doesn't appear that the pop singer
was ever in immediate danger and no one was killed in the alleged elaborate plot
.

Martin, a Vermont man who is serving two life sentences for the 2000 killing of
a 15-year-old girl, said he was angry at Bieber because he didn't respond to any
of his letters.

"This perceived slight made Mr. Martin upset and that, coupled with Mr. Martin's
perception of being a 'nobody' in prison, led him to begin plotting the kidnap
and murder of Victim 3," court documents said.

The documents identified Victim 3 as "J.B.," which New Mexico State Police
spokesman Lt. Robert McDonald later confirmed was Justin Bieber.

Martin told investigators that Mark Staake and Tanner D. Ruane headed from New
Mexico to the East Coast, planning to be near a Bieber concert scheduled in New
York City after killing and castrating two others. They missed a turn and
crossed into Canada from Vermont. Staake was arrested on an outstanding warrant.
Ruane was arrested later.

Court documents say Martin told investigators that Bieber was the "ultimate
target."

New York State Police said Thursday that troopers recovered tools and documents
associated with the conspiracy while executing a search warrant on Ruane's
vehicle.

LONDON (AP) - In 2008, Queen Elizabeth II asked academics why no one saw the
financial crisis coming. On Thursday, she finally got an answer.

Sujit Kapadia from the Bank of England's Financial Services Committee gave the
queen three reasons as she visited the central bank in London. He told her that
financial crises are like earthquakes - rare and difficult to predict. Kapadia
also said growing complacency since markets were stable led people to think
regulation wasn't necessary, and that people didn't realize how interconnected
the financial system had become.

Elizabeth asked what is being done to prevent another global downturn,
acknowledging that "people got a bit lax" and that perhaps financial crises are
"difficult to foresee."

On her visit, the queen and her husband also toured vaults full of gold.

WASHINGTON (AP) - Carole King has a friend in the Library of Congress. She's the
first woman to win the library's Gershwin Prize for Popular Song.

In her five decades of songwriting, King's hits have included "You've Got a
Friend," "So Far Away" and "(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman." The
library said Thursday that King will be the fifth person to receive the prize.
Prior recipients include Stevie Wonder and Paul McCartney.

Librarian of Congress James Billington said King's work has been recorded by
many artists to communicate universal human emotions like love, joy and pain.

King will receive the prize in the spring and said in a statement that she looks
forward to performing in Washington.

Honorees are typically saluted at the White House.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) - For years, the somber fairy tale about a lonely
candle dwelt in oblivion at the bottom of a box in Denmark's National Archives.
Its discovery has sent ripples through the literary world because it is believed
to be one of the first tales written by Hans Christian Andersen.

Retired historian Esben Brage said he found the six-page handwritten tale,
"Tallow Candle," in early October while searching through boxes that belonged to
wealthy families from Andersen's hometown of Odense.

in central Denmark.

The had been left seemingly untouched at the bottom of one of the boxes.

"I was ecstatic. I immediately contacted the curator to tell him about my
discovery. I had never imagined this," Brage said.

The short story tells the tale of how a tallow candle seeks help from a tinder
box to be able to ignite itself.

A senior curator at the Hans Christian Andersen Museum in Odense said the work
is likely one of the author's earliest, written seven years before his official
debut in 1830.

"I often get calls about stuff thought to have been off Andersen's hand. Most of
the time, it is not. This time I was thrilled," Ejnar Stig Askgaard told The
Associated Press. "This is a very early attempt at prose by Andersen who was
then 18."

Askgaard said Andersen knew the Bunkeflod widow well and regularly visited her,
reading to her and borrowing books from her, even after he moved to Copenhagen
to attend university.

"The text is not at the level of the more mature fairy tales that we know from
Andersen's later writing," Askgaard said. "I have no doubts ... this has been
written by Andersen."

Born to a charwoman and a shoemaker in 1805, Andersen wrote nearly 160 fairy
tales in his life including classics like "The Ugly Duckling" and "The Little
Mermaid." He has also written dozens of novels, poems and travel journals.

LOAD-DATE: December 14, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved


                             340 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                The New York Post

                           November 23, 2004 Tuesday

'9/11' PLOTS IN BRITAIN - HEATHROW PLAN FOILED

BYLINE: KATE SHEEHY

SECTION: Sports+Late City Final; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 354 words


Chilling plans for a 9/11- style terror onslaught - complete with hijacked
planes - targeted London's Heathrow Airport and famed financial district Canary
Wharf, it was reported yesterday.

The ghoulish copycat plot was thwarted by British intelligence sometime after
the U.S. terror attacks on Sept. 11, 2001 - and before the would-be suicide
pilots could finish training for their fiendish mission - sources told Britain's
ITV News.

The ominous plan was one of up to five targeting the country and concocted by al
Qaeda, which was behind 9/11, a senior administrative source in Britain said.

The newly detailed plot indicated that the terrorists specifically were aiming
at the London airport, as well as three skyscrapers in Canary Wharf.

The tallest of the targeted buildings was the 50-story One Canada Square. The
two other looming structures beside it also are believed to have been in al
Qaeda's crosshairs.

News of the plot surfaced as the British government prepared to outline proposed
major new legislation to better combat terrorism.

Included in the proposed measures are the creation of citizen ID cards and the
establishment of a national crime agency similar to the FBI.

British Home Secretary David Blunkett, who also is pushing for juror-less terror
trials, admitted some of the measures might raise the alarm with civil-liberty
advocates.

"[But] we will have to take whatever steps are necessary, particularly in terms
of security and intelligence, because it's no good picking up the pieces -
literally - afterward," Blunkett said.

Just last August, a group of eight terror suspects - including one allegedly
stockpiling "reconnaissance plans" of key, vulnerable U.S. targets - were nabbed
in Britain.

The main suspect in that case, Dhiren Barot, reputedly had plans of the New York
Stock Exchange and Citigroup headquarters in Manhattan, the Prudential building
in Newark and the International Monetary Fund in Washington.

All of the men are believed to have been plotting to use "radioactive materials,
toxic gases, chemicals and/or explosives" in an upcoming terror attack,
authorities said.

LOAD-DATE: November 23, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                      Copyright 2004 N.Y.P. Holdings, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                             341 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                             July 22, 2014 Tuesday

Rights report raises questions over US terror prosecutions

BYLINE: Spencer Ackerman in New York

SECTION: GUARDIAN INTERNATIONAL PAGES; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 422 words


Nearly all of the highest-profile domestic terrorism plots in the United States
since 9/11 featured the "direct involvement" of government agents or informants,
a new report says. Some of the controversial "sting" operations "were proposed
or led by informants", bordering on entrapment by law enforcement.

The report, released yesterday by Human Rights Watch, portrays a system that
features not just the sting operations but secret evidence, anonymous juries,
pretrial detentions and convictions significantly removed from actual plots.

"In some cases the FBI may have created terrorists out of law-abiding
individuals," the report alleges. Of the 494 cases related to terrorism the US
has tried since 9/11, the plurality of convictions - 18% overall - are not for
thwarted plots but for "material support" charges, a broad category that permits
prosecutors to pursue charges with tenuous connections to a terrorist act or
group. In one such incident the basis for a material-support case alleging a man
provided "military gear" to al-Qaida turned out to be waterproof socks.

Human Rights Watch's findings call into question the post-9/11 shift taken by
the FBI and other law enforcement agencies toward stopping terrorist plots
before they occur. The report focuses on 27 cases and accordingly stops short of
drawing systemic conclusions. It also finds several trials and convictions for
"deliberate attempts at terrorism or terrorism financing" that it does not
challenge.

The four high-profile domestic plots it found free of government involvement
were the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing; Najibullah Zazi's 2009 plot to bomb the
New York subway; the attempted Times Square car bombing of 2010; and the 2002
shooting at Los Angeles International Airport's El Al counter.

While the FBI has relied on informants, for terrorism cases informants insert
themselves into mosques, businesses and community gatherings and can cajole
people toward a plot "who perhaps would never have participated in a terrorist
act on their own", the study found.

Many trade information for cash. The FBI in 2008 estimated it had 15,000 paid
informants. About 30% of post-9/11 terrorism cases are considered sting
operations in which informants played an "active role" leading to arrest,
according to studies cited in the Human Rights Watch report. Among those roles
are making comments "that appeared designed to inflame the targets" on
"politically sensitive" subjects, and pushing operations forward if a target's
"opinions were deemed sufficiently troubling".

LOAD-DATE: July 22, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2014 Guardian Newspapers Limited
                              All Rights Reserved


                             342 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                  The Guardian

                             July 22, 2014 Tuesday

"opinions were deemed sufficiently troubling".

LOAD-DATE: July 21, 2014

                   Inland Valley Daily Bulletin (Ontario, CA)

                             October 7, 2005 Friday

Anti-terrorism officials reveal new details of 2002 plot

BYLINE: D avid Sanger, N.Y. Times News Service

LENGTH: 639 words


WASHINGTON Government counterterrorism officials gave new details on Friday of
what the White House said was a foiled 2002 plot to fly hijacked airplanes into
targets on the West Coast, but their account suggested that the Bush
administration may not have understood the dimensions of the plot until two
major terror suspects were caught in 2003.

Both of the suspects, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and Riduan Isamuddin, better known
as Hambali, had been involved in plans for such an attack, they said.

President Bush referred obliquely to the planning in a speech on Thursday, when
he said the United States and its partners had stopped three potential attacks
on American soil, and seven more around the world. The White House cited it
later Thursday in a list of the 10 failed plots.

While several of those alleged plots had been disclosed before, officials said
that the 2002 effort had not been publicized until now. Another foiled plot, the
White House said, was aimed at East Coast cities in 2003.

The plan to attack Los Angeles appears to have grown out of a larger plan for
attacks on both coasts, not just New York and Washington, on Sept. 11, 2001.

As described by investigators on Friday in an account that parallels the
findings of the commission that investigated the 9/11 attacks Khalid Shaikh
Mohammed, the architect of the 9/11 plan, was told to delay parts of the broader
plan until later.

It is not clear how far any subsequent planning against Los Angeles advanced
after the attacks of Sept. 11, or exactly how it was headed off during the broad
international campaign against terrorists that ensued.

"It basically got subcontracted out to Jemaah Islamiyah," Isamuddin's radical
Islamic group based in Indonesia, said a senior counterterrorism official, who
had read an account of Mohammed's interrogation after his capture in Pakistan in
2003. "They found a pilot, and some others to overpower the plane. But it never
came together." One apparent target was the Library Tower in Los Angeles, now
known as the US Bank tower, but three counterterrorism officials said they
believed there were other targets in mind as well.

All the officials interviewed about the plots declined to speak on the record,
because the White House had declassified a very limited amount of information to
substantiate the president's statements. But one senior administration official
familiar with the case said that the Bush administration "knew that the plot had
been disrupted before" Mohammed was captured in Pakistan in 2003. Later that
year, Isamuddin was arrested in Thailand. "But we didn't understand the details
at that time," the official said.

[STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.]

"We just knew it involved hijacked planes and the West Coast, including multiple
targets on the coast."

Officials familiar with the information passed to the Los Angeles authorities
say local officials there were given only vague warnings in 2002 that a tall
building might be targeted. But it was not until the next year, the officials
said, that Los Angeles authorities received summaries of the interrogation of
Mohammed. Later they obtained similar summaries of the interrogations of
Isamuddin.

There are significant differences between Mohammed's description of the plot and
Isamuddin's, officials said, referring to how the plan was inspired. Other
members of the cell were captured as well, some during the hunt for those who
carried out a deadly nightclub bombing in Bali in 2002. "By 2003, we were
convinced we had sufficiently undermined the cell that was involved in the plot
," the senior administration official said.

The officials gave few details of the 2003 plot against cities on the East
Coast, saying only that it had been disrupted by a partner of the United States
at a relatively early stage.

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                           September 16, 2016 Friday

Guide maps out PLOTS areas

SECTION: A; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 213 words


The North Dakota Game and Fish Department's Private Land Open To Sportsmen Guide
for 2016 is available online at the Department's website, gf.nd.gov, and was
expected to become available at most vendors throughout the state in early
September.

The guide features about 730,000 PLOTS acres. Because the guide is printed in
mid-August, some PLOTS tracts highlighted in the guide may have been removed
from the program since the time of printing. There also will be some PLOTS
tracts where the habitat and condition of the tract will have changed
significantly. Conversely, Game and Fish may have added new tracts to the
program after the guide went to press.

To minimize possible confusion, Game and Fish will update PLOTS map sheets
weekly on its website.

The PLOTS Guide features maps highlighting these walk-in areas, identified in
the field by inverted triangular yellow signs, as well as other public lands.

The guides are free and will be available at license vendors in the state, by
walk-in at the Game and Fish Department's Bismarck office and at district
offices in Riverdale, Harvey (Lonetree), Williston, Dickinson, Jamestown and
Devils Lake.

The guides are not available to mail, so hunters will have to pick them up at a
local vendor or print individual maps from the website.

                         Geelong Advertiser (Australia)

                            August 12, 2006 Saturday

Officials probe dozens

BYLINE: PRASHANT RAO

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 503  words


AUTHORITIES in Britain and Pakistan quizzed more than 30 terror suspects
yesterday as an increasingly global dimension emerged to an alleged plot to blow
up US-bound aircraft.

The Bank of England identified and froze the accounts of 19 of the 24 men
arrested in Britain, and Pakistan said it had helped uncover the plot with the
arrests last week of seven people, including two Britons of Pakistani origin.

The conspiracy -- which US officials said was the most serious since the
September 11, 2001, attacks -- involved terrorists smuggling seemingly innocuous
liquids in drinks bottles or other containers for assembling into bombs aboard
US-bound planes from Britain.

Chaos at British and foreign airports eased 24 hours after Britain went on
maximum alert before dawn on Thursday over what one police chief called a plan
to commit ''mass murder on an unimaginable scale''.

Hundreds of flights were cancelled and while airlines began yesterday to make up
the backlog, passengers were warned of delays and disruption amid heightened
security measures.

US officials estimated up to 10 planes were targeted in an operation they said
bore the imprint of Osama bin Laden's al-Qaeda terror network.

While Britain's domestic Press Association quoted senior police sources as
saying they believed up to nine planes were due to have been blown up, other
British media said between five and 12 planes were to be used.

The Independent newspaper said anti-terror officers staged raids to arrest the
24 suspects, mostly believed to be of Pakistani origin, ''after it emerged that
the plotters might be ready to strike within 48 hours''.

A US intelligence official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the alleged
plot had targeted United Airlines, American Airlines and Continental Airlines
flights to New York, Washington and Los Angeles, and possibly other major hubs
such as Boston and Chicago.

According to The Washington Post, the first whiff of the alleged plot came after
the July 2005 suicide bombings on London's transit system, when a member of the
Muslim community tipped off British intelligence about the suspicious activities
of an acquaintance.

The vague tip led investigators to a well co-ordinated and long-planned plot to
bomb multiple US-bound transatlantic flights, a senior European intelligence
official said.

London's Metropolitan Police was brought into the investigation in December,
British media reported. Pakistani officials were also brought in.

A senior Pakistani Government official said one of the two Britons was arrested
in the southern city of Karachi and the other in the eastern city of Lahore.

The pair, the official said, ''were key members of the Britain-based network of
militants. The arrests in Pakistan were made prior to the action in London.

''They were in full knowledge of the plot to blow up the airlines, and the
information was passed on to Britain and US intelligence,'' the official added.

US President George W. Bush was informed as early as Sunday of the inquiry, the
White House said.

                        Facts on File World News Digest

                                  July 6, 2006

Terrorism;
FBI Arrests Seven in Sears Tower Plot

SECTION: Pg. 529D3

LENGTH: 409 words


The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) June 22 arrested seven men who were
allegedly planning terrorist attacks on several targets, including the 110-story
Sears Tower in Chicago. FBI officials said the suspects, apprehended in an
undercover sting operation, had thought they were dealing with Al Qaeda
international terrorist network operatives. They described the men as having
"aspirations" but "no means" to carry out the attacks. [See 2006 Terrorism: Man
Convicted in NYC Subway Bomb Plot; 2006 Terrorism: Bush Details Plot Against Los
Angeles; 2005 Spain: Al Qaeda Trial Opens; Other Development]

Federal officials June 23 at a press conference revealed that five of the
suspects, including their leader, Narseal Batiste, had been arrested in Miami,
Florida. Another man was arrested in Atlanta, Georgia, and the seventh was
already in custody on a probation charge. Five of the men were U.S. citizens,
one was a Haitian citizen with permanent U.S. residency, and another was a
Haitian in the U.S. illegally. Officials said the group adhered to a vague
militant ideology combining elements of Christianity and Islam.

At the news conference, Attorney General Alberto Gonzales and Deputy FBI
Director John Pistole said the suspects did not have the capacity to carry out
their plot for attacks on the Sears Tower, the tallest building on the North
American continent, or on the FBI buildings in Miami, New York City, Los Angeles
and Washington, D.C. However, Gonzales emphasized that the group "did take
sufficient steps that we believe does support this prosecution." He added,
"These homegrown terrorists may prove to be as dangerous as groups like Al
Qaeda."

The four-count indictment charged the men with conspiring to bomb targets in the
U.S. and to provide material support to Al Qaeda. It detailed how an undercover
FBI informant posing as an Al Qaeda operative met with Batiste in December 2005
after the group sought aid from foreign organizations. Batiste allegedly
requested supplies, which the indictment said included "boots, uniforms, machine
guns, radios and vehicles," in order to build an "Islamic Army" and attack the
U.S. However, the informant provided only boots for the group, and a video
camera that the suspects allegedly used to conduct surveillance of several
federal buildings.

U.S. Magistrate Judge Ted Bandstra July 5 denied bail for the six men being held
in Miami, and the suspect in Atlanta was also denied bail.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                             347 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                   January 09, 1999, Saturday, Final Edition

Corn Seed Producers Move to Avert Pesticide Resistance

Rick Weiss, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A04

LENGTH: 825 words


Responding to pressure from federal regulators, environmentalists and others, a
coalition of the nation's major producers of genetically engineered corn seed
said yesterday that they would require farmers to grow sizable plots of
non-engineered, old-fashioned corn along with their new biotechnology varieties.

The companies hope to allay increasing fears among scientists that some newly
marketed varieties of gene-altered corn, which exude potent insecticides day in
and day out, may be speeding the evolution of pesticide-resistant "super"
insects.

The announcement, which caught many farmers and others by surprise, was
announced by an official of St. Louis-based Monsanto Co., the country's largest
producer of gene-altered corn, at an Environmental Protection Agency meeting.

EPA officials welcomed the coalition's plan with cautious optimism. "We have not
had an opportunity to review the details of this agreement. However, we hope the
final version will contain the elements EPA feels are required for the effective
management of these products," Loretta Ucelli, EPA's associate administrator of
public affairs, said in a statement.

But the plan was immediately criticized as inadequate by some scientists and
environmental activists, who noted that it calls for plots of non-engineered
crops to be about half the size that several research studies have recently
determined will be needed to prevent ecological disaster.

"It's like having your doctor prescribe five pills a day to prevent a heart
attack: It might help a little bit to take only one, but probably you're going
to die," said Jane Rissler, senior staff scientist at the Union for Concerned
Scientists in Washington. "These companies are responding to an overwhelming
scientific consensus that they have to do something, but what they are proposing
is far, far from what is needed."

The more that insects are exposed to an insecticide, the more rapidly they
develop resistance to that pesticide. That principle has become an issue as
several companies have added a gene to corn that allows the plants to produce a
steady supply of an insecticide known as bt, a bacterial toxin that kills
European corn borers and related caterpillars that drill through stalks and
damage ears.

Growers who use the new varieties can avoid spraying bt during the season. But
periodic spraying, though expensive and troublesome for growers, is in some
respects more environmentally friendly. That's because bt breaks down quickly in
sunlight, keeping exposures so brief that insects hardly have the opportunity to
evolve strategies for becoming resistant to the chemical.

Under constant chemical pressure from bt-exuding plants, insects have greater
opportunity to evolve ways of being unfazed by bt.

Field studies and computer modeling experiments have confirmed that there is a
solution to the problem: Grow plots of normal corn near the bt plots, and don't
spray those "refuges" with any bt. Without the pressure to develop bt
resistance, insects on refuge plots tend to remain susceptible to the pesticide.
And when those insects mate with their neighbors in nearby biotech plots, their
susceptibility genes will dilute any emerging resistance in their mates.

But how big do these refuges have to be? Several recent studies, which have been
compiled into a document that EPA now relies heavily upon, have concluded that a
refuge kept completely free of pesticides must be 20 percent to 30 percent the
size of the engineered plot. They note that a refuge should be about 40 percent
the size of the biotech plot if pesticides are to be used, since spraying can
increase the odds of bt resistance developing.

The new plan, however, calls for only 20 percent refuges, even when sprays are
to be used, said Monsanto spokesman Dan Holman. Moreover, the plan offers no
details about whether the refuges must be planted alongside the biotech plots,
or can be some distance away, where studies suggest they would be less
effective.

"I think it's important that they've come up with something, even a compromise,"
said Fred Gould, an entomologist and bt expert at North Carolina State
University in Raleigh. "But the bottom line is, 20 percent without spraying is
as low as you'd want to go."

Indeed, the EPA has recently been requiring refuges about twice as big as what
yesterday's plan proposes for newly registered varieties of bt corn. But
previously approved varieties, including those made by the companies that came
up with the plan, were registered by the EPA before the agency started insisting
on refuges. That means any such system is voluntary for them until those
registrations start to expire in 2002, even though they account for most of the
15 million acres of engineered corn now planted in this country.

Holman said the coalition would release more details later, including how it
intends to enforce the use of the refuge system among farmers.

LOAD-DATE: January 09, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 1999 The Washington Post
