                             395 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

               April 14, 2003 Monday Five Star Late Lift Edition

NEWS BRIEFS

SECTION: WEST POST ; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 528 words


MARYLAND HEIGHTS

City will provide first community garden

The city of Maryland Heights is providing space for its first community garden
for residents.

The garden, which will feature 15-foot by 15-foot plots, will be situated south
of Maryland Heights Centre on McKelvey Road, and available on a first-come,
first-served basis. The application fee for each plot is $10.

The plots, which may be used for vegetables or flowers, will be assigned by the
parks and recreation staff at an organizational meeting at 7 p.m. on April 24 at
the Maryland Heights Centre, 2344 McKelvey Road.

The city will till and stake out the garden plots and provide a water source and
trash bins. Residents will be responsible for their own tools, hoses and
maintenance of their plots, which will not be fenced.
 Anyone wishing to apply for a plot may call 314-434-1915.

ST. LOUIS COUNTY

County may lease land along lake to rowersSt. Louis County may lease 2 1/2 acres
on the north shore of Creve Coeur Lake to the St. Louis Rowing Club, which uses
the lake, and Washington University, whose rowing team trains there.

The lake is in Creve Coeur County Park. The two groups would construct a
community rowing center with seven storage bays for such boats as rowing sculls,
kayaks and canoes, a locker room, exercise area and restroom.

The center would have one bay for public use. Money from renting the bay would
pay for operating expenses and improvements.

The lease would be for 25 years with options for two five-year renewals.
 County Executive George "Buzz" Westfall has asked the County Council to
authorize the lease.

ROCK HILL

Civic center lawsuits are now consolidatedSt. Louis County Circuit Judge James
R. Hartenbach has consolidated two Rock Hill lawsuits aimed at condemning the
nearly 7.8-acre Gerber property for a new 73,000-square-foot civic center. He
scheduled a hearing on the matter for 9 a.m. on May 15.

The first lawsuit was Rock Hill's initial attempt to condemn the property. After
Hartenbach dismissed it without prejudice, Rock Hill both asked the judge to
reconsider his ruling and filed a second condemnation suit. Hartenbach later
revived the first suit and Rock Hill asked that he combine the two cases.

The Gerber property is on the east side of McKnight Road south of Litzsinger
Road.

PARKWAY DISTRICT

Assessment will be topic of Dialogue NetworkParents of students in the Parkway
School District can learn about the district's assessment methods and ask
questions on April 22 at a meeting of the Parkway Dialogue Network.

The forum on student assessment will be held at 7 p.m. at Parkway Northeast
Middle School, 181 Coeur DeVille Drive in Creve Coeur.

The panel will include:

Dan Coates, director of program evaluation.

Denise Pupillo, coordinator of gifted and talented education. Charlotte Ijei,
coordinator of guidance and counseling.

Enza Haug, Central area coordinator for the Special School District.

Linda Sodemann, high school counselor.

Mary Rueschhoff, middle school counselor.

Nancy Groth, elementary school counselor.

The forum is free and open to the public. For more information, call
314-415-8114.

                       TELEGRAM & GAZETTE (Massachusetts)

                             April 1, 2010 Thursday
                        DOUGLAS/GRAFTON/MILLBURY EDITION

Community Garden needs sponsors, donations

SECTION: Neighbors; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 576 words


GRAFTON - The Grafton Garden Club is looking for sponsors to donate money or
materials for the newly created Community Garden at 48 Old Westboro Road. The
garden needs one ton of lime; hay or stones for the pathways between the plots;
an electric fence around the garden (approximately 500 feet perimeter) including
solar panels and battery; a wheelbarrow and a lawnmower.

To make a donation, call Michael at (508) 887-5600. For more information, go to
garden.graftongardenclub.org.

The Board of Selectmen recently approved the club's proposal for a garden. The
club is now accepting applications from residents to rent 20-by-20-foot plots to
grow vegetables, herbs, flowers and short fruiting bushes. Applications are
available at garden.graftongardenclub.org, by e-mailing
info@graftongardenclub.org or by calling Michael at (508) 887-5600. Applications
and plot fees are due April 15 and should be sent to P.O. Box 453, Grafton, MA
01519-0453. Plot assignments will be mailed out by the end of April and planting
starts in May.

Northbridge students in DECA event

Twenty-three Northbridge High School students recently competed in the 51st
annual Massachusetts DECA State Competition in Boston. The students were: Nick
Abraham, Mike Barkin, Julie Broderick, Denise D'Amico, Hayden Dorfman, Natasha
Farrington, Cynthia Feen, Lauren Gallant, Sadie Green, Matt Kane, Mitch Kelley,
Allison Kosciak, Ashley LeBlanc, Evan MacIntosh, Ryan Masterson, Gabrielle
Mello, Thomas Murphy, John O'Brien, John Perro, Jordan Pimentel, Kirsten Ropiak,
Brianna Scherer and Kraig Spencer.

The team of Sadie Green, Ashley LeBlanc and Brianna Scherer placed second in the
Financial Operation Research Event, qualifying to compete in the International
DECA Competition in Louisville, Ky., in April. The team worked closely with
UniBank of Whitinsville on their project.

Allison Kosciak and Gabbi Mello will be attending the Leadership Development
Academy in Louisville.

Nick Abraham, Mike Barkin, Julie Broderick, Denise D'Amico and Allison Kosciak
placed in the top 10 of their categories. Nick Abraham received two third place
medals for his role playing effort. And, Mike Barkin received a first place
medal for his score on his marketing test.

Allcare Medical celebrates 10 years

MILLBURY- Allcare Medical Supply, 30 Grafton St., is celebrating 10 years in
business. Bill Fredericks, president and CEO, started Allcare on April 1 of 2000
with no clients and no staff. The company now provides home medical equipment to
thousands of patients in the Blackstone Valley and throughout Massachusetts. An
invitation-only dinner is planned at O'Connor's restaurant in Worcester for
staff, family and friends who helped contribute to their success.

Students chosen for science competition

High School juniors Shanise Perez and Jessica Donati have been selected to
participate in the Future Research Scientist Competition hosted by the Center
for Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine at the University of
Massachusetts in Worcester.

The students will have the opportunity to work as research scientists in a
state-of-the-art laboratory. The competitors will complete a DNA fingerprinting
analysis at the Rose Gordon facility in Shrewsbury and will present their
findings in a poster competition on May 1. The grand prize includes a spot in
the center's Biology Boot Camp summer internship program as well as a donation
of laboratory equipment from Bio-Rad to the winner's science department.

                   Inland Valley Daily Bulletin (Ontario, CA)

                             August 11, 2006 Friday

National Guard deployed to watch over Ontario International Airport

BYLINE: By Mason Stockstill, Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 588 words


ONTARIO - National Guard troops arrived at Ontario International Airport on
Friday, providing an additional layer of security at the airport just days after
an apparent terror attack was thwarted in Britain.

The 30 troops will help screen passengers and baggage as well as provide
security throughout the airport's property, said Capt. Jeremy Johnson, of the
1st Squadron, 18th Cavalry Regiment out of Ontario.

"On civil missions like this, we've got a lot of experience," Johnson said. "A
lot of these guys have done three or four of these."

Photo Galleries:
  Ontario International Airport on High Alert after Terror Plot
  Terror plot defeated
  LAX on High Alert, Friday 08/11

Related Articles:
  At ONT, travelers put up with more security
  New airport rules will have varying effects on businesses
  British foil plot to kill thousands in jetliners over Atlantic
The troops -- including several with rifles slung over their shoulders -- served
as a stark visual reminder of the lengths to which state officials would go to
maintain public confidence in airport security.

Clad in camouflage and combat boots, several troops stood watch west of the
pickup and drop-off points at ONT's terminals, with HMMVs parked nearby.

They're the latest security change at the airport since British officials
uncovered a plot earlier this week to blow up several airplanes in midair. If it
had been pulled off, officials said the plan could have rivaled the Sept. 11
attacks in its level of destruction.

Investigators said the suspects planned to detonate liquid explosives smuggled
onto flights from Britain to the United States in items such as shampoo
containers and water bottles.

Because of that threat, nearly all fluids were banned from carry-on luggage
throughout the United States.

"We cannot say how long these measures will remain in place, but we will not be
pressured to change them," said Kip Hawley, assistant secretary of the
Transportation Security Administration, in a statement. "The safety of the
traveling public remains our constant mission. Caution still demands heightened
vigilance."

The move caused severe congestion at airports across the country Thursday, but
by the next day most screening lines were moving at regular speeds. On Friday,
trash cans at ONT that had overflowed the day before with bottles of lotion,
shampoo and water were largely empty.

Still, federal officials urged travelers to arrive at the airport at least two
hours prior to their scheduled take-offs for domestic flights, and three to four
hours early for international flights.

"I can assure the people of California that we are doing everything to keep them
safe and to return our airports to normal operations as quickly as possible,"
Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said.

The governor had originally sent troops only to the international airports in
Los Angeles, Oakland and San Francisco, which serve flights to and from European
destinations.

However, Oakland declined the troops, and the deployment was expanded Friday to
include Ontario and San Diego airports.

The troops will remain at the airports for at least seven days, and perhaps more
if the national terror threat level remains at orange or higher, said Gen.
William Wade, adjutant general of the California National Guard.

"It's been proven, since the events of 9/11, that this additional level of
deterrence is an effective measure in trying to combat acts of terrorism," Wade
said.

Mason Stockstill can be reached by e-mail at mason.stockstill@dailybulletin.com
or by phone at (909) 483-9354.

LOAD-DATE: August 12, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: National Guard troops from the 1st Squadron, 18th Cavalry Regiment out
of Ontario, from left, 1SG Lawrence Smith, Lt. Col. Kurt Andrew Schlichter and
Capt. Jeremy Johnson walk near the front of Terminal 4 at Ontario International
Airport on Friday, August 11, 2006. National Guard troops were deployed to
several airports in California because of the elevated security level in effect
since Thursday. (Marc Campos/Staff Photographer)

                             398 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                      July 22, 1991, Monday, Final Edition

'Gunpowder, Treason and Plot' (Cont'd.)

SECTION: EDITORIAL; PAGE A10; LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

LENGTH: 500 words


Sheila Campbell is dead wrong in her assertion [letters, July 15] that Guy
Fawkes Day has nothing to do with the pope.

Because Guy Fawkes was believed to have set up the Gunpowder Plot to blow up
Parliament in order to return England to Roman Catholicism, Nov. 5 has long been
a day to celebrate England's salvation from the tyranny of Rome.

So strong was this connection that in the colonies Guy Fawke's Day was called
"Pope's Day." In Boston, mobs from different parts of the city made huge
papier-mache popes, which they paraded around the city. One mob eventually beat
out the others and dragged the popes to Boston Common, where they were burned
amid wild jubilation and patriotic anti-Catholic speeches. When the hated Stamp
Act was put into effect Nov. 1, 1765, Sam Adams had the clever idea of
persuading the leaders of the mobs to attack the "real" agent of Roman tyranny,
the Stamp Tax Man, and to burn his office. Hence were born the Sons of Liberty.

During the American Revolution, Pope's Day celebrations were banned mostly to
avoid offending our Catholic allies, the French. After Yorktown, all of the
patriotic hoopla of the old English holiday was transferred to July 4 --
bonfires, patriotic speeches, parades and all. DAVID R. WILLIAMS Lincoln, Va.

Your correspondent Sheila Campbell asserts that Guy Fawkes Day and the Gunpowder
Plot, which it memorializes, had nothing to do with the pope. What an odd
belief. I thought even Americans knew better than that. An American reference
work, to which I would direct Sheila Campbell, notes that Fawkes was a Catholic
convert and that the Gunpowder Plot was "in revenge for penal laws against
Catholics." Fawkes and his fellow plotters made no bones about their motivation
as Roman Catholics.

Is it really possible that the pope was not "in the loop"?

As a young boy in the '20s I pushed my Guy in a barrow and was told that the
Gunpowder Plot was caused by the "dirty Catholics."

As a mature agnostic, I now find Catholics as salubrious as any other group of
faithful, but my respect for historic accuracy calls me to differ with Sheila
Campbell.

LOUIS K. MATHER Arlington

Shelia Campbell is incorrect when she writes that the celebration of Guy Fawkes
Day in England has nothing to do with the pope. The festival dates back to the
reign of James I in 1605, when a plot was discovered to blow up the Houses of
Parliament with all of the royal family. James had ordered the expulsion of all
Catholic priests in England that summer as he became concerned over the growth
of Catholicism in England that followed his initial policies of tolerance. Guy
Fawkes, as well as certain Jesuits and other Catholic leaders, was arrested and
executed. The Gunpowder Plot became a symbol of Catholic treachery and was used
to justify the hysterical anti-Catholicism that followed. It is usually Guy,
rather than the pope, who is burned in effigy in a custom that is still followed
to this day.

BEN F. FORDNEY Harrisburg, Va.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Occasional

TYPE: LETTER

                       Copyright 1991 The Washington Post


                             399 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              January 29, 1983, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

EX-C.I.A. AGENT ON TRIAL, ACCUSED OF SENDING LIBYA EXPLOSIVES

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 7, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 578 words

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Jan. 28


The defense attorney for Edwin P. Wilson, the former intelligence agent charged
with illegally shipping 20 tons of plastic explosives to Libyan terrorists,
maintained in the trial today that Mr. Wilson was ''in effect a de facto C.I.A.
agent'' when the shipment was made in 1977.

The lawyer, Herald Price Fahringer, also said in his opening argument here that
his Mr. Wilson, in his role as a de facto agent, had informed the United States
authorities of a purported plot by a Libyan ''hit squad'' to enter the United
States and assassinate American leaders, including President Reagan.

Mr. Wilson had made that contention earlier, but the Federal authorities said
that while he did provide some information about the purported plot, which has
never been verified, he did so only after the matter had been given wide
publicity and also after he had been indicted for his dealings with the Libyans.

Mr. Fahringer said that he would prove that Mr. Wilson had also informed the
United States authorities of a plot involving a Brussels arms dealer to give
Libya the ability to build nuclear weapons. That was also also given after his
indictment, according to the Government, and the reported plot was never
verified.

Convicted on Other Charge

Mr. Wilson, a former member of the Central Intelligence Agency, was convicted
last year of smuggling weapons to Libya and was sentenced to 15 years in prison
and a $200,000 fine.

In this trial, he is charged with setting up an elaborate clandestine operation
that resulted in the shipping to Libya of 42,300 pounds of plastic explosives,
called C-4 and classified as a ''defense article,'' or strategically important
munition.

A jury of seven women and five men was seated today as the trial got under way.
In the Government's opening argument, Assistant United States Attorney A.M.
Hedges called the matter ''a very simple case'' of a plot to ship the explosives
to Libyan terrorists so they could ''turn toasters, lamps and other household
items into mines, fuses and booby traps.''

1977 Date Given for Plot

The Government says the plot was developed by Mr. Wilson and carried out by him
and several co-conspirators in the latter half of 1977.

The prosecution called as its first witness Jerome S. Brower, president of an
explosives company in Pomona, Calif. Mr. Brower has been named as an unindicted
co-conspirator.

He testified today that he met with Mr. Wilson and several Libyans in Mr.
Wilson's office in the spring of 1977 and made plans for procuring and shipping
a large quantity of plastic explosives to Libya.

Although Libyans were present, Mr. Brower said all arrangements had been made by
Mr. Wilson, and it was to him, and not to the Libyans directly, that the
explosives were sold.

Says He Acted as Go-Between

Mr. Fahringer maintained in his opening argument that Mr. Wilson had acted only
as a go-between in the matter, setting up the meeting between Mr. Brower and the
Libyans to further his credibility with the Libyans as part of his C.I.A. cover.

Mr. Brower described procuring the plastic explosives, a total of 54,000 pounds,
from three manufacturers in the United States and Canada and ultimately sending
42,300 pounds of it to Houston in five-gallon containers labeled as drilling
mud, for air shipment to Libya.

He testified that Mr. Wilson had paid him $13.75 a pouund for the explosives but
had asked for an invoice showing $20 a pound, ''so he could get his money.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1983 The New York Times Company

                                   USA TODAY

                            March 29, 2007 Thursday
                                 FINAL EDITION

The real stars of these books

BYLINE: Carol Memmott

SECTION: LIFE; Pg. 5D

LENGTH: 458 words


William Shakespeare plays a major role in Michael Gruber's new novel, The Book
of Air and Shadows (review, 1D). USA TODAY's Carol Memmott looks at other
historical figures, from Sir Isaac Newton to Emily Dickinson, who are popping up
in fiction.

Burning Bright by Tracy Chevalier (Dutton), in stores

Genre: Literary fiction

Setting: 18th-century London

Historical figure: English poet/artist William Blake

Plot: The Kellaway family moves to London, where chairmaker Thomas Kellaway gets
work with a circus impresario. Blake is their neighbor.

Napoleon's Pyramids by William Dietrich (HarperCollins), in stores

Genre: Thriller

Historical figure: French general Napoleon Bonaparte

Setting: 18th-century Paris and Alexandria, Egypt

Plot: A protege to Ben Franklin escapes enemies who want his mysterious
medallion by accompanying Bonaparte and his army to Egypt.

The Mosaic Crimes by Giulio Leoni (Harcourt), in stores

Genre: Mystery

Setting: 14th-century Florence

Historical figure: Italian poet Dante Alighieri (The Divine Comedy)

Plot: Dante, Prior of the City of Florence, investigates the murder of an artist
whose body is found near one of his unfinished mosaics.

The Wayward Muse by Elizabeth Hickey (Atria), in stores

Genre: Historical fiction

Setting: Mid-19th-century England

Historical figures: Pre-Raphaelite painter Dante Gabriel Rossetti and craftsman
William Morris

Plot: Jane Burden, model for and lover of Rossetti, marries the artist's
protege, Morris.

Nefertiti: The Book of the Dead

by Nick Drake (HarperCollins), April

Genre: Mystery

Setting: Ancient Egypt

Historical figure: Queen Nefertiti

Plot: Rahotep, chief detective of the Thebes Medjay division, must find the
missing queen.

Portrait of an Unknown Woman

by Vanora Bennett (Morrow), April

Genre: Literary fiction

Setting: 16th-century England

Historical figure: English

statesman Sir Thomas More

Plot:  Against the backdrop of

England's Protestant Reformation, two men vie for the hand of More's ward, Meg
Giggs.

Afternoons With Emily by Rose MacMurray (Little, Brown), April

Genre: Literary fiction

Setting: Mid-19th-century

Amherst, Mass.

Historical figure: American poet Emily Dickinson

Plot: An independent young

woman's outlook is informed by her friendship with the reclusive poet.

Ghostwalk by Rebecca Stott

(Spiegel & Grau), May

Genre: Mystery

Setting: 21st-century Cambridge, England

Historical figure: British

mathematician Sir Isaac Newton

Plot: A contemporary historian writing an opus on Newton's alchemy is found
murdered.

The Scandal of the Season by Sophie Gee (Scribner), August

Genre: Literary fiction

Setting: 18th-century London

Historical character: English poet Alexander Pope

Plot: Pope catapults to fame after he writes a risque poem about an illicit
affair between a baron and a beautiful society woman.

                             401 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                    January 16, 1995, Monday, FINAL EDITION

Lawyer: Farrakhan plot was 'induced'

BYLINE: Carolyn Pesce

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4A

LENGTH: 487 words

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS


As the daughter of the late Malcolm X awaits arraignment on charges of plotting
the murder of her father's rival, Louis Farrakhan, claims surfaced Sunday her
arrest is a government attempt to create a climate for Farrakhan's
assassination.

"It provides an inducement to kill Mr. Farrakhan . . . and as we've seen,
there's always some nut with a gun susceptible to this stuff," says Ronald Kuby,
a partner with William Kunstler. Kunstler and Kuby are joining the defense team
of Qubilah Shabazz, 34, indicted on charges of making phone calls and a partial
payment to a hitman to kill Nation of Islam leader Farrakhan.

Shabazz is scheduled to be arraigned Wednesday in the reported plot against
Farrakhan, rumored to be linked to the shooting death of Malcolm X. But reports
about the hitman-turned-informant, Michael Fitzpatrick, have raised questions
about his credibility.

Fitzpatrick attended the United Nations High School in New York with Shabazz. He
has a history of being a government informant and rumored setup artist. He was
arrested in Minneapolis in 1993 during a drug bust. His appearance in court
Tuesday on cocaine charges has been delayed.

"This case is about him enticing, luring and seducing her into the plot," says
Scott Tilsen, Shabazz's lawyer in Minneapolis. "Her friendship and trust in him
was used."

Fitzpatrick has been connected to a plot by Jewish militants to bomb the
Egyptian Government Tourist Office in New York in 1978. The New York Times
reported on Dec. 19, 1978, that Fitzpatrick was seen emerging from a car
carrying dynamite. Another bomber was taken into custody but Fitzpatrick was
not, The Times reported.

Fitzpatrick entered the federal witness protection program under the name
Michael Summers. Former FBI agent Dan Scott of Atlanta told the Minneapolis Star
Tribune that he provided reliable information about the bombing plot.

"He came forth because he is not a violent, racist man, as has been portrayed in
some news reports," Scott says.

But Christopher Gunderson, who owned Back Room Anarchist Books in Minneapolis in
the late 1980s, told Kuby that Fitzpatrick tried to persuade people there to
commit crimes, including bombings.

"It was clear to Gunderson . . . he was an agent provocateur," Kuby says.

Shabazz supposedly told Fitzpatrick she wanted to kill Farrakhan, and he got
word to the FBI. U.S. Attorney David Lillehaug has refused comment.

But Ava Muhammad, a lawyer for the Nation of Islam, argued that the indictment
was a government conspiracy to divide the black community.

"It would be easy for conspirators to entrap this troubled young woman," she
said. "The question that must be raised by the black community today is whether
. . . we can reasonably believe that the United States Department of Justice
desires to protect the life of Minister Louis Farrakhan."

Farrakhan is expected to hold a news conference Tuesday in Chicago.

LOAD-DATE: January 17, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO, b/w, Carolyn Stewart, AP; PHOTO, b/w, Bebeto Matthews, AP

THE NATION

                      Copyright 1995 Gannett Company, Inc.


                             402 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                The New York Post

                             May 9, 2007 Wednesday

THE WAR AT HOME

SECTION: All Editions; Pg. 34

LENGTH: 470 words


The arrests of six foreign-born Muslim men in a conspiracy to attack soldiers at
Fort Dix in New Jersey un  derscores yet again the threat Islamist terror poses
to America.

As if such emphasis is necessary.

The authorities first learned of the plot in January 2006, when an alert
video-store worker notified authorities of a "disturbing" video that he'd been
asked to convert to DVD.

The six, from Yugoslavia and the Middle East, were arrested Monday night and
charged with plotting to "kill as many soldiers as possible."

The arrests tracked similar post-9/11 operations in New York, including:

* The Buffalo-area "Lackawanna Six" plot in 2002.

* The conviction of Pakistani immigrant Shahawar Matin Siraj for planning to
bomb the Herald Square subway station.

* The arrest and conviction of two Albany-based Islamists on charges of
money-laundering and supporting a foreign terrorist organization.

The FBI criminal complaint alleges that the Fort Dix Six considered other
military and governmental targets before settling on Fort Dix.

The father of one suspect owned a nearby pizzeria; the group planned to use that
to gain access to the base. They were caught on tape discussing the use of
mortars and rocket-propelled grenades in an attack.

They were taken into custody while trying to buy automatic weapons from an
informant.

Yes, the White House downplayed the possibility that this cell had any
connection to al Qaeda or other international terror organizations.

So what?

Just because there is no evidence, as of yet, linking these individuals to other
terror groups doesn't mean that such evidence won't turn up.

More importantly, terrorism is as much a state of mind as it is a structured
operation. Plots can spring up almost organically; that some are not explicitly
tied to al Qaeda is no cause for relief.

Quite the opposite: In many ways, it makes tracking these plots that much more
difficult.

No doubt lawyers for the Fort Dix Six soon will be claiming that their clients
weren't engaged in a "real" plot - indeed, that they are victims of
government-inspired "entrapment."

So, here's a question.

Why is it that so many of these individuals, whether in Buffalo, Albany, Fort
Dix - or Dearborn, Mich., or the Pacific northwest - are so eager to be
"entrapped" into plotting to harm Americans and/or U.S. institutions?

It is particularly ironic that this cell emerged in Fort Dix.

Four of the suspects are ethnic Albanian who managed to become part of a
community whose origins stretch back a decade: In 1999, the United States
launched Operation Provide Refuge, which took in some 20,000 mostly Muslim
refugees fleeing Serbian violence during Yugoslavia's civil war.

Fort Dix became one of the American safe havens for the Kosovar refugees.

Then it became a target.

And the war goes on.

LOAD-DATE: May 9, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             403 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               September 19, 2000, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

Man Held in Terrorist Plot Agreed to Talk, Agents Say

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN WEISER

SECTION: Section B; Page 6; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 482 words


Two federal agents testified yesterday that a Brooklyn man arrested last
December in a plot to smuggle explosives into the United States agreed to talk
voluntarily in an interrogation lasting more than 10 hours.

The defendant, Abdel Ghani Meskini, 32, is seeking to block prosecutors from
using a long statement they say he gave. He asserted in court papers that he was
not properly informed of his legal rights, and that he only answered the agents'
questions out of fear.

But two Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, testifying in the first day of
hearings in Federal District Court in Manhattan, said Mr. Meskini was read his
rights against self-incrimination and to legal counsel three times. Mr.
Meskini's lawyer, Roland Thau, sought to discredit their account in
cross-examination, and suggested they had taken advantage of his client.

Mr. Meskini's statement is seen as critical to the government's case in the
terrorist plot, whose origins remain a mystery and whose target in the United
States has also not been revealed. Mr. Thau tried to ask one agent whether he
believed the plot was linked to Osama bin Laden, whom the authorities suspect of
masterminding the bombings of two American embassies in Africa in 1998, but
Judge John F. Keenan sustained the government's objections and would not allow
him to answer.

Mr. Meskini, who has pleaded not guilty in the case, sat quietly during the
hearing yesterday. He might testify this week to offer his own account of what
happened after his arrest on charges that he aided a terrorist plot involving an
attempt by a group of Algerians in Canada to smuggle powerful explosives into
the United States near Seattle.

Mr. Meskini, an Algerian, claimed in an affidavit that he was not advised of his
rights until after he had answered some questions.

"And even while I was informed of those rights," he wrote, "I was told about
them in a way that clearly conveyed to me that the police wanted to make me
talk. I come from a part of the world where police violence, torture and other
abuse is most common."

Yesterday, one of the agents, Francis J. Schulte Jr., testified that no threats
were made and that Mr. Meskini was first advised of his rights after his Dec. 30
arrest as he was being driven to F.B.I. headquarters in Lower Manhattan.

Mr. Meskini "read the advice of rights form out loud to all of us," Agent
Schulte said.

Upon arrival at 26 Federal Plaza around 8 a.m., Agent Schulte continued, Mr.
Meskini was handcuffed and shackled in an interrogation room, and again given
his rights. He signed a written waiver and agreed to be interviewed, the agent
said.

After about three hours of interrogation, the rights were administered a third
time, he said. Mr. Meskini signed another waiver. "I felt he was somewhat
evasive in his answers," Agent Schulte said, "but he did respond. He seemed
cooperative."

                  The State Journal-Register (Springfield, IL)

                            February 10, 2006 Friday

President Bush details thwarted al-Qaida plot  ;
 Attack was to target Los Angeles skyscraper

BYLINE: TOBY ECKERT Copley News Service

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 774 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Terrorists planned to blow open the cockpit door of an airliner with shoe bombs
and crash it into Los Angeles' Library Tower in a plot that was foiled in 2002,
President Bush said Thursday.

Bush, who has been criticized for a secret surveillance program, U.S. treatment
of prisoners and other elements of the war on terror, provided new details of
the incident - which he first mentioned last year - in a speech to the National
Guard Association. His top counterterrorism adviser, Frances Fargo Townsend,
briefed reporters afterward, denying the speech had anything to do with the
surveillance controversy.

But Democrats and some outside analysts said the speech clearly was meant to
bolster the administration's case that its aggressive tactics are justified.
Despite the new details of the plot, Townsend told reporters, "We don't know
when it was planned to actually be executed" or if the plotters intended to
seize a plane from Los Angeles International Airport, leading some experts to
question how far along the plot really was.

Bush said the episode illustrated the continuing danger the nation faces.

"As the West Coast plot shows, in the war on terror we face a relentless and
determined enemy that operates in many nations - so protecting our citizens
requires unprecedented cooperation from many nations as well. It took the
combined efforts of several countries to break up this plot," Bush said, noting
that the attack was derailed when a key al-Qaida figure was arrested in
Southeast Asia.

Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the alleged mastermind of the Sept. 11, 2001, airline
attacks on Washington and New York, started planning the West Coast attack in
October 2001, Bush said. Working with the head of an al-Qaida affiliated group
in South Asia, Jemaah Islamiyah, four terrorists were recruited for the plot and
flew to Afghanistan to swear allegiance to Osama bin Laden.

Mohammed "set in motion a plan to have terrorist operatives hijack an airplane
using shoe bombs to breach the cockpit door and fly the plane into the tallest
building on the West Coast. We believe the intended target was Liberty Tower in
Los Angeles, California," Bush said, with aides later clarifying that he was
referring to the 73-story Library Tower.

The plan was disrupted when the cell leader was arrested in February 2002. All
four of the cell members are in custody, Townsend said. Mohammed and the Jemaah
Islamiyah leader, known as Hambali, who were arrested in 2003.

"We unraveled this over a period of years," Townsend said, adding that it
highlighted the importance of "real-time information sharing" between the
intelligence agencies of the United States and four South Asian and Southeast
Asian countries, which she would not identify.

She insisted the speech was meant to highlight international cooperation in the
war on terror and not to deflect criticism of the surveillance program, which
was the subject of congressional hearings this week. She declined to say whether
the eavesdropping program played any role in thwarting the Los Angeles plot.

However, she said the episode "reminds us that we must continue to gather as
much information as possible and from all sources, especially detainee
debriefings and intelligence operations to reveal the evolving terrorist
networks and plots."

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-San Francisco, suggested Bush's comments
were "scare tactics." She criticized cuts he recently proposed in some homeland
security spending.

"The independent, bipartisan 9/11 Commission's final report card indicted the
continued failure by the Bush administration and the Republican Congress to meet
the security needs of our nation and make Americans safer," she said in a
written statement. "President Bush missed a critical opportunity today to
explain why, more than four years after the 9/11 attacks, the American people
are not as safe as we should be."

White House spokesman Scott McClellan said the speech had been planned for weeks
and "we were looking for an example to highlight a ... plot that was disrupted."

Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa said he first learned of the details
while watching Bush's speech on TV and criticized the White House for not
informing him.

McClellan said administration officials did "reach out" to officials in
California and Los Angeles, whom he did not name, and "the word I heard was
there was great appreciation for the notification."

Bush first alluded to the Los Angeles plot in an October 2005 speech. At the
time, terrorism experts said it was difficult to tell whether it posed an actual
threat or was merely discussed as a possibility by al-Qaida operatives.

LOAD-DATE: February 13, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Los Angeles in October 2001.

                                   USA TODAY

                             August 31, 2012 Friday
                                 FINAL EDITION

September;
It's not all horror flicks this fall -- Hollywood is offering films of all
genres. USA TODAY's and look at the next two months' pictures (schedules are
subject to change).

BYLINE: Scott Bowles and Brian Truitt

SECTION: LIFE; Pg. 2D

LENGTH: 349 words


It's not all horror flicks this fall -- Hollywood is offering films of all
genres. USA TODAY's Scott

Bowles and Brian Truitt look at the next two months' pictures (schedules are
subject to change).

Sept. 7

The Words

Stars: Bradley Cooper, Jeremy Irons, Olivia Wilde

Directors: Brian Klugman, Lee Sternthal

Plot: Cooper plays a young writer who achieves fame and infamy when word leaks
that his work isn't his own.

The Cold Light of Day

Stars: Bruce Willis, Sigourney Weaver, Henry Cavill

Director: Mabrouk El Mechri

Plot: After his family is kidnapped during a vacation in Spain, Will Shaw
(Cavill), a young Wall Street trader, must confront those responsible.

Sept. 14

Finding Nemo (in 3-D)

Voices: Albert Brooks, Ellen DeGeneres, Alexander Gould

Directors: Andrew Stanton, Lee Unkrich

Plot: A re-release of the 2003 hit, Nemo gets the 3-D treatment in this Pixar
story of a clownfish (Brooks) who swims to Sydney to rescue his captured son.

Sept. 21

Dredd 3D

Stars: Karl Urban, Olivia Thirlby, Lena Headey

Director: Pete Travis

Plot: Though it shares the same character as Sylvester Stallone's 1995 Judge
Dredd, filmmakers say this is a closer adaptation of the comic-book character
Judge Dredd, who is tasked with ridding a futuristic city of its futuristic
scourge.

End of Watch

Stars: Jake Gyllenhaal, Michael Pea, Anna Kendrick

Director: David Ayer

Plot: Gyllenhaal and Pea play cops who are marked for death after confiscating a
cache of money and weapons from a notorious cartel.

Trouble With the Curve

Stars: Clint Eastwood, Amy Adams, John Goodman

Director: Robert Lorenz

Plot: An ailing baseball scout (Eastwood) takes his daughter along for a final
recruiting trip.

Sept. 28

Looper

Stars: Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Bruce Willis, Emily Blunt

Director: Rian Johnson

Plot: Set in a future where time travel is possible, Looper casts Gordon-Levitt
as Joe, a hit man with an unenviable mission: to kill the older version of
himself.

Won't Back Down

Stars: Viola Davis, Maggie Gyllenhaal, Holly Hunter

Director: Daniel Barnz

Plot: Two determined mothers (Davis and Gyllenhaal) look to transform their
kids' bleak inner-city school.

                             406 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               The New York Times

                             August 8, 2004 Sunday
                              Late Edition - Final

U.S. Says Man Had Ties to Plot To Disrupt Vote

BYLINE: This article was reported by David Johnston, Thom Shanker and David E.
Sanger, and written by Mr. Johnston.; David Johnston and Thom Shanker reported
from Washington for this article and David E. Sanger from Kennebunkport, Me.

SECTION: Section 1; Column 5; Foreign Desk; THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE
INVESTIGATION; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1382 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7


A Pakistani man whose arrest provided information about the reconnaissance of
financial institutions in New York, Newark and Washington was also communicating
with Qaeda operatives who the authorities say are plotting to carry out an
attack intended to disrupt the fall elections, a senior intelligence official
said Saturday.

Senior intelligence and counterterrorism officials said it was not clear whether
the people behind the surveillance of the financial institutions and the people
involved in the election threat were part of the same group, or belonged to
overlapping or separate ones.

The arrest last month of the Pakistani, Mohammed Naeem Noor Khan, had already
prompted a search in the United States, Britain and other countries to locate
the people behind the surveillance, which took place three or four years ago.
Now the authorities say Mr. Khan's arrest is also helping them unravel a threat
to carry out an attack this year inside the United States.

It is not clear whether Mr. Khan represents the second channel of intelligence
that officials have alluded to in recent days that, they say, convinced them
that the reconnaissance of financial institutions was related to current
threats.

But he is emerging as a central figure in an expanding web of connections that,
the authorities say, indicates that they may have penetrated an operational
Qaeda group whose intentions were previously unknown.

Bush administration officials have talked about a potential threat to the
election since the spring. Early last month, the homeland security secretary,
Tom Ridge, spoke of a plot to disrupt the democratic process.

On Saturday, American authorities said they were close to identifying the main
figures who conducted reconnaissance of the financial centers. Armed with
multiple leads stemming from arrests in Britain and Pakistan, and aided by a
wealth of information from forensic studies of computers seized in Pakistan, the
authorities have begun a large-scale investigation.

Still frustrating investigators is the uncertainty about whether the
surveillance in 2000 and 2001 was part of an ongoing plot. So far, the officials
said, no clear evidence has been obtained that indicates whether the plot was
ever abandoned.

Increasingly, however, the authorities suspect that the Qaeda figures believed
to have been involved in the surveillance were active members of the terrorist
network. They say the clandestine manner in which they operated suggested that
they wanted to carry out attacks inside the United States.

Investigators are counting on people already in custody, or others whom they
hope to apprehend, to help solve the mystery of whether the plot is still
active.

Among those in custody is a suspect named Babar Ahmed, who was arrested in
Britain this week at the request of the United States. Whatever his role in the
surveillance, the authorities now say that Mr. Ahmed obtained detailed
information about the movements of the Navy aircraft carrier Constellation,
including information about the formations used by the carrier and its escort
vessels in maneuvers like its passage through the Strait of Hormuz in the Middle
East in 2001.

As part of the inquiry, Navy officials examined the record of a sailor aboard
the Benfold, a destroyer that was part of the Constellation battle group.
Officials said they had found an e-mail message from the sailor -- who has since
left the service -- that was sympathetic to Al Qaeda.

The officials said that a turning point in the surveillance case came with the
arrest in Britain, earlier this week, of Abu Issa al-Hindi. The authorities say
they believe Mr. Hindi was dispatched to the United States by senior Qaeda
leaders to carry out the reconnaissance operation.

For reasons still not entirely clear, Mr. Hindi was under surveillance by the
British authorities -- believed to be acting on information supplied by the
United States -- even before he is said to have been identified as an operative
in the surveillance of American financial institutions.

One senior counterterrorism official said the outpouring of leads had mushroomed
into a sprawling investigation in which agencies in the United States and
overseas were struggling to coordinate and share the enormous volume of
information.

The inquiry has caused strains between the United States and Britain. There were
signs that some British authorities might not have agreed with the White House
decision to make public information about the surveillance operations. The news
agency Reuters quoted the British home secretary, David Blunkett, as saying that
there was ''a difference between alerting the public to a specific threat and
alarming people unnecessarily by passing on information indiscriminately.''

Officials at MI5, the British domestic intelligence agency, have warned that the
intense news media coverage in the United States of recent arrests in Britain
could interfere with legal efforts to extradite suspects to the United States.

So far, American authorities have sought the extradition of only person, Mr.
Ahmed, who was arrested on charges unrelated to the surveillance operation. He
is being sought on charges that he used a computer Web site to raise money for
fighters in Chechnya and Afghanistan.

Mr. Ahmed is a cousin of Mr. Khan, a Qaeda communications expert whose arrest
last month in Pakistan produced the trove of information that led American
officials to elevate the terror alert level.

A report by Reuters in Pakistan said Mr. Khan had been secretly funneling
information about Al Qaeda to Pakistani authorities and that his arrest and
subsequent identification in news accounts may have cost the United States a
valuable source.

American officials contacted on Saturday would not confirm whether Mr. Khan was
a mole or double agent. They said his arrest had led to intelligence gains of
enormous value in uncovering the surveillance operation in the United States.

Intelligence officials have also recently come into possession of information
about how much Al Qaeda knew about Navy operations.

According to a statement from United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement,
British law enforcement authorities, executing search warrants for several
locations connected to Mr. Ahmed, ''seized, among other things, a document that
set forth plans for a U.S. naval battle group operating in the Strait of Hormuz
in April 2001. The information contained in the document, which was classified
at the time, has been confirmed as legitimate by the U.S. Navy.''

The documents, according to the government statement, ''included the battle
group's planned movements on April 29, 2001, and a drawing of the group's
formation. In addition, the document specifically noted that the battle group
was tasked both with enforcing sanctions against Iraq, and with conducting
operations against Afghanistan and Al Qaeda.''

Most important, the statement said, ''the document specifically described the
battle group's vulnerability to a terrorist attack, and provides specific
examples on how the ships might be attacked (e.g., 'they have nothing to stop a
small craft with RPG etc, except their Seals' stinger missiles').''

The initials R.P.G. refer to rocket-propelled grenade, and Seals are naval
Special Operations Forces.

For unrelated reasons, the Constellation was retired from service in August
2003. In addition, after the attack on the Cole, in October 2000, the Navy began
''force protection'' measures for ships sailing into regions where attacks were
deemed likely. Those measures remain classified.

American officials said the e-mail correspondence from the sailor from the
Benfold occurred in July 2001. Navy officials said on Saturday that
investigators had not found any evidence that the sailor was the source of Mr.
Ahmed's information on the Constellation group.

The content of the e-mail correspondence ''was sympathetic to the jihad
movement,'' according to the immigration and customs statement. ''The enlistee
expressed anti-American sentiment and offered praise for the Mujahedeen, the
attack of the U.S.S. Cole'' and for those ''who have brought honor'' to the
movement ''in the lands of Jihad Afghanistan, Bosnia, Chechnya, etc.''

                                US Official News

                             April 29, 2014 Tuesday

Washington: Felon Arrested for Plotting to Blow Up Store and Gas Stations as
Diversions for Bank Robberies

LENGTH: 524  words

DATELINE: Washington


US Federal Bureau of Investigation, The Government of USA has issued the
following news release:

A recently released prison inmate was arrested yesterday for plotting to blow up
a large store and gas station as part of his bank robbery scheme, announced U.S.
Attorney Jenny A. Durkan. Larry Gillette, 53, of Shelton, Washington, is charged
with solicitation to commit a crime of violence and being a felon in possession
of a firearm. Gillette allegedly began plotting the bombings and bank robberies
while still serving a state prison sentence for identity theft. After being
released from prison on April 14, 2014, Gillette described his plot in detail to
someone he thought would assist him with his crimes. In fact, the person he met
with was an undercover officer working for the FBI's Safe Streets Task Force.
Gillette will appear in U.S. District Court in Tacoma at 2:30 today.

According to the criminal complaint, law enforcement learned that Gillette told
others in prison of his plan to rob banks in Shelton using bombs at various
businesses as a diversion, during which he would commit violent takeover-style
robberies. Following his release from prison, an undercover officer posed as
someone who could assist Gillette in obtaining weapons and explosives for his
plot. On two different occasions in April 2014, Gillette was recorded on audio
and video describing his plot to the undercover officer as they drove around
Shelton. As described in court documents, the plot involved powerful bombs at
Walmart and Arco and Chevron gas stations. The plot allegedly anticipated that
while first responders were busy with the bombings, Gillette would rob three
banks. Gillette indicated he wanted the maximum loss of life to occur in the
bombings and the bank robberies. At one point in the investigation, Gillette
took possession of four Glock firearms. Gillette did not know the firearms had
been modified so they would not fire. Gillette was arrested yesterday afternoon
when he met again with the undercover officer and attempted to ignite a car
bomb. The "bomb" was inoperable.

Solicitation to commit a crime of violence is punishable by up to 20 years of
imprisonment. Being a felon in possession of a firearm is punishable by up to 10
years of imprisonment.

The charges contained in the complaint are only allegations. A person is
presumed innocent unless and until he or she is proven guilty beyond a
reasonable doubt in a court of law.

The case is being investigated by the Seattle Safe Streets Task Force--which
includes special agents from the FBI and task force officers from the Seattle
Police Department (SPD)--and the SPD Major Crimes Task Force. SPD SWAT, the
Mason County Sheriff's Office, and Shelton Police Department, and the Bureau of
Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives (ATF) partnered with the task forces
on the arrest and the serving of search warrants.

The case is being prosecuted by Assistant United States Attorney Jeffrey A.
Backhus.

Press contact for the U.S. Attorney's Office is Emily Langlie, Public Affairs
Officer at (206) 553-4110 or Emily.Langlie@usdoj.gov


For more information please visit: http://www.fbi.gov

LOAD-DATE: April 30, 2014

                             408 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Topeka Capital-Journal (Kansas)

                            October 18, 2010 Monday

Marijuana growing operations on rise in Kansas

SECTION: OBITS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 407 words


The Associated Press

HUTCHINSON - Large-scale marijuana growing operations have been turning up more
frequently in Kansas, as part of what authorities say is a move by organized
crime to the region.

Drug Enforcement Administration statistics show the number of outdoor marijuana
operations found in Kansas and neighboring states has increased over the past
couple of years, and the number has doubled in some cases.

"We're seeing it all over the U.S., but operations are moving to areas in the
Midwest where they think we don't have adequate law enforcement," said Rod Page,
a special agent with the Kansas Bureau of Investigation, told The Hutchinson
News. "They're looking for backwoods areas where they think they won't be
caught."

A large marijuana operation found Oct. 7 in rural Reno County near Haven is one
of eight marijuana plots reported this year in Kansas, according to a report in
the Hutchinson newspaper.

Page said it is the fourth such plot found in the past two weeks. He said each
site had between 3,000 and 4,000 marijuana plants.

In most cases, those who oversee the crop also live on the property, creating a
danger for hunters and landowners who are most likely to stumble upon the plots.

"The West Coast has been seeing these types of operations, particularly on state
and government ground and forests," Page said. "But it's coming to the Midwest."

In Kansas, 12 outdoor marijuana plots and 1,463 cultivated marijuana plants were
eradicated in 2008. Last year, that statistic jumped to 29 plots and 24,478
marijuana plants, including two 10,000-plant operations in Kingman and Sedgwick
counties.

Both Page and Dave Mizell, assistant special agent overseeing DEA operations in
Kansas, said organized crime groups running the operations move out of areas
where there is pressure from law enforcement.

"When the heat is on them, they move away to where they think they are not as
susceptible, like Missouri, Kansas, Oklahoma," Mizell said. "The more
significant operations we do believe are organized - their transportation is
organized, they have a better understanding of how to coordinate the plant, and
they're monitoring (the crop) and living there 24/7.

"Mainly, it's driven by where can we go where we cause the least suspicion and
where can we make a profit," he added, referring to the mindset of those running
the marijuana growing operations. "One expense is law enforcement detecting them
and cutting down their product."

LOAD-DATE: January 30, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2010 The Topeka Capital-Journal
                              All Rights Reserved

                                US Official News

                             April 9, 2015 Thursday

Arkansas: Garden Plot Rentals Now Available

LENGTH: 138  words

DATELINE: Little Rock


Fairfield Bay, Arkansas has issued the following news release:

Garden PlotsRenewals for Garden plots are due by Friday, April 17, 2015 to
guarantee keeping your same plot(s). All unpaid plots will be available for new
rental after that date. The water will be turned on as soon as we are sure
temperatures will remain above freezing.
Anyone interested in renting a garden plot can come by the Utilities office
between 8 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. Monday - Friday. All spaces are currently spoken
for. The only plots which may be available are those who cancel their rentals.
All garden plot renewal and new rental payments are to be paid at the Utilities
office. Please make checks payable to Fairfield Bay Community Club.

contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

Arkansas: Garden Plot Rentals Now Available

Fairfield Bay, Arkansas has issued the following news release:

Garden PlotsRenewals for Garden plots are due by Friday, April 17, 2015 to
guarantee keeping your same plot(s). All unpaid plots will be available for new
rental after that date. The water will be turned on as soon as we are sure
temperatures will remain above freezing.

between 8 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. Monday - Friday. All spaces are currently spoken

                             411 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Capital (Annapolis, MD)

                            December 7, 2008 Sunday

Lincoln assassination plot becomes plot for opera

BYLINE: THERESA WINSLOW Staff Writer

SECTION: LIFESTYLE; Pg. E1

LENGTH: 711  words


It's a good thing John Wilkes Booth wasn't bald.

If he was, Hollis Thoms might have had to look elsewhere for inspiration for his
new opera, "The Moustache."

The original 90-minute work, which premieres at St. John's College in Annapolis
in February, revolves around a fictional meeting between Baltimore barber
Cipriano Ferrandini (a Southern sympathizer) and Booth at the Barnum Hotel just
before the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.

Booth goes to Ferrandini, who is associated with a historically debated plot to
kill Lincoln in 1861, to get a haircut and have his mustache trimmed, and ends
up not only well-groomed but inspired to carry on with his own assassination
plans. At least, that's how it's envisioned by Mr. Thoms.

And according to Booth expert and author Michael Kauffman of Owings, the opera's
story line isn't all that far-fetched.

"The composer has come up with a very clever idea," Mr. Kauffman, author of
"American Brutus," wrote in an e-mail. "I don't know whether Booth knew
Ferrandini personally, but I wouldn't be surprised if he did. He often stayed at
Barnum's, and he almost certainly got a shave at Ferrandini's shop. So the plot
of the opera is no stretch at all."

Regardless of whether the two men ever met, it's certainly a unique premise for
an opera. The Edgewater composer, however, has a history of tackling unusual
subjects; his last work was an opera based on the life of Socrates.

A cut above

"The Moustache" is the result of 18 months worth of research and composing. The
process began at St. John's with a graduate course Mr. Thoms took on Lincoln's
speeches. In the process of researching a paper, he uncovered information about
the 1861 plot and became hooked on the subject.

"I would caution people about this," he said. "It's addictive. I think I found
things that areinteresting."

He read a wide range of books; traveled to the Surratt House Museum in Clinton,
which focuses on Mary Surratt, who was executed for her involvement in the plot
to assassinate Lincoln; visited the Library of Congress; and even got diagrams
of the Barnum. Mr. Thoms' notes bulge out of a large notebook - and this doesn't
even include the music.

"I think it's my most creative, ... most ambitious work," he said, also
mentioning that the premiere comes 200 years after Lincoln's birth.

"It comes at a moment that will have some meaning (because of) the
bicentennial," Mr. Thoms continued. "I hope that there's interest in the
public."

To give the work a feel of the period, he interspersed his own dialogue and
music with 11 Stephen Foster songs, including one called "If You've Only Got a
Moustache."

Mr. Thoms also includes a love interest for Booth to broaden the scope of the
work and add some romance into what is otherwise a very serious subject.

Abigail, a barmaid, is played by soprano Treva Foss of New York, and Booth is
played by her husband, baritone Dr. Jason Thoms, the composer's eldest son. Both
were also in "Socrates," and make the new work another family affair.

"I'm very grateful Hollis is always making music," Ms. Foss said.

Dr. Thoms said he doesn't feel any pressure assuming the role of Booth, and said
one of the best things about opera is getting the chance to be someone very
different from himself.

The other singer in the cast is tenor Kristopher Jean of New York, who plays
Ferrandini. St. John's tutor Robert Williamson will act out some Shakespeare
scenes in a Booth dream sequence as well, and State Archivist Dr. Edward
Papenfuse will give a brief talk on Ferrandini before the show begins.

"It's an intriguing story," Dr. Papenfuse said. "There's a plausibility to the
story line. Hollis did a very good job (of gathering the facts) and then he
entered into the area of imagination."

Mr. Thoms isn't sure what his next project will be after "The Moustache" because
he's been too immersed in historical research to think of anything else. The
opera marries his interests in music, history and creative writing.

"I have to get this Civil War thing out of me," Mr. Thoms joked.

"The Moustache" premieres at 4 p.m. Feb. 15 in the Key Auditorium at St. John's
College. The performance is open to the public. Tickets are $15 for adults and
$5 for students up to undergraduates. For more information, e-mail Mr. Thoms at
hjthoms@aol.com

LOAD-DATE: December 8, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


              Copyright 2008 Capital Gazette Communications, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved

                           Hobart Mercury (Australia)

THE TARGETS

SECTION: Pg. 5

LENGTH: 427  words


Khalid Sheikh Mohammed has claimed responsibility for the planning, financing
and surveying of the following attacks and plots:

1. Managing al-Qaida's cell for biological weapons

2. Managing al-Qaida's dirty-bomb operations on US soil

3. 1993 World Trade Centre operations

4. 9/11 operations, from A to Z

5. Shoe-bombing operations to down two US airplanes

6. Filka Island operations in Kuwait that killed two US soldiers

7. Bombing of nightclubs in Bali, Indonesia

8. A second wave of planned attacks after 9/11 on the Library

Tower in California, Sears Tower in Chicago, Plaza Bank in

Washington State, and the Empire State Building in New York

9. Follow-up operations to destroy US military vessels and oil

tankers in the Strait of Hormuz, the Strait of Gibraltar and the

Port of Singapore

10. Plot to destroy the Panama Canal

11. Plans to assassinate several former US Presidents, including

Jimmy Carter

12. Bombing suspension bridges in New York

13. Destroying the Sears Tower in Chicago using fuel or oil tanker

trucks beneath it

14. A plot to destroy Heathrow Airport, the Canary Wharf

Building and Big Ben in London

15. Planned attacks on nightclubs in Thailand visited by US and

British citizens

16. Planned destruction of the New York Stock Exchange and

Financial District

17. Destroying buildings in the Israeli city of Elat using planes

from Saudi Arabia

18. Plots to attack the US embassies in Indonesia, Australia and

Japan

19. Plots to attack the Israeli embassies in

India, Azerbaijan, the Philippines and

Australia

20. Destruction of an Israeli El-Al

airlines flight departing from

Bangkok Airport

21. Sending several mujahideen

into Israel to conduct surveillance

22. Bombing a hotel in Mombassa

frequented by Jewish travellers

23. Launching a Russian

made SA-7 surface-to-air

missile on Jewish airlines

departing from Mombassa

24. Plans to hit US targets in

South Korea, including

US bases and nightclubs

25. Providing finance to support hits on US,

Jewish and British targets in Turkey

26. Surveillance of nuclear power plants that provide

electricity to several US cities

27. Hit NATO headquarters in Europe

28. Planned the Bojinka operation designed to down 12

American planes full of passengers

29. An assassination attempt on former President Bill Clinton

while he was in the Philippines in 1994 or 1995

30. Shared responsibility for assassination attempt on Pope

John Paul II when he was in the Philippines

31. Planned assassination of Pakistan's President Musharaf.

32. Attempt to destroy an American oil company owned by

former US secretary of state Henry Kissinger on the Indonesia

island of Sumatra.

                      The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)

                        January 8, 2000, Saturday, FINAL

United States: Grave plot prices soar in northern California

SECTION: News; A18

LENGTH: 121 words

DATELINE: SAN JOSE


SAN JOSE -- If you want to RIP in Silicon Valley, you had better have CASH.

Northern California's high-tech economic boom has already caused housing prices
to rocket. Now graveyard real estate is following suit -- with four-person
burial plots in San Mateo's Skylawn Memorial Park going for $265,000 US.

While plots in other local graveyards were significantly cheaper, all were
showing a sharp upward trend, the San Jose Mercury News said Friday.

A survey of local graveyards found that at Oak Hill, a plot that sold for $1,250
in 1987 was valued recently at $3,720. At Chapel of the Chimes in nearby
Hayward, a plot with $2,500 in 1987 is now worth more than $12,000, the
newspaper said.

                          The Sunday Mail (Australia)

                            December 10, 2006 Sunday
                          State - Main Country Edition

Christmas slaughter plot at mall

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 53

LENGTH: 308  words


CHICAGO: An alleged plot to stage a deadly terrorist attack on Christmas
shoppers was marked by violent intentions but no chance of success.

A Muslim convert intent on ''jihad'', Derrick Shareef, 22, was going to use hand
grenades and a pistol to kill people at a shopping center near Rockford,
Illinois.

But federal agents and an undercover informant followed him from the plot's
outset. It is not known how they first learned of Shareef.

Many elements of the alleged plot, including the idea to attack the mall, came
from the informant.

Shareef acted alone and the public was never in any danger. At no time did he
have any weapons or the money to obtain them. But he did have violent intent,
the agents said.

In a recorded conversation with the informant on November 29, Shareef discussed
attacking a courthouse in DeKalb County.

''I just want to smoke a judge,'' he allegedly said.

The next day, the informant suggested the mall become the target. ''I mean, all
right, we gotta look at it this way, we want to disrupt Christmas,'' the
informant is quoted as saying. Shareef allegedly responded: ''Oh hell, yeah, the
mall is where it's at.''

Throughout the plot, Shareef was recorded spewing hatred for Jewish people and
the American justice system. His plan reached its apex when he tried to trade an
undercover federal agent a set of stereo speakers for grenades.

The exchange, which included dud grenades, took place on Wednesday. Shareef was
arrested without incident after the exchange and appeared in federal court in
Chicago on Friday. His attorney said Shareef was aware of his rights and
understood the proceedings.

He was held without bail on charges of attempting to use a weapon of mass
destruction and damage or destroy a building. Under the law, grenades are
considered weapons of mass destruction.

If convicted, he faces up to life in prison.

                             415 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


               National Post (f/k/a The Financial Post) (Canada)

                             March 16, 2007 Friday
                                National Edition

Al-Qaeda Confessions

BYLINE: Stewart Bell, National Post

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 1490  words


An al-Qaeda leader has admitted to killing U.S. journalist Daniel Pearl,
according to a confession released by the U.S. military yesterday in which the
Pakistani terrorist also takes responsibility for the 9/11 attacks and many
other plots.

Khalid Sheikh Mohammed told a military tribunal at Guantanamo Bay that he was
"responsible for the 9/11 operation from A to Z," the 2002 Bali bombings, the
1993 World Trade Center attack and a long list of other, thwarted plots.

The former North Carolina engineering student, captured near the Pakistani
capital, Islamabad, in 2003, said that while he sometimes felt sorry for
killing, he was simply speaking "the language of war." He said his confessions
were made without duress.

"I decapitated with my blessed hand the head of the American Jew, Daniel Pearl,
in the city of Karachi, Pakistan. For those who would like to confirm, there are
pictures of me on the Internet holding his head," he told a hearing on Saturday.

The Pentagon released some of the confessions on Wednesday and made further
disclosures yesterday. Mohammed is the highest-ranking al-Qaeda terrorist to be
captured since the 9/11 attacks; only Osama bin Laden and Ayman Al Zawahiri are
more senior.

While some question whether Mohammed may be overstating his prowess as an
international terrorist leader, others point out that since he is before a
tribunal he should logically want to minimize the extent of his involvement.

"It seems to me that he had no apparent incentive to exaggerate his role and
would probably seek to affirm what he realizes his accusers already know about
his activities so as to seem to cooperate with the tribunal and thus avert to
the extent possible the worst outcomes for himself," said Professor Martin
Rudner of Carleton University.

Prof. Rudner, Director of the Canadian Centre of Intelligence and Security
Studies, said that as the self-confessed operational commander for al-Qaeda's
foreign operations, Mohammed likely engaged in all planned attacks to some
extent.

"Khalid Sheikh Mohammed may have been tasked to exercise a central control or
direction over certain elements of planned operations: in some cases it may have
been in the planning, in others in the allocation of financing, in still others
in tactical matters, and, indeed, in some operations in actual execution."

Twenty-six Canadians died in the acts of terrorism that Mohammed says he
masterminded. One of the plots for which he takes responsibility involved
attacks on U.S. nuclear plants, which could have had dire consequences for
Canada as well.

Another was a plot to bomb the Israeli embassy in Manila. According to
classified Canadian Security Intelligence Service reports, Mohammed sent a young
Canadian named Mohammed Jabarah to oversee the Manila embassy attack. A resident
of St. Catharines, Ont., Mr. Jabarah was arrested in 2002 and is now jailed in
Pennsylvania.

"I wish with his confession that one could say that's the end of it, but we all
know that it's not," said Toronto resident Maureen Basnicki, whose husband Ken
was killed in the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks in Manhattan. "How many people are
ready to take his place and how many new plots are out there?"

Often referred to by his initials, KSM, Mohammed was once dubbed "al-Qaeda's
007" because of his fondness for bars and beaches.

Mohammed is of Pakistani descent but grew up in Kuwait. After completing a
mechanical engineering degree at A&T University in Greensboro, N.C. in 1986, he
left for Afghanistan to fight the Soviets.

He eventually met bin Laden and said in his confession that he eventually swore
a bayat, or oath, to the al-Qaeda leader to "conduct jihad." He also admits he
served on the al-Qaeda council and was its director of media operations and
foreign operations chief.

Mohammed first came to the attention of intelligence agencies after the
February, 1993, attempt to bring down the World Trade Center with a truck bomb.
Investigators traced the plot to his nephew Ramzi Youssef, who had fled to the
Philippines with his uncle.

From Manila, Mohammed began dreaming up the imaginative large-scale terrorist
plots for which he is infamous, starting with Project Bojinka, which involved
planting bombs on a dozen American airliners and timing them to detonate over
the Pacific. He later fled to Afghanistan but kept a home in Karachi, Pakistan,
where he ran urban training camps for terrorists.

Mohammed lists his other plots in his confession: the attempted shoe bombing of
a U.S.- bound plane; the "second wave" of attacks that were to follow 9/11 and
that targeted the Empire State Building, Library Tower in Los Angeles, Chicago's
Sears Tower and the Plaza Bank in Washington State.

In addition, he says he was responsible for plots to assassinate Pope John Paul
and "several former American presidents" including Jimmy Carter and Bill
Clinton, in addition to Henry Kissinger.

Mohammed has already been publicly linked to most of the plots for which he
takes responsibility, and at one point he says he is "not making myself [a]
hero, when I said I was responsible for this or that."

His confession reveals little about the man, although an obsession with Jews is
apparent. He refers to Mr. Pearl as "the American Jew" and calls Mr. Kissinger
"the Jewish former Secretary of State." He also admits to playing a role in the
bombing of a Kenyan hotel that "is frequented by Jewish travelers" and to
attacking a "Jewish airliner" with surface- to-air missiles.

He also appears to have a romantic self-image, citing the Muslim god Allah to
justify his actions and portraying himself as a revolutionary akin to George
Washington.

"I mean the language of the war is victims," he says. "I don't like to kill
people, I feel very sorry they have killed kids in 9/11. What I will do? This is
the language. Sometime I want to make great awakening between American to stop
foreign policy in our land."

Mrs. Basnicki called the terrorist's attempts to justify his violence "miswired
to say the least. I'll even go so far as to say it's not only miswired but an
evil thought that would claim the lives of so many innocent civilians and
inflict terror amongst those who survived."

- - -

THE TARGETS

In the Pentagon transcript, Khalid Sheikh Mohammed confessed to 31 terrorist
attacks or plots. One plot was censored from the U.S. Defence Department
transcript. The other 30 were:

1. The 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center, New York.

2. The Sept. 11, 2001, attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon in
Washington.

3. A "shoe bomber" operation to bring down two U.S. commercial aircraft.

4. The October, 2002, attack on U.S. soldiers on Kuwait's Faylahkah Island.

5. The deadly bombing of a nightclub in Bali, Indonesia, in October, 2002.

6. A plan for a "second wave" assault onmajor U.S. landmarks after Sept. 11,
with targets including the Library Tower, Los Angeles; the Sears Tower, Chicago;
the Plaza Bank building, Seattle; and the Empire State Building, New York.

7. Plots to attack U.S. military vessels and oil tankers in the Straits of
Hormuz, the Straits of Gibraltar, and Singapore.

8. A plan to blow up the Panama Canal.

9. An assassination attempt against former U.S. presidents including Jimmy
Carter.

10. A plot to blow up New York suspension bridges.

11. A plan to burn fuel trucks beneath the Sears Tower in Chicago to destroy it.

12. An operation to destroy London's Heathrow Airport, Canary Wharf and Big Ben.

13. A planned attack on night clubs in Thailand targeting U.S. and British
nationals.

14. A plot targeting the New York Stock Exchange and other U.S. financial
targets.

15. A plan to use aircraft from Saudi Arabia to destroy buildings in Eilat,
Israel.

16. Planned attacks aimed at destroying U.S. embassies in Indonesia, Australia
and Japan.

17. Planned attacks on Israel's embassies in India, Azerbaijan, the Philippines
and Australia.

18. An attack on an Israeli El- Al flight from Bangkok.

19. Sending several "mujahedeen" into Israel to survey "strategic targets."

20. The deadly November, 2002, suicide bombing of a hotel in Mombasa, Kenya.

21. The failed attempt to down an Israeli jet taking off from Mombasa airport
with a surface- to-air missile on the same day as the hotel bomb.

22. A plot to attack U.S. targets in South Korea, such as U.S. bases and night
clubs.

23. Providing the financial support for a plan to attack U.S., British and
Jewish targets in Turkey.

24. Surveillance undertaken for a plan to attack U.S. nuclear power plants.

25. A plot to attack NATO headquarters in Europe.

26. The 1995 "Bojinka Operation," planned to bring down 12 U.S. passenger
flights in the Pacific Rim.

27. An assassination attempt planned against president Bill Clinton during a
mid-1990s trip to the Philippines.

28. A separate plot to kill Pope John Paul II while he visited the Philippines.

29. Plans to assassinate Pakistan's President Pervez Musharraf. 30. An attempt
to attack a U.S. oil company operating in Sumatra, Indonesia.

The Daily Telegraph

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Crime

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
