                             458 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

                             July 7, 2010 Wednesday

In brief

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 501 words


new york

Failed NYC subway attack linked to larger terror plot

A failed plot to set off bombs in New York's subways last year was part of a
larger al-Qaida terrorist conspiracy that included a similar attack planned in
England, U.S. prosecutors said Wednesday.

In an indictment unsealed Wednesday in federal court in Brooklyn, prosecutors
added several al-Qaida figures to the case, including Adnan Shukrijumah, an FBI
most-wanted terrorist.

Shukrijumah, one of the al-Qaida leaders in charge of plotting attacks
worldwide, was directly involved in recruiting and plotting the New York attack,
prosecutors said. Attorney General Eric Holder has called that plot one of the
most dangerous since the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks.

The indictment added new terrorism charges against Adis Medunjanin, who already
was awaiting trial in the subway case. It also named three other men -- Abid
Naseer, Tariq Ur Rehman and an alleged al-Qaida operative in Pakistan known only
as "Ahmad" -- and linked them to a previously undisclosed companion plot in
England.

Washington, D.C.

Guantánamo detainee pleads guilty to charges

A Guantánamo Bay detainee Wednesday pleaded guilty to conspiring with al-Qaida
and to providing material support for terrorism, setting up the first conviction
before a military commission under the Obama administration.

The detainee, Ibrahim Ahmed Mahmoud al-Qosi, a 50-year-old Sudanese man captured
in Afghanistan, admitted to a military judge that he had engaged in hostilities
against the United States in violation of the laws of war.

A jury of military officers next month will determine his prison sentence.

In other news

Alarmed by a spate of near-collisions involving airliners, the government is
trying to find out why air traffic controllers and pilots are making so many
dangerous errors. In recent months, there have been at least a half-dozen
incidents in which airliners came close to colliding with other planes or
helicopters -- including in Chicago, Houston, San Francisco, Burbank and
Anchorage, Alaska.

A wily teenage thief who hopscotched his way across the U.S. and escaped in a
stolen plane to the Bahamas lived up to his legend Wednesday, eluding a manhunt
after allegedly committing a new series of break-ins on a normally quiet island.
Bahamian police interviewed burglary victims while searching for Colton
Harris-Moore on Great Abaco Island days after the fugitive who has been dubbed
the "Barefoot Bandit" crash-landed the plane and made his way to shore.

A man considered a person of interest in the abduction of a 4-year-old Missouri
girl, who was later found safe, shot himself when authorities approached his
home Wednesday, police said. Officers went to the man's home about 4:30 p.m. in
the city of Hawk Point, which is about halfway between where Alisa Maier was
taken from her front yard Monday night and the St. Louis suburb about 70 miles
away where she was found wandering around a carwash late Tuesday.

The Associated Press and the New York Times contributed to this report.

                             459 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                    August 14, 1999, Saturday, Final Edition

Centreville's Lush Life

Claudia Assis, Special to The Washington Post

SECTION: REAL ESTATE; Pg. H01

LENGTH: 1023 words



Green thumbs are not a requirement for living at Post Corners Apartments, but
they would certainly come in handy: The Centreville complex offers 16 free
garden plots. When a plot becomes vacant, the management organizes a lottery to
pick the next gardener.

The 4-by-6-foot plots are a highlight at Post Corners, but the 336-unit
garden-style complex, surrounded by lush landscaping, also offers residents
other attractive features: a gated entrance, a washer and dryer in each unit, 9-
or 10-foot ceilings, walk-in closets, and optional gas fireplaces. Apartments
have either a patio, a balcony or a sunroom.

A variety of plant life--from sunflowers and tomatoes to corn and
zucchini--blooms in the gardens. And the results this summer look barely touched
by the drought that has shriveled plants throughout the Washington area.

Bob Graves wasn't lucky enough to win the Virginia lottery, he said, but he got
a garden plot at Post Corners. Graves and his wife of 44 years, Betty, mostly
grow tomatoes, but the Graves's garden once had spinach, lettuce, beets and
onions. Post Corners "is a setting that closely resembles a country club," he
said.

The Graveses, longtime Northern Virginia residents, with some reluctance left
the 12-room house in Arlington where they raised their five children, fearing
that they would face problems with maintenance and loud neighbors at a rental
community. Luckily, they were wrong. "I've been totally astounded by how
pleasant it has been," he said. "This place is unique."

Post Corners' beautiful landscaping first attracted Frida Hamp, who lists
gardening among her hobbies, a little more than a year ago. She then visited the
community in February and was hooked. "It was gorgeous even in the winter, with
so much green," she said.

Without much spare time to keep up her own plot, Hamp satisfied her love for
plants "subletting" a corner of her next-door neighbor's garden to grow enormous
sunflowers--the plot was chosen as July's "Garden of the Month.' Post Corners,
she said, is a place where it is possible to live right outside Washington "and
still breathe fresh air and have beautiful gardens to walk through."

To make this experience more enjoyable, the management attaches name tags to
some plants, and professional landscapers are available from time to time to
advise residents.

The individual plots are surrounded by apple trees, grape vines, blueberries,
thyme, rosemary and other plants, and residents--gardeners or not--are expected
to help themselves to what they want. And tenants who don't grow a vegetable
garden can still join in the community spirit and exercise their green thumbs by
decorating their balconies: After all, the "Balcony of the Month" contest
features a $ 50 prize.

Jennifer Massaglia, who moved to Post Corners about two months ago, said she
would sign up for a plot if she had more time to garden. She said she liked her
apartment from the moment she saw it: "I just liked how clean it was and how it
looked very new." The 26-building complex was built in 1995.

Massaglia moved from Maryland because of her job. A flight attendant based at
Dulles International Airport, Massaglia finds that living in Centreville gives
her a nice 10-minute commute to work. And, compared with other complexes she
visited while apartment-hunting, Post Corners was closer to grocery and retail
stores. It also is convenient to Fair Oaks Mall.

If the beautiful landscape, gardens and location are a huge plus for most
residents, many prospective tenants were attracted to Post Corners by the units'
layouts, leasing consultant Angela Ballestracci said. "They are more impressed
with what they see inside the apartments," she said.

The complex offers eight different floor plans, and there is a waiting list for
some of them. The turnover is low: Residents leave the community either because
they buy a house or change job locations, Ballestracci said.

Post Corners is managed by Post Properties Inc., a real estate investment trust
based in Atlanta that manages more than 33,800 units in the Southeast and the
Southwest. In Northern Virginia, the company also manages a 364-unit apartment
complex in Fairfax. Seven people work on staff at Post Corners.

Ballestracci and other employees recently were invited to a party organized by
residents, an idea that started at the Post Corners pool-opening party and,
according to organizers, is intended to be a monthly happening. The potluck and
games night attracted a mix of about 20 longtime and new residents to the
complex's clubhouse.

The sociable atmosphere at Post Corners is one of the complex's nicest features
for Shirley Miles, who moved there in March. "Everybody here seems to be very
friendly," she said--and staff members are part of that ambience. "The people
who keep the place up are so anxious to please and to make sure the resident is
happy."

At Post Corners, Miles keeps a vegetable garden and also pursues another
passion, exercise, using the 24-hour fitness room and the swimming pool to keep
in shape. With nice neighbors and a place for gardening and exercise, she said,
"what else could you ask for?"


POST CORNERS APARTMENTS

5804 Post Corners Trail

Centreville, Va. 20120

1-888-239-6765



* Application fee: $ 35; $ 30 each additional applicant


* Security deposit: $ 225 to $ 425; $ 100 to $ 300 refundable


* Lease term: Six months to a year


* Utilities: Not included


* Amenities: Swimming pool; fitness room; clubhouse; vegetable garden; business
center; playground; tennis courts; picnic area; car wash; storage units; guest
apartments


* Parking: Free outdoor lot; $ 115 a month for garage parking



* Pet policy: Pets 20 pounds or less, and one year or older; $ 500 pet deposit,
$ 200 refundable

                                   USA TODAY

                   September 18, 1998, Friday, FINAL EDITION

WEEKEND PREVIEW

BYLINE: Eddie Timanus

SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 14C

LENGTH: 1813 words


Times p.m. Eastern

No. 1 Ohio State (2-0) vs. No. 19 Missouri (2-0)

-- Time/TV: 3:30/ABC. Line: OSU by 26. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Buckeyes face another challenging non-conference
opponent as they attempt to go wire to wire.

-- Plots and subplots: OSU's offensive arsenal led by QB Joe
Germaine and RB Michael Wiley is operating at peak efficiency.
It will be up to Tigers QB Corby Jones to keep up. Missouri's
cutting option attack against Buckeyes' pursuit is game's key
matchup.

No. 2 Florida (2-0) at No. 6 Tennessee (1-0)

-- Time/TV: 8/CBS. Line: Florida by 3. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Enormous as always. Vols look to end five years
of frustration against Gators in this pivotal SEC East clash.

-- Plots and subplots: Did Tennessee's nail-biter at Syracuse
or Gators' easy tuneups provide better preparation? Tennessee's
inability to run against Florida last time was critical, but TB
Jamal Lewis is battle-tested and QB Tee Martin gives added dimension
to offense. Florida QB Jesse Palmer faces hostile Neyland Stadium
crowd.

No. 4 Kansas State (2-0) vs. Texas (1-1)

-- Time/TV: 3:30/ABC. Line: K-State by 25. Turf: Artificial.

-- The stakes: Big 12 opener for both teams is Wildcats' first
test. Longhorns hope to avert slide that began with UCLA loss
in '97.

-- Plots and subplots: Longhorns are without QB Richard Walton
(broken finger). It's Major Applewhite's first start and he will
rely on RB Ricky Williams. Lopsided wins meant limited duty for
Wildcats' first-teamers. Texas defense must contain QB Michael
Bishop.

No. 5 UCLA (1-0) at Houston (0-2)

-- Time/TV: 3:30/FX. Line: UCLA by 271/2. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Bruins' offensive machine takes on second opponent
from Lone Star State before cross-country jaunt to Miami (Fla.).

-- Plots and subplots: While Cade McNown did nothing to damage
his Heisman credentials, Bruins' ground game hasn't suffered with
Jermaine Lewis stepping in at TB. Houston's defense has improved,
allowing 14 points in each of first two games. Turnovers and red-zone
inconsistencies have caused problems for Cougars.

No. 7 LSU (1-0) at Auburn (1-1)

-- Time/TV: 5/ESPN. Line: LSU by 41/2. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: This year's "Clash of the Tigers" is LSU's first
step on long road to SEC Championship Game. Auburn goes for second
conference win in its bid to return to Georgia Dome.

-- Plots and subplots: Auburn's defense must keep this one low
scoring. Limited quick-strike capability could make two-score
lead insurmountable for either team, but LSU's experienced offense
under QB Herb Tyler and TB Kevin Faulk might be better equipped
for comeback. Auburn needs error-free game from QB Ben Leard.

No. 8 Penn State (2-0) at Pittsburgh (1-0)

-- Time/TV: 3:30/CBS. Line: Penn State by 251/2. Turf: Artificial.

-- The stakes: Nittany Lions look to prove they still rule the
roost in western Pennsylvania before embarking on Big Ten campaign.

-- Plots and subplots: It will be up to veteran QB Matt Lytle
and his top WR Latef Grim to keep Panthers moving. LB Brandon
Short and his PSU defense don't allow much ground yardage. Penn
State TB Aaron Harris could see his first action of 1998.

No. 9 Washington (1-0) vs. Brigham Young (1-1)

-- Time/TV: 3:30/ABC. Line: Washington by 91/2. Turf: Artificial.

-- The stakes: BYU takes aim at upsetting another ranked Pac-10
team. Huskies can't afford to anticipate next week's visit to
Nebraska.

-- Plots and subplots: Return of RB Ronney Jenkins after year-long
suspension has given huge lift to BYU's offense. Cougars will
need better output from QB Kevin Feterik and repeat performance
from defense. Washington QB Brock Huard methodically produced
285 yards in last year's win at Provo. Huskies WRs Dane Looker
and Ja'Warren Hooker were banged up in Arizona State game but
should be ready.

No. 10 Virginia (2-0) vs. Clemson (1-1)

-- Time/TV: 3:30/ABC. Line: Virginia by 15. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Cavaliers look to continue fast start with second
Atlantic Coast Conference win. Tigers face second tough opponent
from Virginia.

-- Plots and subplots: Visiting team has won last three meetings,
but Clemson must patch many holes for trend to continue. Foremost,
Tigers' offensive line must protect QB Brandon Streeter. Cavaliers'
defense has nine sacks. Two guys named Jones, UVa RB Thomas and
Clemson LB Chris, could become well acquainted. Cavaliers QB Aaron
Brooks has attempted 54 passes with no interceptions.

No. 11 Florida State (1-1) vs. Duke (2-0)

-- Time: 7. Line: FSU by 281/2. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Seminoles hope to re-establish their dominant
presence, but they face confident Blue Devils.

-- Plots and subplots: Florida State will attempt to take charge
with TB Travis Minor and power running game. Seminoles' defense
has to turn up its pass rush against Duke's hot QB Spencer Romine.
Blue Devils TB B.J. Hill is ACC's top freshman rusher.

No. 12 Georgia (2-0) vs. Wyoming (1-0)

-- Time: 2. Line: Georgia by 181/2. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Cowboys venture into Southeastern Conference country
to take on Bulldogs in first-ever meeting.

-- Plots and subplots: Bulldogs have yet to surrender a TD, but
Wyoming coach Dana Dimel made defense top priority. His unit anchored
by LB Brian Brown and SS Greg Van Leer could keep Cowboys in game.
Wyoming needs production from RB Marques Brigham. Georgia CB/WR
Champ Bailey now starts both ways.

No. 13 Syracuse (1-1) vs. Rutgers (1-1)

-- Time: Noon. Line: Syracuse by 42. Turf: Artificial.

-- The stakes: After big win in the "Big House," Orangemen
will get heroes' welcome as they return to Carrier Dome for Big
East opener.

-- Plots and subplots: QB Donovan McNabb and his multiple-look
attack should control things for Syracuse. Heralded freshman RB
James Mungro should see ample playing time. Rutgers QB Mike McMahon
has yet to find his groove.

No. 14 Wisconsin (2-0) vs. UNLV (0-2)

-- Time: 2. Line: Wisconsin by 38. Turf: Artificial.

-- The stakes: Badgers finish preconference slate as Rebels make
second visit to Big Ten territory.

-- Plots and subplots: RB Ron Dayne is all but assured of breaking
Billy Marek's school rushing record (he is 33 yards away). Impressive
freshman Carlos Daniels will get his share of carries as well.

No. 15 Colorado (2-0) vs. Utah State (0-2)

-- Time: 3. Line: Colorado by 22. Turf: Artificial.

-- The stakes: Big West champion Utah State continues ambitious
non-conference schedule. Colorado looks to regain Week One form.

-- Plots and subplots: Colorado came out of last week's close
call with Fresno State with several injuries, most significantly
QB Mike Moschetti (rib cage) who is questionable. WR Marcus Stiggers
(hand) is out. Aggies' defense led by LB Tony D'Amato could complicate
matters for Buffs if lineup changes are needed.

No. 16 So. California (2-0) vs. Oregon State (2-0)

-- Time: 10. Line: USC by 15. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Is USC back? We might not know for another week.
Beavers are, er, eager to show they're no longer Pac-10 doormats.

-- Plots and subplots: DE Inoke Breckterfield and LBs Brian Rogers
and Bryan Jones are mainstays of Oregon State's defense. Unit
gets toughest challenge to date in trying to contain Trojans big-play
threats, RB Chad Morton and WR R. Jay Soward.

No. 17 Arizona (2-0) vs. Iowa (1-1)

-- Time/TV: 10/Fox Sports Net. Line: Arizona by 111/2. Turf:
Grass.

-- The stakes: Promising start to Wildcats' season resumes in
first home game. Hawkeyes must regroup quickly from Iowa State
loss.

-- Plots and subplots: Arizona hasn't lost its home opener since
15-14 defeat in 1987 -- to Iowa. But this Wildcats' group looks
sharp with RB Trung Canidate up to speed. Hawkeyes must do better
protecting QB Kyle McCann as he fills in for injured Randy Reiners
(knee).

No. 18 Texas A&M (1-1) at Southern Miss (0-1)

-- Time/TV: 3/Fox Sports Net. Line: A&M by 21/2. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: This road trip is no picnic for Aggies. Southern
Miss is solid and has rare opportunity to topple big-name team
in Hattiesburg.

-- Plots and subplots: USM has proven combination of QB Lee Roberts
and WR Sherrod Gideon, but Golden Eagles must find their running
game. Aggies will try to use RBs Dante Hall, Sirr Parker and D'Andre
Hardeman to control clock and neutralize raucous crowd.

No. 20 West Virginia (0-1) vs. Maryland (1-1)

-- Time/TV: 6/ESPN2. Line: WVU by 20. Turf: Artificial.

-- The stakes: Mounties want to make short work of Maryland.
Terrapins need to demonstrate that they have made strides.

-- Plots and subplots: As always, No. 1 assignment for Maryland
defense is containing RB Amos Zereoue, who could be due for breakout
performance. Terrapins' ground potential increased with return
from injury of RB Lamont Jordan. QB Ken Mastrole needs better
line protection.

No. 21 Virginia Tech (2-0) at Miami (Fla.) (2-0)

-- Time/TV: 8/ESPN. Line: Miami by 4. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: This is an early showdown between two Big East
rivals who could figure prominently in conference race.

-- Plots and subplots: Game's key matchup pits Miami's formidable
TB combination of Najeh Davenport and Edgerrin James against Tech's
rock-solid defense that has surrendered only a single FG. Hokies
QB Al Clark is threat to run but must improve his accuracy.

No. 23 Oregon (2-0) vs. San Jose State (1-1)

-- Time: 5. Line: Oregon by 24. Turf: Artificial.

-- The stakes: Oregon takes on its second set of Spartans this
season hoping for similar success. SJSU goes for second win over
Pac-10 foe.

-- Plots and subplots: Oregon QB Akili Smith has firm hold on
starting job, but he must beware of SJSU's secondary, which has
5 INTs. One beneficiary of Ducks' slow offensive start last week
was P Josh Bidwell, now ranked second nationally in net average.

No. 24 N.C. State (2-0) at Baylor (0-1)

-- Time/TV: 12:30. Line: N.C. State by 5. Turf: Grass.

-- The stakes: Wolfpack could benefit from long road trip as
euphoria from Florida State win subsides, but Baylor has other
ideas.

-- Plots and subplots: This will be first game played on newly
installed SportGrass surface at Floyd Casey Stadium. Baylor QB
Odell James had rocky first start at Oregon State. N.C. State
QB Jamie Barnette has thrown two or more TD passes in his last
six games.

Rest of the Top 25

No. 3 Nebraska, No. 22 Alabama and No. 25 Notre Dame are idle.

-- Lines by USA TODAY sports analyst Danny Sheridan.

                             461 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                  July 26, 1998, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

NEIGHBORHOOD REPORTS: EAST SIDE;
Watching Patches of Green Turn to Greenbacks

BYLINE: By EDWARD LEWINE

SECTION: Section 14; Page 5; Column 3; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 545 words


Around the East Village this week, people who garden on city-owned plots of land
were wondering whether the gardens they love had been sold, and to whom, and
what was going to be done with them.

"I can't do anything if the city sells," said Jorge Rivera, 68. "If the city
doesn't sell I will keep gardening." Mr. Rivera did not know on Thursday that
the plot he has tended on Fourth Street just west of Avenue C for the last 20
years had been sold.

"Everyone is against the sale," said Jose Rivera (no relation to Jorge), who was
sitting in his car outside the Villa Vitin Garden on Fifth Street west of Avenue
D, which had been sold for $140,000.

Open land is a hot issue downtown, and it got hotter last Monday when the city
sold 172 plots and buildings throughout the boroughs, including 23 properties
downtown, for a total of $3.98 million. Most of the downtown plots were open
land that fetched prices in excess of $100,000, with some plots going for more
than $300,000.

The auction was repeatedly disrupted by East Village protesters who said that
the land was going to developers. But until the sales become final, which could
take a month, the identities of the new owners remain a secret. Developers,
politicians and community advocates, however, agreed that prices for land in the
East Village were surging because of a demand for housing.

"Two years ago it would have been people buying for speculation," said Robert
Perl, who has been an East Village broker and developer for 15 years and who
said he knows some people who bought at Monday's auction. "Now they are buying
with the intent to build soon."

Shaya Boymelgreen, a developer who is now renting apartments in a new building
he constructed on Second Street and Avenue B, sat down with a calculator and
explained why empty land in the East Village was worth so much. By his figuring,
a seven-unit apartment building on most brownstone-sized plots can earn around
$250,000 a year in rent. Even with taxes and mortgages, that's good money.

"So you are going to earn $125,000 a year," he said. "Why not do it?"

But contrary to the common assumption, a few plots were bought not by developers
but by groups of local residents who wanted to preserve a garden or open space.

"We felt so happy that we got the place," said Catherine Kord, one of five
neighbors who paid $63,000 for a plot on Seventh Street, east of Avenue C. "But
with all the drama going on there at the auction we felt out of touch with a lot
of the people."

What Ms. Kord meant was that many in pro-gardening circles are against the very
idea of the city selling land that, they say, was already paid for by the
efforts of those who worked it.

"It was the community members through sweat equity who made these places
beautiful," said Vivian Miller of the New York City Community Garden Coalition.
"Suddenly you watch some stranger buy this plot you have worked so hard for."

Which is exactly what happened to Mr. Rivera. But he was stoic about the sale of
his little garden, which he had named the Fourth Street Casita Garden. It was
sold for $170,000.

"It is a lot of money," said Mr. Rivera, who lives alone on his pensions. "I
hope they will give me time to get my tools out of there."   EDWARD LEWINE

LOAD-DATE: July 26, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo: "What a Garden Goes For"
These four properties were included in an auction by New York City last Monday.
But while the city called the five sites vacant lots, an activist group said the
sites are gardens that should be preserved.

                            Dayton Daily News (Ohio)

                            January 15, 2007 Monday
                              Correction Appended

Coura ge and passion in the face of adversity;
Martin Luther King Jr. faced constant abuse and threats, including two alleged
plots to kill the civil rights leader here in the Miami Valley.

BYLINE: By Khalid Moss Staff Writer

SECTION: LIFE; Pg. D8

LENGTH: 512 words


Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in Memphis in 1968.

But four years earlier, there was an alleged plot to slay King here in Ohio.

On the morning of June 10, 1964, Greene County Sheriff Russell A. Bradley
received a suspicious phone call. The unidentified female caller informed
Bradley of a plot by the local chapter of the Ku Klux Klan "to assassinate Dr.
Martin Luther King," who was scheduled to speak at Wilberforce University that
evening.

"We checked several bouquets of flowers before they were taken into Shorter
Hall," Bradley later told the Dayton Daily News Greene County Bureau. "But Dr.
King didn't take it too seriously. He indicated he was used to such calls."

A year later, during King's visit to Antioch College, assassination rumors
resurfaced. This time the threat had more teeth because the scheme was confirmed
- under oath before Congress - by the intended trigger-man.

According to a 1965 report from the Dayton Daily News Washington Bureau, King
was targete for assassination in Yellow Srings on June 19, 1965, as he adressed
commencement exercises at Antioch College. Daniel Wagner, the 19 year-old
confessed conspirator, told the House Un-American Activities Committee he
planned the killing with Cincinnati Klanswoman Eloise Witte and was instructed
to use a rifle furnished b a Daytonian identified only as "Mr. Davis." Wagner
was to be assisted by 10 gunmen who would "fire into the crowd at the outdoor
commencement services while I (Wagner) shot King in the head.

"The plot was called off when W itte told me she couldn't organize the 10
shooters because of hr work at the same time with the Ku Klux Klan in South
Lebanon," Wagner testified.

King was a lightning rod for hrassment and abuse. In addition to vicious
encounters with fir ehoses, snarling dogs, billy clubs and tear gas, King's
house was bombed, he was punched at a Selma, Ala., diner, struck by a rock in
Chicago, stabbed in Harlem, brutalized by law enforcement officials in
Mississippi and arrested more than 150 times. All for the cause of freedom.

On April 4, 1968, at 6:01 a.m., an assassin's bullet extinguished the life, but
not the dream, of the idealistic preacher from Atlanta.

Antioch College librarian/ historian Scott Sanders said it's ironic that Antioch
- a bastion of liberalism and Coretta Scott King's alma mater - would be the
backdrop for a plot to kill the man who stood for peace and nonviolence. "I
didn't know about the Yellow Springs plot," Sanders said. "What I do know about
that day at Antioch is there was an enormous amount of security. There were
state, county and local police all over the place and probably some feds
sprinkled in. People who were there that day said they never saw so much
security anywhere, let alone in Yellow Springs. And now, just now, maybe we know
why."

Contact this reporter at (937) 225-2167 or kmoss@DaytonDailyNews.com.

Additional research by Staff Artist MB Hopkins and Assistant Director of News
Research Phillip Elam.

King Jr. was assassinated in Memphis at 6:01 p.m., April 4, 1968.

                                 Ottawa Citizen

                        May 3, 2004 Monday Final Edition

Fine Tuning - Today on TV: Digging deep for reality on Family Plots

SOURCE: The Ottawa Citizen

BYLINE: Alex Strachan

SECTION: Arts; Fine Tuning - Today on TV; Pg. C3

LENGTH: 379 words

The plot thickens on Family Plots, the wry reality series that plays like a
real-life Six Feet Under crossed with The Addams Family, as filmed by a
cinema-verite documentary crew (9 p.m. on A&E).

Shonna Smith, head mortician and chief embalmer at San Diego's Poway Bernardo
Mortuary, prefers to stay in the back room and prepare the dead instead of
organizing funerals with the living. She gets too emotionally involved, you see.

Tonight, however, she has to do everything herself, after funeral assistant
Chuck Wissmiller is suffering from memory loss and keeps losing the money he
needs to buy a new car. A former boxer, he has a really, really bad temper,
which is what every funeral home needs.

The family in Family Plots is nothing like the family in Six Feet Under, of
course. Reality has a way of trumping fiction. Besides, Shonna has never even
seen Six Feet Under.

"The way I see it, I get Six Feet Under all day long here," she says.

Tonight's new episode will be followed by a repeat of the Family Plots premiere,
in which Shonna was given 30 minutes to get a body into its casket and to the
funeral before all hell broke loose. It never ends, in other words. Even after
death.

* First Light, VisionTV's visually splendid documentary series about Tuscany and
the dawn of the Renaissance (9 p.m.), takes a decidedly un-Apprentice-like
approach to everyone's favourite subject, money, in a look at what happened
following the fall of the Roman Empire.

The episode recalls how international trade ground to a halt following Rome's
collapse, until Pope Innocent III launched the first of several crusades to win
back the Holy Land for Christendom. Roads were repaired across Europe, not to
facilitate trade so much as to enable the crusaders to reach Jerusalem without
suffering the indignity of a bumpy ride along the way.

-Charlie (Charlie Sheen) sleeps with someone he isn't supposed to -- his best
buddy's divorce attorney (Heather Locklear) -- on Two and a Half Men (9:30 p.m.
on CBS). Quick, someone call CNN.

- The Fox network has added a last-minute special to tonight's menu, the self
explanatory American Idol: The Final Five 2004 (8 p.m. on Fox and CTV). Because,
let's face it, there isn't nearly enough American Idol on TV these days.

                             464 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                  July 1, 1993, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

9th Held in Bomb Plot as Tie Is Made to a 1991 Murder

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

SECTION: Section B; Page 3; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 909 words


A ninth suspect was arrested yesterday in the plot to bomb targets throughout
New York City. At the same time, law-enforcement officials said one of the
original suspects, Clement Rodney Hampton-El, has been considered a prime
suspect in a 1991 murder in Brooklyn that has become a focal point for
investigators trying to unravel the two recent terrorist cases in New York.

The new suspect, Earl Gant, a 27-year-old Philadelphia man who had discussed
supplying explosives for the foiled plot, was arrested at his home in West
Philadelphia about 4 P.M., the F.B.I. said. Mr. Gant, also known as Abdul Rashid
and Abdul Jalil, was charged with conspiracy to transport explosives in
interstate commerce. F.B.I. agents were still searching his home last night.

A neighbor who lives four doors away, Geraldine Mitchell, described Mr. Gant
last night as a devout Muslim black from Puerto Rico. He dressed in the
traditional Muslim garb and washed his hands and feet with water every morning
on his front stoop, she said, and sold incense, perfumed oil and firecrackers.

Sought Explosives

Law-enforcement officials described Mr. Gant as a minor figure in the case. They
also said discussions continued on whether to arrest Sheik Omar Abdel-Rahman,
the fiery Egyptian preacher who investigators believe knew of the plot
beforehand.

A Federal complaint charged that on May 19, Mr. Gant met in Philadelphia with
Siddig Ibrahim Siddig Ali, the man accused of being the ringleader in the
bombing plot, who was seeking explosives to build a bomb. Afterward, Mr. Siddig
Ali told a Government informant, Emad Salem, who had accompanied him to
Philadelphia, that Mr. Gant could obtain a "powerful explosive."

On May 25, Mr. Siddig Ali said that another one of his sources for explosives,
Mr. Hampton-El, who was arrested last week, could provide two grenades, but he
was still waiting to hear from Mr. Gant about the explosives, according to the
complaint. Four days later, Mr. Siddig Ali called Mr. Salem to say he had no
news from Philadelphia, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

8 Held Without Bail

On June 6, Mr. Siddig Ali elaborated further on his plans, saying he told Mr.
Gant that the explosives he was to supply were to be used for "protection."
F.B.I. agents refused to explain further at a news conference in Philadelphia
last night.

The arrest came as law-enforcement officials said that Mr. Hampton-El, a revered
Muslim figure in Brooklyn who fought in Afghanistan, has been considered a prime
suspect in the 1991 murder of Mustafa Shalabi, a Brooklyn man who raised
millions of dollars and recruits for Afghan rebels.

The murder was never solved but the officials said information from the
confidential informant in the bombing plot could help them solve the case.
Mahmud Abouhalima, a prime suspect in the World Trade Center bombing, is also
considered an important suspect in the slaying. The officials would not
elaborate on the status of the case.

The murder of Mr. Shalabi, who was an Egyptian immigrant, illuminated tensions
within Brooklyn's Arab neighborhood. It has become a major point of interest to
investigators examining the World Trade Center bombing, the foiled plot to blow
up the United Nations, Hudson River tunnels and the Federal building in
Manhattan and the 1990 slaying of the militant Rabbi Meir Kahane. All four
cases, they contend, touch largely on the same pool of suspects and Islamic
militancy.

Investigators had previously linked Mr. Abouhalima to the Shalabi murder. But
this week they confirmed that Mr. Hampton-El, an X-ray technician, has long been
under investigation in the case. Mr. Abouhalima has denied any connection to the
killing. Mr. Hampton-El's lawyer, Ken Wasserman, did not return phone calls
seeking comment.

Both men were deemed suspects because of their involvement in a bitter dispute
in which several members in Brooklyn's Arab neighborhood accused Mr. Shalabi of
stealing up to $2 million intended for the rebels.

Mr. Hampton-El, like Mr. Abouhalima, sided with Mr. Shalabi's accusers,
including a Brooklyn imam, Fawaz Damrah, and Sheik Abdel-Rahman, people
connected to the mosque say.

Mr. Hampton-El, known as Dr. Rashid and described by other worshippers as being
very close to Mr. Damrah, pressed Mr. Shalabi to discuss the dispute. Mr.
Shalabi refused. Tensions mounted, investigators say, and culminated in the
murder. Investigators ruled out a robbery as a motive.

"From the beginning, his name came up," said one official familiar with the
case, referring to Mr. Hampton-El. "He was part of a group that was looking to
have a sit-down with Shalabi about the funds."

Associates of Mr. Hampton-El said that, even before the Shalabi murder, he told
them he was under some kind of surveillance because of his reputation for
militancy.

Law-enforcement officials said Mr. Hampton-El, who injured his leg while
fighting for the Afghan resistance, has connections to al-Fuqra, an Islamic sect
linked to violence in the United States and Canada. And as a respected figure
who helped rid his neighborhood of drugs, Mr. Hampton-El may have given his
blessing to murders and bank robberies, law-enforcement officials say. They say
he has no criminal record.

But local Arabs said the burly 55-year-old man and other Muslim blacks were
often called to provide security for Arab-owned shops and mosques, to deter drug
dealers or other undesirables.

LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                            March 12, 2011 Saturday

BYLINE: KAREN HERZOG Bismarck Tribune

SECTION: DAKOTA WIRE; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 501 words


Planning is under way for this year's community gardens in Mandan and Bismarck.

Last year, some 50 plots were taken for the Mandan Community Gardens along
Memorial Highway near the Mandan soccer fields, said Jackie Buckley, North
Dakota State Universityextension agent for Morton County.

Those interested in participating in the Mandan Community Gardens for the coming
season are invited to the first meeting of the season. The meeting is at 5:30
p.m. March 28 at the Morton County Courthouse, 210 Second Ave. N.W., Mandan, and
is open to anyone interested in becoming part of this year's community gardens.

The Mandan Community Garden plots are 20-by-20 feet. A deposit of $25 and a
rental fee of $25 are required to hold a spot. Remaining spots will be given on
a first-come, first-served basis.

The community garden is a cooperative project of the Mandan Park District, the
Mandan Fire Department, the city of Mandan, Morton County and North Dakota State
University Extension Morton County.

In Bismarck, the 2011 Bismarck Community Gardens and Hunger Gardens are located
just west of the Municipal Ballpark, south of Memorial Highway and east of
Hannifin Street.

Bismarck Parks and Recreation Department provides the land and staff who prepare
the soil in the spring and till it again in the fall. Parks and Recreation also
provides garbage container use and garbage pick-up at the garden site throughout
the growing season.

Community Gardens board volunteers organize the plots, sign-ups and activities
at the garden.

Plots are open on a first-come, first-served basis, with priority given to those
who rented plots last year. Plots are 10-by-10-feet and cost $10 for the season.
Renters are responsible for planting, keeping their plots watered and weeded and
for cleaning up at the end of the season.

Those who had plots last year will be contacted by mail soon. Others who did not
have plots last year and who are interested in a plot this year should contact
volunteer coordinator Kent Morrow at 255-1344.

A small number of plots will be available to those who wish to grow food for the
Creating a Hunger-Free North Dakota Hunger Garden Program and donate their
produce to area food agencies, said volunteer coordinator Karen Ehrens. All area
gardeners are encouraged to plant an extra row to donate some produce, Ehrens
said.

Last year, Bismarck-Mandan area gardeners donated more than 16,000 pounds of
produce to area food agencies, and this year coordinators hope to reach 20,000
pounds.

Hunger Garden plots are 20-by-20-feet; those interested in Hunger Garden plots
should contact Ehrens at 223-2616.

For more information on the Community Gardens, visit http://bismarckgardens.org.

Members who wish to rent last year's Mandan Community Gardens plots should
contact Buckley immediately at jackie.buckley@ndsu.edu

New members may contact either Buckley at 667-3340 or Sue Balcom at 667-0122, to
reserve a spot or for more information.

(Reach reporter Karen Herzog at 250-8267 or karen.herzog@bismarcktribune.com)

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                                 Hobart Mercury

                            March 8, 2006 Wednesday

Man who could have stopped 9/11

BYLINE: ADAM HARVEY

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 306  words


ZACARIAS Moussaoui condemned almost 3000 people to death when he refused to
reveal details of al-Qaida's September 11, 2001 plot, a US court heard
yesterday.

A jury has begun hearing evidence to decide whether to order the death penalty
or life imprisonment for 37-year-old French citizen Moussaoui, the only person
convicted over the 2001 attacks.

Prosecutor Rob Spencer told the jurors in Alexandria, Virginia, they were
looking at the one person who could have stopped the carnage.

''Killers were among us that day and for months before that -- killers that
lived among us in the US, waiting and planning to slit our throats and crash our
planes,'' Spencer said. ''One of them is among us still, and that is Zacarias
Moussaoui.''

Moussaoui was in custody on September 11. He had been arrested nearly one month
before the attacks on the World Trade Centre and the Pentagon that killed 2972
people after a Minnesota flight instructor reported concerns about him.

He was questioned repeatedly by the FBI but did not reveal any details of the
plot.

''He lied so the plot could proceed unimpeded,'' Spencer said. ''With that lie,
he caused the deaths of nearly 3000 people. He rejoiced in the death and
destruction.''

Prosecutors believe Moussaoui was to have been the 20th hijacker, and knew
crucial details about the attacks.

He has always argued that he was destined for a separate attack that never
eventuated. His lawyers say he did not know of the 9/11 plot because other
al-Qaida members viewed him as ''cuckoo''.

Moussaoui's mother, Aicha el-Wafi, watched proceedings from an adjacent room and
wept as the prosecutor outlined the reasons why he should die. Earlier, she
expressed her sadness over the September 11 attacks.

About 200 relatives of 9/11 victims viewed the proceedings from courtrooms in
Manhattan, Boston, Newark and Philadelphia.

                                  Computerworld

                                August 13, 1984

VERSATEC, INC.
Models 7222, 7422, 7224, 7424 plotters

SECTION: SYSTEMS & PERIPHERALS; PRINTERS/PLOTTERS; Pg. 88

LENGTH: 174 words


Versatec, Inc., a Xerox Corp. company, has added four models to its 7000 family
of plotters.

Models 7222 and 7422 plot on 22-in. -wide media, and Models 7224 and 7424 plot
on 24-in.-wide media, the company said. Models in the 7200 series plot at 200
point/in., and models in the 7400 series plot at 400 point/in., the company
said.

An adjustable plot speed control permits the operator or host processor to set
the speed from .125 in./sec to a rated speed of 1.5 in./sec (7200 series),
enabling 24-in. models to plot up to 15 sq ft/min, the company said.

Maximum accumulated error of a plot is c.15%, horizontal and vertical.

The models use standard voltages and demand less power, said to be reduced from
1,600W to 600W.

The 7000 series plotters are intended to meet meantime between failure of 4,000
power-on hours.

The Model 7222 and 7224 cost $26,200; and the Model 7422 and 7424 cost $35,900,
the vendor said. Shipments of the plotters are scheduled for November.

Versatec, 2710 Walsh Ave., Santa Clara, Calif. 95051.

                             468 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                           October 30, 2010 Saturday
                                   Edition 1;
                                    Scotland

Extremists have always looked to the skies;
OTHER PLOTS

BYLINE: Tom Whitehead

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 469 words


TERRORISTS bent on mass slaughter have regularly turned to aircraft to aid in
their plots, from blowing them up in mid-air to using them as weapons.

Long before 9/11, the world's worst terrorist attack, aircraft had been at the
centre of outrages.

In 1988 Pan Am flight 103 was blown up over the small town of Lockerbie in
Scotland, killing 270 people, including 11 on the ground.

Abdelbaset Al Megrahi, a Libyan, was the only man convicted for the attack, in
which a bomb was planted on board. His release from a Scottish jail on health
grounds last year started an international outcry.

But the more modern brand of Islamic terrorism has brought a new dimension to
airline plots with killers prepared to board plane and become suicide bombers.

One of al-Qaeda's earlier attempts for a mass airborne attack was the Bojinka
plot in 1995 when terrorists planned to blow up 12 airliners, killing around
4,000 passengers, as they flew from Asia to the United States.

One of the key men behind the plot was Khalid Sheikh Mohammed who went on to
mastermind the 9/11 attack on the US. On September 11, 2001, al-Qaeda, funded by
Osama bin Laden, flew two passenger planes in to the Twin Towers of the World
Trade Centre in New York killing almost 3,000 people.

Beyond the sheer scale of the outrage that stunned the world, it marked a
turning point as the planes had been used as weapons rather than having
explosives on board.

Airline security was never the same again.

Later that year, Richard Reid, from London, revealed yet another tactic as he
tried to detonate explosives hidden in his shoe while on a flight to Miami.

Despite failing to trigger the explosives Reid, currently serving a life
sentence in America, became known as the "shoe bomber" and his plot led to many
airports demanding passengers remove their footwear as they pass through
security.

Last year Umar Farouk Abdul Mutallab tried to blow up Northwest Airlines Flight
253 from Amsterdam to Detroit.

It is believed that Mutallab had moulded a quantity of explosive powder to his
body, sewn into his underwear and then attempted to detonate the device using a
liquid chemical in a syringe.

Officials believe that a catastrophe was averted only because the makeshift
detonator failed to work. The largest plot since 9/11, however, was the
so-called "liquid bomb" plot in 2006 when al-Qaeda terrorists planned to target
several transatlantic airliners.

The gang planned to disguise bombs in soft drinks bottles and researched seven
flights from Heathrow to the US and Canada.

But police believe an even larger operation was planned after the gang was
bugged and heard discussing as many as 18 suicide attacks.

The plot, which could have seen a death toll of up to 10,000, resulted in severe
restrictions on liquids on planes.

A total of 11 people were eventually convicted.

LOAD-DATE: October 30, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: 1 The aftermath of the Lockerbie bombing in December 1988 2 The 9/11
attacks 3 Richard Reid, who became known as the 'shoe bomber' 4 A video still of
Umar Farouk Abdul Mutallab, who tried to detonate explosives on a flight to
Detroit, at a training camp in Yemen 5 Evidence collected in connection with the
'liquid bomb' plot in 2006, which could have resulted in a death toll of up to
10,000
REUTERS/AP/PA

                         Portland Press Herald (Maine)

                           March 20, 1997, Thursday,

UNE STUDENTS PLAN TO STUDY IMPACT ON RIVER WATERSHED

SECTION: YORK COUNTY EXTRA, Pg. 3E, PUBLIC INTEREST

LENGTH: 764 words

DATELINE: BIDDEFORD


Nine students from the University of New England have joined together for a
community service learning project aimed at better understanding the human
impact on the York River Watershed.

The project will also involve community officials and interest groups,
environmentalists, and UNE professors. Their goal is to develop and implement a
biological and sociological assessment of the watershed for future planning
purposes.

Initially, students will survey York residents to determine how the community
feels about the York River waterway, and what they believe should be done with
the waterway in the future. The students will also assess the microbial and
invertebrate populations of the watershed. The course work will culminate with a
final report prepared for the York town planner.

Romoser is panelist at scholars' conference

ELIOT - George K. Romoser was a panelist at the 27th Annual Scholars' Conference
on the Holocaust and the Churches in Tampa, FL.

Romoser spoke on ''Theses of a Cultural and Artistic Revolt Against Modernity in
the Diagnosis of Nazi Totalitarianism'' on the panel, ''Historical Findings of
the Holocaust Era.''

KENNEBUNK - Habitat for Humanity York County has scheduled several Walks For
Humanity at the following locations:

Church

Saco - April 5, 8 a.m. to 10 a.m., meet at Saco United Baptist Church

Eliot - April 5, 8 a.m. to 10 a.m., meet at Eliot Congregational Church

For more information on participating call 985-4850.

York Extension offers community garden plots

SANFORD - Community Garden plots are available for this spring at the York
County Extension Office on Shaw's Ridge Road.

Plots are available, 10-by-25-feet, with access to water, tools, and hay mulch.
The plots are rototilled, manured, and limed according to the University soil
test recommendations.

The fee for this year is $ 15, and funds will be used for garden purchases.
Plots will be available in mid-April and may be used until the end of September.

Plots will be given out on a first-come, first-served basis. For more
information call 324-2814 or 1-800-287-1535.

April 12 Dance-A-Thon will aid aging agency

WELLS - The Trailblazers Family Club will sponsor its 4th Annual Line
Dance-A-Thon from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. April 12 at the Club on Bill's Lane to
benefit the Southern Maine Area Agency on Aging.

Those participants who would like to raise pledges to benefit SMAAA, entry to
the dance-a-thon is free. To raise pledges, dancers must commit to dancing at
least two hours, and those dancers who raise $ 100 or more in pledges will
receive a free t-shirt. For non-pledge dancers, entry fee is $ 3.

One hundred percent of the pledges raised will benefit SMAAA.

The Trailblazers are currently seeking dance instructors who are willing to
donate their time to this event. For more information, or for pledge forms,
contact Kathy Chase at 646-2118, Kay Bourassa at 646-3153, or Charlene Hill at
646-3377.

Towns' Girl Scout troop conducting bottle drive

WELLS - The Wells-Ogunquit Girl Scout Troop is conducting a bottle drive through
April 5 in the towns of Wells and Ogunquit.

Residents interested in donating their bottles or cans may arrange to have their
returnables collected by the Girl Scouts by calling 646-5646 or may opt to drop
their returnables off at The Bottle Shop on Route 1.

Proceeds are to benefit the Troop's upcoming trip to a June Camporee.

Sidewalk Arts Festival

set for Saco on June 28

SACO - The Saco Sidewalk Arts Festival will be held June 28 downtown.

More than 175 artists will be on hand from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. to display a variety
of artwork, sculpture, and photography. About $ 12,000 in cash prizes will be
awarded, including Best of Show, First Runner Up, and four Merit Awards in the
Art Category. A Photography and Sculpture Award will be given, and Purchase
Prizes are bought by area businesses and individuals to be awarded.

Applications will be accepted on original framed works of art. All paintings,
watercolors, graphics, photographs, and silk screening must be framed or matted,
and displayed in a suitable portfolio or stand. Competition artwork must be
available for all prizes, and may be ''sold'' for a minimum of $ 250.

All applications must be postmarked by May 31, and accompanied with an entry fee
of $ 40. For more information, or an application, contact the Saco Sidewalk Arts
Festival Committee at P.O. Box 336, Saco, 04072.

                               The New York Times

              January 28, 1984, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

GUATEMALAN REPORTS FOILED PLOT

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section 1; Page 4, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 356 words

DATELINE: GUATEMALA, Jan. 27


A Guatemalan security officer said today that the military Government foiled a
planned coup this month in which a group of retired generals hired an assassin
in Miami to kill the chief of state, Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores.

A Guatemalan Army press spokesman, Edgar Djalma Dominguez, declined to comment
on the report.

The security official said in an interview that the generals, who had been
forced to retire by a new military law, met in mid-January at a hotel in a Fort
Lauderdale, Fla., to plan General Mejia Victores's overthrow. The official said
they withdrew money from Miami bank accounts to hire a killer and bribe top
military commanders to join the plot.

The official refused to say which of 10 generals and 25 colonels forcibly
retired in December were instrumental in the plot.

He said the generals believed they could take advantage of the chaos caused by
the killing, which they believed would deepen a split between older and younger
officers.

No Arrests Made

None of the officers were arrested, and most are believed to be abroad.

''We know exactly what they were doing,'' the security official said. ''But how
do you prove a conspiracy?''

The official said the plot was uncovered when several base commanders informed
military intelligence about the plan to kill General Mejia Victores, who took
power in a coup Aug. 8.

He did not say whether the purported assassin, hired in Miami, had come to
Guatemala. He said not a single commander had joined the plot.

Coup rumors were so strong here two weeks ago that the United States Ambassador,
Frederick Chapin, warned in a news conference that Washington ''does not support
military coups.''

Vinicio Cerezo, head of the opposition Christian Democratic Party, said in an
interview that most politicians had heard reports of the plot. He said he had
heard that the former army Chief of Staff, Mario Lopez Fuentez, was called back
to Guatemala from Italy to play a leading role in the takeover.

But General Lopez Fuentes, now the Ambassador to Rome, has said in interviews
that he returned to Guatemala last week to visit his sick mother.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1984 The New York Times Company


                             471 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          Australian Financial Review

                            March 23, 2016 Wednesday
                                 First Edition

Australia a target for terror plots going viral;
Talking point

BYLINE: Jacinta Carroll and Anthony Bergin - Jacinta Carroll is head,
counter-terrorism policy centre, Australian Strategic Policy Institute. Anthony
Bergin is deputy director at ASPI.

SECTION: OPINION; Pg. 39

LENGTH: 715 words


The NSW Joint Counter Terrorism Team announced two arrests on charges of
financing terrorism on Tuesday. One was a 20-year-old male who was part of the
original Operation Appleby disruptions in September 2014. At the time, these
high-profile overt actions attracted some criticism for only resulting in two
arrests; Tuesday's charges bring the total number of arrests to 14.

Appleby illustrates the delicate balance between disrupting terrorist plots to
save lives - as occurred in 2014 - and making arrests on evidence of criminal
action, which may only occur some time later.

There's been a significant increase in terrorist plots against the West,
including Australia, in the past two years. Since 2014 Islamic State (ISIS) has
been tied to at least 75 plots against Western countries, with the United States
the group's main target.

That's the key finding of the report, Terror Gone Viral, released this month by
the US House Committee on Homeland Security. In 2014 there were 19 ISIS-linked
plots against the West. But last year the figure more than doubled to 48.

The high success rate - with more than 40 per cent of total plots executed -
indicates the group will likely continue to initiate frequent attacks.

More than one-third of ISIS-linked terror plots were aimed at the United States
or its interests overseas.

These include the San Bernardino shooting in December last year, which killed 14
and injured many more, an attempted ISIS-inspired attack in Garland, Texas,
outside a Prophet Muhammad cartoon contest, and numerous attempts to attack New
York City landmarks.

ISIS-inspired attacks targeting the West aren't only growing in number. They're
getting deadlier. In the second half of 2014, an average of one individual died
in each successful attack. In the first half of last year the average death toll
rose to 11.

The report notes that US counter-terrorism agencies are increasingly concerned
terrorists are "going dark": ISIS-linked attackers are encrypting communications
or making data inaccessible to authorities. It found that the line between
inspired and directed plots is getting blurrier: an individual can start off
self-radicalised and later gain ties with ISIS.

The study found that ISIS is successfully "crowd-sourcing" its terrorism agenda
by inspiring independent followers to conduct most of its attacks.

The majority of cases involve only a single suspect, some element of online
radicalisation or engagement with ISIS's digital propaganda. But so-called
lone-actor terrorists typically aren't acting alone: they're found to be engaged
with ISIS overseas.

The study notes that terrorists overwhelmingly opt to use easily accessible
weapons, such as knives or guns, over explosives.

At least one-third of ISIS-linked plots against the West involved an individual
who's gone abroad to train or fight in a terrorist safe haven. The report
indicates this estimate is low as accomplice roles aren't always clear.

The US study confirms that Syrian refugee flows and fake passports are being
exploited by ISIS to deploy terrorists to Western countries.

There are several key messages in this latest US study on the 75 ISIS-linked
plots against the West over the last two years for Australia's counter-terrorism
strategy.

Australia is ranked equal-third with the United Kingdom as a target of ISIS, of
those 22 countries attacked by ISIS outside the Syria-Iraq conflict zone.

We can continue to expect more attacks, underscoring the current terrorist
threat level of "probable".

The list of countries targeted belies the argument that ISIS will leave you
alone if you stay out of the coalition operations in Syria-Iraq: Spain,
Indonesia, Kosovo and Switzerland all feature on the list.

The report confirms Australia is right to be concerned about foreign fighters
playing a role in directing or participating in attacks back home. Our 110 known
living foreign fighters remain a problem.

The trend towards a high success rate of executed plots underscores the critical
importance of disrupting plots. The rapid turn-around time of those radicalising
and willing to use violence, as well as the number of plots, are placing extreme
demands on Australia's investigative capacity.

We need a counter-terrorism approach that provides effective powers and means to
disrupt terrorist plots.

                             472 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Capital (Annapolis, MD)

                              June 23, 2013 Sunday

Numbers game muddies NSA surveillance debate;
Intelligence officials citing a wide range of numbers to show importance of NSA
spy programs

SECTION: A; Pg.5

LENGTH: 957  words


WASHINGTON (AP) - Seeking to win back public trust, the Obama administration has
been throwing around a lot of numbers as it tries to describe - in as much
detail as possible without jeopardizing national security- the terror plots it
says were thwarted by the government's sweeping surveillance of U.S.
communications.

There's 702, 215, 90, 50, 20, 12, 10 and four.

The numbers game is just part of the effort to convince skeptical Americans that
the recently disclosed National Security Agency spy programs are vital in
detecting and stopping extremist plots. But the approach has produced relatively
limited, often vague information, and it has ended up confusing many in Congress
as lawmakers grapple with how to assure people that their privacy rights are
protected along with their security.

There are questions about effectiveness that still lack answers, "and we've
gotten some answers that need further clarity," House Intelligence Committee
member Rep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif., said Thursday. He was referring to the
so-called 215 program, which refers to the section of the anti-terror Patriot
Act that authorizes the NSA to collect Americans' phone records.

And, he added, "we also should ask in those cases where it was successful, how
dated were the records."

Another NSA program - known as 702 - authorizes the agency to sweep up Internet
usage data from all over the world that goes through nine major U.S.-based
providers.

Officials have used the rest of the numbers in Capitol Hill testimony over the
past week as they have sought to allay Americans' concerns that the programs
violate their privacy.

Top officials told Congress that the programs have been key in thwarting at
least 50 terror plots across 20 countries. And, they said, an estimated 10 to 12
of those plots were directed at the U.S. They publicly offered four examples
among the 50-plus cases:


     ·    An NSA-provided phone record led authorities to identify a terrorist
          financier in San Diego who was arrested in 2007.
     ·    The NSA's surveillance of Internet usage in 2009 revealed that a
          Chicago man, David Headley, was plotting to bomb a Danish newspaper
          that had published a cartoon of the prophet Muhammad, Deputy FBI
          Director Sean Joyce said. The FBI had been tipped off that Headley was
          involved in the deadly 2008 Mumbai terror attacks.



     ·    Information from the NSA's Internet usage surveillance of overseas
          operatives helped thwart a 2009 plot to blow up the New York City
          subway system. NSA Director General Keith Alexander said this
          information led investigators to Najibullah Zazi in Colorado. And the
          phone records collection gave investigators the connections between
          Zazi and his associates. Zazi ultimately pleaded guilty and provided
          information that helped send two of his friends to prison.



     ·    A plot to blow up the New York Stock Exchange was thwarted in its
          early planning stages because the NSA was able identify an extremist
          in Yemen who was in touch with Khalid Ouazzani in Kansas City, Mo.,
          Joyce said.


This enabled investigators to identify co-conspirators and prevent the attack he
said. Ouazzani pleaded guilty in May 2010 in federal court in Missouri to
charges of conspiracy to provide material support to a terrorist organization,
bank fraud and money laundering. Ouazzani was not charged with the alleged plot
against the stock exchange.

The administration has yet to provide firm numbers of precisely how many plots
have been stopped worldwide because of these programs - in part because
intelligence officials are still trying to figure that out.

On Wednesday, outgoing FBI Director Robert Mueller told the Senate Judiciary
Committee that there are 10 to 12 cases in which the phone records surveillance
program, authorized in the Patriot Act, contributed to breaking up terror plots.

He said that "of those, domestically, I think there will be anywhere from 10 or
12 where 215 was important in some way, shape or form."

But later in the same hearing, Mueller said he's not actually sure if it was the
phone records authorization that helped thwart terror attacks in the 10 to 12
cases.

"I'm not sure whether all of them are 215. They're a combination or the other,"
Mueller said, referring to the phone records program and Internet usage
programs.

The FBI could not immediately clarify Mueller's comments Thursday.

The confusion has, predictably, given rise to demands for more transparency by
the intelligence agencies.

A growing number of Democratic and Republican lawmakers are pushing plans to
open secret court orders authorizing the surveillance. Schiff, who filed House
legislation on Thursday to match a similar Senate proposal, said it aimed at
"allowing Americans to know how the court has interpreted the legal authorities"
to ensure they are not being overly or improperly intrusive.

Additionally, a group of mostly Democratic senators are seeking to amend the
Patriot Act to require the government to cite specific suspected links to
terrorism or espionage before asking the secretive Foreign Intelligence
Surveillance Court to approve the collection of Americans' phone records.

But the legislation isn't likely to be approved quickly, and confusion continues
to hang over Congress and its constituents.

Noting frustration, Republican House Intelligence Committee Chairman Mike Rogers
said trying to balance support for classified intelligence programs against a
transparent democracy is always a challenge. But all concerned agree the current
situation has fueled public skepticism.

"The public trusts their government to protect the country from another
9/11-type attack," Rogers said this week, "but that trust can start to wane when
they are faced with inaccuracies, half-truths and outright lies about the way
the intelligence programs are being run."

LOAD-DATE: June 21, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


              Copyright 2013 Capital Gazette Communications, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                             473 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               The New York Times

                             August 3, 2009 Monday
                              Late Edition - Final

With Demise of Jewish Burial Societies, Resting Places Are in Turmoil

BYLINE: By PAUL VITELLO

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 1123 words


Someone was buried in Florence Marmor's grave, and it was not Florence Marmor.

When Mrs. Marmor visited her deceased husband's cemetery plot in Flushing,
Queens, one afternoon, she found that someone had been freshly buried in the
spot next to his, where she had planned to rest someday. No one could tell her
why.

Strange and wrenching discoveries like that have sprung up repeatedly in Jewish
communities over the past few decades as families have discovered that the
cemetery properties where they expected to be buried among spouses, children and
parents are caught in a legal knot that no one can untangle.

The reason: the Jewish burial societies that sold the gravesites no longer have
administrators. Founded by the immigrant ancestors of the people caught in this
bind, the societies, in effect, have died.

The problem has mainly plagued New York, Boston and other Northeastern cities
where Jews arrived at the turn of the last century from Eastern Europe, bringing
with them the tradition of dues-paying societies -- usually organized by people
from the same hometown -- that bought and maintained cemetery plots.

Besides reducing burial costs, the societies held periodic meetings that became
important social events for networking and keeping up with others from similar
roots. Robust for decades, the associations lost members as descendants grew
affluent, moved away and left a dwindling, aging few to keep the books and the
cemetery lots in order.

Until recently, few religious or government officials took notice. But an
accrual of painful scenes has convinced some of the need for intervention.

''There isn't a week that goes by that we don't have problems with this,'' said
Richard Fishman, director of the New York State Division of Cemeteries, charged
with regulating burial plots. ''A person dies, and they can't get buried because
there is no one left to sign the papers, or the guy in charge is 99 years old
and in a nursing home.''

There are no exact figures, but officials like Mr. Fishman and leaders of Jewish
organizations estimate that while 20,000 or more burial societies once
flourished in the Northeast, managing plots in hundreds of Jewish cemeteries,
all but a few thousand are defunct.

By tradition, Jews must be buried within 24 hours of death. If the deceased is a
member of a burial society or a descendant of members, relatives are supposed to
contact an officer of the society, who verifies the person's membership and
signs a permit allowing the cemetery to open the assigned plot.

But Mrs. Marmor, 76, said that when she asked the cemetery director what
happened to her plot, he told her it had been sold by the president of the
burial society, who had since died.

''They couldn't do anything more for me,'' she said. After much stress, and with
help from a lawyer, she ended up restarting the defunct association, the
Trembowla Sisters Burial Society, and discovered to her relief that the plot on
the other side of her husband was available.

Some burial society officers are reluctant -- and not always reliable --
inheritors of the job.

Sam Falk took over the Friends of Zion of Harlem Burial Society after his
mother, for many years the society's acting president, entered an
assisted-living residence on Long Island a few years ago. He shipped the
society's file cabinets and cemetery maps to his home in Southern California.

''I tried to send out the notices and keep up,'' said Mr. Falk, 59, whose
grandfather founded the society in 1911, ''but to be honest, in the last few
years, I didn't have the time.''

He was rescued by a tiny agency of the New York State Insurance Department known
as the Office of Miscellaneous Estates. Tucked into a cluttered corner of the
state's Liquidation Bureau in Lower Manhattan, Miscellaneous Estates is where
burial societies go to die. The agency took the burial society off Mr. Falk's
hands after an elderly woman -- worried that he would not be able to provide her
a plot next to her mother in a Staten Island cemetery -- found a sympathetic
cemetery administrator who referred her to Miscellaneous Estates.

Robin Kraus, the agency's manager, and her assistant, Alice Jenkins, have taken
hundreds of burial societies into a sort of receivership over the past decade,
collecting dues from members until the last one is buried. They move with
practiced deftness through the thousands of ancient index cards, yellowing
ledger books and rolled-up oilcloth cemetery maps entrusted to their care.

''What we do is step up and perform all the functions of a burial society until
all the people entitled are buried,'' said Ms. Kraus, a lifelong civil servant
who, as the child of Holocaust survivors, found an emotional home when she
joined the bureau 15 years ago. Almost every Jewish cemetery in New York has her
phone number on auto-dial.

Many family members who call are desperate and distraught, she said.

''You have to be able to deal with people who are hard of hearing, and
oftentimes speak in thick accents,'' she said.

Mark G. Peters, who heads the quasi-public Liquidation Bureau, which protects
consumers who hold policies with failed insurance companies, said the government
viewed burial societies as a type of insurer. ''They may be a historically
anachronistic insurance product,'' he said, ''but we are essentially the only
safety net for people still depending on these societies.''

Mark Wittlin, 53, remembered attending meetings with his father at a burial
society in Brooklyn known as the Senate Association. Members would address one
another with honorifics like ''noble grand brother'' and solemnly discuss
financial and maintenance matters while he and other children prowled the rented
hall.

When he graduated from college, his father and other members asked him to become
an officer, but he declined. When his father died, they asked again and he
declined again.

A lawyer took over the society. When the lawyer died a few years ago, Mr.
Wittlin answered the door one day to find a young man there, several large
shopping bags arrayed around him, with rolled-up maps jutting out: the records
of the Senate Association.

'' 'My uncle wanted you to have these,' he says,'' Mr. Wittlin recounted. ''He
was the lawyer's nephew.''

Mr. Wittlin said he tried to be a good president. But there were 60 remaining
members, including some in nursing homes and some unaccounted for -- though
liable to pop up needing service at any time.

When someone told him about Robin Kraus, he went to see her. He took along the
shopping bags.  ''I just don't have the energy for this,'' he told her.

She and Ms. Jenkins told him not to worry. They unpacked the records and maps,
and told him they would take it from there.

URL: http://www.nytimes.com

LOAD-DATE: August 3, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

and oversight had led to neglect. Researching old ledgers and maps, Robin Kraus,
above, manager of New York State's Office of Miscellaneous Estates, helps people
obtain deeds to plots they bought through now-defunct burial
societies.(PHOTOGRAPH BY LIBRADO ROMERO/THE NEW YORK TIMES)

                                  Edmonton Sun

                            August 18, 2016 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

The plot thickens

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A78

LENGTH: 137  words

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I.


A Rhode Island cemetery buried two men in the wrong plots, and now officials are
trying to broker a solution.

The problem started in October, when a 65-year-old man was placed in the wrong
family plot at Pocasset Hill Cemetery in Tiverton. No one noticed until March,
when an 87-year-old man who was supposed to be buried there died. So the
87-year-old was buried in the other man's plot.

"You've got to put him somewhere," Anne Turcotte, chairwoman of the town
cemetery commission. Turcotte says there's an easy fix: switch the deeds for the
plots.

But the 87-year-old's family does not want that; they want him exhumed and
buried in the plot they picked, Turcotte said.

The other man's family wants him kept in what they thought would be his final
resting place. !@COPYRIGHT=© 2016 Sun Media Corporation. All rights reserved.

A Rhode Island cemetery buried two men in the wrong plots, and now officials are
trying to broker a solution.

The problem started in October, when a 65-year-old man was placed in the wrong

                             477 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                              Early Times (India)

                            June 19, 2013 Wednesday

US surveillance foiled 50 plots, says spy chief Alexander

LENGTH: 491 words

DATELINE: U.S.


U.S., June 19 -- The head of America's electronic spying agency has told
Congress surveillance programmes leaked by Edward Snowden helped thwart 50
attacks since 2001.

Army General Keith Alexander, director of the National Security Agency (NSA),
told the House intelligence committee the snooping operations were critical.

Plans to attack the New York Stock Exchange were among those foiled, the panel
heard.

Meanwhile, Mr Snowden's father urged his son not to commit "treason".

It was Gen Alexander's second public appearance before Congress since the
internet and telephone surveillance programmes were exposed this month.

Snowden to face 'justice'

In recent years these programmes, together with other intelligence, have
protected the US and our allies from terrorist threats across the globe to
include helping prevent potential terrorist events over 50 times since 9/11," he
said.

Ten of those plots had been intended for the US, the panel heard.

Sean Joyce, deputy FBI director, told the committee one of the cases had
involved a "nascent" plot to bomb the New York Stock Exchange.

Mr Joyce said a tip from the NSA had led the FBI to arrest Khalid Ouazzani of
Kansas City, Missouri, on conspiracy charges.

Ouazzani admitted in a federal court in 2010 plotting to provide material
support to a terrorist organisation, but he was not charged with the alleged
stock exchange plot.

Mr Joyce also said the surveillance had been essential to disrupting the 2009
conspiracy to bomb the New York City subway, resulting in the capture of that
plot's mastermind, Najibullah Zazi.

Asked what was next for Mr Snowden, Mr Joyce said simply: "Justice."

The former NSA contractor fled to Hong Kong shortly before the scandal broke.
His leaks revealed that US agencies had systematically gathered vast amounts of
phone and web data.

On Tuesday, Google challenged the US government's gagging order on its internet
surveillance programme, citing a constitutional right to free speech.

The web firm asked the secretive US Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court to
allow it to publish the number of government requests in the name of national
security for data about its customers.

Tech firms including Microsoft, Facebook, Apple and Yahoo have released limited
information about the number of surveillance requests they receive.

But they are currently not allowed to show the split in numbers between requests
related to national security and to criminal investigations.

Meanwhile, Mr Snowden's father, Lon Snowden, urged his son, in an interview with
Fox News: "I hope, I pray and ask that you will not release any secrets that
could constitute treason."

He also called on his son to come home and "face justice".

Edward Snowden has vowed to fight any extradition attempts by the US.

                  Prince Rupert Daily News (British Columbia)

                           October 18, 2001 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

Opposition wants envoy fired for old terrorist plot

BYLINE: Canadian Press

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 331  words

DATELINE: QUEBEC


QUEBEC (CP) -- There is no reason to fire a Quebec envoy who took part in a
foiled 1965 plot to blow up the Statue of Liberty and other U.S. landmarks,
Premier Bernard Landry said Wednesday.

Landry angrily rejected calls by Opposition Liberals to dismiss Michelle Duclos,
named last June as the province's representative to Algeria, a non-resident
post.

He scoffed at their argument that Duclos should be dismissed because of the
current scare after the terrorist attacks in New York City and Washington.

``To link Mrs. Michelle Duclos . . . directly or indirectly to the events of
Sept. 11 would be cruel and mean,'' Landry said during a heated debate in the
legislature. ``We would never go to such extremes, which represent a form of
terrorism.''

Landry noted Duclos has been a civil servant since 1976, working under both
Parti Quebecois and Liberal governments.

In the 1965 affair, she got a five-year suspended prison sentence for her role
in an aborted plot to blow up Philadelphia's Liberty Bell, the Washington
Monument and New York's Statue of Liberty.

Duclos pleaded guilty to transporting 30 sticks of dynamite from Montreal to New
York for the plot, which involved the Black Liberation Front, a pro-Castro
American group, and sympathizers of the separatist Front de liberation du
Quebec.

Police infiltrated the plot and arrested several conspirators shortly after
Duclos arrived in New York.

Now 63, Duclos has long repudiated her radical past. In 1973 she said her
actions had been ``foolish'' and ``stupid.''

But Opposition Leader Jean Charest said it doesn't matter that Duclos has been a
longtime employee of the government, including a stint as an economic adviser in
the 1980s to the Quebec delegation in Toronto.

It also doesn't matter that Duclos has kept a clean record for 36 years, Charest
said.

``The events of Sept. 11 substantially changed the situation -- radicalized, if
you prefer -- the way in which we must conduct matters of the state,'' he said
in the legislature.
