                             479 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                             Daily News (New York)

                              July 7, 2006 Friday
                              SPORTS FINAL EDITION

BOMB TUNNEL, FLOOD CITY. One man is busted in Beirut, others hunted across globe
and terrorists are seen linked to Zarqawi

BYLINE: BY ALISON GENDAR in New York and JAMES GORDON MEEK in Washington DAILY
NEWS STAFF WRITERS

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 689 words


THE FBI HAS UNCOVERED what officials consider a serious plot by jihadists to
bomb the Holland Tunnel in hopes of causing a torrent of water to deluge lower
Manhattan, the Daily News has learned.

The terrorists sought to drown the Financial District as New Orleans was by
Hurricane Katrina, sources said. They also wanted to attack subways and other
tunnels.

Counterterrorism officials are alarmed by the "lone wolf" terror plot because
they allegedly got a pledge of financial and tactical support from Jordanian
associates of top terrorist Abu Musab al-Zarqawi before he was killed in Iraq, a
counterterrorism source told The News.

It's not clear, however, if any cash or assistance was delivered.

The News has learned that at the request of U.S. officials, authorities in
Beirut arrested one of the alleged conspirators, identified as Amir Andalousli,
in recent months. Agents were scrambling yesterday to try to nab other suspects,
sources said.

They didn't indicate how many people were the target of the international
dragnet but said they were scattered all over the world.

"This is an ongoing operation," one source said.

U.S. agents were allowed to take part in the interrogation of Andalousli, a
source said.

FBI and New York City Police Department officials would not comment yesterday
about the investigation, which has been kept under wraps for months.

The plotters wanted to detonate a massive amount of explosives inside the
Holland Tunnel to blast a hole that would destroy the tunnel, everyone in it,
and send a devastating flood shooting through the streets of lower Manhattan.

It is assumed by officials the thugs would try to use vehicles packed with
explosives.

Sources said that New York City officials believed the plan could conceivably
work with enough explosives placed in the middle of the tunnel, which runs
underneath the river bed, a source said.

But others doubted the plot was feasible.

"You are talking major, major explosives and knowledge of blast effect to make
this happen," said another senior counterterrorism source.

Besides bedrock, the tunnel is protected by concrete and cast-iron steel.

Experts also said that even if the tunnel cracked, the Financial District would
not be flooded because it is above the level of the river.

The FBI discovered the plot by monitoring Internet chat rooms, where the
aspiring terrorists discussed striking the U.S. economy, rather than causing
mass casualties, a source said.

"They're hell-bent on destroying the economy in the U.S.," a counterterrorism
source said.

Al Qaeda founder Osama Bin Laden has often urged his followers to "bleed"
America financially.

The Lebanese government had been expected to release a statement about
Andalousli's arrest but was asked by the U.S. to hold off while operations to
disrupt the plot continued, sources said.

Sources contrasted the chat room jihadists to the seven wanna-be Al Qaeda cell
members arrested in a poor area of Miami by the FBI last week, who appeared to
have no capability of carrying out plots they hatched to bomb FBI offices in
several cities including New York.

"This is more advanced than the Miami Seven," said one of the sources, who spoke
on condition of anonymity.

The disclosure of the Holland Tunnel plot came at the same time Homeland
Security Department officials announced a boost in funds to protect rail and
transit lines in the New York City area yesterday.

Last month, DHS cut New York's high-threat grants by almost half. But yesterday,
DHS Undersecretary George Foresman said the $47 million rail security grants,
which were 25% higher than last year's, were in response to increased risks
after the 2004 Madrid and 2005 London rail bombings.

jmeek@nydailynews.com

Graphic: THE HOLLAND TUNNEL.

Opened to traffic: Nov. 13, 1927

Depth of water: About 40 feet

Distance between tunnel

roof and water: About 41 feet

Distance between the roof and

the roadbed: 12 feet, 6 inches

Tunnel walls: Made of concrete

and cast-iron steel

Width of each

tunnel roadway: 20 feet

Length of tunnel

North tube: 1.75 miles

South tube: 1.5 miles

Original cost of

construction: $48 million

Depth of the water varies in places and depends on the tides.

LOAD-DATE: July 7, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: GRAPHIC;INFOGRAPHIC;MAP, GETTY IMAGES New Jersey-bound traffic speeds
through Holland Tunnel, beneath more than 40 feet of earth and concrete - and
the Hudson. Experts say that terrorists would need huge amount of explosives,
and even more expertise, to have a chance to rupture the tunnel. AP Officers
stand guard on Jersey City side of Holland Tunnel and in Manhattan (right), as
thousands of vehicles pass daily.

DOCUMENT-TYPE: EXCLUSIVE; FRONT PAGE

                             480 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                   USA TODAY

                            February 10, 2006 Friday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Bush details purported plot to hit L.A.;
President: Southeast Asian men were to fly jet into city's tallest building

BYLINE: David Jackson and Richard Benedetto

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8A

LENGTH: 486 words


WASHINGTON -- President Bush gave new details Thursday of how the government
foiled purported plans by al-Qaeda to attack the tallest building on the West
Coast in 2002.

The scheme involved specially recruited Southeast Asian hijackers who planned to
fly an airliner into the 73-story Library Tower in Los Angeles, Bush said in a
speech to the National Guard Association.

"Since Sept. 11, the United States and our coalition partners have disrupted a
number of serious al-Qaeda terrorist plots, including plots to attack targets
inside the United States," Bush said.

Frances Townsend, counterterrorism adviser to the president, declined to say
whether the investigation involved the National Security Agency surveillance
program that has drawn criticism for using wiretaps without court order.

Townsend said Bush discussed the investigation to remind Americans the threat is
still there and highlight the level of international cooperation needed to fight
terrorism.

"The terrorists are weakened and fractured, yet they're still lethal," Bush
said. "We cannot let the fact that America hasn't been attacked in 4 1/2 years
... lull us into the illusion that the threats to our nation have disappeared.
They have not."

Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid, D-Nev., said after the speech that Bush still
has failed to lay out a comprehensive counterterrorism plan. He cited the Sept.
11 Commission's poor ratings of the administration's homeland security plans.

"This White House has committed a series of national security mistakes that have
made America less secure," Reid said.

Bush said Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the alleged mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks
captured in 2003, planned to have operatives use shoe bombs to enter the cockpit
and hijack a commercial airliner that would be flown into the California
building.

Rather than use Arab hijackers as in the 2001 attacks, the plan was to use
Southeast Asian men because they "would not arouse as much suspicion," Bush
said.

Bush mentioned the alleged plot last October when he listed 10 planned terrorist
attacks that had been thwarted. He did not provide details of those plots,
although news organizations later described an attempt on the Library Tower,
perhaps best known as one of the targets in the 1996 alien invasion movie
Independence Day. Also known as the U.S. Bank Tower, the Library Tower is North
America's tallest building west of Chicago.

Townsend would not disclose how many suspects were arrested, which countries
they were from, where they are today or which nations helped foil the plot.

Bush's revelation triggered a blast from Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa,
who said he was surprised by Bush's announcement because the White House had not
fully informed him in advance. White House spokesman Scott McClellan said, "My
understanding was that we did reach out to officials in California and Los
Angeles to let them know, I think it was yesterday."

                              The Pioneer (India)

                              March 6, 2015 Friday

Pakistani man convicted in plot to bomb UK shopping mall

LENGTH: 311 words

DATELINE: Washington


Washington, March 6 -- A US federal jury has convicted Abid Naseer, a
28-year-old Pakistani national, for his role in an international Al Qaeda terror
plot targeting the United States and Europe that came within days of bombing a
shopping mall in the British city of Manchester in April 2009. Following a
two-week trial in a Brooklyn court, Naseer was found guilty of providing
material support to Al Qaeda and conspiring to use a destructive device.

Apart from targeting the Manchester mall, Naseer and his accomplices had also
planned attacks on the New York City subway system and a Danish newspaper office
in Copenhagen, the US Attorney's Office said, adding all these activities had
been "directed by and coordinated with senior al-Qaeda leaders in Pakistan".
Naseer is the eighth defendant to face charges, and the fourth to be convicted,
in Brooklyn federal court related to the Al Qaeda plot, which also involved Adis
Medunjanin, Najibullah Zazi, and Zarein Ahmedzay, all members of the cell that
targeted New York City.

"This Al Qaeda plot was intended by the group's leaders to send a message to the
United States and its allies," said US Attorney Loretta Lynch, adding the
verdict sends a powerful message that the US will stop at nothing to hold those
plotting to kill and maim on behalf of terrorist groups accountable. Around
September 2008, Al Qaeda leaders in Pakistan recruited Medunjanin, Zazi, and
Ahmedzay to conduct a suicide bombing attack in New York City. Those al-Qaeda
leaders, including Adnan El-Shukrijumah and Saleh al-Somali, communicated with
Zazi about the plot through an al-Qaeda facilitator named "Ahmad," who was
located in Peshawar, Pakistan.

at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                         The Age (Melbourne, Australia)

                              June 4, 2007 Monday
                                 First Edition

JFK airport plot foiled - and flawed;
Alleged terrorists had Caribbean links

BYLINE: Mark Coulton, New York with Agencies

SECTION: NEWS; International News; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 604 words


IT'S a plot straight from the disaster movie genre. Destroy New York's major
airport, its terminals, and even parts of the borough of Brooklyn in one
dastardly explosion.

Unfortunately for the alleged plotters, the real life Jack Bauers (of 24 fame)
were ahead of the ticking bomb. Not only was the idea outlandish and highly
unlikely to succeed, but authorities have been recording the conversations of
the plotters for the past 18 months.

US authorities claim to have foiled the plot, which, in the words of one of the
alleged ringleaders, would have caused "greater destruction than in the
September 11 attacks" and devastated the US economy.

Four men are alleged to have plotted to blow up fuel pipelines and tanks and
terminal buildings at New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport.
According to the FBI, the four suspects had conducted surveillance of the
airport using photographs and satellite images downloaded from Google Earth. One
of the men was a retired cargo handler from the airport.

Another was Abdul Kadir, a former mayor of a Guyanese town and a former member
of the Guyanese Parliament. Kadir was arrested in Trinidad after a
Venezuelan-bound plane in which he was a passenger was turned around in mid-air.
His wife has denied he was involved in any terrorist plot.

He is said to have been helping the former cargo handler, Russell Defreitas, 63,
organise the planning and secure financing for the attack. Defreitas, who sells
books on street corners and exports broken air-conditioners to Guyana, was
arraigned in a Brooklyn court and denied bail.

A third man, Kareem Ibrahim, was arrested in Trinidad. A fourth, Abdel Nur, is
at large, thought to be in Trinidad.

There was no connection to al-Qaeda, officials said, but some suspects were
linked to an Islamist extremist group in Trinidad.

Defreitas was allegedly recorded by an FBI informant as saying that JFK airport,
which is New York's major international airport and handles 45 million
passengers a year, was targeted because it would put "the whole country in
mourning".

"It's like, you can kill the man twice," Defreitas allegedly said, who also
boasted he had been taught bomb-making in Guyana.

US attorney Roslynn Mauskopf said it was one of the most chilling plots
imaginable: "The devastation that would be caused had this plot succeeded is
just unthinkable."

But experts cast severe doubt on the practicalities of the plot. JFK airport,
like other airports around the world, is fed by a series of pipelines that
supply jet fuel and heating oil. In many cases the pipes are beneath the tarmac
and are laid directly to the gates where planes park.

But sabotaging part of the system would be highly unlikely to lead to a chain
explosion. Also, jet fuel does not produce an explosive force unless it is under
pressure or vapourised; and pipelines and tanks have safety valves to contain
any mishap.

The alleged plotters are said to have travelled repeatedly to Guyana and
Trinidad in recent months, seeking to obtain the blessing and financial backing
of an extremist Muslim group based in Trinidad and Tobago called Jamaat
al-Muslimeen.

The arrests were an example of alleged plots to attack US targets that
originated in the US, or by Americans, as opposed to plots instituted by
al-Qaeda leaders in the Middle East.

All the plots were apparently closely monitored by intelligence agencies, almost
from their inception, and all were stopped long before they were capable of
implementing them. In many cases, the suspects are alleged to have expressed an
intention to attack targets, but lacked the financing, training and means to do
so. -- With AGENCIES

LOAD-DATE: July 3, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

court.

                               The New York Times

              December 13, 1984, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

RISE IN MARIJUANA ON U.S. LAND CITED

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 627 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12


Despite stepped-up enforcement efforts, marijuana cultivation is increasing on
Federal lands as the farmers use booby traps, camouflage and violence to protect
their illegal crop, a new study reports.

The report, by the General Accounting Office, says that marijuana plots on
public lands are posing threats to land- management personnel and tourists.

The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, said the
report was based on visits last year to 22 forests and parks under the
jurisdiction of the Forest Service, the Bureau of Land Management or the
National Park Service in California, Oregon, Arkansas, Missouri, Idaho and
Hawaii.

''The Forest Service estimates that over 8,200 marijuana plots were cultivated
on its lands in 1983, an increase of about 128 percent over the estimated 3,600
cultivated in 1980,'' the accounting office said.

Destruction Ratio GivenThe report said that while the Forest Service in 1983
discovered 1,973 of the 8,286 plots it estimated were on its land, ''limited
personnel and equipment resulted in the destruction of only about 1,300.''

In 1983, the Bureau of Land Management destroyed 330 marijuana plots while the
Park Service got rid of 27, the report said.

All three agencies, the report said, ''have intensified their efforts to combat
marijuana cultivation on Federal lands.''

However, the report quoted the Bureau of Land Management as saying that the
growing of marijuana presented ''increasingly serious law enforcement problems''
and that ''management control over and public use'' of the lands involved were
being thwarted as the illegal growers ''take over'' more and more public land.

Many Areas Are ClosedThe accounting office, bringing up to date a study issued
in 1982, said: ''Our recent work indicates that marijuana growers continue to
pose a threat to both employees and land users.

''At six of the 22 sites we visited, areas were closed or restricted because of
potential danger from marijuana growers.

''At 14 of the 22 sites, there were one or more incidents of marijuana growers
shooting at, threatening and harassing employees and Federal land users.''

Traps set by growers included a grenade, an antipersonnel mine, dynamite and
fishhooks strung across trails at eye level, the report said. Because of such
dangers, the Forest Service has ''essentially relinquished control'' of 100
square miles of the Shasta-Trinity National Forest in Northern California,
according to the report.

Environmental Damage NotedThe report said marijuana farmers at 13 sites had
caused environmental damage, from costly fires to soil pollution by fertilizers
and insecticides.

The report said that growers, in a business where a plot of 150 plants could be
worth up to $375,000, were attracted to Federal lands because of ''ideal growing
conditions'' and the difficulty of proving ownership of plants found on public
property.

To lessen the risk of detection, growers are cultivating fewer plants in smaller
plots that are more difficult to spot from the air, the report said.

''Growers are also using camouflage netting and paint to make detection more
difficult,'' the report said. ''A California county sheriff's document reports
that a special military camouflage netting produced in Europe was being sold in
truckload quantities.''

Planting Under Power LinesOther growers' measures cited in the report were
pruning plants to keep them close to the ground; developing plants that grow in
shade, and sowing under high-voltage wires in deep canyons where low-flying
aircraft are unlikely to go.

The study was requested by Representative John F. Seiberling, Democrat of Ohio,
chairman of the Interior and Insular Affairs Subcommittee on Public Lands and
National Parks.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1984 The New York Times Company

                           Ledger (Lakeland, Florida)

                           August 24, 2000, Thursday

CITY AIMS TO RAISE PRICES ON PLOTS; AS UPKEEP FALLS BEHIND, OFFICIALS WANT
INCREASES OF $ 210 FOR RESIDENTS AND $ 420 FOR OTHERS.; HAINES CITY CEMETERIES

BYLINE: AMBER SMITH The Ledger

SECTION: East Polk; Pg. F1

LENGTH: 515 words


HAINES CITY -- City commissioners have agreed to raise the rates for plots in
the city cemeteries to help pay for the upkeep.

According to a survey of local towns, Haines City currently has the cheapest
prices for cemetery plots for residents and nonresidents.

"We are already 50 percent lower than everybody else, and we are operating it at
a loss to the city," Commissioner Philip Hinkle said.

Haines City currently charges $ 150 per plot for residents and $ 300 per plot
for nonresidents for the Oakland Cemetery on the north side of town and Forest
Hill Cemetery off Grace Avenue. That price is the lowest in the county.

"I think we are the cheapest in the entire state," said City Clerk Cherry Dowdy,
who handles selling the plots in the city-run cemeteries.

Commissioners want to raise the prices to $ 360 per plot for residents and $ 720
for nonresidents.

According to the survey, Auburndale and Lake Alfred charge residents $ 300 for
cemetery plots and $ 520 and $ 525 respectively for nonresidents.

The highest rates for residents in the towns surveyed are in Lake Wales with $
450 per plot and the highest for nonresidents is St. Cloud with $ 1,200 for
nonresidents.

Haines City would become the second most expensive city in the area for
nonresident rates.

The average rate for residents is $ 425 per plot and $ 600 for nonresidents.

Commissioner Roy Tyler said the rate increase is unfortunate, but necessary.

"Sometimes reality catches up with you," he said.

Commissioners started discussing raising rates when Mayor Joanna Wilkinson
mentioned calls she had been receiving from residents upset about the grass not
being mowed at the city cemeteries.

City Parks and Recreation Director Kelly Callihan said the cemeteries are mowed
every two weeks.

"In the peak growing season, the grass grows faster than we can get it cut," he
said.

Commissioners want to use part of the money from the rate increase to hire a new
employee to concentrate only on upkeep and mowing at the cemeteries.

Currently, 95 plots are sold a year. About 75 percent of those are sold to
residents, with the remaining 25 percent sold to nonresidents.

Assistant to the City Manager Amy Arrington said the money brought in from
increased prices could offset the cost of hiring an employee at $ 6.92 an hour.

Callihan told the commission one person dedicated to the cemetery upkeep would
help, but would not solve all the complaints.

"One person is going to help, but it's not going to be manicured with just one
person," he said explaining it takes three days to mow the 80 acres at Forest
Hill Cemetery.

Callihan said it takes a day to mow both the Oakland Cemetery and the Fifth
Street Cemetery, which is no longer open and was once maintained and owned by a
local church that is no longer standing.

Callihan said there would be plenty of work for the employee during the winter
months, too, with mowing, tree trimming and other maintenance duties.

Commissioners will vote on the rate increase at their Sept. 7 regular commission
meeting at City Hall.

LOAD-DATE: August 24, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              The Washington Post

                             October 9, 2005 Sunday
                                 Final Edition

10 Al Qaeda Plots Thwarted, Bush Says

SECTION: A Section; A03

LENGTH: 304 words


The United States and its allies have thwarted at least 10 serious al Qaeda
terrorist plots since Sept. 11, 2001, including never-before-disclosed plans to
use hijacked commercial airliners to attack the East and West coasts in 2002 and
2003, President Bush and his aides said.

The reported plots aimed to strike a wide variety of targets, including the
Library Tower in Los Angeles, ships in international waters and a tourist site
overseas, the White House said. Three of the 10 were directed at U.S. soil,
officials said. The government, they added, also stopped five additional al
Qaeda efforts to case possible targets or infiltrate operatives into the
country.

Most of the plots were previously reported in some form, while a few were
revealed for the first time Thursday. The White House had never before placed a
number on or compiled a public list of the foiled attempts to follow up the
Sept. 11 attacks, but it offered only scant information beyond the location and
general date of each reported plot.

Bush cited the disrupted plots in a speech intended to shore up sagging public
support for the war in Iraq and to address more extensively than ever before the
philosophical framework undergirding Islamic extremism. The radical movement, he
said, goes beyond "isolated acts of madness," with the goal to "establish a
radical Islamic empire that spans from Spain to Indonesia."

Bush singled out Syria and Iran for condemnation, saying they have "a long
history of collaboration with terrorists, and they deserve no patience from the
victims of terror." He rebuffed calls to withdraw from Iraq and dismissed as a
"dangerous illusion" the idea that pulling out would make the United States
safer. And he rejected the argument that the Iraq war has fostered terrorism.

--  Peter Baker

and Susan B. Glasser

                              The Washington Post

                           January 17, 2002 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

NATION IN BRIEF

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A24

LENGTH: 445 words


NEW YORK -- An Algerian was sentenced to 24 years in prison yesterday -- the
maximum -- for his role in a plot to detonate a suitcase bomb at Los Angeles
International Airport during millennium celebrations.

Mokhtar Haouari, 32, who lives in Canada, was convicted last summer of federal
charges that he supplied fake IDs and cash to two others in the plot.

The plot was foiled when its mastermind, Ahmed Ressam, was arrested in
Washington state in December 1999 while trying to enter from Canada in a car
with a trunkful of explosives.

Ressam had been trained in terrorist camps financed by Osama bin Laden,
according to investigators.

At the time, prosecutors said the attack on the crowded airport in the days
before Jan. 1, 2000, could have been the bloodiest act of terrorism against the
United States since the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing.

Haouari turned down the opportunity to speak at his sentencing and sat
impassively.

* TAMPA -- Charles Bishop, the 15-year-old student pilot who crashed a small
plane into a Tampa skyscraper, did not have alcohol or drugs in his system when
he died Jan. 5, police said. Bishop's blood tested negative for a range of
substances, including antidepressants, marijuana and cocaine, said Wayne Duer,
chief toxicologist with the Hillsborough County Medical Examiner's Office. The
results, released Tuesday, also didn't show traces of Accutane, an acne
medication with alleged links to depression or suicide. A prescription for
Accutane in Bishop's name was found at his home.

* PHILADELPHIA -- Two high-ranking city police officers were charged with trying
to cover up a 1998 car accident that followed a night of drinking. Former police
Capt. James Brady crashed his car on Feb. 13, 1998, then allegedly allowed Capt.
Joseph DiLacqua to orchestrate the coverup by ordering officers to lie about the
crash, according to the charges.

* ARDMORE, Pa. -- A man who shot and killed his stepdaughter, his wife and his
wife's parents before killing himself was clinically depressed but had never
become violent, police said. Michael Burgess, 44, called a detective seven hours
before the shooting Tuesday, calmly saying he planned to contest charges arising
from a disturbance at a church service where he accused his wife, Cassandra, of
cheating on him.

* NEWPORT, Ore. -- A man who had been on the FBI's "Ten Most Wanted" list for
allegedly killing his wife and three children was arraigned on murder charges,
three days after his capture at a Mexico beach resort. Christian Longo, 27,
showed no emotion during his two court hearings, which he joined via
closed-circuit television from the Lincoln County jail.

-- From news services

                         The Age (Melbourne, Australia)

                              June 14, 2002 Friday
                                  Late Edition

Doubts on US bomb warning

BYLINE: Gay Alcorn, United States Correspondent

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 526 words


Washington

Faced with carefully worded accusations that the alleged radioactive dirty-bomb
plot announced this week was exaggerated for political purposes, the White House
is now acknowledging that the threat to the United States was minimal.

According to a leak to the USA Today newspaper, an alarmed White House has
formally reprimanded Attorney-General John Ashcroft who, in announcing the
detention of Abdullah al Muhajir, an American citizen born Jose Padilla, said
authorities had "disrupted an unfolding terrorist plot to attack the United
States by exploding a radioactive dirty bomb".

The following day, Deputy Defence Secretary Paul Wolfowitz softened the charge.
"I don't think there was actually a plot beyond some fairly loose talk and (al
Muhajir's) coming in here obviously to plan further deeds."

The administration has released no evidence that there was ever a dirty-bomb
plot, beyond alleging that al Muhajir suggested a radioactive attack as well as
more conventional strikes to al Qaeda leaders in Pakistan and Afghanistan. He
was then sent to the US to "scout" for possible targets, US officials say.

Law enforcement officials told USA Today that they doubted whether the
31-year-old former Chicago gang member had the equipment or know-how to develop
a dirty bomb, in which conventional explosives are wrapped with radioactive
material.

Mr Ashcroft also appeared to overstate the likely impact of a dirty bomb attack,
saying it could cause "mass death and injury". Experts yesterday assured jittery
Americans that the likely number of deaths would be small.

Administration officials refused to confirm whether Mr Ashcroft had been ticked
off. But they rejected the suggestion by some members of Congress that the
timing of his announcement was designed to bolster President George Bush's
proposal for a new Department of Homeland Security and to neutralise criticism
of the FBI and the CIA.

Al Muhajir was arrested at Chicago's O'Hare Airport on May 8, more than a month
before his detention was revealed. The Democratic majority leader in the Senate,
Tom Daschle, suggested there "may have been a rush to bring it before the news
media" after recent criticism of the CIA and the FBI for failing to anticipate
the September 11 attacks.

According to The Guardian newspaper in London, Mr Ashcroft's announcement
surprised British authorities, some of whom are concerned about America's
alarming warnings of imminent terrorist strikes and at the apparent willingness
of the White House to suspend fundamental judicial principles such as the right
to a fair trial. Senior British officials say that imprecise or exaggerated
warnings of attacks merely serve to encourage panic.

One official described a blanket warning by US Vice-President Dick Cheney last
month about possible attacks on apartment blocks in the US as being so vague as
to be meaningless.

The White House on Sunday declared al Muhajir an "enemy combatant" and shifted
him from New York to a secure military facility in South Carolina. Al Muhajir's
lawyer, Donna Newman, said there was no strong evidence against him and that his
constitutional right to defend himself was being violated.

                             Daily News (New York)

                            March 25, 2010 Thursday
                              SPORTS FINAL EDITION

FAMILY PLOT THICKENS FIGHTS MOM-IN-LAW OVER BURIAL RIGHTS

BYLINE: BY KERRY BURKE and THOMAS ZAMBITO DAILY NEWS STAFF WRITERS

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 19

LENGTH: 329 words


A QUEENS WIDOW who wants to spend eternity next to her husband is facing a
formidable obstacle - her mother-in-law.

Barred from the family plot, Regina Constantin is going to a higher authority -
a judge - for permission to dig up and cremate her dead hubby.

"I want to be buried with my husband," Constantin, 54, a college professor, told
the Daily News yesterday after filing a suit in Queens Supreme Court.

Her spouse, Mihai (Mike) Constantin, died in 2007 at age 55 and was laid to rest
in his family's plot at St. John's Cemetery near the couple's Woodside home.

His widow assumed there was room for her, too, until told otherwise by her
88-year-old mother-in-law, Polina Constantinescu.

"My mother-in-law . . . who is the owner of the plot where my husband currently
is interred, has made it quite clear that she will not allow my remains to be
interred in the same plot where my husband is currently located," the suit says.

"It was always the intention of myself and my husband that our final resting
place would be in the same plot side by side."

The widow wants to remove her departed husband from the plot, but the elderly
woman is standing in the way.

"As the wife of the deceased, I have the right to have my remains lay side by
side with that of my husband when the time comes," her suit says.

"My mother-in-law should not have the veto power to prevent this from
happening."

Inside Mihai's casket is an urn containing the remains of his father, Ion Petre
Constantinescu. Constantin promises to return the ashes to the casket once her
husband is removed.

"I will treat with respect and dignity the remains of my father-in-law," she
wrote in court papers.

Polina Constantinescu, a retired doctor who lives in the same building as her
daughter-in-law, could not be reached for comment on the ashes-to-ashes dustup.

"It's a wild story," Constantin said. "People can make up their own minds about
this, but I'm not really worried. I'm going on with my life."

tzambito@nydailynews.com

                            Dayton Daily News (Ohio)

                           February 9, 2006 Thursday

This Moraine story has a green plot

BYLINE: Bill Schmidt

SECTION: SOUTHWEST; Pg. Z8-1

LENGTH: 1211 words


It's still winter, of course, but the days are growing longer and the normal
temperature of each day has been slowly climbing. It's enough to drive a
gardener mad.

Each year about this time, the folks over at the city of Moraine add yet another
enticement to the mailboxes bulging with seed catalogs.

They're already into their first phase of offering free garden plots to Moraine
residents.

According to Dave Miller, who's administering the program this year, the city
has been in the garden plot business for a long time. In the late 1970s, Moraine
began the program. "It used to be across from the entrance to Wax Park," Miller
said. That was before Main Street was continued up the hill and Splash! Moraine
further developed the area. The plot nowadays has moved to a field across from
the entrance to German Village. That's just off Vance Road, across from Dorf
Drive. The city-owned field - four or five acres - is divided into about 156
plots. Each is about 20- by 40-feet and enough for a nice garden area. This
first phase of the program runs through Feb. 20 and is limited to those
residents who had plots last year. Miller said about 90 percent of those who
registered for plots in previous years return. Registration for the program must
be completed in person at the Payne Recreation Center, 3800 Main St.
Participants must provide a driver's license or other identification to prove
residency. At this first phase, only one plot is guaranteed. Last year, about 70
people signed up for plots. Miller said Moraine began the program back when the
character of the city was different. That's when many residents had more recent
ties to the country.

Many came from Kentucky, Tennessee and West Virginia.

"Recreation activities in the late '70s were (geared) more toward gardening,"
Miller said. He said the fad then - country line dancing - was replaced with
sports such as softball leagues and going for a swim at Splash! Moraine.

But there's still plenty of interest in gardening. "We have enough people with
that interest to still continue the program," Miller said, noting that as many
as 75 percent of the gardeners are elderly.

Phase II of the registration runs from Feb. 22 through March 3. That's when
Moraine residents who don't already have a plot reserved can register.

"If garden plots are still available after Phase I and II are complete, then
residents may apply for additional garden plots," Miller said. They'll be
distributed on a first-come, first-served basis.

A detailed map will be mailed to each participant the week of March 27. The
plots will be available for gardening as of April 1.

Gardeners have to clean up at the end of the season, too by Nov. 1. That
includes removing any stakes or other items that would damage a tractor. Failure
to comply means losing privileges.

For more information, call Miller at 535-1062.

VA nurse wins national award

Debra Watkins of Germantown and a Dayton Veterans Affairs Medical Center nurse,
has won the prestigious Cherokee Inspired Comfort Award. Watkins was one of 14
people honored nationwide.

Watkins is the nurse manager of the Medical Center's intensive care unit.

She was honored for her everyday work "protecting and healing America's
veterans," and for "her lifesaving rescue efforts at a car accident scene."

That accident occurred in 2004 in Moraine. While driving to work, she came upon
a headon collision between two trucks. With the assistance of two men and a
student nurse who stopped at the scene, Watkins evacuated a pastor and his wife
from inside one of the vehicles just as the truck caught fire.

Watkins performed CPR, an act credited with saving the woman's life.

"My life philosophy has been based on the more you problemsolve for others, the
easier your problems in life are solved," Watkins said.

Watkins received a Nurse Hero Award from the National American Red Cross and
Nursing Spectrum. She was also honored by the local American Red Cross, police
department and the Department of Veteran Affairs.

The Cherokee Inspired Comfort Award is granted annually by Cherokee Uniforms, a
leading designer and manufacturer of health care apparel.

The award recognizes "nurses and other nonphysician healthcare professionals who
demonstrate exceptional service, sacrifice and innovation and have a positive
impact on others' lives."

"Debra is a compassionate nurse and an exceptional person," said Wendell Mobley,
who directs the national award for Cherokee. "We are proud to honor someone of
her character."

Watkins won an all-expensepaid trip to a 2006 U.S. medical conference of her
choice, an annual membership to a clinical organization and a wardrobe featuring
the best of Cherokee Uniforms and Rockers Footwear worth more than $1,000.

She also won a trophy and placement in the Cherokee's 2006 Inspired Comfort
Award calendar.

Former foreign exchange student visits

It's been a long while - 30 years, in fact - since Floria Roa Gutierrez attended
Valley View High School while staying with the Green family.

Now Gutierrez and her husband, Luis Diego Jimenez, reside in San Jose. Gutierrez
is an organic chemistry professor at TEC University in Cartago.

But back in 1975, Gutierrez was an exchange student through the International
Exchange Open Door program. She has maintained contact with her host family
through letters and visits.

On Jan. 10, for the 30th anniversary of being an exchange student, she returned
to Germantown.

In 1989, members of her host family Melanie Green Thiele, Kea Green and Craig
and Courtney Thiele visited Costa Rica for Gutierrez's wedding.

In 2003, the Thieles, who live in New Lebanon, and their six children -
Courtney, Anne, Kyle, Eli, Allie and Cole - returned to Costa Rica for a
two-week visit.

Kea Green, a Spanish teacher at VVHS, said of Gutierrez's January visit, "There
was no snow in southwest Ohio. But Floria's children, Fabian and Tatiana, were
delighted to go tubing at Perfect North in southern Indiana."

But even that wasn't the highlight of the trip. It was closer to home.

"Their favorite activity was ice skating in Kettering!"

Eaton Bicentennial events scheduled

This summer's 200th anniversary for Eaton should be a hot time in the old town.
But already organizers are setting off the fireworks.

Friday at the Eaton varsity basketball game, the Firecrackers, a nationally
known jump-roping team will perform a halftime show. The group hails from the
Kings Local School District in Kings Mills.

The game begins at 6:30 p.m. at Eaton High School, 600 Hillcrest Drive.

The 25-member group will perform an eight-minute routine, according to Karen
Murphy, bicentennial activities chairwoman.

The Eaton Boosters Club co-sponsored the show.

"We have monthly events planned to get the community excited about this
milestone and the grand celebration to take place June 30 through July 4th,"
Murphy said.

For more information on Eaton's Bicentennial plans, visit their Web site at
www.eatonbicen tennial.org.

If you or a friend or relative recently achieved honors of some sort, or your
club or organization has an activity you think would make interesting reading,
call Bill Schmidt at 696-2080, e-mail wschmidt@gemair.com or send a typewritten
notice to Neighborhood News Department, Dayton Daily News, 45 S. Ludlow St.,
Dayton, OH 45402. We want to hear from you.

                                 Irish Examiner

                            August 18, 2016 Thursday

QUIRKY WORLD ... Child's play for police as they narrowly catch suspect

SECTION: WORLD

LENGTH: 550 words


That s what German police must have thought when their car got stuck on a narrow
path while pursuing a moped-riding suspect. Rather than give up, one of the
officers jumped on a child s bike and successfully chased down and arrested the
27-year-old suspect.

Police say the suspect, who had evaded a traffic stop in the southern town of
Bamberg, was carrying drugs and driving under the influence.

Police spokeswoman Silke Gahn said the officer, after the arrest, gratefully
returned the 22in bike he had borrowed.

Grant for Peace

Iceland: British-Indian sculptor Anish Kapoor is among the four recipients of
this year s Lennon Ono Grant for Peace.

Yoko Ono, wife of late Beatle John Lennon, announced that Chinese artist and
activist Ai Weiwei, Hungarian poet and performance artist Katalin Ladik, and
Danish-Icelandic installation artist Olafur Eliasson are also winners of the
peace prize.

The awards will be presented in Reykjavik on October 9, which would have been
Lennon s 76th birthday.

Bodies moving

USA: Officials are trying to find a solution after a Rhode Island cemetery
buried two men in the wrong plots, with one family wanting their loved one to
stay put while the other wants their relative put in the grave they picked.

In October, a 65-year-old man was placed in the wrong family plot at Pocasset
Hill Cemetery in Tiverton. In March, an 87-year-old man who was supposed to be
buried in that plot died. He was buried in the other man s plot. His family
wants him to be moved to the plot they own, but the move is opposed by the
65-year-old s family.

The head of the town cemetery commission said moving them would be  ridiculous .
The town solicitor said they are working on an agreement to switch the bodies.

Super Maze Bros

USA: Images of Mario, Luigi, and friends have been carved into the fields of an
upstate New York farm as part of a corn maze based on Nintendo s Super Mario
Bros series.

It is the latest installment of an annual themed maze at the Stoughton Farm in
Newark Valley. Owner Tom Stoughton said the farm s mazes typically attract about
10,000 visitors annually.

An aerial photo of the eight-acre maze shows Mario, Luigi, Princess Peach, Toad,
and Yoshi carved into the cornfield.

Time to toga toga again

USA: A candidate for New Hampshire governor has vowed to work to restore the
status of a Dartmouth College fraternity that loosely inspired the 1978 comedy
film Animal House.

The Alpha Delta fraternity was kicked out of the Ivy League school s Hanover
campus in April 2015 after officials learned that members branded pledges on
their bottoms, said the Boston Globe.

Democrat Mark Connolly was a member of Alpha Delta when he graduated from
Dartmouth in 1979. He said he wants his former fraternity reinstated once
members prove they are upstanding members of the community. Dartmouth officials
said derecognition is permanent.

Game for a laugh

Germany: Baywatch star David Hasselhoff and Borussia Dortmund footballer Marco
Reus both appeared in virtual form as the Gamescom video games show began in
Germany.

The Knight Rider actor appeared as a DJ in a 1980s disco and theme park-based
Call of Duty: Zombies In Spaceland experience, which was unveiled by the game s
publisher Activision.

German international Reus is the cover star of Fifa 17, which he played at a
pre-show event.

                  The State Journal-Register (Springfield, IL)

                           October 14, 2006 Saturday

Soybean rust present in Illinois

BYLINE: CHARLYN FARGO AGRIBUSINESS EDITOR

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 684 words


Soybean rust was confirmed Friday for the first time in Illinois in a soybean
field at the University of Illinois' Dixon Springs Center in the far
southeastern part of the state.

Adjacent counties are being scouted to determine if the fungal disease has
spread to other fields, the Illinois Department of Agriculture said.

State Agriculture Director Chuck Hartke made the announcement - one Illinois
farmers have anticipated but feared nonetheless - at an Asian soybean rust
research planning meeting.

A U.S. Department of Agriculture lab in Beltsville, Md., confirmed the presence
of rust on leaf samples collected from a U of I test plot adjacent to a
so-called "sentinel" plot in Pope County, just across the Kentucky border.
Sentinel plots are research plots checked daily for the presence of soybean
rust.

"They don't do a windshield survey; they're crawling on their hands and knees
and using hand-held microscopes to find this," said Hartke. "It's so small you
have to use a microscope to see it."

Hartke said he doesn't expect the disease to have any economic impact on
Illinois farmers this year, because the majority of soybeans are mature or have
been harvested. However, it could have a major impact next year if the disease
spreads, he said.

"This discovery, this late in the growing season, will have no impact on the
2006 soybean crop," Hartke said. "If the fungus had arrived here earlier, when
beans were developing and setting pods, it potentially could have caused
significant production losses. Fortunately, the crop has matured, harvest is
nearing completion, and no damage will occur."

A potentially record soybean yield is forecast for Illinois this year.

If infection occurs during the vegetative and early reproductive growth stages
for soybeans, rust  can cause significant defoliation of the plant and
subsequent loss in yield or even death of the plant.

Winter will kill off the fungus, so it will only reappear in Illinois if the
wind-borne spores again are blown in from southern states.

"Our best defense against soybean rust is a hard frost. The disease simply
cannot survive this far north without a green, living host," Jim Larkin, the
state agriculture department's soybean rust program manager, said in a
statement.

In Kentucky, rust was detected a week ago in seven counties, apparently having
blown into the region from the South about two weeks ago.

Asian soybean rust has been confirmed in 113 counties in 10 states this year,
with the Illinois and Kentucky cases being the northern-most detections. Last
year, there were 70 confirmed locations in the United States.

Asian soybean rust (Phakopsora pachyrhizi) causes small, pustular lesions on the
foliage and pods of more than 95 plant species, including soybeans. It also
infects kudzu, an exotic nuisance weed present in southern Illinois. While the
health of the kudzu plant is not severely impacted by the disease, it serves as
a reservoir for the soybean rust pathogen. Some 85 to 90 other plants also can
serve as host plants for the disease.

First recorded in Japan in 1903 and identified for the first time in the Western
Hemisphere in Hawaii in 1994, Asian soybean rust was confirmed in the
continental United States in 2004, the same year Illinois adopted a
comprehensive plan to identify and control the disease.

The plan, a coordinated effort between the Illinois Soybean Association, U of I,
Southern Illinois University, National Soybean Research Center, USDA Animal and
Plant Health Inspection Service and Illinois Department of Agriculture,
emphasizes early detection and timely fungicide applications that can cost
upwards of $20 per acre.

"This is just one of the things that happens," Hartke said. "We knew it was a
possibility. It's been coming farther north every year. I'm sure we will find an
answer to fight this disease. We solved corn leaf blight a couple of years ago.
We'll find a solution for this."

The discovery in Illinois could prompt even more farmers to raise corn instead
of soybeans next spring. That was expected anyway because of increased demand
for corn to produce ethanol.

LOAD-DATE: October 17, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: LOCAL

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                               The New York Times

               July 27, 1988, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

FUNERAL HOME IN BROOKLYN INDICTED IN SALE OF BURIAL PLOTS

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

SECTION: Section B; Page 2, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 278 words


A Brooklyn funeral home, two directors and four employees were charged yesterday
with illegally trading 170 burial plots in Brooklyn and Queens.

The funeral home, I. J. Morris Inc. in the Flatlands area, made an estimated
$70,000 profit in buying and selling the plots, which were bought from burial
societies and sold through advertisements in a Russian-language newspaper, the
prosecutors said. Trading in burial plots is illegal under state law, except for
not-for-profit cemeteries and sales by burial societies to their members.

The 35-count indictment charged one director of the well-known company, Joel
Morris, 47 years old, of New Rochelle, N.Y., with eight counts of buying and
selling grave sites, misdemeanors punishable by six months in prison and a $500
fine.

A second director, Joseph Morris, 66, of Roslyn, L.I., Joel Morris's uncle, was
charged with one count of buying grave sites. The others were charged with the
sale of grave sites.

Not Guilty Pleas

The defendants were arrested yesterday, pleaded not guilty at arraignments in
State Supreme Court in Brooklyn and were released on their own recognizance. An
employee at the home said last night that the defendants would have no immediate
comment on the charges.

The plots were bought and then sold to the funeral home's customers between
August 1986 and last August, the authorities said. The plots were in Washington
Cemetery in Brooklyn and Montefiore and Mount Hebron Cemeteries in Queens.

The four other defendants were Yakov Gavrilov, 39, of Brooklyn; George
Gallarello, 31, of Howell, N.J.; Eric Zweig, 35, of Smithtown, L.I., and Henry
Bulakowski, 35, of Bayside, Queens.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                            The Daily Star (Lebanon)

                             July 8, 2010 Thursday

US charges link British cell to NYC subway plot

BYLINE: Daily Star Staff

LENGTH: 357 words


WASHINGTON: A failed plot to set off bombs in the New York subway system last
year was part of larger Al-Qaeda conspiracy that planned a similar attack in
England, US prosecutors said Wednesday. In a terrorism indictment unsealed
Wednesday, prosecutors added several Al-Qaeda figures to the case, including
Adnan Shukrijumah, whose

Tom Hays and Matt Apuzzo

Associated Press

WASHINGTON: A failed plot to set off bombs in the New York subway system last
year was part of larger Al-Qaeda conspiracy that planned a similar attack in
England, US prosecutors said Wednesday.

In a terrorism indictment unsealed Wednesday, prosecutors added several Al-Qaeda
figures to the case, including Adnan Shukrijumah, whose name is on the FBI's
list of most-wanted terrorists.

Shukrijumah, an Al-Qaeda leader in charge of plotting attacks worldwide, was
directly involved in recruiting and plotting the New York attack, prosecutors
said. Attorney General Eric Holder has called that plot one of the most
dangerous since September 11, 2001.

Two of the men indicted Wednesday, Abid Naseer and Tariq Ur Rehman, were linked
to a previously undisclosed companion plot in England.

"These charges underscore the global nature of the terrorist threat we face,"
David Kris, the Justice Department's top national security prosecutor said.

Three US citizens were arrested in September 2009 before, prosecutors said, they
could carry out a trio of suicide bombings in Manhattan. Najibullah Zazi and
Zarein Ahmedzay have pleaded guilty and admitted planning to detonate homemade
bombs on the subway during rush hour.

A third man, Adis Medunjanin, awaits trial. Prosecutors added new terrorism
charges against him Wednesday.

After 9/11, Shukrijumah, 34, was seen as one of Al-Qaeda's best chances to
attack inside the US or Europe, captured terrorist Abu Zubaydah told US
authorities. Shukrijumah studied at a community college in Florida, but when the
FBI showed up to arrest him as a material witness to a terrorism case in 2003,
he already had left the country.

In 2004, then-Attorney General John Ashcroft called Shukrijumah a "clear and
present danger" to the United States.

                             El Paso Times (Texas)

                           December 13, 2012 Thursday

Alleged Justin Bieber murder plot originated in Las Cruces (updated)

BYLINE: By James Staley / Las Cruces Sun-News

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 451 words


Photos: Justin Bieber target of murder plot

LAS CRUCES -- Tired of being a "nobody" and fed up with all the unrequited fan
mail he had sent to singer Justin Bieber, a convicted murderer persuaded another
convict to try to execute a plot to kill the pop artist and three other people
while the pair were incarcerated together at the Southern New Mexico
Correctional Facility, according to court documents.

Dana Martin, who was convicted of the rape and murder of a 15-year-old girl in
Vermont in 2000, had been transferred this year to the Southern New Mexico
Correctional Facility from a prison in Florida, investigators said.

It was in the prison west of Las Cruces, he told investigators, that Martin
plotted to kidnap and kill Bieber. Martin said he was infatuated with Bieber --
he even had a tattoo of the young singer on his leg.

That large tattoo came up in conversation at the Southern New Mexico
Correctional Facility, where Martin eventually persuaded Mark Staake to try to
carry out that and three other slayings, according to court documents. One was
for Bieber's bodyguard, and the two others were unrelated but particularly
gruesome because they involved the castration of the victims with garden shears,
the type used for "trimming roses," investigators discovered.

The court documents don't make clear whether there were any explicit
instructions of how to kill Bieber. Martin told investigators he was seeking
"notoriety" for planning Bieber's death.

Staake, 41, of Albuquerque, has been charged with two counts each of conspiracy
to commit first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit aggravated battery with a
deadly weapon in connection to the plan, according to a criminal complaint filed
in 3rd Judicial District Court.

According to the criminal complaint, Staake wanted his nephew Tanner Ruane, 23,
also of Albuquerque, to participate in the killings because Ruane is Staake's
"right-hand man."

The complaint says Staake and Ruane left for Vermont for the first two killings
in mid-November -- planning them so they could be in New England near a Bieber
concert scheduled in New York City. But the bumbling duo never arrived because
they missed an exit, resulting in their driving their early 1980s model,
blue-gray BMW sedan into Canada. Staake was arrested by U.S. Border Patrol
agents for a probation violation, the complaint says.

New York State Police eventually arrested Ruane. Both men are awaiting
extradition to New Mexico, according to a news release from State Police.

Martin told prison officials about the plan. He's serving two life sentences for
the 2000 rape and murder.

James Staley may be reached at jstaley@lcsun-news.com; 575-541-5476. Follow him
on Twitter @auguststaley

second night of KIIS FM's Jingle Ball at Nokia Theatre LA Live on Monday, Dec.
3, 2012, in Los Angeles. (Photo by Chris Pizzello/Invision/AP)

                        Contra Costa Times (California)

                            October 10, 2008 Friday

Pleasanton cemetery may add plots

BYLINE: By Robert Jordan STAFF WRITER

SECTION: MY TOWN; Alameda; Growth; News; Local

LENGTH: 372 words


PLEASANTON   The odds are getting better for residents who want to make
Pleasanton their final resting place.

The Pleasanton Memorial Gardens Cemetery, which is at capacity, could handle as
many as 800 more people under a proposed plan to add double plots and cremains
niches on the property's south side.

The Parks and Recreation Commission unanimously approved a plan on Thursday that
would add 200 full-sized, double-depth plots and 200 smaller double plots for
the burial of cremains.

The revenue from the new plots is expected to bring in $1.95 million. Of that
money, $1.18 million would be used to install the new vaults and cremains plots
and to upgrade the entire irrigation system.

"This is a good way to get the landscape system in," said commission chair Kurt
Kummer. "And I think this is what the Pleasanton community wants to see."

The demand for cemetery space is there   represented Thursday by residents, who
all expressed their approval of the plan and asked if a list is created that
they be included.

The plan, approved by the commission and forwarded to the City Council, calls
for five basic conditions.

The biggest point is to give Pleasanton residents the first chance to get one of
the added spots, by giving residents a 12-month period to purchase a plot or
cremains niche before they are offered to nonresidents.

The plan also calls for a pricing scale that ranges from $2,800 for a double
cremains spot to $6,950 for a double burial plot. The commission also supported
the number of spots and their location.

They also approved the city staff's recommendation that Catholic Funeral
Cemetery Services continue to manage the facility, but rejected a recommendation
to give preferences to police officers, firefighters and teachers who worked in
the city but didn't live there.

"I would like (the plots) limited to Pleasanton residents," said Julie Phillips,
a 39-year resident. "We shouldn't categorize how people made their living on
deciding a space but where their roots are."

The additional plots are expected to increase the city's annual cost of cemetery
operation from $75,400 to $85,000.

The city acquired and began managing the cemetery in 2007.

Reach Robert Jordan at rjordan@bayareanewsgroup.com or 925-847-2184.

LOAD-DATE: October 12, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Friday, Oct. 10, 2008, could be expanded if the city council approves a plan by
the city's parks and recreation commission. (Cindi Christie/Contra Costa Times)

                          The Tampa Tribune (Florida)

                              July 23, 2012 Monday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Military is on call for RNC

BYLINE: TED JACKOVICS, The Tampa Tribune

SECTION: NATION/WORLD; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1212 words


Forces have contingency plans in case violence erupts during major public events

BY TED JACKOVICS

The Tampa Tribune

TAMPA Former U.S. Army Command Sgt. Maj. Gary Huber was assigned to a Nike
missile site defending Chicago against Soviet bombers when he first heard about
Operation Garden Plot.

An intelligence agency believed the group Students for a Democratic Society
intended to disrupt the 1968 Democratic National Convention by seizing an Army
installation along Chicago's lakefront.

Nike Hercules missiles were equipped with nuclear warheads, and the federal
government wasn't taking any chances.

Government officials brought in an infantry brigade from Colorado and provided
Chicago-area Nike personnel with riot control equipment and marksmanship
training, said Huber, an electronics specialist whose primary Garden Plot
assignment was as a sniper.

"My job was to shoot to kill as directed," Huber said in a Skype interview from
his Illinois home. "I'm surprised we were issued ammunition because that
normally wasn't the case except when I was assigned along the East German
border."

The 1968 Democratic National Convention was indeed riotous, but nobody took over
the Army installation. More than four decades later, the idea that the military
would be called in to help police a political convention seems drastic.

That doesn't mean plans aren't still in place, though.

During the past 44 years, Operation Garden Plot has evolved and been superseded
by U.S. Northern Command plans created specifically for major public events --
including the 2012 political conventions in Tampa and Charlotte.

"During the Democratic/Republican National Conventions, Department of Defense
personnel will support the U.S. Secret Service," a U.S. Northern Command
spokesman said in an email.

"For operational security reasons we do not discuss the numbers of military
personnel and resources that are involved," U.S. Navy Lt. Cmdr. William G. Lewis
said. "Additionally, we do not share our operational plans."

The Secretary of Defense would have to approve any request for military
assistance, Lewis said.

U.S. Northern Command took over responsibility for homeland security when
President George W. Bush and the Department of Defense created the agency after
the 9/11 attacks. The agency refers to Operation Garden Plot as "an old Army
plan that no longer is in existence," Lewis said.

Military publications have reported security officials have used aspects of
Garden Plot plans and its Northern Command evolution at political conventions
from 1968 through at least 2004.

"I would say that 9/11 increased the threat perception," said John Pike,
director of GlobalSecurity.org, who has been called to testify to Congress on
military affairs. "People have been worried about al-Qaida jumping out of
manhole covers."

Pike said he understands that the military must prepare for an attack at a
political convention, though he sees that scenario as unlikely.

"I think the whole thing is pretty harmless," said Pike, who said Garden Plot
originated from conflicts over civil rights and the Vietnam War. "But look at
what's being planned for the Olympics, with an aircraft carrier in east London.

"If anything goes wrong, you are asked, 'Why didn't you plan for this.' If
nothing happens, people will say 'you overreacted.'"

The details about Garden Plot's successors are labeled "For Official Use Only."
But the original operation indicates how the government in recent years could
have planned for events in which the military would be called upon to support
civilian security forces.

A 1968 copy of the Army's Garden Plot, originally classified as confidential,
categorized Tampa/St. Petersburg as an "intermediate priority" for U.S. Army
planning.

A section on "specifics during disturbances" cited "fire, looting, arson and
numbers and types of people involved (i.e. juveniles, Negroes, Puerto Ricans)."

Indicators of potential violence included "high unemployment and increased crime
rates among minority groups" and "protests by minority groups to such conditions
as slum conditions, segregation in housing and schools, lack of jobs, lack of
recreational facilities, police brutality and local overpricing practices."

Equipment and weapons issued to soldiers involved in Operation Garden Plot
included rifles, pistols, shotguns, M60 machine guns and grenade launchers.

Subsequent documents show Garden Plot was revised over the years and changed how
intelligence was to be gathered.

U.S. Northern Command's creation resulted in Garden Plot successors, called
concept of operations plans, for "Defense Support of Civil Authorities" and
"Civil Disturbance Operations."

Among case studies in a National Guard handbook is a synopsis of planning for
the 2004 Republican National Convention in New York. It said U.S. Northern
Command provided sophisticated communications equipment to provide a common
operational picture of the convention.

"What would happen ... if there were an incident at the Convention?" the case
study said. "(The joint task force commander) could only guess because the
contingencies were simply too many and varied."

Huber, who was based at the Munster, Ind., Nike site south of Chicago in 1968,
became involved in a typical military change of plans during the Democratic
Convention.

At first, he said, he was called upon to evaluate the chemical, biological and
radiological preparedness for an assault by Students for a Democratic Society on
a Nike missile site along Lake Shore Drive, one of nine such sites encircling
Chicago and Gary, Ind.

"We had been told the protestors planned to occupy the site at Jackson Park,"
Huber said.

Launching a Nike missile required a complicated process to ensure security. But
because the launcher area contained nuclear warheads, those areas were provided
additional fencing and dog patrols at Nike sites nationwide.

"I do not know if the Army thought the SDS could launch a Nike Hercules, but
some intelligence agency made the case there was intent by the SDS and a
possibility of success," Huber said.

Huber also coordinated operations between Nike personnel and soldiers from the
5th Infantry Division from Fort Carson, Colo., and prepared to become a sniper.

"The 5th Infantry soldiers were to be used as a show of force. Others from the
Nike sites had security assignments triggered by signals, alarms or voice
announcements to report to a building, a roof, a radar mast or another security
point depending upon the alerting signal."

The Army took the Jackson Park site off operational alert, its missiles and
warheads kept in their underground magazines, and put Huber's Nike site, 20
miles to the southeast, on "hot" status, ready to launch within 15 minutes.

The Jackson Park site remained secure, beyond the Chicago protestors'
confrontations with authorities. Huber rode out the convention at the Munster,
Ind., Nike site, though not without a little excitement.

"A young person chose to penetrate the site through a hole in the bottom of a
fence the Army had temporarily filled with some concrete blocks," Huber
recalled. "He immediately met one of our German shepherd security dogs and got
hauled away."

tjackovics@tampatrib.com

(813) 259-7817

                              LNP (Lancaster, PA)

                             July 9, 2015 Thursday

A Successful Plot;
More Online Garden Plots By The Numbers

BYLINE: Jennifer Kopf

SECTION: B; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 432  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


JKOPF@LNPNEWS.COM

The buzz of an insect whizzing past Farm View Drive is echoed, at a lower pitch,
by the long-distance drone of a massive lawn mower criss-crossing the expanse
between garden plots and tennis courts near Golf Road.

And, though empty horse trailers are parked just around the bend, those dueling
hums are the only sounds heard one recent lunch hour at Lancaster County's
Central Park garden plots. They're broken only occasionally by the call of a
gardener, his head and neck covered against the sun high overhead, shouting a
question to the woman gardening alongside him.

That couple is too busy to chat with a random passerby, but a few rows north,
Joe Devlin eagerly waves in a visitor, past his thick rows of zinnias and
through the latched gate.

There he's been tending row upon row of tomato varieties, including Jet Stars,
he says, "because you have to have Washington Boro(-variety) tomatoes." His peas
and beans already are pulled out, their season over, but Devlin has moved on to
harvesting cucumbers for pickles and is getting ready for salsa. His onions, set
against a perimeter fence, are almost ready for harvesting and he tugs a beet
from the ground that already looks good enough for the table.

Devlin, of Bird-in-Hand, doesn't mind the drive he takes several times a week to
take care of - and weed - the garden plot he's now rented for six seasons.

"I'm retired," explains the former Willow Street postmaster, "and I like it."
Once the newbie in his section of garden plots, Devlin now has been at it long
enough that he can pass along the advice and experience he's gained.

About half a mile away, at the Lancaster County Department of Parks & Recreation
offices, executive secretary Deborah Werner says this "has been a really good
year for garden plots."

The plots rent quickly each year, Werner says, adding that the sections
designated as organic are sold out for 2015.

For video of the Central Park garden plots at midday, visit the story at
LancasterOnline.com

2

n Different sizes of garden plots in the county park; 20 feet by 20 feet, or 20
by 40. The first is $22 a season; the larger is $27.50.

300-plus

n Total number of individual garden plots.

1

n Number of times the regular garden plots are plowed in preparation for the new
planting season.

0

n Number of times the organic garden plots are plowed before each growing season
begins - this allows gardeners in those plots to carry over crops like
strawberries and asparagus that need more than one growing season.

Sources: lancastercounty

parks.org; Deborah Werner, Lancaster County Department of Parks & Recreation

Robust Row Of Zinnias In Bloom; Hardily Growing Cabbages.
Fstaff Photos At High Noon On A Sunny Weekday There Are Few Workers At Lancaster

Guard. Other Sights Include, Right From Top, Sunflowers Stretching Toward The
Clouds Rolling In; Old Wood Serving A New Purpose As A Fence; A Storm Door
Turned Garden Gate; And A Heavily Planted And Carefully Tended Corner Plot.

                                US Official News

                            August 22, 2013 Thursday

Utah: California's iconic redwoods in danger from fire and infectious disease

LENGTH: 903  words

DATELINE: Salt Lake City


National Science Foundation, The State of Utah has issued the following news
release:

First it was sudden oak death, the oak disease caused by the plant pathogen
Phytophthora ramorum, that threatened California's extensive coastal forests.

Now these forests' stately trees are facing a new menace: the combined effects
of sudden oak death and fire. And this time, the iconic redwoods are at risk.

Usually resistant to the effects of wildfires, California's coast redwoods are
now burning as fast as other trees. Why?

Into the redwood forest

To find answers, plant pathologist David Rizzo of the University of California
at Davis (UC Davis) and colleagues monitored more than 80,000 hectares of
forests near Big Sur, Calif. In their plots, tanoaks, California bay laurels and
coast redwoods grow.

The study began in 2006. "In 2008, almost half our plots were burned by
wildfires that lasted the better part of a month," says Rizzo.

That was the beginning of the end for many coast redwoods, surprising
researchers who expected the trees to be fire-proof.

The key to the redwood deaths, discovered Rizzo, Margaret Metz and Kerri
Frangioso of UC Davis, along with Morgan Varner of Mississippi State University
and Ross Meentemeyer of North Carolina State University, lies in the sudden oak
death pathogen.

"If redwoods didn't live in forests affected by the disease," says Metz, "they
could withstand fires just fine."

The biologists recently reported their results online in the journal Ecology,
published by the Ecological Society of America.

After the fires were under control, the scientists returned to their study plots
. Half had long been infested with the sudden oak death pathogen; half had been
spared. The redwoods' mortality risk, it turned out, was four times higher in
the sudden oak death plots as in healthy plots.

"The disease likely created more fuel for wildfires as dead tanoak branches
fell," says Rizzo. "The loss of the oaks also would have decreased the amount of
shade, drying out the forest and turning it into a tinder box, one not even
redwoods could survive."

Pathogens + fires = dead redwoods

The forest ecosystem disturbance that happens when a pathogen like sudden oak
death becomes established and starts killing trees, says Rizzo, "clearly isn't
the only one that may be important to that forest."

Sudden oak death has killed millions of trees in the coastal forests of
California and Oregon. It was first linked with the mortality of tanoaks and
coast live oaks in the San Francisco Bay area in the mid-1990s. In 2000,
Phytophthora ramorum was confirmed as the causal agent.

Analyses of the pathogen's genetic structure indicate that a single introduction
sparked the wave of disease. It likely originated at a nursery in Santa Cruz,
Calif.

Since then, scientists have found that the pathogen has infected plants in 45
genera, including ferns. "These host species are important parts of the forests
along the California coast and at the wildland-urban interface," says Rizzo.

The pathogen's current range extends more than 435 miles from the Big Sur area
in central California north to Mendocino County, with smaller affected areas in
Humboldt County, Calif., and Curry County, Ore. Forests along Big Sur are among
the most affected, with 100 percent of tanoaks infected in some stands.

Many of those forests are also prone to wildfires. "There's a growing concern
that dead trees from the disease may make wildfires worse," Metz says.

The 2008 wildfires were the first in forests affected by sudden oak death. The
largest fire, called the Basin Complex, was ignited by a lightning storm in
June. It burned more than 95,000 hectares in the Big Sur region.

In September, the Chalk Fire started south of the Basin Complex perimeter; it
burned an additional 16,000 acres. "More than 40 percent of our 280 plots went
up in flames, 98 in the Basin Fire, and 23 in the Chalk Fire," says Rizzo.

A month after containment of the Basin Complex fire, the researchers surveyed 61
plots to measure burn severity before the forest could change with the onset of
California's winter rains. "These measurements serve as our baseline data on
ecosystem responses to interactions between fire and infectious disease," says
Rizzo.

Key hidden high in the forest canopy

When sudden oak death kills tanoaks, it alters the trees in ways that leave
neighboring redwoods vulnerable, the researchers found.

Flames are carried high into the tree canopy by the dead tanoaks; they then
scorch the crowns of surrounding redwoods. Injury to the redwoods' crowns is
what likely caused the trees to die in the 2008 fires, the scientists believe.

"Humans are causing widespread changes throughout our world, including greater
wildfires related to changing climate and from increasing infectious diseases
due to more modes of transportation," says Sam Scheiner, program director at the
National Science Foundation (NSF) for the joint NSF-NIH Ecology and Evolution of
Infectious Diseases Program, which funded the research.

"This study shows that these changes can combine in unexpected ways that can be
very destructive. More such research is needed if we are to prepare for what's
to come."

Rizzo agrees. "We're moving species around the globe at high rates, and global
warming has increased fire severity. There may be all sorts of consequences,
among them, dead and dying coast redwoods."

For further information please visit: http://www.nsf.gov/

LOAD-DATE: August 22, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                          The Courier Mail (Australia)

                             March 3, 2012 Saturday
                        1 - First with the news Edition

PILOT TERROR - Lecter leads TV's new list of killers, chillers and thrillers

BYLINE: GEOFF SHEARER

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 28

LENGTH: 679  words


SUPERNATURAL thrillers and serial killers feature prominently in the more than
90 TV drama series pilots in commission by the big US networks.

A haunted New York apartment block, a murderer who gathers an army of serial
killers, the return of Hannibal

Lecter and a modern-day Sherlock Holmes strutting around Manhattan, will all be
competing to make it to air this year.

The pilot season in the US - where networks commission TV producers to go off
and create ``sample'' one-off episodes of their story pitches - annually
attracts a flood of young Australian actors to Los Angeles hoping to be cast.

Already Rebel Wilson has scored her own pilot, backed by talkshow host Conan
O'Brien as executive producer, and Aussie actors Daisy Betts, Dichen Lachman and
Dan Lissing have signed on for the US nuclear submarine thriller Last Resort.

Longtime America-based Anthony LaPaglia will head Americana, while Portia de
Rossi tries for another TV hit with The Smart One, and Rachael Taylor will climb
out from under the wreck of last year's axed Charlie's Angels for the chiller
666 Park Avenue - which sounds the most promising of the supernatural-infused
pilots.

It will share scare space with Gotham, in which a New York policewoman discovers
an unseen world within the metropolis; Hannibal (already picked up for a
13-episode season), which puts the serial-killer cannibal back on the streets;
as well as the futuristic Beautiful People, where mechanical servants begin to
rebel.

This year, the US has again gone dipping into the successful UK TV gene pool
looking for a trans-Atlantic translation that works.

Long-running British sitcom Only Fools and Horses - which starred David Jason -
gets a US makeover.

John Leguizamo and Dustin Ybarra will play the two brothers who, along with
their grandfather, concoct a series of ridiculous get-rich-quick schemes.

And the UK modern-day Sherlock series - with Benedict Cumberbatch and Martin
Freeman - will be

re-imagined (again) as Elementary with Jonny Lee Miller as Holmes and Lucy Liu
as Watson.

Of course, there are a few pitches that sound mightily familiar as they try to
coat-tail recent hits on TV or film.

Shelter is based on rivalries and romances between staff and guests at a
historic New England summer resort. Been there, done that with Hotel.

Also trawling old ground are Notorious, in which a female detective goes
undercover as a maid's daughter to solve a murder in the wealthy family home in
which she was raised; The Carrie Diaries, which features a younger Carrie
Bradshaw from Sex and the City stepping into the limelight as she comes of age
in the 1980s; and Save Me, starring Anne Heche as a woman who starts to believe
that she is channelling God after she has an accident, which sounds like
Enlightened or perhaps Heche Almighty.

Untitled Kevin Williamson project

Stars: Kevin Bacon, James Purefoy

Plot: Thriller that pits a serial killer who has assembled a huge cult against
an FBI profiler.

666 Park Avenue

Stars: Terry O'Quinn, Rachael Taylor

Plot: A young couple are hired as resident managers of a New York building
plagued by supernatural happenings.

All Talk

Stars: Ben Stiller

Plot: The life-altering dramas of a Jewish family in Washington.

Americana

Stars: Anthony LaPaglia

Plot: A legendary fashion designer and his personal, family and business
struggles.

Counter Culture

Stars: Doris Roberts

Plot: Three elderly sisters try to keep their family diner in West Texas up and
running.

Downwardly Mobile

Stars: Roseanne Barr, John Goodman

Plot: She runs a mobile home park and he's a handyman.

Sounds like Roseanne all over again, but in a smaller house.

Joey Dakota

Stars: No names attached

Plot: A time-travel musical in which a filmmaker goes back to the 1990s where
she meets and falls in love with a rock star.

Super Fun Night

Cast: Rebel Wilson

Plot: Three geeky girls and their freaky Friday nights out.

The Viagra Diaries

Stars: Goldie Hawn

Plot: A woman's struggles with being single for the first time in 35 years.

The New Normal

Stars: Andrew Rannells, Justin Bartha, Ellen Barkin

Plot: Gay couple employ a surrogate to start a family.

                       The Day (New London, Connecticut)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             August 19, 2011 Friday

BRIEF: UPDATED: Two arraigned in connection with murder-for-hire plot

BYLINE: Izaskun E. LarraNeta, The Day, New London, Conn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 223 words


Aug. 19--NEW LONDON -- Two of the three men arrested by city police in
connection with a murder-for-hire plot were arraigned this afternoon in the G.A.
10 court.

Gerardo Carrillo, 26, of Westbrook, and Elmer Melendez, 28, of 208 Crystal Ave.,
were each charged with possession of a weapon in a motor vehicle, criminal
attempt to commit murder, and conspiracy to commit murder.

The judge set bail for each man at $2 million and transferred their cases to
Part A, the upper level of Superior Court. Melendez is due to appear Aug. 29 and
Carrillo is scheduled to appear Aug. 30.

Police said the plot was discovered early Thursday morning. Probable cause
reports in the case are remaining sealed to protect the identity of a
confidential informant and to protect the accused men while they are
incarcerated.

A third person, Antonio Pena, 35, of 187 Huntington St., Apt. D14, was arrested
Friday in New Haven in connection with the case. He was charged with conspiracy
to commit murder. He is expected to be arraigned Monday.

http://www.theday.com. Copyright (c) 2011, The Day, New London, Conn.

about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services
